title: Review: Maries Story, a Tale Similar to Helen Kellers
description: A deaf and blind girl is saved by a consumptive nun in Maries Story, a saccharine sister to Arthur Penns The Miracle Worker (1962) from the French director Jean-Pierre Amris.

title: Review: In Maya the Bee Movie, a Young Dreamer Escapes the Hive Mentality
description: Maya the Bee Movie is a sweet, colorful animated story aimed at young children. Lets just hope no actual bees watch it.

title: Review: Natural Resistance, a Documentary on the Italian Wine Industry
description: Natural Resistance returns its director, Jonathan Nossiter, to the subject of his 2005 documentary, Mondovino. That film examined the effects of globalization on the wine industry, a business that might seem like a haven of elitism and individuality  hardly a trade susceptible to homogenization.

title: Germany Is Accused of Helping N.S.A. Spy on European Allies
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels government is fending off allegations that the German secret service helped the United States to spy on European partners and companies, nearly a year after Ms. Merkel expelled the top American spy in a rare display of anger over revelations of widespread United States intelligence operations in Germany.

title: Jameis Winston Is No. 1 in N.F.L. Draft as Talent Trumps Worry
description: CHICAGO  Jameis Winston, the star quarterback from Florida State who played under a swirl of controversy, was chosen first over all in the N.F.L. draft by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Thursday.

title: Chicago Said to Be Choice Over New York as Obama Library Site
description: CHICAGO  Chicago can breathe a sigh of relief: New York City will not be home to the Barack Obama Presidential Library and Museum.

title: Social Media Punished as Results Fall Short
description: A trio of social media stocks is getting pummeled this week, a sign that Wall Street may be unwilling to overlook missteps at some of its Internet darlings.

title: Review: Reality, an Absurdist Comedy of Dreams and Movie Nightmares
description: The indecipherability of Reality, the latest absurdist deathtrap from Quentin Dupieux (Rubber, Wrong), begins with its title: Reality is actually the name of a girl (Kyla Kenedy) who spots a blue VHS tape inside the guts of the hog her father has shot. A hog ingesting a videotape  or even the continued use of tapes  makes as much sense as anything else in this sardonic, self-devouring comedy, in which dreams, movies within movies and reality (such as it is) mix.

title: Republic of Congo Signals a Turn in Poaching Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Denis Sassou-Nguesso, president of the Republic of Congo, smiled broadly as he set fire to more than five tons of illegally hunted elephant tusks this week in Brazzaville, the nations capital.

title: Rules Change on I.R.S. Seizures, Too Late for Some
description: Under mounting pressure, the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department have announced in recent months that they will no longer use a law designed to go after drug dealers and terrorists to seize the bank accounts of small business owners who are not suspected of criminal activity. But Lyndon McLellan, the owner of a convenience store in rural Fairmont, N.C., where catfish sandwiches go for $2.75, is still trying to recover the $107,702.66  his entire business bank account  that was seized by the I.R.S. last summer.

title: Attacks on U.N. Force Add to Unrest in Mali
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Armed groups in the north of Mali have, over the last week, attacked each other as well as United Nations peacekeepers and Malian soldiers  underscoring the countrys fragility as it tries to emerge from several years of political instability and jihadist revolt.

title: Apple, IBM and Japan Post See Profit in the Old-Age Market
description: Japan is an incubator of aging. More than other countries, it is a graying nation. Twenty-five percent of its population, or 33 million people, is age 65 or older, more than double the global average.

title: Bill to Speed Approvals for Drugs Is Cut Back
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that would have accelerated the pace of federal drug approvals in a way that critics said threatened to erode patient safety was formally released this week, in a scaled-back version with many of the most controversial provisions left out.

title: Medicare Releases Detailed Data on Prescription Drug Spending
description: The heartburn drug Nexium  whose advertisements have long been ubiquitous on television  was prescribed to 1.5 million Medicare patients in 2013, for a total cost of more than $2.5 billion, the largest amount spent on any drug prescribed through the government program, according to data released by Medicare officials on Thursday.

title: U.S. Said to Give Warren Weinsteins Family Ransom Advice
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly two years before Warren Weinstein, an aid worker kidnapped by Al Qaeda, was inadvertently killed in an American drone strike, the F.B.I. gave his family guidance about paying a ransom of $250,000 to the militants who were holding him, United States officials said on Thursday.

title: Celebrating Museums All Over Town
description: In case you havent heard, theres a new Whitney.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 142 YEARS AGO

title: Patriot Act Faces Revisions Backed by Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON  After more than a decade of wrenching national debate over the intrusiveness of government intelligence agencies, a bipartisan wave of support has gathered to sharply limit the federal governments sweeps of phone and Internet records.

title: U.S. Lawmakers Press Iran to Free Jailed Americans
description: Congressional lawmakers, already conflicted about an impending nuclear deal with Iran, are increasingly angry over the incarceration of American citizens in that country, where at least three are imprisoned, including one held for more than three and a half years.

title: Jets Add to a Strength, Taking Leonard Williams, a Defender Surprisingly Still Available
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Less than an hour into his first draft as general manager, Mike Maccagnan was presented with a situation that would test one of his guiding principles.

title: Crime, Clinton and a New Era
description: It was a favorite riposte of Hillary Rodham Clintons in her 2008 presidential campaign: I always wonder what part of the 1990s they didnt like, she would say about critics who brought up her husbands administration, the peace or the prosperity?

title: Giants Draft Ereck Flowers, Not the Offensive Lineman They Wanted
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Perhaps no unit on the Giants has been a greater liability in recent seasons than the offensive line. The Giants have struggled to run the ball effectively and have failed to protect quarterback Eli Manning, a combination that has contributed mightily to the teams 13-19 record in the last two seasons.

title: Under Threat Because of His Words, a Charlie Hebdo WriterContinues to Speak Out
description: Like the people who stopped for coffee or missed a train connection on Sept. 11, Jean-Baptiste Thoret is alive because he was late getting to work in Paris one day in January. He is the film critic for Charlie Hebdo, a satirical magazine. That morning, two armed brothers forced their way into its offices. They killed 12 people; five others were killed in a later, coordinated attack. Among the dead were cartoonists thought to have drawn images offensive to some Muslims, a building porter, a man stopping by the office for the first time, police officers and shoppers in a kosher supermarket.

title: Police Board Clears Driver in Freddie Gray Case; No Officers Have Been Convicted
description: Prosecutors dropped all charges against three officers awaiting trial. Three other officers had already been acquitted.

title: New Owner for The Moscow Times and Vedomosti
description: MOSCOW  A Finnish media company on Thursday said it would sell its one-third stake in Vedomosti, Russias most influential business newspaper, as well as ownership of The Moscow Times, the countrys only English-language daily, to a Russian buyer.

title: Obama Pledges to Defend Democrats on Trade Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday made a personal plea to a group of congressional Democrats to support a far-reaching Pacific trade deal even in the face of political peril, promising them during a two-hour meeting at the White House that he would defend and campaign for lawmakers who risked their jobs to back him.

title: Richard Suzman, 72, Dies; Researcher Influenced Global Surveys on Aging
description: Richard M. Suzman once chased a Nobel-winning psychologist through a Washington rainstorm, as a scientific meeting was breaking up, to whet the psychologists interest in a new project. In the middle of the night, Dr. Suzman liked to email social scientists, urging them to take immediate action on a project. Other times, an email or phone call would all but order a researcher to apply for a grant.

title: Jozef Paczynski, Inmate Barber to Auschwitz Commandant, Dies at 95
description: Jozef Paczynski, a Polish Army captain who spent much of his five-year imprisonment in Auschwitz as the personal barber to Rudolf Hss, the Nazi death camps commandant, died on Sunday in Krakow. He was 95.

title: North Korean Diplomats Disrupt Human Rights Panel
description: A United Nations panel on North Korean human rights abuses, organized by the United States delegation at the organizations New York headquarters, briefly degenerated into shouting and disorder Thursday when three North Korean diplomats disrupted the event to deliver a statement denying any wrongdoing in their country. The diplomats interrupted North Korean defectors who were testifying about the deprivations they said they had endured. The United States ambassador, Samantha Power, threatened to call in United Nations security guards to evict the North Korean diplomats, but they left after about six minutes. Ms. Power said  that the North Korean diplomats had been invited to speak but only after the defectors had spoken, and unfortunately, as you heard, the delegation chose instead to try to drown out the testimony of these panelists. She also told the defectors, It must be chilling for those of you who have been subjected to the terror of the regime to be confronted with bullying and disruption and the kind of behavior that we saw today. North Korea has become increasingly angry over actions by the United Nations during the past few years, most notably a human rights report that described much of the country as a large penal colony and called for possible prosecution of North Korean leaders at the International Criminal Court. The United Nations Security Council has tightened sanctions against North Korea because of its nuclear weapons and missile tests. The North Korean authorities have accused the United States of orchestrating such actions as part of what they call an American plot to destabilize their country.

title: Review: Mating-Season Mood Swings in Two Gentlemen of Verona
description: For those of you who had been wondering if spring had decided to skip New York this year, there has been a confirmed sighting of that elusive season at Theater for a New Audiences Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn. Fresh sap, tickling breezes, blushing blooms  yep, theyre all in evidence. So is the tendency of emerging specimens of human fauna to seize the day as if it were made exclusively for mating.

title: Theyll Help You Out
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Sure, David Steinberg might have made his New York Times crossword debut on June 16, 2011, at the tender age of 14, but what has he done for us lately?

title: Clashes in Philadelphia as Freddie Gray Protest Neared Highway
description: PHILADELPHIA  Skirmishes erupted when protesters tried to breach a line of police officers who were trying to keep them off a highway in Philadelphia on Thursday night.

title: Baltimores Rough Rides
description: Residents of Baltimore describe their experience with rough rides in police vans.

title: Port AuthorityDelays Picking Builder for a Terminal at La Guardia
description: The Central Terminal Building at La Guardia Airport, which has been derided as a third world eyesore, should be transformed into a grand portal that welcomes travelers into a unified airport, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Thursday.

title: Jury Finds Mistakes, Not Widespread Fraud, at Seedco Job Agency
description: A former director for a nonprofit agency, which previously settled federal charges of making fake job placements to collect $1.6 million in performance payments, made mistakes but did not engage in a widespread pattern of fraud, a jury in Manhattan found last week.

title: Indiana Governor to Approve Needle Exchanges to Fight H.I.V.
description: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana has said he will sign a bill allowing cities and counties to create needle exchange programs if they are experiencing an outbreak of H.I.V. or hepatitis C because of intravenous drug use.

title: Grooveshark Shuts Down to Settle Copyright Infringement Suit
description: Add Grooveshark to the list of music websites that have been sued out of existence over copyright infringement.

title: Mets Lose Game, but Not Their Patience, as the Calendar Turns
description: Despite an 8-2 loss to the Washington Nationals on Thursday at Citi Field, the Mets turned the page from April in first place in the National League East.

title: Partial Verdict for Teenager Whose Stray Bullet Killed Man on Brooklyn Bus
description: After five days of deliberations, jurors on Thursday said they could not reach a decision in the most serious charge against Kahton Anderson, who was 14 when he fired a gun on a Brooklyn bus and killed a 39-year-old father last year.

title: Chobani Puts Its Ad Money on Becoming a Lifestyle Brand
description: Its not just yogurt. Its a lifestyle.

title: Late Goal Lifts Capitals Over Rangers in Opener
description: The Rangers scored the tying goal with less than five minutes remaining and seemed destined for overtime Thursday in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Washington Capitals.

title: Commonly Used Chemicals Come Under New Scrutiny
description: A top federal health official and hundreds of environmental scientists on Friday voiced new health concerns about a common class of chemicals used in products as varied as pizza boxes and carpet treatments.

title: Word of the Day | redundant
description: redundant  \ri-dn-dnt\  adjective

title: Tesla Ventures Into Solar Power Storage for Home and Business
description: In recent years, the fast-growing popularity of solar panels has intensified a central challenge: how to use the suns energy when it isnt shining.

title: A New Host City Welcomes New N.F.L. Players
description: As many expected, Jameis Winston was the No. 1 pick in the 2015 N.F.L. draft, which was in Chicago after being held in New York for the previous half-century.

title: Clippers Force a Game 7 Against the Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO  The Los Angeles Clippers were under duress, on the brink of elimination against the defending champions. So their 102-96 victory over the San Antonio Spurson Thursday night was something to savor, at least until they began the process of focusing all over again.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (2014) A motley crew of baddies, led by Peter Quill (Chris Pratt), a heavily armed professional scavenger, join forces to stop a crazed warrior from taking over the universe in James Gunns interstellar western, based on the Marvel Comics characters. The cast includes Zoe Saldana as Gamora, a green, mean killing machine; Dave Bautista as the brute Drax; Glenn Close as a space-age Hillary Rodham Clinton; Bradley Cooper as the voice of the raccoon Rocket; and Vin Diesel as a gorgeous tree called Groot, who nibbles his own tender sprouts. Oh, yes  and a blue orb that has incited the mayhem in the first place. That theres a palpable directorial sensibility in Guardians of the Galaxy, along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats. She added: The story may be confusing and generic by turns, but if you shake off the bonds of narrative coherency its liberating letting the weird words  Yondu, Necrocraft, Sakkaran  just slide right past you, much like the zigzagging, exploding 3-D spaceships. What sticks are the fantastical landscapes, the beautiful creature designs and the actors delivering lively performances, even with strata of makeup and digital wizardry.

title: Verne Gagne, Wrestler Who Grappled Through Two Eras, Dies at 89
description: Eighth Avenue traffic was disorganized, pedestrian traffic was jammed for blocks north and south, side doors at Madison Square Garden were torn from their hinges as the crowd stormed the entrances. It was the largest crowd at the Garden in 25 years  larger than for championship fights, rodeos, tennis matches or the circus.

title: Rangers Task Before Game 2: Forget Game 1
description: The Rangers again found themselves in a tight game on Thursday night as the third period wound down and overtime loomed in their series opener against Washington at Madison Square Garden.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When a judge goes home and he keeps thinking over and over that somethings wrong, something is usually wrong.

title: Corrections: May 1, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lost in Nepals Quake, but Preserved in Photos
description: When a devastating earthquake hit Nepal on Saturday, NayanTara Gurung Kakshapati was finishing an oral storytelling and digital-archiving workshop sponsored by the Nepal Picture Library. She and the other participants escaped the severely damaged building and helped construction workers next door who had been injured.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

In the Lap of Boredom

description: To the Editor:

title: Ideology and Integrity
description: The 2016 campaign should be almost entirely about issues. The parties are far apart on everything from the environment to fiscal policy to health care, and history tells us that what politicians say during a campaign is a good guide to how they will govern.

title: The Nature of Poverty
description: Lately it seems as though every few months theres another urban riot and the nation turns its attention to urban poverty. And in the midst of every storm, there are people crying out that we should finally get serious about this issue. This time it was Jon Stewart who spoke for many when he said: And you just wonder sometimes if were spending a trillion dollars to rebuild Afghanistans schools, like, we cant build a little taste down Baltimore way. Like is that whats really going on?

title: What Old Nazis Make Us Remember
description: BERLIN  THE trial of Oskar Grning, the 93-year-old accountant of Auschwitz, began last week in the German city of Lneburg. Mr. Grning is charged with complicity in the murder of at least 300,000 people. At least once during the summer of 1944, according to his accusers, when thousands of Hungarian Jews arrived by cattle car at Auschwitz-Birkenau, he stood at the exit ramp, watching as the passengers were divided into those to be put into forced labor and those to be killed instantly.

title: How to Hold the Baltimore Police Accountable
description: Update 11:34 AM ET:In a surprise announcement, the state attorney of Baltimore, Marilyn J. Mosby, said this morning that she had found probable cause to file homicide, manslaughter and misconduct charges against police officers in the death of Freddie Gray. The prosecutor said that officers had arrested Mr. Gray without grounds, violated procedure by transporting him unsafely in a police van and had repeatedly failed to get him medical attention. The death, Ms. Mosby said, is believed to be the result of a fatal injury to Mr. Gray while he was riding in the van.

title: Picking Up the Tab for Low Wages
description: It is hard to overstate the extent to which work no longer results in a decent paycheck and a rising standard of living in this country. The portion of the economic pie that goes to working people is currently near the smallest on record, in data going back to 1947. Similarly, the gap between worker pay and labor productivity has widened since the 1970s. In a healthy economy, wages and productivity would rise in tandem, but in recent decades, productivity gains have flowed increasingly to executive compensation and shareholder returns, rather than wages.

title: American Beauty, Wherever Its From
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art reopens on Friday in a new building, in a new neighborhood, offering a new chance to chew over an old question. What is American art, exactly?

title: The Pressures on Todays Students
Black Culture Is Not the Problem
description: BALTIMORE  IN the wake of the Michael Brown shooting and subsequent unrest in Ferguson, Mo., commentators noted the absence of black representatives among Fergusons elected officials and its police leadership. A Department of Justice report highlighted how Fergusons mostly white City Council and its courts spurred on explicitly racist policing, in part to harvest fines from black residents.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: May 1
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from buildings in Manhattan, beaches in Queens and a barn in the Bronx.

title: Lloyds Banking Group Profit Slides 19% on TSB Sale
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday that its net profit declined 19 percent in the first quarter as the lender took a pretax charge of 745 million pounds, or about $1.15 billion, related to its sale of TSB Banking Group.

title: Test Yourself | When May Day Was Moving Day
description: Below, several paragraphs from the July 11 article Your Move, Their Headache.

title: Q. and A.: Francis Fukuyama on Chinas Political Development
description: Francis Fukuyamas widely read essay The End of History?  published just before the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989  posited that Western liberal democracy may turn out to be the endpoint of political development. So when Mr. Fukuyama laid out what he considered the weaknesses of the American political system in a new book last year, Political Order and Political Decay, the Chinese state news media immediately asserted that he had altered his views and now considered state capacity, like that of China during the last 35 years of rapid economic development under Communist Party rule, as more important for a countrys prosperity than democracy.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Teenager Is Rescued From Rubble Five Days After Nepal Earthquake
description: In Teenager Is Rescued From Rubble Five Days After Nepal Earthquake, Ellen Barry and Gardiner Harris report on a dramatic rescue in Katmandu.

title: No-Fuss Hamptons Living
description: The intimidating wish list flaunted by discriminating house hunters in the Hamptons is nothing new. These shoppers are like diners who blithely order dishes nowhere in sight on the restaurant menu: Their sense of entitlement is accompanied by a desire for a totally customized experience.

title: Speedy Drug Approvals Have Become the Rule, Not the Exception
description: Congress has over the past few decades passed a series of special approval pathways for important drugs that treat life-threatening or rare diseases. This week, a new bill introduced in the House could add two more.

title: White House Looks to Ease Arab Fears Over Iran Nuclear Pact
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is scrambling for reassurances it can present this month at a Camp David summit meeting to persuade Arab allies that the United States has their backs, despite a pending nuclear deal with Iran.

title: A Father in Texas Takes On Sexual Assault in Sports
description: Months before Jameis Winston became the top pick in the N.F.L. draft, a man named Bill Miller was sitting at his breakfast table in Texas thinking about the problem of sexual assaults in sports.

title: Toronto F.C. Enduring Seven-Game Road Stretch to Start Season
description: TORONTO  After eight years in Major League Soccer without a playoff berth, Toronto F.C. fans might be forgiven for feeling a familiar sense of futility as their club kicked off this season with two wins, four losses and more goals against than for.

title: This Summers Action Heroes Are Several Shades of Gray
description: Summer is supposed to be the season of youth, when the over-25 quadrant surrenders theaters to wisecracking cartoons, thumb-sucking comedies and action franchises based on toys, comic books, amusement park rides. This is when the big studios make most of their money with Krypton-proof titles like Transformers: Age of Extinction, and their year-round obsession with pandering to the kids reaches fever pitch. In the movie world, summer starts the first weekend in May, which this year meant the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron, with those youngbloods Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson and  the 50-year-old Robert Downey Jr.

title: Brooklyn Girl Injured in a Fire That Killed 7 Siblings Is Said to Be Recovering
description: A Brooklyn girl who was badly burned and whose seven siblings died a month ago in a fire has been released from the hospital, and according to a family acquaintance, she is walking, speaking and, in a sign of her resiliency, smiling.

title: The Hunt for a Dead Womans Identity, Aided by Her Faded Tattoo
description: They found a hand first, in a gritty inlet at the mouth of Coney Island Creek. It was a cold afternoon in January, a thin blanket of snow lending the scene a rustic veneer, but beneath it were layers of garbage, and worse.

title: A Woman-Led Law Firm That Lets Partners Be Parents
description: Just past 9:30 on a Wednesday morning in March, after she drove 20 minutes to drop her son, Jack, off at preschool, after she trekked back for an hour across the Washington metro area into Fairfax, Va., for work, and long, long after she answered her first email, Maria Simon sat in a windowless conference room weighing the odds that she would be able to make a party in Jacks class two days hence.

title: Pine Ridge Indian Reservation Struggles With Suicides Among Its Young
description: PINE RIDGE INDIAN RESERVATION, S.D.  A few days before Christmas, Santana Janis, a 12-year-old Lakota Indian, decided that she did not want to live anymore.

title: Senators Running for President Face a Delicate Balancing Act
description: WASHINGTON  After Senator Marco Rubio announced his campaign for president in Miami last month, he did not catch the next plane to Iowa or New Hampshire. Instead, he raced back to Washington to attend a Senate Foreign Relations Committee meeting on a bill giving Congress the power to weigh in on any nuclear deal President Obama reaches with Iran.

title: Displaced Again and Again, Some African Migrants Had No Plan to Land in Italy
description: SYRACUSE, Sicily  By now, the unceasing tides of migrants arriving at the ports of Sicily fall into loose national categories.

title: Have You Ever Lied to Your Parents or Done Something Behind Their Backs?
description: In a recent post, the Motherlode blog offers advice for parents when a child loses their trust  perhaps by sneaking off to a party they werent supposed to attend, or by spending money they didnt have permission to spend.

title: 1915: Zeppelins Grow Like Falstaffs Men in Buckram
description: LONDON  Sir John Falstaffs men in Buckram are recalled by the latest Zeppelin raids  there was another one yesterday [April 30]  for while a despatch from Wells, in Norfolk, reported that four Zeppelins were seen off there at 6:30 oclock on Friday evening, a correspondent at Harwich telegraphed soon afterwards, on the authority of a policeman, that eight Zeppelins were seen off the coast, four at Wells, going north-west, and four at Lowestoft, going south-west.

title: Cook Your Butt Off! With Rocco DiSpirito
description: How can you burn calories while you cook? What are some tips for making tasty gluten-free food? How can you be more active while at the supermarket and in the kitchen? Can you make your favorite foods into low-calorie fare?

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: 1914 | The Movie Clock, No Bigger Than a Pocket Watch
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: COS and Mr Porter Team Up for Travel-Ready Mens Wear and More
description: Plus: Givenchys brave new tuxedos; tees that are far from basic; the bucket hat moves into the fashion mainstream.

title: With Wallets, Thin Is In
description: Mens billfolds are following the trend of slim, tailored mens wear.

title: Riding a Van Back to the 70s
description: Los Angeles  When Ben Vasquez bought his 1975 Chevrolet G10 van, its mural of an eagle soaring over a desert landscape was faded, and its plush interior, intended for amorous assignations, was shredded from years of neglect.

title: High Season Over, Now Is the Time for Beach Getaways
description: After the seemingly endless winter, no one could be blamed for wanting an early jump on summer. The good news is that you can do so this month, at beach getaways that promise sun, surf and temperatures in the 70s, 80s and 90s, but without the crowds or the high prices of the peak season.

description: NAME Brian Shimansky

title: Staying Fit (and Unplugged) With Tai Chi
description: Call me lazy, but Im not big on exercise. For most of my adult life, my weight stayed the same no matter how much I ate or didnt work out.

title: Advice From a Shoe Expert, Steve Taffel of Leffot
description: Leffot, a high-ceilinged boutique in Greenwich Village specializing in classic mens footwear, has occupied the corner of Christopher Street and Gay Street since 2008, when the proprietor Steve Taffel opened it with his wife, Hiroko Taffel, a year after he left Prada. Displayed amid the black walls are swatches of suedes and leathers (for custom design) and about 70 pairs of shoes from traditional makers like Alden and Edward Green. The shop also offers hats, socks, belts and wallets. Here, Mr. Taffel provides an insiders view on how to dress your feet for warm weather.

title: A Tour of the Paris Home of Giancarlo Giammetti, Co-Founder of Valentino
description: Giancarlo Giammetti

title: Are You Man Enough for a Small Watch?
description: Mad Men has been credited with sparking a revival in fedoras, tie bars, pocket squares, wing tips and even old-fashioneds, for those who may (rightly) consider a cocktail a fashion accessory.

title: Ask Well: Is Golf With a Cart Exercise?
description: Question:

title: New York Today: The Whitney Lets the City In
description: Good morning on this brisk Friday.

title: Daily Report: Social Media Companies Take a Beating as Results Fall Short
description: A trio of social media stocks is getting pummeled this week, a sign that Wall Street may be unwilling to overlook missteps at some of its Internet darlings, Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac report.

title: Teenagers in The Times | April 2015
description: Welcome to Aprils edition of Teenagers in The Times.

title: Today in Politics: Time and Distance Might Lessen Familiar Argument Against Clinton
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. Republicans are gathering in South Carolina, and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont made his candidacy for president official. All eyes remain on Hillary Rodham Clinton, who must decide not only how to respond to him, but continues to face questions on how to respond to the policies of former President Bill Clinton.

title: Re: Her Majestys Jihadists
description: It was, in the words of Mika Brzezinski on Morning Joe, revelatory: In her April 19 cover story, Mary Anne Weaver reported that more British Muslims had joined Islamist militias like ISIS and the Nusra Front than are serving the British Army.

title: How Doing Nothing Became the Ultimate Family Vacation
description: Before having a child, my wife and I had always prided ourselves on being travelers and not tourists. We liked out-of-the-way places; my research often took us to absurd locations like the Democratic Republic of Congo near rebel-held territory or old Khmer Rouge bases on the Thai-Cambodian border. We hated anything that smelled of a prepaid vacation package and we generally avoided hotels, preferring guesthouses or staying in locals apartments.

title: New York City From a Pint-Size Perspective
description: Until my 8-year-old granddaughter, Emilia, and I pretended to be tourists in New York, it had honestly never occurred to me that Times Square might be the nicest neighborhood in the city. At the places where out-of-towners go, I was struck by how many young employees of these attractions asked us if we were enjoying ourselves, if we were having fun. More surprisingly, they seemed genuinely interested in our replies. They appeared to have been hired for their humorous, friendly dispositions.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Frans Masereels The City
description: I found it 20 years ago on a secondhand bookstores discard table, the sort of lucky accident that befalls only a prepared mind. It was a paperback 1972 Dover edition of a work originally published in Munich in 1925: The City, by Frans Masereel, a wordless novel made up of 100 woodcuts. The yellowed and slightly water-stained cover bore a blown-up reprint of one of the many indelible urban tableaus that I was about to view for the first time  images that I somehow instantly recognized, even anticipated.

title: Once
description: Once, when I came home from school after being taunted on the playground for having a black mother and a white father, I climbed onto my parents tall bed and lay between them. It was a raft, and the world around us fell away as we drifted there. Saskia Hamiltons poem carries me back to that moment as if speaking to my own particular experience. Its one of poetrys great gifts to show us ourselves through the intimate voice of another.

title: How to Write a Romance Novel
description: Romance novels end happily. Try another approach, and youll anger a lot of readers, says Jayne Ann Krentz, who has written more than 150 books, including 50 consecutive New York Times best sellers. Hero and heroine might spend hundreds of pages kept apart by war, vampires, apocalypse or any number of other exhausting obstacles, but by the end, they must be together in a way that suggests long-lasting love.

title: The Amazing New Thing
Wasting Less of Africas Harvest in Order to Prosper
description: Last year, Tanzania had exciting news: a bumper harvest of corn. But even as farmers were celebrating  corn is a staple eaten at almost every meal  much of the crop had already been spoiled, having grown moldy or been infested by insects and rodents. The problem was that farmers lacked the capacity to store food safely. Even the governments national reserve system had run out of space to hold the overflow.

title: A Collected Home for Inger McCabe Elliott
description: Inger McCabe Elliott, a former photojournalist for Life and a textile designer, lives in a 1914 co-op on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: What Happened When I Joked About the President of Ecuador
description: President Rafael Correa delivers the sabatina, his address, every Saturday. But I had something else to do that morning. By the time I got home at noon, people had written to me on Twitter, saying that I was going to jail. There was a photo of the president during the sabatina, and on the screen behind him was my logo and a photo of my memes. Ive always posted satirical political memes on my Facebook page, about the government, about the opposition.

title: 2 Indicted in George Washington Bridge Case; Ally of Christie Pleads Guilty
description: After a 16-month federal investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a judge in New Jersey unsealed indictments against two people close to Gov. Chris Christie, outlining a conspiracy made with a third confidant to exact political vengeance against a mayor for not endorsing the governors re-election.

title: The Bridge Scandal, Explained
description: Q. What actually happened?

title: Macedonia Indicts Opposition Leader Who Denounced Graft
description: WARSAW  Macedonias main opposition leader has been formally indicted on charges of wiretapping and antigovernment activities after months of political turmoil, prosecutors said this week.

title: Morning Agenda: Greenberg Still in the Ring
description: GREENBERG STILL IN THE RING | In 2005, Maurice R. Greenberg was forced to resign from American International Group under the shadow of an accounting scandal, which he is still battling in court as he gets ready to turn 90 on Monday. And Mr. Greenberg is also the driving force behind a four-year-old lawsuit claiming the federal government unconstitutionally seized A.I.G.s assets during the financial crisis. Few people would choose to spend their golden years surrounded by lawyers, facing subpoenas and hostile cross-examination. Yet, if anything, Mr. Greenberg seems to have been energized, James B. Stewart writes in his Common Sense column.

title: Hogan Fund-Raiser for Christie Comes at a Bad Time
description: When it was scheduled, the May 1 fund-raiser was cast as the glorious reunion of two valiant political allies, Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

title: Everything I Know About Journalism in 395 Words
description: On Wednesday night, I taught my last class of the semester at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and my last class there, at least for now. (I will be teaching an opinion-writing class at the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism in the fall.)

title: Paris in the Springtime, in New York
description: MY breakfast this morning was a perfect croissant. I hadnt realized such a thing existed in New York until a Parisian pointed me in its direction.

title: Tom Hardy on Life as the New Mad Max
description: LAS VEGAS  Tom Hardys mug  oversize, pouty-lipped, bedroom-eyed in the key of Paul Newman  was plastered all over the elevator banks at Caesars Palace here. But at a Starbucks on the casino floor, amid the hypnotic dings and blinkety lights, hundreds of people swirled around as he ordered coffee, barely giving him a second  or even a first  glance.

title: 1940: College Head Offers a Million for Capture of Hitler Alive
description: NEW YORK A $1,000,000 reward for the capture of Adolf Hitler and his delivery alive, uninjured and unhurt, to the League of Nations during the month of May, today [May 1] was offered by Samuel H. Church, eighty-one-year-old president of the Carnegie Institute, on behalf of that organization.

title: That Lovin Feeling
description: Dear Diary:

title: Even at the Top, Making Plans for Lifes Third Chapter
description: WHEN Sherry Lansing, the former chairwoman of Paramount Pictures, decided to end a 40-year career in the rough-and-tumble of Hollywood, the question she faced was where to direct all the energy and drive that had propelled her to the top of the industry.

title: Jurassic World Does Its Own Dinosaur Modifications
description: After three films in the Jurassic Park series, it looks as if the scientists who tinkered with genetics to bring back dinosaurs still havent learned their lesson. Theyre back in Jurassic World, due June 12, to engineer a new dinosaur, the Indominus Rex. Jurassic World takes place 22 years after the first film, now with a fully functioning park. Because of low attendance, park officials have opted for a genetically modified creature to join some of the familiar ones. Chaos, of course, ensues. Returning are the velociraptors, which generated chills in Steven Spielbergs 1993 original and in the sequels. But in Jurassic World, they have more individual moments  and even take to a bit of training.

title: Floyd Mayweather Jr.s Fashion
description: Mr. Mayweather has become boxings singular fashion plate, developing a ring-wear style perhaps best described as Louis Vuitton-meets-Liberace.

title: As Floyd Mayweather Jr. Steps Into Ring, He Turns It Into a Catwalk
description: When Floyd Mayweather Jr. steps into the boxing ring at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on Saturday to fight Manny Pacquiao, the first question on most viewerss minds  including the estimated three million pay-per-viewers  will be, of course, who will win.

title: The Director Paul Feig Prepares Spy With Melissa McCarthy
description: BUDAPEST  Melissa McCarthy was standing in an ersatz C.I.A. office here, on a soundstage a few miles outside the city. With a curly wig and a fake case of pink eye, she was shooting a scene opposite Jude Law for their new movie, Spy, as the director and screenwriter, Paul Feig, looked on.

title: Bernanke and the Inflationistas
description: Ben Bernanke delivers a righteous smackdown of the Wall Street Journal editorial page:

title: Naming a New York Building
description: For as long as developers have been building apartment houses in New York City, they have been giving these buildings names  sometimes a historic reference, sometimes a lofty aspiration and sometimes a developers own name.

title: Shake Off the Winter!
description: TIMES INSIDER  Have April showers succeeded in bringing May flowers? It depends heavily on where you live, but this month we are shaking off the winter doldrums for real. The puzzles for the month of May will get your senses tingling and enjoying the newly warm weather. To wind things up for the month, we will celebrate the most important woman in your life.

title: Police Fire Tear Gas and Water Cannons at Istanbul Protesters
description: ISTANBUL  Riot police officers used tear gas and water cannons to disperse hundreds of protesters who took to the streets of Istanbul on Friday, defying a government ban on May Day celebrations in Taksim Square.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: The Upshot has been fascinated with the value of college educations, so we took particular interest in the Brookings Institutions novel ranking of colleges. It came up with a way to rate a set of two-year and four-year colleges by how much more of a salary youd expect to get by going to a particular one. Some of the technical ones, as expected, got high marks, but its analysis also cited schools like Carleton College and Washington and Lee University.

title: Health Insurance Deadline Passes for Most, but There Are Exceptions
description: THE last chance to sign up for health insurance this year under the Affordable Care Act passed on Thursday, when an extended deadline for enrollment expired.

title: Whats On This Week Around The World
description: Rome

title: Verbatim: Rubios Take on the Food Pyramid
description: Senator Marco Rubio, when asked Friday if he, like his potentialrival for the Republican presidential nomination, Jeb Bush, was also on the Paleo diet.

title: 3 Ways Nepalis Are Using Crowdsourcing to Aid in Quake Relief
description: In the wake of the 7.8 magnitude earthquake that hit their country over the weekend, many Nepalis at home and abroad have found a new way to help  as digital volunteers, spending hours hunched over their laptops, using crowdsourcing technologies and social platforms to participate in the relief effort.

title: 6 Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death
description: BALTIMORE  Baltimores chief prosecutor charged six police officers on Friday with a range of crimes including murder and manslaughter in the arrest and fatal injury of Freddie Gray, a striking and surprisingly swift turn in a case that has drawn national attention to police conduct.

title: Killing Them Softly, at the Supreme Court
description: Most of the rest of the world has moved on from the death penalty, in some cases long ago. But here in the United States, in the year 2015, in the most august courtroom in the land, nine esteemed jurists sat around for an hour and soberly debated the best way to kill someone quickly, painlessly and  perhaps most important  bloodlessly.

title: Topical Fiction
description: OYE WHAT IM GONNA TELL YOU

title: Academy Street, by Mary Costello
description: Named for the street on which its central character, an Irish immigrant, finds her New York home, this debut novel from Mary Costello deepens and magnifies the distinctive style evident in her 2012 collection The China Factory. There, the inner worlds of her often isolated protagonists were examined in short, tight sentences that refused to discriminate between the scars of the dramatic and those of the banal.

title: The Fair Fight, by Anna Freeman
description: Writing any novel involves decisions. In historical novels, these decisions can be agonizing, since readers of this genre are particularly unforgiving. Language? Tense? Voice? Such choices made, youre still left contemplating Henry Jamess dispiriting judgment that in historical fiction the real thing is almost impossible to do, and in its essence the whole effect is as nought.

title: The Battle of Versailles, by Robin Givhan
description: All fashion is spectacle. The industry looks forward, not back  which can make it difficult to imagine a moment before this one, when celebrity-lined fashion shows are live-streamed, a dress can be preordered by a woman in Dubuque the same week it debuts on the runway, and style bloggers are walking advertisements for young designers. There was a time, however, when the fashion world was more firmly rooted in the tradition of haute couture. The story of that change centers on one spectacular evening in November 1973, as told in Robin Givhans The Battle of Versailles.

title: Manchu Princess, Japanese Spy, by Phyllis Birnbaum
description: Yoshiko Kawashima was, at first glance, a winning figure. Described by The New York Times in 1933 as a picturesque film-drama figure, half tomboy, half heroine, she was often called the Joan of Arc of the Manchus. It was the fulfillment of a childhood dream. Riding to school on horseback, Kawashima imagined herself as a new Joan, restoring her people to their rightful glory.

title: The Thunder of Giants, by Joel Fishbane
description: Anna Swan, born in Nova Scotia in 1846, shares Joel Fishbanes novel with Andorra del Alandra, born a half-century later in the Pyrenees principality for which she is named. Anna was a historical figure, Andorra is entirely fictional. Both women immigrate to America, and both are discovered by talent scouts. Anna becomes a featured act in P.T. Barnums American Museum in New York, while Andorra heads for Hollywood. Neither woman actually yearns for the stage, but their career choices are limited. Both Anna and Andorra are almost eight feet tall.

title: Jeffery Deavers Solitude Creek, and More
description: Starring in a Jeffery Deaver thriller isnt all its cracked up to be. Despite their sterling reputations, his sleuths are in constant danger of being outclassed by their preternaturally cunning adversaries. This is what happens in SOLITUDE CREEK (Grand Central, $28) when Kathryn Dance, an agent with the California Bureau of Investigation, takes on Antioch March, a newfangled killer who likes to scare people into causing their own deaths. He plays with perceptions, sensations, panic, Dance discovers, leaving the actual killing to his victims themselves.

title: Review: The Herd, Rory Kinnears Drama About Family Friction
description: CHICAGO  The drama of family discord has been such a staple of the American theater that a curtain rising upon a suburban living room almost automatically makes us settle in and wait for the fireworks to start. But the British can squabble and stew, stiff upper lips be damned, quite as well as the rest of us, as is illustrated by The Herd, a lively and moving comedy-drama by the British actor Rory Kinnear making its United States premiere at the Steppenwolf Theater here.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE WRONG ENEMY: America in Afghanistan, 2001-2014, by Carlotta Gall. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) Gall, The New York Timess Afghanistan bureau chief and correspondent between 2001 and 2011, details the missteps that exacerbated the violence there, and highlights Pakistans role in sheltering leaders of the Taliban and Al Qaeda. In NO GOOD MEN AMONG THE LIVING: America, the Taliban, and the War Through Afghan Eyes (Picador, $18), Anand Gopal lays bare the wars murky intricacies through the lives of three Afghans: a Taliban commander, a tribal strongman and a village housewife turned senator.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Miuccias Museum Opens
description: The Fondazione Prada opens the doors to its first permanent exhibition space on May 9th.

title: Waiting on Line for Free Preschool
description: Margaux Laskey works in Cooking at The New York Times, and over the next 24 hours, she and her husband, Scott Garapolo, will take turns waiting in line to register their 3-year-old daughter for a free preschool program in Jersey City Heights.

title: That Kid Belongs on Broadway
description: Tony Award-nominated actors on the moment they knew they were destined for the stage.

title: Pension Funds Can Only Guess at Private Equitys Cost
description: Partnership agreements outlining private equity firms practices are as closely guarded as the recipe for Coca-Cola.

title: The Washington Senators: A Monument to Bad Management
description: In the fall of 1924, the Washington Senators won their first World Series, over the New York Giants. But it would also prove to be their last.

title: Editors Choice
description: MY STRUGGLE: Book 4, by Karl Ove Knausgaard. Translated by Don Bartlett. (Archipelago, $27.) This is the fleetest, funniest and  in keeping with its adolescent protagonist  most sophomoric of the volumes translated into English thus far.

title: Inside the List
description: Marlon and Me: With her Nobel Prize and her graven prose and a leonine profile as stately and imposing as anything on Mount Rushmore, Toni Morrison can come across as frankly a bit intimidating  the woman has authority. Add to that her four-decade career writing brilliant and often despairing novels about the black experience in America, and its no wonder interviewers frequently want her to proclaim about race relations or the latest tragedy playing out on the nations television screens. Morrison  whose new novel, God Help the Child, hits the hardcover fiction list at No.5  sometimes obliges them. People keep saying, We need to have a conversation about race, she told The Telegraph last month. This is the conversation. I want to see a cop shoot a white unarmed teenager in the back. And I want to see a white man convicted for raping a black woman. Then when you ask me, Is it over?, I will say yes. (Almost 20 years ago, I heard Morrison read from an early draft of her novel Paradise, and when an audience member asked if the gains of the civil rights movement might herald an imminent end to racism, Morrison paused and slowly shook her head. I am not optimistic, she said.) But there is a less foreboding, more playful side to Morrison as well: The critic John Leonard once reported that she liked to chat with Fran Lebowitz about Court TV, and she told The Telegraph that Marlon Brando used to call just to recite her work: I still have his number in my iPhone! How could I erase that?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Calories, Gluten and a Fat-Melting Drug
description: Take the Quiz

title: The Prado and a New Royal Museum Duel Over Paintings
description: MADRID  A royal battle is simmering here.

title: Daniel Loeb Takes Stake in Yum Brands
description: The billionaire investor Daniel S. Loeb is making a bet that Yum Brands is turning the page on its troubles in China.

title: Antipasto Is the Overture to Breezy Italian-Style Entertaining
description: An Italian meal begins with the antipasto. Meant to awaken the palate and stave off initial hunger pangs, it could just be a simple platter of sliced cured meats and a few olives.

title: Student Loan Facts They Wish They Had Known
description: The problem with a lot of the advice that teenagers and their families get about higher education debt is that its totally, utterly bloodless.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Saul Bellow
description: This week, Sam Tanenhaus talks about Zachary Leaders new biography of Saul Bellow; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Emily Bazelon discusses Jon Krakauers Missoula; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Ben E. King, Soulful Singer of Stand by Me, Dies at 76
description: Ben E. King, the smooth, soulful baritone who led the Drifters on There Goes My Baby, Save the Last Dance for Me and other hits in the late 1950s and early 1960s, and as a solo artist recorded the classic singles Spanish Harlem and Stand by Me, died on Thursday in Hackensack, N.J. He was 76.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Saul Bellow
description: This week, Sam Tanenhaus and Emily Bazelon.

title: After the Fair Leaves Town
description: Structures built for global events sometimes live second useful lives  and sometimes not.

title: Food and Culture Through the Years
description: How food has been portrayed in worlds fair exhibits since 1851.

title: Ignacio Mattos Shares a Few of His Favorite Things
description: The chef behind Estela discusses influential food, books and art in anticipation of the James Beard Awards this Monday.

title: For the Mayweather-Pacquiao Winner, a Bevy of Belts
description: LAS VEGAS  By now, even people who do not follow boxing know that two men named Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. are due to fight an important match here on Saturday. But does anyone  boxing fans included  know what they are fighting for?

title: What to Do When a Large Financial Failure Starts With a Bank
description: An important feature of the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul is Title IIs orderly liquidation authority. It is this authority that is supposed to put an end to bailouts by providing regulators with a third way that avoids either Lehman Brothers unplanned bankruptcy or American International Groups unplanned bailout.

title: Marilyn Mosby, Prosecutor in Freddie Gray Case, Takes a Stand and Calms a Troubled City
description: BALTIMORE  Shortly before she became the youngest top prosecutor in any major American city, Marilyn J. Mosby, a daughter and granddaughter of police officers, had tough words about how the nations criminal justice system had handled mistreatment of black men by the police.

title: Tear Gas Breaks Up Protests in Istanbul
description: Riot police in Istanbul on Friday fired tear gas and water cannons into crowds of May Day protesters, who had attempted to defy a ban to gather in the citys Taksim Square.

title: The Philosophy of Warren E. Buffett
description: Lawrence A. Cunningham, a professor at George Washington University and former corporate lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, has written numerous books including, most recently, Berkshire Beyond Buffett: The Enduring Value of Values.

title: Nonbanks Target Single-Family Rental Investors
description: Financing options for real estate investors have been expanding as nonbank lenders step in to fill what they see as a lucrative void.

title: Prices for Private Residence Clubs Slow to Recover
description: SEVEN years after prices for private residence clubs and other fractional developments collapsed, the value of a small slice of paradise is still far from recovered.

title: DuPonts Battle With Nelson Peltz May Confound Shareholders
description: In the battle over DuPonts future, it all comes down to point of view.

title: El Kabeir Scratched From Kentucky Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  El Kabeir, a standout in New York prep races at Aqueduct Racetrack, was scratched from the 141st  Kentucky Derby on Friday afternoon because of an injury to his left front foot.

title: The Escalation of Boxing Purses
description: The fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao on May 2 will be the richest boxing match in history with the purse totaling more than $200 million dollars. A look at the rising paydays for boxers over the years.

title: A Film Series Celebrates 3-D and Its Glasses
description: Is it in 3-D? Movie audiences ask that question a lot, sometimes in anticipation, sometimes in annoyance. After its increase in popularity in the 1950s, then another surge in the 1980s, the use of contemporary 3-D picked up again in the early 2000s and seems like its here to stay. In the series 3D in the 21st Century, BAMcinmatek is looking at the most recent resurgence, showing films both highbrow (Pina) and low (Jackass 3D) to demonstrate the many ways the technology enhances storytelling.

title: Nuclear War? No, Twitter War
description: Whatever the benefits of social media, it does have a way of bringing out the worst in some people, propelling them to engage in snarky and highly personal attacks as a way of gaining attention.

title: Mixed Verdicts in Second Trial of Aleynikov, Ex-Goldman Sachs Programmer
description: For the second time in five years, prosecutors have prevailed over Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer accused of stealing confidential computer trading code from the bank. The first time it took a federal jury just hours to convict; this time it came after more than a week of deliberation and an accusation of food poisoning and avocado tampering in a state court jury room.

title: Marco Rubio Courts Right on Iran and Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio, who described the possibility of his becoming president as an increasingly optimistic hypothetical, spent Friday morning answering questions both immediate and, yes, hypothetical at the National Reviews ideas summit.

title: Goat Cheese Strata Gets an Update
description: A goat cheese strata may sound like the kind of recipe published in womens magazines from the 1980s, right next to the article telling you how to rectify your home perm gone wrong. Both of which youd probably rather forget.

title: Bitcoin Comes Out of the Shadows and Into Wall Streets Sights
description: At the end of a panel discussion at the Inside Bitcoins conference in New York this week  billed as the largest such event in the world  a supporter of the cryptocurrency pointed to one of the three lawyers discussing Bitcoins struggle for mainstream acceptance.

title: Exclusive | Nuits Mansion, Irvington, N.Y.
description: An Italianate villa, once home to John Jacob Astor III, is poised to enter the market at $14.75 million.

title: A Mansion Where an Astor Lived
description: An attention-getter since its appearance in 1853 along the Hudson River, an Italianate villa known as Nuits in the Westchester village of Irvington, once home to John Jacob Astor III, is poised to enter the market with a price tag of $14.75 million, making it one of the highest priced properties in the Rivertowns. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the house has more than 20 rooms and was last listed in 2012 for $11.75 million, but remained in the hands of the present owner, Martin W. Dolan, an investment banker.

title: In Late Night Appearance, Michelle Obama Dishes on Daughters
description: Michelle Obama dished to David Letterman, the late-night television host, on Thursday about dealing with a sulky teenaged daughter in the White House.

title: Long-Unheard Harlem Renaissance Opera Coming in June
description: Voodoo, a long-unheard opera by the pioneering African-American composer and Harlem Renaissance figure H. Lawrence Freeman, will return this June to New York, where it had its premiere in 1928, for a pair of concert performances that will be recorded.

title: A Sports Fans Guide to a Delicious Saturday
description: A fans guide on what to watch and what to eat and drink on the biggest sports Saturday in years.

title: Just Back From the Miss Dior Exhibition Opening, Kate Young Shares Her Sun-Searching Travels
description: The stylist, whose new eyewear and optical designs for Tura hit stores this month, offers T an exclusive look at her recent trips to Puerto Rico, Upstate New York and Beijing, China.

title: David Wildsteins Plea Agreement in Bridge Lane-Closing Scandal
description: The former Port Authority official and a high-school friend of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey pleaded guilty at the United States District Court in Newark to conspiracy to commit fraud and conspiracy against civil rights.

title: A Ringside Seat
description: Its easy now. Well, relatively easy. Not the writing, but getting your copy to your newspapers office. If youre a sports reporter at ringside for a big fight, like the Floyd Mayweather Jr.-Manny Pacquiao extravaganza on Saturday night, you set up your laptop, type your words into the keyboard, move your mouse on the screen, click-click, hit send, and moments later, your article appears on a screen in your office. What a wonderful world.

title: Indictment Against Baroni and Kelly in George Washington Bridge Scandal
description: Bill Baroni, the former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and Bridget Anne Kelly, a former deputy chief of staff to Gov. Chris Christie, were charged with multiple counts of conspiracy.

title: Guggenheim Closes for the Afternoon as Workers Advocates Escalate Protests
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum closed to the public on Friday afternoon after a few dozen protesters descended on the museum and unfurled a red banner that read Meet Workers Demands Now in the crowded lobby.

title: Summer 2015 Movie Releases: A Look at Whats Coming
Homicide Charges in Gray Case Announced
description: Marilyn J. Mosby, the states attorney for Baltimore, said that Freddie Grays arrest was illegal and that there was probable cause to file manslaughter charges against the police officers involved.

title: Watch the Trailers: 14 Movies Coming This Summer
description: A quick guide to standouts of the summer movie season.

title: Bulls, Healthy for a Change, Face a Diminished Cavaliers Team
description: The Chicago Bulls of recent years have risen or fallen with Derrick Rose. A seeming championship trajectory earlier in this decade went wrong primarily because of his injuries. Now he is healthy again, and the Bulls have advanced to the N.B.A.s Eastern Conference semifinals to face the Cleveland Cavaliers, who have a serious injury issue of their own.

title: Midtown Condo With Views for $30.68 Million
description: A sprawling aerie on the 53rd floor of One57, the sky-piercing condominium that has attracted demigods of international business and finance, sold to a mystery buyer, one seemingly versed in the teachings of a much higher power, for $30,683,372.50 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Ignacio Mattos Shares a Few of His Favorite Things
description: In the originality of his cooking, Ignacio Mattos manages to be both a chefs chef  as evidenced by the precise technical execution required for many of his best dishes  and a populist who delivers bold yet comforting flavors. Mattoss biography doesnt do justice to the playfulness, inventiveness, technical skill and earthy appeal of his food, but does provide a little context: He was born and began his career in Uruguay, moved to San Francisco to work at legendary restaurants (and de facto cooking academies) Chez Panisse and Zuni Caf, and then relocated to New York to establish himself at Il Buco.

title: Indictment of David Wildstein
description: The former Port Authority official and a high school friend of Gov. Chris Christie was indicted on two conspiracy counts. He pleaded guilty.

title: Chuck Close and Cindy Sherman Donate Works for Met Opera Benefit
description: It is a little like a bake sale, but one that offers works by famous artists instead of snickerdoodles. The Metropolitan Opera, which has been struggling financially in recent years, announced Friday that 14 major visual artists  including Chuck Close, William Kentridge and Cindy Sherman  have donated artworks for the company to sell to raise money.

title: Andreessen Horowitz, Deal Maker to the Stars of Silicon Valley
description: Since its founding in 2009, Andreessen Horowitz has become a top Silicon Valley venture capital firm by adhering to a simple mantra: Its all about the talent.

title: New Oil Train Rules Are Hit From All Sides
description: Ending months of uncertainty and delays, federal regulators on Friday unveiled new rules for transporting crude oil by trains, saying the measures would improve rail safety and reduce the risks of a catastrophic event.

title: The Enduring Hunt for Personal Value
description: Why does Michael Phelps keep returning to a brutal training regimen in the pool, long after hes achieved every imaginable accolade as a swimmer? Why do men who have earned hundreds of millions of dollars, even billions, work relentlessly to earn even more, long after it could possibly make any material difference in their lives? Why does a substantial group of politicians with no remote chance of being elected president feel compelled to traverse the country campaigning 18 hours a day for more than two years?

title: What I Love | Sandra Brown
description: The author of Lethal and Mean Streak unwinds in a soothing space on the Upper West Side.

title: For Sandra Brown, Suspense Writer, an Island of Calm
description: Sandra Brown wasnt thrilled with the white protea, but there it was, part of a standing order of floral arrangements that fill her Upper West Side pied--terre whenever she and her husband, Michael, come north from their Texas home. Youll find flowers in every room there, as well.

title: Sorry, Etsy. That Handmade Scarf Wont Save the World.
description: IN her memoir, Loretta Lynn: Coal Miners Daughter, Ms. Lynn remembers the thrill of receiving her first store-boughten dress from a social services agent when she was around 7. It was blue with pink flowers and dainty little pockets.

title: Mark Ronsons Hit Uptown Funk Adds Five Writers
description: Mark Ronsons song Uptown Funk has been the biggest pop hit of the year, logging 14 weeks at No. 1 with a sound that evokes 1970s and 80s acts like the Time and Cameo.

title: The End of California?
description: ANGELS CAMP, Calif.  IN a normal year, no one in California looks twice at a neighbors lawn, that mane of bluegrass thriving in a sun-blasted desert. Or casts a scornful gaze at a fresh-planted almond grove, saplings that now stand accused of future water crimes. Or wonders why your car is conspicuously clean, or whether a fish deserves to live when a cherry tree will die.

title: Review: A New-Music Concert by the Orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble
description: Reductio ad absurdum! Thomas Buckner pronounced, in stentorian voice, at one point in AACM50, a momentous new-music concert on Wednesday night at the Bohemian National Hall. It was just one of many lines of text, most of them sung, in the premiere of Kingmaker, by Roscoe Mitchell. But the phrase  best known as a rhetorical device  bore sly implications for the piece, composed for baritone (Mr. Buckner), saxophone (Mr. Mitchell), orchestra and choir.

title: Nepals Helter-Skelter Urbanization and Lax Enforcement Contribute to Quakes Toll
description: Many structures that collapsed in Katmandu were part of a reckless building boom in recent decades, aided by government indifference and corruption.

title: More Excuses on the Patriot Act
description: Software designers have a term  minimal viable product  to describe early versions of things like iPhone apps that they can rush to market. The idea is to get something out and refine it as they go along. Thats the argument being made for a measure in Congress that would modify the Patriot Act to make it somewhat harder for the government to conduct mass surveillance of Americans without regard to whether they committed any misdeeds.

title: At Long Last, a Kentucky Derby Only About the Horses
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  This is an altogether different Kentucky Derby. It hasnt been hijacked by bombastic owners. There has been no need to manufacture story lines. No, for the first time since I have been coming here, the horses are the genuine stars and there is a sense that the 141st running of Americas signature race is going to be one for the ages.

title: The Distinct Californication of Paris Photo L.A.
description: This weekend, the third edition of the art fair is expected to attract 20,000 people to the Paramount Pictures Studios in Hollywood.

title: Readers Respond On Unrest in Baltimore
description: Readers responded with compassion and anguish, but also a strong thread of criticism, to two op-ed articles following the death in police custody of 25-year-old Freddie Gray, and subsequent protests in Baltimore.

title: The Fall of the Cherry King
description: On his desk, Arthur Mondella kept jars of the glossy-red fruits, Dells Maraschino Cherries, that seemed to make everything else possible: the yacht, the Porsche and the Rolls-Royce, the Rolexes, his daughters tuitions, the loans  often forgiven  to the workers hed given second, third and fourth chances. On the wall, he had mounted a large television to keep watch over the business he had helped build since childhood.

title: UKIP Has Changed Britains Conversation. Now It Needs a Big Win.
description: RAMSGATE, England  As word spread that Nigel Farage was on his way for a stroll through this faded seaside town, tensions began to flare.

title: The Inevitable Spectacle of Mayweather vs. Pacquiao
description: Every once in a while, in these latter days since boxing receded from the cultural center, a fight temporarily reverses that history by catching the attention of the general public and becoming, as the TV announcers say, bigger than boxing. Then its not just that two boxers are going to fight. Its more like two celebrities are going to fight  Drake vs. Lionel Messi, say, or Angelina Jolie vs. Angela Merkel  and were in luck because the celebrities in question happen to be atavistically good with their hands. Intimate familiarity with the craft of fist fighting has declined steeply in America and other rich countries since the mid-20th century, but what the spectacle of boxing has lost in daily resonance it has partly gained back in the form of esoteric old-school cachet.

title: Video Reviews of Avengers: Age of Ultron, Iris and Welcome to Me
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Avengers: Age of Ultron, Iris and Welcome to Me. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Movie Review: Welcome to Me
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Welcome to Me.

title: Just Back From the Miss Dior Exhibition Opening, Kate Young Shares Her Sun-Searching Travels
description: While most New Yorkers have been lamenting the lack of sunshine, the stylist Kate Young has been chasing it around the world. She and her husband, Keith Abrahamsson, co-founder of the Greenpoint record label Mexican Summer, left their Brooklyn home to celebrate her birthday and their 10-year wedding anniversary in Puerto Rico. It was heaven, Young recalls. Easy to get there, amazing food, good surfing and beautiful rooms. They also spent some time at their house upstate in Ruby, N.Y., when the weather finally felt like spring. Our friends Kyle Creane and Gaines Peyton came for the weekend with their kids. We pretended we were camping and cooked over the bonfire and lazed around in hammocks. And then, for the Miss Dior exhibition that opened yesterday at the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, Young flew to Beijing with her friend Natalie Portman, the face of Miss Dior. We went to Shanghai last year  its really interesting to see the differences and similarities between the two cities, Young says. The Forbidden City is epic, and there are really beautiful parks. The pollution is mind-blowing, though, and Ive been wearing that mask almost constantly. Shes also been almost constantly wearing a pair of sunglasses from her spring/summer 2015 collection for Tura, which will be available later this month at shopbop.com ($250  $350). In the above slide show, she shares exclusively with T a diary of her recent travels.

title: Movie Review: Iris
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Iris.

title: U.S. Auto Sales Jumped in April, Again Led by S.U.V.s and Pickups
description: Auto manufacturers nearly across the board reported strong April sales gains in the United States, powered by the continued rise in sales of pickup trucks and crossover sport utility vehicles.

title: UKIP Leaders Candidacy Divides a Town
description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, visited Ramsgate, England, last week during his campaign for a seat in Parliament. He faces both strong support and opposition there.

title: Review: Avengers: Age of Ultron
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Avengers: Age of Ultron.

title: A Game 7: Spurs-Clippers Series Deserves Nothing Less
description: SAN ANTONIO  Doc Rivers had two large problems. Seconds into the fourth quarter at AT&T Center on Thursday night, Glen Davis of the Los Angeles Clippers sprained his left ankle and hopped several times on one leg in apparent agony before tumbling like an industrial-size sack of potatoes.

title: New Albums By Zac Brown Band and Tyler Farr
description: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss records from country dissenters and what, if anything, countrys borders mean anymore.

title: Cleveland Indians Have Home-Field Advantage on Recycling
description: CLEVELAND  Well before the start of a Cleveland Indians game at Progressive Field, as players warmed up on the jewel-green field, it was business as usual in the garage behind left field for C. L. Gholston, a dishwasher.

title: Marco Rubio Makes Generational Case for His Presidential Bid
description: WASHINGTON  One of the most devastating lines of Senator Marco Rubios presidential kickoff was an implicit rebuke of two of his potential rivals: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic candidate for president, and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Life of Saul Bellow
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Sam Tanenhaus reviews Zachary Leaders The Life of Saul Bellow: To Fame and Fortune, 1915-1964. Mr. Tanenhaus writes:

title: What an Android Update May Get You
description: Q. My old Nexus 7 tablet has a message saying I can update to Android 5.1. Will this fix the problems with sluggishness Ive been having with Android 5.0?

title: Austerity and British Inflation
description: Tony Yates responds to Simon Wren-Lewis with a sort-of kind-of defense of the turn to austerity in 2010; I want to weigh in briefly, then turn to a point he reminds me of.

title: Popcast: New Albums By Zac Brown Band and Tyler Farr
description: Its beginning to seem like the dissenters have squarely conquered the center of mainstream country. Artists who seemed outr and boundary-pushing a few years ago  Luke Bryan, Jason Aldean, Florida Georgia Line, and so on  are now the genres biggest stars, much to the chagrin of an earlier generation that still refuses to mix hip-hop into its country.

title: Style on the Gold Carpet
description: Some of the best looks from the first day of the N.F.L. draft Thursday night in Chicago.

title: At the N.F.L. Draft, Fashion Takes the Field
description: If Emily Blunts harried assistant in The Devil Wears Prada perfectly embodied fashions standard approach to looking ones best when she bragged about being just a stomach flu away from her goal weight, D. J. Humphries proves football has the opposite problem.

title: Jets Fans at N.F.L. Draft Find Less to Boo About in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  The Jets checkered history with first-round draft picks is no secret. Neither is their fans frustration, which usually manifests in a flurry of boos inside the draft hall each spring.

title: An Artisan Marketplace Celebrating the Spirit and Style of Topanga Canyon
description: Tucked deep in Topanga Canyon, Calif., high above a frog-filled creek, sits the small cabin the photographer Heather Culp calls home. Since moving to the neighborhood from Taos, N.M., almost two years ago, Culp has fully embraced the ethos long associated with Topangas stretch of winding highway. Hers is a warm, relaxed, salt-of-the-earth spirit that calls to mind small-town hospitality  a vibe thats very much at the core of her current work alongside artist and fellow Topanga dweller Carly Jo Morgan. This weekend, the two L.A. natives and New York expats roll out the second installment of their Mercado Sagrado, a market, music festival and experience-based art gathering taking place in the SoCal hills.

title: Nepals Fast Urbanization and Lax Enforcement Add to Quakes Toll
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Bikash Suwal, a lithe, tanned Nepali trekking guide, has climbed the 18,805-foot Yala Peak in the towering Himalayas. But since a powerful earthquake rocked Nepal a week ago, he has been afraid to climb the stairs to the rented rooms he shares with five family members.

title: President Obama on Freddie Gray Charges
description: The president commented on the filing of homicide, manslaughter and misconduct charges against police officers in the death of Mr. Gray.

title: It Dont GTMO Better Than This
description: Debi Cornwall took home a collection of bizarre souvenirs from her time photographing Guantnamo Bay.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are four-bedroom homes in Long Beach, N.Y., and Hopewell, N.J.

title: Enchiladas, Tostadas and Tacos
description: Lightness is not an attribute usually associated with enchiladas, the most comforting of Mexican tortilla foods, writes Martha Rose Shulman. But these enchiladas, filled with a mix of blanched seasoned chard and succulent diced chayote squash and covered with a classic cooked tomatillo salsa, are both light and incredibly satisfying.

title: Naomi Campbell on Screen, John Mayers Watch Watch and Bianca Jaggers Legendary Entrance
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Turkey Says, Were All Blonde
description: ISTANBUL  The United States ambassador to Turkey went blond this week in a post on Instagram that poked fun at the mayor of Ankara, Turkeys capital, who had made sexist remarks about an American government spokeswoman on Twitter, calling her a stupid blonde.

title: Who Is Teslas Home Battery For?
description: Late Thursday, Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, said the company will starting selling the batteries that are used in its luxury cars for use in homes and businesses. The home versions of the batteries, called Powerwall, will cost $3,000 for a 7 kilowatt-hour model and $3,500 for a 10 kilowatt-hour model.
