The company will sell larger batteries to businesses and utilities, which could use them to store power from solar panels, windmills and other sources during off-peak hours to use during peak hours.(Tesla says its prices do not include the cost of an inverter and installation.)

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include co-ops in Carnegie Hill and on the Upper West Side, and a townhouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: A Funeral, Protests, Riots and Rebuilding: Chronicling Unrest in Baltimore
description: Twenty-three years ago this week, as a young reporter for The Los Angeles Times, I covered the riots that devastated Los Angeles after a jury acquitted four police officers in the beating of Rodney King. After spending much of the last 10 days in Baltimore, I cant help wondering: Has nothing changed?

title: Bernie Sanders Has a Better Fund-Raising Start Than Republican Counterparts
description: The three Republican senators who are running for president  Ted Cruz, Rand Paul and Marco Rubio  all boasted about raising $1 million in their first 24 hours as candidates. But they have nothing on Bernie Sanders.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: At These Weddings, Forget the Rice, Bring Sneakers
description: At 7 a.m. one day last August, Paul Donnelly, Laura Oliver and 40 others ran a five-kilometer race. Later, they attended an awards ceremony and drank Gatorade. Then they showered, changed into dressy attire and went on to the days main event: the wedding of Mr. Donnelly and Ms. Oliver.

title: The Blue Boy
description: T contributing editor David Netto visits The Blue Boy, Thomas Gainsboroughs iconic 18th-century masterpiece, at the Huntington Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Six Officers Charged in Baltimore
description: The suspended police officers were charged in the death of Freddie Gray.

title: Munich Museum Is Another Step in Acknowledging the Citys Nazi Past
description: MUNICH  The Nazis first displayed their overt hunger for power in lock-step parades through Munichs elegant Knigsplatz. Today, against the backdrop of imposing neo-Classical buildings, the striking white form of the citys new Documentation Center for the History of National Socialism appears oddly misplaced. It is too simple, too clean.

title: The Search for New York Philharmonics Next Maestro
description: Early in 2001, during the final phase of the New York Philharmonics hapless, embarrassingly leaky three-year search to find a successor to Kurt Masur as music director, the players of the orchestra were granted unusual input into the deliberations. The discussions led to the appointment of Lorin Maazel, then 70, a last-minute candidate. In retrospect, there may have been drawbacks to giving the players so much say.

title: Big Day in Sports
description: It is simply the biggest sports Saturday in years.

title: La Sylphide Is Taking Flight at New York City Ballet
description: Yesssss! Peter Martins yelled with relish, as he pulled a scarf out of a caldron and brandished it overhead. Wipe the floor with him! Mr. Martins was enthusiastically demonstrating a moment in his new production of La Sylphide, when the witch Madge gives a poisoned scarf to the hero James. Two dancers, watching nearby, laughed. He is so enjoying this, one said to the other.

title: The Distinct Californication of Paris Photo L.A.
description: With nearly 200 art fairs on the international cultural calendar, its no surprise that art-world denizens have a case of fair fatigue. Paris Photo L.A., however, seems to have the cure for what ails them. Expecting 20,000 people for its third year at Paramount Pictures Studios in Hollywood this weekend, it is an art fair that feels like entertainment, with a location that strikes the magic balance between convention center and amusement park.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
description: United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Eve Risser, Van Hunt, Casey J and William Basinski Exceed Boundaries
description: Eve Risser

title: May 1, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, South Korea, Yemen and Burundi.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: With Bridge Case Charges, a Cloud Descends on Christies White House Hopes
description: In an era of maddeningly careful politics, Gov. Chris Christie rocketed to national stardom as brazenly incautious. His excesses defined him: the scorching rants, the seductive oversharing, the caustic insults and endless public feuds.

title: Chase Website Issue Said to Be Caused by Heavy Customer Use
description: Customers of JPMorgan Chases consumer bank were unable to log into their accounts online for several hours on Friday.

title: Strait of Hormuz Once Again at Center of U.S.-Iran Strife
description: The Strait of Hormuz, the slender waterway that connects the Persian Gulf to the rest of the world and is a critical conduit in the global oil supply chain, has again become a point of contention for Iran and the United States  just as they are trying to reach a nuclear accord.

title: Southern Californias Best-Kept Art Secret
description: Thomas Gainsboroughs 18th-century painting The Blue Boy is an iconic example of Grand Manner portraiture, and is considered an epitome of the form  instantly recognizable, it has been referenced in films from Ghostbusters II to Django Unchained. Perhaps surprisingly, given its stature as an English masterpiece, The Blue Boy  along with its sister painting, Thomas Lawrences Pinkie  resides in the Huntington Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif., home to the largest collection of British full-length Grand Manner portraiture in the world. When The Blue Boy was bought by Henry Huntington for over $700,000 in 1921, it was the most expensive painting ever sold  and its move to California sparked plenty of controversy. In the above video, the Huntingtons chief curator of European art, Catherine Hess, takes T contributing editor David Netto on a private visit to The Blue Boy and discusses its unique legacy.

title: American Dream? Or Mirage?
description: ECONOMIC inequality in the United States is at its highest level since the 1930s, yet most Americans remain relatively unconcerned with the issue. Why?

title: Rand Paul Says Comment About Baltimore Was Misinterpreted
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky drew widespread criticism this week for sounding indifferent and flip when he said that he was glad his train had not stopped in Baltimore as the city was erupting in racially fueled chaos.

title: Kindred Spirits, Five Years in the Making
description: When Stephanie Cate walked into Winston Bao Lords Georgetown home for a party five years ago, he had already been named to a People magazine list of the countrys up-and-coming men that included the actor Bradley Cooper. And Mr. Lord had been selected by The Washingtonian as one of the capitals most stylish men.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Loretta E. Lynch is finally sworn in, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visits Washington and another senator enters the presidential race.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
The Rise of Emoji on Instagram Is Causing Language Repercussions
description: At 30, I am still considered a millennial. Yet unlike many in my age group, for years I was stubborn about one very popular, unimportant activity: I disliked using emoji in my text messages.

title: Souvenirs From the Guantnamo Bay Gift Shops
description: Near the end of a recent visit to the Guantnamo Bay Naval Base, the photographer Debi Cornwall noticed some curious souvenirs in a gift shop. She bought them, took them home and photographed them. This project was considerably simpler than her previous one  which appeared on The Timess Lens blog last year  documenting the bases recreational spaces, which involved abiding by a 12-page list of things she couldnt photograph and submitting her memory cards to the scrutiny of military escorts. She even developed her film negatives under their watch.

title: Andre Kertesz, Watching From Above
description: From his window perch, Mr. Kertesz captured candid moments where his subjects were unaware the master photographer was watching them.

title: New Zealands Contribution to the Venice Biennale: A Library and an Airport, Transposed
description: I like that its hard to see  you have to show your passport to even get to the installation, says the artist Simon Denny of his pavilion representing New Zealand at this years Venice Biennale. I think that adds another layer to the clandestine world of contemporary intelligence. Denny is not referring to the intellectual world of contemporary art, but rather to intelligence with a capital I  the big data harvested by the N.S.A. and its international equivalents, which Dennys new work addresses.

title: A Final Column
description: It is tough to write ones final column. But I must pay particular tribute to Alan Truscott. We first met in 1971, when I was 19. Ceri Evans and I won a junior event in London for which the prize was a trip to New York to play in the Fun City Regional. Alan organized our tour, including arranging for us to be invited to a Long Island country club where all the local bridge experts were given the run of the club, then, after a huge buffet dinner, we played in a duplicate with a club member. (Evans and I finished second and third, causing a small stir.)

title: A.I.G. Considers How to Act With Sifi Tag
description: If there is a path leading out of the realm of systemically important financial institutions, the American International Group may already be on it, the insurers chief executive told securities analysts on Friday.

title: Oh, Those Clever Librarians and Their #Bookface
description: How complicated can it be to take a photograph of a book cover for the purpose of posting it on Instagram? Fairly complicated, particularly for those trying to create an image in what has become known as bookface style.

title: The End of Gaydar
description: In the wrong context, being asked if youre gay is like pulling back the shower curtain in the morning and finding a census taker scribbling frantically on his clipboard. You think: Why now? Why so close to my loofah?

title: Breakthrough Performances of the Summer Movies Season
description: The Diary of a Teenage Girl

title: Times Journalist Ellen Barry Answers Readers Questions on Nepal
description: Almost a week after an earthquake struck Nepal, killing more than 6,250 people and devastating villages, a rescue operation continues, and tens of thousands of people remain displaced in Katmandu alone. Ellen Barry, the South Asia bureau chief for The New York Times, recently spent five days reporting on the damage and loss of life there. She answered readers questions on Friday during a Facebook Q. and A. on the situation on the ground and how people can help.

title: Review: Penny Dreadful Returns for Season 2
description: Few actresses are more fun to watch than Eva Green when shes in her warrior-princess mode, and Showtimes Penny Dreadful takes full advantage of this fact. Playing an intrepid Victorian monster hunter who communes with the dead and is, inconveniently, semi-possessed by a nasty Egyptian goddess, Ms. Green throws her huge eyes open wide and writhes, jerks and gibbers with spine-tingling grace and gravity. If there were a factor that measured the convergence of sexy, scary, silly and self-aware on television, her performance would top the chart.

title: How Loaded Is the Word Thug? Readers React
description: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

title: Ally of Christie Pleads Guilty
description: The U.S. attorney for New Jersey announced the guilty plea of David Wildstein for conspiring to cause traffic jams around the George Washington Bridge. He also announced the indictment of two others.

title: I, Too, Am America Shares Snapshots From Workers Living on the Edge
description: You are not dressed if you dont have your smile on commands the sign in a Popeyes fried chicken restaurant in Kansas City, Mo. In front of it, a man in an apron, half-smiling, stands over the fryer with a basket of chicken in his tattooed hand.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: Trisha Brown: In Plain Site, on Spring Street
description: Trisha Brown, one of the founding figures of postmodern dance in the 1960s, choreographed her last work in 2011. Since then, the dance company that bears her name has found ways to keep her work before the public. In its latest project  Trisha Brown: In Plain Site  the troupe selects items from her multidecade repertory for specific locations; each of these events will be named for its setting.

title: Amid Katmandus Earthquake Wreckage, Hints of a Shift to Safer Construction
description: In the worlds crowded earthquake zones, from the Himalayas to the Pacific Northwest, every community faces enormous challenges in designing for inevitable, but unpredictable jolts.

title: Los Angeles and Its Booming Creative Class Lures New Yorkers
description: It started with Instagram. Or maybe it ended with Instagram. Last fall, Christina Turner, a fashion stylist in Brooklyn, was dreading another New York winter in her cramped, lightless Greenpoint, Brooklyn, apartment while gazing longingly at the succulent gardens and festive backyard dinner parties posted on social media by her friends in Los Angeles.

title: Foreign Diplomats Try to Track Down the Missing in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  The thousands of foreigners who were in Nepal when the earthquake struck have mostly been found, but hollow-eyed diplomats here still clutch lengthy lists of the names of those who remain unaccounted for.

title: Its Me or the Dog
description: The night my girlfriend discovered she wouldnt be my only bedfellow, she was baffled. Where I come from, you only sleep with a dog in your bed if youre single, or your central heating is broken, she said upon finding Whisky, my 15-pound terrier-spaniel mix, settled in comfortably for the night, her head resting daintily on my pillow.

title: Review: City Ballets New Gods and Duos
description: Adrian Danchig-Waring, who made his debut as Apollo on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater, didnt need to be told he had big slippers to fill. The two Apollos of recent seasons at New York City Ballet have been superlative: In Robert Fairchild, there is a raw, athletic exuberance and in Chase Finlay, a cool, unassailable polish. With both unavailable  Mr. Fairchild is performing on Broadway in An American in Paris, and Mr. Finlay is recovering from an injury  two new dancers are getting a shot at the lead in George Balanchines Apollo, the oldest work in the companys repertory. (On Tuesday, Zachary Catazaro takes over.)

title: Women Turn Tables on Online Harassers
description: About 24 hours after joining Tinder, Ashley Brincefield, 31, a management specialist for customs in Port Tobacco, Md., began getting creepy messages. Married men propositioned her for sex. Guys lashed out if they didnt get a reply in a timely fashion. Various men sent naked selfies.

title: Making Room (on the Web) for Daddy
description: A few years ago, when Avi Moskowitz wanted advice about which highchair, stroller and car seat to buy for his first child, he didnt turn to Consumer Reports or let his wife handle the research. He posted on Daddit, a part of the social networking site Reddit that was formed in 2011 to meet the growing demand of fathers seeking their own cozy corner of the web.

title: Why Were Honoring Charlie Hebdo
description: AN organization that champions dissidents must embrace dissent in its ranks. Over the last week, PEN American Center has been criticized by many writers, including some of our members, over our decision to present our PEN/Toni and James C. Goodale Free Expression Courage Award to Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical magazine that was the target of a murderous attack in January. The heated debate proves the relevance of groups devoted to freedom of expression. It also demonstrates that in an open society, well-intentioned people with shared values can interpret and weigh principles differently.

title: Theres No Easy Way to Get Inside Alicia Vikanders Head
description: With her dainty features eerily detached from her silicone skull, Alicia Vikander, as Ava, the alluring fembot in the sci-fi fantasy Ex Machina, is a wonder of radical engineering. So it may have been apt, if not downright predictable, that during her stay in New York last week she would visit an exhibition of experimental design at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Women in Military Cite Retaliation After Assault Complaints
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly two-thirds of women in the military who filed sexual assault complaints last year said they faced retaliation, according to a Pentagon report released on Friday.

title: The Psychologists and the Torturers
description: To the Editor:

title: Vows | Song and Support
description: Dr. Linda Marie Daniels and Dr. Lisa Lynn Paine initially bonded while trying to impersonate James Brown and Luciano Pavarotti, and that bond has strengthened over an appreciation for serving others.

title: Hundreds Protest in Manhattan Against Police Brutality and Income Inequality
description: Protesters marched in the streets of New York City on Friday night to bring attention to police brutality and income inequality, two days after dozens of demonstrators were arrested.

title: A Shared Act and a Common Purpose
description: One evening in January 2010, Lisa Lynn Paine believed she had found the perfect person to be the James Brown to her Luciano Pavarotti.

title: Laszlo Jakab Orsos, Cultural Curator, and His Sunday Routine
description: You know that tender melancholy that seeps unbidden into the last hours of the weekend? Yes, you do. Laszlo Jakab Orsos, director of the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, was trying to put his finger on it the other day. There is this unspoken sense that behind the walls everyone is preparing for the ordeal of the next week, he said, from his apartment in Brooklyn Heights. You feel that anxiety somehow. Best-case scenario is when youre home with a nice red wine, listening to music, and then a friend calls and you talk about life. The festival comes to New York May 4 through 10, and Mr. Orsos, who is either 50 or 51 (thats a larger philosophical question, he said), will be responsible for herding more than 100 writers and artists from around the world. After which a little swoony melancholy and red wine might not seem so bad.

title: Clinton Loyalist Joins Priorities Super PAC
description: A longtime leading operative for Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton will join Priorities USA Action, the dominant super PAC that will seek big-ticket donations to finance what is expected to be the long and expensive presidential campaign of Mrs. Clinton.

title: 30th Street Guitars, a Shop of Good Vibrations
description: To the uninitiated, the anonymous blocks surrounding Pennsylvania Station might seem an odd place for a quirky music shop like 30th Street Guitars.

title: Guitars Galore
description: When Matt Brewster opened 30th Street Guitars in Midtown Manhattan, he envisioned a friendly, low-key sales and repair shop without snobbery and pretense.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashion and Art
description: The fashion world could use the energy displayed during the 10-day preview of the new Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Fashion and Art at the New Whitney Museum
description: The fashion world could use the energy displayed during the 10-day preview of the new Whitney Museum of American Art on the West Side below 14th Street. Many guests exhibited an uncorraled style of dress. The building, with its vistas and terraces overlooking the city, is a revelation.

title: A Psychiatric Centers Art Gallery
description: Two good reasons to visit Queens Village are the Living Museum, featuring work mostly by the Creedmoor hospitals outpatients, and Rajdhani, an Indian restaurant.

title: Evening Hours | Benefits and a Memorial
description: Remembering John B. Fairchild, a fashion pioneer.

title: The Living Museum, on the Creedmoor Campus in Queens, Puts Patients Work on Display
description: The rambling campus of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, where Lou Reed was treated and Woody Guthrie died, is home to an unbridled collection of contemporary art, though finding it among the nearly century-old buildings takes some mettle. Once you enter the gates at 80-45 Winchester Boulevard, ask someone to direct you to a faded-brick edifice framed by beribboned trees and ghostly white sculptures.

title: Mexican Helicopter Shot Down, Killing 3 Soldiers
description: MEXICO CITY  A Mexican military helicopter was shot down Friday in southwestern Mexico, killing three soldiers and wounding several others during an outbreak of violence in the region that left banks and gas stations ablaze and residents hunkering indoors, military and regional officials said.

title: Parting for Womens World Cup, but Hopefully Not for Good
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  This is an exciting year for womens soccer, especially in the United States. While everyone awaits the Womens World Cup in Canada this summer, it is also Year 3 of the National Womens Soccer League.

title: Tidal, Music Streaming Service, Seeks Footing After a Stumble
description: As a celebrity-studded, headline-grabbing product release, Jay Zs unveiling of Tidal was about as big as could be.

title: Giants Move Up in N.F.L. Draft to Take Alabama Safety Landon Collins
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A prized football recruit in high school and an all-American safety at Alabama, Landon Collins always dreamed of being a first-round selection in the N.F.L. draft. Collins attended the N.F.L.s nationally broadcast first-round extravaganza on Thursday, eager to leap on the stage when his name was called.

title: Silent Seashores
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  AS the spring days lengthen, shorebirds have begun their hemispheric migrations from South America to nesting grounds in Canadas northern spruce and pine forests and the icy Arctic.

title: Dean Skelos, New York Senate Leader, and His Son Are Said to Face Arrest Next Week
description: Dean G. Skelos, the leader of the New York State Senate, and his son are expected to be arrested on federal corruption charges next week, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Responding to Suffering by Counting the Omer
description: PHILADELPHIA  One morning last week, Lance Laver went to visit a dying friend. Mr. Laver is Jewish and his friend is a retired Episcopal priest, and they had formed a bond over nearly a decade of working together here on an annual interfaith walk for peace.

title: A Secret Warrior Leaves the Pentagon as Quietly as He Entered
description: WASHINGTON  ASKED what he is looking forward to, Michael G. Vickers, who retired this week as under secretary of defense for intelligence, answered without hesitation: Sleeping.

title: Enlisting Bystanders to Fight Online Abuse
description: Harassment remains a big problem on social networks; according to a Pew survey, 40 percent of Internet users have experienced it in some form.

title: A New Jet Once Wished He Were Smaller. Now Opponents Do.
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  One of the seminal moments of Leonard Williamss life occurred when he was 13.

title: U.S. Liable in New Orleans-Area Flooding
description: The federal government must pay for some of the flooding damage from Hurricane Katrina caused by failures of the hurricane protection system in the New Orleans area, a judge ruled Friday.

title: Russia Assails West Over Yemen
description: In an outburst of diplomatic finger-pointing, Russia on Friday blamed the West for blocking a Security Council statement that sought humanitarian pauses in the Saudi-led airstrikes on Yemen to allow the delivery of food, fuel and medicine. Emerging from an emergency session of the Council, the Russian ambassador, Vitaly I. Churkin, said Yemen was running out of food and medicine and sharply suggested that the United States, which supports the bombings, is responsible for their humanitarian consequences. Russia had proposed a statement that would be unenforceable, and not legally binding. If you cant agree to a motherhood and apple pie statement, what can you agree on? he said. The criticism was in sharp contrast to Russias response to efforts by Western countries over the last couple of years to force the Syrian government, which Russia supports, to allow aid convoys into rebel-held areas. In a statement, an American official said Washington supported the idea of a humanitarian pause and was working with its Saudi allies to facilitate the delivery of aid.

title: Baltimores Mood Shifts From Grim to Elated After Charges Are Announced
description: BALTIMORE  The crowd of African-American residents and activists pooled around Marilyn J. Mosby, the states attorney in Baltimore, expecting disappointment. But as she announced that charges would be filed against all six officers involved in the arrest of Freddie Gray, jubilation and shock rippled from one cluster of friends to another.

title: Pedro Martinez Tells His Story
description: The transformation of Pedro Martinez  from ferocious competitor to baseball sage  is now complete. In the last few months, Martinez, the former star pitcher for the Boston Red Sox and four other teams, has analyzed the postseason for TBS, been elected to the Hall of Fame on his first try, joined MLB Network and, this week, become an author. The intellect behind the fire is on regular display.

title: Walking a Fine Line in Promoting a Trade Deal
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama defends the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a far-reaching agreement to tear down trade barriers between the United States and 11 other nations, he often argues it would cure the ills inflicted on American workers by trade pacts of the past, particularly the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Live From the Morgue: Reporters Notebook
description: HOUSTON  I remember being in a journalism class at Fresno State University in central California as everyone sat in silence, stumped. The professor had asked us the simplest of questions.

title: Hillary Clinton Courts the Democratic Left, but Is Pressured to Take Progressive Stands
description: WASHINGTON  Months before Hillary Rodham Clinton started delivering Democratic primary voters a liberal-minded message about a stacked deck in favor of the wealthy and the need for criminal-justice reform, she met quietly at Esca, a Mario Batali restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, with four powerful labor leaders.

title: Friday Night Music: Lone Bellow, Angel from Montgomery
description: You know how sometimes you find yourself watching and listening to a clip over and over, because it does something for your soul?

title: Reviews: Works by Rebecca Davis and Milka Djordjevich, and Lyon Opera Ballet
description: Bloowst Windku

title: Eat, Drink and Be Merry, Like the French?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Battle for Eyes Is Waged via New N.F.L. Players Ears
description: CHICAGO  It was a moment that all company executives crave: a celebrity wearing their product on prime-time television.

title: Officers Facing Charges Find Themselves on an Unfamiliar Side of the Law
description: BALTIMORE  The six suspended Baltimore police officers charged Friday in the death of Freddie Gray are a mix of veterans and recent recruits, of varying ranks and assignments. Three of them are black and three of them are white.

title: Rolf Smedvig, Trumpeter in the Empire Brass, Dies at 62
description: Rolf Smedvig, a virtuoso classical trumpeter who helped found the Empire Brass, a renowned quintet whose repertory extends from the Renaissance to the Jazz Age, died on April 27 at his home in West Stockbridge, Mass. He was 62.

title: Report of an Inquiry Into a Former President Rattles Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils political establishment was shaken on Friday by the news that federal prosecutors had opened an influence-peddling inquiry into the business activities of Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the former president who presided over Brazils emergence this century as a leading power in the developing world.

title: Lounge Performer, Nearing 100, Has 88 Keys to the Good Life
description: On a recent Sunday, as a mother and her son ate brunch at the upscale Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan, they did a double take to stare at an older gentleman playing spirited lounge-style piano to the otherwise empty dining room.

title: A Bills Surveillance Limits
description: Bipartisan legislation passed by the House Judiciary Committee would reauthorize mass surveillance programs revealed by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, but impose new limits on them. Although it does not limit the governments authority to collect information overseas, including data on telephone and email records, if passed the bill would:

title: Why the N.S.A. Isnt Howling Over Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON  For years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, even as the National Security Agency fiercely defended its secret efforts to sweep up domestic telephone data, there were doubters inside the agency who considered the program wildly expensive with few successes to show for it.

title: Clash Over Frozen Embryos
description: To the Editor:

title: A Path to Citizenship for Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Money for the National Institutes of Health
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Indictment Details Plotting in New Jersey Bridge Scandal
description: Bill Baroni, Bridget Anne Kelly and David Wildstein waited for the first day of school.

title: Suspect Is Identified and Arrested in a Manhattan Rape From 1995 After a DNA Match
description: A man trailed a 25-year-old woman from a movie theater in the West Village and then forced her at knife point into the vestibule of a nearby building. He raped and robbed her and then vanished, court papers say. But doctors at the hospital she ran to collected the assailants DNA.

title: Alex Rodriguez ofYankees Ties Willie Mays With 660th Home Run
description: Alex Rodriguez, the Yankees lightning rod slugger, hit his 660th home run at Fenway Park on Friday night, tying him with Willie Mays for fourth on baseballs career home run list.

title: Where Chamorro is Spoken
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Rules are made to be broken. If this puzzle by Barry C. Silk had a theme, thats pretty much what it would be.

title: William Pfaff, Critic of American Foreign Policy, Dies at 86
description: PARIS  William Pfaff, an international affairs columnist and author who was a prominent critic of American foreign policy, finding Washingtons intervention in world affairs often misguided, died on Thursday in a hospital here. He was 86.

title: Marty Napoleon, 93, Dies; Jazz Pianist Played With Louis Armstrong
description: Marty Napoleon, a jazz pianist best known for his many years with Louis Armstrong, died on April 27 in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 93.

title: Bernie Sanders Yells His Mind
description: Our topic today is: Bernie Sanders for president?

title: After 660, There Are Bigger Numbers in Sight
description: So Alex Rodriguez has now hit 660 home runs, as many as the great Willie Mays and a total surpassed by only Barry Bonds, Hank Aaron and Babe Ruth. Rodriguez was supposed to get a $6 million bonus from the Yankees for this, but now he may not. An arbitrator may well decide.

title: Governor Christies People
description: No matter how Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spins the George Washington Bridge scandal as he eyes a run for president, one thing should be clear: These are his people, charged with a conspiracy to exact revenge against a local mayor by closing lanes to one of the worlds busiest bridges.

title: Louis Armstrong, the Real Ambassador
description: March marked the 50th anniversary of Louis Armstrongs historic tour behind the Iron Curtain, as the Soviet bloc was then called. The second stop on the tour was East Berlin, where, on March 22, 1965, he and his All Stars played a memorable two-hour concert. The concert was broadcast on German television and radio; a few years ago, a condensed version found its way to YouTube. More recently, the Louis Armstrong House Museum got ahold of the entire thing, and on Thursday, it held a screening at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens.

title: Hawks Eliminate Nets in Game 6
description: The last big Barclays Center cheer of the 2014-15 season occurred between the third and fourth quarters on Friday night, when the Nets troupe of older dancers, the NETSational seniors, joined forces with their adolescent counterparts, the Brooklyn Nets Kids, to perform a spirited number at midcourt.

title: On a Stage for High Drama, Alex Rodriguez Belts No. 660
description: Fenway Park is the site of so much history for Alex Rodriguez, a polarizing figure in baseball but an especially antagonistic one here.

title: Edward Chambers, Early Leader in Community Organizing, Dies at 85
description: Edward T. Chambers, a lapsed seminarian who succeeded Saul Alinsky as leader of Mr. Alinskys social justice foundation, advancing his radical agenda of community organizing and grounding its progressive objectives in the Gospels, died on April 26 at a nursing home near his home in Drimoleague, Ireland. He was 85.

title: Floyd Mayweather Jr., a Champion in the Ring, Is Something Very Different Out of It
description: LAS VEGAS  Boxing is admirable in its primal beauty. The best fighters are ferocious athletes, tacticians with the endurance of marathon runners.

title: Miuccias Museum Opens
description: The Fondazione Prada  the art branch of the legendary fashion house  opens the doors to its first permanent exhibition space in Milan this month. Housed in a converted 1910s distillery reimagined by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, the 10-building complex will feature the work of the American artist Robert Gober, the cheeky Surrealist best known for manipulating everyday objects: warped bathroom sinks without faucets or drains, disembodied wax-colored legs with real hair. A selection of Gobers new and old works occupies the top three floors of the Haunted House, now clad in 24-karat gold leaf.

title: Alex Rodriguez Speaks of His Regrets (a Few) and Willie Mays (the Greatest Ever)
description: BOSTON  Hours before he matched Willie Mayss career home run total with a laser into the seats above the Green Monster on Friday, Alex Rodriguez tried to distinguish himself from the Hall of Famer in his sights.

title: Emphasis in N.F.L. Draft Is on Passing Game and Defending It
description: CHICAGO  The fireworks of the first night of the N.F.L. draft, with its red-carpet treatment for top prospects and a prime-time television audience, gave way to the more mundane rhythms of wheeling and dealing.

title: Matt Harvey Leads the Mets to a Bounce-Back Win Over the Nationals
description: Giving a professional athlete a nickname can be a fruitless endeavor if it is done hastily or without any serious thought. Only the ones that speak to an athletes character or persona ever seem to stick. And it helps if the name plays off pop culture.

title: Lovely Maria Wins Kentucky Oaks
description: Lovely Maria won the 141st Kentucky Oaks by two and three-quarter lengths against Shook Up at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., in an emotional finish for Kerwin Clark, her 56-year-old jockey, and Larry Jones, her trainer, who nearly lost his life in a riding accident last April.

title: Umberto D., a Triumph of Neorealism
description: Italy was adrift and in flux right after World War II, and the neorealism brand of filmmaking was a result. Directors focused on upheaval and economic hardship, generally using nonprofessional actors. A classic of the genre, Vittorio De Sicas Umberto D., is being shown Friday at 7 p.m. at the New-York Historical Society as part of a series called Justice in Film.

title: Going From Broadway to Racings Biggest Stage
description: Inside a Manhattan office, perched high above Broadway, two passions intersect.

title: Report Shows Mixed Picture for Mets Finances
description: With a 16-8 start, the Mets are hoping to make their fans forget about their dismal recent history and look toward a future filled with postseason appearances. Sure, they have lost four of their last six, but they are still in first place in the National League East.

title: Rory McIlroy Escapes Elimination at World Golf Championships
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The World Golf Championships match-play event was tweaked this year to guard against the early exits of marquee players. The single-elimination format was replaced by round-robin play, which guaranteed that each player in the 64-man field would be around for at least three matches.

title: Rangers Try to Match Toughness of Capitals
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The physical tone adopted by the Washington Capitals against the Islanders in the first round of the playoffs has continued against the Rangers in the second.

title: Joel Wards Rare Feat for the Capitals
description: The Washington Capitals Joel Ward scored with 1.3 seconds left on Thursday night to win Game 1 against the Rangers, his third career game-winning goal in the playoffs. He most memorably netted the winner in overtime of Game 7 against the Boston Bruins in 2012. According to Elias Sports Bureau, Thursday was the third time a winning goal had been scored in the final two seconds of an N.H.L. playoff game.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) DRAFT DAY (2014) Sonny Weaver Jr. (Kevin Costner), the beleaguered general manager of the Cleveland Browns, tries to rebuild his flailing team by choosing from among a Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback (Josh Pence), a gold-hearted linebacker (Chadwick Boseman) and a troubled but gifted running back (Arian Foster) at the N.F.L. draft. But first theres some wheeling and dealing to be done. Frank Langella plays the Browns imperious owner; Denis Leary is their bellicose coach; and Jennifer Garner is the executive in charge of salaries  and of Sonnys affections. Mr. Costner handles it all with his usual gruff grace, allowing you to entertain the possibility that he might be a jerk or a loser just long enough to be gratified when he turns out to be a great guy in every way, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Ivan Reitman film. He has a knack for making born winners look like underdogs, and for making you root for him at his most brazenly manipulative. I dont really buy Draft Day  its a shallow and evasive movie, built more around corporate wish fulfillment than around reality  but I have to say that it sells itself beautifully.

title: Alex Rodriguez: A Continual Stir
description: From when Alex Rodriguez broke into the majors in 1996 to his retirement in 2016, he has been unable to escape the bizarre and controversial stories that seem to follow him on and off the field.

title: Opposite Styles Attract; Ability to Adapt Is the Key
description: LAS VEGAS  The playbook on fighting Floyd Mayweather Jr. usually goes something like this: Apply relentless pressure. Throw combinations. Cut off the ring. Make him fight every minute of every round.

title: Corrections: May 2, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: For years and years, victims of police violence in our city, overwhelmingly black people, have sought justice for their loved ones to no avail. This is an historic moment.

title: City Ballet
description: Ashley Bouder, Taylor Stanley and members of New York City Ballet in Square Dance. Choreography by George Balanchine/George Balanchine Trust

title: Lovely Maria Wins Kentucky Oaks, Capping Comeback for Injured Trainer
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Lovely Maria won the 141st Kentucky Oaks by two and three-quarters lengths against Shook Up on Friday at Churchill Downs in an emotional finish for Kerwin Clark, her 56-year-old jockey, and Larry Jones, the fillys trainer, who nearly lost his life in a riding accident in April 2014.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from an abandoned stable in the Bronx to the aftermath of the earthquake in Katmandu.

title: Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, Gives Birth to Baby Girl
description: LONDON  Lo, and it came to pass at last on Saturday morning, unto Kate, who was late, a child was born  a baby girl, who will be fourth in line to the British throne.

title: After Thousands Rally in Baltimore, Police Make Some Arrests as Curfew Takes Hold
description: BALTIMORE  This beleaguered city took on a festive, almost celebratory feel Saturday as thousands of people of all ages and races rallied peacefully in front of City Hall to call for an end to police mistreatment of black men, but also an end to the curfew imposed by Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake amid riots set off by the death of Freddie Gray, who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody.

title: Poverty Policy Truths
description: Last year was the 50th anniversary of the War on Poverty, and the date provoked a flurry of studies correcting some widespread myths; perhaps most notable was an enlightening report from the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: The Most Exciting (Fill in the Blank) in Sports
description: They call the Kentucky Derby the most exciting two minutes in sports, and it is hard to argue. The gate opens, and after 120 seconds or so of thundering hooves in front of 150,000 fans, a horse and jockey have become immortal, while some bettors have won or lost a small fortune.

title: South Korean N.Y.U. Student Is Reported Arrested in North Korea
description: HONG KONG  North Korea said Saturday that a man it identified as a South Korean student at New York University had been arrested and charged with illegally entering the country.

title: When a Commercial Tenant Isnt Welcome
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: A Portrait of the Sandtown Neighborhood in Baltimore
description: Freddie Gray lived in Sandtown-Winchester, a crime-ridden Baltimore neighborhood that has been depressed for decades.

title: Baltimore Prosecutor Faces National History of Police Acquittals
description: With an unexpectedly speedy and sweeping announcement on Friday of charges against six police officers in the death of Freddie Gray, Baltimores chief prosecutor sent an unmistakable signal that the days when police misconduct drew a wrist slap are over.

title: Third Horse, International Star, Is Scratched From Kentucky Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Kentucky Derby lost its third starter in as many days when International Star, the Louisiana Derby winner, was scratched Saturday morning. According to the owner Ken Ramsey, the colt appears to have an abscess or bruise in his left front foot.

title: F.E.C. Cant Curb 2016 Election Abuse, Commission Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON  The leader of the Federal Election Commission, the agency charged with regulating the way political money is raised and spent, says she has largely given up hope of reining in abuses in the 2016 presidential campaign, which could generate a record $10 billion in spending.

title: Variety: A Hazy Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  When I was a young mother, one of the more alarming suggestions my parents gave me when The Girl developed a cold and was up screaming all night was to add some brandy to her bottle. The old school logic there was that it would make it easier for her to sleep, which would, in turn, help her healing process and, more importantly, help her exhausted mother get some sleep. I never took them up on the idea, but I have to say that, after doing this puzzle, their suggestion sounds fairly benign.

title: Star Lacrosse Players Move From Midfielder to Attacker Raises Her Profile, and Hofstras
description: On the first day of practice with her new team, Shannon Smith had an idea. Barely into her tenure as the womens lacrosse coach at Hofstra, Smith saw a sophomore midfielder with the athleticism and ability to have a greater impact. All she had to do was persuade the player, Brittain Altomare, that making a major change would make her a major player.

title: Hints of Normalcy in Katmandu, but Rebuilding Lies Ahead
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  After spending eight days living in a tent in this citys Tudikhel Park, Bikesh Karki and his family decided, like tens of thousands of others, to pack up and go home.

title: Yankees Say They Arent Obliged to Pay Alex Rodriguez $6 Million Bonus
description: BOSTON  A little more than 12 hours after Alex Rodriguez tied Willie Mays for fourth on baseballs career home run list, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made it clear that the team would not be paying him a bonus for doing so.

title: As Blackpool F.C.s Failures Grow, So Does Fans Displeasure
description: BLACKPOOL, England  Judge us at the end of the season, not now, Karl Oyston wrote to the supporters of Blackpool F.C. last August. A week before the season, Blackpool had only eight players on its books and no goalkeepers, and Oyston, the clubs embattled chairman, had some explaining to do.

title: That Two-Foot Putt? Nothing to Concede
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Bubba Watsons opponent was eyeballing a three-foot par putt on Wednesday, and Watson was eyeballing his caddie, Ted Scott. It was the opening day of the World Golf Championships match-play event at Harding Park and Watson, unsure if he should concede the putt to Miguel ngel Jimnez, asked Scott for his opinion.

title: Voice From Past Adds Its Timbre to Floyd Mayweather Jr.-Manny Pacquiao Fight
description: The world welterweight title bout on Saturday between Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. had two links to the storied boxing announcer Don Dunphy. His son Bob directed the joint HBO-Showtime pay-per-view broadcast. And HBOs Jim Lampley, who credits Dunphy with inspiring his ringside work, delivered the blow-by-blow call.

title: Reinvigorating The Chicago Defender, a Historic Print Voice
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr. held up a copy of The Chicago Defender, the citys storied black newspaper, its cover plastered with photos of two dozen black men killed by the police. The headline read, Wake Up: Theres No Justice for Black Men.

title: In Algeria, Entrepreneurs Hope Falling Oil Prices Will Spur Innovation
description: ALGIERS  Algeria, a country that depends on energy for 97 percent of its exports and two-thirds of its government revenue, is facing an economic crisis precipitated by the plunge in oil prices. And that is just fine with Toufik Lerari and Marhoun Rougab, entrepreneurs who see it as salvation for the rest of the Algerian economy.

title: The Performance Art of Rsums
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Making Machines Work
description: Sean Hopkins, 26, is a reliability engineer at the design and manufacturing company Dyson. He is based in Chicago.

title: Dave Goldberg, Half of a Silicon Valley Power Couple, Dies at 47
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dave Goldberg, the chief executive of SurveyMonkey and the husband of Sheryl K. Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, died on Friday night. He was 47.

title: Brooklyn Tenants Receive a Judgment in a Heating Dispute
description: On Jan. 25, the Metropolitan section published an article tracing the tortuous progress of an ordinary heating complaint in Brooklyn Housing Court. The case, involving two buildings in Crown Heights, was nothing complicated: There was a clear record of complaints to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, and of inspectors issuing citations for inadequate heat or hot water. Lawyers on both sides said that compared with other cases in Housing Court, this one was moving quickly. Translation: At the time of the article, it had been going on for more than a year.

title: Jonas Hiller, a Goalie for the Flames, Faces a Familiar Challenge
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Last April, goalie Jonas Hiller sat at his stall in the Anaheim Ducks dressing room, staring into the distance and breathing heavily, the loneliest man in a crowded room.

title: Mario Calmi, a Teaching Golf Pro, Makes Time to Fish and Eat Well
description: On Monday, Mario Calmi stood at the North Woodmere Golf Course driving range, where he is the head professional, and gripped the shaft, aimed and swung.

title: Spirit of the Skaters
description: The photographer Melissa Cacciola set out to capture skateboarders energy in a static way. The result is Flip It and Reverse It, a series of 35 portraits.

title: Highfliers, Sitting Still
description: Melissa Cacciola doesnt skateboard, but she has long marveled at the brash physicality of thrill-seekers hurtling themselves along New York City sidewalks, streaking through space and piercing the urban landscape on a board with wheels.

title: Baltimore Taught Me About Hope
description: GO ... go. Sonja  go!

title: Mathematicians and Blue Crabs
description: BALTIMORE  IN Tom Stoppards play Arcadia, the mathematician Valentine tries to predict how the grouse population on an estate changes from year to year. He does this by using old shooting records as data, under the assumption that the number of grouse killed annually is proportional to the size of that years population. His goal is to create a mathematical formula that takes any years population as input and gives the next years population as output.

title: From Hamlet to Hillary
description: IF Hillary Clinton goes the distance, she may have Shakespeare to thank.

title: What Black Moms Know
description: I FEEL sorry for the others. You know those mothers: the highly informed, professionally accomplished  usually white  women who, judging by the mommy blog fodder, daytime TV, and new parenting guides lining store shelves, are apparently panicking all day, every day, over modern child rearing and everything that comes with it. They feel compelled to praise their kids, but fret the dosage. They worry about pesticides; this years best birthday-party theme; enrichment summer camps; preparing Johnnie for college admissions in 2025 (its never too early); and, of course, the biggie  keeping their kids happy.

title: I Was Raised by Psychotherapists
description: Being the child of psychotherapists is no fun. For one thing, you are surrounded by books with titles like The Anatomy of Melancholy and Im OK  Youre OK. What other families call love is known in yours as attachment theory. You are both over-scrutinized by your parents and in competition for attention with their patients, whose problems are often more pressing (and always more lucrative). Your parents are paid to listen to other people cry. The only upside is that it is very easy to get your friends parents to feel sorry for you, and that their pity sometimes takes the form of free candy.

title: The Medical Bill Mystery
description: I CONFESS I filed this column several weeks late in large part because I had hoped first to figure out a medical bill whose serial iterations have been arriving monthly like clockwork for half a year.

title: Our Police Union Problem
description: FOR decades now, conservatives have pressed the case that public sector unions do not serve the common good.

title: What to Keep Secret in a Secret War
description: IF you were reading the two sentences by themselves, you might be surprised they appeared in the same newspaper.

title: Star-Crossed on a Hawaiian Mountaintop
description: Sometime in the 2020s, when an international consortium completes the Thirty Meter Telescope, the most powerful telescope on the planet, astronomers will gaze from the 14,000-foot summit of Mauna Kea volcano, on the Big Island of Hawaii, out to the edge of the observable universe.

title: After the Mayhem, Politics as Usual
description: Colorado is now reliving, in the trial of James Holmes, the 2012 shooting at a movie theater in Aurora in which a military-style assault rifle was used to murder 12 people and wound 70. Yet even in this painful moment, the new Republican majority in the State Senate seeks to repeal one of the gun safety laws enacted after the massacre.

title: Another Chance for Teens
description: THE conventional wisdom among social scientists is that theres little payoff in investing in troubled teenagers. As the University of Chicago economist James J. Heckman argued in 2011, we overinvest in attempting to remediate the problems of disadvantaged adolescents and underinvest in the early years of disadvantaged children, when the potential gains are supposedly the largest.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Stroke of Fate
description: EDGEWATER, Md.  THE thing thats easy to miss about Tara is how competitive she is.

title: Inequality Is a Choice
description: THE eruptions in Baltimore have been tied, in complex ways, to frustrations at American inequality, and a new measure of the economic gaps arrived earlier this year:

title: Stumbling Into a Wider War
description: It should come as no surprise that the United States and its coalition partners are discussing widening the war against the Islamic State beyond the borders of Iraq and Syria. Wider wars have become almost habitual in recent years, as military conflicts have expanded with little public awareness or debate. President George W. Bushs war on terror began in Afghanistan, then moved to Iraq and elsewhere. Fourteen years after the Sept. 11 attacks, President Obama is still deploying American troops and weapons to fight Al Qaeda and other extremists in far-flung parts of the world, including Pakistan.

title: Mark Petersen
description: Mark Petersen is chief of the United States Geological Surveys National Seismic Modeling Project, which forecasts where the earth is likely to shake because of natural or human activity such as fracking.

title: Divestment Campaigns
description: Should universities focus on sustainable investments rather than divestment?

title: Books on the History of the Police, the Landmarks Commission and the Waldorf Astoria
description: New Yorkers wary of overzealous policing and racial profiling might benefit from The NYPDs First Fifty Years: Politicians, Police Commissioners & Patrolmen (Potomac Books), which provides some welcome historical perspective on current events, as well as a de facto endorsement by the current commissioner of the Police Department, William J. Bratton, who wrote the books introduction.

title: How Not to Drown in Numbers
description: BIG data will save the world. How often have we heard that over the past couple of years? Were pretty sure both of us have said something similar dozens of times in the past few months.

title: Injured and Abandoned in Afghanistan
description: After years of war, many Afghan soldiers and policemen were grievously injured. But the pensions and health care they receive are often insufficient.

title: Its Not Just About Quality of Life
description: My patient had been having chest pains for several days before his heart stopped. Paramedics managed to revive him, but not before his lungs, kidneys and brain were severely damaged by the lack of blood flow. The prognosis was grim. A neurologist in the intensive care unit said the best possible outcome would be life in a persistent vegetative state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Disabled and Facing More Challenges in Afghanistan
description: Thousands who were disabled while fighting for the Afghan government are overwhelming the resources available.

title: Maimed Defending Afghanistan, Then Neglected
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  Saheb had a problem: His left leg had been blown off by a Taliban bomb and he could not afford a prosthesis. He also had a solution: His 11-year-old daughter, Noor Bibi, whom he sold last year for $3,000 to pay for a new leg. Saheb is among the tens of thousands of soldiers and policemen who have been wounded fighting for the government in the countrys long-running civil war. Faced with inadequate or nonexistent official support, many are resorting to desperate measures to survive.

title: British Media Endorsements in the 2015 Election
description: In the run-up to the general elections in Britain on May 7, several of the nations newspapers and magazines have issued endorsements of various political parties.

title: With Campaign Spending Limited, British Politicians Vie to Be Liked and Retweeted
description: LONDON  There is no political advertising on television or radio in Britain. Fund-raising and spending are strictly limited. Tight elections can turn on a relative handful of votes in a small number of competitive parliamentary constituencies.

title: Katmandu Residents Aim to Resume Life of Normalcy
description: One week after a severe earthquake, residents tried to resume some of their regular activities along with recovery and rebuilding efforts.

title: Many Songs, No Snooze for the Northern Mockingbird
description: The Northern mockingbird is elegant in its many shades of gray, its long tail and short, sharply marked wings, but it is every insomniacs worst nightmare.

title: Review: Rolling Out the Welcome Mat at Mishmish Restaurant in Montclair
description: Within minutes of sitting down at Mishmish, the new Mediterranean restaurant in Montclair, we were welcomed with a large plate of homemade vegetable pickles, warm focaccia and a dish of olive oil.

title: Rangers Get Just Enough to Beat the Capitals
description: The Rangers needed contributions from fresh sources against the Washington Capitals in a Game 2 Saturday matinee at Madison Square Garden.

title: Atlanta Hawks Sculptors Were Shaped by San Antonio Experiences
description: With some reluctance, and with his Atlanta Hawks scheduled to begin an N.B.A. playoff series against Washington on Sunday, Coach Mike Budenholzer conceded that he would sneak a look at Saturday nights biggest sports showdown.

title: Rachel Nichols and Michelle Beadle Say They Were Barred From Mayweather Jr.-Pacquiao Fight
description: LAS VEGAS  Two prominent female journalists, each of whom has detailed the domestic-violence history of Floyd Mayweather Jr., wrote on Twitter on Saturday morning that they had been denied credentials to the evenings fight between Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao.

title: Hard Earned Documents the Plight of the Working Poor
description: Last week I had one of those days where I woke up and just realized where I was at in life, Emilia Stancati says. Im 50 years old and tired of carrying trays and running and getting up at 4 oclock in the morning, and tired of always depending for my money on how other people feel about me. But when asked her dream, this Chicago waitress, who toils at two restaurants, responds, I just want weekends off.

title: Colum McCann Work Is Set in Motion
description: The Irish writer Colum McCann may be primarily a novelist, but he knows dance, too: His 2003 novel, Dancer, is a tasty fictionalized biography of Rudolf Nureyev and reveals a curiosity for, and attraction to, the artful ways of the body. Mr. McCann is credited with the libretto of Writing Ground, which receives its New York premiere this week when the San Francisco troupe Alonzo King Lines Ballet visits the Joyce (accompanied by a second New York premiere  Concerto for Two Violins). Mr. McCann traded prose for poetry to better suit dances ungraspability; his words will be printed in the program but arent spoken  the soundscape is a compilation of sacred chants from a rainbow of world religions. Since 1982, Mr. Kings company has practiced his distinct brand of balletic Neo-Classicism  fervent, fluid and bearing the marks of myriad cultures. Arriving from California, its liquid from a parched land. (Tuesday through next Sunday, 175 Eighth Avenue, 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

title: Tony Oursler Maps the Interior Life of the Face
description: What? Worry about boundaries?

title: The Eternal Road by Kurt Weill, Revisited at Carnegie Hall
description: Kurt Weills sweeping, rarely seen spectacle of Jewish history, The Eternal Road, gets a new lease on life in concert on Wednesday and Thursday at Carnegie Hall as The Road of Promise. Featuring the Collegiate Chorale, the performances star Ron Rifkin, Anthony Dean Griffey and Mark Delavan; Ted Sperling conducts. (8 p.m. Wednesday and 7 p.m. Thursday, 646-435-9465, collegiatechorale.org.)

title: Freddie Gray Rally Draws Large Crowds in Baltimore
description: Thousands of people attended a rally and hundreds marched in the wake of the death of Freddie Gray from injuries he suffered while in police custody.

title: At 26, the Mets Juan Lagares Appears to Be on the Fast Track to Stardom
description: In the corner of Juan Lagaress locker hangs a pair of gold-colored boxing gloves. The Mets presented them to Lagares during a team meeting in spring training, a gesture after he won the Gold Glove award last year.

title: The Jets New Man Seems to Have a Plan
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Beyond their personalities and pedigrees, there seems to be another significant difference between Mike Maccagnan and his predecessor as the Jets general manager, John Idzik.

title: Dave Isay of StoryCorps: A Place to Collect Stories, Not Admire the View
description: Staying focused

title: Review: A Zany Version of the Romance Ernest Shackleton Loves Me in New Brunswick
description: Wildly quirky in its contemporary style and tone, Ernest Shackleton Loves Me is an intrepid new musical at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Inspired by a true story and set within the frame of a fantastical romance, the musical relates one of the most amazing exploits of the last century. This year marks the centennial of the real-life, nearly two-year adventure, that involved a thwarted expedition, a ship wrecked by ice and an indomitable hero, Ernest Shackleton.

title: Churchill Downs Bolsters Its Hospitality After a High-Profile Criticism
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  As the owners of the Kentucky Derby contenders picked at a buffet, sipped on cocktails and placed bets from their seats in the shadow of the winners circle, the people responsible for the enhanced hospitality were nowhere to be found.

title: Maya Plisetskaya, Ballerina Who Embodied Bolshoi, Dies at 89
description: MOSCOW  Maya Plisetskaya, one of the greatest ballerinas of the 20th century and virtually the embodiment of the Bolshoi Theater for decades, died on Saturday in Munich. She was 89.

title: The Rotation, an Unexpected Strength, Lifts the Yankees Over the Red Sox
description: BOSTON  After watching Dellin Betances strike out all four batters he faced to close out the Yankees 4-2 victory Saturday over the Boston Red Sox, catcher Brian McCann was asked a simple question:

title: Giants Top Pick,Ereck Flowers, Brings One-Man Support Team: His Father
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Ereck Flowers, the Giants 2015 first-round draft pick, arrived for his first news conference with New York-area reporters Saturday morning and stepped onto an auditorium stage.

title: Leave the Laptop at Home
description: Bradleys is a bakery and cafe, but describing it as such is like describing Carnegie Hall as merely an auditorium.

title: Livestock Farming Is Changing Agriculture on Long Island
description: It was early spring at 8 Hands Farm in Cutchogue and a dozen baby lambs capered about in the barn they shared with ewes, rams, a litter of Tamworth pigs and a chicken named Bitty. Although the adjacent fields were still frosty and fallow, the flock of about 145 Icelandic sheep, a heritage breed prized for its fleece, milk and meat, would soon be grazing on the green pasture of the 28-acre farm.

title: Improvisations Concert Series Unites Subversive Musicians
description: Joe Morris makes no apologies for his anarchic streak. The New Haven-born guitarist and bassist has, during the four decades in which he has toiled in the minefields of avant-garde music, purposely tripped a wire or two, challenging concepts widely associated with the music, prime among them free improvisation.

title: Katonah Museum of Art Celebrates Its Anniversary, Its Architect and Its Town
description: Its hard not to feel flummoxed by Studio Unhinged, a massive, site-specific installation by the artist Chris Larson at the Katonah Museum of Art. In a wonky conglomeration of rough-hewn chambers, corridors lead nowhere, fluorescent lights flicker and floors become walls. (Or are the walls actually floors?) Visitors who stand at a particular corner will find a wooden staircase leading down to a littered work space and simultaneously, impossibly, up to an adjacent room.

title: Non-Starters
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  We have a letter deletion theme today, and I will admit to a certain amount of fondness for these, because Ive made them in the past. Theyre probably one of the easier types of themes to develop, and theyre fun.

title: Christies Camp Mobilizes to Salvage White House Hopes
description: Around 7:30 a.m., as an audience of technology executives started streaming through the ballroom doors of a Ritz-Carlton Hotel in suburban Virginia on Friday, Chris Christies iPhone buzzed with the grim news he has awaited for 16 months.

title: G.O.P. Expands Labor Battle to Laws Setting State Construction Wages
description: A bill that would end prescribed wages on public construction projects in Indiana awaits the signature of Gov. Mike Pence. And Henry Burks, a union electrician who lives near Indianapolis, is bracing.

title: Kentucky Derby 2015: American Pharoah Wins a Close Race
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It was no secret that Bob Baffert had brought a couple of big horses to Americas biggest race, the Kentucky Derby: Dortmund had never been beaten, and his stablemate, American Pharoah, was being compared to the great Seattle Slew. In fact, some closed their eyes and transported themselves back to 1948, when the legendary trainer Ben Jones brought a couple of iconic colts named Citation and Coaltown to Churchill Downs.

title: Swarthmore Declines to Drop Investments in Fossil Fuels
description: Swarthmore College will not drop fossil fuel stocks from its $1.9 billion endowment, the schools board of managers announced on Saturday.

title: 3 New Jersey Officials Are Cleared of Coercion Against Hoboken Mayor
description: The revelation in January 2014 that officials in the administration of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey had ordered the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge to punish the mayor of Fort Lee set off a squall of allegations from other mayors who said they had also been strong-armed by the governor.

title: Protests Continue in Baltimore
description: Thousands of people gathered at a rally at City Hall in Baltimore a day after six police officers were charged in the death of Freddie Gray while he was in custody.

title: The 141st Run for the Roses
description: American Pharoah won the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

title: The Run for the Roses
description: The 141st running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: Going Way Back With Cubans, Tampa Leads Push Forward
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Decades before Miami danced to a Cuban rhythm, Tampas Ybor City grew up and got rich to the sounds of Cuban-inflected Spanish as thousands of workers rolled cigars by day and plotted the islands independence from Spain by night.

title: The Driverless Now
description: Sixty years after automakers started to fantasize about our driverless future, semiautonomous features are hitting the market. But the reality is a little more hands-on.

title: Hands-Free Cars Take Wheel, and Law Isnt Stopping Them
description: A General Motors promotional film envisions the future: Drivers enter the highway, put their cars on autopilot and sit back as the vehicle takes over and heads for the horizon. The films date? 1956.

title: Police Officer Is Shot and Critically Wounded in Queens
description: A New York City police officer in plain clothes was shot in the face and critically wounded on Saturday in Queens after driving up in an unmarked car to question a man on the street, officials said.

title: American Released by Cuba Plays Role as U.S. Relations With Havana Thaw
description: MEXICO CITY  For five years, Alan P. Gross, an American aid worker, sat in a Cuba prison growing so despondent that he openly considered suicide.

title: Notable Met Gala Themes: A Photographic Timeline
description: The event has a theme each year. Here is a look back at some memorable ones since Anna Wintour has been involved.

title: At the Helm of the Met Gala
description: For more than a decade, Anna Wintour has been at the center of the celebrities and notable individuals who have served as co-host of the Met Gala.

title: Its Called the Met Gala, but Its Definitely Anna Wintours Party
description: On Monday, as twilight falls on Fifth Avenue, more than 500 Oscar-winning actresses and actors, Wall Street titans, Silicon Valley wunderkinds, fashion designers and Hollywood players will walk up a 150-yard red carpet leading into the Metropolitan Museum of Art for what has become, over the last decade, the undisputed party of the year on the New York social schedule.

title: Nuns Intercede for Victims of Sex Trafficking in Italy
description: CASERTA, Italy  The Nigerian woman told a familiar tale. Fleeing poverty, with few prospects at home and lured by the promise of legal employment, she became one of the tens of thousands of migrants who have been braving the Mediterranean in crowded boats, bound for Europe.

title: Ruth Rendell, Novelist Who Thrilled and Educated, Dies at 85
description: Ruth Rendell, a prolific and hugely popular writer of intricately plotted mystery novels that combined psychological insight, social conscience and, not infrequently, teeth-chattering terror, died on Saturday in London. She was 85.

title: William Sokolin, Wine Seller Who Broke Famed Bottle, Dies at 85
description: The slightest mishap can cause someone to cry over their beer, or shed tears over spilled milk, but on April 23, 1989, at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan, nobody could have blamed William Sokolin if he had sobbed over a broken bottle of wine.

title: Chris Kreider Makes His Presence Felt
description: Three years ago, Chris Kreider burst on the scene as a 20-year-old forward just out of Boston College and boosted the Rangers run to the Eastern Conference finals.

title: City for Next Years Draft? N.F.L. Could Have Its Pick
description: CHICAGO  When N.F.L. executives chose last year to move the draft for the first time in a half-century, the decision was based as much on issues in New York as opportunities elsewhere.

title: Marlins Shut Out Phillies for Ninth Victory in 10 Games
description: Martin Prado homered and drove in four runs, leading Dan Haren and Miami over visiting Philadelphia.

title: Outlander Recap: Time to Kill
description: Season 1, Episode 13: The Watch

title: Strikes on Syria Tied to Deaths of 52 Civilians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Airstrikes by the American-led coalition against Islamic State militants have killed several dozen people in northern Syria, with the death toll from Fridays attacks rising to more than 52 civilians on Saturday, according to a Syrian monitoring group and local activists.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: People think the F.E.C. is dysfunctional. Its worse than dysfunctional.

title: Chris Paul, Clippers Limping Leader, Knocks Out Spurs on Last-Second Shot
description: LOS ANGELES  Seconds after Chris Paul grabbed at the back of his left hamstring while dribbling the ball up the court late in the first quarter, he left for the bench and buried his head in his hands as a trainer tended to him. Paul soon departed for the Clippers locker room at Staples Center on Saturday night, his steps slow and tentative, his face contorted in a grimace.

title: Saudi-Led Group Said to Use Cluster Bombs in Yemen
description: CAIRO  The Saudi-led military coalition fighting a rebel group in Yemen has in the past few weeks used cluster munitions supplied by the United States, Human Rights Watch said in a report released on Sunday.

description: Dr. Donna Reva Kesselman and John Joseph Raggio were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Plaza Athne in Manhattan. Peter S. Shaerf, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

Moser of Purchase, N.Y., was married Saturday to John Doran, the son of Laurie Golubieski of Sweet Valley, Pa., and the late Christopher Doran. Rabbi Jonathan Blake officiated at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

description: Michael David Lindsay and Albert Stodieck Nichols were married in a nondenominational ceremony Saturday at their vacation home in Glen Ellen, Calif. Judith Caldwell, a minister of the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness, officiated.

description: Sarah Sibley Hsu and Frank Anthony Provenzano were married Saturday evening at Saint Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Victor Lee Austin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

description: Brenda Carina Mendoza and Gregory Scott Messinger were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Nicholas J. Boas, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Ocean Edge Resort and Golf Club in Brewster, Mass.

description: Julianne Weber Staino, a daughter of Ellen M. Staino and Rocco A. Staino of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married Saturday to John T.S. Heavey, a son of Kathleen B. Heavey and Joseph F. Heavey of Poughkeepsie. The Rev. Jennifer Cook performed the ceremony at the Thompson Congregational Church in Thompson, Conn.

description: Christine Elizabeth Donnelly and Daniel George Spadacino were married Saturday at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Richard Curry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

Blacker of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Joshua Stanton officiated at Guastavinos, an events space in New York.

description: Jamie Lauren Aderski and Brian David Ray are to be married Sunday at the Buddakan restaurant in Manhattan, where the groom is an executive chef. Matt Levy, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

Bridge, a clerk of the Durham Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, witnessed the proceedings, along with Andrew D. Bridge, a fellow clerk.

description: Paul Anthony Giordano and Simon James Mathis are to be married Sunday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. Kimberlee D. Auletta, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate.

Baker of the Eastern District of Arkansas, for whom the bride was a law clerk, officiated, assisted by Judge Jesse M. Furman of the Southern District of New York, for whom the groom was a law clerk.

description: Amy Hilary Phillips and Elia Dylan Einhorn are to be married Sunday at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. Erin McCready, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

description: Joaqun Alejandro Avi and Daniel Duane Walker were married Saturday in the main performance hall of the New World Symphony in Miami Beach. Jeremy Silver, who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, officiated.

description: Erin Elena Romeo and Andrew Douglas Sickinger were married Saturday at St. Philip Church in Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Michael Boccaccio, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

Doud Jr. of Glenmoore, Pa. The Rev. Thomas S. Summers Jr., a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Turkey Hill Plantation, a hunting retreat in Ridgeland, S.C., owned by the brides family.

title: Life in Sandtown-Winchester, Baltimore
description: The neighborhood of West Baltimore where Freddie Gray was raised can be hazardous for young people.

title: Mayweather Beats Pacquiao
description: Floyd Mayweather Jr. defeated Manny Pacquiao in a unanimous decision at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on Saturday night.

title: Hard but Hopeful Home to Lot of Freddies
description: BALTIMORE  The teenagers stood inside Sun Deli and Grocery, ordered iced tea and fruit punch through the bulletproof glass and casually divided the marijuana they planned to sell, unconcerned that it was broad daylight or that other people were present.

title: Floyd Mayweather Jr. Defeats Manny Pacquiao in Boxings Big Matchup
description: For nearly 20 years, boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. has frustrated opponents in the ring with his cool calculation. He has been criticized out of the ring for his lavish lifestyle and outbursts of domestic violence. And he has navigated it all by winning habitually and becoming unapologetically rich.

title: Thousands of Freddie Grays
description: Women from the Sandtown-Winchester area of Baltimore discuss the problems plaguing the neighborhood where Freddie Gray was raised.

description: Fans packed the MGM Grand in Las Vegas for the highly anticipated bout between Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao.
