title: The Laid-Back, Mathematical Vibes of Astronauts, etc.
description: As musical-project monikers go, Astronauts, etc., is an especially appropriate one: its frontman, the Oakland, Calif.-based Anthony Ferraro, is something of an artistic wanderer, dedicated to exploring unmapped creative territories. Ferraro is classically trained, but had to abandon the orchestral route midway through his studies at Berkeley, when severe arthritis began to take its toll on his hands, forcing him to pursue a less technically demanding musical path. Since then, hes recorded as Astronauts, etc., served as the touring keyboardist for the chillwave progenitor Toro Y Moi and, most surprisingly, become heavily involved in the algorithm writing scene. The what? Let him explain. I serendipitously fell in with this group of hackers, Ferraro explains. I learned how to program really quick, and wanted to use it as a composition aid for myself. Hes since come to look at coding as an art form, and hopes others, including forward-thinking collectors, will follow suit: in March, his work Hypothetical Beats was included at the worlds first algorithm auction at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum. (Larry Gagosian was on the guest list.)

title: Review: Hunting Season on Vimeo Starts Second Season
description: As Vimeo tries to change its image from business-oriented video-sharing site to viewer-oriented video-on-demand site, it sets itself up for comparisons to the leaders in its new field  Netflix, Amazon, Hulu. But its choices so far suggest a different identity: farm team for HBO.

title: In Performance | Peter Sarsgaard
description: Mr. Sarsgaard in a scene from a new production of Hamlet, at Classic Stage through Sunday.

title: A Flu Epidemic That Threatens Birds, Not Humans
description: Although much of the country has barely noticed, avian influenza  a version of the virus that generated Killer Bird Flu! headlines a decade ago  is now sweeping the Midwest.

title: The Tattoos, Tintypes and Tarot of Pioneer Works Village Fete
description: Since it wasfounded by the artist Dustin Yellin in 2011, the massive Red Hook, Brooklyn arts space Pioneer Works has become a mainstay in the boroughs creative scene, hosting contemporary exhibitions of all stripes, as well as artist residencies, events, classes and forums (this month alone, you can learn to do anything from picking locks to creating fermented herbal sodas there). Of course, the true test of any art institutions staying power is the scale of its annual benefit  and Pioneer Works Village Fete, held Sunday night at the space, didnt disappoint. Revelers joined a glamorous squadron of hosts (including Liv Tyler, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler, Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard) for dinner, virtual reality demonstrations, throwback tintypes, tarot readings, a custom gin and tonic bar by Bombay Sapphire East (garnishes included coriander and cassia bark), a theremin performance and much more. The photographer Paul Quitoriano was on hand to capture all the action.

title: Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star
description: A recording from Edisons Talking Doll. (Audio quality is low.)

title: Therapy Borne on Electrical Currents
description: I draw an uneasy breath as I step into a bright purple office on the 14th floor of Bostons Prudential Building. I am shown to a small conference table, where I take a seat and await the experiment.

title: 3 Protesters Dead in Burundi After Clashes With Police
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Three demonstrators were killed on Monday in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, as protests against President Pierre Nkurunziza spilled into a second week.

title: Review: Triangles and Circles, an Album From the Dafnis Prieto Sextet
description: DAFNIS PRIETO SEXTET

title: Review: Roslyn Kind Swoons to an Era
description: Youre all from my era, arent you? asked Roslyn Kind at 54 Below on Friday evening before leading an audience singalong of the mid-60s hit What the World Needs Now Is Love. A quick look around the room answered that question mostly in the affirmative.

title: Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep
description: A recording heard from Edisons Talking Doll. (Audio quality is low.)

title: There Was a Little Girl
description: The first recording heard from Edisons Talking Doll. (Audio quality is low.)

title: Charles Masson Is Leaving Chevalier
description: It has been little more than a month since the opening of Chevalier, the restaurant in the Baccarat Hotel & Residences in Midtown. But that appears to have been enough time for Charles Masson to decide to step down as its genial restaurant director.

title: Explaining US Inequality Exceptionalism
description: Disposable income in the United States is more unequally distributed than in most other advanced countries. But why? The answer to that question has important implications for our understanding of inequality more generally, and also for policies intended to reduce inequality. And new work by my colleagues Janet Gornick and Branko Milanovic at the CUNY Graduate Centers Luxembourg Income Study Center shed light on the question, partly overturning what all of us believed until recently. They explain their findings in the first Research Brief in a new series launched on the LIS Center website.

title: How to Live It Up in Austin, the Simon Miller Way
description: The labels co-creative directors share snapshots from their work-hard-play-harder trip in Texass capital.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: Nepal and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Charlie Hebdo Award at PEN Gala Sparks More Debate
description: Guests at your typical $1,250-a-plate Manhattan fund-raiser usually face no quandary more urgent than red or white?

title: Ghostly Voices From Thomas Edisons Dolls Can Now Be Heard
description: Though Robin and Joan Rolfs owned two rare talking dolls manufactured by Thomas Edisons phonograph company in 1890, they did not dare play the wax cylinder records tucked inside each one.

title: How the Bombardier Beetles Bomb Goes Off
description: The bombardier beetle is famous for producing a hot, lethal toxin expelled forcefully through a channel near its abdomen. Now, using a technique known as synchrotron X-ray imaging, researchers have witnessed exactly what happens inside the beetles body when the explosion occurs.

title: Lessons From Baltimore, and Beyond
Hillary Clinton Offers to Appear Soon, but Once, Before House Panel on Benghazi
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons lawyer on Monday told the congressional committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, that Mrs. Clinton would testify before the panel only once, and that she was willing to do so in two weeks.

title: Pictures of the Day  May 4, 2015
description: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, North Korea and England.

title: Soccers Split Scarves Have Some Fans Up to Their Necks in Scorn
description: Some call them friendship scarves while others refer to them as half-and-halfs. Vendors have recently taken to marketing them as match-day scarves, while in Spanish they are labeled, more lyrically, bufandas con los dos escudos, or scarves with two shields.

title: Review: Women of Will, by Tina Packer, a Look at Shakespeares Feminine Side
description: On the cusp of the 400th anniversary of Shakespeares death, his work seems more radically modern than ever. Not only does it anticipate a contemporary view of the world as an irrational place subject to flux and the contingencies of time, but it also prefigures a postmodern art that would reinvent traditional genres, while mixing high and low tropes and breaking the fourth wall.

title: The Big Problem With the New SAT
description: AT first glance, the College Boards revised SAT seems a radical departure from the tests original focus on students general ability or aptitude. Set to debut a year from now, in the spring of 2016, the exam will require students to demonstrate in-depth knowledge of subjects they study in school.

title: Last Mammoths Spent Final Years on Solitary Island
description: Researchers have now sequenced the genome of the woolly mammoth and have concluded that the last members of the species probably died on an isolated island, where inbreeding may have led to a population too small to be sustainable.

title: Review: Jonah Bokaer Plucks Other Myths From the Past
description: Mythology has long been a pool that choreographers have dipped their toes in for inspiration. Martha Graham had her way with Medea and Clytemnestra; Mark Morriss gorgeous Dido and Aeneas, a danced opera, is a classic. But the choreographer Jonah Bokaer wants to steer mythology into the present. For Other Myths, which made its New York premiere on Sunday at Lightbox, in Manhattan, he created a setting in which his dancers, five performers mainly from Eastern Europe, could explore their own myths.

title: Espresso? Now the International Space Station Is Fully Equipped
description: ROME  Samantha Cristoforetti had an espresso on Sunday that was out of this world, and she did it in the name of science.

title: Letters to the Editor and Online Comments
description: Global Health

title: Native American Actors Work to Overcome a Long-Documented Bias
description: Late in April, after Native American actors walked off in disgust from the set of Adam Sandlers latest film, a western sendup that its distributor, Netflix, has defended as being equally offensive to all, a glow of pride spread through several Native American communities.

title: Huckabee Battles a Government Initiative (In His Florida Neighborhood)
description: He talks about running for president to take on the big fights, but Mike Huckabee has recently been battling a local big government issue.

title: A Cheeky Peek Into the Life of Simon Porte Jacquemus
description: Being a modernist with the heart of a child informs the sunny, slightly off-kilter fashion of the up-and-coming French designer.

title: Mourning Officer Brian Moore
description: The idea that police officers put their lives on the line to protect the public is treated as a clich, an abstraction, until reality destroys such complacency.

title: Dean Skelos Must Go
description: How many indictments, arrests, jail sentences, scandals or embarrassments does it take for New Yorks lawmakers to get the message? Like most members of the public, we are sick of the sleaziness that serves as everyday business in Albany. Yet, once again, on Monday morning, another state bigwig marched into a federal courthouse to face corruption charges.

title: Review: Paul Offits Bad Faith Explores Casualties of Doctrine
description: In a small Illinois town during the summer of 1977, 15-month-old Matthew Swan came down with a fever, headache and stiff neck, unmistakable signs of bacterial meningitis. This was a medical emergency, but Matthews parents, both college professors with Ph.D.s, were Christian Scientists.

title: Review: Barnard/Columbia Dances at the Miller Theater
description: Barnard/Columbia Dances, a project produced by Barnard Colleges department of dance, matches students from Barnard and Columbia University with notable choreographers and puts on a show with what they make together. The program that opened at the Miller Theater on Friday was unusual in including an early-80s classic, Mark Morriss Gloria. That is great material, although the crucial material in these programs is the cast of students.

title: Eco-Friendly Mothers Day Blooms, Paris and State Guides, and Street Style
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Review: Mumford & Sons Lose the Twang in Wilder Mind
description: The hoedown is over while the sorrows remain on Mumford & Sons decisively transformed third album, Wilder Mind. Led by the singer and drummer Marcus Mumford, the band ascended to the arena circuit with foot-stomping songs topped by jaunty banjo picking; it set off a wave of revitalized folk-rock. But with Wilder Mind, Mumford & Sons implies that all the old-timey touches were nothing more than decoration. Behind them were the martial beats and inexorable buildups of arena rock, and those have surfaced fully on Wilder Mind. Its an album of mostly despairing love songs that have found an unexpected but fitting outlet: a mope-rock resurgence.

title: Making Sense of the Chemistry That Led to Life on Earth
description: It was the actions of Jupiter and Saturn that quite inadvertently created life on Earth  not the gods of the Roman pantheon, but the giant planets, which once orbited much closer to the sun.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Fragments of Unknown Dinosaur Discovered in Chile
description: A 7-year-old boy in Chile discovered bone fragments of a previously unknown dinosaur. Named Chilesaurus diegosuarezi  after the country and the boy, Diego Surez  the new dinosaur is closely related to Tyrannosaurus rex but was an herbivore. Chilesaurus was about the size of a turkey, had unusually short arms, a long neck, a small head and leaf-shaped teeth. Diego found the bones while accompanying his parents, the geologists Manuel Suarez and Rita de la Cruz, as they studied rocks in Chilean Patagonia.

title: Candidates for a Coalition in Britain
description: A look at the three parties  the Liberal Democrats, Scottish National Party and U.K. Independence Party  that may determine the balance of power if British voters deliver a hung Parliament.

title: Lou Lamoriello Steps Down as Devils General Manager
description: Citing his advancing age and a need for a progression, Lou Lamoriello turned over his job as general manager of the Devils to Ray Shero, one of the N.H.L.s top free-agent executives.

title: Hamilton Named Best Musical by New York Drama Critics Circle
description: The rapturously received Hamilton on Monday was named the best musical of the New York theater season by the New York Drama Critics Circle.

title: The New York Times/CBS News Poll on U.S. Race Relations
description: Public perceptions of race relations in America have grown substantially more negative in the aftermath of the death of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

title: Negative View of U.S. Race Relations Grows, Poll Finds
description: Public perceptions of race relations in America have grown substantially more negative in the aftermath of the death of a young black man who was injured while in police custody in Baltimore and the subsequent unrest, far eclipsing the sentiment recorded in the wake of turmoil in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

title: Review: Red Flamboyant Is Earthbound and Flush With Romanticism
description: A newspaper article fired Don Nguyens imagination: A group of women in Vietnam, shunned by their society, gathered together to stave off fear and loneliness with laughter. All of them were H.I.V. positive, and to many in their culture, their virus was cause for shame.

title: Clinton Team Bolsters Its Defense Ahead of Negative Books Release
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign team is ratcheting up its already-intense pushback on Clinton Cash, the book about foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation, on the eve of its release.

title: Lauryn Hill Cancels Performance in Israel
description: Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning rapper and R&B singer, has canceled a performance in Israel on Thursday, citing her inability to schedule a separate concert in the Palestinian territories.

title: Pamela Geller, Organizer of Muhammad Cartoon Contest,Trumpets Results
description: Less than a day after two gunmen were shot and killed while trying to attack a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas, Pamela Geller, the New York blogger who organized the contest, took to the Internet.

title: Finding Scandal in New York and New Jersey, but No Shame
description: From sea to shining sea, or at least from one side of the Hudson to the other, politicians you have barely heard of are being accused of wrongdoing. There were so many court proceedings involving public officials on Monday that it was hard to keep up.

title: Nepals Young Men, Lost to Migration, Then a Quake
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  When the dense pillar of smoke from cremations by the Bagmati River was thinning late last week, the bodies were all coming from Gongabu, a common stopover for Nepali migrant workers headed overseas, and they were all of young men.

title: Trying to Stay Ahead of Earthquake Disasters
description: Earthquakes do not kill people, seismic experts often say. Buildings do.

title: The Met Gala
description: Photographs from the red carpet at the Costume Institute Gala, an annual fund-raiser for the Metropolitan Museum Costume Institute.

title: No Charges for Ex-Correction Officer in Killing at Brooklyn Subway Station
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office will not pursue charges against a retired correction officer who followed and fatally shot a construction worker inside the Borough Hall subway station in March, after a physical dispute that began on a crowded No. 4 train.

title: Periscope, a Streaming Twitter App, Steals the Show on Boxings Big Night
description: Periscope, the Twitter live-streaming app, barged its way onto sports biggest stage on Saturday as Floyd Mayweather Jr. defeated Manny Pacquiao in Las Vegas. How many thousands of people watched the bout via Periscope is not easy to calculate, but for those who did, the rogue approach to viewership represented saving a pay-per-view fee of as much as $100  and a potentially worrisome moment for rights holders.

title: Award to Charlie Hebdo
description: To the Editor:

title: Tale of Two Cities Widens Worldwide for Children, Study Shows
description: A widening gap between rich and poor in cities worldwide has contributed to deepening disparities in urban maternal health and child survival rates, the global charity Save the Children said Monday in an annual report.

title: Apple TV Remote Expected to Add Touch Pad in Redesign
description: Apple has long ridiculed remote controls for being too complex. Now after eight years of a minimalist design for its Apple TV remote, the company is revising the devices design.

title: Marine Selected to Head Joint Chiefs
description: President Obama plans on Tuesday to name Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., a former top commander in Afghanistan who now serves as commandant of the Marine Corps, to be the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, according to officials briefed on the selection.

title: Some Progress Is Reported in Informal Afghan-Taliban Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two days of informal talks between Afghan government and Taliban representatives produced a series of agreements that, while not binding, raised the prospect of advancement in Afghanistans long deadlocked peace process, judging from a summary of the talks released by the organizers on Monday.

title: How Some Men Fake an 80-Hour Workweek, and Why It Matters
description: Imagine an elite professional services firm with a high-performing, workaholic culture. Everyone is expected to turn on a dime to serve a client, travel at a moments notice, and be available pretty much every evening and weekend. It can make for a grueling work life, but at the highest levels of accounting, law, investment banking and consulting firms, it is just the way things are.

title: Doctor Zhivago Will Close on Sunday
description: Doctor Zhivago, a musical based on the sprawling Boris Pasternak novel that took more than a decade to get to Broadway, with stops in Australia and South Korea, will close on Sunday, after 26 previews and 23 regular performances.

title: Life Goes On, Difficultly, in Nepal
description: As the nation continued to recover from a major earthquake last month, scenes of devastation and despair remained.

title: Jets General Manager Fires Scouts
description: General Manager Mike Maccagnan continued his revamping of the Jets scouting department, firing five college scouts and Brandon Prophett, who had been the teams pro personnel director for nine seasons and been with the organization since 2000. Four of the scouts were hired by Maccagnans predecessor, John Idzik, and the other had been with the Jets since 2006.

title: Tamir Rices Mother Asks Ohio Authorities to Finish Inquiry
description: The mother of Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old boy who was fatally shot by a Cleveland police officer while playing with a fake pistol, pleaded on Monday for the Cuyahoga County Sheriffs Department to conclude its monthslong criminal investigation into the matter.

title: Fertilizer, Also Suited for Bombs, Flows to ISIS Territory From Turkey
description: AKCAKALE, Turkey  The laborers work all day, piling bags of fertilizer onto carts and wheeling them through the crossing that connects this southern border town to Syria.

title: Far-Right Party in France Tries to Push Jean-Marie Le Pen, Provocative Founder, to the Margins
description: PARIS  Leaders of Frances far-right National Front suspended the partys founder, Jean-Marie Le Pen, on Monday after repeated instances in which he made anti-Semitic and racist comments, a first step in distancing themselves from the aging patriarch.

title: Tony Nominations Help Fun Home, Something Rotten! at Box Office
description: A bounty of Tony Award nominations helped give Fun Home its biggest week at the Broadway box office to date. And Something Rotten! is vying to join An American in Paris and Finding Neverland among audience-pleasing new musicals, according to figures released by the Broadway League on Monday.

title: Justice Department Conducting Criminal Investigation of Leak at Federal Reserve
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve said on Monday that the Justice Department was conducting a criminal investigation into the disclosure of confidential information in 2012 about a crucial meeting of the Fed committee that sets monetary policy.

title: Baltimore Residents Away From Turmoil Consider Their Role
description: BALTIMORE  In the afternoons, the streets of Locust Point are clean and nearly silent. In front of the rowhouses, potted plants rest next to steps of brick or concrete. There is a shopping center nearby with restaurants, and a grocery store filled with fresh foods.

title: F.C.C. Allows Pandora to Buy South Dakota Radio Station
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Monday gave Pandora Media permission to buy a small radio station in South Dakota, bringing to an end one of the companys more contorted fights with the music industry.

title: With Boxing Match, Video Piracy Battle Enters Latest Round: Mobile Apps
description: The method used by thousands of people to watch unauthorized broadcasts of Saturday nights big boxing match might have been new, but to longtime media executives, who have led one battle against piracy after another, it was the same old story.

title: Panera Bread Plans to Drop a Long List of Ingredients
description: Acesulfame K. Ethoxyquin. Artificial smoke flavor.

title: Strategies Funded to Help Boston Airport Guard Against Effects of Climate Change
description: BOSTON  Officials at Boston Logan International Airport have announced a broad multimillion-dollar plan to make the airport, which is almost surrounded by water, more environmentally sustainable and resilient in the face of climate change.

title: New Way to Judge Hitters? Its Rocket Science, Sort Of
description: Something is sweeping through Major League Baseball this season that makes the batting-practice cage, the stands and the suites of team executives feel more like the halls of NASA. Everywhere you go at the ballpark, it seems, people are talking about exit velocity.

title: South Sudan: Worlds Youngest Nation Is at Grave Risk, Kerry Warns
description: Secretary of State John Kerry warned Monday that the violent civil conflict, mass displacement and deepening food crisis straining South Sudan, the worlds youngest country, were threatening its future. He also said the United States had allocated $5 million for the creation of a special court or other independent judicial mechanism that would hold perpetrators of atrocities and other crimes in South Sudan to account. Speaking at a news conference while visiting Nairobi, Kenya, Mr. Kerry said South Sudans promising potential after achieving independence from Sudan in 2011 is now at grave risk of being squandered because of civil violence, because of more than two million people who have been displaced from their homes. He sharply criticized President Salva Kiir of South Sudan and his political rival, the former vice president, Riek Machar, who have not yet chosen to make the compromises needed for peace. In an interview with South Sudans Eye Radio, Mr. Kerry was even more blunt, saying South Sudans leaders need to come to their senses and make peace. Loyalists of Mr. Kiir, a member of the Dinka ethnic group, and Mr. Machar, of the Nuer ethnic group, have been fighting since December 2013.

title: Dean Skelos, Albany Senate Leader, Aided Son at All Costs, U.S. Says
description: Over the last five years or so, it seemed there was little that Dean G. Skelos, the majority leader of the New York Senate, would not do for his son.

title: Lawsuit Leads to New Limits on Solitary Confinement at Juvenile Prisons in Illinois
description: CHICAGO  A settlement to a federal lawsuit will sharply limit the practice of solitary confinement in juvenile correctional facilities run by the state of Illinois, the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois announced on Monday.

title: Sorrow and Celebration for Minnesota Wild Teammates
description: ST. PAUL  An optional skate in the N.H.L. is exactly what the name suggests: a practice that is not mandatory. Stars do not usually take part in optional skates. Lesser-known veterans often skip them as well, to ease rubbery legs and the accumulating aches of a long season.

title: Berkshires Warren Buffett Shows His Teddy Bear Image Has Tough Side
description: OMAHA  I dont know of any company that has a policy that says, Were going to have a lot more people than we need.

title: For-Profit Colleges File for Bankruptcy
description: Corinthian Colleges, a for-profit college company that was formerly a Wall Street favorite, filed Monday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, listing $143 million in debt and less than $20 million in assets. Based in Santa Ana, Calif., Corinthian was once one of the nations largest for-profit college companies, enrolling more than 100,000 students at its 100 Everest, Heald and WyoTech campuses. But for the last few years, the company has faced charges of predatory recruiting and false placement and graduation rates. It went into its death spiral last year when the Department of Education suspended its access to the federal student aid it depended on, and then brokered the sale of most of its campuses. Corinthian closed its last remaining campuses  on a days notice  April 25, leaving 16,000 students in the lurch.

title: Federation Leader Fills a Class Instead of Stadiums
description: Sunil Gulati was sitting inside his office at Columbia University late Monday morning when a student walked in and began to cry.

title: A Photographic Study in Contrasts
description: As a high school football game raged in the foreground and a building burned in the back, Robert Van Fleet snapped a photograph. Nearly fifty years later, it continues to turn up.

title: In Nepal, a Dangerous Journey Home
description: Trapped by an earthquake hundreds of miles from home, 28 Nepalese workers hiked for days braving landslides and collapsed roads to reach family members.

title: Cocktail With a Kick
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Happy Cinco de Mayo!

title: Review: In Forever, Dael Orlandersmith Finds Comfort in a Cemetery
description: Dael Orlandersmith delivers an elegy with a knife-sharp edge in her solo show, Forever, which opened on Monday at New York Theater Workshop. In this raw and haunting work about her troubled youth and the rocky path she forged out of it, Ms. Orlandersmith illuminates in acid-etched detail her fraught relationship with her mother, who was abusive and alcoholic but also set an example in her hunger for books and music and her dream of a career as a dancer.

title: After Skeloss Arrest, Republicans in New York Are Left Scrambling
description: ALBANY  Now its the New York State Senates turn to fret.

title: Obama Speaks of a Sense of Unfairness
description: At an event announcing the creation of a nonprofit focusing on young minority men, President Obama talked about the underlying reasons for recent protests in Baltimore and other cities.

title: Toll Climbs to 6 in Mexican Helicopter Downing
description: MEXICO CITY  The death toll in the crash of a Mexican military helicopter shot down Friday by members of a drug gang climbed to six Monday after tests of remains at the scene determined that they were of three soldiers initially reported as missing.

title: The Met Gala  China: Through the Looking Glass
description: The red carpet at the Costume Institute Gala, an annual fund-raiser for the Metropolitan Museum Costume Institute, is a crossroad of the arts, fashion and entertainment.

title: Btard Tops James Beard Award Winners
description: On Monday night, for the first time, the annual James Beard Foundation gala  widely regarded as the Oscars ceremony of the food world  was held in Chicago rather than New York, recognizing Chicagos dynamic and often cutting-edge food scene.

title: Iran: American Prisoner Resumes Hunger Strike Over Languishing Case
description: Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran imprisoned in Iran longer than any other American inmate there, resumed a suspended hunger strike on Monday out of despair over the apparent paralysis in his case, Mr. Hekmatis sister said. In an interview on Fox News, the sister, Sarah, said that Mr. Hekmati had informed his family in the United States by telephone of his decision to stop eating. She said Mr. Hekmati had written to the officials of Evin Prison, where he has been held for more than three and a half years, declaring that hes going to start a hunger strike as of today, hes already begun. She also disclosed that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had visited with Mr. Hekmatis Michigan family on Sunday. That is the highest-level meeting the Obama administration has given to the family since Mr. Hekmati was arrested. Mr. Hekmati, 31, an American of Iranian descent from Flint, Mich., first went on a hunger strike in December but suspended it after prison officials assured him that his case would be revisited, his family said at the time. He was seized in Iran in August 2011 while visiting relatives for the first time.

title: Intertwining Celebrities and Fashion at the Met Gala
description: The ostensible theme of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was China, but as ever, the gala celebrating it Monday night was really and truly about the extraordinary pull of celebrity and its current symbiotic relationship with the fashion world.

title: The Blue Jays Halt the Yankees Mustache Momentum
description: TORONTO  In the middle of April, with the Yankees off to a dispiriting start to the season, Brett Gardner arrived at the visitors clubhouse at Tampa Bay with several days of stubble, knowing he had to shave before someone tapped him on the shoulder with a reminder that the Yankees had a no-beard policy.

title: Joshua Ozersky, Food Writer Who Extolled Meat, Is Dead at 47
description: Joshua Ozersky, a food blogger who translated appetite and ambition into columns, books and an international food festival called Meatopia, died on Monday in Chicago, where he was to attend the annual James Beard Awards. He was 47.

title: With a Carom, the Capitals Bounce Back Against the Rangers
description: WASHINGTON  So far this series, the Rangers have endured the daily exercise of discussing Alex Ovechkin and then going out and trying to neutralize him. It has all become a bit tiring, as if he is the lone Washington player they must contend with, but just as exhausting are the Capitals brutish forecheck and physical style.

title: Michael Blake, 69, Writer, Dies; Won Oscar for Dances With Wolves
description: Michael Blake, who had been washing dishes in a Chinese restaurant when an old friend, Kevin Costner, asked him to adapt his own novel into a screenplay, which became the Oscar-winning script for the Oscar-winning western epic Dances With Wolves, died on Saturday in Tucson. He was 69.

title: Robert Rietti, Movies Man With a Thousand Voices, Dies at 92
description: Robert Rietti began his long acting career as child, appearing in Depression-era films and stage productions in his native England, and his career continued into the 21st century when, among other roles, he appeared as an Italian scholar in Hannibal (2001), a sequel to The Silence of the Lambs, one of the myriad international characters he affected over hundreds of films, plays and radio and television broadcasts.

title: Thomas R. Shepard Jr., Look Magazines Last Publisher, Dies at 96
description: Thomas R. Shepard Jr., who as the last publisher of Look magazine oversaw its sudden and rapid descent from record advertising revenue and circulation to its demise, died on April 29 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 96.

title: Inside The Timess Editorial Board
description: Drones were in the news whenPresident Obama apologized, on April 23, for the deaths of two Al Qaeda hostages, both killed in an American drone strike in Pakistan.

title: The Apple Watch: More Than Just a Bracelet
description: The musings, observations and procrastinations of Ts critic at large Jody Rosen.

title: Nice Lights
description: The furniture designer Karl Zahn is known for his animal-shaped wooden toys and delicate mobiles, but for his recent collaboration with the Brooklyn-based lighting company Roll & Hill he has created two new fixtures: Bounce, a folded disc, suspended from the ceiling, which casts a soft glow projected from a lamp positioned underneath, and Cora, a pendant with eight LEDs and a bronze finish. The pieces debuted at the Milan Furniture Fair and reflect Zahns interest in earthy, elemental materials such as walnut and brass.

title: An Uber for Doctor Housecalls
description: New smartphone apps can deliver doctors to your doorstep.

title: Word of the Day | cantankerous
description: cantankerous  \kan-taN-k(-)rs, kn-\  adjective

title: Papua New Guinea: Fourth Earthquake
description: A magnitude 7.5 earthquake struck off the coast of the New Britain region on Tuesday, but early reports said the quake caused only minor damage to buildings. Vanessa Bale, who works at the Gazelle International Hotel in Kokopo in New Britain, said that she felt the earthquake and that pots containing plants had broken, but that the three-story hotel had not sustained any structural damage. She added that no one had been injured. The United States Geological Survey, which originally said the earthquake had a magnitude of 7.4 but later updated the figure, said its center was about 81 miles south of Kokopo, in the Solomon Sea. Robin Brown, a district administrator in Namatanai, said he had heard reports food had fallen from shelves in some shops in Rabaul, a township in New Britain, but there were no reports of injuries. There have been four earthquakes off the coast of Papua New Guinea, with a magnitude of 6.1 to 7.5, over the last month.

title: For Top 25 Hedge Fund Managers, a Difficult 2014 Still Paid Well
description: For investors in hedge funds, like big pension funds, 2014 was not a lucrative year. But for those who managed their money, the pay was spectacular.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 4:10 P.M. (Flix) SECRETS & LIES (1996) Hortense (Marianne Jean-Baptiste), a black London optometrist who was adopted as an infant, discovers that her birth mother, Cynthia (Brenda Blethyn), is a white, lower-class factory worker with a dysfunctional family in this Mike Leigh drama. Timothy Spall (the star of Mr. Leighs Mr. Turner), Phyllis Logan (Mrs. Hughes on Downton Abbey) and Claire Rushbrook play Cynthias brother, sister-in-law and daughter, who have secrets of their own. In a performance that lurches thrillingly from grief to comedy to compassion, never losing its tart humor, her Cynthia rises up from the sodden mess of her life to face regret over the past and uncharacteristic hope for the future, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about Ms. Blethyn, who along with Ms. Jean-Baptiste and Mr. Leigh received Oscar nominations. Soap opera? Ms. Maslin asked. Never. Mr. Leighs wry and magnanimous intelligence keeps Secrets & Lies determinedly unsentimental, helped immeasurably by Cynthias fine, tough resilience and idiomatic verve.

title: Corrections: May 5, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I grew up without a dad. I grew up sometimes lost and adrift, not having a sense of a clear path. The only difference between me and a lot of the other young men in this neighborhood and all across the country is that I grew up in an environment that was a little more forgiving.

title: Met Gala Fashion Inspires Photoshop Remixes in China
description: The theme of the new exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Costume Institute is China: Through the Looking Glass, an exploration of Chinese influence on Western fashion. And as celebrities paraded on the red carpet for the annual Met Gala on Monday evening, Chinese Internet users created their own interpretations of a few of the bolder fashions on display.

title: UBS Profit Rose 88% in First Quarter
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS said on Tuesday that its first-quarter profit rose 88 percent on gains in its investment bank and its wealth management business amid a sharp increase in the value of the Swiss franc.

title: On Mount Everest, Surviving an Earthquake and an Avalanche
description: Roberto Schmidt, the chief photographer for South Asia for Agence France-Presse, was at the Mount Everest base camp in Nepal when an avalanche triggered by a massive earthquake hit. His dramatic images of the avalanche and its aftermath were published around the world. Mr. Schmidt, 49, recounted his experiences in a phone conversation with James Estrin, which has been edited.

title: Saudi Arabias Future
Marketing of Marijuana
description: To the Editor:

title: DNA and the F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Secrets Doomed Script
description: In every episode of Silicon Valley, the terrific HBO comedy series created by Mike Judge, there is always a moment, rendered utterly deadpan, that both mocks and explains the current, are-we-in-a-bubble-yet state of play in, well, Silicon Valley.

title: Q. and A.: Mark Clifford on The Greening of Asia
description: After 20 years in Asia as a journalist, Mark Clifford took over as executive director of the Hong Kong-based Asia Business Council in 2007. His new book, The Greening of Asia: The Business Case for Solving Asias Environmental Emergency, explores how Asian companies are making strides in providing environmental solutions. China is a special focus because of the countrys huge emissions of carbon, but also because of its potential for innovation.

title: Should Jackson Stay on the $20 Bill?
description: WASHINGTON  IN 1928 the Treasury Department issued the first $20 bill featuring Andrew Jackson, replacing Grover Cleveland. After almost a century, Jackson needs to step aside  and this time, the bill should feature John Ross, a Cherokee leader and Old Hickorys opponent in a fight to control Indian land.

title: Transgender Students at Womens Colleges
description: The questions have confounded admission officials at womens colleges in recent years.

title: What Is Your Purpose?
description: Every reflective person sooner or later faces certain questions: What is the purpose of my life? How do I find a moral compass so I can tell right from wrong? What should I do day by day to feel fulfillment and deep joy?

title: Runaway Drug Prices
description: A drug to treat abnormal heart rhythms can cost about $200 on one day and more than $1,300 the next. A diagnosis of multiple sclerosis can lead to a drug bill of at least $50,000 a year. How companies set prices of specialty drugs for these and other complex diseases, like cancer and AIDS, has been a mystery to the patients who need them. Now the Obama administration and some states are tackling that lack of transparency and the rising costs.

title: 6 Qs About the News | For-Profit Colleges Face a Loan Revolt by Thousands Claiming Trickery
description: In For-Profit Colleges Face a Loan Revolt by Thousands Claiming Trickery, Tamar Lewin reports on a student debt strike.

title: Test Yourself |The Royal Babys Name
description: Below, several paragraphs from the May 4 article Charlotte Elizabeth Diana Is Royal Babys Name.

title: The Empty River of Life
description: There is something strange going on in Isfahan, where the water under the famous Bridge of 33 Arches has disappeared.

title: Crying Gotcha
description: If there is one thing politicians agree on, its that there are no bad answers, only gotcha questions. Whenever reporters, being reporters, ask something unwelcome, or surprising, or even just dumb  any kind of query that requires a politician to say something a politician would prefer not to say  thats a gotcha. The victims are not pleased.

title: Mayor de Blasio Is Irked by a Subway Delay
description: The email, blunt and to the point, popped into City Hall aides inboxes at 12:17 p.m., and the subject line said it all: 2 problems today.

title: The Empty River of Life
description: In the last episode of Our Man in Tehran, Thomas Erdbrink traveled to Isfahan to see how Iranians confront the countrys drought. He also answered readers questions, below, about the governments environmental policies and the prospects for dealing with the countrys lack of water.

title: Bentonville, Ark., Hosts a Film Festival Without a Movie Theater
description: BENTONVILLE, Ark.  It makes sense that the fate of this quintessential company town is being plotted in a conference room just a mile from Walmart headquarters. But what Trevor Drinkwater and his lieutenants are plotting is cultural, artistic and urban. In other words, something less stereotypically Walmart.

title: Fire Raged, They Played On, and the Photo Still Beguiles
description: GILL, Mass.  The photograph, nearly 50 years old, is a social media favorite, a perennial entry on top-10 lists of strange-but-true sports images. And it is certainly strange. Fans watch a football game from the stands as a building burns behind them, failing to look even mildly alarmed at the flames shooting out and the black smoke billowing into the sky.

title: Wisconsin, Politics and Faith Bind Scott Walker and Paul Ryan
description: DELAVAN, Wis.  Who could have guessed in the mid-1980s, at a pair of otherwise forgettable McDonalds restaurants some 20 miles apart, that two bushy-haired teenagers working the burger grills would become Wisconsins most powerful Republicans?

title: Rural Indiana Struggles to Contend With H.I.V. Outbreak
description: AUSTIN, Ind.  She became addicted to painkillers over a decade ago, when a car wreck left her with a broken back and doctors prescribed OxyContin during her recovery. Then came a new prescription opiate, Opana, easily obtained on the street and more potent when crushed, dissolved in water and injected. She did just that, many times a day, sometimes sharing needles with other addicts.

title: How Green Are You?
description: Sometimes trying to go green has its trade-offs. To save energy and reduce light pollution, New York City is considering dimming the lights on its iconic night skyline. What trade-offs do you make in your life to try to reduce your environmental footprint?

title: Venezuelas Economy Suffers as Import Schemes Siphon Billions
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The weed whackers were $12,300. Each.

title: PEN 6 Exercise Freedom to Dissent
description: This week, Jack Shafer reviews David K. Shiplers Freedom of Speech: Mightier Than the Sword. In the days just before this issue went to press, free speech made headlines in the literary world when six writers (Francine Prose, one of our Bookends columnists, among them) publicly withdrew their support for PEN America Centers decision to present its annual Freedom of Expression Courage award to the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo. Islamic extremists murdered 12 staff members of the newspaper in Paris on Jan. 7. Shafer, who writes about the press for Politico, was unfazed by the dissent within PEN.

title: Economic Growth in Eurozone Appears to Be Gaining Momentum
description: PARIS  It may not be at escape velocity yet, but the European economy is definitely picking up steam, an official forecast showed on Tuesday, as low oil prices, favorable foreign-exchange rates and central bank stimulus added momentum to a modest recovery.

title: Freedom of Speech, by David K. Shipler
description: Free speech martyrdom aint what it used to be in these United States.

title: Look Whos Back, With a Resurrected Adolf Hitler
description: E.M. Forster makes a limitlessly useful distinction, in Aspects of the Novel, between the novelist and the historian: The historian, he explains, deals with actions, and with the characters of men only so far as he can deduce them from their actions. On the other hand, it is the function of the novelist to reveal the hidden life at its source: to tell us more about Queen Victoria than could be known, and thus to produce a character who is not the Queen Victoria of history.

title: The Quartet, by Joseph J. Ellis
description: When and how did the United States become a nation? This question is the core of The Quartet. In his customary graceful prose, Joseph J. Ellis, the author of such works of popular history as the prizewinning Founding Brothers, argues that the United States did not become a nation with the Declaration of Independence in 1776. Rather, he says, American nationhood resulted from the creation, adoption and effectuation of the United States Constitution.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Anti-Tax Group Wastes No Time Targeting Mike Huckabee
description: Mike Huckabees longtime nemesis, the anti-tax group Club for Growth, is bringing the welcome wagon for his entry into the 2016 Republican presidential primary  with a $100,000 ad buy denouncing his record.

title: New York Today: Mourning an Officer
description: Good morning on this hazy Tuesday.

title: Top 5 Hedge Fund Earners
description: The men at the top of the hedge fund universe now run firms that are bigger than they have ever been.

title: HSBC Profit Up Slightly on Market Uptick in First Quarter
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC said that its profit rose slightly in the first quarter as it benefited from increased market activity, particularly after a difficult fourth quarter.

title: Texas Attacker Left Trail of Extremist Ideas on Twitter
description: WASHINGTON  Counterterrorism officials on Tuesday were studying the electronic trails left by two men killed by a police officer as they shot at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas, looking for any direct ties to the Islamic State extremist group in Syria. The group praised the gunmen in a statement as soldiers of the caliphate, the unified Muslim land that it purports to be building.

title: This Is My Brain on PMS
description: Two days before my period, having just decreased my dose of bupropion from 150 to 100 milligrams, I am in the throes of some record-breaking premenstrual syndrome. Id rather not discuss it. I feel like a traitor admitting that PMS lays me flat  women have been fighting for decades to shake our image as hysterical, chocolate-wolfing slaves to the moon cycle. But PMS is as much a part of my depression as gray skies, insomnia, and difficult writing days. About five years ago, after reading my journals with a therapist (we were trying to identify patterns in my depression), she gave me a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)  basically, brutal PMS.

title: What Hollywood Can Teach Us About the Future of Work
description: Recently I visited a movie set. It was the first day of production, and I arrived just as the sun was coming up, but already, around 150 people were busy setting up that days shot in an abandoned office building. Crew members were laying electric cables and hanging lights. The cinematographer was in one corner with his team, discussing how the suns rays filtered through the window blinds. Carpenters were putting the finishing touches on a convincing prop elevator  I pushed the call button and waited, until I finally realized it was a fake.

title: Mike Huckabee and the Continuing Influence of Evangelicals
description: The religious right remains the largest voting bloc in the Republican Party, and that gives Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, the potential to play a big role in the presidential nominating contest.

title: Today in Politics: Clinton to Call for a Path to Citizenship
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. The Senate is still snagged on its Iran measure. The itinerary of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey takes him far from the George Washington Bridge, and Hillary Rodham Clinton is traveling to Nevada to talk about overhauling the immigration system, an issue that has tripped her up in the past.

title: South Korean N.Y.U. Student Held by North Says He Wanted to Make a Point
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean student at New York University who is being held by North Korea said in an interview broadcast on Tuesday that he had entered the reclusive country intending to be arrested, and that he had hoped to bring about better relations between the two Koreas by doing so.

title: TV or Not TV?
Weekly News Quiz | April 28-May 4, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Unanswered Questions
description: Nothing is more frustrating to a reader than a story that leaves an obvious question unanswered. Sometimes the writer and editor know the background so well that they forget to include all the basics. Sometimes a crucial fact cant be learned on deadline; in that case, we should say so clearly, so readers dont go back and forth through the story wondering how they missed it.

title: In Performance: Peter Sarsgaard of Hamlet
description: This weeks video features Peter Sarsgaard as the title character in a new production of Hamlet from the Classic Stage Company. In this scene Hamlet is buoyed by the night to seek revenge against Claudius, and wonders how to confront his mother about her hasty remarriage. Now I could drink hot blood, he says, and do such bitter business as the day would quake to think on. The show is at Classic Stage through Sunday.

title: Morning Agenda: Big Paychecks Despite Tough Year
description: BIG PAYCHECKS DESPITE TOUGH YEAR | Last year, the hedge fund industry had returns of only 3 percent on average, according to HFR, a firm that tracks the industry. But the top 25 managers still managed to earn $11.62 billion in compensation in 2014, according to an annual ranking to be published on Tuesday by Institutional Investors Alpha magazine, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook.

title: Shanghai Enacts Curbs on Business Dealings of Officials Relatives
description: HONG KONG  Responding to calls by President Xi Jinping to rein in corruption in China, Shanghai has enacted strict rules to keep the spouses and children of top local officials from entering private business and profiting from their government connections.

title: The Bus Stop and the Velvet Rope
description: Dear Diary:

title: Gains Across the Disney Empire Lift Earnings 10%
description: LOS ANGELES  It was supposed to be a rare quarter of weakness for Disney, with analysts fretting about higher programming costs at ESPN and a comedown from last years Frozen-fueled highs.

title: BGC Partners Buys Real Estate Consulting Firm
description: In a move to bolster its real estate arm, the brokerage firm BGC Partners has struck another takeover.

title: Becoming Foster Parents, a Moment at a Time
description: The boys are each wielding a baseball bat, running back and forth across the backyard. They pause at the slide, fake scream at the sight of a bug and bring the bats down with resounding thuds.

title: European Union Delays Action on Apple, Amazon and Starbucks Tax Inquiries
description: BRUSSELS  European officials investigating whether Apple, Amazon and other companies received sweetheart tax deals from Ireland and Luxembourg will not take action as soon as expected, the European Union competition commissioner said Tuesday.

title: Rand Pauls Donations Show His Small-Town Appeal
description: Online fund-raising data from the first several weeks of Rand Pauls presidential campaign suggests that much of his initial small-dollar support has come from smaller cities and towns.

title: Veg-O-Matic Egonomics
description: All successful researchers have gigantic egos. If they didnt  if they did not have, at the core of their being, a frightening level of intellectual arrogance  they would never have had the temerity to decide that they had insights denied to all the extremely clever scholars who preceded them. And it takes even more egotism to persist in the face of all the people who will, in fact, tell you that your insight is trivial, its wrong, and they said it in 1962.

title: Bank of America Hires Technology Banker Chris Cormier
description: Bank of America has hired Chris Cormier, a specialist in helping companies in the technology, media and telecommunications sectors go public, as a managing director, the firm announced on Monday in an internal memorandum.

title: Stephen Curry as Best Player? Sure. Most Valuable? Maybe Not.
description: Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors was the best player on basketballs best team. Yet he might not have been deserving of the Most Valuable Player Award he easily won. The key is the phrase most valuable.

title: Daily Report: Change of the Old Guard at Cisco
description: Technologys older generation of rebels has now almost completely disrupted itself, writes Quentin Hardy.

title: Mike Huckabee Joins Republican Presidential Race
description: HOPE, Ark.  Mike Huckabee, who excited evangelical voters in his first presidential race in 2008 and retains much of their good will, announced on Tuesday that he would again seek the Republican nomination despite a crowded field of rivals for his natural base in the party.

title: Brace Yourself
description: Orthodontia is the latest unexpected trend to make a play for the runway, popping up at a Hood by Air show, in the mouth of the Chanel-approved model Charlie James (above) and on the cover of Carine Roitfelds CR Fashion Book.

title: Mike Huckabee Has Chuck Norris in His Corner Again
description: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas has won the endorsement of one of his most loyal supporters as he announces his second run for president Tuesday morning.

title: The Most On-Theme Red Carpet Looks at Last Nights Met Gala
description: These 10 ladies did the Chinese White Tie dress code justice.
