description: Explore street view, find things to do in San Luis Obispo and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: Bernie Sanders Urges Breaking Up Big Banks
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont and a 2016 Democratic candidate for president, is pushing his new role as a voice to the left of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Berlin Philharmonic Prepares to Vote on New Chief Conductor
description: When they gather for their conclave on Monday, the 124 eminent electors will be asked to surrender their cellphones. Then they will deliberate and, through means opaque to the outside world, select a leader to guide their venerable, revered institution farther into the 21st century.

title: Relying on Product Reviews? Knowing How a Company Treats Its Customers Is Just as Valuable
description: PRODUCT reviews are broken. They are great at telling you about the speed of a computer or the brightness of a screen. But theres a big gaping hole in evaluations of most products, from phones to computers to televisions.

title: 36 Hours in San Luis Obispo, Calif.
description: Occupying a dramatic stretch of coast midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles, San Luis Obispo County is nothing if not well-positioned. It has the Pacific to the west, the fertile San Joaquin Valley to the east and a delicious Mediterranean climate. It is here, on an isolated hill overlooking the ocean, that William Randolph Hearst built his bizarre, opulent castle (worthy of a visit), and it was here that the construction magnate Alex Madonna erected his own kitschy, faux-Alpine landmark, the Madonna Inn, a decade later. Like California itself, San Luis Obispo (SLO, as its called here) is both a place and a lifestyle. Sprawling and rural, it sits at the intersection of surf culture, cowboy culture and California cuisine. And that is a fine place to be.

title: Cherries, Marijuana and a Suicide in Brooklyn: A Reporters Notebook
description: When Arthur Mondella killed himself in February, soon after investigators discovered he had kept a marijuana farm under his maraschino cherry factory in Red Hook, Brooklyn, there seemed no obvious way to unravel his life and death.

title: Tom Brady Probably Knew Footballs Were Doctored, N.F.L. Finds
description: He called himself the deflator. A longtime locker-room attendant for the New England Patriots, Jim McNally, was responsible for controlling the air pressure in the footballs that quarterback Tom Brady would use on the field.

title: Google Loses to LinkedIn in Silicon Valley Headquarters Pitch
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Early this year, Google unveiled renderings of several clear, tent-like buildings that would replace its current Silicon Valley headquarters, known as the Googleplex. Renderings may be about as far as the idea is likely to go.

title: Syria Is Using Chemical Weapons Again, Rescue Workers Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Eyes watering, struggling to breathe, Abd al-Mouin, 22, dragged his nephews from a house reeking of noxious fumes, then briefly blacked out. Even fresh air, he recalled, was burning my lungs.

title: The Top 10 Hedge Fund Managers, and How They Spend Their Money on Politics
description: Masters at hedging their financial bets, most of the top managers dont bring the same approach to American politics, favoring one party over the other.

title: Reaction to French Surveillance Bill
description: Members of the French conservative party reacted after parliament voted on Tuesday to adopt new surveillance rules.

title: Mike Huckabee, Anti-Reform Conservative
description: Four and a half years ago, duringtheTea Partys heyday and just after the G.O.Ps 2010 midterm success, Dave Weigel (then of Slate, now of Bloomberg) wrote a piece in which he asked various writers, myself included, who had argued that the G.O.P. needed a new domestic policy agenda to explain why Republicans had won back the House of Representatives while (seemingly) just doubling down onsmall-government rhetoric and offering little that could reasonably be described as new. I cant get the link to the original Weigel piece working, but here is my follow-up, which includes a point with some relevance to Mike Huckabees just-launched presidential campaign: Namely, that theres more than one way to operationalize the insights about American politics and working class voters that Reihan Salam and I tried to offer in Grand New Party many years ago, and that undergird what were calling reform conservatism today.

title: Fun Home and Other Quests for Self
description: A contagion of self-consciousness is raging on Broadway. Yes, that unblushing capital of extroverted entertainment went all introspective on us during the theater season that just ended.

title: Baltimore Mayor On D.O.J. Investigation
description: Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake of Baltimore has asked the Justice Department to investigate policing practices at the Baltimore City Police Department.

title: Investigative Report on A.F.C. Championship Game Footballs
description: The investigative report into accusations that the New England Patriots improperly deflated game balls in last Januarys A.F.C. championship game.

title: Water Pricing in Two Thirsty Cities: In One, Guzzlers Pay More, and Use Less
description: FRESNO, Calif.  When residents of this parched California city opened their water bills for April, they got what Mayor Ashley Swearengin called a shock to the system.

title: Oil Tank Car Fire Forces Evacuation of North Dakota Town
description: A train carrying highly volatile crude oil derailed and erupted into flames on Wednesday morning, forcing the evacuation of a small town in North Dakota, according to local and federal officials.

title: Manicurists in New York Area Are Underpaid and Unprotected
description: Nail salon workers are routinely exploited, endure ethnic bias and other abuse, and get little help from government agencies, The New York Times has found.

title: Two Kinds of Water Bills: Flat or Tiered
description: In Fresno, Calif., where residents pay a flat rate for water, per-capital usage was 222 gallons a day last year; under Sante Fes tiered pricing system, per-capita usage is about 100 gallons a day.

title: LPL Financial to Pay $11.7 Million to Settle Finra Case
description: A relatively little-known brokerage firm that has grown into one of the nations largest has been fined again for failing to supervise its brokers properly.

title: Two Kinds of Water Bill: Flat Rate or Tiered
description: In Fresno, Calif., where residents pay a uniform rate for water, per-capital usage was 222 gallons a day last year; under Sante Fes tiered pricing system, per-capita usage is about 100 gallons a day.

title: U.S. Airports Are Better, but Not Best
description: As major airports around the world scramble to brand themselves as luxury entities rather than mere transportation centers, some have adopted a star-ranking system, like hotels. It was inevitable.

title: Business Travelers Want to Be Left to Their Own Devices
description: Leisure travelers have become used to controlling every step of a trip, from booking a flight or a car to making dinner reservations. Business travelers, less so; there has always been some corporate bean counter looking over their shoulders.

title: The Newest Edition
description: A tour of Ian Schragers hotel in New York.

title: U.S. Ambassador Criticizes Indias Crackdown on Charities and Activist Groups
description: NEW DELHI  The American ambassador to India expressed concern Wednesday about the potentially chilling effect of recent actions by the Indian government against charities and advocacy groups.

title: Alice Notley Wins $100,000 Poetry Prize
description: Alice Notley, a poet who has worked in a wide variety of forms and styles in more than 25 books, has been awarded the lucrative and prestigious Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize. The prize, presented annually by the Poetry Foundation to to a living American poet for lifetime accomplishment, comes with $100,000.

title: Viewfinder: Matthias Schaller
description: By documenting their materials, the photographer Matthias Schaller creates abstract portraits of van Gogh, Matisse, Picasso, Twombly and more.

title: With Children, Talking Money Means Talking Values
description: When my daughter displayed her first bursts of curiosity it was merely cute. Ah dis? she asked, pointing at anything and everything that she did not recognize or had no words for. Doing? Doing? she inquired of grownups engaged in unfamiliar tasks. Talking about? she wondered, when the conversation went over her head.

title: Trader in 2010 Flash Crash Case Is Denied Bail Reduction
description: LONDON  Navinder Singh Sarao, the British futures trader accused of playing a major role in causing the widespread flash crash of 2010, told the court on Wednesday that he had done nothing wrong, asserting that he was just good at my job.

title: On Broadway, Portraits of the Powerless
description: Broadway trades primarily in the business of pure escapism, whether it is to the happy-land of most musicals, the profitable nostalgia of classic revivals or the fun of gawping at the doings of British royalty. But I was struck that this season even Broadway  where plays of political relevance are as rarely sighted as tumbleweeds on 42nd Street  hosted a handful of productions that spoke to contemporary concerns, including radical Islam and the topic thats likely to be on the lips of every politician on the long and windy road to the presidency: the countrys increasing income inequality.

title: Issues, Schmissues. Can the  Presidential Candidates Sing?
description: The cacophony of presidential candidates is getting louder by the day, and while they have a variety of views on political matters, many of them have at least one thing in common  a love of music.

title: Bradley Cooper and Carey Mulligan Compare Broadway Notes
description: Their faces grace the covers of national magazines, and heads turn when they walk down the street.

title: Robert Fairchild and Tony Yazbeck Have It All on Broadway Stages
description: Two young men currently exemplify the best of what Broadway has to offer: Robert Fairchild in An American in Paris and Tony Yazbeck in On the Town. They sing, they talk, they dance, they switch gears between those activities seamlessly, and their energy and charm stay long in the memory. Both men are playing roles associated, in the film versions of these shows, with Gene Kelly; neither suffers from the comparison with that Hollywood legend. And each gives the most remarkable performance in his musical.

title: Ian Schrager Unveils the New York Edition
description: Ian Schrager, the Bronx-born, Brooklyn-raised hotelier, will unveil his latest property, the New York Edition, in the landmark Metropolitan Life Tower on Madison Avenue on May 11.

title: Chita Rivera, the Oldest Tony Nominee, and Sydney Lucas, the Youngest, Discuss Their Work
description: They met in the hallway of the Paramount Hotel. It was the annual Tony-nominees-meet-the-media event, and Chita Rivera, 82, was about to leave for her matinee performance when she spotted a fellow nominee, 11-year-old Sydney Lucas. She stopped, said hello, posed for a few photos. And then, while mugging for the cameras, the oldest of this years acting nominees pointed at the youngest and cracked, Before, and after.

title: How Michael Zelehoski Activates the Everyday
description: Michael Zelehoski isnt exactly finished with The Allegory of the Cave. The Massachusetts-born artist, whose first solo show at Mike Weiss Gallery, New Order, opens this Thursday, first delved into Platos famous thought experiment when he used it as the subject for his early admissions essay for Bard College at Simons Rock at the unruly age of 16. Art is a shadow of a shadow. This is why a lot of these philosophers didnt really have a place for art  they saw it as a distraction, says Zelehoski in his self-built studio in Beacon, New York, where hes been working since a fateful trip to Dia, the minimalist Mecca, back in 2011. For his upcoming exhibit, Zelehoski has transformed found objects, mostly discarded wooden stockroom palettes and police barricades, into intricately cut 2D, wall-mounted assemblages. The works function as optical illusions that seek to alter our relationship not only to physical space but to the often overlooked, humble, utilitarian objects that move within it.

title: Under the Sea, a Missing Link in the Evolution of Complex Cells
description: Unlike bacteria, humans have big, complex cells, packed with nuclei containing DNA and mitochondria that produce energy. All so-called eukaryotes share our cellular complexity: animals, plants, fungi, even single-celled protozoans like amoebae.

title: Jim Wright Dies at 92; House Speaker Resigned Amid Ethics Charges
description: Jim Wright, a driven Texas Democrat who rose to the pinnacle of congressional power before ethics charges forced his resignation as speaker of the House in 1989, died on Wednesday in Fort Worth. He was 92.

title: Review: At Dinner With the Boys, a Serving of Mafia Jokes
description: A taste for shtick is all but required to enjoy Dinner With the Boys at the Acorn Theater. And since this cast is eager to mug, an appetite for ham wouldnt hurt either.

title: Kenya Steps Back From Threat to Expel Somali Refugees
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya on Wednesday softened a threat to expel hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees within three months, saying there would be no forced repatriations.

title: Free Speech vs. Hate Speech
description: There is no question that images ridiculing religion, however offensive they may be to believers, qualify as protected free speech in the United States and most Western democracies. There is also no question that however offensive the images, they do not justify murder, and that it is incumbent on leaders of all religious faiths to make this clear to their followers.

title: Review: Judy Collins Performs at Cafe Carlyle
description: The moon was full on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle, and I dont mean literally. Im describing the voice of Judy Collins at the opening night performance of her engagement at the club. The cool, sweet caress of her vibrato-less soprano has always evoked various lunar phases. Always lovely, it can be a delicate wisp or a graceful crescent. But on Tuesday, it was full-bodied, confident and pitch-perfect.

title: German Minister Denies Spying Allegation
description: The interior minister, Thomas de Maizire, denies accusations that Germanys intelligence agency helped the United States spy on European officials and firms.

title: Questions for Hillary Clinton: Immigration
description: Since she declared her candidacy on April 12, Hillary Rodham Clinton has answered just seven questions from reporters. This is the first installment of a regular First Draft feature in which The Times will publish questions we would have asked Mrs. Clinton had we had the opportunity.On Tuesday, at an event in Las Vegas, Mrs. Clinton laid out an extensive and ambitious plan to overhaul the nations immigration system, including expanding the Dream Act, which defers deportation for the children of undocumented immigrants, to include their parents, a step President Obama has not taken. Our question for Mrs. Clinton would have been:

title: Corinthian Colleges Lean Business Model Leaves Little for Creditors
description: Corinthian Colleges, the for-profit education company familiar to corporate law professors for its appearance in textbooks about securities regulation, now has a chance to appear in bankruptcy and restructuring texts as well.

title: App Smart | Be Prepared for Disaster
description: In the event of an emergency, your phone can be a lifeline in more ways than one. New apps give instructions on first aid, disaster preparedness and can help you find missing loved ones.

title: Video Feature: Apps to Cope and Help in a Disaster
description: The deadly earthquake in Nepal serves as a reminder that natural disasters can strike at any time. But being prepared and informed can help, and a smartphone can be a vital tool for that.

title: Ben Brantley: The Tony Award Nominations Should Be ...
description: Ben Brantley makes his Tony Award choices. For the Should Have Been Nominated category, the Timess critics were allowed to expand the potential nominees to Off Broadway productions, which are ineligible for the Tonys. But they didnt consider Hamilton, which is moving to Broadway.

title: A Place for Breast-Feeding Mothers at New York Area Airports
description: Breast-feeding mothers usually struggle to find a private space at the airport to nurse their babies or pump their milk. The Burlington, Vt.-based household and baby care company Seventh Generation was aware of that challenge and decided to take action by sponsoring the installation of four pumping and nursing pods in New York area airports: one in the JetBlue terminal at Kennedy Airport, two at Newark Liberty International Airport and one at La Guardia Airport.

title: Navy Robots Test the Limits of Autonomy
description: This is the second episode in a Bits video series, called Robotica, examining how robots are poised to change the way we do business and conduct our daily lives.

title: Building the Autonomous Machine
description: Navy robotics engineers are working to develop autonomous tools that can integrate with other technologies. But in field tests, the autonomous future still seems far away.

title: Youre Never Too Young to Build a Castle
description: Playing in the sand has gone beyond a primary-colored plastic pail and shovel. Taking a cue from extracurricular instruction in subjects like music and sports, sand-castle lessons are now part of a childs syllabus.

title: Review: Alonzo King Lines Ballet at the Joyce Theater
description: Alonzo King Lines Ballet opened a run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with a 2013 work by Mr. King, Concerto for Two Violins. It is set to a Bach score that for many dance lovers, especially in New York, is indelibly associated with George Balanchines 1941 masterpiece Concerto Barocco. The inevitable contrast is unsurprisingly cruel. The more interesting and favorable comparison is between Mr. Kings Concerto and the rest of his program.

title: Elton John Testifies Before Senate
description: The singer Elton John testified before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee on Wednesday, asking for its help in the fight to end the AIDS epidemic.

title: Hillary Clinton Puts White House in Awkward Position on Immigration
description: When President Obama issued an executive order in November sparing millions of illegal immigrants from deportation and offering them work permits, he argued that he was doing as much as the law would allow. Now Hillary Rodham Clinton says she will do even more if she becomes president.

title: A-Line Minis, Without Maxi Prices
description: Plus: Jewelry with a Danish sensibility; romantic dresses from Colombia; and a terry tunic from Lisa Marie Fernandez.

title: City Ballet Usher Has Spotlight as a Designer for La Sylphide
description: Most nights find Susan Tammany working at the David H. Koch Theater  dressed in black, wearing a name tag, handing out programs and helping balletomanes to their seats. But she wont be working as an usher on Thursday night at City Ballets spring gala.

title: Point72 Hires Ex-Prosecutor as General Counsel
description: Steven A. Cohens search for a former federal prosecutor to serve as the general counsel for his Point72 Asset Management family office ended on Wednesday with the hiring of Kevin J. OConnor, a former United States attorney for Connecticut.

title: Some See Liberty Hire as an Insult to W.N.B.A. Fans
description: Helen Wheelock began buying Liberty ticket plans in 1997, the first season of the W.N.B.A.

title: Party Leaders End British Election Campaign More Energized Than Voters
description: LONDON  BBC Radio 4 had a laconic, one-word weather forecast Wednesday morning: changeable.

title: Review: Caring for Mom & Dad on PBS Looks at Elder Care Struggles
description: The discussion of aging often doesnt get much further than: Your parent has Alzheimers, and youre caring for her? That must be hard. A PBS special on Thursday night (check local listings) at least tries to go deeper. Though it still spends considerable time on elder-care anecdotes  stories that are heart-rending but at this point familiar  it also acknowledges difficult questions of costs, rights and medical capabilities.

title: At William Okpo, Lively Clothes That Flatter the Quiet Parts
description: The developmental milestones for a human at age 5 include drawing basic shapes, turning a somersault, using a fork and distinguishing between genders. In todays retail climate, the most common five-year milestone for an upstart fashion house is nonexistence. For a label called William Okpo, the half-decade mark has brought about its very first stand-alone location, an airy boutique in the South Street Seaport.

title: Lynn Grefe, Advocate for Those With Eating Disorders, Dies at 65
description: If Lynn Grefe ever agreed with the adage that you cant be too rich or too thin, she publicly denounced it as dead wrong after her teenage daughter confided that she was suffering from bulimia and anorexia. That inspired Ms. Grefe to organize a national campaign to promote education and treatment for eating disorders and to convince women whom teenage girls idolize, like fashion models, that being too thin can be fatal.

title: Zac Brown Band Hits No. 1
description: Zac Brown Band, country musics favorite bar band, scored its third Billboard No. 1 album this week with Jekyll + Hyde (John Varvatos Records/Republic/Big Machine), selling 214,000 copies and racking up 3.9 million streams for a total of 228,000 album equivalent units, according to Nielsen Music.

title: Simon Callow in Tuesdays at Tescos
description: Youve seen the British actor Simon Callow in heady stuff like Being Shakespeare, perhaps, and maybe caught his performances in films including Four Weddings and a Funeral, but you havent seen all that this versatile performer, director and writer has to offer until you catch Tuesdays at Tescos, which begins previews at 59E59 Theaters on Thursday.

title: Courts in China Face  Balancing  Act on Domestic Abuse
description: Three days after suspending a previous death sentence on Li Yan, a battered woman who killed her husband in 2010 in a case that attracted attention around the world, Judge Feng Weis work was not yet done. He still had to ensure social stability.

title: Robert Redford, on David Brooks
description: To the Editor:

title: After Shooting in Garland, Readers Weigh In on Matters of Free Speech
description: Marie Tae McDermott is a news assistant and comment moderator for The Times.

title: Al Jazeera America Chief Is Ousted After Turmoil
description: Al Jazeera America announced on Wednesday that it was replacing its chief executive, Ehab Al Shihabi, who had held that position since the networks founding two years ago.

title: Review: In Oh! You Pretty Things, Shanna Mahin Dishes on Hollywood Foibles
description: Shanna Mahins Oh! You Pretty Things falls into the gofers-revenge genre, to which The Devil Wears Prada and The Nanny Diaries also belong. But the difference lies in location, and in this case location is everything. Ms. Mahins debut novel is set in Hollywood, which she uses less to denote a geographical location than a state of mind. Its that clichd but ever-trendy place with two castes: the rich, beautiful, famous types and the yes-people who do their bidding.

title: Julie Kent Looks Effortless in Ballet and Beauty
description: The ballerina Julie Kent joined the American Ballet Theater in 1985, was anointed a principal dancer eight years later, and will be retiring her pointe shoes after this season. With A.B.T. celebrating its 75th anniversary, Ms. Kent, 45, is slated to dance in Pillar of Fire, Othello, Giselle and Romeo and Juliet. Her role as Juliet on June 20 will be her farewell performance. Born in Bethesda, Md., she lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Victor Barbee, associate artistic director of A.B.T.; her son, William, 11; and her daughter, Josephine, 5.

title: Cody Wilson, Who Posted Gun Instructions Online, Sues State Department
description: When is a gun not just a gun? When its also constitutionally protected free speech.

title: Chuck Close, Collaborating in a Big Way
description: A new exhibit of Chuck Closes photos shows not just mastery of everything from daguerreotypes to 20x24 Polaroid images, but also his penchant for collaboration.

title: Andrew M. Cuomo: Fast-Food Workers Deserve a Raise
description: ALBANY  INCOME inequality is a national problem that leaders at all levels of government are grappling with. While American capitalism never guaranteed success, it did once guarantee opportunity. But today, too many Americans dont believe their children will have a better life than their own. The ideal of mobility has been replaced by the reality of stagnation.

title: Ciaras New Album Jackie Shows a Singer Evolving
description: For more than a decade, Ciara has been a stalwart of the R&B margins. At the beginning of her career, she was more a rhythm instrument than a singer  a high-energy, sleek dancer with chilly songs to match. That approach has sustained, but not nourished, her. Shes long been an unremarkable vocalist, meaning shes been more memorable for delivery than content, for pulse over feeling. Her best songs  including 1, 2, Step, and Ride  were often about literal movement, but almost never about what was happening on the inside.

title: Hot Pursuit and Other Films Elevate the Art of the Blooper Reel
description: When directors first began attaching blooper reels to their films end credits in the late 1970s and early 80s, there really wasnt much to them. Actors flubbed a line or several, or laughed when they shouldnt have. In the 1979 comedy-drama Being There, one of the pioneers of the tradition, Peter Sellers struggles for three minutes to get through three lines. In Smokey and the Bandit II the following year, Burt Reynolds forgets lines and trips over others; in one scene, he mistakenly says dialogue written for a co-star, Sally Field. Back then, watching actors botch their parts was still such a novelty that the reels didnt have to do much, or be much, to make audiences laugh.

title: Premature Babies May Survive at 22 Weeks if Treated, Study Finds
description: A small number of very premature babies are surviving earlier outside the womb than doctors once thought possible, a new study has documented, raising questions about how aggressively they should be treated and posing implications for the debate about abortion.

title: Mosque Installed at Venice Biennale Tests Citys Tolerance
description: VENICE  The 18th-century novelist William Beckford wrote that he couldnt help thinking of this citys most beloved sight, St. Marks Basilica, as a mosque, with its pinnacles and semicircular arches all so oriental in appearance. But despite the profound stamp that Islamic culture has left on Venices art and architecture over centuries, it remains one of the few prominent European cities without a mosque near its historic center, leaving Islamic residents who work there to pray in storerooms and shops amid the tourist crush.

title: Hillary Clinton Embraces a Super PAC, Trying to Erode a Republican Edge
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin personally courting donors for a super PAC supporting her candidacy, the first time a Democratic presidential candidate has fully embraced these independent groups that can accept unlimited checks from big donors and are already playing a major role in the 2016 race.

title: High-End Culture Comes to Shopping Malls
description: Kathy Row took a look at the discreetly lettered sign pointing her to The Fashion Project. Her curiosity piqued, she trotted up the three flights of stairs to the top of the mall in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Head of Goldman Sachss Venture Capital and Clean-Tech Groups to Retire
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The head of Goldman Sachss venture capital and clean-technology teams, Stuart Bernstein, plans to retire from the firm at the end of June, the bank announced in an internal memorandum on Wednesday.

title: Proposed Design Changes to the Four Seasons Prompt an Outcry
description: With its sleek elegance and white marble pool of bubbling water, the Four Seasons restaurant in the landmark Seagram Building has long been considered an architectural gem  not to mention a haunt for the likes of Henry A. Kissinger and Madonna.

title: Rihanna and Madonna Make Costume Changes for the Met Gala After-Parties
description: After the red carpet, the cocktails, the exhibition and the dinner, the Met Gala splintered into after-parties. It was an opportunity to change outfits.

title: Rita Wilson Talks About Cancer Surgery and Returning to Broadway
description: When Rita Wilson told Larry David, her co-star in the Broadway play Fish in the Dark, that she had breast cancer and needed to take a month off for a double mastectomy, he sank down into the sofa and put his head in his hands.

title: Signs of Higher Oil and Gas Prices as Stockpiles Dwindle
description: HOUSTON  Oil and gasoline prices have been on a ferocious rebound over the last month, and there were signs on Wednesday that declining domestic inventories could mean still higher prices as the summer driving season approaches.

title: Mike Huckabee Strikes Populist Stance in Iowa Factory Visit
description: OSKALOOSA, Iowa  In announcing his presidential candidacy, Mike Huckabee on Tuesday pledged to champion men who sweat through their clothes at work but whose wages have stagnated for decades.

title: Barcelonas Lionel Messi Carves Up Bayern Munich in Champions League Semifinals
description: BARCELONA, Spain  He knew. Of course he knew. Pep Guardiola spent four remarkable years as the coach at Barcelona, won 14 trophies at Barcelona, saw Lionel Messi score more than 200 goals for Barcelona. When Guardiola, who now coaches Bayern Munich, said Tuesday that Messi was unstoppable, it was not hyperbole. It was simply the truth from a man who could not lie.

title: Buyer of Goldwyn Picasso Is a Chinese Movie Mogul
description: Hollywoods power base has been shifting to China, and now its art is headed there, too: Wang Zhongjun, a Chinese movie tycoon, was the mystery buyer at Sothebys on Tuesday of a Picasso portrait owned for nearly seven decades by one of Hollywoods royal families.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: Still looking for the perfect gift for Mom? Me&Ro has a heart and anchor pendant in recycled sterling silver ($165) and 18-karat gold ($1,475) from which all of the net proceeds benefit the Sloane Hospital for Women at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center. At 241 Elizabeth Street.

title: China: Through the Looking Glass
description: A look at the new show at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: In Nepal, a Brothers Desperate Search
description: One of thousands of Nepalese struggling to find a friend or relative after the April 25 earthquake, Bishow Ram Shrestha went from hospital to hospital looking for Sita, his 27-year-old sister.

title: Zynga Is Trimming Its Staff and Its Game Ambitions
description: Zynga said on Wednesday that it would cut its work force by 18 percent and leave the sports video-game category, moves meant to narrow its business and improve the quality of its video games.

title: Cuomo Moves to Raise Wages for New York Fast-Food Workers
description: Frustrated by his inability to persuade lawmakers in Albany to raise the statewide minimum wage, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says he will try a different approach to raise the pay of thousands of fast-food workers.

title: Fewer Limbs but Healthier Trees as New Yorks Parks Budget Rebounds
description: A tree trimmer with a chain saw moved up and down the trunk of the London plane in a bucket one recent afternoon, lopping off rotted branches and pruning boughs hovering over the sidewalk. Suddenly, a resident leaned out her second-story window and exhorted him in Italian to remove a branch that almost brushed the building.

title: Pandora Wins Appeals Court Ruling on Ascap Royalty Rates
description: In Pandora Medias second victory against the music industry in a week, a federal appeals court affirmed a judges ruling about royalty rates for the millions of songs represented by Ascap.

title: Putting Out the Welcome Mat for China
description: Last year, Chinese travelers ventured abroad more than 100 million times, according to estimates from the European Travel Commission, not only helping it surpass the United States as the worlds leading source of tourism but also affirming that China is a leading force in business travel as well.

title: Traditional Geishas Entertain Western Guests
description: KYOTO, Japan  Wearing a pearl gray kimono, Reiko Tomimori, 62, bows deeply while greeting guests to Ochaya Tomikiku, her teahouse in the Gion district. Then she escorts them to a room on the second floor where geishas or soon-to-be geishas, who are called maikos, entertain them.

title: In a Car-Obsessed City, Learning to Love Mass Transit
description: LOS ANGELES  For the estimated 6.6 million people who visit here each year for business purposes, a good mass transit system could mean less frustration and fewer hours spent in the citys legendary freeway jams.

title: Photos of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Nepal, Philippines, South Korea and South Africa.

title: May 6, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Nepal, Philippines, South Korea and South Africa.

title: 21st Century Fox Posts Lower Profit on Flat Revenue
description: LOS ANGELES  Quarterly profit declined at 21st Century Fox as continuing struggles at the Fox broadcast network, higher sports costs and unfavorable foreign exchange rates combined to overshadow strength in movies and climbing cable fees.

title: The Fed Does Not Control the Money Supply
description: Brad DeLong points us to David Glasner on John Taylor; I dont think I need to add to the pile-on. But I do think Glasner misses a point when he says that

title: Conspiracy Theories Over Jade Helm Training Exercise Get Some Traction in Texas
description: DALLAS  The questions being raised by right-wing bloggers and conservative commentators about a Pentagon training exercise called Jade Helm 15 traverse the outer edges of political paranoia.

title: U.S.-Iran Tensions Appear to Ease in Strait of Hormuz
description: The United States and Iran appeared to be pulling back on Wednesday from any possible confrontation in the Strait of Hormuz, a critical Persian Gulf oil-shipping passage, a week after Iranian forces impounded a cargo vessel there at gunpoint.

title: Gates Foundation Plans Teams to Determine Causes of Child Mortality
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation plans to create a network of disease-surveillance teams in poor countries to do minimal autopsies on children to plumb causes of child mortality and also possibly spot emerging epidemics, the foundation announced Wednesday.

title: A Lift From Oil Prices
description: Airlines are reaping a tremendous windfall from falling oil prices, but travelers should not expect to share in their gains anytime soon  at least not in terms of lower airfares.

title: To Cuba on Business
description: Since President Obama moved to normalize relations with Cuba in December, you might think the nation has put out a big Open for Business sign. Trade delegations seem to land in Havana every day. But traveling there for business is not as easy as it might appear, despite significant changes.

title: How Many Stars for the Wi-Fi?
description: A few years ago, Yaroslav Goncharov was head of the mobile department at Yandex, Russias largest search engine, and traveling the globe for meetings with device manufacturers, wireless carriers and other companies Yandex did business with.

title: The Power Grab at Airports Has a New Headache
description: Anyone who has ever been desperate to charge a mobile device at an airport knows the feeling of frustration that can arise from trying to find something thats been around for more than 100 years: an electric outlet.

title: Loyalty Program Rules Arent Ironclad
description: Along with all the other paperwork that comes with being newly widowed, Roberta Bekerman had to persuade Delta Air Lines that she was entitled to inherit her husbands frequent-flier miles.

title: A Room With a View of the Runway
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As a student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Frank Welborn used to spend some evenings just outside the gates of the Raleigh-Durham airport watching airliners land. It was pretty exciting, he said. Later, after he had become a pilot with FedEx, he would request an airfield view at any hotel that offered one, Hilton Chicago OHare Airport being a favorite.

title: How Britains Election Stumped Pollsters and the Betting Markets
description: UPDATE, May 7: A small movement in the political betting markets in recent hours makes David Cameron, the Conservative Party leader, the slight favorite to be returned as prime minister. Most British bookies give Mr. Cameron about a 51 to 52 percent chance.

title: Oculus to Ship Virtual Reality Headsets in Early 2016
description: Early next year, consumers will finally be able to buy the Oculus virtual reality headgear that so impressed Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook that he spent $2 billion to buy the company.

title: At the Epicenter of Nepal Earthquake, Rising From the Rubble
description: Barpak, Nepal, was the epicenter of the Nepal earthquake on April 25, which left more than 7,000 people dead and many more trapped under debris.

title: More Land in Colombia Used to Grow Coca, U.S. Says
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The amount of land in Colombia used to grow coca, the plant that drug traffickers use to make cocaine, increased significantly last year, according to an annual survey by the United States government.

title: Daniel Loeb Strikes Back Against Buffetts Criticism of Hedge Funds
description: LAS VEGAS  To many Americans, the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett is the Oracle of Omaha. To another billionaire investor, Daniel S. Loeb, he is a hypocrite.

title: Acrimony in Albany as Senate Republicans Stop Effort to Oust Skelos
description: ALBANY  Democrats walked out of the New York State Senate in protest on Wednesday after Republicans blocked their effort to oust the majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, following his arrest on federal corruption charges.

title: New Charlie Hebdo Issue Skewers PEN Critics
description: Since the news broke last week that six writers had withdrawn from PEN American Centers annual gala to protest an award to the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, social media and op-ed pages around the world have been flooded with debate about free speech, blasphemy and anti-Muslim prejudice.

title: U.N. Wants to Let Europe Use Military Force to Stop Migrant Smuggling Boats
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council plans to put forth a draft resolution that would authorize Europe to use military force to stop migrant smuggling boats that set off from Libya across the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the Continents resolve to stanch the tide of migrants fleeing the Middle East and North Africa.

title: Tom Bradys Legacy as One of the Best Takes a Hit
description: To find out if the New England Patriots knowingly used deflated footballs during the A.F.C. championship game in January, the N.F.L. hired lawyers and physics geniuses and investigators who dug so deeply that it seemed they were investigating a federal crime.

title: Ex-Prisons Official Testifies in Boston in Defense Effort to Spare Life of Bomber
description: BOSTON  In case the jury in the Boston Marathon bombing trial has been wondering, vacancies exist in the most secure cellblock at the remote supermax penitentiary in Colorado, the toughest, bleakest prison in the federal system.

title: Losses Widen at Tesla, but Company Says Production Is on Track
description: Tesla Motors reported a larger first-quarter loss on Wednesday, but it was still smaller than analysts forecast and the company appeared to be on track for important production milestones.

title: Marcia Brown, 96, Dies; Book Illustrator Won Three Caldecott Medals
description: Marcia Brown, a childrens book illustrator who was a three-time winner of the Caldecott Medal, her fields highest honor, died on April 28 at her home in Laguna Hills, Calif. She was 96.

title: In the End, Science Works Against the Patriots
description: The laws of physics worked in favor of the New England Patriots when a football spiraled into the arms of one of their players at the end of the Super Bowl. But those same laws could not save the Patriots from the conclusion that they almost certainly tampered with footballs  by improperly deflating them  to help the team win an earlier playoff game.

title: Errol Brown, 71, Dies; Wrote and Sang Disco Hit You Sexy Thing
description: Errol Brown, the lead singer for the British band Hot Chocolate and the writer of the bands indelible disco hit You Sexy Thing, which returned to the pop charts when it was featured in the comedy The Full Monty, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bahamas. He was 71.

title: Aid Needs in Yemen Are Dire, Kerry Says
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry said Wednesday that a humanitarian crisis in Yemen was growing more dire by the day and that he would discuss plans with officials in Saudi Arabia to halt the Saudi-led bombing campaign in order to allow the delivery of food, medicine and other aid.

title: Alexion Puts Its Soaring Stock Price to Good Use
description: Alexion Pharmaceuticals is putting its high-flying stock to good use. The drugmakers $8.4 billion offer for its rival Synageva BioPharma includes an astonishing 136 percent premium. The price is based on the rare disease specialists view that investors underestimate its targets value. Exchanging a chunk of expensive paper for those assets may be a savvy move.

title: Thomas A. Constantine Dies at 76; Led N.Y. State Police and U.S. Drug Agency
description: Thomas A. Constantine, a former chief of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration and the first uniformed trooper in three decades to rise through the ranks to become superintendent of the New York State Police, died on Sunday at a hospice in Pinehurst, N.C., where he had a winter home. He was 76.

title: Ukraine: Soldiers Die in Strife in the Separatist East
description: Ukrainian military officials said Wednesday that five soldiers had been killed and 12 wounded in fighting in the separatist east, casting further doubt on the prospects for a months-old cease-fire that has never fully taken hold. Four soldiers died when their vehicle carrier drove over a mine in Avdiivka, a town just north of Donetsk, the rebel capital, and the fifth in an ambush, a military spokesman, Andriy Lysenko, said. The fighting flared as envoys prepared to meet in Minsk, the Belarusian capital, for talks on better implementing the agreement. Those talks broke up inconclusively on Wednesday evening. Ukraines envoy, former President Leonid Kuchma, said the participants had not touched on Ukrainian requests that an outside peacekeeping force be deployed to the region, though that had been on the agenda.

title: Now the Pressure Is on Roger Goodell. Poor Commissioner.
description: Perhaps weve reached the point where it is officially permissible to feel a quiver of pity for Roger Goodell.

title: Elton Simpson Eluded U.S. Inquiry Before Texas Shootout
description: WASHINGTON  From 2006 to 2009, long before he would briefly become infamous, Elton Simpson spent many hours sitting in the Kabob Palace, a Phoenix restaurant, earnestly explaining Islam to a Sudanese friend who said he had converted to the faith.

title: W.H.O. Officials Report a Drop in New Ebola Cases
description: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new cases in the West Africa Ebola epidemic this year, calling it an encouraging development but expressing caution about complacency until all infections from the highly contagious virus have been eradicated. In an update posted on the organizations website, it reported 18 confirmed Ebola cases for the week ended last Sunday  nine each in Guinea and Sierra Leone. In Liberia, the third country that has been ravaged by Ebola, the patient with the last confirmed case died on March 27 and was buried on March 28. If no new cases are reported through Saturday, 42 days from that burial, the outbreak will be declared officially over in Liberia. The number of deaths from the Ebola outbreak, which began more than a year ago, totaled at least 11,005 as of Sunday, the update said.

title: Reports Author Is Former Football Player Known Best as Trial Lawyer
description: Over the course of his nearly 40-year legal career, Theodore V. Wells Jr. has defended a cross section of Washington politicians and Wall Street financiers, becoming one of the best-known trial lawyers in public corruption and insider trading cases. In recent months, his focus shifted to a much different sort of wrongdoing: deflated footballs.

title: Chicago to Pay $5 Million to Victims of Police Abuse
description: CHICAGO  For decades, they had waited for an apology. This group of black men, some now graying and bent by age, had complained of violent abuse at the hands of the police in the 1970s and 80s on this citys South Side. They said they had been suffocated with plastic bags, beaten with phone books, shocked with cattle prods  torture tactics meant to extract confessions to crimes.

title: After Nepal Quake, Searching for a Sister
description: Bishow Ram Shrestha was one of thousands of Nepalese struggling to find a friend or relative after the April 25 earthquake. His mission was to locate Sita, his 27-year-old sister, who was married and had a 2-year-old daughter.

title: University of Mary Washington, Where Woman Was Killed, Faces Scrutiny
description: When Grace Rebecca Mann, a popular junior and outspoken feminist at the University of Mary Washington in Virginia, was killed in April, her death was treated as not only a tragedy but a mystery. The police quickly apprehended a suspect, Ms. Manns housemate, but her friends and family were at a loss to explain the motive.

title: Caddies Get Their Shot Before Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  George McNeill stood behind his caddie, Ernie Rose, as Rose bent over his ball, waggling McNeills 9-iron. It was the Wednesday practice round at TPC Sawgrass, and Rose was taking aim at the island green of the signature 17th hole, a par 3 that was playing 134 yards into the wind.

title: Reducing Ones Carbon Footprint
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  This just goes to show you that absolutely nothing good can come from changing up your solving routine. I kid, of course. Its a good thing to try new methods, but I do have a point to make here. Somewhere.

title: Harlem Boy, 12, Fatally Struck by Livery Cab
description: A 12-year-old boy was fatally hit by a livery cab as he crossed the street near his school in Manhattan on Wednesday, the police said.

title: To Avoid Last Years Problems, Belmont Attendance to Be Capped
description: If the hospitality at last years Kentucky Derby was a disappointment for the winners owners, the 2014 Belmont Stakes was a disappointment for nearly everyone else. Long lines at concession stands and betting windows, a lack of food and drinks late in the day, a shortage of ushers and transportation blunders after the race left many unsatisfied.

title: Mayor de Blasios Budget Commits $100 Million to Combat Homelessness in New York
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio began his Wednesday morning discussing income inequality on MSNBC and ended it with the publication of an op-ed in The Washington Post. In between, a largely sympathetic profile landed in Rolling Stone, outlining his push for a national platform.

title: Pope Approves Sainthood for Missionary
description: The Vatican announced Wednesday that Pope Francis had given his approval to the decision to canonize the Rev. Junipero Serra, an 18th-century missionary who brought Christianity to the American Indians along the West Coast. Some Native Americans have questioned Father Serras saintly nature, saying that Father Serra, a Franciscan missionary, imposed Christianity even as he suppressed local culture and traditions. Others have accused Father Serra of mistreating Indians. The pope said in January that he would celebrate Father Serras canonization Mass in Washington during his trip to the United States in September.

title: Mayor de Blasios Plan Aims to Spur More Affordable Housing in New York
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is calling for an overhaul of housing programs and tax incentives to spur the construction of tens of thousands of apartments for poor New Yorkers, as well as teachers, firefighters and other workers, who increasingly find themselves priced out of a booming real estate market and rapidly gentrifying neighborhoods.

title: Yankees Are the Ones to Buckle as an 11-Year Drought Ends for Buehrle
description: TORONTO  The disappearance of Amelia Earhart, the construction of Stonehenge and the publics fascination with the Kardashians are among the worlds great unresolved mysteries. No longer on that list is one of baseballs curiosities: Mark Buehrles drought against the Yankees.

title: Primer: The 2015 British Elections
description: An overview of the current British government and how it may change following the election.

title: Chicago Pays for Past Pain
description: Chicagos City Council approved $5.5 million in reparations for a group of black men tortured by the police in the 1970s and 80s under the watch of a notorious police commander, Jon Burge.

title: A Step Slow, the Rangers Have a Foot Out the Door
description: WASHINGTON  The light behind Henrik Lundqvist flashed red, the same color as the wardrobe of all those fans screaming and stomping their feet, and the same color as the jerseys of all those Washington Capitals reveling along the boards.

title: Jacob deGrom Bounces Back, and Mets Gain a Sweep
description: It was still early, but the situation was certainly unsettling: fifth inning, bases loaded, two outs, two-run lead, and Chris Davis, the Baltimore Orioles slugger, stood at home plate.

title: Yoko Ono Trusts You Not to Break This One Espresso Cup
description: Yoko Ono is the latest artist whose designs will grace a set of espresso cups for illy, the Italian coffee company. Timed to the debut of Yoko Ono: One Woman Show, 1960-1971, which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on May 17, they were inspired by Kintsugi, a Japanese method of fixing broken pottery using powdered metals (gold, silver, platinum, bronze or aluminum) mixed with water and lacquer. Onos designs have the look of Kintsugi, with fine gold lines used to mimic a shattering effect, and each saucer features a sentence marking a shattering event in her life, with the name of the event and the date. They include the My Lai Massacre (March 16, 1968), the bombing of Dresden during World War II (Feb. 13, 1945) and John Lennons death in New York (Dec. 8, 1980). The set of seven ($250) will be available at the MoMA design shop beginning tomorrow  and one plain white cup, with a saucer bearing the words This cup will never be broken as it will be under your protection, will be sold separately for $40.

title: A Cheeky Peek Into the Life of Simon Porte Jacquemus
description: Being a modernist with the heart of a child informs the sunny, slightly off-kilter fashion of the up-and-coming French designer.

title: Striking Images of Painters Palettes
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Gone Girl
description: Languid days of sea and sun  and very little else.

title: Producers Turn to Indiegogo to Finance Orson Welless Final Film
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Add a few more twists to the decades-long quest to release The Other Side of the Wind, the unfinished final film of Orson Welles.

title: Word of the Day | indicative
description: indicative  \in-di-k-tiv\  adjective and noun

title: Company Creates Bioethics Panel on Trial Drugs
description: Johnson & Johnson has appointed a nationally known bioethicist to create a panel that will make decisions about patients requests for potentially lifesaving medicine, responding to an emotional debate over whether companies should allow desperately ill people to have access to the drugs before they are approved.

title: Eager to Opine on the Toughest Calls in Medical Ethics
description: Arthur Caplan is not a medical doctor, but he has made a successful career offering his opinion to physicians, institutions and the news media about doctors and how they should act.

title: Victoria Azarenka Falls to Serena Williams After a Potential Ace Sails Wide
description: MADRID  It was a narrow escape  a matter of three centimeters wide of the line, Serena Williams said Wednesday.

title: Clippers Put Up a Fight Without Chris Paul, but Rockets Win a Foul-Marred Game
description: HOUSTON  Lester Hudson and Hedo Turkoglu playing important minutes in Game 2 of a Western Conference semifinal series was never the part of the grand plan for the Los Angeles Clippers. But it was their realityWednesdaynight against the Houston Rockets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is our country, just like anyone elses country.

title: Corrections: May 7, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Chuck Close, Collaborating in a Big Way
description: Not every photograph Chuck Close makes ends up as a painting, but every painting Chuck Close creates starts out with a photograph. And while there are certain rules about which photos become paintings  family and friends take precedence  its also evident that he has experimented with many techniques, from the 19th-century Woodburytype, daguerreotype and Jacquard tapestry, to the large-scale Polaroid and modern-day hologram.

title: Transportation Emerges as Crucial to Escaping Poverty
description: James Baker was pedaling to work along a slick, snow-covered road in Frederick County, Md., when a traffic light changed abruptly. He braked and skidded to the ground, unhurt but making a mess of his clothes before a long day of work and school.

title: Albanys Worst Offense
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Bill de Blasios Subway Complaint
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Biased Brains
description: To better understand the roots of racial division in America, think about this:

title: Battle Over a Bill: Mayor Landrieu vs. Governor Jindal
description: To the Editor:

title: Reducing Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond the Demon Sheep
description: Do you want the next president to be somebody who brags about not being a politician?

title: Homeless in New York City, an Unending Crisis
description: The crisis of homelessness that ballooned under Mayor Michael Bloomberg shows no signs of deflating anytime soon under his successor, Bill de Blasio. Nearly 57,000 people were sleeping in city shelters at last count, 24,000 of them children. It was a disaster then. It is a disaster now.

title: Futility Care: Hard Medical Choices at the End of Life
Hillary Clinton Takes the Lead on Immigration
description: With her speech on immigration in Las Vegas on Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton took a large step forward, up front and to the left of President Obama. That is a good place to be for a presidential candidate who proposes to get the stalled debate moving again, and to bring hope to the millions living here outside the law.

title: ArcelorMittal Cuts Profit Expectations for the Year
description: ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter as a recovery in Europe failed to offset a sharp drop in prices for iron ore and steel.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Patriots, With Tom Bradys Knowledge, Likely Deflated Footballs, Report Says
description: In Patriots, With Tom Bradys Knowledge, Likely Deflated Footballs, Report Says, Ken Belson writes about a long-anticipated N.F.L. investigation.

title: Test Yourself | The First Espresso in Space
description: Below, several paragraphs from the May 4 article Espresso? Now the International Space Station Is Fully Equipped.

title: Alabama May Turn to the Gambling It Has Long Fought
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  After years of crackdowns, police raids, Bible Belt oratory and admonitions about corruption, Alabama lawmakers have had a change of heart. They are now seeking fiscal salvation at the casino.

title: Something Between Brooklyn and the Bronx
description: Carlos P. Naudons apartment-hunting priority was a quick trip to work. That meant a location near a northbound entrance to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: Review: In China: Through the Looking Glass, Eastern Culture Meets Western Fashion
description: The Costume Institute is housed within the Metropolitan Museum of Art but exists in a separate universe, one with its own galleries, budget, press representative and aesthetic protocols. To some this fashion-world apart is a Martian oddity, to others it is a vital preserve of Venusian luxe. Either way  and for better and worse  it has never been as fully integrated with the Met as it is in the exhibition that opened this week called China: Through the Looking Glass.

title: Suddenly, Tehrans Mayor Becomes a Patron of the Arts
description: TEHRAN  The mayor of Tehran, Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf, is well known in Iran as a former Revolutionary Guards commander, retired pilot and the loser of two presidential elections. This week he added one more title  patron of the arts  as he directed all of the citys 1,500 billboards fitted out with copies of famous works of art, including many by prominent Western artists.

title: Google, Dominant in Search, Tries Disruptor Role in Wireless and Broadband
description: Call it the Google paradox.

title: A Part-Timer Whose Work for the Patriots Was Sure Noticed
description: Imagine this Massachusetts moment. Kickoff for the A.F.C. championship game between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts is minutes away. Gillette Stadium is packed, while another 40 million fans are waiting by their televisions. The winner goes to the Super Bowl.

title: Do We Still Need Libraries?
description: Libraries have played an important role in this country, helping generations of immigrants, young people, job seekers and readers to learn, stay connected and get ahead in life. Offering access to free books, newspapers and, later, computers, they opened up a world of knowledge and ideas for millions of people. But now, with information literally at our fingertips on smartphones and tablets, are libraries still important?

title: Telecity of Britain Receives Bid From Data Center Provider Equinix
description: LONDON  The British data center provider Telecity Group said on Thursday that it was reviewing a cash-and-stock takeover bid from its much bigger American rival Equinix.

title: Maggie Nelsons The Argonauts
description: To become a mother is to learn, among many other things, that mothers are treated as both central and peripheral to American culture. The most important job in the world is such a sentimental truism that even women who dont want to have children report having to explain themselves to incredulous busybodies. Yet actual mothering is accorded little social or economic value beyond hazy reverence and pious declarations. Mothers are allowed some authority when it comes to their homes, their children and their bodies; their domain is one of domestic necessity, which is supposed to stand in mute contrast to the wider world of work, of ideas, of rationality, of free will.

title: Senate Easily Passes Bill for a Voice on Iran Nuclear Accord
description: WASHINGTON  A bill that would give Congress a voice in any nuclear agreement between world powers and Iran passed the Senate overwhelmingly on Thursday, a rare bipartisan accord to curb executive authority in an era of expanding presidential power.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Siemens Announces Layoffs as Slump in Oil Price Hurts Sales
description: FRANKFURT  Siemens, the German industrial giant, said on Thursday that it would cut 4,500 jobs as it reacts to a slump in oil prices that has eroded its sales of equipment to the energy industry.

title: Benjamin Netanyahus Last-Minute Government Puts Him in Tenuous Position
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu led his conservative Likud Party to a major victory over its chief rival, the center-left Zionist Union, in the March 17 elections. But the fractured mosaic of Israeli politics has kept him from translating that victory into a solid grip on power.

title: New York Today: Name That Specimen
description: Good morning on this brilliant Thursday.

title: Throwback Thursday | May the Fourth: Star Wars Day
description: Did you celebrate Star Wars Day on Monday? Here, according to StarWars.com, is how the tradition began:

title: China to Russia: Putin Is a Hunk. Now, About Those Gas Prices.
description: Propaganda posters are so 1955. Six decades after legions of Soviet engineers swarmed over China, helping build steel mills, oil refineries and aircraft factories, theres a new way to trumpet ties between the two giant neighbors.

title: Molefi Kete Asante: Why Afrocentricity?
description: This is the 11th in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Molefi Kete Asante, a professor of African-American studies at Temple University, known for his pioneering work in the area of Afrocentricity. He is the author of more than 70 books, including As I Run Toward Africa, a memoir.  George Yancy

title: A Conversation About Growing Up Black
description: In this short documentary, young black men explain the particular challenges they face growing up in America.

title: A Small Child, a Big Board, on Oahus North Shore
description: Standing cross-armed on the beach, stiff with anticipation, I watched as my little towheaded son made his first solo ride on a surfboard. Jacopo scrambled to his feet shakily, the wave propelling him toward us, and then, as his toothpick legs set into a wider, firmer stance, he determinedly stood up to his full three-and-a-half-foot self, a huge smile taking over his whole face. Back on the shoreline, my own expression reflected his joy. He was just a week shy of his fifth birthday, and Id brought him here, to the fabled North Shore of Oahu, specifically so that he could have his first lesson with none other than Garrett McNamara, one of the worlds most famous surfers. I am still not sure who was more excited.

title: The Accidental Winemakers of Mendoza
description: On a hot summer afternoon in the Uco Valley, south of Mendoza, Argentina, last December, six of us gathered for a wine blending of malbec, cabernet franc and syrah grapes that had been harvested nine months earlier. Our task: to decide what to do with the juice that had been aging in oak barrels for several months.

title: Snoop Dogg Has More Than Money on His Mind
description: You have a new album, Bush, coming out this month, and theres more singing than rapping on it. Its very funk-inspired. Why the change? Theres a void for that style of music. I think if rap never came out, Id have been a R&B singer. I would have been like Rick James, though  an edgy renegade.

title: The Cost of Getting Kicked in the Face
description: This happened in June 1997. It was around 2 in the morning. I was walking home, alone, from a party at a friends house. As I walked, I looked at the streetlights above, first with one eye closed, then the other, and it was as though the streetlights were winking at me. Id been doing this for several blocks, long enough that the whole exercise had turned from time-passing to tiresome, but I kept doing because it seemed like bad luck to stop. I was drunk, obviously, although not very, just relatively  just a relatively drunk 28-year-old man who was in relatively good shape, feeling relatively happy. I had, at that time, a good head of hair, and a mouthful of good teeth. Out of all that information, only the last bit is especially relevant to this story.

title: Today in Politics: A Distant Finish Line in a Crowded Republican Race
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington. President Obama leaves for Oregon for his third Democratic fund-raiser of the week, while some New York politicians are making national news. As for Republicans, the number of candidates and changes to the nomination calendar could make for a protracted fight.

title: Shady Schools, Serious Debt
Poetry Pairing | The Garden by Moonlight
description: This Poetry Pairing, our last for the 2014-15 school year, features Amy Lowells poem The Garden by Moonlight and the article Plants With Roots Attached by Michael Tortorello.

title: The Conversation: Viewers Weigh In With Their Stories About Race in America
description: The people and perspectives featured in each short video are only the beginning.

title: A Conversation About Growing Up Black
description: Imagine strangers crossing the street to avoid you, imagine the police arbitrarily stopping you, imagine knowing people fear you because of the color of your skin. Many of this countrys young black men and boys dont have to imagine.

title: Hillary Clinton Shows New Willingness to Tackle Risky Issues
description: It has been only three weeks since Hillary Rodham Clinton  declared her candidacy for the White House, but she already looks more confident than she did during the almost 17 months of her last campaign.

title: A Parade Hailing Russias World War II Dead and Marching Further From the West
description: MOSCOW  The Russian version of Hitlers defeat emphasizes the enormous, unrivaled sacrifices made by the Soviet people to end World War II, so the country has long staged a colossal military parade on May 9 to recognize Victory Day as the most important event in Russian history.

title: Alibaba Names New Chief Executive and Reports Revenue Rise
description: HONG KONG  Before Alibaba raised $25 billion in an initial public offering last year, its founder, Jack Ma, said he did not care much about share prices.

title: Morning Agenda: Some Choice Words for Buffett
description: SOME CHOICE WORDS FOR BUFFETT | When the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb decides to take on corporate chieftains, he usually does it in the form of a scathing letter to them. On Wednesday, however, he used the spotlight at the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference in Las Vegas to issue some pointed remarks about Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire Hathaways chief executive,  Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook. Mr. Loeb, who runs the $17.4 billion hedge fund Third Point, was aiming at Mr. Buffetts takedown of hedge funds during Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting last weekend, during which Mr. Buffett pointed out that the S.&P. 500 had gained 63.5 percent since 2008, while an index of hedge funds had increased by 19.6 percent over the same period.

title: The Price of Nice Nails
description: The women begin to arrive just before 8 a.m., every day and without fail, until there are thickets of young Asian and Hispanic women on nearly every street corner along the main roads of Flushing, Queens.

title: Review: In Grace and Frankie on Netflix, Comedy Enters a New Age
description: People who complain about aging sound old. But Grace and Frankie is a senior angst comedy that somehow doesnt seem fusty and out of date.

title: Un trabajo tan duro como las uas
description: Todos los das las mujeres aparecen un poco antes de las 8 a.m. hasta que casi cada esquina de las calles principales de Flushing, en Queens, se llenan de jvenes asiticas e hispanas. Como si obedecieran una orden, llegan retumbando una procesin de maltrechas camionetas Ford Econoline para ser abordadas por las trabajadoras.

title: Something Rotten in New York City Nail Salons
description: Sarah Maslin Nir spent 13 months investigating workplace conditions in New York City nail salons. The two-part series appeared in The Times this week.

title: Deprived by DC
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Sixth Annual New York Times Summer Reading Contest
description: Every year since 2010 we have invited teenagers to add The New York Times to their summer reading lists, and every year more and more have taken us up on the offer.

title: Exit Poll Sees Gains for Britains Conservatives, but No Clear Winner
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Camerons Conservative Party was projected by a national exit poll to have done well in the British general election on Thursday, but the nation still faced the possibility that there would be no outright winner.

title: China Rebukes U.S. Over Criticism of Civil Rights Lawyers Detention
description: BEIJING  After criticism from the United States over the detention of a civil rights lawyer in China, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said on Thursday that Washington should address human rights problems at home and stop trying to be the worlds policeman or judge.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Taking a Stand
description: The Challenge: A 23-year-old woman slowly becomes so weak that she has difficulty getting up out of a chair. Strangely so does her twin. Can you figure out why?

title: Kimmel Will Not Broadcast New Episode Opposite Letterman Finale
description: How do you say goodbye to the late-night host who has long been a source of inspiration, but who happens to anchor a directly competing program?

title: Daily Report: Alibaba Names New Chief Executive and Reports Revenue Rise
description: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba said Thursday that its revenue grew 45 percent compared with last year, meeting expectations, but it announced a new chief executive in the wake of concerns about inefficiency, Paul Mozur writes.

title: Review: Mariah Carey and Her Cant-Look-Away Debut in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  You watch the crash because you want to see how it will end: near miss or carnage, relief or horror, laughter or tears. Part of the appeal is the feeling of helplessness  you are a viewer, but not an agent. Whatever happens, youll be affected, but you cant chart the course. And looking away is never the right choice.

title: Iowans Unfazed by Criticism of Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has faced a flurry of bad publicity since announcing her presidential bidlast month, but Democrats in Iowa do not appear to be bothered by any of the criticism.

title: Welfare Warfare in the Missouri Statehouse
description: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri made his veto message as blunt as possible last week when he rejected the Republican legislatures welfare crackdown plan that would end federal benefits for an estimated 9,500 recipients  three out of five of them children  in the first year. I dont sign bills that hurt kids  period, Governor Nixon, a Democrat, declared in vetoing legislation he described as a mean-spirited attempt to force adults off public assistance by focusing on their children.

title: Fashion in the Skies
description: Designers have long played a role in keeping airline crews stylishly attired.

title: John Ashbery: By the Book
description: The poet, whose latest collection is Breezeway, enjoys reading novels. Im no doubt a frustrated novelist. Maybe I should try, but at barely three months shy of 88 it seems unlikely.

title: With Delta, Zac Posen Becomes New Yorks Busiest Designer
description: Forget double-dipping, that fashion practice of running your own line while also designing for another, as exemplified by Alexander Wang (his own line and Balenciaga), Jeremy Scott (his own and Moschino), Jonathan Anderson (his own and Loewe) and so on. Zac Posen, the 34-year-old New York designer, is quintuple-dipping. Maybe even sextuple-dipping.

title: Mindy Project May Be Moving to Hulu
description: Fox will not renew The Mindy Project for a fourth season when it announces its fall lineup in the coming days, said a source familiar with the plans for the show.

title: Netanyahu, Seeking to Broaden Coalition, Reserves Crucial Post for Rival
description: JERUSALEM  When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called early elections five months ago, he aimed to strengthen his 68-member governing coalition, which was riven over West Bank settlement-building and how to balance Israels democracy and Jewish character. He was particularly frustrated that as justice minister, Tzipi Livni, a onetime member of his party who veered sharply to the left, headed the powerful committee that controls legislation.

title: Lumber Liquidators Suspends Sales of Laminate Flooring From China
description: Lumber Liquidators has suspended sales of Chinese laminate flooring after facing accusations that the products contained dangerous levels of formaldehyde.

title: N.S.A. Collection of Bulk Call Data Is Ruled Illegal
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court in New York ruled on Thursday that the once-secret National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting Americans phone records in bulk is illegal. The decision comes as a fight in Congress is intensifying over whether to end and replace the program, or to extend it without changes.

title: Hold Still, a Memoir by Sally Mann
description: Before reading Hold Still, my knowledge of Sally Mann was based entirely on her photographs of her family on their Virginia farm, her dreamlike Southern landscapes, and some memory of the controversies that have surrounded the question of whether her intimate portraits of her children, often nude, were exploitative. Id assumed she was continuing to make new work and enjoying placid rural domesticity periodically interrupted by brief but abrasive trials in the court of public opinion.

title: Saudis Propose Truce for an Aid Effort in Yemen
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi Arabia has proposed a five-day halt to hostilities in Yemen to allow aid agencies to reach civilians suffering because of the countrys war, the Saudi foreign minister said on Thursday.

title: Teenager Dies in India After Eating Toxic Fruit
description: NEW DELHI  One teenage athlete was dead and three other young women were in critical condition in the southern Indian state of Kerala on Thursday after they consumed highly toxic fruit from what is widely known as a suicide tree.

title: Marco Rubios Immigrant Story, and an Aging Party in Search of a Spark
description: ANKENY, Iowa  At a recent ice cream social here, Jim Hallihan liked what he heard from Senator Marco Rubio.

title: Israeli Leaders Discuss New Government
description: Naftali Bennett, the head of the far-right Jewish Home party, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced on Wednesday the formation of a new Israeli government.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Need to make plans for the weekend?

title: Bitcoin Exchange Receives First License in New York State
description: New York States top financial regulator has granted the first license to a Bitcoin exchange, allowing it to open legally to customers across the country.

title: Letters: In Infamy
description: To the Editor:

title: What About Teens Who Dont Have Smartphones?
description: Smartphones are frequently blamed for stunting teenagers social relationships and rotting their brains (or at least keeping them from listening to their parents). But such worries leave out a significant percentage of teens: those who dont have smartphones at all.

title: The New Southern Cuisine
description: Rising chefs are putting shrimp-and-grits country on the culinary map.

title: Raclette
description: A tiny restaurant in the East Village serves the Swiss specialty.

title: Dutch Activist Faces Trial Over Profanity-Laced Tirade Against King
description: LONDON  The Netherlands has long been celebrated for its liberalism, but an anti-racism activist appears to have run up against the limits of Dutch tolerance after cursing the countrys first king in more than 120 years.

title: For Cardinals Matt Carpenter, a Bad Elbow in College Led to Good Things
description: ST. LOUIS  It is a speech, Jim Schlossnagle guessed, that he has given a thousand times to hundreds of college baseball players. Distilled, the coachs message is simple: Give yourself a chance to succeed. Or, in blunt terms: Stop wasting your talent.

title: Queens Pizzeria Owners Charged in Cocaine Smuggling Operation
description: A restaurant in Corona, Queens, was the center of an international drug-trafficking ring that smuggled cocaine in the linings of cardboard boxes containing produce, federal authorities said on Thursday.

title: Cider Bars Are Taking Root
description: Ive heard the term cider snob, Ben Sandler said, but I havent met one yet.

title: 3 Ways to Be a Socially Conscious Nail Salon Customer
description: So what salon should you go to?

title: Germany Limits Cooperation With U.S. Over Data Gathering
description: BERLIN  Germany has curbed its cooperation with United States intelligence, pushing back against a key ally amid new revelations of spying on Germans and other Europeans that have set off a domestic firestorm.

title: 1915:  Lusitania Sunk by Germans
description: LONDON  The giant Cunard liner Lusitania, with 1,978 souls on board, including hundreds of American citizens  scores of them famous on both sides of the Atlantic  was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine off the Irish coast at 2.15 oclock yesterday afternoon. A despatch sent from Liverpool at 9.30 says that the Lusitania was sunk without warning.A number of boats with rescued passengers are now making for the coast. The Lusitania had on board 290 saloon, 662 second class and 361 third class passengers, as well as a crew of 665 men.  The New York Herald, European edition, May 8, 1915

title: British Party Leaders Cast Their Votes
description: The leaders of five of the political parties in Britain cast their votes on Thursday.

title: Swiping Right on Tinder, but Staying Put
Restored Apu Trilogy Returns Satyajit Rays Humane Work to Theaters
description: John Huston and Satyajit Ray. One might not think these two major directors had similar taste in movies. In the 1950s, Huston made The African Queen and Moby Dick; Ray made the three films generally known as the Apu Trilogy: the epic story of Apu, a boy born in a village in India who struggles for education and recognition as a man in the cosmopolitan city of Calcutta (now Kolkata). Yet, when I was writing a biography of Ray in the 1980s, Huston sent me a letter about Ray and his work. I recognized the footage as the work of a great filmmaker, he wrote. I liked Ray enormously on first encounter. Everything he did and said supported my feelings on viewing the film.

title: Classmate or Friend?  Skeptic or Denier? Word Choice in The Times
