description: ATHENS  The United States, wading into the international efforts to shape Greeces economic and geopolitical orientation, is pushing the leftist government in Athens to resist Russias energy overtures.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Translating the Muni-Meter
description: Dear Diary:

title: Student Protest Derails Chinese Military Visit to Hong Kong Campus
description: The Chinese University of Hong Kong has postponed a campus visit of soldiers from the Peoples Liberation Army, after students protested against the invitation to what they called troops of a totalitarian regime.

title: From Broken Angel to Condos
description: Standing at Downing and Quincy Streets in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, one would never know that the handsome yet unremarkable brick building on the quiet corner was once a whimsical neighborhood mascot known as Broken Angel, with eclectic, stacked rooftop additions that reached ever higher.

title: Bedazzled Sandals
description: The humble shower slide has ascended to high fashion, with crystal beading, golden grommets and a metallic sheen.

title: For Carly Fiorina, Resentment Over Firing Softens With Time
description: It has been 10 years and two autobiographies since Carly Fiorina was ousted as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, the technology giant where she began her career as a secretary

title: Review: Young Concert Artists Gala Features Three Rising Soloists
description: Young Concert Artists makes no claim to quality in its name. But over 54 years, through its choices of artists it has helped to develop careers, in many cases, major ones.

title: April Jobs: Not Good News. Not Bad News. Relieving News.
description: The latest jobs numbers are a classic glass half-empty/glass half-full report on the state of the economy.

title: How to Talk to Your Childs Wary Professors
description: In the coming days, at universities around the United States, a miracle will occur. Parents and professors will watch their college students walk with awkward confidence across stages, and for the first time in years, many of those students will be wearing clean laundry. Afterward, those students will want to introduce their biological parents to their intellectual parents.

title: Chinese Province Issues Draft Regulation on Church Crosses
description: HONG KONG  Cities in Zhejiang, one of Chinas most prosperous provinces, are studded with Christian churches, Protestant and Catholic alike. Until recently, many of them had been topped by large crosses soaring into the sky, often illuminated with neon lights at night.

title: A New Look at Works Banned by the Catholic Church
description: Romes prodigious Angelica Library, founded in 1604 by the Augustinian bishop Angelo Rocca, is endowed with some 200,000 volumes and manuscripts on the history of Catholicism, with particular emphasis on the Reformation and Counter-Reformation of the Church. Enshrined amongst the librarys texts is a precious collection of first editions of books that, over the course of the centuries, were officially banned by the Catholic Church and placed in its Index Librorum Prohibitorum. These volumes include works by Machiavelli, Copernicus and Erasmus, as well as Voltaires Candide and Jonathan Swifts A Tale of a Tub. The collection, which includes the very first Index of banned books compiled by the Church in 1559, is what inspired the artist Ileana Florescus new show, Libri Prohibiti, which opens at Angelica Library next week.

title: Politics Are Set Aside as Thousands Mourn Officer Brian Moore
description: SEAFORD, N.Y.  This time, politics was not on display at a funeral for a fallen New York City police officer. No officers turned their backs to Mayor Bill de Blasio and no one voiced support for protests that have riven communities from Ferguson, Mo., to Baltimore.

title: Prime Minister Camerons Victory Speech
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said he would bring the country together and govern as a party of one nation, one United Kingdom, in his victory speech on Friday.

title: Britains Labour Leader Miliband Resigns
description: Ed Miliband, the leader of Britains opposition Labour Party, offered his resignation on Friday a day after Thursdays general election.

title: The Benefits and Caveats in Physical Challenges for Charity
description: SEAN MALONEY had an ambitious plan: to be the first stroke survivor to bicycle from San Francisco to New York via a circuitous route that would take him down the West Coast and across Texas. It would be over 5,000 miles.

title: Top Economist Sees Clinton Money Machine as Problematic
description: Questions surrounding foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation are beginning to fester beyond the usual conservative critics who hope to derail the presidential hopes of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: How to Use Siri, Google Now and Cortana Voice Commands
description: Q. I ask the Google app on my phone only about the daily weather forecast, but how does it compare to the Siri program for the verbal instructions it understands?

title: Shirley Jacksons Life Among the Savages and Raising Demons Reissued
description: When Life Among the Savages, a collection of warm and funny magazine pieces chronicling the ups and downs of Shirley Jacksons household, was first published in 1953, Jackson was already a well-known writer  of a rather different kind. She had made headlines five years earlier with The Lottery, which attracted attention not only for its shocking content, but also for the vehemence of the response it provoked. Many were unsure whether this tale of ritual stoning in an American village was fact or fiction; some railed at The New Yorker for printing such barbarism; others just wanted to know what on earth it meant. Jackson, who had already published the novel The Road Through the Wall (1948), about murder and suicide in a small California town, sealed her macabre reputation with her next two books: The Lottery (1949), a collection of often suspenseful short stories, and Hangsaman (1951), a coming-of-age novel about a college student who suffers a mental breakdown.

title: Concern for Business Leaders as Camerons Win Edges Britain Closer to E.U. Exit
description: David Camerons re-election as Britains prime minister increases the risk that the country will quit the European Union in the next few years. Although this is still not a probability, the possibility will concern business, as an exit would degrade Britains access to by far its largest market.

title: When Mother Leaves the Room
description: Every year on Mothers Day the lists appear: Bad Mothers in Fiction, Monstrous Mothers in Literature, 10 Worst Mothers in Books We Love. There are a few Most Wonderful lists, but these mothers are not from books generally recognized as great or enduring works. The two most famous are Caroline Ingalls in Little House on the Prairie and Marmee in Little Women  its a bonnet thing perhaps, though a good straw poke does not save Mrs. Bennet in Pride and Prejudice from the charge of foolishness. This makes you a bad mother too, apparently. Perhaps there should be an exam. Who could pass it? To be ordinary in any way  weak, fallible, occasionally drunk or desiring, all of these make you a liability to your fictional childrens fictional well- being. Thank goodness reality is not like that.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Use Polarizing? Site Begs to Differ
description: For years, political scientists and social theorists have fretted about the Internets potential to flatten and polarize democratic discourse, Farhad Manjoo writes.

title: Embracing Squid in Its Many Forms
description: Its funny that people who are normally squeamish about eating oddball food have no problem with squid.

title: Tax Documents: What to Shred, and What to Keep
description: THE income tax filing deadline is, thankfully, receding on the calendar. And while most people would prefer to move on to other, more pleasant activities, now is a good time to consider how you save your tax returns and other financial documents.

title: To Cameron, the Tory Victor, Now Go the Headaches
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron, having achieved a smashing and unexpected outright victory in Britains general election, heads into his second term facing severe challenges to his nations identity and place in the world: how to keep the United Kingdom in the European Union and Scotland in the United Kingdom.

title: 1915: Roosevelt Remarks on Lusitania
description: NEW YORK  The Herald obtained an interview with Colonel Roosevelt in the Court Room in Syracuse, where he was attending the trial of the libel suit brought against him by Mr. William Barnes, whom he lately called a boss.

title: ESPN Is Splitting With Bill Simmons, Who Offers an Uncharacteristic Word Count: Zero
description: When Bill Simmons learned on Friday morning that his nearly 15-year-old relationship with ESPN was over, he responded with something uncharacteristic: silence.

title: The Mysterious Persistence of the Cronut
description: The line begins about a third of a block into Spring Street and still regularly wraps around the corner up Thompson Street. One morning last week, on the second-to-last day of the month of Strawberry Rhubarb and Thyme  otherwise known as April; the flavor changes every month  a man named Thao stood at the front of the neatly assembled crowd. He was visiting from Vietnam, and had arrived at 5:30 that morning. At 7:36 a.m. there were 35 people lined up, including a baby in a stroller. The line was nearly half a block long. In the middle of the procession stood an older, serious-looking man named Greg Ingram, who was in town on business from Atlanta. If people are still lining up, there must be something about it, Ingram said. But also: What else are you going to do at 7 in the morning?

title: 1940: Confidence Vote in Britain
description: LONDON  The Chamberlain government obtained such a narrow vote of confidence late tonight [May 8] at the end of a two-day debate on the Norwegian debacle that it was believed in some political quarters that the Prime Minister might go soon to King George VI and offer to step down. The vote on the division was 281 for the government, 200 against it. One hundred and thirty-two members abstained.

title: Baltimore Case Is Full of Conflicts, Lawyers for Officers Contend
description: BALTIMORE  Lawyers for the six Baltimore police officers charged in connection with the death of Freddie Gray unleashed a personal and professional broadside on Friday against the prosecutor who brought the charges, accusing her and her office of being riven by conflicts of interest and alleging that she had betrayed professional standards.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Golf, Memory and Food Cravings
description: Take the Quiz

title: Stuff We Liked
description: We like it, of course, when an Upshot feature gets lots of attention  and our analysis and visualization of a new study on the importance of where a child grows up certainly did. We also liked how Emily Badger over at Wonkblog took the same study and applied her own analysis to the case of Baltimore for a very readable article.

title: With Berlin Philharmonic Vote Looming, Mariss Jansons Stays On in Munich
description: The invisible primary being waged before the players of the Berlin Philharmonic meet Monday to elect their new chief conductor and artistic director continues apace: Mariss Jansons, who had been thought to be a possible candidate, announced Friday that he had agreed to remain as chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra until 2021.

title: Patrick Lynch, Police Union Leader, Faces Election Fight
description: In early January, mutiny broke out within the upper ranks of the Patrolmens Benevolent Association, the citys largest police union. At a monthly meeting, at a catering hall in Queens, a cabal of senior delegates confronted the unions president, Patrick J. Lynch, with a defiant declaration: It was time to end his distracting battle with Mayor Bill de Blasio and refocus his attention on his members.

title: Aftermath of Pakistan Crash
description: Video shows the aftermath of a helicopter crash in Pakistan on Friday that killed foreign dignitaries, with initial reports suggesting it crashed into a school while attempting to land.

title: Watching Maya Plisetskaya
description: The great Bolshoi ballerina Maya Plisetskaya died on Saturday at 89. I saw her only once, in 1988, at a gala in her honor in Boston; an announcer proclaimed the priceless words: And now Maya Plisetskaya will dance her immortal Dying Swan  which she validated by dancing it twice. And thats what many people remember her for, the number of times her Swan would dance and die. (One colleague remembers her dancing it six times in a row.)

title: Idina Menzel to Tour in If/Then
description: Idina Menzel is hitting the road.

title: Adult Onset, by Ann-Marie MacDonald
description: Do our more modest northern neighbors talk about the Great Canadian Novel? After all, they have big geography there too  the mountains, the prairies. Always in view was the vastness of what in most countries would be called a sea but in Canada was known simply as one of the Great Lakes, the Canadian writer Ann-Marie MacDonald writes in her big, troubling and brave new novel. Books like hers have a continental sweep: The writer amply stocks them with people and ideas, with all she knows. Spare, quiet perfection isnt the aim.

title: On the Job
description: THE BAREFOOT LAWYER

title: The Lost Child, by Caryl Phillips
description: At age 57, Caryl Phillips is seen by many as the father of Afro-British fiction. Phillips was born on the island of St. Kitts in 1958, but as an infant he left with his parents during the mass migration of people from the Caribbean islands  still colonial subjects  to Britain in the 1950s. Immigration has been a key topic in Phillipss work from his very first novel, The Final Passage (1985). His first two novels were fairly straightforward in style and structure, but with his third, Higher Ground (1989), Phillips introduced the more ambitious and unconventional approach he has used ever since. Rather than tell one linear story, these later novels bring together several independent narratives set at different places on the globe and at different moments in time. The stories are linked by theme and situation as opposed to setting and plot.

title: Where Women Are Kings, by Christie Watson
description: Not all children love magic. Seven-year-old Elijah, the central character in Christie Watsons second novel, has a scar on his forehead and more on his body. And he is convinced he has a wizard inside him. This isnt fun, and the magical power it involves is a pernicious, festering force, endangering everyone around him. Or so Elijah believes.

title: Smart Money, by Andrew Palmer
description: In 2012, The Economist published a 14-page special report on financial innovation entitled Playing With Fire. It opened with the line Financial innovation has a dreadful image these days. The goal: rehabilitate that image.

title: Romantic Outlaws, About the Lives of Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley
description: They had it all. When they eloped, 16-year-old Mary Godwin and 21-year-old Percy Shelley had everything artists could desire: genius, beauty, literary pedigree, aristocratic inheritance, Mediterranean villas, famous friends, fearless admirers, freedom and  above all  faith in free love.

title: Firstborn, by Tor Seidler
description: The glint of wolves eyes in the night is a chilling sight. If Id been wingless, I would have been terrified. Thats Maggie, the lively magpie who narrates Tor Seidlers artful and affecting new novel, Firstborn. As it turns out, those eyes belong to wolves who, improbably, become her family. Together, led by the fearless Blue Boy, wolves and bird journey to the remote Lamar Valley in Yellowstone National Park where, they hear, an abundance of food awaits them. In the valley  where gray wolves were reintroduced 20 years ago, nearly a century after hunters drastically reduced their numbers  they will birth pups, raise and lose progeny, challenge other wolf packs and re-examine their loyalties to themselves and one another.

title: Hermit of the Jungle Guards a Brazilian Ghost City Rich in History
description: AIRO VELHO, Brazil  SHIGERU NAKAYAMA, the guardian of this ghost city in the Amazon rain forest, gazes at the Rio Negro, a vast blackwater tributary. From some angles, it looks less like a river than a sea, spurring him to remember Japan.

title: Sara Pennypackers Meet the Dullards, and More
description: Despite the efforts of story-time subversives as varied as Jo March, Tom Sawyer, the Mad Hatter, Madeline, Eloise, Ramona Quimby, the Cat in the Hat, Willy Wonka and the Stinky Cheese Man, namby-pambyism has for generations been a scourge of childrens literature. The impulse to force-feed kids the bookish equivalent of steamed spinach is unlikely ever to fade, though our notions about what that should be continue to evolve. But in recent years an opposing virus has also infected the nursery library. You might call it peepee-poo-ism: the anxious, overeager impulse to engage children on what we adults think of as their own terms, lest they believe us uncool  or worse, and more to the point, old.

title: I Will Always Write Back: How One Letter Changed Two Lives
description: In a suburban Pennsylvania classroom in 1997, a life-altering moment: Caitlin Alifirenka, a typical 12-year-old American girl, more interested in what she should wear to school than what she might learn there, chooses a pen pal from Zimbabwe. Caitlin has never heard of Zimbabwe, but the name, exotic, and difficult to pronounce, intrigues her.

title: Ben Draws Trouble, How to Draw a Dragon and My Pen
description: The trouble with drawing is that its fun. Almost too much fun. Drawing can become uncontrollable, a force you can barely handle. Children know this and give in; adults knew it once, but forget. For children a notebook for math class can easily transform into a sketchbook for art. Lines, shapes and colors become little masterpieces at the margins of the page. How can one stop? Why should one stop? Theres seemingly no choice in the matter. The drawing has to come out.

title: Black Dove White Raven, by Elizabeth Wein
description: Historical fiction, especially historical fiction for young adults, presents many challenges for a writer, not least of them this one: While history is decidedly political, novels are decidedly not political treatises. To ignore the politics of history is nave  and what novelist wants to be that? On the other hand, objectivity is an undesirable trait in a literary work. Point of view is very serious business.

title: Lost in the Sun, by Lisa Graff
description: The title of this simple yet soulful novel refers to a fly ball that drifts over the head of a Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, leaving the books sixth-grade narrator (and obsessive Dodger fan), Trent Zimmerman, in a confused rage. He had it, Trent whines. If hed just shifted even a little, he wouldve caught it easy.

title: Gordon Kormans Masterminds, and More
description: What happens during summer vacation has a lot to teach us about children and reading. Librarians and teachers are very aware of the summer slide. This friendly-sounding phrase describes the loss of reading skills during the long break. After two months of not reading, a student experiences a gap in learning that, by the time she reaches middle school, might add up to a two-year lag in skills. We also know that children who choose reading as a leisure activity will do well on those dreaded tests of comprehension, vocabulary and reading speed.

title: Bone Gap, by Laura Ruby
description: The goddess Demeter had a daughter, Persephone, who was abducted by Hades, the lord of the underworld. In her daughters absence, Demeter let the world go barren out of sorrow and anger. Anyone who had a dog-eared copy of the DAulaires illustrated Book of Greek Myths has a handle on Persephone.

title: Listen, Slowly, by Thanhha Lai
description: Literature in English for children and young adults offers few books about Vietnam and even fewer about the Vietnam War. Walter Dean Myerss 1988 novel Fallen Angels explored the costs borne by American soldiers sent to Vietnam with little knowledge about where they were and less about why they were there. The book deglorified war, exposing the sharp irony of sending young men, not yet old enough to vote and often marginalized by race or socioeconomic status, to defend ideals of democracy. They fought a war filled with hours of boredom, seconds of terror; if they came home again, it was not as angel warriors, but as fallen angels.

title: Ms. Rapscotts Girls and The Girl With the Glass Bird
description: Who can resist a good boarding school novel? The literary tradition dates back as far as the mid-19th-century Tom Browns School Days, by Thomas Hughes, and Frances Hodgson Burnetts 1905 classic, A Little Princess. These beloved stories shunt the parents aside without (necessarily) killing them off, leaving children to discover their own mettle. Two new boarding school tales for middle-grade readers offer fresh approaches  one whimsical and magical with a dose of gentle social satire, the other a whodunit of sorts, with a taste of international intrigue.

title: An Ember in the Ashes, by Sabaa Tahir
description: An Ember in the Ashes presents a vicious empire that has subjugated several cultures, including the once learned Scholars. Usually, the Empire raids in the heat of the day, we are told. The soldiers want Scholar mothers and children to watch. They want fathers and brothers to see another mans family enslaved. One Scholar, Laia, is so desperate to free her imprisoned brother that she becomes a slave and a spy at Blackcliff, an imperial academy where young men (and one other young woman, Helene) train to become the Empires soldiers. We also meet Elias, the son of the schools commander. Appalled by the Empires rule, he wants to run away, but the announcement of a competition changes his plans. If Elias wins, he will become emperor. And only if he competes, the imperial magicians tell him, will he attain a true moral freedom.

title: 15 European Opera Houses to Offer Free Online Streaming
description: A free showing of Verdis La Traviata will be streamed live from Madrids Teatro Real on Friday, inaugurating a new program backed by the European Union in which some of Europes top houses will stream performances free to make opera more accessible.

title: Inside the List
description: Smileys People: Jane Smileys new novel, Early Warning  it enters the hardcover fiction list at No.10  is the middle volume of a trilogy that started last year with Some Luck, covering a century in the life of an Iowa family at the rate of a chapter per year. This installment takes the characters from 1953 through 1986, introducing a new generation and letting them contend with milestones like the Vietnam War, Jim Joness seductive Peoples Temple and the early days of the AIDS crisis. In some hands the conceit could have felt gimmicky or forced, a kissing cousin to Forrest Gump or Billy Joels We Didnt Start the Fire. But reviewers so far have been largely impressed, comparing Smiley to the giants of 19th-century literature. (Americas Tolstoy, ruled Christobel Kent in The Guardian.) Smiley also keeps an eye on her forebears, if more humbly. Trollope would sneer, she told one interviewer last year, after announcing she was about done with the trilogys 1,300 pages. In the same profile, she remembered with approval the motivational note  Nobody asked you to write this novel  that a former classmate kept taped to her typewriter. What we do as writers is voluntary, so dont complain, Smiley said, recalling how inspired she was by an exhibit of hand-corrected page proofs at the Balzac museum in Paris. Its good to see what it meant to be a popular author in the middle of the 19th century, she said. When you see how hard Balzac worked, youll never complain again.

title: Missouri Lawmakers Limit Revenue From Traffic Fines in St. Louis Area
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Missouri legislators have agreed to a proposal that would sharply limit revenue from traffic fines in municipalities across St. Louis County, where heavy fines and ticketing helped inflame unrest after the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer here last year.

title: Jeb Bushs Middle-East Role Model: His Brother?
description: Theres a bit of controversy today about a remark that Jeb Bush, Republican presidential contender, made about his brother, former President George W. Bush, at a meeting on Tuesday in Manhattan.

title: Bookshelf: This Is How We Roll
description: New picture books include The Bus Is for Us! and The Red Bicycle.

title: Bookshelf: Dig It
description: New picture books include The Potato King and If You Plant a Seed.

title: Editors Choice
description: THERE IS SIMPLY TOO MUCH TO THINK ABOUT: Collected Nonfiction, by Saul Bellow. Edited by Benjamin Taylor. (Viking, $35.) The nonfiction shows the same strengths as the novels: a dynamic responsiveness to character, place and time.

title: Scottish Nationalists Rejoice in Big British Election Win
description: PAISLEY, Scotland  When the results were in last September and the Scottish National Party  lost its bid for Scotlands independence, a spirited young separatist, Mhairi Black, walked past local officials of the Labour Party who were clapping sarcastically and goading her. Better luck next time, they said.

title: Highlights at This Weekends Echo Park Craft Fair
description: This weekend, stylish and creatively inclined Angelenos will flock by the thousands to the Echo Park Craft Fair. The biannual event is a showcase for L.A.s thriving scene of independent designers and artisans, and for a certain type of Los Angeles aesthetic that fuses the handmade and earthy with sophisticated modern design. (We imagine there will be some overlap with last weekends Mercado Sagrado fair.) Visitors can shop for Modernist-inspired ceramics (Mt. Washington Pottery; BZippy & Co.), unusual cacti (The Cactus Store), jewelry and objets such as rocks from the L.A. River wrapped in strands of leather (Matthew Ready), ideal for decorating their (real or imagined) Craftsman bungalows.

title: In Alex Rodriguezs Big Moments, Yankees Start to Look Small
description: I live in what I call the New York Yankees historical baseball district.

title: On Englands Coast, Thomas Hardy Made His World
description: It was in Lulwind Cove, an inlet on Englands south coast, that the dastardly Sergeant Troy took an impromptu swim in Far From the Madding Crowd, Thomas Hardys 1874 novel about an uncommonly independent Victorian woman and her suitors. The water in the cove was smooth as a pond, Hardy wrote, until Troy swam between the two projecting spurs of rock which formed the pillars of Hercules to this miniature Mediterranean, whereupon he was swept out to sea and presumed drowned, only to make a dramatic reappearance  this being a Hardy novel  at a most inconvenient moment.

title: National Sawdust, a New Concert Hall, to Open in Williamsburg in October
description: The transformation of a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into a new music center is nearly complete: organizers said Friday that the hall, National Sawdust, would open this fall and host three concerts in the New York Philharmonics Contact! series.

title: China and Russia Honor WWII Relations
description: President Xi Jinping of China met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday, a day before the 70th anniversary celebration of Victory Day in Moscow.

title: Paperback Row
description: ON THE RUN: Fugitive Life in an American City, by Alice Goffman. (Picador, $16.) This is a closely observed study of the criminal justice systems impact on life in a poor black Philadelphia neighborhood. Goffman, a sociologist, spent six years in a community she calls 6th Street, documenting the routine police stops, raids and beatings that young men navigate. The level of detail in this book and Goffmans ability to understand her subjects motivations are astonishing, Alex Kotlowitz wrote here.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A God in Ruins
description: This week, Tom Perrotta discusses Kate Atkinsons A God in Ruins; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Shirley Jackson; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A God in Ruins
description: This week, Tom Perrotta and Ruth Franklin.

title: Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martn Rejtman at Lincoln Center
description: Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martn Rejtman, a retrospective of work by the Argentine filmmaker at Lincoln Center, Wednesday through May 19, will culminate with a weeklong run of his newest film, Two Shots Fired, a comedy about a 16-year-old boy, Mariano, who survives self-inflicted gunshot wounds to his stomach and head. Although he suffers from auditory disturbances, he is otherwise barely injured. From the seemingly unmotivated suicide attempt, the absurdist movie radiates outward to observe the foibles of family members and friends, who like Mariano, act on impulse.

title: Yve Laris Cohen at the Kitchen
description: In the work of Yve Laris Cohen, choreography often takes the form of construction: walls and floors being built, transported, taken apart. Traversing the worlds of dance and visual art, Mr. Laris Cohen is interested in their architectural spaces, the nature of black boxes and white cubes. Recently at St. Marks Church, he assembled and disassembled, over several nights, a portable stage belonging to New York City Ballet.

title: Carnegie Hall Has Big Week Planned
description: Lovers of great orchestras, opera singers and pianists may want to claim a seat at Carnegie Hall for three consecutive nights this week. On Thursday, Yannick Nzet-Sguin, the superb young music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, brings that storied ensemble to the hall for Nico Muhlys Mixed Messages, Beethovens Third Piano Concerto (with the eminent Emanuel Ax as soloist) and Rachmaninoffs rhapsodic Third Symphony. (8 p.m., Thursday, 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

title: Isabella Boylston on Treasuring Giselle and Trusting Herself
description: Some years are so full of happy transformation that they seem conjured from a fortunetellers hopeful reading. In 2014, the ballerina Isabella Boylston had one of those years. She danced her first Giselle, magnificently, with American Ballet Theater and was promoted to principal soon after. She got married. Hes not a dancer, Ms. Boylston said, flashing a smile. He works in finance. And she performed as a guest artist at the Mariinsky Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet. You show up, and theyre expecting you to be this prima ballerina, she said. So you just have to fill the shoes.

title: Pop Music Catches Up to Shamir
description: NORTH LAS VEGAS, NEV.  On the small patio at the far-from-it-all apartment here that the singer Shamir shares with two friends, an ashtray sat on a small table, though you could barely see it underneath the lava flow of cigarette butts erupting out of it. He was perched on a high chair, puffing his way through a Maverick, lamenting the disarray, and also passing the buck.

title: Monitoring the Metropolitan Operas Vital Signs
description: In news reports over the past year, the Metropolitan Opera has come across as an ailing patient, its costs and revenues spiraling in opposite directions. While many observers agree that the companys financial model is unsustainable, at least in the long term, theres far more disagreement about the quality of its performances. At the beginning of the 2014-15 season, which ends on Saturday, I resolved to take the Mets artistic temperature by attending, as I never had before, all of the operas it presented  26 this year  at least once each and often more. I tried to catch notable newcomers and cast changes, to move beyond the premieres and big stars to see how things are faring on those ordinary nights that are an opera houses lifeblood.

title: Freddie Highmore on Bates Motel
description: Season 3 of A&Es Bates Motel, which has its finale Monday night at 9, has been transformative for young Norman Bates. And not just figuratively.

title: Race and Gender in Black and White
description: The South African photographer Zanele Muholi, born in Durban in 1972, specializes in portraiture of a particular kind: Almost all of her subjects are members of South Africas lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex communities. Early on, combining political activism and art, she began in 2002 documenting hate crimes against gays. In 2007, she initiated the portrait series, which is ongoing and forms the centerpiece of Zanele Muholi: Isibonelo/Evidence at the Brooklyn Museum, her largest solo show in the United States.

title: Della Mae and Kris Davis Release New Music
description: Della Mae

title: The Economy and the British Election
description: Just a reminder: The overwhelming evidence for US elections is that they are not judgements of an administrations overall performance  they are driven by the rate of growth just ahead of the election, as in the chart above (taken from Larry Bartels.) (Any pointers to UK-specific work along the same lines would be welcome.) Ive also put in the closest growth number I could get to the one Bartels uses for the US, taken from the ONS.

title: The Curious Case of Negative Interest Rates
description: Anthony Scaramucci is founder and co-managing partner of global investment firm SkyBridge Capital and host of the television program Wall Street Week.

title: B.B. King, in Hospice Care at Home, Is Focus of Court Battle
description: B.B. King, the esteemed bluesman, who at 89 is currently in hospice care at his home in Las Vegas, will for now remain under the guardianship of his longtime manager, Laverne Toney, despite claims of abuse by three of Mr. Kings children, The Associated Press reported.

title: Stop-Go Austerity and Self-Defeating Recoveries
description: Sometimes good things happen to bad ideas. Actually, it happens all the time. Britains election results came as a surprise, but they were consistent with the general proposition that elections hinge not on an incumbents overall record but on whether things are improving in the six months or so before the vote. Cameron and company imposed austerity for a couple of years, then paused, and the economy picked up enough during the lull to give them a chance to make the same mistakes all over again.

title: In Paris, Craft Cocktails Sidle Up to the Bar
description: PARIS  On the menu at Mabel, a rum-focused bar in the Second Arrondissement, is a section titled Mabels Recommendations. It lists the names and addresses of nearly 30 other cocktail bars in Paris.

title: How Labour Gained Votes but Still Lost Seats
description: Thursdays election in Britain was great for the Conservatives and terrible for Labour  so terrible that Labours leader, Ed Miliband, is stepping down. Yet Mr. Miliband has something to brag about: Not only did Labour take a larger share of the vote this week than it did in 2010, but it also improved its vote share by substantially more than the victorious Conservatives did.

title: Queen Latifah Stars in Bessie on HBO
description: Within the first 10 minutes of Bessie, HBOs new biopic of Bessie Smith, we see the blues legend sing, cry, dance, cut a man and kiss, lustily, both men and women. The drinking comes later, but not much. At a party at the home of Carl Van Vechten, the Harlem Renaissance patron and gadfly, a soused Bessie, played by Queen Latifah, belts the anthem Work House Blues, to an audience including Langston Hughes, then throws a drink in the hosts face when he uses a racial epithet.

title: Chinese Debate the Meaning of Alan Maks Election to the British Parliament
description: For the first time ever, an ethnic Chinese has been elected to the British Parliament. But the new Conservative Party member for Havant, in southern England, has downplayed that aspect of his victory in Thursdays general election.

title: A Rebound in Hiring
description: Employers in the United States added 223,000 jobs in April. Sectors like construction and health care did well, while the oil and gas category fared poorly.

title: On the French Riviera, Fitzgerald Found His Place in the Sun
description: Unless you happen to be on a billionaires yacht requiring a deepwater port or are a paparazzo stalking Leonardo DiCaprio along the Riviera, you might have no reason to find yourself near Antibes or its charming little sister village, Juan-les-Pins, on a summer evening. And that would be unfortunate, because among the legendary diversions of Cap dAntibes is exploring the rocky playground peninsula on the French Riviera that inspired one of Americas greatest writers.

title: On Medicare and Assessing the Value of Lung Cancer Screening
description: You smoked for years. Maybe you still do. Now that Medicare promises to begin covering lung cancer screening, should you sign up?

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York City region:

title: Liberia, Ravaged by Ebola, Faces a Future Without It
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  When a taxi dropped off a man dying of Ebola one evening in June 2014, the Logan Town clinic was defenseless.

title: New York Archdiocese Will Close 7 More Churches
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced on Friday the shuttering of seven more churches as part of the biggest reorganization in its history, a process of parish consolidations that will leave the archdiocese 20 percent smaller than it was last year.

title: Illinois Supreme Court Rejects Lawmakers Pension Overhaul
description: CHICAGO  The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday rejected changes that legislators made to fix a deeply troubled public pension system, leaving the state where it had started  with a significant budget crisis, a vastly underfunded pension program and no plan in sight.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Families Share Stories of Raising Transgender Kids
description: Roughly a year ago, a California couple posted a video on YouTube about their child, Ryland Whittington.

title: Nine Rooms in the San Remo for $20.75 Million
description: A nine-room apartment on the 16th floor of the venerable San Remo that was owned for more than three decades by Robert W. Wilson, a hedge fund pioneer and philanthropist, sold for $20,750,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: The Classic, Trendy and Elevated Sides of a White Port and Tonic
description: Rising in popularity along with aperitifs like vermouth and sherry is white port  the drier, bittersweet cousin of red. Mixed with tonic, it makes for an unexpectedly bracing yet refreshing spring cocktail thats lower in proof than a classic gin and tonic, but with more kick than a wine spritzer.

title: Ben Carson Bucks G.O.P. and Backs Raising Minimum Wage
description: Ben Carson has adopted many positions that align closely with conservative orthodoxy, supporting a flat tax not to exceed 15 percent and going so far as to urge the elimination of not only the Internal Revenue Service, but also Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Investors Choose Bojangles Over Shake Shack
description: Fried chicken is in and modern-day roadside burgers are out  at least on Wall Street.

title: Anticipating a Crowd, Milans Cathedral Undergoes a Restoration
description: For Milans Duomo, beauty has its price. The citys massive Gothic cathedral, on which construction began in 1386, is undergoing a restoration, and the marble that provides its celebrated luster is a particular challenge.

title: Unless You Are Spock, Irrelevant Things Matter in Economic Behavior
description: Early in my teaching career I managed to get most of the students in my class mad at me. A midterm exam caused the problem.

title: Post-Election Britain: A Disunited Kingdom
description: LONDON  One of the most anodyne election campaigns in living memory has left Britain with a result that few expected  and one that could transform Britain both internally and externally. This was an election that recast the political geography of Britain. It may redraw the boundaries of the nation. And it raises questions about the future shape of the European Union.

title: Tony Awards: Getting to Know You
description: Portraits of Tony Award-nominated actors.

title: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival Arrives
description: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival offers three full-scale genre immersions this week: in dancehall, noise and what might be called avant-garde ambience. The first is free: on Sunday at 1 p.m. at Fort Greene Park, where Yardcore: Brooklyn Bashment, savors the connections between Jamaica and New York. It features King Jammy, the Jamaican producer whose collaboration with Wayne Smith on Under Mi Sleng Teng gave dancehall a new electronic sound. A six-hour marathon of noise  as assault, experiment, improvisation, torment and catharsis  features Merzbow, Pharmakon, Prurient and Genesis P-Orridge (performing the Psychic TV album Electric Newspapers) at 10 p.m. Wednesday at Output, 74 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg. On Friday, Tri Angle Records celebrates its fifth anniversary with nine acts including Haxan Cloak, Forest Swords and Evian Christ. Theyre primarily electronic musicians creating soundscapes that can be darkly immersive and push you around; 10 p.m., 23 Wall Street, redbullmusicacademy.com.

title: Review: Joan Jonass Venice Biennale Pavilion Is a Triumph
description: VENICE  Performance art is a young persons sport, most often pursued in heat, often accompanied by sensationalism and abandoned as stamina fades. But, at 78, Joan Jonas has avoided all of the above, quietly but determinedly elaborating performance into an immersive multimedia art form that has sustained her for more than five decades.

title: Hepatitis C Drugs Added to W.H.O. List of Essential Medicines
description: The World Health Organization put five new hepatitis C drugs on its essential medicines list for the first time on Friday, including drugs that cost $1,000 a pill or more in wealthy countries. The new drugs are ground-breaking because they usually cure quickly with minimal side effects.

title: Tina Feys Letterman Farewell, Much Ado About the Maxi Dress and What Price Nails?
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Pressure on Sygenta From Monsanto Offer
description: Monsanto is heaping pressure on Syngenta.

title: Art Imitates Life as The Audience Gets a New Post-Election Scene
description: LONDON  The Conservatives have won; David Cameron has been called to see the Queen before forming a new government. That happened on Friday morning here, and was to happen again onstage Friday evening in a hot-off-the-press new scene in The Audience, which offers a fictional account of the meetings between Queen Elizabeth II and her prime ministers over the 63 years of her reign.

title: In Time for Memorial Day, Atlantic City Attempts a Turnaround
description: Since it arrived in 1978, casino gambling has been the engine driving Atlantic Citys economy.

title: First Draft Focus: A High-Flying Celebration for V-E Day
Trout Fishing in Iceland
description: The sporting outfitter Frontiers International Travel recently introduced a website dedicated to fishing in Iceland, one of the most highly regarded wild trout and char destinations in the world.

title: Russia and China Sign Cooperation Pacts
description: MOSCOW  On the eve of a celebration commemorating to the defeat of Nazi Germany, the presidents of Russia and China on Friday signed 32 bilateral agreements designed to highlight the warming of relations between the countries even as Russias have soured with the West.

title: Strained Ties With Israel
No Comment Necessary: Saving Students From Learning About Evolution
description: Mack Butler, a state legislator from Alabama, has introduced a bill that would allow public school teachers to help students understand, analyze, critique, and review the scientific strengths and scientific weaknesses of all existing scientific theories covered in a science course. If youre confused about what that might mean, Raw Story has found this helpful explanation on Mr. Butlers Facebook page:

title: Salman Khan, Bollywood Star, Is Allowed to Remain Free on Bail in India
description: NEW DELHI  A Mumbai court on Friday ruled that the Bollywood actor Salman Khan would be allowed to remain free on bail until it hears his appeal of his conviction in a drunken-driving hit-and-run case.

title: Australian Football Visits U.S. in Search of Basketball Big Men
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  Jalen Carethers, four weeks removed from his final game as a basketball player at Radford, was at a loss. Sports had always come easily to him, but now he was standing in the middle of a multipurpose field at IMG Academy, cradling an oblong ball in his hands and doing his best to figure out how to make this foreign object fly.

title: All Aboard: The Luxe Boat
description: Luxurious cruise lines have been around since 1900, when the German designer Albert Ballin created Prinzessin Victoria Luise, but the newly unveiled Regent Seven Seas Explorer is gaining attention, touting itself as the most luxurious cruise ship ever. It is set to make its 14-night maiden voyage in July 2016, from Monte Carlo to Venice, the latest entrant in the busy category of high-end cruises.

title: Bonding in a Show of Unity
description: New York police officers paid their respects to Officer Brian Moore, who was shot and killed in Queens.

title: Saudi Arabia Announces Cease-Fire in Yemen
description: PARIS  Saudi Arabia announced on Friday that it would halt its bombing campaign in Yemen for five days beginning on Tuesday, in a sign that it was bowing to international pressure to ease a worsening humanitarian crisis in a country battered by weeks of war.

title: Democrats Relish Hillary Clintons Embrace of Cultural Issues
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons call this week for more expansive action on immigration was the latest in a series of policy statements likely to appeal to her partys liberalbase. But her comments also reflect a growing feeling among Democrats thatthe political balance oncultural issues has shifted in their favor since her last campaign.

title: In Venice, Plenty to See Beyond the Pavilions
description: The 56th Venice Biennale officially opens on Saturday, but La Serenissima has already been saturated by the international art world for almost a week  previews, parties and canal-navigating ad infinitum. One absolutely ephemeral and unintentional piece of performance art made headlines when, on Wednesday, acqua alta knocked a pontoon-load of well-heeled guests entering the Fondazione Prada into the water (or was it Miuccias ingenious interpretation of a trap door for gatecrashers?). Dont fret if you missed it; there are plenty of other extra-Biennale highlights scattered throughout the city.

title: Tempur Sealy Shareholders Vote to Remove C.E.O. and Chairman From Board
description: Spurred by an activist investor, shareholders of Tempur Sealy International voted on Friday to overhaul the mattress makers board, including by stripping the companys chief executive of a director seat.

title: When a City Stops for Soccer
description: On Sunday, New York will get its own derby when the citys two Major League Soccer teams, New York City F.C. and the Red Bulls, meet for the first time. So to preview this one, we asked veterans of other derbies to share their memories.

title: Book Review Podcast: Kate Atkinsons A God in Ruins
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Tom Perrotta reviews Kate Atkinsons new novel, A God in Ruins. Mr. Perrotta writes:

title: U2 Prepares to Go on Tour
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss U2 and Songs of Innocence as the group heads out on a world tour.

title: The Insurance That Poses a Hidden Threat
description: Another financial crisis is inevitable, the only question is what will ignite it.

title: Lynch Announces Baltimore Investigation
description: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch announced Friday that the Department of Justice would open a civil rights investigation into the Baltimore Police Department.

title: Homemade Pasta
description: Melissa Clark makes fresh pasta with flour, salt, eggs and olive oil

title: Officials Threaten to Close Mosque Installation at Venice Biennale
description: VENICE  A provocative art installation in the form of a functioning mosque opened here on Friday for prayers, attended by dozens of Muslim worshipers who were outnumbered through much of the day by art spectators crowding the city for the 56th Venice Biennale.

title: Verbatim: Obama Makes the Case for Trade Pact
description: President Obama, speaking about the Pacific free-trade pact at Nike headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.

title: Fresh Pasta, Made Simply
description: The myth that you need to be an Italian grandmother to make great pasta was so ingrained in Anna Klinger that when she went to Italy as a young cook to study the craft, she assumed it would take years to master.

title: As a Plant Nears Completion, Croton Water Flows Again to New York City
description: Water from the Croton watershed  historically the cradle of New Yorks supply  began flowing to taps on Thursday for the first time in seven years, officials announced, as one of the largest construction projects in the citys modern history neared completion.

title: More Like a Book Launch  The Timess Push to Build Buzz for Its Nail Salon Series
description: The Timess series of stories on the abused and underpaid young women who are the employees of New York Citys omnipresent nail salons has hit big since it appeared online Thursday.

title: Jurors in Etan Patz Case Fall One Vote Shy of a Conviction
description: A judge declared a mistrial in the Etan Patz case on Friday after jurors said for a third time that they could not reach a verdict despite three weeks of deliberation, leaving unresolved a missing-child case that vexed New York City for decades and led to a sea change in the way Americans view the security of their children.

title: Mothers Day Brunch
description: Do your home chefs need a little help with Mothers Day brunch? Martha Rose Shulman offers these delicious crepes you can make in advance, and let the little ones put them together for your well deserved Mothers Day meal. If your better half is handy in the kitchen, suggest these other delicious recipes to celebrate the day.

title: On Breast Milk and High-Impact Journalism
description: What is the true afterlife of an article, in readers minds and in their actions?

title: A Reading of Ruin by Mark Bibbins
description: An American poet meditates on the short life of actress Candy Darling.

title: What I Love | Michael A. Clinton
description: The president for marketing and publishing director of Hearst Magazines lives in an apartment filled with mementos of his travels.

title: In Battle of Ex-Obama Aides in Britain, Jim Messina Bests David Axelrod
description: Two former Obama campaign aides spent the last year going head-to-head as strategists in Britain, with Jim Messina working for Prime Minister David Cameron of the Conservative Party and David Axelrod representing Ed Miliband, who stepped down Friday as the Labour Party leader.

title: Why the New York Fed Should Not Be Reined In
description: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Popcast: U2 Prepares to Go on Tour
description: U2 will shortly begin its next world tour, with a physically damaged lead singer and after the release of Songs of Innocence, a record whose influence was, as Jon Pareles puts it, uncertain.

title: At Home With Michael A. Clinton of Hearst Magazines
description: You could call Michael A. Clinton an escape artist.

title: Mylans Too-Harsh Takeover Defense
description: If etiquette counts in deal-making, Miss Manners would not be happy with Mylans heated attempt to fight off a $40 billion unsolicited bid by Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.

title: Making Play Streets Mean Streets
description: In December, two days after Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos from the 84th Precinct in Brooklyn were killed in a squad car by a man who had come from Baltimore having declared a violent will toward the police, Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke at a luncheon for the Police Athletic League. The league by then could trace its roots 100 years, having begun in 1914 when Police Commissioner Arthur Woods, an advocate for the poor who worried about the effects of tenement life on children, set about searching for vacant lots that could be converted to playgrounds.

title: Conservative Party Wins Surprising Victory in Britains General Election
description: The result defies pre-election opinion polls that suggested a tight race between the Tories and Labour, and it gives Mr. Cameron a second term as prime minister.

title: The Immigration Bidding War
description: Hillary Clintons big immigration speech earlier this week, in which she endorsed not only comprehensive reform in general but afuture executive amnesty that goes where even President Obamas Office of Legal Counsel said a president cant legally go, is beinggreeted by liberalpundits and over-wroughtRepublicans alike as a potentiallybrilliant politicalmove, one thatputs G.O.P. presidential candidates in a very difficult position, trapped as ever between the need to reach out to Hispanics and the demands of their base. New York Magazines Jonathan Chait, for instance, argues that the Republican contenders have been trying to maintain some strategic ambiguity on immigration, which is harder the more explicit Hillary gets:

title: Russian Court Sentences Ex-Official to 5 Years in Prison in Corruption Case
description: MOSCOW  A Russian court on Friday sentenced a former Defense Ministry contractor to five years in prison after a corruption investigation led to a major shake-up in the ministry and prompted President Vladimir V. Putin to fire Anatoly E. Serdyukov as defense minister in 2012.

title: Caroll Spinney, Big Birds Heart and Soul (and Body)
description: Twenty-five years ago this month, Caroll Spinney, the puppeteer who has played Big Bird on Sesame Street since 1969, was invited to sing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The occasion was Jim Hensons funeral.

title: A Harlem Townhouse, a Sentimental Journey
description: It may not seem so to outsiders, but New York City is really a collection of small towns with residents and businesses connected in the most surprising ways. Just ask David Daniels.

title: A Club Lingers On
description: The Ziegfeld Club, founded in 1936, outlasted the women it was formed to help. It is ready for an encore.

title: Rediscovering the Ziegfeld Club and Its Showgirls
description: The mysterious business card was tucked into one of the vitrines at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan, where rare costume pieces from the Follies, the revue staged by the impresario Florenz Ziegfeld Jr. from 1913 to 1927, are on display. Bent and coated with dust, it bore the words The Ziegfeld Club, Inc. and offered several telephone numbers and an address on Park Avenue.

title: A Relationship That Has Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Julissa Ferreras, a New York City councilwoman, and Aaron Copeland, an aerospace engineer, were married by Mayor Bill de Blasio at City Hall in Manhattan.

title: Its Not a Stream of Consciousness
description: IN 1890, the American psychologist William James famously likened our conscious experience to the flow of a stream. A river or a stream are the metaphors by which it is most naturally described, he wrote. In talking of it hereafter, lets call it the stream of thought, consciousness, or subjective life.

title: Its Called Love, Not Rocket Science
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York is known for being able to read the political tea leaves, but even he admits that he misread Councilwoman Julissa Ferreras, a Democrat from Queens.

title: David Camerons Challenge
description: A strong showing by an incumbent party usually brings stability and continuity. That, at least, is how the markets read the unexpected and decisive victory by Prime Minister David Camerons Conservative Party in Britains general election on Thursday. The pound and stock prices had quick bounces. Further down the line, however, this election may prove to be a fateful turning point for British and European unity.

title: Do a Little Dance, Have a Little Fish
description: At Astoria Seafood, an unusual pairing of market and restaurant in Long Island City, Queens, dancing may break out at any time.

title: Dancing With the Fishes at a Restaurant in Queens
description: Lets dance! a waitress said one Friday at Astoria Seafood. It was a relatively quiet night, which means the wait for a table was only 25 minutes. The waitress, Elena Faroupos, 56, her eyes glamorously lined with a cheerful shade of green, threw her hands in the air and spun elegantly as Spyro Christakos, the owner, turned up the bouncy, brassy sounds of Greek music from behind the cash register.

title: Review: Arlo Hill, Always in Love With Loesser
description: The charismatic theater singer Arlo Hill aimed for the bulls-eye in his Frank Loesser tribute, Ive Been in Love Before, on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The 28-year-old performer, accompanied on piano by Rick Hip-Flores, didnt merely sing the work of the songwriter who turned Broadway on its ear 65 years ago with Guys and Dolls. He became Loessers champion and surrogate, punching out his songs in the brash, unpretty voice of a scrappy, streetwise rebel against the polite, polished musical theater of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

title: First Manhattan Condo by a Chinese Developer
description: A 38-story tower rising on a busy block in Midtown is being billed as the first condominium project in Manhattan developed entirely by a company from China.

title: A Review of StreetEasys Mobile App for Apple and Android
description: A little more than a year ago, I reviewed an app called Movement, writing that it was the best service I had found for searching for apartment rentals on the smartphone. That a bootstrapped and relatively flawed app could be the best option spoke to the fact that big players had yet to fully enter the space, and as many could have predicted, Movements lead did not last long.

title: Review: NewYorknewyork @Astor Place, a Multilayered Production
description: Stacked books arranged like city blocks fill the diminutive stage of Joes Pub at the Public Theater. The book covers are white; there are no titles. Instead, the names of writers are projected against the back wall as a voice reads aloud: Samuel Beckett, Mark Twain, Upton Sinclair, Grace Paley. A feather-slim woman, Mei Yamanaka, winds around the stacks with nimble plis and razor-sharp turns until her legs and arms turn deadly, and she demolishes the literary landscape. (Make way for e-readers.)

title: A Loan Modification Programs Limited Reach
description: A federal inspector is taking the Treasury Department to task for not doing enough to increase participation in the governments Home Affordable Modification Program, known as HAMP, which helps keep homeowners out of foreclosure. Borrowers having trouble paying their mortgage can apply to HAMP for a loan modification that lowers their monthly payment. So far, about 1.5 million homeowners have received HAMP modifications, about half as many as originally predicted by the Treasury. The department has repeatedly extended the programs initial December 2013 deadline; HAMP now is scheduled to expire in December 2016.

title: Obama Speaks at Nike Headquarters
description: The president selected the Oregon site for a speech to promote the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Nike says it will manufacture more products in the United States if the deal is adopted.

title: What I Missed (Personal and Meta)
description: My new office at the CUNY Graduate Center is small  so is my Princeton office, but it has more shelf space, not to mention enough books stacked on the floor to get me warnings from the fire marshal. So Im culling my three-and-a-half decade collection drastically. The picture above shows the books I put out to be taken away today, which was day three; the books from the previous two days have already been taken away, and I expect to need all weekend to finish.

title: Review: The Road of Promise, Warning to All About Jews in Germany
description: Anonymity in the performing arts is usually restricted to publicity-shy donors. But on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, it was the Voice of God that remained elusive, a booming tenor attributed only to Anonymous in the program for Kurt Weills The Road of Promise.

title: Unbreakable Bonds in the Folds of a Wedding Dress
description: When Olivia Krieger went shopping for a wedding dress last July, she was only 15 years old.

title: Review: Tectonics Festival New York Takes Wing at a Church Setting
description: In the vast sanctuary of the First Unitarian Congregational Society in Brooklyn Heights on Thursday, with the lights dimmed to a sepulchral shadowiness, the music seemed as simmering and enveloping as a primordial ritual. Immersion was the title of the first piece, by Annea Lockwood, but it could just as easily have been applied to the other five works, too.

title: At Castellanos House of Music, Instruments to Sell and Stories to Hear
description: John Castellano, 68, who owns Castellanos House of Music on Staten Island, was segueing between stories  from how he lent amplifiers to Jimi Hendrix, to how he became the only white member of the Chambers Brothers  when a customer began bargaining him down on a 40-watt Marshall amplifier.

title: The Trophy Life: Winning in Golf Is Only the Beginning
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The moment Martin Kaymer walked into the room Wednesday and saw the crystal trophy seated at the table, he beamed as if he had been reunited with a lost love. At last years Players Championship, Kaymer embraced it, posed for photographs with it. He may have even kissed it. And then he traveled home to Germany without it.

title: Surviving Remnants of the Village of Flatbush
description: Q. Does anything remain from the Village of Flatbush from before the American Revolution, aside from the Dutch Reformed Church?

title: Airport Security Advances Clash With Privacy Issues
description: BOSTON  At a mock airport in an underground laboratory here at Northeastern University, students pretending to be passengers head through a security exit in the right direction, while a young man enters going the wrong way. On a nearby computer screen, a newly developed video surveillance software program flags the wayward person and sounds an alarm.

title: Credit Cards With 2% Rebates, While (or if) They Last
description: For years, the holy grail for many seekers of credit card rewards has been a guaranteed 2 percent back on every dollar they spend.

title: Unvarnished Series on Nail-Salon Workers: Readers Respond en Espanol
description: Esta semana The New York Times solicit comentarios en espaol con el fin de reunir las reacciones a un trabajo de investigacin, publicado en dos partes, que mostr las condiciones de trabajo de las manicuristas en salones de uas en Nueva York.

title: Unvarnished Series on Nail-Salon Workers: Readers Respond in  (Hangug-ui)
Grand Army, a New Seafood Bar in Brooklyn
description: Grand Army, which opened on Tuesday evening in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, represents the coming-of-age of the neighborhoods restaurants  a cocktail bar with only small plates, and nothing repurposed in sight. Its also the coming-of-age of some restaurateurs: Noah Bernamoff of Mile End and Julian Brizzi of Rucola, who teamed up with a longtime Prime Meats bar director, Damon Boelte, to open in what was once the chrome-plated Victory Cafe. (The fourth partner, Daniel Krieger, is a photographer who contributes to The New York Times and other publications.)

title: Millepied to Take On Vertigo at Cannes
description: Dance will be on the program of the official opening of the Cannes Film Festival on Wednesday at the Palais des Festivals. Benjamin Millepied, the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, will present a five-minute piece, set to a section of Bernard Hermanns music for Alfred Hitchcocks Vertigo.

title: Unvarnished Series on Nail Salon Workers: Readers Respond in English
description: Reader reaction was incredibly strong to Unvarnished, the two-part investigative report by Sarah Maslin Nir that found many manicurists in the New York area endure questionable labor practices and potential health risks in the workplace.

title: Traces of Ziegfelds New York
description: A century ago, Broadway actors spoke of a Ziegfeld Curse, because so many of Florenz Ziegfeld Jr.s famous showgirls came to tragic ends. In the generations since the impresarios death in 1932, New Yorkers might be forgiven for thinking that there is also a curse on anything to do with Ziegfelds memory. His lavish theater on Sixth Avenue was demolished in 1966, and now the owners of the Ziegfeld Theater, the worlds largest single screen cinema, built near the site of the original, have considered closing it, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

title: Spotifys Revenue Is Growing, but So Are Its Losses
description: As streaming music has spread around the world, Spotifys financial picture has remained much the same year after year: rapid revenue growth, with steady losses.

title: Myrna Blyth, AARP Executive, and Her Sunday Routine
description: No offense to our nations capital, but for Myrna Blyth, who lives there Mondays through Thursdays, it is just not home. Home is where she spends her Sundays, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where she has lived in the same huge apartment for four decades. Ms. Blyth, 76, is a senior vice president at AARP and the editorial director of AARP Media. After three years of commuting, she is struck by the differences between the two cities. There are more people on the street in New York at 10 oclock on an O.K. evening than there are in Washington on any day but the inaugural, she said. One draw Washington has for Ms. Blyth is her adorable 5-year-old grandson, who lives there, as does her son Jonathan. Her beautiful redheaded granddaughter and her other son, Graham, live in Portland, Me. For Mothers Day, she and Jonathan plan to be in Manhattan together.

title: U.S. Urges Openness From Hedge Funds, an Industry Not Used to Sharing
description: LAS VEGAS  When John P. Carlin, the head of the Justice Departments national security division, appealed on Friday to the hedge fund industry to share more information with the government, it was a tough sell.

title: Review: Pharoah Sanders at Babys All Right in Brooklyn
description: The 74-year-old jazz saxophonist Pharoah Sanders played in an unusual context on Wednesday night. He was at Babys All Right, the year-and-a-half-old, mostly indie-rock club in Williamsburg, during a slate of bands programmed as a birthday party for the curator, archivist and gallerist Johan Kugelberg, a man with discerning taste and a lot of friends.

title: New Math for Retirees and the 4% Withdrawal Rule
description: More than two decades ago, Bill Bengen, then a financial planner in Southern California, said he had several anxious clients with the same question: How much can I spend in retirement without running out of money?

title: What Tom Brady Told Me During Deflategate, and What He Didnt
description: Im always a thinker  Ive got to outthink them, Tom Brady told me. It was early January, and I was working on an article for this magazine about the N.F.L.s ageless, ruthless, peerless superstar, as the cover text would read. The New England Patriots quarterback was describing how he had surmounted a history of being overlooked and underestimated. He talked a lot about flouting conventional wisdom throughout his career.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: A Different Shot at the Pros
description: Fifteen athletes gathered in Bradenton, Fla., in April for a three-day scouting combine for the Australian Football League. Curiously, they were all basketball players.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Taking a Stand Solved
description: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the difficult case of twin sisters who, in the prime of youth, developed a weakness that forced them to use their arms to rise from a chair. Nearly 300 of you wrote in with thoughts on this difficult case.

title: Bonding in a Show of Unity
description: New York police officers paid their respects to Officer Brian Moore, who had been shot and killed in Queens.

title: A Hidden Gender Gap for Parents
description: When they become parents, many couples want to share child-care responsibilities equally, says Sarah Schoppe-Sullivan, a professor of human development and family science at Ohio State University. But in a recent study, she found that moms shoulder much more of the additional work when a baby is born  and, perhaps more surprising, that parents arent necessarily aware of the discrepancy.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, May 10 to 16, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Feedel Band and the Libyans, African Sounds at the Global Beat Festival
description: Vintage 1970s-style funk and ancient Jewish prayers shared the double bill of African music that opened the three-night Global Beat festival at the Winter Garden at Brookfield Place (the former World Financial Center) on Thursday night. It brought together Feedel Band, a Washington group built around musicians from Ethiopia, and the Libyans, a group from Israel that has researched and reconstructed traditional songs from the Jews of Libya.

title: Grayson Perry Prepares His American Introduction
description: LONDON  I dont normally dress up for an interview, the artist Grayson Perry said, opening the door of his studio. But Im going to a Royal Academy council meeting straight afterward.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, May 10 to 16, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, Syria, Ukraine and Britain.

title: May 8, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from New York, Syria, Ukraine and Germany.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Elton John on Capitol Hill, V-E Day festivities and more.

title: Frida Kahlo Is Having a Moment
description: She was a genius before she was a refrigerator magnet, an ace manipulator of society and media nearly a century before social media came into existence. Born in 1907, dead at 47, Frida Kahlo achieved celebrity even in her brief lifetime that extended far beyond Mexicos borders, although nothing like the cult status that would eventually make her the mother of the selfie, her indelible image recognizable everywhere.

title: Havana Nights
description: To wander through the dimly lit streets of Old Havana after dark is to enter a world of shadows and silhouettes.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Things to Do in New Jersey, May 10 to 16, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Debi Mazars Talent for Glamour
description: The actress Debi Mazar has often considered the question of what constitutes glamour, and so she had a ready answer as the designer Isabel Toledo zipped her into a tightly fitted black Swiss silk tulle dress frosted with vivid floral embroidery on a recent morning.

title: Review: New York City Ballet Performs Bournonville Classics at Spring Gala
description: The new double bill at New York City Ballet, choreography by the great Danish ballet master August Bournonville (1805-79), presents the oldest pieces in the companys repertory. Yet Bournonvilles ideas remain fresh and modern in these dances; and the program shows how todays performers are challenged, focused and refreshed by them. Apart from one or two over-bright smiles as dancers sail through brilliant series of rapidly beaten jumps, theyre as engaged as if Bournonville himself was watching in the wings. And their steps are stitched, gleamingly and tightly, into their music

title: A Splashy Entrance by Rihanna Puts Chinese Designers in the Spotlight
description: When Rihanna wore a fur-trimmed yellow satin gown by the Chinese-born designer Guo Pei to the Met Gala on Monday night, it became the talk of Twitter, which erupted with jokey comparisons to omelets and pizzas. Memes using cartoon characters like SpongeBob SquarePants were rampant. The fashion world pretty much came to a standstill, Glamour magazine wrote of the jaw-dropping cloak, while Time magazine declared that the singer stole the show.

title: A.J. Jacobs and the Worlds Largest Family Reunion
description: A. J. Jacobs, the best-selling author and humorist, was hoping to get former President George H. W. Bush on the telephone for a project involving genealogy. There was only one way to accomplish that, he reasoned: nepotism.

title: Review: Stockholm, Pennsylvania, With Cynthia Nixon, About Life After Release
description: Stockholm, Pennsylvania is not your grandmothers Lifetime movie. Its premise  a woman kidnapped at 4 and kept in a basement for 18 years is reunited with the parents she doesnt remember  fits the channels female-in-extremis profile. But its release pattern is highly unusual: from the Sundance Film Festival in January straight to basic cable in May.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 10 to 16, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Angela Simmons Has Her Hands in Everything
description: Age 27

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Emily
description: An embarrassment of riches this week: a band I didnt know (DakhaBrakha), new stuff from Lucius, and more. Ill get there. But after a long period when San Fermin was weirdly lacking in videos showing how great they are live, a bunch have been appearing. And I dont think Ive put up a video that features Allen Tates fantastic voice. So here we are:

title: Israeli Identity Among Arabs and Jews
description: Kholood Eid, a child of Palestinian parents, went to Haifa from the United States to explore how Israeli women of different religious and ethnic backgrounds saw themselves.

title: Evening Hours | Monday Night Dream
description: New York Citys biggest social event of the year and more.

title: Bill Cunningham | Spring Luncheon
description: At the annual event, dress and jacket in blue were favored, as was a dress with a princess line and a flower pattern.

title: Bill Cunningham |Spring Luncheon
description: 1,400 people attended the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon in Central Park, raising $3.6 million. The event honored Anne Harrison and Marty and Michele Cohen. A dress and jacket in blue were favored, as was a dress with a princess line and a flower pattern. Some women wore evening dresses like those with a dipping hem, seen also at a gala in Boston. Fanciful hats abounded.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Nuit de Chine at the Costume Institute: A Sleuth Finds the Formula for a Lost Perfume
description: Nuit de Chine has made a long journey, from a Paris fashion house in 1913 to an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today.

title: The Legacy of Etan Patz: Wary Children Who Became Watchful Parents
description: It is there in the quick steps of a woman hurrying up the street in Brooklyn, muttering to herself, Im a good parent, Im a good parent. She was regretting letting her son run home alone from a restaurant and was rushing to catch up with him.

title: Nepalese Village, Devastated by Quake, Is Left to Cope as International Attention Shifts
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  There was an unearthly quiet on Friday in Langtang, where the remains of as many as 300 people are believed to be buried under 20 feet of rock and ice that sheared off a mountain during the earthquake that hit Nepal two weeks ago.

title: Plane Crash on Atlanta Highway
description: A small plane crashed onto an interstate in Atlanta, catching fire and killing all four people on board.

title: On Mothers Day, Embrace Embarrassment
description: PARIS  EARLIER this year, I took my kids to see a soccer match in Paris. Along with practically everyone else in the stands, we chanted Allez les Bleus  Go Blues  to cheer on the French team.

title: The Porn Star Sunny Leones Bollywood Makeover
description: NEW DELHI  A few weeks ago I went to see a Hindi movie at my local cinema. It was an unremarkable potboiler, a story of thwarted lovers and triumphant love, punctuated with song-and-dance sequences, percussive fisticuffs and the rhythmic hips of a voluptuous heroine.

title: WWII Aircraft Fly Over National Mall
description: As part of the celebrations on Friday to mark the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, dozens of vintage aircraft from the era flew over the National Mall.

title: The Labor Picture in April
description: The U.S. economy added 223,000 jobs last month, while the unemployment rate fell to 5.4%, a turnaround from the disappointing performance in March.

title: Court Ruling on N.S.A.s Data Collection Jolts Both Defenders and Reformers
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court ruling that the National Security Agencys bulk collection of phone records is illegal has scrambled bipartisan efforts to overhaul the program, emboldening those who say the efforts do not go far enough and undermining Senate Republican leaders who want to keep the current program in place.

title: This Year, Columbia Event Finds Joke Fodder in Sexual Assault Debate
description: With jokes about student protests, a new sexual respect requirement and one very famous mattress, a group of Columbia University students early on Friday turned a year of uncomfortable debates about campus sexual assault into fodder for a late-night comedy show.

title: U.N. Official Accuses France of Delays in Child Sexual Abuse Case
