description: Dear Diary:

title: Running From Police Is the Norm, Some in Baltimore Say
description: BALTIMORE  Some do it because there are warrants for their arrest. Others because they possess drugs, are seeking a thrill, or are just plain scared. Sometimes people do it even when they have done nothing wrong.

title: Kris Bryant, a Cub in the Image of the Games Ideal Hitter
description: ST. LOUIS  The first thing Ted Williams told Mike Bryant was that he was late, because he was only 10 minutes early to their practice session. The second thing he told him just may help end the most persistent streak of failure in professional sports: the championship drought of the Chicago Cubs.

title: After Illness, Former President Jimmy Carter Ends Trip Monitoring Guyanese Election
description: Former President Jimmy Carter ended an election-monitoring trip to Guyana early and flew home on Sunday after falling ill, the Carter Center, his nonprofit organization, said in a statement.

title: Little Uzbekistan in Brooklyn
description: The Uzbek population in Brooklyn is the largest concentration anywhere in the United States.

title: Accusations of Terrorism Worry Brooklyns Uzbek Community
description: To understand the Uzbek community of Brooklyn, sit down and share a cup of tea with some of them. Please, drink. They pride themselves on hospitality, and to refuse would be impolite.

title: Federal Cuts Would Be Major Blow to New York Citys Public Hospitals, Comptroller Says
description: New York Citys public hospital system is looking at a major cash squeeze within four years if federal cuts to hospitals serving large numbers of poor and uninsured patients take place as scheduled, according to a report by the city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, to be released on Monday.

title: Dean Skelos Faces Growing Opposition as Support Wanes Among Republicans
description: ALBANY  Facing a rising tide of opposition from within his party, State Senator Dean G. Skeloss position as Senate majority leader was deeply imperiled on Sunday night, though it was not clear how, and under what terms, his tenure might end.

title: Whats Your Television I.Q.?
description: The upfronts shine a spotlight on the highly anticipated fall television season. How well do you know your television trivia, current and past?

title: Rickie Fowler Outlasts Logjam to Win Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Rickie Fowlers mother and sister held reservations on a commercial flight from Jacksonville International to San Diego that was scheduled to leave Sunday night at the same time the Players Championship was supposed to end. They had lunch with Fowler, who began the day three strokes off the lead, before his 1:25 p.m. tee time.

title: Broadcast TVs Big 4 Review Their Wins and Losses
description: As the major television networks prepare to showcase their lineups for the fall season in pursuit of advertisers, each has successes it will trumpet, new shows it hopes will generate excitement and weak spots it needs to address. Here is some of what to expect from this weeks upfront presentations in Manhattan.

title: For a Decorated Athlete, a Global Campaign for a Top Job
description: The middle-distance star has become a marathoner.

title: How Is U.S. TV Changing? Ask Jane
description: Gina Rodriguez was home in Chicago last month when she stopped at a Subway sandwich shop on the way to the golf course with her father. The Hispanic teenager working behind the counter instantly recognized her as the star of the CW Networks breakout comedy-drama Jane the Virgin and said that the order was on the house. Ms. Rodriguez protested, but the girl insisted, telling the actress how inspirational it was to see someone on television who looked like her and grew up in her neighborhood.

title: Chasing Outbreaks: How Safe Is Our Food?
description: A 1993 E. coli outbreak linked to Jack in the Box hamburgers sickened 700 people and drew new attention to the dangers of food-borne illness. More than 20 years later, how far have we come?

title: Action and Dysfunction in the U.S. Food-Safety Effort
description: The notion that a crisis is a terrible thing to waste is credited to the American economist Paul Romer, who offered the thought a decade ago in a discussion about education. Mr. Romers observation has since been echoed in a variety of contexts. It could be applied as well to stewardship of this countrys food supply. Significant measures to keep Americans from being sickened, and sometimes killed, by what they eat have tended to come only after calamity strikes. Even then, in the view of many experts on food safety, the United States has wasted too many crises for comfort.

title: Russia Tests Distant Waters, Resurfacing Cold War Fears
description: ARDGLASS, Northern Ireland  After a day of fishing in the Irish Sea, Paul Murphy was about to head for home when his trawler, the Karen, suddenly shuddered to a halt.

title: Popular Demand
description: Once a song is on the radio it tends to stay popular. But radio is not always in sync with downloaded songs or albums.

title: Drugmaker and University Ally to Seek Cure for AIDS
description: Years ago, curing AIDS was considered so out of the question that some scientists dared not even mention the possibility.

title: @_FloridaMan Beguiles With the Hapless and Harebrained
description: MIAMI  Dangling into the sea like Americas last-ditch lifeline, the state of Florida beckons. Hustlers and fugitives, million-dollar hucksters and harebrained thieves, Armani-wearing drug traffickers and hapless dope dealers all congregate, scheme and revel in the Sunshine State. Its easy to get in, get out or get lost.

title: Tony Rodhams Ties Invite Scrutiny for Hillary and Bill Clinton
description: The heavyset 60-year-old man who walked with a cane seemed an unlikely speaker at the glamorous launch party for a cosmetics company held in Santa Monica, Calif., in March.

title: Silicon Valley Recap: The Power of the Server
description: Season 2, Episode 5: Server Space

title: Hamilton Wins Big at Lortel Awards
description: No, Hamilton will not win a Tony this year  it will arrive on Broadway too late. Instead, its sweeping up just about everything else its eligible for, including the Lucille Lortel Awards, which honor Off Broadway works and were announced on Sunday. Hamilton took home 10 awards, including for outstanding musical, director (Thomas Kail), lead actor in a musical (Lin-Manuel Miranda), and lead actress in a musical (Phillipa Soo).

title: Frank DiPascali Jr., Madoff Aide Who Pleaded Guilty in Fraud, Dies at 58
description: Frank DiPascali Jr., a top lieutenant to Bernard L. Madoff, who helped carry out one of the biggest frauds in Wall Street history, died on Thursday. He was 58.

title: King Salman Upends Status Quo in Region and the Royal Family
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  For much of the past decade, change has come slowly to Saudi Arabia, if at all.

title: Red Bulls Back Up Taunts With Victory in New Rivalry
description: HARRISON, N.J.  As the energy and noise rose in the final moments before the historic first kickoff between the Red Bulls and the nascent New York City F.C., an enormous banner rose in front of the home end at Red Bull Arena, a giant sheet many stories high poking fun at the visiting team.

title: Veep Recap: The Former Veep Has Veep Problems
description: Season 4, Episode 5: Convention

title: Wolf Hall Recap: In Finale, King Henrys Masque and Annes Little Neck
description: Part 6, Master of Phantoms

title: Veep Q&A: Anna Chlumsky on Amys Meltdown
description: On this weeks episode of Veep, Amy Brookheimer (Anna Chlumsky) was infuriated and had finally had enough. Fed up with being frozen out of the loop by yes-woman Karen Collins (Lennon Parham), the manager in the presidential re-election campaign of Selina Meyer (Julia Louis-Dreyfus), she went down in flames in the middle of the convention with an expletive-filled tirade. (I wouldnt let you run a bath without having the Coast Guard and the Fire Department standing by. But yet, here you are, running America. You are the worst thing that has happened to this country since food in buckets. And maybe slavery.)

title: Rangers Turn Lights Red and Knuckles White, Edging the Capitals
description: WASHINGTON  Braden Holtby lay stretched on his stomach in the crease and stayed there for a moment, looking back over his shoulder, as Chris Kreider let out a tribal scream and embraced his teammates Sunday night. This was unusual, the Rangers beating Holtby with such ease, and he needed time to process what had happened.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There are thousands of women who are working in this, but no one asking: Whats happening to you? How do you feel? We just work and work.

title: Roxana Baldettis Resignation as Vice President Shadows Guatemala Politics
description: MEXICO CITY  The resignation of Guatemalas vice president has plunged the countrys politics into disarray, with a presidential election in September and the public growing more indignant over corruption.

title: To Market, to Market with Rob Pruitt
description: From Obama to Marilyn Monroe to  naturally  himself, the artist Rob Pruitt has covered a wide range of subjects and mediums in his lifetime; one of his most prominent works to date is The Andy Monument, a 2011 statue of Andy Warhol that spent nearly a year and a half standing proudly in Union Square, near Warhols Factory stomping grounds. T caught up with the artist as he prepared a new retrospective at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., Rob Pruitt 50th Birthday Bash (this Sunday, May 17, is actually Pruitts 51st birthday; shh). The foundation commemorated the exhibition with a private event yesterday, which included an auction of items contributed by members of the Brant family themselves  yes, including the billionaire paper magnate after whom the foundation is named, Peter M. Brant, and his wife, the supermodel Stephanie Seymour; and yes, the offerings include a to-die-for assortment of Seymours shoes. Proceeds from the tag sale, which is ongoing throughout the exhibition, will benefit the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College. In the slide show above, Pruitt shared a few of his favorite items up for sale with T; hell also select some items later this month to add to his famous eBay page.

title: How Blue Hill at Stone Barns Transplanted Its Farmhouse Feel Into a Sothebys Gallery
description: Michael Moore, Sothebys director of events, continually outdoes himself  its in his job description. With a three-person team, Moore produces more than 350 American events (and some abroad) for Sothebys each year, the crowning jewel of which is the ultraexclusive dinner that precedes the high-profile New York contemporary auction each spring and fall. This year, Moore faced the task of topping last springs contemporary dinner, for which Sothebys flew in 16 chefs from Noma, the Copenhagen restaurant often cited as the best in the world, and asked them to recreate its dining experience right in Sothebys New York flagship on the Upper East Side. (Moore and his team attempted to meet all of the chefs requests, no detail too small  one consequence of which was a long, thorough search for just the right river rocks for Noma to serve its langoustines upon.)

title: Seaport Smorgasburgs Sleek, New Look
description: This summer, hungry visitors to the Smorgasburg markets location in Lower Manhattans Seaport district will also be able to satisfy their appetite for contemporary architecture. When the gourmet street-dining series opens its outpost there later this month, vendors will prepare and serve meals from a new series of eight semipermanent pods designed and built by the Brooklyn-based firm Guild, as seen for the first time here (pictured inside the companys studio).

title: A Dual Review of Whats New Starring Roseanne Barr and Diplo
description: Diplo and Roseanne Barr chew over anti-hangover pills, Frida Kahlo paintings and a doll that looks like a Sicilian widow.

title: Word of the Day | desiccate
description: desiccate  \de-si-kat\  adjective and verb

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 11:30 A.M. (Showtime) FRUITVALE STATION (2013) On Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, a 22-year-old black father, was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., his killing captured on cellphone. Ryan Cooglers feature directorial debut reconstructs the final 24 hours in the life of Mr. Grant (played by Michael B. Jordan, above with Ariana Neal) who, after two stints in prison, had returned to selling drugs after losing his job at a supermarket because of chronic lateness. Octavia Spencer plays his mother and Melonie Diaz the mother of his daughter, with whom hes trying to stay. Mr. Cooglers main intention  and his great achievement, as well as Mr. Jordans  is to make Oscar a fully human presence, to pay him the respect of acknowledging his complexities and contradictions, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The radicalism of Fruitvale Station lies precisely here, in its refusal to turn a man into a symbol. Nearly every black man, whether or not he is president, tends to be flattened out by popular culture and the psychopathology of everyday American life, rendered as an innocent victim, a noble warrior or a menace to society. There is a dehumanizing violence in this habit, a willed, toxic blindness that Fruitvale Station at once exposes and resists.

title: Rick Nash Picks Opportune Time to Get Back on Scoreboard
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Nash led the Rangers with 42 goals this season but had yet to find similar success in postseason play. Nash scored just once in the teams first 10 playoff games and not at all through the first five games of this second-round series against the Washington Capitals.

title: Kim Kyok-sik, North Korean General Tied to Attacks, Dies at 77
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Kyok-sik, the North Korean general who South Korean officials have said was behind two deadly attacks on South Korea in 2010, died on Sunday. He was 77.

title: Israeli Identity Among Arabs and Jews
description: When Kholood Eid arrived in Haifa, Israel, last summer, she had trouble distinguishing Jews from Arabs. They all spoke Hebrew and, except for those who were devout, they dressed similarly. Many even looked alike.

title: Wall Street Vampires
description: Last year the vampires of finance bought themselves a Congress. I know its not nice to call them that, but I have my reasons, which Ill explain in a bit. For now, however, lets just note that these days Wall Street, which used to split its support between the parties, overwhelmingly favors the G.O.P. And the Republicans who came to power this year are returning the favor by trying to kill Dodd-Frank, the financial reform enacted in 2010.

title: Suicides on an Indian Reservation
Smart Social Programs
description: WASHINGTON  DO government efforts to support low-income families work? Since the War on Poverty in the 1960s, skeptics have argued that even if these programs provide temporary relief, the only long-term impact is increased dependency  witness, they say, the persistent lack of mobility in places like inner-city Baltimore.

title: Transgender at the C.I.A.
description: The day she nervously told her boss that they needed to talk in the summer of 2012, the young intelligence analyst was mindful of the ordeal of the transgender woman at the Central Intelligence Agency who came before her. The story had become C.I.A. lore. In the late 1980s, a standout senior analyst who became the butt of jokes when she came out resigned after enduring months of cruel glances and crude remarks.

description: Season 7, Episode 13: The Milk and Honey Route

title: Q. and A.: Andrew S. Erickson on Chinas Military Goals and Capabilities
description: Every year, the United States Department of Defense must submit a report to Congress a classified version and an unclassified one  on military and security developments involving the Peoples Republic of China. This years 89-page unclassified report, released last week, analyzes Chinas evolving military goals and strategies and new developments in its naval, air and ground capabilities.

description: Below are several paragraphs from the May 1 article The Rise of Emoji on Instagram Is Causing Language Repercussions.

description: Aaron E. Carroll answered readers questions about this article in a follow-up here.

title: Airbnb Grows to a Million Rooms, and Hotel Rivals Are Quiet, for Now
description: By any measure, Airbnbs growth has been stunning since the company was founded in 2008. It now has more than a million rooms available in homes, apartments and even former barns  more places to sleep than hotel giants like Marriott and Hilton.

title: Mayor de Blasios Days on the Road Fuel Criticism at Home
description: A rally by the steps of the United States Capitol. Fire-up-the-base speeches in Iowa and Wisconsin. Cross-country political trips, paid for with private money, and a Silicon Valley fund-raiser hosted by tech moguls, with tickets going for up to $10,000 apiece.

title: Middle Class Is Disappearing, at Least From Vocabulary of Possible 2016 Contenders
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton calls them everyday Americans. Scott Walker prefers hard-working taxpayers. Rand Paul says he speaks for people who work for the people who own businesses. Bernie Sanders talks about ordinary Americans.

title: Greater Aims Than Marketing With a Film Starring Green Luxury Apartments
description: The film shows a man in a leather biker jacket and a woman in an oversize black parka leaning against the gunwale of a boat, staring up at the huge icebergs floating by, dressed more for the cobblestones of SoHo than for the shoals of Greenland. The camera captures their amazement at the drifts of glacial beauty. Just then  crack!  both jump as a piece of ice the size of a townhouse cascades into the water.

title: Raising Paddles in Seattle to Ward Off an Oil Giant
description: SEATTLE  A dozen or so men and women, cinched into life jackets, paddles at the ready, were about to launch their kayaks into Elliott Bay early Thursday evening with Seattles glittering skyline as the backdrop. For some of the paddlers, it was a first-time experience, and with the water at 50 degrees and choppy, there were some obvious signs of trepidation.

title: Do You Ever Feel Embarrassed by Your Parents?
description: Its no question that childrens behavior can be potentially embarrassing to their parents  throwing a tantrum in public, asking a stranger a perfectly innocent though horribly inappropriate question are just two examples.

title: Navy Report on the Death of Lt. Nathan Poloski
description: The Navys investigation into a fatal mishap during an aviation training exercise in the western Pacific in September 2014.

title: A Navy Pilots Death Reflects the Everyday Hazards of the Job
description: WASHINGTON  All the Navy recovered after Lt. Nathan Poloskis fighter jet collided in midair with another Navy jet on a training mission in the western Pacific in September were his flight helmet and a few bits of debris. The 26-year-old pilot, who was deployed aboard the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson, died one month before the ship steamed into the Persian Gulf and began launching combat missions against the Islamic State.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: For an Aging Brain, Looking for Ways to Keep Memory Sharp
description: With people worldwide living longer, marketers are seizing on every opportunity to sell remedies and devices that they claim can enhance memory and other cognitive functions and perhaps stave off dementia as people age.

title: Swimming Pigs: Reporters Notebook
description: HONG KONG  Reporting about China, journalists often follow the secretive circuitry of political power, or the money, or both.

title: Review: Prince, in Baltimore, Nods to Unrest in Song and Asides
description: BALTIMORE  You look around, and the system is broken, Prince said about two hours into his Rally 4 Peace concert at the Royal Farms Arena here on Sunday night.

title: ScienceTake | Evolutions Undulations
description: The answer to how one long fin has made for agile swimmers of different species.

title: The Right Ratio to Engineer a Swim
description: The knifefish doesnt swim the way a trout or tuna does, waving its tail fin back and forth. Its propulsion comes from one long fin on its belly, and when it swims, the fin, not the body, undulates. A continuous wave passes along the fin, and watching it can be mesmerizing.

title: New York Today: Sneezing Into Spring
description: Good morning on this motley Monday.

title: Making It Explicit in Israel
description: In Israel, we are used to hearing that everything is more complex than one might think. Situations are typically described as variegated, imprecise or intangible and they seem almost intentionally so. Implicitness  about politics, religion, military actions, and human rights  rules. But I would argue that that situation has changed. In the past year in Israel, things have become clear and precise. Things have become explicit.

title: Today in Politics: Trade Fight Intensifies as Vote Looms
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where presidential candidates of both parties have spent the weekend singing their mothers praises. Senator Mitch McConnell and President Obama are also starting to feel the love for each other after all these years, while even one of the biggest political donors thinks campaign spending is getting out of control. Trade will be the talk of Congress this week, but with many Democrats resisting a deal, will anything get done?

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | May 11, 2015
description: Updated: May 12, 2015

title: How to Eat Healthy Meals at Restaurants
description: Most meals at American restaurants are packed with processed food and enough calories to cover two or three sensible meals. Yet its entirely possible to eat healthy, tasty restaurant meals. Every meal here stays under 750 calories, and every breakfast is under 500. Well start with some good news...

title: Polish Presidential Election Heads for Runoff
description: WARSAW  The conservative challenger toPolands incumbent president has defied pre-election polls and stunned the ruling party by winning the largest number of votes in the first round of presidential balloting, the electoral commission announced Monday night.

title: Morning Agenda: Speedy Start-Up Financing
description: SPEEDY START-UP FINANCING | Ubers most recent fund-raising talks are notable not just for the $50 billion valuation that would come with a $1.5 billion round of financing, but also for amount of time that has lapsed in between rounds  just five months. Uber and other start-ups have been raising money at a pace that is unprecedented in Silicon Valley, driven by money pouring in from hedge funds, strategic investors and more, and by the willingness of entrepreneurs to embrace the cash, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced write in The New York Times. Mark Suster, a partner at the venture capital firm Upfront Ventures, said theres only one reason these companies are raising money so quickly: Because they can. When capital markets are this loose, people tap them, whether its right to or not, he said.

title: Bank of England Holds Rates Steady
description: LONDON  The British central bank said on Monday that it would maintain its benchmark interest rate at 0.5 percent, the level since March 2009, as the markets digest the implications of the Conservative Partys election victory last week.

title: Fiskars Agrees to Buy Owner of Wedgwood and Waterford
description: LONDON  The Fiskars Corporation, a Finnish maker of home and garden products, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the maker of Wedgwood china and Waterford crystal for $437 million.

title: Chinese Billionaire Takes Over 6,000 Employees on a Trip to France
description: They filled the streets of Paris and the beaches of the Cte dAzur. Clad in blue T-shirts and waving flags, they descended on the Louvre en masse. On the sand in Nice, they broke a world record for the longest human-formed sentence visible from the sky.

title: American Idol Will End Its Run in 2016
description: At its height, American Idol minted breakout stars and drew more than 30 million viewers an episode. It was the No. 1 broadcast show for eight years, provided a boon to an ailing music industry and was the sort of appointment television that industry executives are desperately trying to recreate.

title: Kerry, Seeking Answers on Conflict in Syria, to Meet With Putin
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry traveled to Russia on Monday to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin and discuss whether it is possible for the two sides to work together on a political solution for the conflict in Syria, American officials said.

title: Court Clears an Ex-Chief Minister in India of Graft on Appeal
description: NEW DELHI  The powerful former chief minister of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, Jayalalithaa Jayaram, on Monday was cleared of corruption charges on appeal, paving the way for a possible return to office.

title: Chinese Smartphone Makers Try to Make Inroads in India
description: HONG KONG  The most important market for Chinese smartphone makers may no longer be China.

title: Greece Moves to Pay Debt, but European Finance Ministers Unsatisfied
description: BRUSSELS  The government of Greece, quickly running out of cash, moved on Monday to quell fears of an imminent default on its debts, authorizing its treasury to make a big loan payment to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Poll Shows Lack of Excitement Over Presidential Hopefuls
description: Those vying against Hillary Rodham Clinton for the presidency will face multiple obstacles, but a new poll from George Washington University shows that her fame could be one of the biggest.

title: The Life and Times of an Artists Muse
description: Rachel Feinstein offers layers of depth to the themes of mortality and magic in Mark Bibbinss ode to the Warhol superstar Candy Darling.

title: Preakness 2015: American Pharoah, Dortmund and Firing Line Headline Field
description: Three horses dominated the Kentucky Derby from start to finish, and all three will be back for the second leg of the Triple Crown, the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore on Saturday. Though others will be in the gate, too, it is hard to see a win from anyone other than the big three: American Pharoah, Firing Line and Dortmund.

title: European Commission Prepares Plan to Distribute Migrants Across E.U.
description: LONDON  As Europe struggles to address a worsening migration crisis, the executive arm of the European Union is expected this week to submit a proposal to distribute migrants across the 28-member bloc, officials said on Monday, a plan that would encounter fierce resistance from some national governments.

title: Pirates of Penzance Gives Lift to English National Opera
description: LONDON  When an opera company finds itself in trouble, theres always Gilbert and Sullivan. Having been in serious trouble for months, it was lucky that the English National Opera had plans for a new production of The Pirates of Penzance, which opened on Saturday and has already proved so popular that the run has been extended. Say what you like about this repertoire, it sells.

title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not: Seth Meyers, John Oliver and Fashion
description: Theres been a lot of speculation recently about whither goeth late-night comedy on television, and understandably so, given the churn in hosts. One of the answers, in any case, seems to be toward fashion  though whats really interesting is the divide that seems to be opening up in approaches to the subject.

title: On the Move, by Oliver Sacks
description: Medicine is dominated by the quants. We learn about human health from facts, and facts are measurable. A disease is present or not present; a reckonable proportion of people respond to a particular drug; the inability to predict gene-environment interactions reflects only a failure to map facts we will eventually be able to determine; and if the observable phenotype varies for an established genotype, the differences must be caused by calculable issues. In this version of things, the case histories that constituted most of medical literature up to the early 20th century reflect a lack of empirical sophistication. Only if we cant compute something are we reduced to storytelling, which is inherently subjective and often inaccurate. Science trades in facts, not anecdotes.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 511  524
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 511  524

title: Pep Guardiola Is Returning to Bayern Munich, He Insists
description: It will take a remarkable comeback for Bayern Munich to advance from Tuesdays Champions League semifinal second leg against Barcelona, but Pep Guardiola, the Bayern manager, said Monday that the result would have no bearing on whether he would be coaching a new club next season.

title: Reaction to Polish Presidential Election
description: President Bronislaw Komorowski of Poland and his challenger, Andrzej Duda of the Law and Justice party, spoke after a combination of exit polls and early ballot counts pointed to a runoff.

title: Comcast Hires Michael Cavanagh as Chief Financial Officer
description: Comcast announced on Monday that it had hired Michael J. Cavanagh as its chief financial officer, choosing a prominent Wall Street executive to help the company move forward after the collapse of its proposed $45 billion merger with Time Warner Cable.

title: Daily Report: Uber Funding Talks Highlight the Speedy Pace of Investments
description: Uber raised a total of more than $2 billion from investors in June and December last year  and is now back for another round. The anonymous messaging start-up Yik Yak collected $73.5 million in three financing rounds in seven months, and Zenefits, a human resources start-up, raised more than $580 million in less than two years, with the latest deal done last week, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced write.

title: Rampaging Inmates Kill 2 at a Nebraska Prison Described as Understaffed
description: Two inmates died and several people were injured in rioting at a Nebraska prison as inmates took over part of the complex for several hours before guards were able to retake control on Monday.

title: Rise of the Robots and Shadow Work
description: In the late 20th century, while the blue-collar working class gave way to the forces of globalization and automation, the educated elite looked on with benign condescension. Too bad for those people whose jobs were mindless enough to be taken over by third world teenagers or, more humiliatingly, machines. The solution, pretty much agreed upon across the political spectrum, was education. Americans had to become intellectually nimble enough to keep ahead of the job-destroying trends unleashed by technology, both robotization and the telecommunication systems that make outsourcing possible. Anyone who wanted a spot in the middle class would have to possess a college degree  as well as flexibility, creativity and a continually upgraded skill set.

title: Chris Christies Expense Account: Drinks Were on Him
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey likes to point out how he has made big cuts to state spending. But when it comes to using his allowance money as governor, he appears happy to be a high roller.

title: How to Avoid Saying Middle Class
description: A selection of clips from presidential hopefuls jockeying to be champions of the middle class without actually using the term, which has now become a precarious word in the American psyche.

title: Choosing the Battlefield in S.E.C. Cases
description: Lawyers are often accused of elevating procedure over substance, emphasizing the need to follow the rules over reaching the proper outcome in a case. In dealing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the focus lately has been arguing about where an action is filed, on the theory that picking the forum can be half the battle.

title: Sparkling Jewels Take Flight
description: Larkspur & Hawk celebrates the relaunch of its website with compelling images of its designs  in exactly the context its designer wants you to experience them (on the wings of birds).

title: A Dual Review of Whats New Starring Roseanne Barr and Diplo
description: Roseanne Barr, the Emmy-winning domestic goddess, crass comedian and macadamia-nut farmer whose upcoming film Roseanne for President! recounts her 2012 bid for the Oval Office, will return in July as a judge on NBCs Last Comic Standing. She takes on Diplo, a Twitter-trolling music producer and Mad Decent label boss who will release his third album as part of Major Lazer in June. A cartoon based on the electronica act premiered last month on FXX.

title: A Mans Tan, Without the UV
description: Men may not like to discuss bronzing creams and self-tanners, but that doesnt mean they dont use them.

title: Best-Selling Science Books
description: 1 Being Mortal by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/ Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better. (Last months ranking: 1)

title: Review: In Extreme, by Emma Barrett and Paul Martin, Psychologists Explore Those Who Test Limits
description: Funny thing happened on the way to the Moon: not much, wrote the astronaut Gene Cernan in his memoir about life in NASAs space program.

title: Multiple Colors Can Trick the Mind
description: Q. I heard that people cant look at a color in one room and then pick it out of a set of similar colors in the next room. But there are people with perfect pitch, so are there people with perfect hue?

title: 1915: No Remorse After Lusitania
description: As the Kaiser and his Government stand indicted for the murder of 1,145 men, women and children, including more than 100 Americans, as the result of the torpedoing and destruction of the Lusitania, the people of the civilized world have their eyes turned on the White House, waiting for the answer to the question: What is President Wilson going to do about it? That Herr Dernburg and Count Bernstorff believe that nothing will be done is evident, as the former has announced that the crime of the Lusitania will be followed be more murders of neutral passengers on the high seas.  The New York Herald, European Edition, May 12, 1915

title: Some Schools Embrace Demands for Education Data
description: MENOMONEE FALLS, Wis.  In this small suburb outside Milwaukee, no one in the Menomonee Falls School District escapes the rigorous demands of data.

title: Rangers Staying Guarded Despite History in Game 7s
description: WASHINGTON  On the back of the Rangers playoff warm-up T-shirts, there is a not-so-subtle reminder of last years Stanley Cup finals shortcoming, and this years mission: Change the ending.

title: Drillers Answer Low Oil Prices With Cost-Saving Innovations
description: KENEDY, Tex.  These are lean days in the South Texas oil patch, with once-bustling roads and hotels now empty as the price of oil has plunged and rig after rig sits idle.

title: Ask Grover: A Muppet Answers Questions About Feeding Kids
description: Who knows more about children than Sesame Street? Sesame Street Lets Cook! is a new family cookbook featuring kid-friendly recipes from Elmo, Cookie Monster, Grover and other Muppet celebrities from the Sesame Street gang.

title: Tempur Sealy C.E.O. and Chairman to Resign in Corporate Governance Fight
description: Days after losing a corporate governance challenge to an activist investor, Tempur Sealy International announced on Monday that it would overhaul its management and board.

title: Agns Varda to Be Honored at Cannes
description: The French film director Agns Varda will become the first woman to receive an honorary Palme dOr at this years Cannes film festival, which opens on Wednesday.

title: The Good Wife Season 6 Finale Recap: Were Those Two Even in the Same Place?
description: Season 6, Episode 22: Wanna Partner?

title: Muslims Flee to Malaysia and Indonesia by the Hundreds
description: BANGKOK  More than 1,000 refugees, including many women and children, came ashore in Malaysia early on Monday in what appears to be a sign of an accelerated exodus from western Myanmar and Bangladesh.

title: A Real-Life Closet (and Now, Book) Filled With Couture
description: For a new book called Electric Fashion, the collector Christine Suppes modeled in her own rare clothes all over the world.

title: Restaurant Guy Savoy
description: The chef Guy Savoy is moving his signature restaurant to the Monnaie de Paris.

title: Restaurant Guy Savoy Has a Striking New Home in Paris
description: PARIS  For 28 years, one of this citys most famous restaurants operated out of a dark, starkly modern site on rue Troyon, a banal street in the 17th Arrondissement close to the Arc de Triomphe. Now diners at Restaurant Guy Savoy will enter a grand 4,300-square-foot top-floor space on the site of both the oldest institution in France and the oldest factory in Paris: the Monnaie de Paris  the French mint.

title: An Art Auction for a Cause
description: A look at the items up for sale on Sunday at the Brant Foundation auction, which occurred in conjunction with a retrospective of the artist Rob Pruitt.

title: Henk Tijms: Boys and Girls in New Clothes
description: Our puzzle this week was created by Henk Tijms, a Dutch mathematician and emeritus professor at the VU University Amsterdam and the Tinbergen Institute in Amsterdam.

title: 20 Ex-C.I.A. Officials Fault The Times
Freed From Coalition, David Cameron Picks Conservative Cabinet
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron, fresh from winning a parliamentary majority in the general election last week, announced a cabinet on Monday that retains many senior figures but brings in some new faces, a number of them women.

title: Tasting Tours in New Delhi
description: When it comes to eating out in New Delhi, tourists tend to stick to well-known restaurants and miss out on how locals really eat, at least according to Anubhav Sapra, a longtime resident who started Delhi Food Walks to show travelers the citys authentic cuisine through themed trips in different parts of town.

title: What a Healthy Restaurant Meal Looks Like
description: Its never been easier to eat a healthy meal at a chain restaurant  so long as you know what youre doing,

title: Submarine With a Head and Eyes, 500 Million Years Old
description: A 500-million-year-old fossilized arthropod found in the Burgess Shale, a fossil field in the Canadian Rockies, may provide clues to how heads evolved in early animals. The fossil is a submarine-shaped arthropod, Odaraia alata, of the Middle Cambrian Period. A paper in Current Biology reports that both Odaraia alata, originally found about 100 years ago, and another ancient arthropod have a hard plate, known as the anterior sclerite, and eye-like features that were connected by nerves to their brains. They may have controlled their vision in much the same way that modern insects, crustaceans and spiders do.

title: NASAs Mercury Messenger: What It Learned Before It Crashed
description: Mercurys magnetic field is nearly four billion years old, researchers have found.

title: Blonde Redheads Simone Pace Finds His Backbeat in Two Tiny Sips
description: Simone Pace started drinking espresso at age 6. That might have been because he grew up in Milan, where the first espresso machines were produced more than a century ago. Also, my mother had to get the kids to school, he said, as he gently tamped down freshly ground coffee in a portafilter basket, careful not to pack it too tightly.

title: Pedaling Through Provence
description: The bicycle outfitter Ride & Seek has introduced a tour in the Provence region to highlight some of the most beautiful villages of France as ordained by the group Les Plus Beaux Villages de France.

title: Turkish Cargo Ship Attacked Off Libyan Coast
description: CAIRO  A Turkish cargo ship off the coast of Tobruk, Libya, was attacked by warplanes and artillery, killing a Turkish officer and injuring members of the crew, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

title: Carly Fiorina Taunts Hillary Clinton on Transparency
description: Carly Fiorinas presidential campaign is keeping track of how many questions the Republican candidate is taking each day and using the tally to taunt Hillary Rodham Clinton over her lack of transparency.

title: Folk Meets Rock
description: The romantic spirit of early Joni Mitchell  peasant dresses, poet blouses and textured coats  is toughened up when paired with a simple Chelsea boot.

title: Podcast: Transgender Today  Inside The Timess Editorial Series
description: Two editorial staff members provide insight into the thinking behind the series.

title: Sparkling Jewels Take Flight
description: Before she created the Georgian-inspired fine-jewelry line Larkspur & Hawk, Emily Satloff was immersed in the world of antiques: She worked as a curator of decorative arts at the New-York Historical Society, a consultant for the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a dealer of 18th-century jewelry. (It was the latter pursuit that led her to discover her signature technique of mounting metallic foil behind gemstones to enhance their color and shine.) Now, Satloff has commissioned a series of photographs by Horacio Salinas, debuting exclusively here, that capture her designs in their historical and artistic context. The images, styled by the creative director and former jewelry editor Talya Cousins, take as their point of departure an antique book of bird illustrations printed in 1873; they feel, Satloff says, almost as if a bird had flown in and collected the jewelry. Modern-day magpies can do the same through Larkspur & Hawks new website and online store, which relaunches today.

title: Speaking the Language of Risk
description: When I say risk and you say risk, chances are high we dont mean the same thing.

title: 1890: Kidnapped Girls Die on Ship
description: LONDON  Full details were received at Plymouth to-day [May 11] of the appalling disasters on board the Japanese steamer Fushibi Maru. This steamer left Nagasaki for Hong Kong, and, unknown to the officers, she had aboard a number of young girls destined for the English colony, who had been induced to go there by the agent of several disreputable houses. The scene of the tragedy was a manhole, which was only 3 feet high at the highest point and 2 feet in width. It is impossible to imagine the sufferings of a dozen persons crammed into such a hole for five days.  The New York Herald, European Edition, May 12, 1890

title: 2 Sunni Leaders Denounce Lack of Role in Iraqi Government
description: WASHINGTON  One month after Iraqs prime minister assured American officials here that his Shiite-dominated government was striving to build a multisectarian state, two leading Sunni politicians said Monday that Sunnis were being squeezed out of the countrys political system.

title: Interest Rates Are Still Very Low
description: Sorry about blog silence; still trying to get as much as possible of my great office cull done before I leave for England. Heres the scene right now:

title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Hires Tech Banker
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Bill Frauenhofer, a longtime adviser to chip-making companies, as its head of global semiconductor investment banking, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

title: For Clippers and Rockets, Hack-a-Shaq Strategy Isnt Working
description: How many times does a strategy have to fail before it is abandoned?

title: Wyndham Revamps Its Frequent-Stay Program
description: Trying to use loyalty points to book free hotel stays, which are often subject to blackout dates, shifting point minimums and high thresholds, is the bane of frequent travelers.

title: The Importance of Getting Sick in the Right Place
description: An unholy racket was coming from our clinic waiting room. It is never what you would call serene out there, but this degree of noise immediately penetrated everyones primal brain: Something was definitely wrong.

title: Tsarnaev Expressed Sympathy for Boston Bombing Victims, Sister Helen Prejean Says
description: BOSTON  Wearing street clothes, a silver cross dangling from her neck, Sister Helen Prejean, a Roman Catholic nun and prominent opponent of the death penalty, testified on Monday that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted Boston Marathon bomber, had expressed sympathy for his victims.

title: Ahold and Delhaize Is a Deal Waiting to Happen
description: It is a deal waiting to happen. To be completed, however, the protagonists may have to show that a 25 billion euro tie-up between Ahold of the Netherlands and Delhaize of Belgium is not an accident waiting to happen.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: What started last week finishes this week, with second-leg matches in the Champions League set for Tuesday and Wednesday. The soccer editor Andrew Das, a shameless Ajax supporter, tells you what to watch.

title: Public Theater Season Will Feature New Musicals by LaChiusa and Stew
description: Familiar collaborators will be front and center next season at the Public Theater, which will offer two new musicals by composers who have been regular presences there: First Daughter Suite, Michael John LaChiusas sequel of sorts to his 1993 First Lady Suite; and The Total Bent, by Stew and Heidi Rodewald, whose Passing Strange went from the Public to Broadway in 2008.

title: U.S. Will Allow Drilling for Oil in Arctic Ocean
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday gave conditional approval to allow Shell to start drilling for oil off the Alaskan coast this summer, a major victory for the petroleum industry and a devastating blow to environmentalists.

title: A Real-Life Closet (and Now, Book) Filled With Couture
description: Later tonight, a new, glossy tome will be privately feted at Londons Victoria and Albert Museum, coinciding with the European launch of Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty. Shot over the past five years by the fashion and portrait photographer Frederic Aranda, the 287-page labor of love, titled Electric Fashion ($80, Skira), features the San Francisco art patron and online fashion editor Christine Suppes and her personal collection of YSL, Chanel, Rodarte, Geoffrey Beene, Christian Lacroix, Vivienne Westwood, Alexander McQueen and more  which she has amassed over three decades and which, until recently, had sat quietly in her Palo Alto basement-turned-couture-closet, climate controlled and carefully preserved under muslin cloth. I feel like theres no difference with someone buying a dress to wear once, preserve and maintain, and someone buying a painting, she says. Its all art.

title: White House Warns Insurers About Surcharges and Gaps for Contraception
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday put health insurance companies on notice that they must cover all forms of female contraception, including the patch and intrauterine devices, without imposing co-payments or other charges.

title: Lucy Statue Gets a New Home
description: It was the statue laughed at across the country and around the world, but not in the way it was intended: a 400-pound bronze sculpture meant to depict Lucille Ball, the comic actress and I Love Lucy star, was instead nicknamed Scary Lucy for its large, glaring eyes, frightening smile and general lack of resemblance to the television pioneer. (At least the statue was holding a bottle of Vitameatavegamin.)

title: Stephen A. SchwarzmanGives $150 Million for Yale Cultural Hub
description: The Wall Street financier Stephen A. Schwarzman has fond memories of Commons, the 114-year-old limestone building at Yale where he first took meals as a shy freshman from a public school in suburban Philadelphia.

title: Tornados Destruction Cuts Deep in a Small Texas Town
description: VAN, Tex.  Pete Lucas, 75, sat outside his home in this debris-strewn East Texas town on Monday and stared at J.E. Rhodes Elementary School next door.

title: Despite Displeasure With U.S., Saudis Face Long Dependency
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Persian Gulf leaders, led by King Salman of Saudi Arabia, are sending increasingly public messages of displeasure with the Obama administration over its policies in the Middle East, even as the president seeks to reassure them this week in meetings at Camp David.

title: Chloe Perrin Shares Highlights From the Venice Biennale
description: The New York-based brand director of the French accessories house Perrin Paris offers a close look at her recent trip.

title: Jennifer Doudna, a Pioneer Who Helped Simplify Genome Editing
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  As a child in Hilo, one of the less touristy parts of Hawaii, Jennifer A. Doudna felt out of place. She had blond hair and blue eyes, and she was taller than the other kids, who were mostly of Polynesian and Asian descent.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Sentenced in Leak Case Tied to Times Reporter
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  A former Central Intelligence Agency officer on Monday was sentenced to three and a half years in prison on espionage charges for telling a journalist for The New York Times about a secret operation to disrupt Irans nuclear program. The sentence was far less than the Justice Department had wanted.

title: At Rebelle, a Shaved Cheese Course
description: To Nibble: Shave a Cheese, Serve a Crowd

title: Aide to Rand Paul Shatters the Yuck Barrier
description: A member of Rand Pauls staff in New Hampshire was all too ready for his close-up.

title: Nepal: A Travelers Memories
description: After his grandfather died in 2004, Kashish Das Shrestha, a Nepali photographer living in New York at the time, found himself with a surprise inheritance. Unknown to the 33-year-old, his grandfather, a longtime photographer in Kathmandu, had left him a suitcase of old slides.

title: President of Chile Removes Five From Cabinet in a Shake-Up
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  President Michelle Bachelet, responding to a series of corruption scandals that have shaken Chiles political establishment, made sweeping changes in her cabinet on Monday.

title: Cured From Cancer, Almost
description: I had to admit I was more than a little excited to see my next patient. This was a big day, for both of us.

title: Dean Skelos, New York Senate Leader, Vacates Post
description: ALBANY  The capital was thrown into familiar tumult on Monday as yet another of the states leaders fell from grace: Dean G. Skelos, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, stepped down from his leadership post.

title: Cleveland Museum Returns Ancient Statue to Cambodia
description: The statue of a kneeling Hindu deity with human and monkey features, above, believed stolen from a jungle-shrouded Khmer temple more than 40 years ago, has been returned to Cambodia by the Cleveland Museum of Art, which had displayed it since 1982, officials said on Monday.

title: Can the Union Hang On?
description: Since my Sunday column took a rather bleak view of the United Kingdoms prospects for continued unity after last weeks Tory/Scottish Nationalist sweep, let me offer the case for (relative) optimism about the unions near-term fate, which Tyler Cowen delivers in four points:

title: Jeb Bushs Revisionist History of the Iraq War
description: Last week, a spokesman for Jeb Bush, who used to be governor of Florida and is now vacuuming up as much dark money as he can without actually announcing a run for president, tried to unspin a comment Mr. Bush made in a private gathering that suggested he was taking advice about the Middle East from his brother, former President George W. Bush.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: What Were Reading Now
description: Chipotles announcement that it would stop serving genetically modified ingredients was largely met with scorn and derision by the media. But there is a bigger picture: Just because genetically modified crops have been deemed safe to ingest doesnt make them safe to grow.

title: A Climate-Modeling Strategy That Wont Hurt the Climate
description: It is perhaps the most daunting challenge facing experts in both the fields of climate and computer science  creating a supercomputer that can accurately model the future of the planet in a set of equations and how the forces of climate change will affect it. It is a task that would require running an immense set of calculations for several weeks and then recalculating them hundreds of times with different variables.

title: The Trans-Pacific Partnership Trade Deal Explained
description: Read an updated version here

title: Fight Over China Currency Policies Threatens Vote on Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON  A heated dispute over how to challenge China on currency policy has imperiled a trade bill that has become President Obamas top legislative priority, uniting even the presidents top Democratic supporters against taking up the bill in the Senate.

title: Security at Muhammad Cartoon Event Is Defended by Police
description: DALLAS  Police officials in Garland, Tex., the Dallas suburb where two gunmen opened fire May 3 outside a contest for caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, defended their handling of the events security at a news conference on Monday amid questions about whether local officials had been warned by federal authorities that one of the gunmen posed a threat.

title: Transgender Videos Tell-All: Live on the Times Editorial Page
description: Ernesto Londoo is a member of the Times editorial board. He describes the thinking behind Transgender Today: Real Stories, a video series in which readers tell their stories, in their own, memorable, words.

title: Tony-Nominated Musicals Are (Mostly) Soaring at Box Office
description: Three of the four Tony Award nominees for best new musical had their best week of sales yet at the box office, while one is struggling.

title: Searching for Identity in Chinas Outer Lands
description: Q. Sakamakis quest to understand himself has taken him to China, where he explores marginalized groups clinging to their identity.

title: Fear of Ruin as Disease Takes Hold of Italys Olive Trees
description: RACALE, Italy  Across the stony heel of Italy, a peninsula ringed by the blue-green waters of the Mediterranean, olive trees have existed for centuries, shaping the landscape and producing some of the nations finest olive oils. Except now, many of the trees are dying.

title: Jeb Bush Says He Would Not Repeal Obama Immigration Order Right Away
description: Jeb Bush said in an interview that he would not immediately move to repeal President Obamas executive order on immigration  suggesting he would instead wait for a new law to be passed addressing the matter.

title: Chinese Sailors Come a Long Way in the Volvo Ocean Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  The Chinese team in the Volvo Ocean Race could not have performed worse during a trial run in September, less than a month before the actual race began.

title: Beetle Found, No Sign of Relatives
description: A newly identified beetle species in the wetlands of South Africa has no direct relatives on the continent, a new study reports.

title: Review: Europa Galante Plays at Alice Tully Hall
description: During a visit to New York last year, the period-instrument ensemble Europa Galante offered a Vivaldi program showcasing (with distinctive interpretive touches) the oft-heard Four Seasons. On Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall, they played something far less common: a vivid programmatic work by Carlo Monza, part of a concert tracing the development of the symphonic genre in Italy and its impact on a young visitor, Mozart.

title: Chloe Perrin Shares Highlights From the Venice Biennale
description: Perrin Pariss creative director Chloe Perrin is no stranger to Venice. I lived in Venice for a bit of time when I was a student working at the Peggy Guggenheim Museum, she says. Im lucky I found a room to rent from an old Italian architect who guided me through town to his favorite local spots, away from the countless tourists. I have been going back for the Biennale this is my second  ever since, and always make time to go back to my favorite places. This trip, she stayed at the home of the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija, who was the consulting chef at The New York Times Luxury Conference gala last December, where he demonstrated that art, like food, is a form of sustenance.

title: Review: The Nordic Body Moves at 92nd Street Y
description: The Nordic Body: Choreographers From the Land of the Midnight Sun was one of the 92nd Street Ys more unusual evenings and not merely because of the free cocktails provided by the Consulate General of Sweden. On Saturday, as part of the Ys Dig Dance series, Helena Franzen, Irne Hultman, My Lindblad and SU-EN Butoh Company gathered for a 10 p.m. performance  not exactly midnight, but close enough  celebrating Swedish culture.

title: Finding a New Broadband Connection
description: Q. How do you find a broadband connection other than the cable company? Its really expensive and the only other option I can find here in my area is the phone company, which has a really bad reputation for reliability.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Indonesia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Artists, Others Ask City to Block Proposed Addition to the Frick Museum
description: Prominent artists, architects and gallerists have urged Mayor Bill de Blasio and Meenakshi Srinivasan, chairwoman and commissioner of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, to deny the Frick Collections expansion plan.

title: Obamarama
description: Every morning since President Obamas inauguration in 2009, the artist Rob Pruitt has made a small portrait of the commander in chief. The idea was born of his optimism following Obamas win: It seemed odd to not have any place to put that energy. More than 2,000 of these images go on display this month at the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit.

title: Emanuel Ax and Stephen Hough Explore the French Side of Chopin
description: The novelist George Sand, who had a volatile 10-year relationship with Chopin, used to quip to mutual friends in Paris that Chopin was more Polish than Poland.

title: A Grisly Find Under a Supermarket Illuminates Frances Medieval History
description: PARIS  Past the racks of hair accessories on the ground floor of the Monoprix supermarket on the corner of the Rue Raumur and the Boulevard de Sbastopol in the Second Arrondissement, there is a door marked staff only.

title: May 11, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Indonesia, Macedonia, Yemen and Gaza City.

title: Review: Night and Day, Vincent Herrings New Album
description: VINCENT HERRING

title: In Etan Patz Mistrial, a Latter-Day Henry Fonda
description: It is impossible to read the fascinating personal account of Adam Sirois, the lone holdout juror in last weeks mistrial in the long-awaited Etan Patz murder prosecution, and not think of Juror No. 8  better known as Henry Fonda.

title: University Grades Are Mixed on Research for the Poor
description: For the second time, American universities have been ranked by how well they do global health research. This time only one  Johns Hopkins  earned a grade as high as A minus.

title: Review: Jennifer Sheehan at 54 Below, With Stars Her Eyes
description: If the quirky world of New York cabaret were a high school class, Jennifer Sheehan would qualify for valedictorian, prom queen and the person most likely to succeed. Her new show, Stardust: A Night in the Cosmos, which she performed at 54 Below on Saturday, is a leap forward for a performer who initially evoked a demure, traditional ingnue playing by the rules.

title: Review: Torress New Album, Sprinter, Shows an Artist Opening Up
description: TORRES

title: U.S. and Georgia Start Military Exercise Criticized by Russia
description: VAZIANI MILITARY BASE, Georgia  Hundreds of American and Georgian service members stood at attention on this former Soviet airfield on Monday, as the two countries began joint military exercises to bolster cooperation between Georgian forces and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Review: War of the Encyclopaedists, by Christopher Robinson and Gavin Kovite
description: With an all-volunteer military and Americans at home being asked to make no real sacrifices, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan opened up a chasm between soldiers (the other 1 percent) and civilians. While troops were being killed and wounded over there, life back here went on very much the way it had before the Sept. 11 attacks. Many recent fiction and nonfiction books about those wars have looked at that disconnect by examining the difficulties that veterans face upon returning home to an oblivious country, feeling alienated and cut off, and often still reeling from the physical and emotional traumas of combat.

title: Self-Blame Still Common After Miscarriage
description: Miscarriage is common. Fifteen to 20 percent of clinically recognized pregnancies end within the first 20 weeks, and 80 percent of those miscarriages occur within the first 12 weeks. In many individual cases, the cause of the miscarriage remains unknown; statistically, about 60 percent of miscarriages are caused by chromosomal abnormalities, and most of the rest are caused by factors outside of the control of the mother, such as uterine abnormalities, endocrine or autoimmune disorders, or infection.

title: Judges Ruling Against 2 Banks Finds Misconduct in 08 Crash
description: Many on Wall Street have long argued that the banks did not generally break the law when they packaged shoddy mortgages and sold them to investors in the lead-up to the financial crisis of 2008.

title: Patriots Tom Brady Suspended for Four Games in Deflation Case
description: New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, a golden boy of American sports and perhaps pro footballs biggest star, was suspended Monday for four regular-season games without pay by the N.F.L., which said he had deliberately and secretly violated league rules.

title: E.U. Is Prepared to Combat Migrant Smugglers, Official Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  The top diplomat for the European Union said Monday that the bloc was prepared to take action against migrant smuggling rings based in Libya even without the approval of the United Nations Security Council. But the diplomat also sought to assure critics that the people trying to cross the Mediterranean would be rescued and given an opportunity to apply for asylum in Europe.

title: A Hardwood Romance
description: Brittney Griner and Glory Johnson, opponents in the Womens National Basketball Association, were married Friday at a resort in Phoenix.

title: For Brittney Griner and Glory Johnson, a Complicated Match Made on the Hardwood
description: These days, even in conservative Arizona, same-sex weddings are a dime a dozen. But this one was different.

title: Volvo Selects South Carolina for $500 Million Assembly Plant
description: Volvo Cars will build a factory in South Carolina, the company said on Monday, making it the first time a Chinese-owned automaker will have an auto assembly plant in the United States.

title: Scott Walker Helps Journalists in Wisconsin Cover His Trip to Israel
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin was adamant that his trip to Israel this week be a listening tour that focused exclusively on Israel, not about his presidential-campaign-in-waiting.

title: Review: Dumb Flesh, From Blanck Mass
description: BLANCK MASS

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: U.S. Must Do More on Civil Rights, Officials Agree
description: GENEVA  The United States acknowledged that it needed to do more to uphold civil rights and improve policing in a review of its human rights record at the United Nations on Monday, but faced calls for action by states on issues ranging from the death penalty, torture and targeted killings to mass surveillance by intelligence agencies.

title: Review: Witnesses, Now Streaming, Unpeels an Eerie Mystery
description: Turns out the French know how to peel an onion too.

title: Justice for Nail Salon Workers
description: Across the country, countless workers in the nail salon industry, mainly immigrant women, toil in misery and ill health for meager pay, usually with no overtime, abused by employers who show little or no consideration for their safety and well-being. It is a world of long days and toxic chemicals, where the usual protections of government have failed, at all levels.

title: Moone Boy, a Comedy Series With Chris ODowd, on Hulu
description: The Irish actor Chris ODowd has kept a full and varied schedule the last few years  starring in the British cult-favorite sitcom The I.T. Crowd, playing Brendan Gleesons antagonist in the grim indie feature Calvary, voicing Dr. Cockroach in the Nickelodeon series Monsters vs. Aliens, popping up in Thor: The Dark World.

title: Mark Halperin Apologizes for Remarks in Ted Cruz Interview
description: Mark Halperin, a political journalist for Bloomberg, issued an apology on Monday for a television interview he conducted with Senator Ted Cruz, in which he questioned the senator on his Cuban heritage, and asked him to speak Spanish.

title: Dean Skelos Steps Down  Finally
description: Only three months ago New Yorks seemingly untouchable Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver was forced to step down after his arrest on corruption charges. Now, from the other side of New Yorks famously gloomy capitol building, Dean Skelos, the majority leader of the State Senate,has followed Mr. Silvers lead.

title: In Sign of Palestinians Mood, Hamas Wins Vote at a West Bank University
description: BIRZEIT, West Bank  Lina Halsa certainly made a splash at the student rally for the Islamist Hamas movement here at Birzeit University last month. Wearing a sleeveless top, tight jeans, and with her hair in a ponytail, Ms. Halsas attire was revealing even by the standards of this liberal, secular campus. But it was downright scandalous according to Hamas norms.

title: In Performance | Nirbhaya
description: Poorna Jagannathan, foreground, and Japjit Kaur in a scene from Yael Farbers play in which Indian women describe their experiences of abuse. The show runs through Sunday at the Culture Project.

title: 2 Police Lives Lost Are the Focus in Mississippi
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  By the time a single bagpiper marched to the front of Hattiesburg Hall on Monday afternoon, scores of law enforcement officers from across Mississippi had lined the walls of the room in a local convention center. They, along with hundreds of ordinary citizens, had come to remember two young police officers, to seek solace and, perhaps, to seek meaning.

title: Life Without Tom Brady? The Patriots Will Rely on Jimmy Garoppolo
description: The suspension of Tom Brady means the Super Bowl champion New England Patriots have to face playing without their star for four games. How will they fare?

title: American Idol Stars: Where Are They Now?
description: American Idol has made a habit of creating stars  some who have managed to ride their Idol fame to bigger singing and acting careers, while others have struggled to make a name for themselves beyond the show.

title: TV Networks Borrow Page From Digital Rivals to Attract Advertisers
description: Coca-Cola has created some of the most memorable commercials in television history. Now the company is looking for something more.

title: Needle Moves in Las Vegas (and Not Into a Football)
description: It is a good thing Tom Bradys four-game suspension for his role in the ball-deflation case was not announced during the N.F.L. season, or else there might have been a run on Nevada sports books.

title: George Zimmerman Injured by Flying Glass in Shooting, Police Say
description: George Zimmerman, the former neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin in 2012, was injured on Monday during a confrontation in Central Florida with a man who had previously accused him of making threats and stalking, according to local authorities.

title: No New Conductor Chosen for Berlin Philharmonic
description: Orchestral democracy can be hard. One hundred twenty-three musicians in the Berlin Philharmonic met for 11 hours on Monday to try to elect a new chief conductor and artistic director, but failed to agree on a candidate to succeed Simon Rattle when he leaves the post in 2018.

title: George Zimmerman Was Shot, Police Say
description: Bianca Gillett, the spokeswoman for the Lake Mary Police Department in Florida, said that Mr. Zimmerman was taken to a hospital with minor injuries.

title: Readers Ask About the Exploitation of Nail Salon Workers
description: For 13 months, Sarah Maslin Nir investigated the workplace conditions in nail salons in the New York City area, discovering that manicurists are routinely underpaid and during their workdays, use nail and beauty products that could cause serious health conditions. Ms. Nir answered readers questions on Monday, during a Facebook Q. and A., on how she reported the two-part series, Unvarnished; what steps government agencies are now taking; and how consumers can help.

title: G.M.s Ignition Switch Death Toll Hits 100
description: DETROIT  The consequences of General Motors long-delayed recall of defective small cars hit a grim milestone on Monday, when the companys compensation fund said it had approved the 100th death claim tied to faulty ignition switches.

title: Alexandre Lamfalussy, a Euro Founder, Dies at 86
description: FRANKFURT  Alexandre Lamfalussy, a Hungarian-born economist and banker considered a founding father of the euro, died on Saturday in Ottignies, Belgium. He was 86.

title: Nepal: Officials Seek Escaped Inmates
description: Nepalese prison authorities are searching for more than 200 inmates who escaped after last months devastating earthquake. Himnath Dawadi, head of the Prison Management Department, said Monday that 216 prisoners had fled from Sindhupalchok, one of the worst-affected districts, where the prison was destroyed, and that four more had escaped from Kathmandus prison. The department said 16 prisoners were killed in Kathmandus central jail after the building collapsed.

title: Rand Paul Tries to Stake Territory as Lone Candidate Whod Guard Civil Liberties
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Senator Rand Paul cant stop swearing.

title: JPMorgan Hires Banker for Private Financing
description: JPMorgan Chase has hired a senior banker to lead the firms effort to provide private financing for companies like hot Silicon Valley start-ups, the bank announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

title: India: Dozens Die in Bus Plunge
description: At least 25 people died and 30 were injured Monday when an overcrowded bus fell into a deep gorge in Indian-controlled Jammu and Kashmir. A police official said the bus, which belonged to a private company, fell more than 150 feet into the gorge, apparently because of driver error.

title: Seymour Hersh Article Alleges Cover-Up in Bin Laden Hunt
description: WASHINGTON  Four years after a Navy SEAL team killed Osama bin Laden in his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, lingering questions remain about the raid and what led up to it. Now, in a 10,000-word article in The London Review of Books, the journalist Seymour M. Hersh challenges nearly every facet of the semiofficial narrative that has emerged over the years, alleging a vast cover-up that involves hundreds, possibly thousands, of people and goes all the way to President Obama himself.

title: Cuomo, Taking Aim at Campus Sexual Assaults, Calls for a Stricter Law
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, appearing at a Manhattan college with Representative Nancy Pelosi, on Monday called for the passage of the toughest law in the nation on campus sexual assault, a message aimed at state lawmakers who have expressed some reservations about his proposals.

title: Mira Rothenberg, Pioneer in Therapy for Children, Dies at 93
description: Mira Rothenberg, whose experience and commitment to caring for concentration camp orphans as a college student in Manhattan shaped her pioneering therapy for autistic and schizophrenic children, died on April 16 in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 93.

title: Second Trial in Etan Patz Case Is Almost Inevitable, Experts Say
description: The Manhattan district attorney remained silent on Monday about whether he will retry a former store clerk accused of murdering Etan Patz, but former prosecutors said a second trial is almost inevitable, given that the Patz family is pushing for one and that the prosecution was one vote shy of a conviction.

title: Yankees Routine: Two Set Table, and Two Others Wipe the Floor Clean
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees rode Michael Pinedas dominating pitching performance  he had 16 strikeouts, the most by any pitcher in the major leagues this season  to a win over the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday. At other times, the resurgent power of Mark Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez has carried the Yankees to victories.

title: Main Street Portfolios Are Investing in Unicorns
description: With Uber now reportedly valued at $50 billion, there are justifiable worries that some private start-up technology companies worth $1 billion or more  known as unicorns  are in bubble territory.

title: Brooklyn District Attorney to Appeal New Trial for Man Convicted in 1991 Killing
description: One month after a Brooklyn judge ordered a new trial for a defendant convicted of a 1991 murder, the Brooklyn district attorney has filed notice that he will appeal the decision.

title: David Blatt Draws Scrutiny After Cavaliers Crucial Victory
description: CLEVELAND  Eleven minutes had passed in David Blatts news conference Monday afternoon when he finally betrayed some impatience with the reporters encircling him on the Cleveland Cavaliers practice court.

title: Picasso and Giacometti Artworks Top $120 Million Each at Christies Sale
description: To a medley of whoops, hollers and gasps on Monday night, Pablo Picassos 1955 painting Les Femmes dAlger (Version O) sold for $179.4 million including fees at Christies Looking Forward to the Past sale of artworks spanning the 20th century. The price was the highest on record for a work of art sold at auction, the company said, and was well over its estimate of $140 million.

title: Kings Absence at Meeting Signals a Saudi-U.S. Marriage Adrift
description: WASHINGTON  The decision by King Salman of Saudi Arabia to skip a summit meeting called by President Obama reflects a new reality for two nations that for generations shared goals in the Middle East but that are now at odds in fundamental ways.

title: A Sudden Elevation for John J. Flanagan, a Vocal Legislator
description: ALBANY  John J. Flanagan was 25 and a second-year law student when his father  Assemblyman John Flanagan Sr., a well-respected Republican from Long Island  died of a heart attack while jogging near the familys home in Suffolk County.

title: Wrigley Field Is Feeling Familiar With Bleachers Return
description: CHICAGO  Adorned in Cubs gear  hat, sweatshirt and jacket  Al Yellon was the first in line nearly four hours before the Wrigley Field bleacher gates opened Monday night. He has sat there regularly since the 1970s, has had season tickets since the early 90s and rarely misses a game. The bleachers, he said, were like home.

title: Clues on Twitter Show Ties Between Texas Gunman and ISIS Network
description: Hours before he drove into a Texas parking lot last week and opened fire with an assault rifle outside a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, Elton Simpson, 30, logged onto Twitter.

title: Disunion Panel Featuring David Blight, Ken Burns, Adam Goodheart and Jamie Malanowski
description: This discussion was recorded April 4, 2011, at the TimesCenter.

title: Iran: Blacklisted Airline Buys Planes
description: An Iranian airline blacklisted under United States sanctions has bought nine used Airbus passenger planes, in a move that could further complicate the multilateral talks aimed at resolving Irans disputed nuclear program by the end of next month. The Iranian news media reported Sunday that the airline, Mahan Air, bought the aircraft  eight Airbus A340s and one A321  for an undisclosed amount from unidentified sellers, and that they were placed into service last week. The Iranian news accounts described the purchase as an important boost for the countrys civilian aviation industry, which has struggled for many years because of an aging fleet and American-imposed restrictions on access to replacement aircraft, parts, technology and service. Mahan Air was placed on a sanctions list in October 2011 by the Treasury Department over what it called the airlines support for activities of Irans Revolutionary Guards Quds Force and Hezbollah militants. The purchase could inflame congressional critics of the nuclear talks who contend that Iran cannot be trusted and that it already is openly flouting the sanctions.

title: Office Item
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Even after all this time, a theme will occasionally take me by surprise. Paul Hunsbergers SNAPpy theme did exactly that, and its a good lesson. Never assume that you have figured out a theme early in your solve, because the constructor and Will Shortz may just pull a fast one on you.

title: Review: The Painted Rocks at Revolver Creek, an Athol Fugard Play
description: They got eyes but they do not see us, says the gentle old man to the young boy in The Painted Rocks at Revolver Creek, the tender, ruminative new play written and directed by Athol Fugard. Both man and boy are black South Africans, and the mans observation refers to the white farmers for whom he works.

title: Days Before Prom in Shelton, Conn., a Dress Code Adds to the Stress
description: SHELTON, Conn.  As surely as flowers bloom, springtime brings prom drama around the country. The dates, the dancing, the photos, the cost  it is all fraught. And the dresses. Oh, the dresses.

title: The Works of Chris Burden
description: Mr. Burden was one of the foremost performance artists of the 1970s.

title: W.H.O. Needs Reforms in Wake of Ebola Crisis, Report Says
description: GENEVA  The World Health Organization needs structural reform and a radical change of culture to enable it to cope with future health emergencies, a panel of experts said in a preliminary report issued Monday that was critical of the agencys delayed reaction to the Ebola crisis.

title: Former Students Seek to Shape Corinthian Colleges Bankruptcy
description: Lawyers for an ad-hoc student group, seeking to represent the interests of about 500,000 former students of the recently collapsed Corinthian Colleges Inc., have asked that a special committee be formed to press the students claims and ensure their participation in bankruptcy proceedings that will affect their futures. Scott Gautier, bankruptcy counsel for the ad hoc student group, estimated the students claims at $25 billion or more, and said that an official student creditors committee would help the students focus on redress, including student loan forgiveness or programs to help them with education and job placement.
