title: Judge Denies Groups Whistle-Blower Standing in Suit Against U.S. Bank
description: A federal judge this week dismissed an innovative lawsuit that had threatened to open a new front in the legal assault on the foreclosure practices of large banks.

title: Eva Zuckerman, the Original X-Woman
description: Plus: A touch of abstract minimalism for a frock that works at any hour; song titles and lyrics on tees; and more shopping news.

title: All White Looks
description: Some examples from recent events.

title: Summers Color Forecast: Whiteout Conditions
description: At a pivotal moment in Ex Machina, the sci-fi fantasy drawing crowds to the multiplex, Ava, the movies saucer-eyed android, sallies into a fine spring day, incandescent in white lace. Alicia Vikander, who plays the electronic temptress (and models a similar dress on the cover of this months W), is keenly aware of its evocative powers.

title: Missouri Passes Anti-Union Bill, but It Isnt Veto-Proof
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  The Republican-controlled Missouri General Assembly on Wednesday approved legislation that would enact a so-called right-to-work policy in the state, but it fell far short of the required number of votes to overcome a likely veto from Gov. Jay Nixon.

title: Fearing Bangladeshi Blogger Might Claim Asylum, Sweden Blocked Visit That Could Have Saved His Life
description: A Bangladeshi blogger and secular activist who was hacked to death on Tuesday would still be alive if Sweden had not blocked his planned visit to Stockholm this month to celebrate World Press Freedom Day, according to the Swedish chapter of PEN, an international writers group.

title: In Ukraine, Bones of War Dead Re-emerge to Stir Political Passions
description: LVIV, Ukraine  The calls come in with distressing regularity: A man, out for a walk in the forest, stumbles on a human shinbone; another, digging a basement for a house, finds a skull.

title: A Police Shooting in Midtowns Seedier Side
description: Two police officers responded to a 911 call of an assault on Wednesday morning. It turned out to be nothing, and so they left empty-handed, emerging from an office building at 580 Eighth Avenue, between 38th and 39th Streets. It was a sunny, breezy day on a stretch that can look anything but sunny and breezy.

title: For Lending Start-Up, a Man Whos Been Through a Few Cycles
description: Through three decades, Jerry Weiss wore coats and ties to the offices where he managed credit risks at the nations biggest banks  a 50-story Citigroup tower in Queens and the 60-story Chase Manhattan Plaza in Lower Manhattan.

title: Bank of England Expects Zero Inflation Rate to Pick Up
description: The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it expected Britains inflation rate, which has been stuck at zero for two months, to pick up by the end of the year as the economy gathers steam. The central bank trimmed its economic growth forecast for the year to 2.5 percent, from an earlier estimate of 2.9 percent. But the revision reflects the low growth in the first quarter  0.3 percent  which was short of the banks estimate of 0.6 percent. The inflation rate will rise to 0.6 percent by the end of 2015, the bank predicted. Its policy target is an annual inflation rate of 2 percent, which is deemed a healthy sign of economic growth.

title: The U.S. Corporate Tax Isnt That Weird
description: We wouldnt want to follow North Koreas lead on tax policy. But what about South Korea?

title: Some Doubt That North Korea Executed a Top General
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Even to longtime analysts familiar with the unpredictability of the North Korean government, the news was shocking: a top general, the countrys equivalent of a defense minister, who had delivered a speech at an international symposium in Moscow last month, was executed by an antiaircraft gun while hundreds of fellow generals and senior party officials watched.

title: Program Providing Legal Help to Immigrants Will Expand Beyond New York City
description: New York Citys melting pot has been boiling over in the larger metropolitan area.

title: Verizons Deal for AOL Is a Push Into the Technology of Advertising
description: A new generation of Math Men is taking over the Mad Men of Madison Avenue.

title: Ed Fouhy, TV Newsman and Promoter of Civic Journalism, Dies at 80
description: Ed Fouhy, a television news executive who won five Emmy Awards, worked at all three major broadcast networks and produced two presidential debates during a 35-year career in Washington, died on Wednesday in Chatham, Mass. He was 80.

title: Political Turmoil Returns to Burundi as President Seeks New Term
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  Under a cloudy sky, Kamaro Pierre recounted passionately how he barely escaped death as a teenager.

title: Publishers Send Diverse Group of News Articles in Facebook Debut
description: Some felt it would revolutionize journalism. Others thought it might be the beginning of its destruction. But on Wednesday, what readers mostly saw in Facebook Instant Articles, the new format by which news organizations are publishing directly on Facebook, was an eclectic mix of articles rather than a clear signal of what is to come.

title: Wave Hill Puts Spotlight on Art to Celebrate Its Gardens and Lure Visitors
description: Summer has come early to a public garden in the Bronx: Dragonflies skim over clusters of lily pads in a lush aquatic garden in full August bloom. But only at night.

title: B Vitamin Is Found to Help People Prone to Some Types of Skin Cancer
description: An inexpensive vitamin can help reduce the occurrence of common skin cancers in people prone to that disease, researchers reported on Wednesday.

title: One Day After Wreck, Increased Funding for Amtrak Fails in a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON  The bodies had not yet been fully recovered from the Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia before Capitol Hill erupted hours later into its usual partisan clash over how much money to spend on the long-struggling national rail service.

title: Amtrak Needs Help
description: It may take a while to learn exactly why an Amtrak train speeding out of Philadelphia Tuesday night suddenly derailed on a sharp curve. Whether the train was going too fast or the equipment failed or it was something else entirely, the horrifying accident left at least seven people dead and more than 200 injured on one of the busiest train routes in the country.

title: Chad: Date Is Set for Ex-Presidents Trial
description: Former President Hissne Habr will stand trial on charges of crimes against humanity on July 20 at a special court in Senegal, the court announced Wednesday. It will be the first case to be tried in Africa on the principle of universal jurisdiction, which holds that certain crimes transcend borders, and it has the backing of the African Union. A panel of judges from Burkina Faso and Senegal will preside. Mr. Habrs prosecution is the result of a campaign began more than two decades ago by some of his former prisoners, supported by human rights groups, who demanded an end to Mr. Habrs comfortable exile in Senegal, where he fled after he was ousted in 1990. He became president in 1982, receiving weapons and funds from the United States, which sought a counterweight to neighboring Libya. He was indicted in 2013, accused of killing thousands of political prisoners and torturing uncounted others during his eight years in office.

title: Three Amtrak Victims With a Common Thread: All Were Heading Home to Family
description: PHILADELPHIA  One was a midshipman at the Naval Academy who wanted to become a member of the Navy SEALs. Another was the young chief executive of an education start-up, excited about her new job. A third was a seasoned software engineer helping The Associated Press news service move into video. Another was a banking executive. Still another, an educator.

title: Uber and Internet Giants Assail New York Citys Plan to Bolster Rules for Car-Hire Apps
description: From the stage of a Midtown Manhattan ballroom last week, Mayor Bill de Blasio indulged in a little bit of positive bragging about the success of start-ups in the city.

title: Christies Has Art Worlds First $1 Billion Week
description: It was a week the art world had never seen before. For the first time, an auction house sold more than $1 billion of art  over three days at that  a vast outpouring of money that amazed even the wealthy and the celebrities who flocked to the auction floor.

title: Brothers Past Proves Tricky for Jeb Bush
description: A young woman berated Jeb Bush in Reno, Nev., on Wednesday for his brothers bungled war in Iraq, saying it had spawned the group calling itself the Islamic State. Your brother created ISIS, she declared. Mr. Bush said he respectfully disagreed.

title: Saudi Arabia Promises to Match Iran in Nuclear Capability
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama began making the case for a deal with Iran that would delay its ability to assemble an atomic weapon, his first argument was that a nuclear-armed Iran would set off a free-for-all of proliferation in the Arab world. It is almost certain that other players in the region would feel it necessary to get their own nuclear weapons, he said in 2012.

title: Technology That Could Have Prevented Amtrak Derailment Was Absent
description: For the second time in two years, a passenger train traveling well above its speed limit has derailed, leaving a trail of death and injuries. And for the second time, existing technology that might have prevented the accident was missing.

title: 5 Big Banks Expected to Plead Guilty to Felony Charges, but Punishments May Be Tempered
description: For most people, pleading guilty to a felony means they will very likely land in prison, lose their job and forfeit their right to vote.

title: Traces of Chemicals in Syria Add to Pressure on Obama to Enforce a Red Line
description: WASHINGTON  If President Obama hoped that the danger of chemical warfare in the Middle East receded when Syria gave up tons of poison gas, mounting evidence that toxic weapons remain in the strife-torn country could once again force him to decide just how far he is willing to go to enforce his famous red line.

title: Marco Rubio Casts U.S., and Himself, as Strong Leader
description: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a 2016 presidential candidate, offered a robust and muscular foreign policy plan Wednesday, laying out his vision for the use of American power in the 21st century.

title: Report Sees Alcohol Involved in Secret Service Car Episode
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security inspector general has found that two senior Secret Service agents were most likely under the influence of alcohol in March when they drove into an area near the White House where the authorities were examining a suspicious package.

title: Johnny Gimble, Who Fiddled His Way to Fame, Dies at 88
description: Johnny Gimble, a virtuoso Texas fiddler who played with a roster of country superstars including Bob Wills, Marty Robbins, Merle Haggard, Willie Nelson and George Strait, died on Saturday in Marble Falls, Tex., northwest of Austin. He was 88. His wife, Barbara, said the cause was a stroke.

title: Somalia Executes 2 Militants Convicted of Assassinations
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Somali government on Wednesday executed two men convicted of killing four lawmakers and an intelligence officer in a series of attacks, officials said.

title: Verizon Takes to the Battlefield
description: Meet the new disrupter.

title: Lose It
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Be careful what you wish for, Will Shortz. Crossword constructors have a perverse sense of humor.

title: Rachel Rosenthal, Bold Performance Artist, Dies at 88
description: Rachel Rosenthal, a performance artist whose work  fierce, funny, earthy and cantankerous  bemoaned the political and ecological fate of the planet, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Jerome Cooper, a Multitextured Jazz Percussionist, Dies at 68
description: Jerome Cooper, a percussionist who played an important role in the post-1960s jazz avant-garde, especially as a member of the influential trio the Revolutionary Ensemble, died on May 6 in Brooklyn. He was 68.

title: New Review Policy for Migrant Families in Detention
description: Migrant families in detention will have more frequent case reviews to determine if they can be released, Department of Homeland Security officials said Wednesday. Women with their children being held in three family detention centers will have a first review after 90 days and then every two months after that. The immigration authorities will no longer point to a general goal of deterring illegal border crossing as the reason for detaining women and children. But the authorities will continue to place a high priority on deporting or detaining migrants caught crossing the border illegally. Central American women seeking asylum and their children have faced many months in detention while their cases moved through the immigration courts. The new policy is designed to continually re-evaluate whether detention is necessary for them, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said.

title: Sudden Life: Rangers Advance With Game 7 Win Over Capitals
description: The Rangers and the Washington Capitals had battled for six games  each one decided by a single goal  and well into overtime Wednesday night in Game 7 of their memorable second-round playoff series. What separated the teams at Madison Square Garden was a stunning six-second sequence.

title: North Carolina: More Seized Assets to Be Returned
description: Federal prosecutors agreed Wednesday to return more than $100,000 that was seized from a rural convenience store owner even though the owner, Lyndon McLellan, was not accused of a crime. The Justice Department announced in March that it would no longer pursue such seizures, a form of civil asset forfeiture based on a pattern of small cash deposits, without a criminal charge or evidence of criminal activity. The prosecutor in Mr. McLellans case had expressed displeasure that Congress had been given sealed court filings and offered him a settlement of half his money. Last week, the Justice Department said it would investigate two other prosecutors after one business owner whose assets were seized said he had been punished more harshly after publicizing his case and another said he had been threatened with a felony charge if he did not agree to give up some of his money. This is the third high-profile case that prosecutors have dropped in recent months.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Thursday
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Lori Fouch | Leading Through Sandy
description: At the helm of an insurance company during Hurricane Sandy, Lori Dickerson Fouch, C.E.O. of Prudential Group Insurance, stresses that when it comes to a crisis, there is no management playbook.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The first bump, you didnt know what it was, except that it was something strong. The second, you knew something was wrong. And the third, forget about it, now youre praying.

title: Adam Warren Has Strong Outing, but Signs Point to Return to Bullpen
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Chris Capuano, recovered from a quadriceps injury, is ready to return to the Yankees any day now. Ivan Nova is on track to return next month from Tommy John surgery. Masahiro Tanaka reported no problems with his forearm, which had been strained, after he threw a bullpen session Tuesday.

title: For One Photographer, Still Lifes as an Act of Rebellion
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: At ICFF, Marble Tables That Transform Jorts Into Design Objects
description: To the average person, T-shirts and jeans are nothing more than everyday wardrobe basics. The artist Sean Knibb has a different point of view. Beginning May 16, the L.A.-based designer will show his latest work, Casa Canova, a collection of six hand-carved marble tables featuring motifs of tees and denim shorts. The tables, which took more than 700 hours to create and weigh about 770 pounds each, were conceptualized by Knibb in his Venice, Calif., studio and created by master artisans in Carrara, Italy, using classic 18th-century techniques.

title: Rock Legend
description: Deep in the desolate heart of Joshua Tree hides a house as otherworldly as the landscape itself.

title: Piet Hein Eek Brings His Singular Furniture  and a Couple of Friends  to NoHo
description: Piet Hein Eek  whose furniture famously elevates found material into high design  is more than just one of the Dutch scenes most prominent exports; hes also an influential curator and inspire-er, as David Alhadeff, owner of the design gallery The Future Perfect, puts it. To that end, the top floor of Eeks vast studio and workshop in Eindhoven (a former Philips lighting factory that also encompasses a restaurant and store) has been christened the Wonder Room and exhibits collaborations, most of them among emerging Dutch talent, that blur the lines between design, fine art and technological innovation. Now, to coincide with New York Design Week (and change), Eek is commandeering the entire Future Perfect storefront in NoHo to create a Stateside iteration of that space. On view and available for purchase are a number of new pieces created in collaboration with some of Eeks favorite young compatriots  such as a hardware-out exoskeleton cabinet by Paul Heijnen and artwork by Marc Mulders  as well as never-before-seen works by Eek himself, including a brass mesh lamp and a burned-and-oxidized steel cabinet. Eek also brought American designers into his Wonder Room mix for the first time via a lighting showcase, featuring such local mainstays as Lindsey Adelman, Bec Brittain and Jason Miller.

title: A Venture Capital Firm Led by 2 Women Plans to Introduce a Fund
description: SAN FRANCISCO  More than a year after striking out on their own, the founders of Aspect Ventures are preparing a formal introduction of a sizable fund.

title: Word of the Day | fete
description: fete  \fat, fet\  noun and verb

title: Matt Harvey Foils the Cubs, but the Mets End Up Stopping Themselves
description: CHICAGO  The Mets sent Jacob deGrom and Noah Syndergaard to the mound for the first two games of their series against the Cubs, and both struggled in losses.

title: Derek Stepan Scores a Stunner, but the Games Margin Is Not So Surprising
description: It almost had to come to this  another one-goal game for the Rangers after a litany of them in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 9:40 A.M. (TMC) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Mr. Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric; Emmanuelle Seigner is Cline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Jose Croze is a speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. The phrase triumph of the human spirit hovers over The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichs, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind  among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration  Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual, he added, noting that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.

title: Momentum Regained and Order Restored, Warriors Roll Over Grizzlies
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When the Golden State Warriors come, they do it in waves, as relentless as any tide pulling across the San Francisco Bay. The Memphis Grizzlies are merely the latest to feel the brunt of their momentum.

title: Corrections: May 14, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Chinas Superrich: The Bling Dynasty
description: The current occupant of the White House can keep the Rose Garden. Somewhere on the other side of the globe, a Chinese billionaire built a replica of the White House with an even better view: of Mount Rushmore.

title: Qualcomm, on Patent Law
description: To the Editor:

title: The Restaurant Industry, on the Minimum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Drilling in the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: Real-Life, Not TV, Policing
description: To the Editor:

title: An Oklahoma Suburb, Tornado-Ready
description: SHERMAN, Tex.  SOMETIMES it appears as if there is a target hanging over Moore, Okla.: Storms seem to find it.

title: Wow, Jeb Bush Is Awful
description: Lets discuss Jeb Bushs terrible week.

title: H.I.V. Outbreak in Indiana
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis at Sea
description: One of the worlds most beautiful regions, the seas of Southeast Asia  home to sparkling white beaches and $7,000-a-night beach villas  is becoming a scene of a mass atrocity.

title: The Changing Role of the Professor
David Letterman Knew How to Talk
description: THE imminent end, on May 20, of David Lettermans 33-year run as a late-night TV host is a sad event for a number of reasons. Mr. Lettermans Late Show monologues are still the gold standard in an increasingly crowded field. His Top 10 lists remain the most durable running gag in late-night television. (Top 10 Things Overheard in Hillary Clintons Van: Polling indicates we should take the Taconic.) He virtually invented the age of irony, and his self-mocking style has kept him a paragon of cool, even as his competitors have grown younger and his audience older.

title: Shortcomings of Cybersecurity Bills
description: A series of brazen hacking attacks against companies like Sony Pictures, Target and Anthem have spurred lawmakers in Congress to propose cybersecurity legislation. These bills could help make American networks somewhat less vulnerable to hackers, but they would do so at a cost to the privacy of individuals.

title: A Tiny Crack in the Russian Ice
description: It is a measure of how low American-Russian relations have sunk that a meeting between President Vladimir Putin and Secretary of State John Kerry that achieves nothing is perceived as good news. But good news it was when they met for four hours in the southern Russian city of Sochi on Tuesday, following talks between Mr. Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov.

title: The Baltimore Police Dept. Policy for Persons in Custody
description: The Baltimore Police Department issued these revisions to the departments general order on handling persons in custody on April 3, 2015.

title: Baltimore Officers Plan to Challenge Prosecutors Basic Accusation
description: BALTIMORE  Less than two weeks after six police officers were charged in the arrest and death of Freddie Gray, the officers lawyers and supporters have sketched the outline of a defense, taking aim at the substance of some of the most serious accusations, as well as at procedural issues.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed
description: In Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed, The Times reports on what is currently known about the crash.

title: Chinese Investigators Describe Capture of Panda Killers
description: Given the popularity of giant pandas as attractions both in China and in zoos around the world, it is easy to forget that they still face mortal threats.

title: Uncertainty Reigns in Burundi After Attempted Coup
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Pierre Nkurunziza was back in Burundi on Thursday, news agencies reported, a day after an attempted coup against his government.

title: Test Yourself | Jay, Bey and a Vegan Food Company
description: Below, several paragraphs from the May 7 article Jay Z and Beyonc Want to Put You in a Vegan State of Mind.

title: How Myanmar and Its Neighbors Are Responding to the Rohingya Crisis
description: Myanmar and its neighbors see the people of the Rohingya ethnic group and the seaborne trafficking of migrants in the region very differently, complicating the refugees plight.

title: A Bronx Apartment Just Like the One in Manhattan
description: Beth Rosen and Maryann King had every reason to think they would never move again. Since 1981, they had lived in the same building on West 110th Street in Morningside Heights.

title: 12 Years Later, a Mystery of Chemical Exposure in Iraq Clears Slightly
description: The toxic vapors acted quickly against the Second Platoon of the 811th Ordnance Company, whose soldiers were moving abandoned barrels out of an Iraqi Republican Guard warehouse in 2003. The building, one soldier said, was littered with dead birds.

title: What Is the Role of Religion or Spirituality in Your Life?
description: How important is a spiritual life to you? Do you identify yourself as a member of a particular religion or spiritual tradition, or are you one of the growing group of young people who consider themselves nothing in particular?

title: Telefnica of Spain Reports Profit Jump From Pending Sale of O2
description: LONDON  Telefnica, the Spanish telecommunications giant, said on Thursday that its net profit in the first three months of the year almost tripled after it benefited from a one-off financial gain from the pending sale of its British division.

title: Weed the People, by Bruce Barcott
description: Bruce Barcotts title spares the reviewer of a certain age  cured in the smokehouse of the 1960s  from starting with his own weak, drug-related jest. The book has several other virtues. One of which is not focus.

title: James Merrill: Life and Art, by Langdon Hammer
description: Some people are born with a silver spoon, but the poet James Merrill  son of a founder of Merrill Lynch  had whole place settings jammed down his throat. His family was exceedingly rich, with houses in Greenwich Village and Southampton, where an estate named the Orchard became a showplace for weekends and summers. Broad lawns unrolled on either side of the drive, with huge squat boxwood hedges for sentinels and wistful, champagne-glass-shaped elms shading the gravel circle at the front door, Langdon Hammer (chairman of the English department at Yale) writes in his eloquent and sympathetic new biography, James Merrill: Life and Art. That such great wealth never sapped Merrills ambition as a poet seems remarkable in itself. Jimmy was no less of a competitor than his father, Hammer notes, and no less hungry for public recognition.

title: The Psychology of Choking Under Pressure
description: Choking, or failing in a pressure-filled situation, is common enough. But the underlying psychology is surprisingly mysterious for such a familiar phenomenon. So scientists at Johns Hopkins University and the California Institute of Technology decided to investigate what happens in the brain of a person who chokes. They recruited 26 men and women to practice playing a mentally taxing video game  which involved moving dots on a screen quickly  while lying down in an M.R.I. machine.

title: Are You a Risk Taker? Take the Quiz
description: Are you a bit of a daredevil when it comes to taking risks? Or more conservative?

title: Going Viral: Behind the Digital Strategy for Metros Nail Salon Expos
description: When Sarah Maslin Nirs two-part investigation of the mistreatment of nail salon workers in New York was published last week, her 13 months of research and reporting saw almost immediate results: On Monday morning, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced statewide measures to protect salon workers.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Death Toll in Philippine Factory Fire Climbs Above 70
description: MANILA  The toll from one of the deadliest industrial fires in Philippine history rose to 72 on Thursday, officials said, as firefighters carried one body bag after another out of the blackened remnants of a slipper factory.

title: New York Today: Train Crash Snarls Transit
description: Good morning on this crystalline Thursday.

title: Rohingya Migrants From Myanmar, Shunned by Malaysia, Are Spotted Adrift in Andaman Sea
description: IN THE ANDAMAN SEA OFF THAILAND  A wooden fishing boat carrying several hundred desperate migrants from Myanmar was spotted adrift in the Andaman Sea between Thailand and Malaysia on Thursday, part of an exodus in which thousands of people have taken to the sea in recent weeks with no country willing to take them in.

title: Let Syrians Settle Detroit
description: Detroit, a once great city, has become an urban vacuum. Its population has fallen to around 700,000 from nearly 1.9 million in 1950. The city is estimated to have more than 70,000 abandoned buildings and 90,000 vacant lots. Meanwhile, desperate Syrians, victims of an unfathomable civil war, are fleeing to neighboring countries, with some 1.8 million in Turkey and 600,000 in Jordan.

title: Donors Must Find Their Own Lunch at Hillary Clinton Gathering
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign may be wooing donors in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn on Thursday, but there will be no free lunch.

title: Hotel Review: The Paper Factory
description: Double rooms from $149.

title: Update: The Multimillion-Dollar Kidnapping Case in Hong Kong
description: The kidnapping case last month of Queenie Rosita Law, 29, granddaughter of the late textiles tycoon Law Ting-pong, has gripped Hong Kong, a city that, despite its low crime rate, has seen a number of sensational abductions over the years targeting some of its richest families.

title: Restaurant Report: 27 in Miami Beach
description: New restaurants on and around Ocean Drive in Miami Beach  usually housed in the latest branded boutique hotel with big-name absentee chefs, high-priced fusion menus and 80s dcor  are a dime a dozen. Then theres 27, a spot that opened in November just a few steps, but a world away, from that touristy, neon-dotted strip.

title: In Barcelona, a New Draw for Design Fans
description: Not so long ago, travelers might have stopped in the Glries area of Barcelona only if they were stuck in traffic. Three major roads leading in and out of this Spanish city  Avenida Diagonal, Avenida Meridiana and the Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes  converged here at an elevated roundabout, where cars often came to a standstill.

title: Shopping for Antiques, Finding My Mother
description: ST. PETERSBURG, FLA.  My mother sat next to me on her sofa. She held a brass candlestick like a baton. Put stickers on the things youd like to have, she said. With your initials. So when Im gone theres no confusion.

title: The Morning After the Same-Sex Marriage Decision
description: Lets assume, as I do, that the Supreme Court finds a constitutional right to same-sex marriage when it decides Obergefell v. Hodges sometime next month. What happens next?

title: The Underground Art of the Insult
description: On March 6, 2014, Aretha Franklin paid a visit to the White House for a special event celebrating women of soul. Dressed in a brown fur coat, a sequined black dress and a large, glittery pendant, she strode through a dark red door into the East Room, waving regally at a line of well-wishers who stood to applaud her. Among them was another diva, Patti LaBelle, who reached out to grab Franklins hand. With a small, swooping motion, Franklin twisted her body away from LaBelle, evading her greeting, and continued walking. She hardly missed a beat.

title: The Legal Power of Standing
description: CHICAGO  It just goes to show the importance of jurisdiction. Recently, the Supreme Court added a new case to its docket for next year, Spokeo v. Robins, which is about a technical question of jurisdiction  when a plaintiff has standing to sue in federal court. But the courts decision to hear a case on that technical issue may have the surprising effect of causing the court to postpone its ruling in Zivotofsky v. Kerry, a major case about separation of powers and foreign affairs that the court is expected to decide any day now.

title: The President, Fox News and the Poor
description: This week, during a panel discussion on poverty at Georgetown University, President Obama lambasted the media, and in particular Fox News, for creating false, destructive narratives about the poor that paint them broadly as indolent and pathological.

title: The Last Day of Her Life
description: Sandy Bem, a Cornell psychology professor one month shy of her 65th birthday, was alone in her bedroom one night in May 2009, watching an HBO documentary called The Alzheimers Project. For two years, she had been experiencing what she called cognitive oddities: forgetting the names of things or confusing words that sounded similar. She once complained about a blizzard on her foot, when she meant a blister; she brought home a bag of plums and, standing in her kitchen, pulled one out and said to a friend: Is this a plum? I cant quite seem to fully know.

title: The Confederate Diaspora
description: By early May 1865, a month after Gen. Robert E. Lees surrender at Appomattox, most of the remaining Confederate soldiers had laid down their arms. While some Southerners were angry, and others were relieved, nearly all were apprehensive about the future. Many moved west and north; some decided to leave the United States completely.

title: Montserrat Caball, Spanish Soprano, Fails to Appear in Court to Settle Tax Case
description: The opera singer Montserrat Caball failed to appear in a Spanish court this week to settle a tax fraud case, and her lawyer stepped down as her legal representative in the matter.

title: Is It Wrong to Let Children Do Extreme Sports?
When Teaching Comes Cheap for Colleges
Today in Politics: Gulf Leaders to Push Obama for Support
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where fans of the local basketball and hockey teams are busy licking their wounds. Republicans are gathering in Arizona for their partys spring meetings, where the presidential primary debates will be a hot topic, and the International Monetary Fund will soon be in the market for a new top economist. In the meantime, President Obama is hosting some important guests from out of town.

title: I Like Being Afraid
description: For some kids, the playground isnt enough  extreme sports like snowboarding or motocross are the best ways to have fun. But are they safe?

title: Manchester Festival Appoints New Artistic Director
description: John E. McGrath, the artistic director of the National Theater Wales, will become the chief executive and artistic director of the Manchester International Festival, taking over from Alex Poots, who has led the festival since it began in 2007. Mr. Poots gave the biennial Manchester festival its distinctive identity by programming only new work, and he established it as a major international event. He is leaving after this years edition to run a new arts space, Culture Shed, in New York.

title: Brandon Bostian Agrees to Talk About Amtrak Derailment but May Recall Little
description: PHILADELPHIA  As the death toll from this weeks fatal Amtrak derailment rose to eight, federal investigators on Thursday turned their attention to the trains engineer  and said that a new analysis of video showed the train quickly accelerated from 70 to 100 miles per hour in less than a minute before it entered a sharp curve and careened off the tracks.

title: Lori Dickerson Fouch of Prudential on the Limits of Self-Reliance
description: Q. Were you in leadership roles or doing entrepreneurial things when you were younger?

title: Chinese Police Order Residents in a Xinjiang Prefecture to Turn In Passports
description: BEIJING  Residents of an ethnically diverse prefecture in far northwest China that borders several nations have been asked to hand over their passports to the police by Friday or have the documents canceled, according to a notice circulating online and an interview with an officer on Thursday.

title: In Israel, Desalinization at the Heart of a Water Revolution
description: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.

title: Morning Agenda: Tempered Penalties for Guilty Pleas
description: TEMPERED PENALTIES FOR GUILTY PLEAS | For banks, a guilty plea in a felony case is the equivalent of a scarlet letter, one that could lead to a revoked license in the worst-case scenario. But for the five big banks that are expected to plead guilty to conspiring to manipulate foreign currency rates, life will go on, probably without much of a hiccup, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook.

title: Sheldon Adelson Receives a George W. Bush Original Painting
description: Sheldon Adelson is the owner of several casinos, hotels and a large bank account. Hes now also the owner of a genuine George W. Bush.

title: Harry Shearer Is Leaving The Simpsons
description: It is not looking like an okely-dokely day in the town of Springfield: Harry Shearer, an Emmy Award-winning cast member of The Simpsons, who provides the voices of characters like the irritatingly upbeat neighbor Ned Flanders, the billionaire tyrant Mr. Burns and his faithful manservant, Smithers, has indicated that he is parting ways with this long-running Fox animated series.

title: Jeb Bush Taunts Hillary Clinton Over Not Taking Questions
description: RENO, Nev.  Jeb Bush has a pointed message for Hillary Rodham Clinton: Im willing to face tough questions. Youre not.

title: Surrounded by Disturbing Art
description: Read all recent entries and our updated submissions guidelines. Reach us via email diary@nytimes.com or follow @NYTMetro on Twitter using the hashtag #MetDiary.

title: Martin OMalley Courts Democrats Before May 30 Announcement
description: Former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland has recently urged Democrats on the left to end any remaining wishful thinking about Senator Elizabeth Warren and to invest their energy in him.

title: Ireland Makes Arrests and Finds Bombs Before Visit by Prince Charles
description: DUBLIN  Irish Army bomb experts disarmed several potentially lethal devices and the police arrested six men with links to dissident republican groups amid heightened security before next weeks visit by Prince Charles of Britain and his wife, Camilla Parker Bowles, a police spokesman said on Thursday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Mad Max Fury Road
description: George Miller narrates a sequence from his film featuring Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron and Nicholas Hoult.

title: Cloudy Skies, Illustrated
description: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

title: Joseph J. Ellis: By the Book
description: The historian and author, most recently, of The Quartet keeps Plato, Kant, Hume, Locke and Nietzsche on his shelves. Just looking over at them reminds me that once upon a time I was a very serious young man.

title: Teaching Children to Love Bees, Not Fear Them
description: Several years ago, reports of the declining bee population inspired my partner to keep bees in our yard. Her reasons were mainly practicalnot only did she want to support the vanishing bees, she hoped our plum trees might increase their yield. But it took less than one season for my partner to fall in love, and over time the number of hives in our backyard has multiplied from two to 10. At my house this week we know that spring has arrived because my 2-year-old points out the window and yells excitedly: Bees!

title: Mad Max: Fury Road (With Movie Trailer): George Miller Narrates a Scene
description: Its been a long road to Mad Max: Fury Road, George Millers continuation of his postapocalyptic series that began in 1979 with the film Mad Max, starring Mel Gibson. Tom Hardy now has the role, but the sparse dialogue and complicated, outrageous action remain. Its a return to live-action terrain after Mr. Miller directed two animated films, Happy Feet and Happy Feet Two. In this video, Mr. Miller discusses the meeting of Max and Furiosa (Charlize Theron). In interviews at the South by Southwest film festival in Austin and in New York, Mr. Miller talked about updating the franchise.

title: Review: Mad Max: Fury Road, Still Angry After All These Years
description: Desolate, post-apocalyptic landscapes, zombie-ridden or not, are perennial popular tourist destinations for 21st-century moviegoers and couch potatoes. Mad Max: Fury Road is like a visit to a World Heritage site. Some of us  old enough to remember when nuclear Armageddon had not yet given way to climate change as the main source of existential anxiety  harbor a special fondness for the young Mel Gibson as Max Rockatansky, the grieving, aggrieved former cop who motored across the Australian desert in Mad Max, The Road Warrior and Beyond Thunderdome.

title: With Gas Prices Less of a Worry, Buyers Pass Hybrid Cars By
description: Affordable gasoline is making hybrid car owners rethink their loyalty.

title: Myanmar Migrants Spotted in Andaman Sea
description: A wooden fishing boat carrying several hundred migrants from Myanmar was seen adrift west of the Thai mainland on Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Technology Behind Advertising Is at the Heart of Verizons Deal for AOL
description: A new generation of Math Men is taking over the Mad Men of Madison Avenue, Emily Steel and Sydney Ember report.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton Ups the Super PAC Ante
description: For all the candidates grand promises, it turns out the most creative area of the presidential contest so far has been the strategic rush to shift costly campaign duties from budget-tight headquarters to an armada of new super PACs. These groups are free to raise unlimited funds from big-check writers shopping for influence while supposedly operating independent of their candidates. It sounds like a neat trick, and legions of campaign lawyers are working on pulling it off.

title: In Flight
description: En route from London to Tokyo, a pilots-eye view of life in the sky.

title: Honda Recalls Nearly 5 Million Vehicles With Takata Airbags
description: TOKYO  Honda on Thursday recalled 4.9 million vehicles equipped with airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata, a day after Toyota and Nissan announced similarly vast recalls.

title: Stephen Currys Odd Line Shows a Shift in Warriors and N.B.A.s Game
description: Stephen Curry is the N.B.A.s most valuable player, but there was one thing he could not do Wednesday night: make a 2-point shot.

title: Letters: 18 West 11th Street
description: 18 West 11th Street

title: Bodies Recovered in Manila Factory Fire
description: The Philippine interior secretary and the Valenzuela city fire marshal discussed the recovery efforts on Thursday for victims of a factory fire in Manila.

title: Greece Rules Out Suing British Museum Over Elgin Marbles
description: Stepping back from a fight with Britain over ownership of the so-called Elgin marbles, the Greek culture minister has declared that Athens will not pursue legal action to settle the bitter, decades-old dispute, despite the advice of international lawyers.

title: Patriots Rebuttal Is Foray Further Into Farce
description: So it has come to this. After four months of speculation and outrage, as well as an investigation costing millions of dollars and diverting attention from what would seem to be more serious matters, the focus of the N.F.L.s air-pressure scandal has seemingly narrowed to one man  a crass, overweight jokester with a full bladder.

title: Nissan Recalls Millions of Cars
description: Carlos Ghosn, the chairman and chief executive of Nissan Motor, said the decision to recall 1.56 million cars was part of the solution to tackle the trouble over Takatas defective air bags.

title: Schumer to Recommend Brooklyn Prosecutor for U.S. Attorney Post
description: Robert L. Capers, a longtime federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, has won the critical support of Senator Chuck Schumer to be the next United States attorney for the Eastern District, which covers Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: Plus-Size Market Gets a Pitch Perfect Voice
description: The plus-size market, a segment thats been long overlooked by designers but increasingly insists on getting its due, is getting another boost: a celebrity collaboration.

title: Hillary Clinton Enlists Bigger-Name Backers in Novel Ways
description: In previous presidential election cycles, campaigns have sent out press releases that screamed the news of endorsements received. In 2008, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was the considered the early front-runner, endorsements were a gauge of support used by reporters and others.

title: Matthew Weiner, the Creator of Mad Men, Prepares for Another Fade to Black
description: It took almost 55 years, but the 1960s are finally over. They ended without our even realizing it, somewhere in the middle of this bifurcated final season of Mad Men, after Don Draper and his fellow employees at Sterling Cooper & Partners watched the moon landing and mourned the death of the agencys gentle co-founder Bert Cooper. When the AMC drama returned a year later, in April, for its final seven episodes, suddenly it was the spring of 1970, and the decade that had defined this show was gone.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something to do this weekend?

title: Why Facebooks News Experiment Matters to Readers
description: Facebooks new plan to host news publications stories directly is not only about page views, advertising revenue or the number of seconds it takes for an article to load. It is about who owns the relationship with readers.

title: Russ Feingold Will Run for Senate in Wisconsin
description: Russ Feingold, the liberal Democrat and former three-term senator, announced on Thursday that he will run for his old seat in the United States Senate from Wisconsin.

title: Its a Process, Rangers Say, and Sometimes It Takes Seven Games
description: The Rangers take their cues from Alain Vigneault, their stoic coach, who preached sticking to the process all season.

title: The Art of Medicine
description: In 1986, Oliver Sacks was one of 10 doctors who wrote about their lives as both physicians and writers in the Book Review. Sacks contrasted himself with a doctor novelist, saying: I have no literary aspirations whatever, only the desire to report clinical reality in all its richness.

title: Pew and the Three American Worldviews
description: Having offered some cautions about over-interpreting the findings of the latest Pew religion survey, let me throw that caution to the wind and offer a quick interpretation myself. A few times in the past this old column, this recent post Iveplayed with the idea that we have three major worldviews sharing space in American culture, which you might label biblical, spiritual and secularrespectively. (The spiritual category overlaps substantially with the nation of heretics described in my last book.) Heres how I tried to sketch this division  in the context of the Christmas story, hence the references two years back:

title: Narendra Modi Starts Trip to China With a Burst of Sightseeing
description: HONG KONG  Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India pressed President Xi Jinping of China on border disputes and a yawning trade deficit on Thursday, after Mr. Modi started a trip to China with a burst of sightseeing intended to highlight the ancient ties between the two neighbors.

title: A Range of Reactions to Airlines Removal of Autistic Child
description: A United Airlines pilots decision to divert a flight to remove a family with an autistic daughter has set off a firestorm online, with some calling for a boycott of the carrier.

title: Portraits of the Victims: Amtrak Train Derailment
description: At least seven people were killed Tuesday, when Amtraks Northeast Regional Train No. 188 derailed in Philadelphia shortly before 9:30 p.m. About a dozen people are still missing. Here are some of the victims who have been identified.

title: Euro, Clawing Its Way Back, Hits 3-Month High
description: PARIS  As recently as March, the dollar was looking so strong against the euro that the only question seemed to be how soon the eurozone currency would sink to parity.

title: George Stephanopoulos Acknowledges Giving Money to Clinton Foundation
description: ABC Newss chief anchor, George Stephanopoulos, acknowledged Thursday that he had made donations to the Clinton Foundation in recent years without disclosing those contributions to his employer  even as he reported on the Clintons and their foundation.

title: Still Hungry, the First-Place Royals Are Looking to Return to the World Series
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  A week or so after it ended, after a pop-up landed in the paws of a Panda, Lorenzo Cain came out of hibernation. He wanted to see the postseason again, to relive the joy ride of the Kansas City Royals. In a way, he still is.

title: Witness and Police on Kabul Hotel Attack
description: Kabuls police chief, Gen. Abdul Rahman Rahimi, said investigative teams were looking into a deadly attack at a guesthouse that took place Wednesday night.

title: Small Packages, Big Fun
description: New picture books include I Am the Wolf ... and Here I Come! and Circles.

title: 1915: U.S. Warns Germany of Action
description: NEW YORK  President Wilsons Note to Germany arraigns the Empire for repeated violation of American rights. It is the final paragraph of the Note that conveys the intimation of ACTION, if Germany does not cease its murderous piracy campaign, that may have the effect on convincing Berlin that the United States will not tamely submit to further outrage. Everyone realizes that with the presentation of President Wilsons note to Germany last night [May 13], one of the most critical stages in American history has been reached.  The New York Herald, European Edition, May 15, 1915

title: How to Rebuild After an Earthquake Like Nepal's
description: Experts offer tips on how a country like Nepal can rebuild after an earthquake with whatever materials are available.

title: Obama Pledges More Military Aid to Reassure Persian Gulf Allies on Iran Deal
description: CAMP DAVID, Md.  President Obama on Thursday offered Saudi Arabia and smaller Arab states new support to defend against potential missile strikes, maritime threats and cyberattacks from Iran, calling his commitment to their security ironclad in an effort to allay fears that a nuclear accord will empower Tehran, their main rival in the Middle East.

title: Rand Paul: George Stephanopoulos Shouldnt Moderate 2016 Debates
description: A Republican backlash against George Stephanopoulos, the public face of ABC News and the networks top political anchor, was beginning to build on Thursday after the disclosure that he had made large contributions to the Clinton Foundation in recent years.

title: Fruit Flies Are Shown to Enter a Fearlike State
description: Whether fruit flies feel anything resembling emotion is hard to determine, but new research suggests they can experience a fearlike state.

title: Kottu House
description: Sri Lankan street food finds a wider audience on the Lower East Side.

title: Kottu House Captures the (Good) Spirit of Sri Lanka
description: A devils face with goggle eyes and swollen tongue stares from the window of Kottu House. Its only a vinyl decal, meant to evoke the wooden masks  often flanked by cobras, peacocks or flames  that guard the entrances of Sinhalese homes in Sri Lanka, warding off evil.

title: The N.H.L.s Conference Finals Are a Story of Mirror Images and Even Matches
description: The conference finals have been a habit recently for the Rangers and the Chicago Blackhawks, with each reaching the third round three times in the past four seasons. But of the final four teams, the Rangers have gone the longest without winning the Stanley Cup. When the Rangers won in 1994, the Tampa Bay Lightning were two years old and the Anaheim Ducks were one, but each has won a championship since.

title: Sheldon Adelson Comes to New York, and Presidential Candidates Follow
description: The so-called Sheldon Adelson primary  in which Republican presidential hopefuls have been auditioning for the approval of one of the richest men to play in politics  is coming to New York City in two weeks.

title: A Crisis in the Heart of Egg Country
description: More than three-quarters of the birds that have died or must be killed nationwide as a result of bird flu are in Iowa, where one in every five eggs consumed in the country is laid.

title: My Brothers Peacekeeper
description: My brothers wife left him and their two young sons to redefine herself. She wrote my family members an email saying she would still like to be included in our gatherings and maintain strong relationships with all of us. My brother is a good guy, and we are distraught by her abandonment of him and their children. I have not replied to her email yet. Should I keep quiet or call her out for deserting her family, then expecting my friendship?

title: Swearing Off the Modern Man
description: The Modern Man has an iPhone 6 Plus and goes to Coachella every year. Hes thinking about starting a blog and has been like really into standup lately. He has a favorite microbrewery because he likes his beer really hoppy, whatever that means. He has a fun Twitter feed and interesting theories about what could happen on House of Cards.

title: 1937-1961 | Regrettable Spellings? Weve Had a Few
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Egg Farms Hit Hard as Bird Flu Affects Millions of Hens
description: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa  J.T. Dean is facing a gargantuan task.

title: Safely Costuming Permission, a High-Impact Comedy From Robert Askins
description: A couple of months ago, Paloma Young went online and ordered a wide assortment of shaper panties, booty-padded panties, butt lifters and butt enhancers. Ms. Young, an award-winning costume designer, had just signed on to Permission, a dark comedy by Robert Askins, whose Hand to God is up for the Tony Award for best play. It posed a design challenge like none she had ever experienced.

title: Reddit Introduces Anti-Harassment Policy
description: Reddit, the popular online message forum, has long been a free-for-all for the collective id of the Internet. A few sacred commandments kept users in check: Thou shalt not spam, thou shalt not post personally identifiable information and thou shalt not break the site.

title: Greek Finance Minister Lashes Out at E.C.B. Chief
description: FRANKFURT  Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, on Thursday once again demonstrated his flair for inflaming the debate about his countrys economic future.

title: Preakness 2015: Predictions and Analysis
description: The horses for Saturdays 140th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses. The morning-line odds were set by Keith Feustle of Pimlico Race Course.

title: Viewfinder: Leonard Greco
description: Leonard Greco began assembling and capturing everyday objects to combat his dissatisfaction with his mundane commercial work.

title: Marco Rubios Answers on Iraq a Departure From the Past
description: The question du jour for Republican presidential candidates, it seems, is if they would have authorized the 2003 invasion of Iraq knowing what the nation now knows  that the country did not possess weapons on mass destruction.

title: A French Film Ingenue Shares Her Provencal Pleasures
description: Rosalie Varda-Demy, the 56-year-old daughter of the French film impresario Agns Varda and the late director-screenwriter Jacques Demy, once designed costumes for films and theater but now organizes events for the Cannes Film Festival and manages her parents catalog. From her mothers The Creatures with Catherine Deneuve, to her fathers Lola, featuring music by the acclaimed composer Michel Legrand, theres much to preserve. Eight years ago, I began to think that I wanted to share some time with my mother, whos an incredible woman, says Rosalie, herself a mother of three grown boys, about the 86-year-old force in her life whos still showing work around the world. This October, Agns will debut a new exhibition  photos of Cuba from 1962  at the Centre Pompidou in October. Shes done incredible things in her life as a film director and photographer. So I thought Ill quit my business to share hers with a new generation. She gave me a lot, and Im giving her a lot now.

title: Eight Exhibition-Inspired Courses
description: For its spring benefit, the Museum of Food and Drink asked chefs to prepare dishes inspired by future shows.

title: Quiz: Which of These Simpsons Characters Did Harry Shearer Voice?
description: Which of the characters below did Harry Shearer portray? Do well, and we wont release the hounds.

title: Senate, in Reversal, Begins Debate on Trade Authority
description: WASHINGTON  Two days after Democratic senators blocked it, the Senate voted on Thursday to take up legislation that would grant the president negotiating freedom to complete an expansive trade accord with 11 nations on the Pacific Rim, setting off a contentious congressional debate on one of President Obamas top priorities for his remaining time in office.

title: Cuomos Job Creation Program Is Slow to Take Hold
description: ALBANY  In May 2013, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a program he promised would supercharge the states economy and take job creation efforts to a level never seen before. He poured tens of millions of dollars into advertising to push the program, Start-Up New York.

title: The Science Behind the Dress
description: Nearly three months after the infamous blue and black dress (or was it white and gold?) tore the Internet apart, three teams of scientists have provided a closer look at the science behind the viral phenomenon. In their papers, published Thursday in the journal Current Biology, the teams have proposed reasons that different people saw different colors, and what the whole thing means for our understanding of visual perception.

title: Throwback Thursday | The Times Reports on Prom, 1955-2015
description: Its prom season, and that means articles about dress decisions, increasingly elaborate promposals, and, of course, the seemingly-annual prom controversy (promtroversy?).

title: Gunfire Heard in Burundi
description: Residents fled from gunfire in Burundis capital, Bujumbura, the day after an army general said a coup had overthrown President Pierre Nkurunziza. It was not clear who was in charge of the country.

title: Taliban Attack Kills 14, Including American, at Kabul Hotel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 14 people were killed in a Taliban attack at a popular Kabul hotel late Wednesday night, when a gunman went room to room killing guests, according to witnesses and Afghan and foreign officials.

title: Yoko Ono: One Woman Show
description: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Piet Hein Eek Brings His Singular Furniture  and a Couple of Friends  to NoHo
description: The Dutch designer collaborated with the gallery The Future Perfect on a takeover of the storefront, featuring his own work and that of his compatriots.

title: A Good Time for Visa to Take Europe
description: Its a good time for Visa to charge up overseas. Buying its former subsidiary Visa Europe may cost the American payments company as much as $20 billion. There are plenty of reasons to act now.

title: Review: In Yoko Ono: One Woman Show, 1960-1971, Text Messages From the Edge
description: On the principle that imagining something can make it real, Yoko Ono gave herself a solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1971. What was the likelihood of the museums coming up with the idea on its own? Practically zero. Historically, women were rarely shown there; nonwhite women, never. And, most of Ms. Onos work was on a far-out fringe of art-world orthodoxy where, to her cost and our good fortune, she chose, in her early years at least, to stay.

title: Jeb Bush Says, I Would Not Have Gone Into Iraq
description: TEMPE, Ariz  After days of sidestepping, Jeb Bush on Thursday offered a definitive answer to the question of whether he would have authorized the invasion of Iraq in 2003 had he known about the intelligence failures at the time.

title: An Abortion Bans Bogus Arguments
description: For the second time in two years, the House  voted Wednesday to pass legislation that would ban almost all abortions 20 weeks or more after fertilization. The bill, called the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, claims that an unborn child is capable of experiencing pain at least by 20 weeks after fertilization, though medical evidence does not support this.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
Watch an Artist Create a Perfect Little Cloud Indoors
description: Berndnaut Smildes Frieze Week forecast is cloudy with no chance of anything but art-making. The cheery young Dutchman, who sees himself as a sculptor, mainly, has stirred lots of attention for his Nimbus series of atmospheric creations, in which he plays weatherman and creates clouds indoors. For centuries, humans have tried to control the atmosphere, and Smilde, who is not particularly scientific  I have a Lego background, he says, has managed to hack nature. Moisture is the main factor, and if its cold, that really helps, he explains. Other than that, Im using all kinds of means to create an image and idea. Mostly, that entails fog machines and squirt bottles filled with water  and shutting down the fire alarms, he laughs, otherwise everybody will get very wet!

title: 1965: Cannes Shows Social Realism
description: CANNES  Two films today [May 14] gave the Cannes Film Festival its first taste of the social realism now favored by serious film-makers in most of the underdeveloped countries. Neither film was given much chance of earning a prize, but each in its way had considerable power. In the case of the Egyptian film El Haram (The Sin), it was a virtuoso performance by Fatem Hamama as a farm worker falsely accused of murdering an unwanted child. The Bulgarian entry, Gorechto Plande (Torrid Summer), gave a touching account of a communitys efforts to rescue a boy whose hand has got stuck in a hole in a bridge.  New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 15, 1965

title: Review: In The Film Critic, a Snob Is Tripped Up by His Heartstrings
description: Reviewing a pretentious little movie can be like shooting fish in a barrel. Sometimes all you can do is start with a clich. But sometimes the target in the water looks familiar, as if you were staring at your own glassy-eyed reflection. That is more or less the case with The Film Critic, a movie from the Argentine director Hernn Guerschuny whose protagonist is a grumpy middle-aged guy in less than perfect physical condition who writes dyspeptic notices for a big-city newspaper and hates just about everything that isnt Godard.

title: Ivy Ziedrich, College Student, Warms to Role as Jeb Bush Critic on ISIS
description: RENO, Nev.  On Wednesday afternoon, just as she sat down to watch TV and eat a corn dog, Ivy Ziedrichs phone rang. It was her sister in Montana.

title: For Amtrak Engineer Brandon Bostian, Childhood Passion Became a Career
description: PHILADELPHIA  Growing up in Memphis, Brandon Bostian, the engineer in the fatal Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia this week, loved railroads so much that he made a pilgrimage each Friday during high school to watch the late-night City of New Orleans rumble through town.

title: With Ill See You in My Dreams and Grandma, Hollywood Pays Attention to Older Viewers
description: A survey of recent and coming films will reveal, as usual, a surfeit of sex, drugs and rock n roll. Whats not so usual is the number of people over 70 engaging in sex, drugs and rock n roll.

title: No Comment Necessary: Republicans Cant Name a Favorite Living President
description: Asked to pick a favorite living president, many of the likely Republican presidential candidates at the South Carolina Freedom Summit brought up Ronald Reagan, despite the fact that he has been dead for nearly 11 years.

title: In a First, a Fish Is Shown to Be Fully Warm-Blooded
description: The moonfish, or opah, is the first fish shown to be fully warm-blooded, researchers report in the journal Science. Although some large predatory fish, like tuna, can temporarily warm their muscles or organs, the opah is the only fish that warms its heart. A silvery fish the size of an automobile tire, the opah is found in oceans around the world. To warm its organs, the fish harnesses the heat generated by rapidly flapping its pectoral fins. The heat gives the moonfish a competitive advantage in the chilly waters that it lives in, several hundred feet below the oceans surface.

title: Review Board Notes Rise in New York Police Officers False Statements
description: An officer drew his weapon on a bystander holding a cellphone but denied using a racial obscenity. In another case, an officer told investigators that he had not shoved a man in handcuffs, but that the man tripped.

title: George Stephanopouloss Gifts to Clinton Foundation Reinforce G.O.P. Doubts
description: WASHINGTON  Even after more than a decade as an analyst, anchor and public face for ABC News, George Stephanopoulos has never been able to shake the image that many Republicans have of him: Clinton hatchet man.

title: John Bolton Decides Against Entering Presidential Fray
description: John R. Boltons run for president has ended before it had a chance to get started.

title: A Phantom Offer Sends Avons Shares Surging
description: The federal governments system for filing securities documents may not be as secure as many on Wall Street assume, considering what appears to have been a fake bid on Thursday for Avon Products.

title: Sienna Millers Perfectly Fitted Hourglass Figure
description: The Star: Sienna Miller

title: Matching Colors Between Display and Document
Questions for Jeb Bush: Iraq Is Just the Beginning
description: Jeb Bush has been tied in rhetorical knots this week trying to answer whether he would have ordered the invasion of Iraq, as his brother George W. did as president in 2003. On Thursday, Mr. Bush ultimately said that knowing what we know now, he would not have invaded.

title: The Rise of Middle Class as an Ordinary American Term
description: Middle class, a term as much aspirational as descriptive, may end up as a linguistic flash in the pan.

title: Naval Academy Honors Amtrak Victim
description: The United States Naval Academys superintendent said Thursday that Justin Zemser, the midshipman who died in an Amtrak train derailment, was a talented and highly respected young man.

title: Court Blocks Spanish Soccer Players Plans to Strike Over TV Money
description: A planned players strike in Spanish soccer was suspended Thursday by the countrys national court, allowing matches to proceed on schedule this weekend and positioning Barcelona to clinch La Ligas title Sunday with a victory at Atltico Madrid.

title: Ros Wine to Drink This Summer
description: The world loves ros in summer. And why not? Its pretty, refreshing and carefree in the best possible way. Yet the publics easy embrace of ros often means an uncritical acceptance of anything in pink.

title: A Look Inside the Kips Bay Show House
description: The annual designer showcase opens at the Arthur Sachs Mansion, with proceeds benefiting the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club, which turned 100 this year.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Confirms Crash Toll
description: Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia said Thursday that the remains of an eighth victim of the Amtrak derailment had been found and that all passengers had been accounted for.

title: Heaven Knows What Captures the Hooked and Homeless
description: As Josh and Benny Safdie, the makers of Heaven Knows What, strolled through Central Park on a recent spring day, they related the names and routines of park regulars; they rattled off rules that street kids live by. (Dont stay after 1 a.m.) In Strawberry Fields, Josh indicated the spot where Ilya Leontyev, the inspiration for one of the films leads, was found dead last month, at 25.

title: Scrutinizing an Employees Suspicious Sick Day
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: The Freedom of I Do, Take Two
description: Andrea Seabrook describes her first wedding, a large affair in 2001 in a historic Episcopal church, as tasteful, beautiful and respectable.

title: Body Found in Hudson River Is Not Missing Kayaker, Police Say
description: The police in the Town of Poughkeepsie said on Thursday that a body recovered from the Hudson River this week was not that of Vincent Viafore, the 46-year-old man who prosecutors say was killed by his fiance as the couple kayaked last month.

title: Text to Text | Making Meaning From the Art in Our Lives
description: As the school year winds down, weve created a final Text to Text with questions that we hope follow you into the museums and galleries you visit on vacation this summer.

title: The Arcane Charms of Mangle Boards
The Museum of Food and Drinks Forward-Looking Menu
description: Last night at Carnegie Hall, a symphony of plates designed by culinary heavyweights filled the bellies and emptied the pockets  ofsupporters of the Museum of Food and Drink (MOFAD). In its effort to raise $25 million towards a brick-and-mortar exhibition space in New York, where visitors will be able to eat their way through each exhibition, the organization held its second annual spring benefit (hosted by Questlove and sponsored by T Magazine). The below slideshow of the artful dinner doubles as a road map of whats to come from from MOFAD: Each of the eight courses was inspired by a forthcoming exhibition.

title: How To | Make a Thai Chili Cocktail
description: Nico de Soto demonstrates how to make a frothy, egg-based drink off his menu for Mace, a new East Village bar that celebrates spices.

title: Review: Alex Katz at Gavin Browns Enterprise
description: Among the more moving art experiences is seeing a painter excel late in life. Alex Katz, 87, is well known for landscapes and portraits that combine direct perception; wet-on-wet speed-painting and scale; and a distinct merging of Pop Art, abstraction and the plein-air tradition. But now he is having one of the best gallery exhibitions of his career, a display of landscape paintings  lately his surest work  that while seeming to modulate his familiar style have a new, more emotional resonance.

title: Review: Rosy Keyser, The Hell Bitch
description: ROSY KEYSER

title: Review: Arthur Ou at Brennan & Griffin
description: In the preface to his Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, from 1921, the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein writes, Perhaps this book will be understood only by someone who has himself already had the thoughts that are expressed in it  or at least similar thoughts. The same might be said of Arthur Ous current exhibition, which features 14 black-and-white images of contemporary photographers reading passages from the Tractatus.

title: Secret Service Arrests Man After Drone Flies Near White House
description: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service arrested a man who was flying a small drone less than a block from the White House on Thursday afternoon, law enforcement officials said.

title: Review: Andrew Lord, at sunset, with snow falling, by starlight
description: At once bracingly ugly and sensuously beautiful, the recent ceramic sculptures by the British artist Andrew Lord look as if theyd been made by a clumsy but aesthetically sensitive giant. Displayed on three white tables are pitchers in the form of human heads with handles, variously shaped vases and constructions resembling maquettes for fountains populated by little nude female figures. Each retains the marks of its vigorous manual formation in the gouging, impressing and squeezing of the clay. They are glazed in Abstract Expressionist style with the colors brushed, poured and drizzled, creating lively marriages of sculptural form and painterly surface.

title: NATO Officials Sing We Are the World at Summit in Turkey
description: In a scene captured on video by a Turkish news agency, a group of NATO foreign ministers and European officials performed a rousing, after-dinner version of We Are the World, the 1985 charity single, after a summit meeting in the resort town of Antalya on Wednesday.

title: Aaron Douglas Paintings Go to the Met and the National Gallery
description: For many American museums, the Harlem Renaissance painter Aaron Douglas (1898-1979) is an almost Vermeer-like figure, whose shadowy, graphically powerful depictions of African-American themes appear so rarely on the market that when canvases surface, curators pounce. And that is exactly what the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington did recently. Each institution has acquired one of his major paintings, which were sold by a private collector who had purchased them from Douglas himself the year before his death.

title: The Tyranny of Constant Contact
description: Everything I know about the Internet, I learned from my 87-year-old mother.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand, Burundi and Elsewhere
description: Thailand, Iraq and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Rdio Introduces a Cheaper Limited Subscription for Music Streaming
description: In the latest volley in the music worlds digital price war, Rdio, which competes with both Spotify and Pandora, has introduced a limited subscription version at $4 a month  significantly lower than the industrys $10 default price.

title: ISIS Releases a Recording It Says Was Made by Its Leader
description: Amid reports that its reclusive leader had been injured and possibly incapacitated, the Islamic State terrorist group released an audio statement on Thursday that it said was from the man himself, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

title: May 14, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Follow Lens on Facebook and Twitter.

title: John Flanagan Trips Over a Climate Issue
description: A day after John Flanagan moved into his powerful new job as leader of New York State Senate, he quickly made news. It was not about his predecessor, State Senator Dean Skelos, the latest Albany politician to be arrested for corruption. Nor was it about taxes or education or his relations with the mayor and governor.

title: Hillary Clinton Makes First Visit to Brooklyn Since Announcing Campaign
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday made her first trip to Brooklyn since she joined the presidential race a month ago, visiting her headquarters and taking an unannounced stroll in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Cannes
description: The best looks from Cannes.

title: The Garden Is Rocking. Imagine That, Knicks Fans.
description: A dejected Ted Leonsis walked into the freight elevator at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, minutes after his Washington Capitals had been eliminated from the N.H.L. playoffs on an overtime goal by the Rangers.

title: Beer Week in Paris
description: In celebration of the growing craft beer movement in Paris, the city will play host to the second annual Beer Week from May 22 through May 31.

title: Amtrak Says Shortfalls and Rules Delayed Its Safety System
description: WASHINGTON  The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was equipped with an automatic speed control system that officials say could have prevented the wreck, which killed eight passengers and injured hundreds. But the system, which was tantalizingly close to being operational, was delayed by budgetary shortfalls, technical hurdles and bureaucratic rules, officials said Thursday.

title: Tiny Macedonia Confronts a Supersize Scandal
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  An almost surreal scandal involving hundreds of thousands of secretly recorded conversations caught top government officials discussing everything from rigging votes to covering up killings.

title: Roy Anderssons Movies at the Museum of Arts and Design
description: Youd probably recognize the work of Roy Andersson even if you havent seen his films. His 1970s ads for a Swedish insurance company are quaint classics. In a typical example, a man gets on a pay phone to buy a car policy, while in the background a falling tree destroys the vehicle in question. The mishaps are good for a chuckle, but from these humble origins, Mr. Andersson has gone on to make some of the most elaborate comedic features since the heydays of Jacques Tati and Jerry Lewis.

title: Editors Note
description: Two articles in this series last year, by the author Karen Abbott, copied specific language and passages from several books and papers. In most of these instances, the writer cited the sources in the articles endnotes. However, copying language from other sources without proper attribution is a violation of Times policy.

title: Afghans Look Back at Karzai Presidency With Surprising Fondness
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Just seven months after Hamid Karzai stepped down from the Afghan presidency, leaving a tattered relationship with the Americans, a battered economy and worsening security, Afghanistan already seems to be awash with nostalgia for the former president.

title: Travelers Struggle to Change Plans After Amtrak Derailment
description: A major stretch of rail line remained shut Thursday after Tuesday nights deadly Amtrak derailment, forcing thousands of commuters to adjust travel plans and generally muddle through an abrupt suspension of train service. The derailment in Philadelphia killed eight people and injured more than 200.

title: Is Your Child Your Excuse to Buy an Apple Watch?
description: The Apple Watch does exactly what I wanted it to do  but its not the killer app for parents. Yet.

title: Review: Zanele Muholi, a Visual Activist, Presents Isibonelo/Evidence
description: Zanele Muholi: Isibonelo/Evidence, an exhibition of 87 works at the Brooklyn Museum by a South African artist, ends with a celebration. But it begins on a much darker note.

title: Going Back to the Future for Tomorrowland, From Disney
description: Nothing screams bright, shiny future quite like a jetpack. In the film Tomorrowland, when Casey Newton (Britt Robertson) enters the gleaming utopia of the films title, its one of the first things she sees. If you exit a time machine and spot a jetpack, you know you havent landed in some postapocalyptic dump.
