No, youve probably arrived in a hope-filled future like the ones promised us in the 1950s, when space colonies were just around the corner and the atom was our friend.

title: Johnny Depps Dogs Face Deportation or Death in Australia
description: Capt. Jack Sparrow has outsmarted Hector Barbossa, Davy Jones, Blackbeard and Lord Cutler Beckett. But he may have met his match with Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce of Australia.

title: Odd, Old Days in Times Square
description: Andrew Savulichs photos of 1980s New York are quirky and off-kilter, like the city itself was before became a sanitized tourist mecca.

title: Review: Cats Paying Dues Tap and Sing, Dont Meow
description: The founder and director of an organization called Cats Paying Dues, Andrew Nemr says he encounters a lot of confusion about that name. No, his group isnt some feline labor union or animal act. Its a troupe of young tap dancers  cats is old jazz slang for hip musicians  and the dues are a kind of apprenticeship. Mr. Nemr wants to pass on some of the knowledge and opportunities he received from mentors like Jimmy Slyde, Gregory Hines and Savion Glover. Cats Paying Dues is a company of hoofers in that jazz tradition.

title: Review: St. Thomas Choir and Concert Royal Perform Handel
description: If mere mischief can stir boys souls and imaginations, what effect might something on the scale of biblical plagues have? You didnt have to wonder on Wednesday evening, when the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and the period band Concert Royal gave a rousing performance of Handels great oratorio Israel in Egypt at St. Thomas Church in Manhattan.

title: Model Ink
description: Tattoos on and off the runway

title: Review: Faith No More, Reunited and Reclaiming Its Spot
description: Single-minded sincerity isnt for everyone. Faith No More, which is about to release Sol Invictus (Ipecac), its first new studio album since 1997, has always trafficked in more contradictory impulses, and they were all on display when the reunited band played the first of two sold-out shows at Webster Hall on Wednesday night. The band members (and most of their equipment) were dressed in white and surrounded by bouquets of flowers, while the music was decidedly less angelic.

title: Two Takes on Imitation of Life: Exploitation in Eastmancolor
description: I would have made the picture just for the title, Douglas Sirk said of his last Hollywood production, Imitation of Life (1959). But, newly released on Blu-ray by Universal, along with its original version, directed in 1934 by John M. Stahl, the movie is far more than an evocative turn of phrase.

title: U.S. Introduces New DNA Standard for Ensuring Accuracy of Genetic Tests
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government opened the door to a new era of genetic medicine on Thursday by introducing a standard way to ensure the accuracy of DNA tests used to tailor treatments for individual patients.

title: Mark Hogancamp, the Artist as (Imagined) War Hero
description: In Mark Hogancamps other life, he is a World War II fighter pilot and the owner of a clubby bar in Belgium, where all manner of international adventurers and baddies congregate. He has an adoring and courageous wife, Anna, and the flirtations of a minx in fishnets, Deja. With the chiseled visage of a Hollywood star, Captain Mark is epically cool.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 15-21
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Grateful Dead Fans Replace VW Vans With Jets and the Ritz-Carlton
description: Twenty-seven years ago, Adam Cott and a bunch of his buddies climbed into his 1974 white Opel station wagon, which he had bought from a friend of his fathers for $100, and drove from New Rochelle to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to take in a Grateful Dead show.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for May 15-21
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Pitch Perfect 2, With Anna Kendrick and More Fat Amy
description: At one point in Pitch Perfect 2, for no especially compelling narrative reason, the Barden Bellas, an all-girl a cappella group at a fictional Georgia college, find their way to an underground sing-off hosted by a pajama-clad harmony geek played by David Cross. The other contestants include the Treblemakers, the Bellas male counterparts; a highly disciplined German vocal ensemble and some Green Bay Packers. Its a single-elimination contest with strict rules, and the first category is Songs About Butts.

title: Theater Listings for May 15-21
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Rick Santorum Says Hes Baffled by Jeb Bush on Iraq
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz  Rick Santorum, the former senator from Pennsylvania who delivered a surprisingly strong performance in the 2012 presidential campaign and may run again in 2016, said Thursday he was baffled by Jeb Bushs handling this week of a question about the 2003 war in Iraq.

title: Cubs Rally to Complete 4-Game Sweep of Mets
description: Three weeks ago, Matt Harvey shut down the Yankees on a Saturday afternoon in the Bronx in a game that left the Mets with a 14-4 record and a growing sense that they were becoming the dominant force in New York baseball.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 15-21
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: In Heartbreak, Talk Is Complicated
description: In Ariel Stesss Heartbreak at the Bushwick Starr, a father offers his lovelorn daughter relationship advice. Have a team-pardner-person, he says. (Odd pronunciations and spellings are a stylistic hallmark of the playwrights.) Support-pardner-person. Listen-pardner-person. Laugh-pardner-person. Adjust-pardner-person. Person-person stuff, pardner-person stuff. Pardner stuff. Be with one yeah.

title: Review: John Patitucci Takes His Electric Bass to the Iridium
description: Deep undertow and dazzling technique share a home in the bass playing of John Patitucci, whose prominence as a sideman goes back 30 years. But they arent always peaceable cohabitants, or the easiest to bend toward a common cause. Mr. Patitucci proved that point in an otherwise rousing first set at the Iridium on Wednesday night.

title: Fashion Bonanza for British Designer Patrick Grant
description: Of all the major fashion week cities for mens wear  New York, London, Milan and Paris  London may have a claim to be the most flexible.

title: Frieze Art Fair at Randalls Island Park Offers a Bit of Everything
description: With 198 commercial dealers and three nonprofit galleries displaying all kinds of modern and contemporary art under its white, quarter-mile-long tent, the fourth annual New York edition of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island is a lot for even two critics to cover, but we gave it our best effort. This year offered more opportunities for visitors to participate in specific artworks, and circled back to the careers of overlooked women artists from earlier periods. Here are some things that caught our eyes.

title: Review: In Animals, a Couple in Love With Heroin
description: Every so often, an image in Animals will underline the implication of the title: that Jude and Bobbie, the drug addicts whose lives occupy the films attention, lead a primal, almost bestial existence. Looking at predatory cats or beluga whales (on television and at the zoos and aquariums of Chicago, where Animals was shot), you are invited to notice parallels to the couples behavior: their moments of rest and tenderness, their fights and flights, their raw, ferocious need.

title: Review: At NADA Art Fair, Collecting for Pleasure, Not Status
description: If you like your art fairs of manageable size and relaxed mood, as well as free, with a more-than-respectable level of quality, the fair of the New Art Dealers Alliance, or NADA, is for you. Especially if you dont have, oh, $179 million, give or take several zeros, to toss around. And also if you thrill to the idea of simply taking art home in a large shopping bag and starting to live with it immediately.

title: Spare Times for May 15-21
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Movie Listings for May 15-21
description: Movies

title: Benghazi Panel Wants Documents Before Hillary Clinton Testifies
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, said on Thursday that he would not call Hillary Rodham Clinton to testify until the State Department turned over a trove of documents about the episode.

title: Changing Course, Russia Will Sell Rubles Instead of Buying
description: MOSCOW  The Russian economy is sliding into a recession. Consumers are retreating. Corporate profits are suffering.

title: 2015s Most Memorable (Sartorial and Experiential) Exhibitions at Frieze New York
description: The G-force of the global art world ratchets ever upward this year, as Biennale peepers depart Venice en masse and spin around the world to New York for the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island, which opens to the public today. Yesterday, VIPs toured the fair to take stock of offerings by nearly 200 contemporary art galleries from around the world, brought together by the fairs new director, Victoria Siddall, and its new artistic director for the Americas and Asia, Abby Bangser.

title: Comedy Listings for May 15-21
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for May 15-21
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for May 15-21
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: First Draft Focus: Reassuring Persian Gulf Allies
Pointed Fanfare Over the Year of la Femme at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Vive les femmes, bb! The Cannes Film Festival is legendary for the beautiful women who pass across its big, bright screens and down its magic red carpet. This year, though, the festival is also grandly making conspicuous room for women of all kinds, including those rarely deemed good enough to compete for the Palme dOr: directors. It reserved its opening night slot for Emmanuelle Bercot, touting her film La Tte Haute as the first from a female director to be so honored. Diane Kurys had been there, done that back in 1987 with A Man in Love  but no matter.

title: Review: The Edge Becomes the Center Explores the Rubble of Rebuilding
description: Thrive, cities, Walt Whitman wrote in Crossing the Brooklyn Ferry, one of his great love songs to urban life. Expand but Keep your places.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 15-21
description: The Big Family Quiz Thing

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are one-bedrooms located in Tudor City, Midtown East and Clinton Hill.

title: For Amanda Green, a Fathers Legacy in Her Lyrics
description: In The Legacy, an 11 oclock number from the 1978 Broadway musical On the Twentieth Century, the egomaniacal producer Oscar Jaffee is at the end of his theatrical rope. Fearing financial ruin, he whips out a gun, announces hes going to kill himself and offers to bequeath his collection of theater memorabilia to his henchmen:

title: ISIS Advance in Syria Endangers Ancient Ruins at Palmyra
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamic State militants advanced to the outskirts of the Syrian town of Palmyra on Thursday, putting the extremist group within striking distance of some of the worlds most magnificent antiquities.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a six-bedroom in Chappaqua, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Review: Good Kill Stars Ethan Hawke Fighting Enemies Half a World Away
description: Disregard the arguments for and against drone warfare advanced in Good Kill, and the movie still makes a persuasive case that our blind infatuation with all-powerful technology is stripping us of our humanity.

title: Review: In Ill See You in My Dreams, Blythe Danner Seeks Fulfillment
description: To the lengthening list of well-mannered films aimed at moviegoers who have reached an age when, to quote Shakespeare, the heyday in the blood is tame, add Ill See You in My Dreams, a modest, quietly touching portrait of an older woman radiantly embodied by Blythe Danner. Her character, Carol, widowed for two decades, is a nice, sensible woman who lives alone in a comfortable Southern California house with her ailing dog, Hazel. When, near the beginning of the movie, she has to have the animal put down, she is briefly grief-stricken.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, May 17 to 23, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Minnesota Orchestras Cuba Trip Puts It at the Cultural Vanguard
description: HAVANA  They shimmied with dancers on stilts who greeted them in this old city, where book stalls sell comic-book retellings of the Cuban Revolution. Conservatory students welcomed them with flowers and chamber music. And when a band serenaded them at dinner, a few even got up and cha-chaed.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, May 17 to 23, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Slow West, a Wry Twist on Classic Frontier Fables
description: The surreal frontier fable Slow West, written and directed by John Maclean (Man on a Motorcycle), is an absurdist deconstruction of classic Hollywood westerns whose 21st-century view of frontier mythology is as sardonic as that of the Coen brothers.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, May 17 to 23, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: De Blasios Housing Push Spurs Anxiety Among Those Its Meant to Help
description: When New York City planners unveiled maps charting a 73-block area in the Bronx to be developed with housing, they called it Cromwell-Jerome.

title: Blackstone Buys Minority Stake in Hedge Fund Magnetar Capital
description: The Blackstone Group is taking a minority stake in Magnetar Capital, the $13.6 billion hedge fund run by the former Citadel trader Alec Litowitz.

title: What I Love | Danny Burstein and Rebecca Luker
description: Home for the two Broadway actors is a Manhattan building that has known celebrity, including Cecil B. DeMille and Barack Obama.

title: Review: Bessie, on HBO, Stars Queen Latifah as Blues Singer Bessie Smith
description: Bessie is about a blues singer, but what the movie could really use is more soul.

title: Jeb Bushs Mixed Answers on the Iraq War
description: In the days since an interview with Fox News, Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor, has sought to clarify his position on the invasion of Iraq.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 17 to 23, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: No Charges for Engineer in 2013 Fatal Metro-North Derailment
description: The Bronx district attorneys office said on Thursday that it would not file charges against the engineer who fell asleep on a Metro-North Railroad train in 2013, causing the train to hurtle off the rails in an accident that left four people dead.

title: Beloved Writing Instruments
description: A closer look at The Secret Life of the Pencil, a new exhibition.

title: Bike Rides in Bike Month, and Shakespeare vs. Mad Men
description: A bicycle ride along the Hudson River waterfront in Manhattan is a trip to the past.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 45 YEARS AGO

title: Review: Where Hope Grows, a Baseball Career Lost and Relationships Found
description: Not to be flip, but Where Hope Grows has the potential to be a decent inspirational film until God shows up.

title: SummerStage
description: The music series turns 30.

title: In a Musical Milestone, All the Citys a Stage
description: WHEN the Central Park Mall began hosting musical performances in the 1860s, only classical was permitted. In the 1920s, with the Naumburg Bandshells arrival, collars loosened and the sounds of the day  folk, pop, jazz  trickled in. But only in the last three decades, with the rise of SummerStage, the annual festival of largely free shows presented by the City Parks Foundation, has the tradition of live music in the citys public spaces been truly cemented  and gleefully trampled on.

title: Summer Theater Festivals: From the Fringes to Center Stage
description: AMERICAN PLAYERS THEATER

title: Exclusive | 50 Central Park South
description: A two-bedroom condominium on the 33rd floor of the Ritz Carlton Hotel is poised to enter the market at $50 million.

title: Review: Our Man in Tehran Recounts Iran Hostage Crisis Escape
description: It made a darn good Hollywood movie, and the story of how the Canadian ambassador and others helped six American Embassy workers escape Iran in 1980 also makes a pretty watchable documentary. Its called Our Man in Tehran, and if it doesnt have the slickness of Ben Afflecks Oscar-winning version of events, Argo, it can claim authenticity. Theres nothing like hearing a harrowing tale from the people who lived it.

title: A Debate Over How Long Democracy Can Wage Battles in Shadows
description: WASHINGTON  When the House voted this week to end and replace the National Security Agencys once-secret program that collects Americans phone records in bulk, it was both an ordinary act of government and a striking exception to post-9/11 national security policy making.

title: In California Budget Plan, Brown Wins Deal on Tuition Freeze for In-State Students
description: LOS ANGELES  Ending a standoff over whether tuition at the University of California schools would rise, Gov. Jerry Brown said Thursday that he would send millions more dollars to the university system than he had proposed earlier this year, in exchange for a tuition freeze for in-state students in the 10-campus system.

title: Review: In Know How, Teenagers Portray Their Plight in Foster Care
description: Written and acted by young men and women who grew up in New York Citys foster care system, Know How tours the mean streets of a rough urban adolescence rarely acknowledged. Originally a musical presented by the nonprofit Possibility Project, the film weaves together tales of five teenagers striving for stability in turbulent settings.

title: Tony Ayala Jr., Boxer Convicted of Rape, Dies at 52
description: Tony Ayala Jr., a fierce, gifted and troubled fighter who was a rising middleweight contender before a rape conviction sent him to prison, was found dead on Tuesday at his familys boxing gym in San Antonio. He was 52.

title: An Airline Investment in Uruguay Becomes a Catch-22
description: It might have been the volcano.

title: Review: Dark Star Peers Into H. R. Gigers Creative World
description: If you crossed The Addams Family with an episode of Hoarders, you might come up with something like the documentary Dark Star: H. R. Gigers World. A deferentially admiring visit with the Swiss surrealist artist whose beastie design for Ridley Scotts Alien (1979) earned him Hollywood renown, this disordered portrait seems heavily influenced by its equally jumbled setting.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Review: L for Leisure, Vignettes of Graduate Students on Vacation
description: Divided into segments with postcard-ready titles (Thanksgiving, 1992, Beaumont, TX; Summer Break, 1993, Baja, Mexico), L for Leisure, set in the early 1990s, follows graduate students on vacations around the world. The vignettes offer ample opportunities to watch ostensibly smart people behaving stupidly. The conceit, to paraphrase one character, is that grad school is for people who never moved on from high school.

title: Eight Amtrak Passengers Deaths Echo Across the Region and the World
description: Boarding the train in Washington, a commercial real estate broker texted her mother: she was safely in her seat, she said, on her way home to Manhattan. A businessman usually flew for work, but for this quick trip the train seemed more convenient. A Wells Fargo executive had dropped everything for his uncles funeral, but had to return to his job. An Italian olive oil and wine salesman preferred to fly, but jumped on Amtrak when his flight arrangements fell through.

title: Iraqi Who Worked for the U.S. Military Is Arrested in Texas in Link to Islamic State
description: WASHINGTON  An Iraqi man who worked as a translator for the American military before moving to the United States in 2009 was arrested on Thursday in Texas by F.B.I. agents who say he pledged allegiance to the leader of the Islamic State last year and misled them about his travels to Syria.

title: Review: The Connection, a Crime Thriller Retold From a Gallic Perspective
description: So French, and so 1975, the drug-running drama The Connection is a riot of cleft chins and tight pants, manicured sideburns and precariously buttoned shirts. Amid these distractions, separating cops from criminals would be challenging enough, even if the proceedings were not 135 minutes long and peppered with look-alikes.

title: Understanding Southeast Asias Migrant Crisis
description: About 25,000 migrants left Myanmar and Bangladesh on rickety smugglers boats in the first three months of 2015, according to a United Nations estimate.

title: Missouri House Speaker Quits Over Texts
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  John Diehl, Missouris State House speaker, said Thursday that he would resign, one day after the revelation of sexually suggestive text messages that he exchanged with a 19-year-old legislative intern.

title: Jokes Aside, David Letterman Leaves Behind a Costlier Neighborhood
description: When the Late Show first started taping at the Ed Sullivan Theater in Midtown Manhattan in September 1993, the area was very fringy, said Rupert Jee, an owner of the Hello Deli on West 53rd Street, around the corner from the theater entrance and next to the stage door and the corporate offices.

title: Review: In the Name of My Daughter, a Family-Business Scandal
description: Andr Tchins latest film, In the Name of My Daughter, a bit like his The Girl on the Train, centers on a young woman who hurls herself into an obsessive pursuit, heedless of the consequences as she fulfills a deeper need. Both are also dramas based on true stories, yet Mr. Tchin uses this fodder not as a fount of titillating scandal but as a chance to portray mysterious urges and passions, which come to feel slightly less mysterious the closer we get.

title: Every Secret Thing, an Unsettling Story of When Babies Go Missing
description: Nothing is creepier than creepy children and teenagers, and the ones in Every Secret Thing are first-rate examples. The story may be fictional  its based on a Laura Lippman novel  but by the end of this movie youll be warier than ever of the local youngsters.

title: Defying U.S., Colombia Halts Aerial Spraying of Crops Used to Make Cocaine
description: BOGOT, Colombia  The government of Colombiaon Thursdaynight rejected a major tool in the American-backed antidrug campaign  ordering a halt to the aerial spraying of the countrys vast illegal plantings of coca, the crop used to make cocaine, citing concerns that the spray causes cancer.

title: Duke Energy Agrees to Pay $102 Million for Breaches
description: Duke Energy, the nations largest utility corporation, pleaded guilty on Thursday to criminal violations of the federal Clean Water Act for the discharge of coal ash, a potentially toxic waste product, and for a failure to properly maintain equipment at a number of power plants in its home state of North Carolina. The company also agreed to pay $102 million in fines and environmental fees.

title: Netanyahus Coalition Gets Rocky Start With Discontent Over Leadership Posts
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus new government was sworn in on Thursday night after a stormy Parliament session that reflected much broader discontent over the political process that gave rise to the coalition dominated by right-wing and religious parties.

title: Review: Childless, a Film of Connected Monologues, Stars Joe Mantegna
description: Theres solid acting in Childless, but mostly there are words  torrents of them.

title: Witness Accounts in Midtown Hammer Attack Show the Power of False Memory
description: The real world of our memory is made of bits of true facts, surrounded by holes that we Spackle over with guesses and beliefs and crowd-sourced rumors. On the dot of 10 on Wednesday morning, Anthony OGrady, 26, stood in front of a Dunkin Donuts on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. He heard a ruckus, some shouts, then saw a police officer chase a man into the street and shoot him down in the middle of the avenue.

title: Review: Echoes of War Follows a Confederate Soldier Home
description: If you havent had your dose of dourness for the day, Echoes of War will provide it in well-acted abundance. Its a gloomy, somewhat underwritten story of two families just after the Civil War, an exploration of the kind of disruption that lingers after fighting on the battlefield is over.

title: Barbaros Owners Are Back for Another Preakness
description: BALTIMORE  When Gretchen and Roy Jackson settled into their seats to watch the Preakness Stakes on May 20, 2006, they expected to see Barbaro, the brilliant Kentucky Derby champion they bred and owned, take another step toward a Triple Crown that many fans thought was inevitable.

title: Democrats Balk at Sparing Only Military Spending From Mandated Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Key Democrats on Thursday said they opposed Republican efforts to circumvent broad, congressionally mandated cuts in military spending as lawmakers considered the annual Pentagon budget.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 15, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Mad Max: Fury Road, Pitch Perfect 2 and Ill See You In My Dreams.

title: Yemen: Al Qaeda Outlaws a Stimulant
description: Al Qaedas branch in Yemen, which seized control over the port of Al Mukalla nearly a month ago, has barred residents from trading or chewing khat, the leafy green stimulant that has been a habit in that country for centuries, local Yemeni journalists reported Thursday. Armed men were seen confiscating bundles of khat, burning them in bonfires and inspecting the markets for violators. At least five trucks loaded with khat were reported to have been stopped from entering Al Mukalla. The militant group, known as Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, was able to exploit the chaos caused by airstrikes by Saudi Arabia against Houthi rebels to occupy Al Mukalla on April 16. The Houthis, who have received support from Iran, occupied the capital and ousted the president in recent months. The Saudis and Houthis on Thursday accused each other of violating a truce that began Tuesday as a way to provide an opportunity for aid groups to provide food, fuel and medicine to Yemens civilians.

title: Audree Norton, Who Paved Way for Deaf Actors, Dies at 88
description: Audree Norton, a deaf actress whose fight to be cast on a television show in the late 1970s effectively ended her career in the medium but greatly helped the careers of deaf actors who followed her, died on April 22 at her home in Fremont, Calif. She was 88.

title: Romney vs. Holyfield: Im Staying Far Away From His Ears
description: Friday night in Utah  not exactly Las Vegas  the former Republican heavyweight Mitt Romney will face the former heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield in a charity boxing match. The bout will benefit CharityVision, an organization that provides sight-restoration surgery for people in very poor countries around the world. It will not benefit the dignity of Mitt Romney.

title: Gaza: Dozens Injured at Hamas Camp
description: A huge explosion at a training camp for Hamas militants in northern Gaza wounded more than 60 people, including women and children, on Thursday night, Hamas officials said. The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, said in a statement that the blast was caused by an Israeli missile left over from the war last summer. But Iyad al-Buzom, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry in Gaza, described it in a Facebook post more vaguely as an internal explosion. Witnesses said the blast, in Beit Lahiya, damaged nearby houses and caused power failures in the area.

title: Goodell Says He Will Hear Brady Appeal
description: Tom Brady formally appealed his four-game suspension on Thursday for his reported role in the deflation of footballs before the A.F.C. championship game in January against the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Obama Reviews Talks With Gulf Leaders
description: President Obama recapped a range of topics he discussed with Persian Gulf leaders at Camp David, including the situations in Syria and Yemen and nuclear talks with Iran.

title: Massachusetts: Jurors Continue Work in Marathon Bombing Case
description: Jurors in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted in the Boston Marathon bombing,on Thursdayspent their first full day considering whether he should be put to death or given a life sentence for killing three people and wounding more than 260. The jurors, who had deliberated for less than an houron Wednesday, have been given a 24-page verdict form and have been instructed to weigh a variety of factors.On Thursday, they passed the court questions about the idea of aiding and abetting, and about how they should fill out the verdict form. Mr. Tsarnaev was convicted of 17 counts that carry a maximum sentence of the death penalty; to impose it, the jury must unanimously agree it is appropriate on at least one of the counts.

title: Ruling in Royalty Case Gives BMI a Victory Against Pandora
description: Last week, Pandora Media won two battles in its long-running war against the music industry, but on Thursday, it lost one  this time over how much it should pay the licensing agency BMI in royalties.

title: Patrick Kanes Quick Return and Healthy Scoring Touch Provide a Salve for a City
description: CHICAGO  At practice a couple of weeks into his rehabilitation of a broken collarbone, Chicago Blackhawks wing Patrick Kane knew he was ahead of schedule. He had only just resumed skating, which he could do without pain, and he was juggling the puck on his stick. He was still under strict medical orders not to shoot, but he could not help himself: He glided down the ice and snapped off a wrist shot toward the net. Still no pain.

title: Harry Potters One-Time Crush
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I had a tough time getting started with this puzzle by David Phillips, largely because of the northwest. Mr. Phillips tells us about the construction of this puzzle below, so Ill just say that I didnt know INA CLAIRE or K.C. JONES, and was not able to recall DARK ANGEL, so that sector remained fairly empty for a long time.

title: New York Police Dept. Questioning of Protesters Was Improper, Rights Lawyers Tell Commissioner
description: Five civil rights lawyers have sent a letter to Police Commissioner William J. Bratton saying that the recent questioning of protesters by detectives violated a federal consent decree and was not conducted by the proper New York Police Department division.

title: When News Comes Knocking: Securing Exclusive Photos of a Police Shooting
description: Jessie Schwartz is a photo editor on the Metro desk.

title: Pete Rose Comes Out Swinging as an Analyst
description: Pete Roses first three days as a studio analyst for Fox Sports 1 this week suggests that he might be terrific  even if hes not getting dirty or bowling over catchers.

title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Opens Private Fund-Raising Arm for Start-Ups
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has set up a group to help companies raise money through private fund-raising, the investment bank announced in an internal memorandum on Thursday.

title: New York Senate Votes for Bill Allowing Dogs in Outdoor Dining Areas
description: A brush of terrier fur against a patrons open toes as she sips her morning coffee. A nudge from a rangy German shepherd beneath an outdoor table piled high with croissants. Paws scraping against the sidewalk in pursuit of dropped bits of omelet.

title: Marine Veteran Held in Iranian Prison Ends Hunger Strike at Familys Request
description: Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran who is the longest-held American prisoner in Iran, reluctantly ended his second hunger strike this past weekend after relatives  particularly his terminally ill father  beseeched him to stop, Mr. Hekmatis sister said Thursday.

title: David Baril Is Charged With Assault in Manhattan Hammer Attacks
description: The police said on Thursday that they had filed assault charges against David Baril, who was suspected of wielding a hammer in a series of attacks before he was shot by an officer in Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: Murray Heads to Paris With 2 New Assets: Winning Streak and Belief
description: ROME  Given that clay has been dominated by a single player for the last decade in the mens game, it is not surprising that a top player is going into the French Open undefeated on the surface this season.

title: Stan Cornyn, Creative Record Executive, Is Dead at 81
description: Stan Cornyn, an offbeat recording industry executive known both for his unusual promotions and for his album notes, two of which won Grammy Awards, died on Monday at his home in Carpinteria, Calif. He was 81.

title: Yanks Lose Third Straight as Offense, Like Division Lead, Keeps Fading
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees packed their bags and, they hoped, their offense and enough healthy pitchers, and prepared to board a flight late Thursday night to Kansas City, Mo.

title: LeBron James Helps Cavaliers Coast Past Bulls Into Eastern Finals
description: CHICAGO  LeBron James is 6 feet 8 inches and 250 pounds of rippling muscle and world-class skill, but to the Chicago Bulls he looked like a mountain they could never scale.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I dont want to be too overdramatic, but if these people arent treated and brought to shore soon, we are going to have a boat full of corpses.

title: The New Tattoo
description: Full-color illustration has given way to a playfully personal twist on ink.

title: A French Bartender Spices Things Up Behind the Bar (and on Video)
description: The French bartender Nico de Soto first grew to prominence at the Experimental Cocktail Club  either the Paris, London or New York locations, hes worked all three (and created the menu for the Manhattan outpost when it opened in 2012). Now in his own bar, Mace, which opened in the East Village at the end of March, de Soto has drawn upon that broad wealth of sensory experience inspired by food from everywhere, he says.

title: In Its Second Year, Sight Unseen Offsite Promises Double the Fun
description: In the five years since its inception, Sight Unseen  the online hub run by the writers and curators Monica Khemsurov (a T contributor) and Jill Singer  has not only documented new currents in the design world, but defined them. (The site can arguably take credit for the Memphis Group revival currently swirling through the scene.) Last year, during New York Design Week, the duo staged the first edition of Sight Unseen Offsite, a 20,000-square-foot showcase for independent talent which, Singer says, crystallized for everyone what our aesthetic and point of view is. This week, that vision is all over town: Offsite has a satellite presence at the Collective Design fair, while the main event has returned for an encore at a new space, opening today and conveniently located a stones throw from the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Javits Center.

title: The Nuns Spoke Out, but the Archbishop Listened
description: When 25 leaders of the largest organization of American nuns met for the first time with Archbishop J. Peter Sartain of Seattle in 2012, after the Vatican appointed him to lead an overhaul of their group, they expected conflict.

title: Word of the Day | rusticate
description: rusticate  \rs-ti-kat\  verb

title: Christies and Phillips Have Auctions With Differing Results
description: Toward the end of a week that saw $2 billion worth of art change hands, the question Thursday night was whether buyers in New York would have the energy  and money  to spend still more as Christies and Phillips held auctions that overlapped a bit in time.

title: Match in Argentina Is Suspended After Attack on River Plate Team
description: BUENOS AIRES  Police and soccer officials in Argentina opened investigations on Friday after visiting players in one of the most anticipated matches of the Argentine soccer season the previous night were attacked with an irritant and the game was halted at halftime.

title: Five Upper East Side Bedrooms for $21 Million
description: A sprawling five-bedroom apartment at the Marquand, a century-old Beaux-Arts Revival building on the Upper East Side that was converted into luxury condominiums two years ago by the HFZ Capital Group, sold for $21,082,866.25 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 11:45 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FOR NO GOOD REASON (2014) I really thought what I would do, if I ever learned to draw properly, was I would try to change the world, the British artist Ralph Steadman explains in Charlie Pauls documentary about him. So in 1970, Mr. Steadman jetted to New York, where he planned to take a thousand photographs that would inspire the illustrations he couldnt seem to get quite right. There was an arrogance missing, there was a wildness missing, there was a rawness missing, he says of that early work. It lacked that bite I needed, that real ferocious bite, the thing that would make it noticeable. Then he received instructions to meet Hunter S. Thompson, not long after his infiltration of the Hells Angels. The weekend became a vicious, drunken nightmare, and he and Thompson went to pieces. Thus, gonzo journalism  in which the writer (and in this decadent collaboration, the illustrator) becomes the story  was born. What would Thompsons Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas be without Mr. Steadmans ink-speckled and splotched drawings, Mr. Steadman argues. There is a formal discipline and thematic coherence to Mr. Steadmans images that his friends writing sometimes lacked, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Steadman has frequently aimed to shock, and almost always with good reason.

title: B. B. King, Defining Bluesman for Generations, Dies at 89
description: B. B. King, whose world-weary voice and wailing guitar lifted him from the cotton fields of Mississippi to a global stage and the apex of American blues, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 89.

title: Test Yourself | High Fashion at the Mall
description: Below are several paragraphs from the May 7 article High-End Culture Comes to Shopping Malls.

title: Corrections: May 15, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 6 Qs About the News | Anna Kendrick on Pitch Perfect 2 and Not Trying Too Hard
description: In Anna Kendrick on Pitch Perfect 2 and Not Trying Too Hard, Brooks Barnes profiles the actress.

title: Missing U.S. Marine Helicopter Is Found in Nepal, Official Says
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  The wreckage of a United States Marine helicopter was found on Friday on a high mountain pass in Nepal, where below-freezing temperatures, raging winds and thunderstorms had made it too dangerous even to recover the bodies.

title: Odd, Old Days in Times Square
description: Among the denizens of the pre-Disney Times Square was a casually dressed man with unruly white hair sitting in a beat-up Dodge Valiant outside a Howard Johnsons restaurant. He spent his time listening to a police scanner, which emitted a steady, scratchy stream of reports of gang shootings, car accidents or suicide jumpers.

title: What Do You Want More From a Career: Happiness or Wealth?
description: A study published this week found that lawyers in public-service jobs who made the least money, like public defenders or Legal Aid attorneys, were more likely to report being happy than lawyers with high-income jobs at corporate law firms. It seems that law students may have to choose between happiness and wealth before starting a career.

title: After the Amtrak Crash: Preventing Future Derailments
College Sports: Thats Entertainment, Not Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids Who Cant See Cant Learn
description: LAST year, I went with a small group of ophthalmologists to a South Bronx middle school to conduct vision exams. One neatly dressed boy had trouble seeing the big E at the top of the chart. He hesitated and made mistakes on the second line, and then put his head down, embarrassed. I dont think you can see the chart, I said.

title: Jobs in the Inner City
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Francis and the Art of Joy
description: In the modern era, Europe has never had fewer practicing Christians. The United States, according to a Pew survey released this week, is trending in the same direction, led by millennials wary of pontifical certainty.

title: Mentor the Children
End Immigration Detention
description: Of all the malfunctioning parts in the countrys broken-down immigration machinery, probably the most indefensible is the detention system.

title: The Vatican and the Palestinians
description: The practical effect of the Vaticans decision to sign a treaty recognizing the state of Palestine is debatable, but it is a symbolic victory for Palestinians who are struggling to keep alive their dream of a Palestinian state, which has been thwarted by the Israeli government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Fraternity of Failure
description: Jeb Bush wants to stop talking about past controversies. And you can see why. He has a lot to stop talking about. But lets not honor his wish. You can learn a lot by studying recent history, and you can learn even more by watching how politicians respond to that history.

title: An Invitation to High School Students
One-Week Student Competition | Write a Letter to the Editor, for Publication in the Opinion Section
description: If our recent Student Editorial Contest left you wanting to write more about the issues that matter to you most, heres your chance.

title: Modi Calls on China to Rethink Stances That Strain Ties to India
description: HONG KONG  Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, told Chinas leaders on Friday that it was up to them to rethink policies that he said had hindered cooperation between the Asian giants.

title: New Look, British Retailer, to Be Acquired by Brait of South Africa for $1.2 Billion
description: LONDON  Brait, a South African investment firm, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling interest in the British retailer New Look Retail Group for 780 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion.

title: Burundi Government Says It Has Crushed Coup Attempt
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  Loyalist police and army officers have crushed an attempted coup in Burundi, the government said Friday. The announcement followed two days of confusion over who controlled the central African country, which has been shaken by weeks of violent protests over the presidents ambitions to stay in office.

title: Want a Green Card? Invest in Real Estate
description: Like many of her fellow classmates at New York University, Yanchu Zhao has a busy schedule. A college junior, she has a double major in economics and journalism, and juggles classes, an internship and life with roommates in a rental near Herald Square.

title: From the Quotable Mouths of the Memphis Grizzlies, Straight to Ad-Libbed T-Shirts
description: MEMPHIS  The Western Conference semifinal series between the Memphis Grizzlies and the Golden State Warriors was heating up last week when Tony Allen, the Grizzlies hyperkinetic guard, stripped the Warriors Klay Thompson of his dribble. In celebration, Allen slapped the court and shouted, for the world to hear: First-team all-defense! First-team all-defense!

title: What You Get When You Blend a Drone and a Gecko
description: There is a wide array of obstacles facing the drone deliveries proposed by Amazon and Google. If the deliveries do happen, however, researchers from the mechanical engineering lab at Stanford University believe they have made a technological leap in the science of the drones landing.

title: Ayelet Shaked, Israels New Justice Minister, Shrugs Off Critics in Her Path
description: JERUSALEM  She has been called the Michele Bachmann of Israeli politics, a nod to their shared far-right ideology and striking appearance. She was assigned a bodyguard after a social media post was made to show her wearing a Nazi uniform and accused her of promoting Palestinian genocide. She was belittled by a former minister as the most prominent politician who could star in a calendar hanging in garages, prompting even ardent critics to rush to her defense.

title: Caught in Nepals Earthquakes
description: When Daniel Berehulak flew into Kathmandu four days after a 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal in April, his initial impression was that the damage was not as catastrophic as he had expected. His first days were spent photographing people pulling valuables  televisions and teddy bears and kitchen cupboards  from rubble piles around the city, sometimes carrying them away balanced on their heads. It was a sight that struck him as brave and hopeful.

title: China Clears Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Man, but Controversy Isnt Over
description: Once again, the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by a police officer has set off a heated public debate, but this time in China.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: May 15
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from Bryant Park, a funeral of a police officer and an Uzbek birthday party.

title: Ask Well: Reducing Belly Fat
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Q. and A.: Nicholas R. Lardy on Markets and the State in China
description: Chinas biggest companies are still, for the most part, state-owned enterprises, or S.O.E.s. Companies controlled by the Chinese government dominate energy, finance and telecommunications, and they often have better access to capital from state-run banks. But in his latest book, Markets Over Mao: The Rise of Private Business in China, the economist Nicholas R. Lardy argues that Chinas economic boom has been fueled by private enterprise and policies that have allowed the market to play a greater role.

title: Artists Respond to B. B. Kings Death on Social Media
description: The pioneering blues singer and guitarist B. B. King, who won over a dozen Grammy Awards and is perhaps best known for the song The Thrill Is Gone, died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 89.

title: West Point and the Culinary Institute of America: An Exchange of Experiences
description: We are hard pressed to think of many world-class liberal arts colleges with entire student bodies ambitiously studying and training toward a single profession  and in uniforms that are far from Vassars or Columbias baseball caps or yoga pants. While the Culinary Institute of America prepares its student chefs for successful careers in hospitality, just across the Hudson River, the United States Military Academy at West Points mission is to educate, train and inspire its own student body for the profession of arms. The two institutions seem worlds apart, yet conversations over a couple of meals quickly demonstrate otherwise.

title: Decoding the Enigma of Satoshi Nakamoto and the Birth of Bitcoin
description: It is one of the great mysteries of the digital age.

title: New York Today: Basking in the Spring Sun
description: Good morning on this temperate Friday.

title: Bernie Madoffs Essential Man
description: One morning years ago, an auditor from the firm KPMG paid a visit to Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities offices at 885 Third Avenue, the sleek, tubular Midtown office tower known as the Lipstick Building. The auditor informed Frank DiPascali Jr., Madoffs de facto chief financial officer, that he was conducting due diligence for a major European bank and asked to see a trade ledger  a roster of Madoffs transaction records  for the investment fund.

title: How to Fall Asleep
description: Quality sleep impacts performance profoundly, says Christopher Winter, a neurologist and sleep consultant to many professional sports teams, including the San Francisco Giants and the Oklahoma City Thunder. Frequent travel across time zones turns their players into what Winter calls glorified, overpaid shift workers who are particularly vulnerable to the repercussions of being chronically tired. Winter studied Major League Baseball players and found that 86 percent of those who reported the highest levels of drowsiness were no longer in the league two years later.

title: The Corn Baby
description: Poems are made things and, at their best, remake the world for us. The syntax, repetition and alliteration of this poem feel like a kind of bundling  the poet composing the form of the corn baby, sound by sound, word by word. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Flight Paths
description: Displayed on a small plinth in a university museum in the German city Rostock is a famously gruesome exhibit: a stuffed white stork with its long neck pierced by an iron-tipped wooden spear from Central Africa. This unlucky bird survived the attack and flew back to Germany, only to be shot by a hunter in the spring of 1822. Newspaper reports revealed the spears distant origin, and the newly christened pfeilstorch, or arrow-stork, was celebrated for solving the puzzle of where German storks spent their winters.

title: Re: Backed Into a Corner
description: For the May 3 special issue on money, Gideon Lewis-Kraus told the story of the rise and fall of a Kickstarter company called ZPM Espresso  the home-espresso-machine mega-failure that came to define the crowdfunding era of specialty coffee tech, in the words of an aggregator named Sprudge Wire.

title: Bob Baffert Already Has Only Crown He Seeks: Kentucky Derbys
description: BALTIMORE  Bob Bafferts hair remains snowy white, and his eyes still water beneath his ever-present shades. It is a heck of a thing that a horse trainer is allergic to horses. At 62, his mouth moves faster than his legs. Then again, it always has.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Blind Contour Drawing
description: A few years ago, I became unhappy with my drawing style. I had been an enthusiastic doodler since childhood, but my art hadnt really evolved since then. Every time I sat down to draw, I found myself producing two-dimensional googly-eyed cartoon figures (pencils, avocados, dinosaurs, hamburgers, tacos, clouds, whatever) that would raise their tiny stick arms whimsically whenever they needed to speak to one another. It was cutesy and severely limited and  after several decades  excruciatingly boring. I had lost the ability to surprise myself. My visual relationship to the world had atrophied. Occasionally, there were minor coups; a 4-year-old would ask me to draw a pirate ship or a dinosaur, then tell me that I was the worlds greatest artist. Eventually, however, they would grow up and change their minds.

title: Upward Mobility for the Worlds Destitute
description: Theres poor, and then theres ultrapoor. The ultrapoor are almost always women and largely found in Africa, South Asia and to a lesser extent, parts of Latin America. They are most often rural. They work as maids or field laborers, often paid not with wages but in food scraps. They might have just one dress or sari, and must wash a part of it at a time while wearing it, or stay in the river for modesty till it dries.

title: How Your Hometown Affects Your Chances of Marriage
description: People are less likely to marry if they grow up in certain places, especially liberal ones.

title: Travel Industry Responds to Rise in Solo Sojourners
description: Vacations have long gone hand-in-hand with company: family bonding, honeymoons, babymoons, bands of oats-sowing college backpackers. Yet today, more and more travelers are going solo  and theyre not who you might expect them to be.

title: Where to Shop in the Berkshires
description: The town of Great Barrington, nestled in the Berkshires in Massachusetts, has long been a popular weekend destination because of its picturesque setting and proximity to many cultural attractions like the Tanglewood summer music festival. But the area also has a vibrant year-round community of residents, some of them former New Yorkers who have opened a mix of eclectic stores selling everything from housewares to high fashion. Most of the shopping is concentrated on Main Street with a few spots tucked away nearby.

title: Like Hillary Clinton in 08, Jeb Bush Is Haunted by Specter of Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON  Eight years after Hillary Rodham Clinton was haunted by her Senate vote to authorize the use of force in Iraq, another leading White House hopeful is struggling with questions about the war.

title: When Maestros Cry
description: Via Mark Thoma, today in liberal fascism: Apparently Im part of the liberal speech police, blocking debate on important subjects, because I criticized Alan Greenspan for planning to headline a goldbug conference taking place next to the Feds annual Jackson Hole event. And its true  I used vicious, undemocratic tactics like calling attention to Greenspans record of bad predictions. I even used sarcasm and ridicule. And you know who else used sarcasm and ridicule? Hitler The Piranha Brothers.

title: Today in Politics: Republicans Head to Iowa to Court Activists
Clippers Big Collapse Against Rockets Forces a Game 7
description: LOS ANGELES  The confetti was ready to fall from the rafters, like a curtain to the past. The Los Angeles Clippers, finally, were minutes away from overcoming their own history.

title: Morning Agenda: Hoax Bid for Avon Points to S.E.C. Security Hole
description: HOAX BID FOR AVON POINTS TO S.E.C. SECURITY HOLE | A phantom takeover bid for Avon Products on Thursday highlighted a potential weakness in the federal governments system for filing securities documents, Matthew Goldstein and David Gelles write in DealBook. A firm calling itself PTG Capital Partners, supposedly a British investment firm, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had offered to buy Avon for $18.75 a share, which caused shares of Avon, which had opened the days trading at $6.71, to rise more than $1. The companys shares closed nearly 6 percent higher at $7.07 even after it was determined that neither PTG Capital nor the firms supposed lawyer in the United States existed at the locations given in the regulatory filing and after Avon denied that it had received an offer.

title: Matisse From Gurlitt Collection Is Returned to Jewish Art Dealers Heirs
description: MUNICH  The slide made public in November 2013 showing a painting of a woman wearing a white blouse embroidered with blue, purple and red flowers, with a fan on her lap, was grainy, but its subject was immediately recognizable to Elaine Rosenberg. It showed a priceless Matisse. Her familys Matisse.

title: South Korean Leader Voices Alarm at Kim Jong-uns Reign of Terror
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas president on Friday warned that the North Korean leader Kim Jong-uns extreme reign of terror and his governments recent hostilities along the two countries disputed maritime border were raising uncertainty on the divided peninsula.

title: Boat With Hundreds of Migrants From Myanmar Heads Farther Out to Sea
description: LIPE ISLAND, Thailand  A wooden fishing boat carrying hundreds of desperate migrants from Myanmar moved farther out to sea on Friday after the Thai authorities concluded that the passengers wanted to continue their journey, instead of disembarking in Thailand, according to an aid group involved in negotiations over the vessels future.

title: George Stephanopoulos Apologizes to Viewers on Clinton Donations
description: George Stephanopoulos, the ABC News chief news anchor, told Good Morning America viewers on Friday that it was a mistake for him to donate $75,000 over the last three years to the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation, and he apologized for not disclosing the contribution.

title: A Jewish Litmus Test Was Unacceptable
description: A Ph.D. candidate at the University of California, Berkeley, David McCleary, wrote to me this week with a complaint about being subjected to what he called a Jewish litmus test during a Times interview.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Con Edison Worker Foils Hood
description: Dear Diary:

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Singapore

title: Families Find the Principles That Keep the Business Going
description: PETER GORDON, a member of the family that owns Glenfiddich whisky, has a distinct memory of the workers lined up as he walked into the Scottish distillery in the 1970s. They were waiting for a dram of day-old whisky  the equivalent of a double shot. If they didnt drink it, they rubbed it into their hands, in the belief that it toughened calluses.

title: Diane Keaton and Morgan Freemans Real Estate Adventure
description: Soon after they married in the mid-1970s, a promising young artist and his schoolteacher wife moved into a rundown two-bedroom apartment on the top floor of a walk-up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. For 40 years, amid canvasses and clutter, it was home sweet home.

title: B.B. King, Bluesman of Distinction
description: Jon Pareles reflects on the rawness and finesse of B.B. King, whose musical style made him approachable to audiences and propelled him to fame.

title: Homeland Beckons Immigrants as Retirement Nears
description: THEY came to America from all over the world for many reasons  to make money, to marry, to live in peace. But now, as they face their retirement years, many of these longtime immigrants want to go home.

title: Chinese Rights Lawyer Detained in 2014 Will Stand Trial
description: HONG KONG  One of Chinas best-known human rights lawyers, Pu Zhiqiang, will stand trial in Beijing on charges of inciting ethnic hatred and picking quarrels, prosecutors said on Friday. Their announcement came just over a year after the police detained Mr. Pu, making him one of the most prominent targets of the Chinese Communist Partys vigorous campaign against dissent.

title: Daily Report: Unearthing the Enigma of Bitcoins Birth
description: It is one of the great mysteries of the digital age.

title: ISIS Fighters Seize Government Headquarters in Ramadi, Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  In a major setback for the Iraqi governments efforts to defend its hold on Ramadi, a crucial regional capital, Islamic State militants conquered the citys government sector on Friday, raising their black flag over the main compound before setting fire to the building, local officials said.

title: Haruki Murakamis Strange Library and Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage
description: Whats so beguiling about Haruki Murakami? Its a question asked by admirers and detractors alike. As with few other authors, the charms of Murakamis books are difficult to pin down, so completely and gracefully does his work slip past the usual benchmarks of enjoyable literature. His plots are full of interesting incidents, but they build slowly, or not at all, or in a way thats completely off kilter, rather than following any real discernible arc. Regular readers of Murakami will find him reusing his favorite devices  cats, missing girls, obscure works of music  making them less startling and/or more enduring, depending on ones point of view. Structurally, his work appears to proceed by instinct rather than by strategy; his use of the third person in 1Q84, for instance, feels exactly like his vast, samey array of first-person narrators. Murakamis work brushes up against some grand themes but doesnt quite tackle them; his best novel, The WindUp Bird Chronicle, explores the horrors of World War II, but nobody would describe the book as making a major statement about war. As for his language  well, most of us New York Times readers are receiving Murakami in translation, but even so theres little to indicate were missing some grand linguistics in the original. His language is accessible, plain-spoken, even banal, perhaps purposefully so.

title: Future Crimes, by Marc Goodman
description: Theres a certain type of technology writer who presents himself as a modern-day Paul Revere, breathlessly warning us about all the dangers of our rapidly digitizing world.

title: Jo Nesbos Blood on Snow, Read by Patti Smith
description: Meet Olav Johansen, the antihero of Jo Nesbos latest thriller, Blood on Snow. Olav is a departure from Nesbos familiar Harry Hole, the dogged Norwegian police inspector who has selflessly tracked down killers through 10 international best sellers. Olav isnt a good guy; hes a bad guy. Sort of.

title: Toward an Oral Art
description: I love it when you read to me, Stephin Merritt croons in The Book of Love, that mainstay of moderately alternative bride-and-groom dances. Hes not alone. At some point, almost everyone likes to be read to  at weddings and funerals, where we expect to hear a little tasteful verse; at religious services, where we want to hear a few passages from Scripture; and at bedtime, where we (assuming we are preschoolers) would like to hear about Thing One and Thing Two. But until relatively recently, the car and the kitchen werent standard venues for listening to a story, poem or novel. That has changed with the well-documented rise of the audiobook, a format in which, as The New York Times has previously noted, publishers released nearly 36,000 titles in 2013, up from 6,200 in 2010, according to the Audio Publishers Association. The Wall Street Journal calls audiobooks a rare bright spot in the publishing industry, and pins the total market for them at well over a billion dollars.

title: The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty, by Amanda Filipacchi
description: This is how Im going to find the man of my dreams, declares Barb, the narrator of The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty, Amanda Filipacchis kindhearted meditation on looks, friendship, creativity and love in a superficial world. Barbs method is unconventional. Cursed with a gorgeousness so extreme that she is constantly being swarmed by irritating suitors, devastated by the suicide of a friend who said her beauty was painful for me to behold, she has taken to shrouding herself in a homemade fat suit accessorized with unappealing clothes, fake teeth, color-obscuring contact lenses and a frizzy gray wig. Her disguise makes her feel safe and weeds out shallow men. All men, really. She has not had sex in two years.

title: Kerry Expected to Bring Up Chinas Sea Claims During Visit
description: BEIJING  Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here on Saturday amid rising tensions over Chinas expansion of shoals and islets  in areas of the South China Sea claimed by at least three countries.

title: Cannes-Do: Rodarte Designers Always Wanted to Direct
description: Fashion is playing a bigger role in Cannes this festival season than merely red carpet decoration  though looking at the photos from the South of France over the last two days, it has been something of a banner display for a variety of brands.

title: Reverse Mortgages, Family Style
description: A mortgage company that specializes in setting up home-purchase loans funded by the buyers parents is now creating a vehicle through which siblings can pool their money to help their elders in a similar way.

title: 1915: Anti-German Riots Dwindle
description: LONDON  Now that the Governments proposals for the comprehensive internment of enemy aliens of military age are beginning to be enforced, the anti-German excitement in London due to the Lusitania horror has cooled down, and there was only one or two sporadic outbursts yesterday [May 14]. The Metropolitan police began their work of arresting enemy aliens yesterday, but wholesale arrests are being discouraged, as such a procedure would only embarrass the authorities.

title: Bus Goes Over Hillside in China, Killing at Least 35
description: HONG KONG  A tour bus traveling through countryside in northwest China toppled off a steep hillside in Shaanxi Province on Friday, killing at least 35 people, according to state-run news media. It appeared to be the deadliest traffic accident in nine months in China, where the government has struggled to curtail the danger on roads and highways.

title: Migrants at Sea, Up Close: Reporters Notebook
description: This is going to be like finding a black cat in a dark room.

title: Online Gambling Firm GVC Holdings Makes Bid for Rival Bwin.Party
description: LONDON  The British online gambling company GVC Holdings said on Friday that it had made a takeover proposal for its rival Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment.

title: Clippers History Offers Hope for Game 7
description: The Los Angeles Clippers were up by 19 points in the third quarter. They were up by 12 points with eight minutes to go. But down the stretch they missed 11 straight shots, were outscored, 25-2, and somehow managed to lose to the Houston Rockets in Game 6 of their series on Thursday night. It is hard to call it anything but a choke.

title: The Case for Black Doctors
description: DURHAM, N.C.  IN virtually every field of medicine, black patients as a group fare the worst. This was one of my first and most painful lessons as a medical student nearly 20 years ago.

title: Unlike His Brother, George W. Bush Stands by His Call to Invade Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  So Jeb Bush now says he would not have invaded Iraq if he knew then what he knows today. Neither would Chris Christie, Ted Cruz, John R. Kasich, Rand Paul, Rick Santorum or Marco Rubio. In fact, Mr. Rubio said, Not only would I not have been in favor of it, President Bush would not have been in favor of it.

title: 1940: Dutch Troops Lay Down Arms
description: Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands addresses her hopes for her country after German acts aggression, in a speech broadcast in Britain in 1940. (britishpathe.com)

title: Matthew Weiner On the End of Mad Men
description: In a special supplement from The Timess culture desk, Mr. Weiner, the creator of Mad Men, discusses the coming conclusion of the series with Dave Itzkoff, a reporter for The Times.

title: A Hint of Versailles on Central Park South
description: An elegant full-floor apartment that is one of just 12 residences above the Ritz-Carlton at 50 Central Park South  and the only one with parquet de Versailles floors made with hand-hammered German silver over wood  is poised to enter the market for $50 million.

title: House Passes Military Bill After Fight on Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  House lawmakers on Friday passed a roughly $612 billion annual military spending bill, concluding a week of fighting on issues ranging from congressionally mandated spending caps to immigration.

title: Republican Presidential Candidates Rally Around Flat Tax
description: No matter how many Republicans end up squeezing onto a campaign stage for the 2016 presidential primary debates, one thing is just about certain: Every one of them will vow to cut taxes. So, with as many as 19 contenders all repeating the same message, standing out from the crowd will be a challenge.

title: 50 Essential Summer Festivals
description: The weather warms up, the itch of wanderlust rises with the early sun. Heres a seasonal tasting menu of potential cultural pilgrimages.

title: American Pharoah Is a Fan Favorite, but Not Vice Versa
description: BALTIMORE  American Pharoah, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, appears to glide over the racetrack, a mark of a supremely gifted thoroughbred. His ability to find yet a higher gear in the homestretch leaves jockeys on opposing horses in awe. And his pedigree  a son of the Derby runner-up Pioneerof the Nile, who is also making a mark in the breeding shed  leaves little doubt that he is a formidable contender to win the Preakness Stakes here on Saturday.

title: Larry Kramers The American People, Volume 1
description: This book requires some preliminary steeling of the nerves. Its almost 800 solidly printed pages. The subject is vast and  you wince at the thought  its only Volume 1. Since this first installment has been 40 years on the way, the older readers chances of getting to the end arent guaranteed. Nor, you cant help calculating, are those of an almost 80-year-old author.

title: The Dig, a Novel by Cynan Jones
description: The first word we hear in Cynan Joness intense and remarkably compressed third novel, The Dig, is bitch. It is said of a dead badger sow on the road, as an unnamed man tries to cover up the evidence that she had been tethered during an illegal fight with dogs. Then he ground his foot down on the leg, Jones writes, and stamped over and over, smashing the thin precise line of the wire out of the raw flesh. The echo of that violent exclamation resonates throughout this powerful book. We move between two strands  one the unnamed badger baiter known as the big man and the other, Daniel, a Welsh farmer grieving for his recently dead wife and trying to keep her memory alive as well as their lambs. Thus the novel becomes a kind of diptych about violence, loss and the different ways one can be trapped.

title: After the Tall Timber Collects Renata Adlers Nonfiction
description: In the first essay in this new collection of nonfiction, Renata Adler writes about the cultural role of her generation. Adler was born in 1938, coming of age after the heroism of World War II and before the antics of baby boomers. In college, under Eisenhower, we were known for nothing, or for our apathy, she wrote in 1969. We are unnoticed even as we spread clear across what people call, without taking account of us, the generation gap. Neither here nor there, she went on to explain, we cut across, and in this function her generation found its purpose: At a moment of polarization, and other clichs that drain the language of meaning, the continuity of the American story seems to rest just now in us.

title: Odysseus Abroad, by Amit Chaudhuri
description: The title of Amit Chaudhuris sixth novel may use the Greek form of the ancient heros name, but the predecessor hes got in mind for this story of two Bengalis wandering around London isnt so much the Odyssey as it is Ulysses. Still, both Homer and Joyce begin the same way: with a young and callow man setting out in search of an absent father. Call him Telemachus, call him Stephen Dedalus. Or call him Ananda Sen, who in 1985 is studying English literature in Britains capital and making a bad thing of it. He wants to be a poet, he likes Ted Hughes and Philip Larkin, and he has begun to learn that Shakespeares language isnt so much universal as rooted in English particulars. In a country with Indias weather, Shall I compare thee to a summers day sounds like an insult; in England, its a compliment.

title: The Enlightenment of Nina Findlay, by Andrea Gillies
description: Nina Findlay, an inquisitive book editor, and Luca Romano, a passionate wine distributor, are a universe of two. They confide only in each other. Constantly, they touch, they glance, they email and call. They clasp hands as if no one else exists. What Nina and Luca have joined together since childhood no one can put asunder, and the fact that theyre married to other people would be, to them, incidental were Ninas husband not Lucas elder brother, Paolo.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Here are a few of the things on the web that caught our eye this week.

title: Indian Premier Discusses Talks in China
description: Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, spoke to reporters in Beijing on Friday after meeting with Premier Li Keqiang of China. Mr. Modi said progress had been made on some issues.

title: Don Rickles Recalls His CPO Sharkey Days
description: Hey, hockey puck: You may know Don Rickles best as that venerated stand-up comic with the tongue of a tiger and the heart of a pussycat, and a career of some 60 years that includes roles in films like Casino and the Toy Story series.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Coffee, Work Breaks and a Vitamin for Skin Cancer
description: Take the Quiz

title: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 3: Go Ahead, Lick the Cart
description: Whats this? A Random Penguin! Let it brighten your day, or read more about the Penguins here.

title: Gotham Chamber Opera Names Edward Barnes Executive Director
description: Gotham Chamber Opera, known for thoughtful productions in unexpected spaces, announced Friday that its next executive director would be someone with ties to both music and theater: Edward Barnes, the producing director of the Collegiate Chorale.

title: A New Dance by Rebecca Patek at Chocolate Factory
description: The title of Rebecca Pateks new performance piece is a mouthful: The Future Was Looking Better in the Past: My Family Herstory: or from religious persecution to american greed to murderous infamy to denial, repression and the slow dissolution into moral confusion, financial ruin and karmic retribution. In the work, Ms. Patek, a choreographer and performance artist who often confronts disturbing subject matter  her last show involved rape  explores facets of violence, both buried within herself and out in the world. In her premiere, presented by the Chocolate Factory and Abrons Arts Center, she finds inspiration in the vicious 1924 murder of Bobby Franks by Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb. Performed by John Hoobyar, Sam Roeck and Chris Tyler, the work blends material from the murder trial, Pateks family history and her own imagination: Who were Leopold and Loeb? What were their psychological complexities? What leads to acts of horror? For Ms. Patek, armed with a wry, twisted sense of humor, the answers float somewhere in the subconscious.

title: TV on the Radio Plays Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: They dont make bands like TV on the Radio anymore  thats a clich, and true, and was equally true in the mid-2000s, when the group burst out of Williamsburg with a howl and a shriek and more clatter than all its neighborhood peers combined. The idea of this group as a going concern is looking increasingly slim  last year it released Seeds, its fifth studio album, though the members have been pursuing individual projects.

title: Isabella Rossellini on the Birds and the Bees
description: Somewhere in the midst of conceptualizing her latest project, Isabella Rossellini imagined herself reciting poetry like the Beats, surrounded by a forest of penises. Soon, she was cavorting onstage with an assortment of phalluses in different shapes and sizes. It wasnt what you might think.

title: James Levine Conducts Symphonie Fantastique at Carnegie Hall
description: Berlioz tells it like it is. You take a trip, you wind up screaming at your own funeral, Leonard Bernstein said about Berliozs colorfully macabre Symphonie Fantastique, a musical hallucinogenic that evokes an opium-using, heartbroken artist. There is also plenty of emotional tumult in Brahmss Piano Concerto No. 1, which James Levine will conduct on the same program on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. The pianist Yefim Bronfman  a consummate Brahms performer who combines burly firepower and elegance  will no doubt bring out the wild side of this fiery work with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra as superb partners. (3 p.m. on Sunday, Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

title: Blue Velvet at IFC Center
description: Its a shame David Lynch declined to direct Twin Peaks, if and when Showtime resurrects that landmark TV series he created with Mark Frost. More so considering that 2015 represents the 25th anniversary of the shows introduction. But at least we have IFC Centers Memorial Day weekend tribute to the director: midnight screenings Friday, Saturday and Sunday of his 1986 breakthrough, Blue Velvet.

title: Carlos Lyra, a Pioneer of Bossa Nova, Reintroduces Himself
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Nearly 60 years has passed since the bossa nova sprang out of this city. For most of the world, that cool, minimalist sound, with its insinuating pulse, still defines Brazil. Inside the country, though, the music is a respected but quaint form of nostalgia. Tourists who seek it out tend to leave disappointed.

title: Tyondai Braxton Talks About Punk, Percussion and Dad
description: Before Tyondai Braxton, the experimental musician and composer, could complete his new album, HIVE1, he had to find himself in a machine. The project, which started as an installation and performance at the Guggenheim in 2013 before making its way to the Sydney Opera House, is built around a warped backbone of uneven percussion  thwacking woodblocks, bursts of pitter-pattering snares  but finds its voice, sans vocals, in the robotic moans and whirrs of a modular synthesizer.

title: The Good, Bad and Ugly Guide to Donating Clothing
description: Goodwill will take all clothing donations, even if the company rejects them for resale and sends them to be recycled.

title: Tax-Deductible Clothing Donations Are Great, Except Your Used Socks
description: It is the season of spring cleaning, and if you paid more in taxes than you would have liked last month, you may well be looking to donate as much of your underused clothing as possible.

title: Columbia Acquires Archives of Arthur Mitchell, Dance Pioneer
description: When Arthur Mitchell was contemplating where his archives should go, he thought about where he grew up and later, with Karel Shook, formed the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Simple Ricotta Tart
description: Make Melissa Clarks creamy tart the anchor for whatever seasonal fruit you have on hand.
