title: This Ricotta Tart Is a Canvas for Any Summer Fruit
description: Sometimes the trickiest thing about serving ripe summer fruit for dessert is resisting the urge to do too much to it.

title: Housebreaking, by Dan Pope
description: What so captivates us about the American suburbs? In fiction as in life, were perennially beguiled by their careful advertisement of order and serenity  and by the ugly incongruity of their discontented residents. Dan Popes second novel, Housebreaking, embraces this clash: All the white houses and green lawns, one character muses, the childrens toys lying unattended in driveways. Pretty in a sculpted sort of way, but mildly sad. It was an illusion, one that promised happiness indefinitely. But the whole thing could collapse at any moment.

title: The Subprimes, by Karl Taro Greenfeld
description: Imagine a world in which every liberal anxiety has been realized: a world where business interests have annihilated the greater good, where the environment is in irreversible decline, where the police have been privatized and renewable energy is banned. In this world, honest, hardworking Americans have lost their homes to foreclosure, and you cant cross state lines without a credit score of 650; the have-nots have been reduced to furtive squatting in abandoned real estate developments, where they fear ejection by teams of brutal thugs in the employ of big oil.

title: One Nation Under God, by Kevin M. Kruse
description: Did you ever wonder how In God We Trust came to be quoted on every American coin and dollar bill? Or why the Pledge of Allegiance to the most revered symbol of the nation includes an explicit declaration of confidence in the Almighty? Or why the president and members of Congress host a National Prayer Breakfast the first Thursday of each February?

title: Walter Mosleys And Sometimes I Wonder About You, and More
description: Walter Mosley breaks every rule in the private-detective-story stylebook in his new mystery featuring Leonid McGill, AND SOMETIMES I WONDER ABOUT YOU (Doubleday, $26.95). His New York sleuths disorderly domestic affairs keep threatening to overwhelm the crime elements, and a vital piece of the plot isnt introduced until midway through the book. And when Mosley does wrap things up, he makes no effort to connect any of the multiple subplots.

title: Inside the List
description: Dead in the Water: Deal, Bill Kreutzmanns memoir of his decades playing drums for the Grateful Dead, is new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No.10. The book (written with Benjy Eisen) opens with an anecdote from the late 1980s, when the band finally broke through to mainstream success: Its only Top 40 hit, Touch of Grey, reached No.9 on the Billboard chart; the video was in constant rotation on MTV; and the band sold out a five-night run at Madison Square Garden. The attention, Kreutzmann acknowledges, was a little overwhelming. We decided to celebrate by getting as far away from it all as possible, he writes, explaining how he and Jerry Garcia, the singer and lead guitarist, ended up scuba diving in Hawaii one day with their roadie Steve Parish. It was as psychedelic and far-out as anything we had seen during the Acid Tests, or at Woodstock, or during our strange days wandering around San Francisco during the Summer of Love. And yet, we were sober for this one. After years of persistent pot smoking, psychedelic excesses, alcohol benders, cocaine binges and heroin abuse, scuba diving was going to be our new drug. It was, eventually  Kreutzmann and Garcia dived together many times over the years, as the rest of the book makes clear. But that first trip didnt take them as far from fame as they had hoped: Underwater, a scuba instructor swam up to Garcia with a waterproof notepad and asked for his autograph. Twenty feet below the surface! Kreutzmann writes. I nearly spat out my regulator from laughing so hard.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Mounting Evidence of Advantages for Children of Working Mothers
description: Nearly three-quarters of American mothers with children at home are employed. That fact doesnt necessarily make it any easier for mothers to drop a toddler at day care or miss school plays. The mommy wars might seem like a relic of the 1990s, but 41 percent of adults say the increase in working mothers is bad for society, while just 22 percent say it is good, according to the Pew Research Center.

title: Broken Windows and American Oligarchy
description: Some years ago I gave a talk to a group of businesspeople  I dont remember the occasion  and afterward, during the drink and mingle part of the event, had a conversation about executive pay. Quite a few of the businesspeople themselves thought that pay had grown excessive, but what has remained with me was the explanation one guy offered, more or less seriously: its all the fault of Monday Night Football.

title: Carl Icahn Invests $100 Million in Lyft
description: For years, Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, has been the loudest public voice on how ride-hailing start-ups will upend the transportation industry.

title: Free Range vs. Helicopter Parenting: Get the Facts
description: 1. What are Free Range and Helicopter Parenting?

title: A New Resource for Biking Routes
description: Megan Rameys first bike-related vacation with her husband and their daughter, now 5, helped inspire her to start Bikabout, an online travel resource for everything bicycling, with information on bike-friendly lodging, traveling with bikes, renting them and where to ride them around town, along with tips on culture, etiquette and safety.

title: Paperback Row
description: IN THE LIGHT OF WHAT WE KNOW, by Zia Haider Rahman. (Picador, $17.) On a September morning in 2008, Zafar, a Bangladeshi mathematician from humble beginnings, shows up at the London home of an old friend, a rogue Pakistani-American banker. Zafar is there to make an unsettling confession, and as his story unfolds, Rahmans extraordinary novel of ideas roams from London and New York to Islamabad and Kabul as it explores questions of love, belonging, science and war.

title: Manhattan School of Music to Offer Musical Theater Degree
description: Music conservatories have a reputation for being high-minded purveyors of elite art. Countering this rap, the Manhattan School of Music announced that in fall 2016 it would begin to offer a degree program in musical theater.

title: Editors Choice
description: A GOD IN RUINS, by Kate Atkinson. (Little, Brown, $28.) This companion volume to Atkinsons Life After Life is a sprawling, ambitious saga about a family in postwar Britain and a love letter to the men and boys who achieved the victory.

title: Voices in the Night, by Steven Millhauser
description: I never may believe/These antique fables, nor these fairy toys, Theseus declares in A Midsummer Nights Dream, dismissing the poet who seeks to make something out of an airy nothing. The sorcery Theseus deplores is Steven Millhausers signature strength, and indeed, at the start of a Millhauser story, there is often a spirit of airiness and wonder as we enter a phantom-haunted town or the Garden of Seven Noble Pleasures. Yet the stories in Millhausers spellbinding collection Voices in the Night are anchored by dark human yearnings  for perfection, or excitement, or some ungraspable form of fulfillment. These yearnings have a combustible quality, threatening to consume the towns and minds where a pervasive sense of unease provides the tinder.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Future of Work
description: This week, Barbara Ehrenreich discusses Rise of the Robots and Shadow Work; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Andrew Solomon talks about Oliver Sackss new memoir, On the Move; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Future of Work
description: This week, Barbara Ehrenreich and Andrew Solomon.

title: Amar Ramasars Unlikely Path to Becoming a Prince for City Ballet
description: Amar Ramasar was 11 when he first saw ballet. It was a video of the New York City Ballet dancers Heather Watts and Mel Tomlinson, in Balanchines radical 1957 ballet Agon, the dancers clad in minimal leotards and tights, performing spiky, extraordinary movements to Stravinskys astringent score. Mr. Ramasar, an outgoing, talkative boy from the Bronx, knew right away what he thought. Thats the ballet I want to dance, and thats the company Im going to get into, he said.

title: Susanna Malkkis Wide Appeal on Both Sides of the Atlantic
description: A few months ago, during the Los Angeles Philharmonics performance of Unsuk Chins 2007 opera Alice in Wonderland, Susanna Malkki did something you hope a conductor never does while the music is still going: She left the podium.

title: Hulu Picks Up The Mindy Project
description: Fox canceled The Mindy Project last week but Hulu is here to save the day.

title: De Blasio Says New York Will Investigate Nail Industry Practices
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday that his administration would take steps to address what he called deplorable conditions that workers in the nail salon industry confront, including several investigations by New York City agencies and a day of action next week to inform manicurists of their rights.

title: If Youre Older and You Know It, Shake Your Arms
description: I was watching Jane Fonda in the new Netflix show Grace and Frankie, in which she plays a woman who has just been dumped by her husband, and I was amazed to see Jane, who is 77, with the universally dreaded Inner Upper Arm Wiggle Waggle.

title: The Double-Edged Sword of Online Anonymity
description: Reddit, a site whose huge range of sub-communities has long included both the fascinating and the downright repellent, announced Thursday that it would implement an anti-harassment policy.

title: Marisa Tomeis Perfect Proportions
description: The Star: Marisa Tomei

title: Rick Perry Marks June 4 on Calendar for Special Announcement
description: The next wave of potential Republican presidential candidates is coming ashore.

title: Our Man in Tehran Answers Your Questions About Iran
description: Thomas Erdbrink, the Tehran bureau chief for The New York Times, responds to readers questions about Iran and his video series, Our Man in Tehran. Read more below and submit your questions for Mr. Erdbrink.

title: Entourage Movie to Land in a Transformed, Buttoned-Up Hollywood
description: BURBANK, Calif.  The ride aint over, declares a poster for Entourage, the coming movie version of the hit HBO series.

title: Friday Night Music: DakhaBrakha
description: I know, its early afternoon in NYC, but Im in Oxford and about to go off for drinks.

title: Woody Allen on Philosophy, Film and Regrets Over His Amazon Deal
description: CANNES, France  The sun was shining, his latest film, Irrational Man, had been well received at its press premiere here, and Woody Allen was in a cheerful mood  musing on death, meaninglessness, Kants categorical imperative and how he fears that the series he is developing for Amazon promises to be a cosmic embarrassment.

title: A Much-Needed Rule on Forced Labor
description: Like all controversial legislation, the trade bills making their way through the Senate are filled with provisions that can be hard to keep track of. One important measure that deserves more attention than it has gotten is a proposal to close a loophole that has for decades allowed businesses to import goods made with forced, prison, indentured and other exploitative labor.

title: Bobs Burgers, After Five Seasons, Remains a Reliable Meal
description: Everybody has a go-to restaurant. Its probably not the best one around or the trendiest, but its the place you can count on to give you a decent meal cordially served.

title: Rather Than Fight or Flee, Take Responsibility
description: I was in a large meeting at my company, sharing an idea that had occurred to me, when one of my younger colleagues raised her hand and jumped in. Im feeling like were getting off track, she said with some impatience. We have an agenda, and I think we ought to stick to it.

title: Works in Progress
description: A very small sampling of the female artists now in their 70s, 80s and 90s we should have known about decades ago.

title: Caught in Nepals Earthquakes
description: While photographing the aftermath of Aprils devastating earthquake in Nepal, Daniel Berehulak found himself caught in yet another temblor. You just react, he said. You go. You run. And then you take pictures.

title: Brittney Griner and Glory Johnson Suspended 7 Games in Domestic Violence Case
description: Brittney Griner and her wife, Glory Johnson, were each suspended for seven games by the W.N.B.A. on Friday over a domestic violence incident between the two in April.

title: Dont Be So Sure the Economy Will Return to Normal
description: It is hard to avoid the feeling that our current economic problems are more than just a cyclical downturn. We know that the economy has gone through some bad times. But what exactly are we experiencing?

title: First Draft Focus: Mitt Romney and Evander Holyfield Ready to Rumble
description: Romney vs. Holyfield: Im Staying Far Away From His Ears

title: Love, Redeployed
description: A soldier returns from his second tour of duty. Now he and his wife must find their way back to each other.

title: Home From Afghanistan, and Learning to Be a Couple Again
description: On the day before Thanksgiving, First Lt. Rafael Ramirez, 37, just back from his second deployment to Afghanistan, walked past the welcome-home balloons and stepped into his Bronx apartment.

title: September 11 Museum Drew 2.7 Million Visitors in First Year
description: The National September 11 Memorial Museum marked its first year of operations on Friday, saying that it hosted about 2.7 million visitors during that period and slightly exceeded attendance projections.

title: Speaking Out for Shareholders in Corporate Bankruptcies
description: By virtue of the absolute priority rule  which I will concede, I have recently argued is poorly named and oversold  shareholders are at the bottom of the heap in a corporate bankruptcy. They get paid only when everyone else has been paid.

title: Republicans Had Reservations on George Stephanopoulos Before Revelation
description: The Republican National Committee told ABC News that it would not agree to have George Stephanopoulos moderate a debate well before news broke of the anchors donations to the Clinton Foundation.

title: To Iowa G.O.P., Jeb Bush Appears to Be Ignoring the Family Playbook
description: DES MOINES  When Jeb Bushs lone staff member in Iowa, Annie Kelly, recently telephoned Sherill Whisenand, a chairwoman of the Polk County Republican Party, she got an earful.

title: Danny Burstein and Rebecca Luker in Morningside Heights
description: When they began looking for an apartment to buy just before their wedding nearly 15 years ago, the Broadway performers Danny Burstein and Rebecca Luker could not have been more clear with their broker: They werent interested in seeing anything past 96th Street, and that was that. What with both of them tethered to the theater district, they wanted a short, easy commute to 42nd Street. So nothing doing north of 96th. No deviating from the script.

title: New Cannes President Sees Role for Festival in a Streaming World
Bond Turmoil Signals a New Era of Return-Free Risk
description: United States and German government bonds are gyrating as they rarely do. Yields are shooting higher for no apparent reason, and sometimes falling back within hours for equally unclear motives. Such turbulence in the biggest and most liquid bond markets is ushering in a new era. The traditional concept of risk-free returns has been turned on its head.

title: Review: Yve Laris Cohens Fine Dissects the Nature of Performance Spaces
description: With a background in classical ballet and a compulsion to reframe the tools of the theater, Yve Laris Cohen has carved out an unusual place as a choreographer. He plays with the materials that make a dance possible  the floors, the walls and, now, the curtains. Part of his practice involves the installation and dismantling of objects. Over the course of three nights of performances at Danspace Project recently, it was a portable stage used by New York City Ballet; at the Whitney Museum of American Art last spring, it was a piece of a wall.

title: Fall 2015 TV Schedule
description: Here is a look at what shows will be where come mid-September.

title: Migrants in Rome Try to Recover After Ponte Mammolo Camp Is Destroyed
description: ROME  The bulldozers pulled up after some of the residents had already left for work. They lumbered through the encampment, methodically mowing down corrugated tin walls, laminated sheet roofs and concrete blocks.

title: Kristen Schaal on Dadbods, Rihanna for Dior and Mo Money, Mo Leggings
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: George Stephanopoulos and the Line Between News and Entertainment
description: First Brian Williams and now George Stephanopoulos. Credibility, or in this case, incredibility, is the Dutch elm disease of network anchors  once it spreads, its ferociously damaging and hard to stop.

title: Helicopter Wreckage Found, Marines Say
description: Lt. Gen. John Wissler, speaking from Kathmandu, Nepal, on Friday, confirmed that the wreckage of a United States helicopter missing since Tuesday had been found.

title: From Senate Sideline, Elizabeth Warren Is Face of Attack on Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat whose vituperations against Wall Street have helped push her party to the left, has no official role opposing President Obamas trade agenda.

title: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Given Death Penalty in Boston Marathon Bombing
description: BOSTON  Two years after bombs in two backpacks transformed the Boston Marathon from a sunny rite of spring to a smoky battlefield with bodies dismembered, a federal jury on Friday condemned Dzhokhar Tsarnaev to death for his role in the 2013 attack.

title: At NADA, a Fresh Crop of Young Talent
description: With all the commotion of Frieze New York playing out uptown on Randalls Island, it might be easy to overlook the action unfolding at the decidedly downtown New Art Dealers Alliance (NADA) fair. Now in its fifth year, the New York arm of NADA (the other fair takes place in Miami) once again returns to Pier 36, exhibiting 100 galleries in a cavernous warehouse space bordered by the Lower East Side and the East River. Billed as a nonprofit arts organization with the aim of promoting new and emerging artists, NADA has gained a reputation as a go-to destination for art world insiders and collectors looking to take the pulse of the next generation of artists.

title: Readers Respond: On Wow, Jeb Bush is Awful
description: Gail Collinss barbed take on Jeb Bush gave way to hundreds more, and a few defenses, as readers responded to the former Florida governors unpolished approach to his not-quite campaign for president.

title: Bin Laden Aide Sentenced to Life in Prison in 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombings
description: A Saudi who was one of Osama bin Ladens earliest and most trusted aides was sentenced to life in prison on Friday after being convicted of taking part in a global conspiracy to kill Americans, which included the deadly bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa.

title: Chelseas Risqu Businesses
description: Along with its handsome brownstones and quiet side streets, Manhattans Chelsea neighborhood is known for liberal politics, social activism and a large gay professional class that is accepting of all sorts of lifestyles.

title: Drama League Names An American in Paris Best Musical
description: The Drama League, a national organization of theatergoers, has chosen An American in Paris for its top musical honor this year.

title: Amy Schumer and Judd Apatow Plan a Stand-Up Tour for Trainwreck
description: Before the highly anticipated film Trainwreck is released in July, several of the comics from the movie, including its star, Amy Schumer, who wrote the script, and Judd Apatow, its director, will be headlining a seven-city, eight-night tour, with the shows proceeds going to charity.

title: Bill Simmons Will Get Paycheck but No Role at ESPN Through September
description: The official end of the Bill Simmons era at ESPN came Friday: He will be paid through the end of September, when his contract expires, but he will no longer run the Grantland website or do any other work for the company.

title: Running on Rent, and Winning
description: If you have ever sent a 25-year-old babysitter home late at night from one of Brooklyns long-established breeding tracts, you have probably paid for a cab to Crown Heights, thinking to yourself, as you hand over the cash, that at the same age you would have been as likely to land there as you would have in a Tasmanian circus.

title: The Unofficial Lifeguard of East Rockaway Inlet
description: Floyd Smith, 71, Far Rockaways self-appointed lifeguard in a wheelchair, rolled along the East Rockaway Inlet beachfront boardwalk looking out at the ocean.

title: Movie Review: Pitch Perfect 2
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Pitch Perfect 2.

title: A Bar That Takes Soccer and Its Fans Seriously
description: The Factory is among the citys premier houses of soccer worship.

title: Stateside, Kicking and Screaming at the Football Factory
description: Roger Smith, a bleary soccer fan, was still waking up as he sipped his Guinness, squinting through the darkness at the television. Others in the basement bar drank stronger stuff, washing down heavy breakfast sandwiches. The grotto reverberated like a tuning fork when a ball whistled into the net, jolting Mr. Smith alert, before the room returned to its reverent silence.

title: Movie Review: Mad Max: Fury Road
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Mad Max: Fury Road.

title: 10 Striking Moments From the Boston Marathon Bombing Trial
description: BOSTON  After hearing a cascade of testimony, jurors in the Boston Marathon bombing trial reached a final decision on Friday: They sentenced Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 21, the convicted bomber, to death.

title: Touring New York, With Mad Men in Mind
description: Mad Men ends its run on Sunday night, and a toast is definitely in order. Martinis and Manhattans are among the cocktails made for the occasion, New York City the optimal locale.

title: Mens College Basketball Looks to a 30-Second Shot Clock to Speed Game
description: After another season of low scoring and slow play, N.C.A.A. rule makers on Friday proposed that mens basketball games switch from a 35-second clock to 30 seconds, limit timeouts and be officiated to encourage less physical play.

title: How Danielle Chang, Founder of LuckyRice, Spends Her Sundays
description: Danielle Chang is the founder of LuckyRice, which produces culinary events that celebrate Asian culture. Her next project will be a dinner in honor of Buddhas birthday at the James Beard House on Tuesday. Other credits include the introduction of Bombay Sapphire East gin in 2011; a new cooking and lifestyle show called Lucky Chow that will have its premiere on PBS this summer; and a cookbook, to be published in early 2016. Ms. Chang, 43, lives in a loft on Mercer Street in Manhattan with her husband, Todd Leong, 45, a hospitality consultant, and their daughters, Colette Leong, 10, and Clarissa Leong, 9.

title: The Republican Brady Bunch
description: The slate of candidates in the Republican presidential nominating campaign is starting to feel like the Bizarro version of a Brady Bunch reunion  overcrowded, over-familiar and lacking any evident reason to exist.

title: Review: Ill See You In My Dreams
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Ill See You In My Dreams.

title: Hotels Are Helping Children Sleep Tight
description: While hotels have long focused on giving adults a good nights sleep, a few are creatively enabling their youngest guests to tuck in peacefully.

title: Joey Alexander, the Young Jazz Sensation
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss Joey Alexanders debut album.

title: Nurse Reflects on Tour Treating Ebola Patients in Sierra Leone
description: Returning from the Ebola zone, Lindsey Hallen worried that she would be swallowed by the petty concerns of her life as a nurse in New York City.

title: Alison Chi Shares Her Favorite New York Design and Food Haunts
description: From a very young age, Alison Chi knew what refined design looked like. Her mother, Tammy Chou, and her father, Tony Chi, the architect and designer behind the New York-based Tony Chi & Associates  which is responsible for the interiors of places like the Andaz 5th Avenue, Asiate at the Mandarin Oriental New York and the Bar Les Nations at the Intercontinental Geneva  were in the business before the younger Chi, who is now 27 and calls New Yorks Greenwich Village home, was born. Her parents would buy beautiful pieces, like rattan placemats from Indonesia, during their travels abroad and use them at their former home in Westchester County.

title: Books on Joseph Mitchell, the New Yorker Writer, and the 1963-64 Broadway Season
description: In 1942, Joseph Mitchell published his famous profile in The New Yorker of a homeless man named Joe Gould, who was said to be writing a magnum opus known as An Oral History of the Contemporary World.

title: Petition Seeks Better Treatment of Monkeys
description: Animal welfare activists have scored several victories in recent years in their efforts to mandate better treatment of chimpanzees. Now they are asking a federal agency to make similar changes to the housing and treatment of monkeys.

title: Popcast: Joey Alexander Makes His Debut
description: Joey Alexander is an extraordinarily gifted jazz pianist; he is Balinese-born, Indonesia-raised and currently living in New Jersey. His first album, My Favorite Things, came out this week from Motema, and quickly became the No. 1 jazz record on iTunes. He is 11.

title: The Yellow Ladys Slipper, Afoot in Central Parks Ramble
description: In the heart of Central Park, midway between the riches of the American Museum of Natural History and the masterpieces of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, grows an ethereal masterwork of nature. Given the incredible biology of the yellow ladys slipper and its evocative beauty, no plant could be more appropriately situated. For many naturalists, this orchid is the queen of spring blooms. Its rarity is legendary, and its flower, a magnum opus of evolution, is a beguiling trap designed to force insect pollinators into its service. The elaborate flower is brilliant yellow, with spiraling sepals and a yellow slipper that bends more than bees to do its bidding. I am among the humans who search for the plant annually, hovering around its fragrant beauty like pollinating bumblebees.

title: Obama vs. Warren on Free-Trade Pact
description: In the last month, President Obama has held a long-distance debate with Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts over his trade accord, the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

title: How to Get People to Pitch In
description: LAST month Jerry Brown, the Democratic governor of California, issued the drought-racked states first-ever mandatory water reductions. As Californians, we must pull together and save water in every way possible, he said.

title: Detroits Recovery, and My Dads, Too
description: I WAS 7 or 8. My parents had divorced. My father had moved out. Perhaps in an attempt to solidify his place in our young lives in the wake of these changes, my father took my sister and me to Detroit.

title: Review: Don Quixote Ballet Unites Lovers, Dryads and Toreadors
description: Don Quixote, viewing the world through the lens of his fantasies, mistakes a windmill for a giant and has visions of what isnt actually there. But during the vision scene of Don Quixote, which Gelsey Kirkland Ballet presented at the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University on Thursday, the ranks of classically trained dancers that crowded onto the stage were real. Mounting a full-length 19th-century story ballet with a cast of 100 might have seemed a quixotic goal for a troupe only two years old, but this one already has a Nutcracker and a Sleeping Beauty under its belt. Don Quixote is less a leap than a sensible next step.

title: Review: Lost Dog Ensemble Delves Into John Luther Adams
description: Type Brooklyn-based composer into Google, and some 12,000 results pop up; a search for Queens-based composer yields around 300. But while living in Brooklyn has become a rite of passage for many artists, there is also a thriving arts scene in eclectic (and mostly affordable) Queens, often said to be the most diverse urban area in the world.

title: Sheen Center Cancels Event Featuring Neil LaBute Play About Mohammed
description: A downtown Manhattan performance center has canceled an event featuring a new play by Neil LaBute with a title making reference to Mohammed, on the grounds that the play is offensive to Muslims.

title: Frieze New Yorks Big Red Riding Hoods
description: After combing through thousands of works of art culled from multiple time zones on view at Frieze New York this weekend, you might ask yourself, where does the May 2015 contemporary art zeitgeist converge? The answer to this question is irreducibly clear: on marsala-colored cloaks! Is it a Pantone conspiracy that the design authoritys official color of the year has been tracked not once but three times on Randalls Island  in cape form? At the booth of the Bogot gallery Instituto de visin, a scroll of wine-colored fabric terminating in a poncho is emblazoned with the words PIA FOR SALE, advertising a performative action by the Mexican artist Pia Camil. Meanwhile, a not dissimilar garment has been committed to canvas by the Brazilian artist Edoardo Berliner at the booth held by the So Paulo gallery Casa Tringulo. Titled Sapatos (Shoes), the headless, matadoresque draping calls attention to the glossy black footwear beneath it. Perhaps the most striking of maroon gowns on display, however, is the chromed sculpture at Parisian dealer Jocelyn Wolffs stand. As part of an elegant solo presentation by the French artist Guillame Leblon, this merlot mantle without a wearer is an homage to Giacometti that triggers a theme consistent throughout Leblons work, the spectral absence of the body. Enjoy these fine reds!

title: Back in (Show) Business
description: Paige Felgner knew going in she might not see herself on the big screen. But that didnt dim the 11-year-olds enthusiasm as she waited for showtime at the Picture House Regional Film Center, in Pelham, on Earth Day.

title: Save New Yorks Four Seasons
description: MONTREAL  THE Seagram Building is one of the architectural masterpieces of the 20th century, and arguably the most significant modern building in New York City. At its center is the Four Seasons, perhaps Americas most famous restaurant and an architectural gem itself, having won landmark protection in 1989.

title: Luxembourg Premier Is First E.U. Leader to Marry Same-Sex Partner
description: PARIS  The prime minister of Luxembourg on Friday wed his partner of several years in the first same-sex marriage of a European Union leader.

title: FKA twigs Lives Large, in Congregata and Beyond
description: FKA twigs, the experimental R&B singer, sat at a novelty typewriter in the lobby of a faux-vintage Manhattan hotel, only to find that the machine actually worked. Hunting and pecking, she clacked out a message: Hello world.

title: Review: Wayne Shorter Goes Solo With the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra
description: When the saxophonist Wayne Shorter has come through town over the past 15 years or so, he has generally been with his quartet, a group that plays soul-drilling, gonzo-Zen interventions on about 50 years worth of his music. There is much open space in these performances, much insight and mystery, a settling into a zone between direction and indirection. Apart from Mr. Shorters stature as a small-group composer in jazz  the best, pretty much  the alert and unscripted way the quartet operates has for many listeners represented a current ideal for how jazz works and what it can contain: immediacy, collectivity, discipline, freedom.

title: Obama Pays Tribute to Fallen Officers and Calls for Healing of Rifts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday saluted fallen officers as heroes and called for renewed efforts to support law enforcement, emphasizing the perils and challenges faced by the police as national attention is focused on the tensions between them and many African-American communities.

title: Debating the Complications Involved in Saving Preemies
description: Should doctors make more effort to save the very youngest preemies, even if they are at high risk for serious impairments?

title: They Built a Commune but No One Came
description: Two men, dreaming of utopia, end up with a museum.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Google to Test Bubble-Shaped Self-Driving Cars in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The world is one step closer to the day when people can, in good conscience, drive to work while sipping coffee, texting with a friend and working on a laptop computer.

title: Pressure Builds for Swift U.S. Action Against Spreading Salamander Threat
description: There are signs of hope for American salamanders in the face of a potential biological catastrophe  a fungus that could be carried here through the global trade in exotic pets. Federal wildlife officials have signaled a crackdown may be coming on imports of amphibians.

title: Freezing Fish, Killing Parasites?
description: Q. Does deep-freezing fish kill harmful parasites?

title: Penn States College of Engineering Hit by Cyberattack
description: Hackers from China infiltrated the computer systems of Pennsylvania State Universitys College of Engineering, gaining usernames and passwords in what investigators described as a sophisticated cyberattack that lasted more than two years.

title: The Kips Bay Show House: Grand Gesture as a Rite of Spring
description: Maximalism is thriving at the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, a spring rite at which designers prove their mettle with pelmets, marquetry, French Art Deco and many other special effects.

title: Ad Promoting Anti-Clinton Book Reaches Unlikely Audience
description: The writers at The Nation, one of the foremost liberal media outlets in the country and a driving force behind Bill de Blasios rise in the 2013 mayoral primary in New York City, have been open about their desire to see a challenge from the left to Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2016.

title: Kurdish Syrians, Beyond the Border Crossing
description: Esa Ylijaasko has spent almost two years capturing the life of Kurdish refugees in enclaves of Istanbul.

title: Charged With Graft in China, Some Fugitives Are Finding Luxury in U.S.
description: Even before his name appeared on the most wanted list, holes had emerged in the immigrant success story of Wei Chen.

title: Ask a Greenmarket Guru
description: As summer approaches, the selection at the farmers market turns from root vegetables to the fresh bounty of the regions farms and orchards. But how should you shop your local market, and what new produce can you expect to find? What do you do with tomatillos or green garlic?

title: True Colors
description: OFTEN THE THINGS that seem to us the most beautiful and rare are those that remain true over time, that endure. This doesnt mean that they dont change or evolve, just that they feel authentic and honest. Many of us seek this quality in our travels: places that are unspoiled and yet very much themselves.

title: Mad Men and the 1960s as Wild Republican Times
description: Eight years ago  before the divorces, remarriages, suicides, mangled feet, mergers, acquisitions, restructurings, bastard children and rough sex that have characterized AMCs Mad Men  the Sterling Cooper advertising agency was angling for Richard Nixons business.

title: Book Review Podcast: Welcome to Your Obsolescence
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Barbara Ehrenreich reviews Rise of the Robots, which explores how technology threatens even the nimblest and most expensively educated, and Shadow Work, which shines light on the increase of unpaid work. Ms. Ehrenreich writes:

title: A Diplomatic Victory, and Affirmation, for Putin
description: MOSCOW  For Russia, victory came three days after Victory Day, in the form of Secretary of State John Kerrys visit this week to the Black Sea resort city of Sochi. It was widely interpreted here as a signal of surrender by the Americans  an olive branch from President Obama, and an acknowledgment that Russia and its leader are simply too important to ignore.

title: Review: The Duchamp Syndrome Debuts at the Flea Theater
description: Juan, a lonely janitor new to this country, has lowered the bar for friendship all the way to the floor, where a skittering insect named Tony is his best bet for a meaningful connection.

title: A Resilient Blythe Danner Happily Takes Things in Stride
description: Blythe Danner was peering intently the other week at the work of her friend Kim McCarty, whose vaporous watercolors were about to go on view at the Morgan Lehman gallery in Chelsea.

title: Racist Police Emails Put Florida Cases in Doubt
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  The Miami-Dade state attorneys office is combing through more than 150 criminal cases of black suspects arrested by Miami Beach police officers who wrote or received racist emails, the latest in a series of high-profile episodes around the nation that have raised troubling questions about the relations between the police and the communities they serve.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Inside Ts Travel Issue
description: Ts latest issue explores some of the most unique travel destinations around the world. We begin with an anomaly: an ancient farming community in northwest India where locals and leopards have lived in peaceful harmony for hundreds of years. The novelist Hari Kunzru sets up camp to experience the potentially precarious phenomenon firsthand. In Joshua Tree, we visit a far-out house, designed by the visionary architectKendrick Bangs Kellogg, that is nearly as awe-inspiring as the landscape itself. We also stop by one of the worlds great inns  La Colombe dOr in Provence  where a centurys worth of famous artists toting their own works have helped create an environment that is as much a world-class gallery as it is a hotel. And because summer is coming, we sent the photographer Karim Sadli to Hawaii, where he shot the model Julia Bergshoeff in the seasons best bikini bottoms and lightweight knits. Elsewhere, female artists in their 80s and 90s get their long-awaited due; the finance journalist Felix Salmon shines a light on conferences like the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where the parties are usurping the panels for all-important networking (and Spring Break-style fun); Jody Rosen cracks the spine on street lit, the hard-boiled, sexed-up book genre whose greatest practitioners may just be the most successful literary couple in America; and tattoos, which have grown increasingly idiosyncratic in recent years, leave their mark on the minds (and bodies) of the creative worlds most stylish. See all stories from this issue >>

title: Cerberus, Unable to Sell Remington, Will Let Investors Cash Out
description: After a deadly school shooting in Newtown, Conn., more than two years ago, the Wall Street owner of the manufacturer of the rifle used in the assault publicly pledged to sell the company.

title: Review: Art for the Planets Sake at the Venice Biennale
description: VENICE  The world is a mass of intractable ills on which art must shed light. With oceans rising, climates warming, the income gap widening and human rights abuses of every imaginable kind occurring, the very future of the planet  its many futures  hangs in the balance. This is not the time for art as an object of contemplation or delight, much less a market commodity  certainly not in a public exhibition whose chief responsibility is to stimulate debate.

title: 2 Women Moved to Write Stories Uncover a Surprisingly Personal One
description: Lizzie Valverde and Katy Olson were strangers when they enrolled at Columbia University a few years ago. Ms. Valverde is from New Jersey, while Ms. Olson had grown up mostly in Florida and Iowa.

title: Opposition Activists in Burundi Fear Crackdown After Presidents Return
description: Opposition activists in Burundi expressed concern on Friday that President Pierre Nkurunziza would intensify a crackdown on dissent after having thwarted  a coup attempt and returning to the capital, Bujumbura.

title: Greek Prime Minister Rejects Further Austerity or Labor Changes
description: ATHENS  Greeces prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, said in a speech on Friday that his government wanted a deal with the countrys creditors but that it would not enforce additional austerity measures, like further pension cuts.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Trade votes, summit meetings and visits to Manchester, N.H., made up the week in politics.

title: Israel, Palestine and the Boycott Debate on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Jeb Bushs Florida Record
description: To the Editor:

title: John Boehner, Ted Cruz and a One-Finger Salute
description: Speaker John A. Boehner has had ample reason to give Senator Ted Cruz of Texas the stink eye, shall we say. Mr. Cruz has repeatedly encouraged House conservatives to push Mr. Boehner sharply, even untenably, to the right, and he helped orchestrate the government shutdown at the end of 2013, which Mr. Boehner tried mightily to prevent.

title: Reinvest in Transportation
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Blame the Prom Dress
description: To the Editor:

title: A Huge Gift to Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: A Review of Wolferts Roost Restaurant in Irvington
description: Wolferts Roost, a fresh-faced, whitewashed storefront restaurant at the top of Main Street in Irvington, has one of the more exuberant menus Ive been handed lately.

title: Amtrak Train Possibly Hit Before Wreck
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Amtrak train that derailed Tuesday, killing eight people and injuring more than 200, may have been struck by an object before it careened off the tracks, an assistant conductor on the train told investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Review: Bombay Velvet Is a Bollywood Ode to American Gangster Movies
description: In the period world of Bombay Velvet, Ranbir Kapoor  with his pencil mustache, crop of flyaway hair and broad-shouldered jacket  looks more than a bit like his grandfather Raj Kapoor. And he has some of his raffish, leading-man charm.

title: Evening Hours | Calendar in Bloom
description: Plenty of benefits to keep New Yorkers busy.

title: Marco Rubio Reports Income From Book Royalties and Teaching
description: Marco Rubio, one of the least-wealthy candidates in the growing Republican presidential field, showed little change in his financial picture in 2014, according to disclosures released Friday.

title: Netflix Said to Be in Early Talks With Chinese Companies
description: Netflix is in preliminary discussions with a handful of Chinese media companies to explore how it can bring its streaming service to China, a development that has the potential to increase its subscriber counts but also faces significant challenges, including censorship.

title: A Review of Sunny Palace in East Brunswick
description: Its not often that I find myself eating tripe on a Sunday morning. But I had been hearing good things about Sunny Palace in East Brunswick.

title: Rocky Mountain Chocolate FactoryRecalls False Bid Similar to One at Avon
description: Bryan J. Merryman, the chief financial officer of the Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory, says it is far too easy for a potential stock manipulator to gain access to a federal securities database and submit a false takeover bid for a company.

title: Emotional Undercurrents Abound in Five Mile Lake in Princeton
description: Describing Five Mile Lake as Chekhovian is fitting, but that may raise audience expectations a bit too high. The understated yet touching contemporary play by Rachel Bonds is currently enjoying its East Coast premiere at the McCarter Theater in Princeton.

title: Bill Cunningham | At the Market
description: On Saturday morning, the harsh city vanished in favor of a village friendliness. People, arms loaded with lilacs, dogwood and irises, dressed casually.

title: 18 Years Probation for Arizona Woman Who Left Sons in Car
description: PHOENIX  A woman who left her two young sons alone for an hour in a hot car while she was at a job interview was sentenced Friday to 18 years of supervised probation.

title: Bill Cunningham | At the Market
description: On Saturday morning, the harsh city vanished in favor of a village friendliness. People, arms loaded with lilacs, dogwood and irises, dressed casually, like the bicyclist with a giant tiger backpack. Highlights at the market: a woman selling $40 pigeon dolls and impromptu chess games. And of course, the dogs. Pink hoodies showed up next to pink azaleas. In the parks, women wore wisteria-print dresses.

title: A Review of Tarry Lodge, in New Haven
description: The metro area has few culinary A-listers to rival Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich  the restaurant-world power duo behind Manhattan venues like Babbo (winner of multiple James Beard Awards), the Michelin-starred Casa Mono, and more than a dozen other American eateries.

title: The Pipe Dream of a Perfect Television Finale
description: The better the TV show, the harder it is to end it. This is the lesson of the past decade and a half of high-end TV drama  not least Mad Men, which wraps up seven obsessed-over seasons on Sunday. Anticipation mingled with marketing makes it practically impossible for otherwise good TV shows to live up to the expectations weve created for them. Mad Men faces a particularly acute version of this problem, thanks to AMCs strategy of splitting the shows final season in half  now apparently standard procedure for the network, which did the same with the buzzy final season of Breaking Bad and continues to split seasons of its ratings cash cow, The Walking Dead.

title: Welcome to the Wastelands
description: A post-apocalyptic car race in the Australian desert.

title: U.S. Attorney on Tsarnaev Death Sentence
description: U.S. Attorney Carmen Ortiz said that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev would pay for his crimes with his life. Mr. Tsarnaev was sentenced to death for his role in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings.

title: Review of The Liar at the Westport Country Playhouse
description: If he is known at all, the 17th-century French playwright Pierre Corneille is renowned for his tragedies. But David Ives is reshaping that reputation with The Liar, a witty, wacky adaptation of Corneilles little-seen, little-read comedy of the same name, which is kicking off the Westport Country Playhouses 85th season in high style.

title: A Review of Verde Kitchen & Cocktails in Bay Shore, N.Y.
description: Verde is more than the name of a six-month-old Mexican restaurant in Bay Shore. The word, Spanish for green, also refers to the restaurants environmentally friendly attitude. Wherever possible, reclaimed materials were used in its construction: used brick on one wall, other walls made from barn siding; some tabletops made from barn doors, others from tin roofs. Then there is the greenhouse, which also serves as the main dining room. It has about 60 planter boxes holding edibles like peppers, peas and herbs, which are regularly incorporated into the cooking. Flowers and evergreens are in the boxes during the colder months.

title: 2 New York City Jail Employees Arrested on Smuggling Charges
description: Despite a campaign by New York City officials to crack down on contraband smuggling at Rikers Island, investigators say that jail employees continue to flout the law.

title: Clintons Earned $30 Million in 16 Months, Report Shows
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband made at least $30 million over the last 16 months, mainly from giving paid speeches to corporations, banks and other organizations, according to financial disclosure forms filed with federal elections officials on Friday.

title: Time Travelers Welcome at Out of the Vault: 25 Years of Collecting at the Nassau County Museum
description: Wandering through Out of the Vault: 25 Years of Collecting, the current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, a visitor might sometimes feel a jolt. The content and style of the art can change drastically from gallery to gallery.

title: Victims Find Solace and Sorrow in Boston Verdict and Are Ready to Move On
description: BOSTON  It was the worst terror attack in America in a dozen years, but after its surviving perpetrator was sentenced to death on Friday, many of his victims voiced ambivalence about the jurys judgment even as they spoke of how they now, finally, might be able to get on with their lives.

title: Wreck Adds to the Debate on Amtrak Funding
description: WASHINGTON  The question on congressional culpability for the deadly train derailment in Philadelphia was not even finished when House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio gruffly declared it stupid.

title: Washington Governor Declares Drought Emergency
description: SEATTLE  Gov. Jay Inslee declared a statewide drought emergency for Washington on Friday, with mountain snowpack at 16 percent of average and water levels in rivers and streams drying to a trickle not seen since the 1950s. He said that residents should also be prepared for an early and active fire season that could reach higher elevations in the Cascade and Olympic mountain ranges, where many spots are already completely clear of snow.

title: Investigating the Journey of a Coffin, With Bones, to a Brooklyn Street
description: Felipe Figueroa, 67, is a retired bus driver who doesnt want to sit around the house all day, so he still shows up for work at 5:30 a.m. weekdays at Happy Day Transit Inc., a bus company in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: Wichita Bookstore Expresses Its Founders Eclectic and Christian Tastes
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Eighth Day Books lives in an old three-story house on Douglas Avenue, just east of C&R Comics and Superior Rubber Stamp. It is not exactly a Christian bookstore  while sitting at the communal table, I can pull off the shelf works like Greil Marcuss The History of Rock n Roll in Ten Songs or scoot my chair a couple of feet and grab, Laura Hillenbrands Unbroken.

title: It Is, in Fact, Rocket Science
description: THE other week I was working in my garage office when my 14-year-old daughter, Olivia, came in to tell me about Charles Darwin. Did I know that he discovered the theory of evolution after studying finches on the Galpagos Islands? I was steeped in what felt like the 37th draft of my new book, which is on the development of scientific ideas, and she was proud to contribute this tidbit of history that she had just learned in class.

title: U.S. Approves SunOpta System for Detecting Genetically Modified Crops
description: A little-known but publicly traded organic food processing company, SunOpta, has persuaded the federal government that its system for detecting genetically modified crops is so effective that the company should be permitted to label ingredients from one of its plants in Minnesota as free of such alterations.

title: Farmers Flying Drones May Soon Be Given Clearance
description: NUNN, Colo.  As the sun peeks over the fields of organic grain in this grassy patch of the state, some mornings, a dark dot appears in the sky as well, and a loud buzz slices through the pastoral scene.

title: F. A. O. Schwarz to Close Its Doors on Fifth Avenue
description: F. A. O. Schwarz, the legendary toy store on Fifth Avenue, will close its doors July 15, a victim of rising rents and ultraluxury retailing in New York Citys hottest shopping district.

title: Lightning Center Tyler Johnson Thrives as Top Scorer in Playoffs
description: BRANDON, Fla.  The comparison would become inevitable, mostly because Tyler Johnson stopped growing when he reached 5 feet 8 inches tall. Like the Rangers Martin St. Louis, Johnson was always considered too small, a judgment that caused both players to go undrafted and forced them to scrap through hockeys roughneck minor leagues.

title: Mad Maxs Disciples
description: Just south of Lake George in Australia, off the highway between Sydney and Canberra, there is a small piece of land known as the Wastelands. For a select few, the Wastelands is the site of an annual gathering called the Wasteland Cup, where cobbled-together franken-cars race in the dirt, kicking up plumes of dust that can be seen for miles. Its a sort of D.I.Y. Mad Max; corrugated metal, leather, animal bones and rust abound.

title: Poland: Reparations Deadline to Be Met for 2 Terrorism Suspects Held by C.I.A.
description: Poland will meet a Saturday deadline set by a European court to pay a total of $260,000 in reparations to two suspected terrorists who were interrogated in a secret C.I.A. prison in Poland, a foreign ministry spokesman said Friday. The European Court of Human Rights ruled in July that Poland had violated the rights of the two inmates by permitting the C.I.A. to imprison them in 2002 at a facility in northeast Poland. The secret prison is now closed. We will abide by the ruling, as we always do, said Marcin Wojciechowski, the chief spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In February, Mr. Wojciechowski said the authorities had come up with a plan to put the money into accounts that the suspects could gain access to only after they had been released. The two men  Abu Zubaydah, a high-ranking Al Qaeda official, and Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who was accused of planning the attack in 2000 on the American destroyer Cole in the Yemeni port of Aden  are being held in the American military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Germany: Hackers Attack Computers in the Lower House of Parliament
description: Hackers have launched an attack on the computer system of the Bundestag, the lower house of the German Parliament, a parliamentary spokesman said Friday. The spokesman, Ernst Hebeker, said that the origin and dimensions of the attack were not yet known, and that administrators in the Bundestag had spotted the first indications of a cyberattack a few days earlier. Warnings of a disruption went out to at least some lawmakers on Friday morning, when many were absent because of the Ascension holiday weekend. The attack followed an assault in January on the websites of some government offices, including Chancellor Angela Merkels office. Responsibility for those attacks was claimed by a Russian hacker group that said it opposed German support for the government of Ukraine.

title: Franz Wright, Pulitzer Prize Winner for Poetry, Dies at 62
description: Franz Wright, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet whose work illuminated his passage from abiding despair to religious transcendence, died on Thursday at his home in Waltham, Mass. He was 62.

title: Latin American Allies Resist U.S. Strategy in Drug Fight
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Colombia just discarded a cornerstone of the American-backed fight against drugs, blocking the aerial spraying of coca, the plant used to make cocaine. Bolivia kicked out the United States Drug Enforcement Administration years ago and allows farmers to grow small amounts of the crop. Chile, long one of Latin Americas most socially conservative countries, is gathering its first medical marijuana harvest.

title: Speedy Lightning Could Test One of Rangers Strengths: Their Defense
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  A stalwart defense is a major reason the Rangers have won eight playoff series over the past four springs.

title: Let George Do It
description: Just in case you havent heard: May 28 is the date that George Pataki will announce whether hes running for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: The Greatest Generation of Scientists
description: A great man died late last month, one of the last of the pioneering biologists who essentially created the modern science of molecular biology. His name was Alexander Rich; he was 90 years old; and he had spent the past 57 years as a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was still going to work right up until the last two months of his life.

title: Kyle Buschs Accident Prompts Safety Measures, but Drivers See a Slow Reaction
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Nearly three months after a crash at Daytona International Speedway on Feb. 21 left him with a broken right leg and left foot, Kyle Busch climbed back into his No. 18 Toyota on Friday for his first practice laps.

title: Yemen: Aid Coordinator Asks Saudis to Simplify Restrictions
description: Scrambling to bring emergency aid into Yemen during a five-day humanitarian pause in the Saudi-led bombing of Houthi rebels and their allies, the United Nations said Friday that the relief effort was still encumbered by Saudi Arabias stringent import inspections. Johannes Van Der Klaauw, the United Nations humanitarian coordinator for Yemen, said at a news conference conducted by telephone from Yemen that even during the bombing halt, the arms embargo and its inspection regime results in commercial goods, be it by air or by ship, no longer reaching the country. The Saudi inspection process, he said, needs to be simplified, needs to be faster.

title: The Chicken or the Egg or the Dinosaur?
description: If we accept what scientists tell us, and we usually do, a chicken is really a modified dinosaur. If thats tough to stomach, how about the report that a group of scientists has managed to turn a chickens beak  a piece of critical avian equipment that appeared relatively late in the evolution of dinosaur to bird  back into something resembling the dinosaur snout it once was.

title: I Havent the Foggiest
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Weve talked about puzzles that are crunchy, which essentially means that the entries are both lively and more than suitably challenging, and the clues require a lot of thought to solve. They are typically late-week puzzles, filled with misdirected and toughened cluing. In other words, crunchy puzzles give you something on which to really chew.

title: Breaking Laws in the Mortgage Bubble
description: The government won a big victory this week in a case against two banks that were found to have systematically deceived investors about shoddy mortgage securities they peddled during the housing bubble. The magnitude of falsity, conservatively measured, is enormous, wrote Judge Denise Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan in a strongly worded 361-page ruling.

title: Nanny Stops Abduction of Boy in Central Park
description: A woman walked into a Central Park playground one morning this week and tried to kidnap a toddler, but was stopped by the young boys nanny, who pulled him out of her arms, the police said on Friday.

title: President Obama and the Gulf Arabs
description: Saudi Arabia is so angry at the emerging nuclear agreement between Iran and the major powers that it is threatening to develop its own nuclear capability  one more indication of the deep differences between the United States and the Persian Gulf Arab states over the deal, which the major powers and Iran aim to complete by June 30. President Obama had hoped to bridge that gap with a show of American-Arab unity at this weeks summit meeting at Camp David. The summit meeting fell well short of his ambitions, an unfortunate outcome for both sides.

title: The End of the War in the West
description: After Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Courthouse on April 9, 1865, the Civil War continued. After the final pitched battle at Palmito Ranch, Texas, on May 12-13, 1865, the Civil War continued. After Cherokee leader Stand Watie became the last Confederate general to surrender on June 23, 1865, the Civil War continued. Even after Aug. 20, 1866, when Andrew Johnson formally declared an end to the war and began to pull back the troops occupying the former Confederate states, the war wasnt really over, at least not in the American West.

title: John J. Flanagans Former Law Firm Had Matters Before State Agencies
description: ALBANY  For years, the newly installed State Senate majority leader, John J. Flanagan, has added to his income by working part-time as a lawyer.

title: Jesper Fast, a Ranger Known for Speed, Rises to the Second Line
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Compile the defining images of the Rangers comeback from a three-games-to-one series deficit against Washington into a scrapbook, and there would be Ryan McDonaghs overtime winner in Game 5 and Chris Kreiders beauty of a backhander 40 seconds into Game 6 and, of course, Derek Stepans rebound in Game 7 that lifted the Rangers into the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Yankees Chase Whitley Joins Disabled List With Elbow Tear
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Chase Whitley, who walked off the mound Thursday night with an elbow injury, was found to have a tear in his elbow ligament Friday. He will be examined by the Yankees team doctor on Monday to determine whether he will be able to undergo rehabilitation for the injury or require Tommy John surgery.

title: Last-Place Brewers Add to Mets Growing Anxiety
description: When the Mets returned home after being swept by the Chicago Cubs in a four-game series, General Manager Sandy Alderson conveyed a message that the team and its worrying fans need to relax.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They didnt know about the blues. They had been taught that the blues was the bottom of the totem pole, done by slaves, and they didnt want to think along those lines.

title: Royals Chris Young Tops Yankees Chris Young
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  When Yankees outfielder Chris Young was an emerging slugger with the Arizona Diamondbacks, he received letters from fans that included baseball cards they asked him to sign.

title: 8 Bodies Found in Wreckage of Marine Helicopter, Nepal Army Says
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Eight bodies were found at the site of the crash of a United States Marine helicopter that disappeared in Nepal while assisting in earthquake relief efforts, the Nepalese Army said Saturday evening.

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS Robert Osborne and Sally Field explain why The Red Shoes (1948)  starring Moira Shearer, above, as a famous ballerina torn between art and love in Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburgers take on the Hans Christian Andersen fable about a girl bewitched by her red dancing shoes  is required viewing. After going wildly over budget and fizzling at the box office in Britain, Universal Pictures paid for the American release in 1951, where it played an exclusive engagement at the Bijou Theater in New York for 110 weeks. The film was then rereleased back at home, becoming one of the highest-grossing films in the history of British cinema and was heralded as among the most beautiful movies ever made. This unrestricted romance, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, is a visual and emotional comprehension of all the grace and rhythm and power of the ballet.

title: Stephen Curry Puts On Show, and Warriors Pull Curtain on Grizzlies Season
description: MEMPHIS  Against all odds, the Memphis Grizzlies had managed to turn the Golden State Warriors glorified instructional video into an actual basketball game.

title: Corrections: May 16, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Bob Bowman, Michael Phelpss Coach, Finds New Focus at Arizona State
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  As the 2012 Olympics approached, Bob Bowman took an out-of-shape Michael Phelps and tried to ripen him in a hurry by placing him in marquee events like the Arena Pro Swim Series stop at Mecklenburg County Aquatic Center.

title: Russian Rocket Carrying Mexican Satellite Is Said to Crash in Siberia
description: MOSCOW  A Russian-made rocket ferrying a Mexican telecommunications satellite crashed in eastern Siberia minutes after its launching on Saturday, Russian news agencies reported, citing officials at the countrys space agency.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from Cambodia to a competitive chess game in 1920s Paris.

title: They Built a Commune but No One Came
description: Two men, dreaming of utopia, end up with a museum.

title: They Built It. No One Came.
description: PITMAN, Pa.  They slept in the barn their first winter, on a straw mattress with antique linen sheets and a feather tick. There was no electricity, heat or plumbing, so they made their own candles, used a chamber pot and drew water from a spring.

title: For the Highest-Paid C.E.O.s, the Party Goes On
description: It pays to work for John C. Malone.

title: How the Chief Executives Pay Figures Were Calculated
description: To measure the sums that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: The Highest-Paid Female C.E.O.s
description: There are very few women on the list of top-paid executives  just 13 out of 200  and their average pay, $20 million, is 11.5 percent less than the $22.6 million overall average.

title: Shareholders Votes Have Done Little to Curb Lavish Executive Pay
description: Its been five years since the Dodd-Frank law required that companies let investors vote on their executive pay practices. The idea, lawmakers said, was to give shareholders a chance to sound off when compensation plans are not in their best interests.

title: Highest-Paid Chiefs in 2014
description: Here are 200 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business.

title: Blinkers and Lies
description: Jeb Bush definitely did us a favor: in his attempts to avoid talking about the past, he ended up bringing back a discussion people have been trying to avoid. And they are, of course, still trying to avoid it  they want to make this just about the horserace, or about the hypothetical of if you knew what we know now.

title: Egyptian Court Sentences Ousted President Morsi to Death
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Saturday sentenced to death the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, along with more than 100 others, for fleeing prison during the 2011 revolt against President Hosni Mubarak.

title:
ISIS Official
Killed in U.S. Raid in Syria,
Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON  American Special Operations forces mounted a rare raid into eastern Syria early Saturday, killing a leader of the Islamic State and about a dozen militant fighters, as well as capturing his wife and freeing an 18-year-old Yazidi woman who Pentagon officials said had been held as a slave.

title: Getting Rid of Mice
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Minnesota Orchestra, in Groundbreaking Cuba Tour, Sells Out House
description: HAVANA  The Teatro Nacional, a 2,056-seat theater on the Plaza de la Revolucin, was sold out. Two dozen photographers and videographers swarmed the aisles. The Minnesota Orchestras concert here Friday night was greeted not only as a rare chance to hear an orchestra from overseas, but as a symbol of the rapprochement between the United States and Cuba.

title: Amy Winehouse Documentary Unveiled in Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Amy, Asif Kapadias new documentary on the too-short life of Amy Winehouse, opens with grainy video footage of the performer as a goofy, zaftig 14-year-old from North London singing Happy Birthday to one of her best friends. It closes with images of some of the same friends weeping at her funeral some 13 years later.

title: Hillary Clinton's Financial Disclosure Form
description: The personal financial disclosure form filed on May 15 with the Federal Election Commission by Hillary Rodham Clinton shows that she and her husband made at least $30 million over the last 16 months, mainly from giving paid speeches to corporations, banks and other organizations.

title: From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola at MoMA
description: Among the artists who fled Berlin in the 1930s were two avant-garde photographers who met at the Bauhaus, Grete Stern (1904-1999) and Horacio Coppola (1906-2012). Stern had made her mark when she formed the studio Ringl & Pit with the photographer Ellen Auerbach (then Rosenberg). Coppola had started out in Argentina, where his interest in new modes of photography prompted a pilgrimage to the Bauhaus. After escaping Germany in 1933, they stayed briefly in Britain, where they married, then moved to Buenos Aires.

title: Variety: A Spaced-Out Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Its not often that a constructor reads my mind, but Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have done it this week. Their acrostic put me in mind of one of my favorite David Bowie songs and, even though I dont usually post videos with the variety puzzle, I was thinking about including a video of his song Space Oddity, the take of Major Tom, the astronaut who cut himself loose from his spaceship and, consequently, the rest of humanity. Our constructors beat me to it and sent a video by the author of todays quote performing the same song. While in zero gravity.

title: In Vatican, Abbas Is Praised as Angel of Peace
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis praised Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, as an angel of peace during a meeting at the Vatican on Saturday. The Vatican also expressed hope that Israel and the Palestinians would resume talks to find a just and lasting solution to the conflict that has roiled the Middle East for decades.

title: Death Sentence for Boston Bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, Unsettles City He Tore Apart
description: BOSTON  The finish line of the Boston Marathon is a landmark here, a blue and yellow slash across Boylston Street that has represented pride and achievement for those who stagger across it in one of the great races of the running world.

title: A Very Suspicious Traveler
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  I DONT know if Ill ever be comfortable with the silence that comes after Ive handed my papers to the passport control officer. In that moment, I instantly recall all my faults and sins from my childhood, including the day I accidentally broke an entire bowl of ceramic fruits from a friends dinner table. (I later tried to glue them back together.)

title: Texts From Strangers
description: CHICAGO  ONE day last fall, I started receiving text messages about a boy, whom Ill call Ollie. He was 5 years old, maybe 6. Blue shorts. Spiderman T-shirt. Supercool Velcro sneakers.

title: China Stands by Its Claims Over South China Sea Reefs
description: BEIJING  Chinas top diplomat, emerging from talks here with Secretary of State John Kerry, suggested Saturday that Beijing had no intention of scaling back island-building efforts in the South China Sea that have aggravated tensions in waters claimed by a number of neighboring governments.

title: Stitching Up Fuzzy Friends
description: Nancy Robert, 58, works for the Vermont Teddy Bear Company in Shelburne, Vt.

title: Rock Hurling Is Old Nemesis of Train Crews
description: PHILADELPHIA  In the dark blocks of crumbling rowhouses pushed up against vacant factories along Glenwood Avenue, a group of young men hanging out on a stoop on a recent night said it was easy to sneak onto the nearby railroad tracks.

title: Realizing His Dream, as a Pitcher
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Nick Martinez has always held on to this belief, the one that sustains every amateur baseball player with a dream.

title: Natalia Maria Ruderman of IBM: A Sweet Spot for Global Traditions
description: A changing landscape

title: By Now, Weary Rangers Fans Know the Score (Its Probably 2-1)
description: It has been 21 years since the Rangers last won the Stanley Cup, so their onslaught of 2-1 scores in the current postseason feels like an improvised Morse code reaching out to the past: 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1, 2-1.

title: Amtrak, After Derailment, Told to Expand Automatic Brake Use
description: The Federal Railroad Administration said Saturday that it had instructed Amtrak to expand its use of a technology that would automatically stop speeding trains, an existing system that could have prevented the derailment of an Amtrak train on Tuesday.

title: For American Pharoahs Owners, Chaotic Stretch After Derby Win
description: BALTIMORE  The two weeks between the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes are always hectic for the connections of the Derby winner. Still, for the Zayat family, which owns this years Derby champion, American Pharoah, it was a particularly taxing stretch.

title: He Is Heavy. Hes My Brother.
description: WASHINGTON  IT isnt about what we know now.

title: Let the Kids Learn Through Play
description: TWENTY years ago, kids in preschool, kindergarten and even first and second grade spent much of their time playing: building with blocks, drawing or creating imaginary worlds, in their own heads or with classmates. But increasingly, these activities are being abandoned for the teacher-led, didactic instruction typically used in higher grades. In many schools, formal education now starts at age 4 or 5. Without this early start, the thinking goes, kids risk falling behind in crucial subjects such as reading and math, and may never catch up.

title: Whats Lurking Behind the Suicides?
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D.  OUTSIDE the Oglala Lakota tribes child protection service office, staff members updated a police officer on the latest emergency: An 11-year old girl had texted her cousin that she wanted to kill herself and then had gone missing.

title: What Wild Has Wrought
description: ON THE PACIFIC CREST TRAIL, Calif.  THIS is arguably Americas greatest hiking trail, a 2,650-mile serpentine path running through desert and wilderness from the Mexican border to the Canadian border. The Pacific Crest Trail meanders through cactus and redwoods, challenging humans with rivers and snowfields, rattlesnakes and bears.

title: Thou Shalt Worship None of the Above
description: GROWING up Catholic in the 1980s, I attended a number of Boston-area churches, each a snapshot of a religious community in flux: an African-American parish that had once been Baptist, a historically Irish parish making room for immigrants from Vietnam, a suburban parish whose acoustic guitar hymns made it virtually indistinguishable from Protestant churches down the road. At other times, my family worshiped with conservative Anglicans, liberal Congregationalists and assorted charismatics. After I left home for college, when a favorite professor led Shabbat services at the campus Hillel, I attended those, too. Later, I dabbled in Buddhism, got married in a Presbyterian church and wrote a dissertation on Yiddish literature at a Jesuit university.

title: Poor Little Rich Women
description: WHEN our family moved from the West Village to the Upper East Side in 2004, seeking proximity to Central Park, my in-laws and a good public school, I thought it unlikely that the neighborhood would hold any big surprises. For many years I had immersed myself  through interviews, reviews of the anthropological literature and participant-observation  in the lives of women from the Amazon basin to sororities at a Big Ten school. I thought I knew from foreign.

title: Past Time to Reform Bretton Woods
description: The reluctance of American and European officials to give developing nations a greater role in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank risks making those institutions less relevant and effective than they could be.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Abuses at Nail Salons
description: Readers discuss the wage violations and health hazards for those who give manicures.

title: Greed and the Presidency
description: AFTER two terms of sucking it up for the citizens of Arkansas, Mike Huckabee itched to cash in. So he signed on as a pitchman for a bogus diabetes remedy and rented out his mailing list to charlatans peddling Scripture as a cure for cancer.

title: Housing Apartheid, American Style
description: The riots that erupted in Baltimore last month were reminiscent of those that consumed cities all over the country during the 1960s. This rage and unrest was thoroughly explained five decades ago by President Lyndon Johnsons National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, also known as the Kerner Commission. The commissions report was released in 1968  the year that the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. touched off riots in 125 cities  and contains the most candid indictment of racism and segregation seen in such a document, before or since.

title: Cara McCarty
description: Cara McCarty is the curatorial director for the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum in New York.

title: No Longer Wanting to Die
description: In January 2012, two weeks after my discharge from a psychiatric hospital in Connecticut, I made a plan to die. My week in an acute care unit that had me on a suicide watch had not diminished my pain.

title: For Reviewers, How Close Is Too Close?
description: AS a reviewer of the fourth volume of Karl Ove Knausgaards My Struggle, the novelist Jeffrey Eugenides didnt exactly come to the subject cold.

title: Do Churches Fail the Poor?
description: LAST week two prominent Americans  an eminent social scientist and the president of the United States  decided to answer the question: How have Americas churches failed the poor?

title: LeBron James, Under the Microscope, Continues to Come Up Big
description: These N.B.A. playoffs have developed so many intriguing story lines.

title: I Love the Post Office
description: NOT because it still delivers letters  the Alamo of warm and fuzzy Luddites like my mother and multinational credit card corporations.

title: A Russian Smartphone Has to Overcome Rivals and Jokes About Its Origin
description: MOSCOW  Few people looking to buy a trendy, state-of-the-art smartphone anywhere in the world today would even think about a Russian model, but the makers of the YotaPhone aspire to change that.

title: Village of Bedouins Faces Eviction as Israel Envisions a Village of Jews
description: UMM AL-HIRAN, Israel  Salim al-Qian settled back on his white faux leather couch strewn with pink cushions and took a sip of tea, clearly comfortable in his tiny home in this ramshackle hamlet in the dusty hills of southern Israel. The sense of permanence suggested by his comfort, however, looks to be short-lived.

title: Red Carpet at the Cannes Film Festival
