description: Sometime in the near future, Mohamed Morsi, Egypts first democratically elected president, could be hanged to death by the state. That would be a profound injustice, considering the sham trial that landed him on death row.

title: Mayor de Blasios Public Housing Plan to Seek City Aid and More Money From Tenants
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Tuesday an aggressive plan to shore up New York Citys deteriorating public housing, calling for significant new financial help from the city and for squeezing more revenue out of the housing projects and their residents.

title: A Players All-Clay Schedule Aids His Career, and Knees
description: When a small clay-court event in Tallahassee, Fla., was moved indoors because of incessant rain last season, Jason Kubler pleaded with tournament officials to delay his match to the evening session or the next day, hoping to play outdoors.

title: ISIS Fighters Seized Advantage in Iraq Attack by Striking During Sandstorm
description: WASHINGTON  Islamic State fighters used a sandstorm to help seize a critical military advantage in the early hours of the terrorist groups attack on the provincial Iraqi capital of Ramadi last week, helping to set in motion an assault that forced Iraqi security forces to flee, current and former American officials said Monday.

title: Grizzled Manager Part of a Bygone Era
description: Two members of the fraternity are gone now, two fewer major league managers who also managed in the minors.

title: The War Over the Waters of the United States
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, facing strong opposition from some farmers, ranchers and industrial groups, has tried to defend a major proposal aimed at protecting the nations drinking water. Here is a look at the dispute and the tactics the agency has used to fight back.

title: Leafy Refuge in Liberty Park for Residents Annoyed by Construction
description: There is almost nothing neighborly about the neighborhood south of the World Trade Center.

title: Hamilton, You Got Older and Invisible Hand Among Obie Award Winners
description: The critically acclaimed musical Hamilton, which is preparing to transfer to Broadway after a sold-out, celebrity-packed run at the Public Theater, was named the best new American theater work at the 60th annual Obie Awards on Monday night.

title: Critics Hear E.P.A.s Voice in Public Comments
description: WASHINGTON  When the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a major new rule intended to protect the nations drinking water last year, regulators solicited opinions from the public. The purpose of the public comment period was to objectively gauge Americans sentiment before changing a policy that could profoundly affect their lives.

title: With Triple Crown Possible, Belmont Can Expect a Big Draw
description: Boxing and horse racing occasionally revive from their mainstream slumber with big events: pay-per-view fights and thoroughbreds vying for the Triple Crown.

title: Prashant Bhargava, Filmmaker of Patang (The Kite), Dies at 42
description: Prashant Bhargava, a promising director whose boyhood memories of his uncles rivalry inspired his film Patang (The Kite), about how Indias largest kite-flying festival united a city ravaged by religious divisions and natural disaster, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 42.

title: Amtrak Crash Illuminates Obstacles to Plan for Controlling Train Speeds
description: Nearly seven years after Congress instructed the nations railroads to install an automatic speed control system by the end of 2015, the crash of a speeding Amtrak train last week has laid bare the industry hurdles, regional rivalries and often dismal economics of rail safety.

title: Review: Ensemble Studio Theaters 35th Marathon of One-Act Plays
description: In just two hours, Series A of the Ensemble Studio Theaters 35th Marathon of One-Act Plays races from Manhattan to Brooklyn, from a port town in Kenya to the capital of Idaho, from the 1950s to right now. A collection of short works, most Ensemble regulars, this speed-trial evening emphasizes how difficult it is for theater artists to work in miniature and how satisfying when they succeed.

title: Review: In The Flick, Moments at the Movies, but Not on Screen
description: People always freak out when like, you know, when like art forms move forward, says Sam, one of the lonely souls working in a run-down Massachusetts movie theater in the wondrous Annie Baker play The Flick.

title: The Mysterious Lady
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Tuesdays are harder than Mondays. That is an unwritten rule of most published crosswords, and the difficulty level is usually ramped up by either including harder entries, or cluing the puzzle in a slightly more difficult way, or both.

title: Son of Indicted New York State Senator Receives 6-Month Sentence
description: WHITE PLAINS  Among the wide variety of scandals that have gripped Albany in recent years, the past year has seemed to favor family affairs.

title: An N.B.A. Lottery So Rich, Luck Seems Sure to Favor the Knicks
description: As a former N.B.A. executive, Stu Jackson is familiar with the mood at the annual draft lottery. He has sat on that dais. He has felt the bright lights. Jackson, now an analyst for NBA TV, described it as the party no one ever wants to go to.

title: Bid to Impose Monitor on East Ramapo School Board Meets Resistance
description: A bill that would establish a state monitor for the East Ramapo School District, where a school board dominated by Orthodox Jews has drawn criticism for diverting money from public schools to children in local yeshivas, faces an uncertain future after running into resistance in the New York Legislature.

title: Missouri: No Charge for St. Louis Officer in Killing
description: Prosecutors in St. Louis will not charge the police officer who fatally shot VonDerrit D. Myers Jr. in October, a shooting that renewed tensions with law enforcement weeks after Michael Brown was killed by an officer in nearby Ferguson. In a report released Monday, Jennifer M. Joyce, the circuit attorney for St. Louis, found that Mr. Myers produced a gun during the encounter with the officer, Jason Flanery, who was working an off-duty security detail for a private company. Police had said Mr. Myers, 18, who was black, shot a stolen handgun before Officer Flanery, who is white, returned fire. Prosecutors said in their report that witnesses had seen gunfire coming from both directions and from two guns and that a semiautomatic pistol had been recovered next to Mr. Myerss body. Mr. Myerss family disputed the police account and insisted that he had been unarmed. Protesters marched for several nights after the shooting, and some drew parallels between Mr. Myerss death and that of Mr. Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old shot by a white Ferguson officer in August. In a statement, Ms. Joyce expressed condolences to the Myers family and called his death a tragic situation for our entire community.

title: Hall of Famer Phil Esposito Links Rangers and Lightning
description: Phil Esposito  unlikely Rangers hero and founder of the Tampa Bay Lightning  looked around Madison Square Garden on Monday night and remembered the hysteria of the spring of 1979.

title: Idaho Approves Child Support Bill, Removing Treaty Roadblock
description: An Idaho child support bill that was initially rejected over concerns that it could force the state to follow Islamic law, and which endangered American participation in an international treaty, passed on Monday after the governor called legislators back for a special session.

title: Weight of a Hat Trick Buckles the Rangers
description: The puck struck the post, then Henrik Lundqvists back. He looked behind himself for it, but it had already fluttered into the crease. He tried steering it away with his glove, but the puck skittered free, there for the taking, before winding up on the stick blade of the highest-scoring player in these N.H.L. playoffs.

title: Militant Group Says It Has Romanian Hostage
description: A jihadist group that is based in the Sahara and was once a part of Al Qaedas global network announced that it was holding a Romanian hostage, just five days after it pledged allegiance to the Islamic State.

title: An Artist Championed by Saint Laurent Brings His Paintings of Trance Dancers to Brooklyn
description: The self-taught artist Arrington de Dionyso, 40, can recite his first art-theory lesson, which came from his mother, a Methodist minister and painter. When I was four or five years old, my mom told me that Picasso spent his entire life trying to learn how to paint like a child, he says. Of course, Picasso had a huge classical background  but she told me, Do your thing, do what you feel, because thats what a real artist will spend his or her entire life trying to do.

title: Report Highlights Threats to Cartoonists Worldwide
description: The immediacy of visual imagery and the rise of social media have created an environment in which cartoonists are particularly vulnerable to censorship, punitive lawsuits, physical assault, imprisonment, disappearance and murder, according to a report to be issued on Tuesday by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: Word of the Day | rabid
description: rabid  \ra-bd also ra-\  adjective

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN THE BEDROOM (2001) Sissy Spacek, above, and Tom Wilkinson earned Oscar nominations for their portrayals of Ruth and Matt Fowler, a small-town New England couple who deal with the murder of their college-age son, Frank (Nick Stahl), in an unexpected way in this best-picture contender from Todd Field. Marisa Tomei, also nominated, plays the older, married girlfriend who unwittingly leads Frank to his demise. This adaptation of the short story Killings, by Andre Dubus, is a perfectly observed, wrenchingly acted drama that cuts to the quick, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. It reminds us that, like it or not, the capacity to commit a crime of passion is part of being human.

title: Bullpen Falters for Matt Harvey, but Mets Pull Out Win
description: Three St. Louis Cardinals infielders toed the grass between second base and first base at Citi Field on Monday night, standing within a few feet of one another, like wide receivers bunched along the line of scrimmage.

title: Lightnings Special Teams Race to an Early Advantage and Never Look Back
description: The game was about five minutes old, and the Lightning already seemed in trouble.

title: State Department Proposes January Release of Hillary Clinton Emails
description: More than 50,000 pages of emails from Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure as secretary of state might not be made public until early 2016, according to a State Department court filing on Monday.

title: Corrections: May 19, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: What it means to grow up young and black has changed. Something happened that put black teens at risk.

title: Yingluck Shinawatra Pleads Not Guilty to Negligence Over Thai Rice Subsidy
description: HONG KONG  Former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra of Thailand pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges of criminal negligence over a plan to prop up rice prices, which her political opponents called a corrupt bid to buy support from the countrys farmers.

title: Trade and the Decline of U.S. Manufacturing Employment
description: As Matthew Yglesias notes, many people believe that US manufacturing has disappeared because it has all moved to China and Mexico  but theyre largely wrong. Im not sure that pointing to measures of industrial production is the bet way to make this point, however. A better approach, or so Id argue, is to ask how much of the decline in manufacturing employment would have been avoided if we werent running big trade deficits.

title: Q. and A.: Peter Chan on Making Movies in China
description: Peter Ho-sun Chan, 52, was born in Hong Kong, spent his teenage years in Thailand and studied film in Los Angeles. Despite his transnational upbringing, the director of films such as Comrades, Almost a Love Story (1996), about mainland Chinese migrants in Hong Kong, and Perhaps Love (2005), a musical set in mainland China, still sees himself very much as a Hong Kong filmmaker. No matter what the subject matter is, the Hong Kong sensibility in me will never change, Mr. Chan said by telephone from Hong Kong, where he lives. I cant pretend that Im mainland Chinese and make films like a mainland Chinese. I will always be an observer and a storyteller with a Hong Kong perspective.

title: Chester Higginss Homage to Ethiopia
description: Chester Higgins Jr. has traveled to Africa every year since 1971 as a way to meditate, disconnect and examine his life. Through the experience of photographing new people and places, his art both shapes and reflects his narrative. And nowhere is that truer for him than in Ethiopia, a place that has long enchanted him.

title: Stupid Austerity Tricks
description: Against willful stupidity, the gods themselves contend in vain. So its no surprise that Simon Wren-Lewis is having a hard time of it. Still, its amazing just how dependent the pro-austerity camp has become on one dumb trick  misunderstanding, or pretending to misunderstand, the difference between levels and rates of change.

title: Give Thought to Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Practices at Well Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vatican Recognizes Palestine
Death and Dysfunction
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Trade Is Not the Enemy
description: CHICAGO  IN 1993, President Bill Clinton tapped me as special counsel to lead the fight to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement. As a new trade debate rages in Washington, Ive thought a lot about that effort. The mistake we made in the 1990s was overestimating the potential of Naftas positive impact. Today, we are making the mistake of underestimating what defeat of the Asia-Pacific deal would mean economically, globally and politically.

title: Learning From Mistakes
description: If you could go back to 1889 and strangle Adolf Hitler in his crib, would you do it? At one level, the answer is obvious. Of course, you should. If there had been no Hitler, presumably the Nazi Party would have lacked the charismatic leader it needed to rise to power. Presumably, there would have been no World War II, no Holocaust, no millions dead on the Eastern and Western fronts.

title: Chemo for the Planet
description: Whats the best way to reduce the chances of climate change wreaking havoc on Earth?

title: Everybody Wins When Generations Get Together
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Prevent an Oil Train Disaster
description: SIX days before last weeks deadly Amtrak derailment, a train carrying crude oil went off the tracks in rural North Dakota and burst into flames. Thankfully, no one was killed. But it should not take a deadly disaster  like the one that took 47 lives in the town of Lac-Mgantic, Quebec, in July 2013  for us to grasp the risk from oil trains, which pass through many densely populated parts of the United States.

title: The Fight to Regulate Formaldehyde
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been trying for several years to reduce the risk of toxic formaldehyde fumes from commonplace items and materials found in American homes. It has been stymied at every turn by industry, antiregulatory Republicans and even some Democrats. These opponents, abetted by the White House, have at least temporarily forced the agency to retreat from a proposal formulated in 2012 that it had hoped would address the issue. Unless the agency and its supporters in Congress fight back, the result could be thousands or even tens of thousands of needless illnesses.

title: Can Republicans Avoid the Romney Tax Trap?
description: In 2012, Mitt Romney made a promise that would come back to haunt him: that he could cut federal income tax rates by 20 percent across the board; eliminate enough tax deductions and credits to do this without increasing the deficit; and not raise taxes on people making less than $200,000.

title: Test Yourself | Driverless Cars
description: Below are several paragraphs from the May 15 article Google to Test Bubble-Shaped Self-Driving Cars in Silicon Valley.

title: Vodafone Returns to Quarterly Growth
description: LONDON  The British telecommunications giant Vodafone reported its first quarterly revenue gain in almost three years on Tuesday, as the carriers European operations started to show signs of recovery.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Fake Diplomas, Real Cash: Pakistani Company Axact Reaps Millions
description: In Fake Diplomas, Real Cash: Pakistani Company Axact Reaps Millions, Declan Walsh reports on a secretive software company selling fake online degrees.

title: Block by Block | Inwood
description: Perched on the northernmost tip of Manhattan, Inwood offers parks, new restaurants and bars and some of the boroughs more affordable apartments.

title: Block by Block: Inwood (Video Series)
description: Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, Block by Block. Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

title: Hillary Clinton May Not Need a Second Chance to Make a First Impression
description: Jeb Bush has his famous last name as a calling card, for better or worse. But Scott Walkers name does not ring many bells outside Wisconsin.

title: No. 10: How to Leave Late Show With David Letterman; No. 9: Whats Next?
description: Gathered with her colleagues for one of the last times in the offices of the Ed Sullivan Theater, Jude Brennan, an executive producer at CBSs Late Show With David Letterman, was reflecting on how she started working for the host some 35 years ago.

title: 5 Things You Might Not Know About Hillary Clinton
description: She is not exactly an open book, though she has written six of them. Most presidential candidates would count themselves lucky to finish their campaigns as recognized as Hillary Rodham Clinton started this one (excluding Chipotle restaurants near Toledo, at least). Here are some things you may still not know about her.

title: Does Technology in the Classroom Ever Get in the Way of Learning?
description: School districts have spent millions of dollars wiring classrooms, installing smart boards, and purchasing laptops and iPads so that students will have more access to technology. The intention is that all these devices will increase student learning.

title: Paul Shaffer, Late Show Bandleader, on Saying Goodbye to Letterman After 33 Years
description: Its not only the late-night television career of David Letterman that will come to an end on Wednesday night, when he hosts his final episode of CBSs Late Show. That broadcast will also bring to a close Mr. Lettermans memorable partnership with Paul Shaffer, the bespectacled, fashion-forward keyboardist who has been the hosts quip-firing bandleader and sidekick throughout his 22-year CBS run, and for 11 years before that on NBCs Late Night.

title: ISIS Finances Are Strong
description: ISIS has more than enough in its coffers despite expectations that airstrikes and falling oil prices would hurt the group.

title: Man in Profile: Joseph Mitchell of The New Yorker, by Thomas Kunkel
description: In his salad days as an uncommonly dapper reporter for The New York Herald Tribune and The World-Telegram, Joseph Mitchell wrote about celebrities, crimes and the quotidian disasters of city life during the Depression: He covered the Lindbergh kidnapping trial (a mess), witnessed the electrocution of six men, and watched a woman who had been stabbed in the neck bleed to death while he tried to make her lie still. He might have gone on like that and had a productive if ultimately forgettable career, were it not for a newspaper series he wrote on the anthropologist Franz Boas that became, for Mitchell, a kind of graduate-level seminar: Dont take anything for granted, Boas told him, among other things. The advice helped transform Mitchell from a competent beat reporter with a graceful prose style into, arguably, our greatest literary journalist  a man who wrote about freaks, barkeeps, street preachers, grandiose hobos and other singular specimens of humanity with compassion and deep, hard-earned understanding, and above all with a novelists eyes and ears. When the New Journalists came ashore, John McPhee observed, Joe Mitchell was there on the beach to greet them.

title: God Is Not Here, by Bill Russell Edmonds
description: This is a soldiers sad and troubling account of his yearlong tour in Iraq (2005-6) and his subsequent struggle to regain his balance and find meaning in the experience. In May of 2005, Lt.Col. Bill Russell Edmonds, then a Special Forces captain, volunteered for duty in an ad hoc organization, the Iraqi Assistance Group, which the United States military created to supply advisers to the nascent Iraqi military. He was sent to Iraq, given a brief training course in Baghdad and then loaded into a convoy to Mosul, where he would spend the next year on a small compound Saddam Hussein had called the Guest House.

title: Some People Do More Than Text While Driving
description: Phones are getting smarter, drivers seemingly less so.

title: Four Apps for Mapping Your Walking Routes
description: Who needs yet another smartphone app, let alone one that plots and records your wanderings?

title: A Pencil Shop, for Texting the Old-Fashioned Way
description: About 500 years after a graphite deposit was discovered in England and sliced into the first pencils, a store devoted to pencils has opened in Lower Manhattan. If the enterprise seems belated, well, it is. Who uses a pencil anymore?

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Kitchen Garden Goes High Tech
description: If you have always wanted to grow your own food but lack the expertise or outdoor space to do it, a high-tech indoor garden may be the answer. Various start-up companies now offer a bumper crop of garden gadgets to make it easier to grow food in your home.

title: New York Today: Subterranean Tunes
description: Good morning on this sticky Tuesday.
Vogue

title: Proving My Blackness
description: I grew up a black boy who looked like a white one. My parents divorced when I was 4, and I was raised mostly by my black mom, in a black neighborhood of Philadelphia, during the Black Power movement. I put my dashiki on one arm at a time like every other black boy, but I was haunted by the moments Id be out with my mother and other black people would look at me as if I were a cuckoo egg accidentally dropped in their nest. The contrast between blackness and how I looked was so stark that I often found myself sifting through archaic, pre-20th-century African-American racial definitions to find a word that fit me. Mulatto, 50 percent African. Quadroon, 25 percent African. Octoroon, 12.5 percent African. The next stop down, at 6.25 percent African, was mustefino. Id never heard anyone call himself mustefino, and I didnt want to personally relaunch that brand.

title: How the Civil War Changed the World
description: Even while the Civil War raged, slaves in Cuba could be heard singing, Avanza, Lincoln, avanza! Tu eres nuestra esperanza! (Onward, Lincoln, Onward! You are our hope!)  as if they knew, even before the soldiers fighting the war far to the North and long before most politicians understood, that the war in America would change their lives, and the world.

title: When It Comes to Wage Abuses, Its Not Just the Nail Salons
description: The cash registers of many gas stations never sleep. I was there seven days a week, 12 hours a day, 84 hours minimum. Minimum, said Chitra KC, 35, who worked in a station on Sunrise Highway in Holbrook, N.Y. He is one of about 27 immigrant workers from Nepal, Bangladesh, Pakistan or India with wage claims against stations on Long Island owned by Steve Keshtgar, who filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 on Dec. 24.

title: Global Priorities in the Arctic
Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Says Citizens United Would Guide Supreme Court Picks
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where the congressional debate over National Security Agency surveillance has highlighted a Republican divide, and where Twitter gained a new user with an exclusive handle. And, in Iowa, Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a rare metric for a presidential candidate amid increased scrutiny of the Clinton Foundation.

title: Morning Agenda: Bad Behavior in Finance Persists, Study Says
description: BAD BEHAVIOR IN FINANCE PERSISTS, STUDY SAYS | In some ways, Wall Street has cleaned up its act after the 2008 financial crisis, with firms carrying much less risk and banks increasing their capital requirements. Yet the ethos of the finance industry remains worrisome, according to a new study,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

title: Weekly News Quiz | May 12-18, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Hillary Clinton Tamps Down Third Term Chatter
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has started to address a critical issue about her candidacy  the loaded third term question.

title: Bright Passages
description: Dont worry  theres plenty of nitpicking to come. But since my most recent sampling of sparkling prose, several new examples have caught my eye.

title: In Performance: Dael Orlandersmith in Forever
description: This weeks video is a scene from Forever, Dael Orlandersmiths solo show about her troubled childhood and fraught relationship with her mother. In this scene Ms. Orlandersmith recalls a visit to the Pre-Lachaise cemetery in Paris, and talks about finding inspiration in the Doors. In his review, Charles Isherwood calls the show a raw and haunting work that holds the audience in a taut, quiet spell. Directed by Neel Keller, Forever continues through May 31 at New York Theater Workshop.

title: Anton Corbijn: Capturing the Mood of the Music
description: THE HAGUE  For 40 years, the Dutch photographer and filmmaker Anton Corbijn has captured some of the most iconic rock musicians and other artists of our era  Bono, Mick Jagger, Bjrk, William S. Burroughs, Clint Eastwood  for magazines and books. So at first glance his conceptual series, A. Somebody, featuring what appear to be images of his personal musical heroes, doesnt seem like a major departure.

title: Pinned by a Scam
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Fight, Then a Struggle in Lewiston
description: Lewiston, Me., hosted the heavyweight bout between Muhammad Ali and Sonny Liston in 1965, but the city struggled with declining population throughout the 20th century.

title: Big Law Firms Winning More of Intellectual Property Work
description: As disputes over patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets have grown, the nations biggest law firms have wrested away much of the lucrative intellectual property litigation work from smaller boutique firms.

title: A Foster Family, Forced to Focus on the Present
description: The details of my son Ryans milestones are clearly etched in my memory. The way he took his first steps around his first birthday, then promptly sat down and waited three more months before he stood up and walked across a room unassisted. He was a frustratingly late talker, but he would impress you now, at 4 years old, with his vocabulary and his use of casual expressions like, I was off like a shot!

title: The Night the Ali-Liston Fight Came to Lewiston
description: LEWISTON, Me.  A couple of times each month, with the rate accelerating during summer, a car will pull into the parking lot of a small, quaint multipurpose arena on Birch Street in this once-thriving mill city along the banks of the Androscoggin River.

title: The Mis-selling of TPP
description: One of the great blog posts of all time was from Daniel Davies, who declared  apropos of Iraq  that

title: Iran Sets Trial Date for Washington Post Reporter Jason Rezaian
description: TEHRAN  Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been detained in Iran for almost 10 months and accused of spying for the United States, will go on trial on May 26, the judicial authorities told the state news media on Tuesday.

title: Profit Slips at Walmart as Revenue Falls Flat
description: Walmart, the nations largest retailer, reported a drop in profits on Tuesday as it absorbed for the first time the effects of its decision to raise its employees wages.

title: Contest Aims to Harness Low-Cost Devices to Help the Poor
description: The timing and technology are right to bring the power of digital sensing to the poor to improve health, safety and education.

title: Aiming for a Comeback, RealNetworks Introduces the Photo-Sharing App RealTimes
description: After a hiatus from his company RealNetworks, Rob Glaser is hoping for a Steve Jobs-like comeback.

title: In London, Creative Types Celebrate an Old Architects Restored Apartment
description: This week in a palatial square in Londons legal district, the private apartment of Sir John Soane  the eminent Bank of England architect who started life as a bricklayers son  opens to the public for the first time in 160 years. Its a significant piece of real estate expansion that adds an entirely new floor, says the director Abraham Thomas of the chambers, which sit on the second story of the museum  Soanes spectacular former home, library and Regency architectural practice in Lincolns Inn Fields.

title: Daily Report: In Singapore, the Post Office Evolves for E-Commerce
description: When a German lingerie brand wanted to sell bras online in Malaysia, it turned to Singapores nearly 200-year-old national postal service, writes Alexandra Stevenson.

title: Should There Be a Minimum Age for Writing a Memoir?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and Benjamin Moser debate whether someone should reach a certain age before writing a memoir.

title: EDF, Worlds Biggest Nuclear Operator, Will Bid for Arevas Reactor Business
description: PARIS  EDF, the worlds biggest operator of nuclear power plants, is planning to make a bid for the reactor business of Areva in the next few weeks, EDFs chief executive said on Tuesday, confirming that a reorganization of Frances nuclear industry was at hand.

title: 1940: Reynaud and Ptain Pray
description: The bells in the ancient towers of Notre Dame Cathedral pealed through the bright afternoon sunshine yesterday [May 19] as thousands of Parisians gathered in the square below to take part in the special services attended by the highest figures in France to offer solemn prayers for an Allied victory.

title: Former Thai Premier Speaks Before Trial
description: Former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra of Thailand spoke on Tuesday outside the courthouse in Bangkok before the start of her trial on charges of criminal negligence.

title: Young Women Arent Sold on Hillary Clinton
description: Will young women rally behind Hillary Clinton? According to Molly Mirhashem at the National Journal, Mrs. Clinton needs them to be a base of her grassroots efforts, as fired up as young people were for Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012. But she may have a tough road ahead of her, because a Hillary Clinton presidency doesnt look like a victory to every young feminist.

title: More Outrage at Latest Depiction of Rape on Game of Thrones
description: A rape scene in Sundays episode of Game of Thrones has brought renewed criticism to this popular HBO fantasy series, which has previously drawn fire for what some viewers believe is its frequent and callous depiction of sexual violence.

title: Charlie Hebdo Cartoonist Who Depicted Muhammad After Attack to Leave
description: LONDON  The cartoonist known as Luz, who drew the polarizing cover of a weeping Prophet Muhammad for the first issue of Charlie Hebdo after the January attack on its office in Paris, is leaving the satirical French newspaper, saying the pressure had become too much to bear.

title: Faced With Legal Puzzles, Judges Often Turn to Fellow Jurists
description: Federal district judges are often described as the quintessential deciders, whether from the bench or in written opinions. But what happens when a difficult question arises, the parties are in sharp disagreement, and the answer is not obvious?

title: Tyler Johnsons Hat Trick for Lightning Was an Uncommon Version
description: When the Rangers string of gripping one-goal victories finally ran out, the main architect was Tyler Johnson. His hat trick on Monday night helped the Tampa Bay Lightning to a 6-2 victory and evened the Eastern Conference finals at one game each.

title: Pakistani Investigators Raid Offices of Axact, Fake Diploma Company
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Pakistani investigators on Tuesday raided the offices of Axact, a software firm in Karachi that has come under scrutiny for running a global diploma mill that made tens of millions of dollars through a network of fake online schools.

title: Mad Men Finale Draws 3.3 Million Same-Day Viewers
description: The much-anticipated series finale of AMCs Mad Men on Sunday drew about 3.3 million viewers live and on the same day, according to Nielsen data provided by Horizon Media.

title: Readers Turn: The Rat Race of College Competition
description: Each Tuesday, The Upshots newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

title: Behind the Poster: The Whale
description: Water as a motif flows through much of The Whale, Samuel D. Hunters 2012 play about Charlie, a morbidly obese man, and his troubled relationship with his daughter, Ellie. The title itself refers to a creature that lives in water. Charlie, who teaches writing over the Internet, refers to Moby Dick throughout the play. A sense of drowning  emotionally and spiritually  builds inside his cluttered home.

title: A Fight, Then a Struggle in Lewiston
description: Lewiston, Me., hosted the heavyweight bout between Muhammad Ali and Sonny Liston in 1965, but the city struggled with declining population throughout the 20th century.

title: 1965: U.S. Planes Hit North Vietnam
description: SAIGON  Forty U.S. planes today [May 19] pounded targets in North Vietnam for the second straight day after the failure of an American bid to force peace talks. A U.S. military spokesman said planes from the carrier Coral Sea inflicted severe damage on two targets  the Hoan Lao barracks and the nearby Chanh Hoa military radio station  about 40 miles north of the border. The planes raked the targets with 50 tons of bombs and rockets and radio-guided missiles. A five-day pause in the attacks on the North ended yesterday after Canada failed in efforts to get North Vietnam to agree to talks. Speculation was growing here that the United States would seek more important targets in the North, possibly in the industrialized Hanoi-Haiphong region, to increase the pressure for talks.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 20, 1965

title: Creative Figure to Be the New Face of Britains 20-Pound Note
description: LONDON  J.M.W. Turner? William Blake? Virginia Woolf? Who will be the face of the new 20-pound note?

title: Pandora Buys Next Big Sound to Track Popular Music
description: In the latest example of the music industrys rush over online consumer data, the music streaming service Pandora Media announced Tuesday that it had bought Next Big Sound, a six-year-old company that tracks the popularity of songs online and in social networks.

title: Why Were These Patients Legs Weak?
description: Twin sisters have trouble standing. A doctor thinks the problem is genetic.

title: Italy Drops Some Charges in Migrant Shipwreck Case
description: ROME  Italian prosecutors on Tuesday dropped charges of illegal detention against two men accused of being smugglers in the shipwreck of a boat loaded with an estimated 800 migrants that capsized in the Mediterranean last month.

title: Northern Ireland BakeryDiscriminated Against Gay Customer, Court Finds
description: DUBLIN  A Belfast court ruled on Tuesday that a Northern Ireland bakery discriminated against a customer by refusing to provide a cake with the words Support gay marriage inscribed on it.

title: Arrests Made in Waco Biker Gang Shooting
description: Sgt. Patrick Swanton, a spokesman for the Waco Police Department, said that 170 people had been arrested in the wake of Sundays shootout between rival motorcycle gangs in Texas.

title: My Long Trek Through Nepal, to Deliver a Stiff Drink
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Sometimes the most important thing you do on a reporting trip is not reporting. So it was two Saturdays ago, when I found myself scaling a mountain in Nepals Himalayan foothills to deliver a bottle of whiskey to an 80-year-old woman.

title: 4 Cancer Charities Are Accused of Fraud
description: There were subscriptions to dating websites, meals at Hooters and purchases at Victorias Secret  not to mention jet ski joy rides and couples cruises to the Caribbean.

title: Your Tired, Your Poor and Your Xenophobes at a Rebuilt and Re-Envisioned Ellis Island
description: The people who most love Ellis Island are used to nearly impossible tasks. In 1982, when they took up the challenge of making something out of the site, its long-abandoned historic buildings were in a state of dereliction hard to imagine today. In 2012, after Hurricane Sandy left the island almost completely underwater, another formidable rebuilding job presented itself.

title: In Iowa, Hillary Clinton Stays Vague on Trade
Javelina
description: A Tex-Mex restaurant in Gramercy Park.

title: Restaurant Review: Javelina in Gramercy Park
description: I like Texans. I love their food and their music and their boots. I admire their ability to tame landscapes that are hostile to human life. I respect how quick they are to stick up for their state and its culture. In fact, I may be slightly afraid of Texans. I have no desire to mess with them. I can read the bumper stickers.

title: Selling the Young on Gaming Fuel
description: Two popular video gamers in black T-shirts posed as snipers wielding real semi-automatic guns at an outdoor range, blasting orbs of fruit and cups of deep orange liquid in ultra slow motion. Introducing Blood Orange, announced a video of the spectacle.

title: Some Boys Ask, Whats a Barber, Mom?
description: Mariel Osborn was not trying to make a statement with her son Jacksons hair. The 2-year-olds shoulder-length mane is not a declaration about gender equality. Nor is it a commentary on obsessive parenting. Nor does it stem from religious customs.

title: Why Remingtons Investors Should Not Sell
description: Cerberus Capital Management dodged a bullet with its recent decision to let investors sell out of one of the worlds biggest gunmakers, Remington Outdoor. Its the company that made the assault rifle used to kill 20 children and six of their teachers in a Connecticut elementary school in December 2012.

title: In Normandy, a Summer-Ready Seaside Getaway
description: In Trouville, a gorgeous Belle Epoque bathing beauty  the Cures Marines Trouville Hotel  has just had a glamorous makeover. Part of a casino complex that opened at the southernmost edge of the Calvados communes famous white sand beach and boardwalk in 1912, the 103 rooms now echo the Norman coastline. Shades of sand, seafoam blue and slate fill the property thanks to the Paris-based architect Jean-Philippe Nuel, who also recently redesigned the legendary art-deco Piscine Molitor municipal-swimming-pool complex in the French capitals 16th arrondissement into a 124-room hotel. At the Cures Marines, Nuel highlighted Trouvilles proud literary pedigree with oversized, stenciled quotes about the port town on the walls from writers who lived, worked or played there, including Stendhal, Flaubert, Proust and Marguerite Duras, the author of The Lover, who lived in Trouville for many years.

title: N.F.L. Explores Making the 2-Point Conversion More Tempting
description: Your team scores a big touchdown. Time to stretch your legs, grab a snack, maybe chat with a friend about the game. Anything but watch the extra point, one of the most anticlimactic plays in sports.

title: Share Your Favorite David Letterman Memories
description: Update: We posted a compilation of Letterman moments and clips here.

title: E.C.B. Said to Be Unlikely to Cut Greece Loose
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank is not ready to pull the plug on Greece  not yet at least.

title: 6 Chinese Men Indicted in Theft of Code From U.S. Tech Companies
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday announced the arrest of a Chinese professor and the indictment of five other Chinese citizens in what it contended was a decade-long scheme to steal microelectronics designs from American companies on behalf of the Chinese government.

title: Top Aide to S.E.C. Chairwoman Mary Jo White to Step Down From Post
description: Mary Jo Whites top aide at the Securities and Exchange Commission is stepping down, the latest personnel move at the Wall Street regulator.

title: 4 Killed and Dozens Wounded in Suicide Bombing in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber detonated explosives packed in a car in a Justice Ministry parking lot on Tuesday afternoon in Kabul, killing at least four people and wounding dozens more.

title: Rise in Home Building Suggests U.S. Economy Is Regaining Momentum
description: Home building across the nation accelerated in April, far exceeding expectations and suggesting that the economy was getting back on track after overall growth ground to a halt during the first quarter of the year.

title: A Routine So Important Goalies Bend Over Backward for It
description: Cam Talbots locker sits next to Henrik Lundqvists, and as an unspoken sign of courtesy between the Rangers goalies, Talbot leaves the room before a game to give Lundqvist space to stretch.

title: Gerry Adams Shakes Princes Hand
description: Sinn Feins leader Gerry Adams commented ahead of a meeting with Britains Prince Charles on Tuesday in Ireland. The two men shook hands in a symbolic gesture.

title: Prince Charles and Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein Shake Hands
description: DUBLIN  It was a small gesture, but one with historical resonance, and it was not easy to say which man had reached farther to make it.

title: U.S. Says It Disrupted Major Heroin-Importing Operation in Bronx
description: There were few outward signs of the thriving heroin stash house that federal officials say was being operated on a quiet block in the Bronx across from Van Cortlandt Park. No one seemed to be permanently living in the apartment, 5E, at 210 West 251st Street, just outside the exclusive Fieldston neighborhood, officials said.

title: Driven | 2016 Honda HR-V
description: The Honda CR-V has been Americas best-selling crossover in seven of the last 10 years. So its new and smaller sibling, the HR-V, is a big deal.

title: Torture Still Widely Used in Morocco, Amnesty International Says
description: RABAT, Morocco  Violent interrogation methods are still widely used by the Moroccan authorities to crush dissent and forcefully extract confessions from detainees, even though the government has pledged for years to eradicate torture, a new report by the human rights group Amnesty International says.

title: The Ann Coulter Critique of American Christianity
description: My Sunday columndiscussed recent remarks from President Obama and the sociologist Robert Putnam on American churchesand the fight against poverty, in which both men suggested that culture-war fixations have sidelinedAmerican Christianitys mission to the poor. Given the sums raisedand man-hours invested by religious groups in charitable work, this is not a particular compelling argument; in fact,its pretty dumb, asa number of writershad already pointed outby the time I got around to the subject.So I added my voice to their chorus, but I also tried to raise one possibleway in which you could argue that the churches are failing poorer Americans: Not in their charitable works, but in the actual business of soul-winning itself, as evidenced by the fact that downscale Americans are both less likely than the affluent to attend church and less likely to attend, period, than in the recent past. And I noted that you dont even have to believe in the soul to see this as a failure: Since the social benefits of religion seem to flow through participation and belonging, even from a purely secular perspective (well, if such a thing exists) Americas churches would probably be doing more for the poor than charity alone can offer if they werekeeping more people in the pews.

title: A National Day of Action, for a Better America
description: Today, May 19, should have been the day that the United States took a step forward on immigration reform. Not an enormous step in the global scheme of things, but a huge one for the people it would have helped.

title: Rejecting the Cubicle for an Expanse of Space
description: In the era of the coffee-shop office, where a bit of countertop can be enough room from which to run a business, some tenants in New York are clamoring for a very different kind of workplace: one that spans a cavernous 100,000 square feet or more.

title: Airbag Recall Widens to 34 Million Cars as Takata Admits Defects
description: For more than a decade, the Japanese company Takata, one of the largest suppliers of airbags, denied that its products were defective even as motorists were killed by exploding airbags and automakers around the world recalled millions of cars equipped with its products.

title: New Rules for Guardrails Close a Testing Loophole
description: The Federal Highway Administration has tightened its standards for highway guardrails, closing a loophole that allowed guardrail makers to revise older devices without additional crash tests.

title: Hillary Clinton Answers Questions on Iraq, Emails, the Foundation and Wealth
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa  Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed reporters Tuesday, fielding questions on topics ranging from her personal wealth and her familys foundation to the deteriorating situation in Iraq, saying at one point that she had made a mistake as a United States senator in voting to authorize the war in Iraq.

title: Video Review: The Honda CR-V Gets a Little Brother, the HR-V
description: Consider that Hondas CR-V has been Americas best-selling crossover seven of the last 10 years. Ponder the Swiss Army knife interior of the Fit. Now, put the two into Seth Brundles teleportation chamber (without the fly, thanks) and you get HR-V. It joins Chevy Trax, Fiat 500X, Jeep Renegade and Mazda CX-3 in the current automotive it segment, the compact crossover.

title: Los Angeles Lifts Its Minimum Wage to $15 Per Hour
description: LOS ANGELES  The nations second-largest city voted Tuesday to increase its minimum wage from $9 an hour to $15 an hour by 2020, in what is perhaps the most significant victory so far for labor groups and their allies who are engaged in a national push to raise the minimum wage.

title: Patriots Wont Appeal N.F.L. Punishment, Owner Says
description: Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, who has been confrontational as his team warred with the N.F.L. over whether the Patriots inappropriately deflated footballs in a conference championship game four months ago, did an about-face on Tuesday, saying he would accept the leagues punishment and quit debating culpability.

title: Many Probiotics Taken for Celiac Disease Contain Gluten
description: Last year, doctors at Columbia University found that people with celiac disease frequently use probiotic supplements, but that those who take these products tend to experience more symptoms of the disease than those who do not.

title: Beyond Gin and Tonic
description: For many of us, there is only one summer cocktail: the gin and tonic.

title: Dueling Views on the First-Quarter Slump
description: No one really knows how fast the economy is growing, or indeed if it is growing at all. This question has started an unusual wonk war among economists working in different parts of the Federal Reserve system.

title: Iraqs Sunni Strategy Collapses in Ramadi Rout
description: AMIRIYAT FALLUJA, Iraq  More than a thousand Iraqi Sunni fighters stood at attention, dressed in camouflage but holding no weapons, as the tribal leader began exhorting them to fiercely battle the militants of the Islamic State, taking up rhetoric tinged with Arab notions of vengeance.

title: A Boston Photo Exhibition Focuses on a Disaster in Japan
description: The March 11, 2011, earthquake near Honshu, Japan, and the subsequent tsunami and nuclear meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, left an indelible mark on Japan  and the world.

title: Neil LaBute Withdraws a Play About Mohammed From a Fund-Raiser
description: An evening of short plays about censorship that lost its original venue because of concerns about a play by Neil LaBute making an off-color reference to a character named Mohammed has found a new performance space, but Mr. LaButes play will not be on the bill.

title: In Puebla, a New Rosewood Resort
description: Rosewood Puebla, the fourth Mexican property from the luxury hotel company Rosewood Hotels & Resorts, is likely to attract more high-end tourism in a historic destination famous for mole poblano and the painted ceramic tiles called azulejos.

title: Mass Roundup of Bikers in Waco Shootout Tests Limits of Court System
description: WACO, Tex.  The deadly shootout here on Sunday between rival motorcycle gangs has led to what appears to be the largest roundup and mass arrest of bikers in recent American history, experts said. As the roughly 170 people facing organized-crime charges in the case continued to clog up the local court system on Tuesday, new details emerged about the disputes that led to the violence.

title: MacDowell Colony Establishes Fellowship for Diversity
description: The MacDowell Colony, the prestigious artists retreat in New Hampshire, has announced it will finance an annual residency of up to two months to writers representing populations across racial and cultural boundaries.

title: Whats In and Out at Bergn
description: Headliner

title: Cannabis Coffee, Vegan Weed Bonbons and Other Emerging Marijuana Edibles
description: In states where pot has been legalized, demand for pot edibles has exploded, leading to a stunning assortment of mints, gummy candies and savory snacks infused with THC, the main psychoactive chemical in marijuana.

title: Looking at Appalachia Anew
description: Fifty years after the war on poverty highlighted need in Appalachia, Roger May set out to dispel stereotypes and redefine how the region was portrayed in photographs.

title: Sandra Lee, TV Host and Companion of Cuomo, Has Double Mastectomy
description: Sandra Lee, the television host and longtime companion of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, had a double mastectomy on Tuesday, a week after announcing she had breast cancer.

title: A Smoky Bourbon Cocktail from a Legendary Toronto Experimentalist
description: Impactful aromatics have always played an essential role in the creations of the Canadian mixologist Frankie Solarik. Inside BarChef, his Modernist cocktail laboratory on Torontos Queen Street West, multisensory presentations evoke the flavors of the season  not just in the glass, but surrounding it, too. Solariks Spring Thaw is served in a cool, perfumed fog of cedar, lilac and grapefruit, billowing from a bed of wet moss that nestles a glass of vanilla Campari granita swimming in chamomile gin and sparkling wine. That drinks a showstopper, wafting in all directions across the bar; a perennial Vanilla and Hickory Smoked Manhattan (the preference of the rappers Jay-Z and Drake) is more self-contained, infused tableside under one of two antique glass domes. If those drinks appear daunting to replicate, Solariks Canadian bestseller bar manual The Bar Chef: A Modern Approach to Cocktails ($30, Harper) is released today in the United States. And if the drinks recall the culinary artistry of Grant Achatzs Alinea, it will come as no surprise that the Chicago chef penned the books foreword. Grant came into BarChef in 2009 when we first opened, and his incorporation of aromatics and theater changed my life, Solarik recalls of the research trip Achatz took prior to opening The Aviary.

title: A Solution to Student Debt
Walmarts Raises
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Finances Social Returns
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Link Risky Burials to Ebola Rise in West Africa
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Only days after declaring the lowest number of new Ebola cases in Guinea and Sierra Leone this year, officials at the World Health Organization said Tuesday that there had been a nearly fourfold increase during the most recent week of reporting, to about 35 new cases.

title: Father Didnt Know Son Would Be Smuggled Into Spain in Suitcase, Lawyer Says
description: MADRID  The father of an African boy who tried to enter Spanish territory inside a suitcase said he got caught up with smugglers because his salary fell just a few euros short of the legal minimum required to apply for his sons residency in Spain, according to his lawyer.

title: The Semantics of Soaking
description: To the Editor:

title: A Difficult but Treatable Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: In Nell Zinks Mislaid, Sex, Race, Marriage and Other Cosmic Jokes
description: Early in Nell Zinks second novel, Mislaid, a young wife drives her husbands beloved car, a VW Thing, into a lake and walks away. As it sinks, it makes a sucking sound.

title: Art and Commerce
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stylists Diary
description: Lupita Nyongos stylist, Micaela Erlanger, shares personal snapshots of their experience at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Where Insurance Money Goes
description: To the Editor:

title: Boehner Urges Obama to Withdraw Request to Use Force Against ISIS
description: Just over three months have passed since President Obama sent a formal request to Congress for authorization to fight the Islamic State  a measure that was largely considered dead on arrival and that has languished on the Hill ever since, seeming to please neither Republicans nor Democrats.

title: The Modern American Shrub
description: A shrub is exactly what the people who invented the phrase slake your thirst had in mind.

title: Alicia Vikanders Glamorous Green Getup at Cannes
description: The Star: Alicia Vikander

title: Tanlines Share Their Influences
description: The electro-pop duo, whose album Highlights is out today, tells T about the clothes, books, podcasts and more that inspired the album.

title: Hillary Clinton Takes a Detour but Stays on Message
description: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa  Hillary Rodham Clinton followed a round-table discussion with small-business owners in Cedar Falls, Iowa, on Tuesday with an impromptu shopping trip in nearby Independence.

title: 1897: From Mary Jones to Mother Jones
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Tech Giants Urge Obama to Reject Policies That Weaken Encryption
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A collection of tech industry giants like Facebook, Google, Apple and Microsoft, as well as civil liberties organizations and Internet security experts, sent a letter to President Obama on Tuesday warning of the unintended consequences of any policy meant to weaken the encryption technologies that protect Internet communications.

title: Fudge Pop Perfection
description: The Fudgsicle was my move when the ice cream truck came around. But like so many childhood food memories, it just doesnt deliver in adulthood. So I went looking for a way to mix the fun and convenience of a chocolate ice pop with a better ingredient list and more sophisticated flavor.

title: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis Confirms a Hacker Attack
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis confirmed on Tuesday that hackers had successfully attacked the bank, redirecting users of its online research services to fake websites set up by the attackers.

title: Review: American Ballet Theaters Frenetic Anniversary Gala
description: For its big birthday year at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater, at 75, changed its approach: Instead of the traditional opening-night gala, the company got its feet wet last week with a wince-free run of classic repertory, or heritage works, by some of its early choreographers: George Balanchine, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins, Antony Tudor. A gala was inevitable, though, and on Monday the company presented nearly two dozen excerpts and seven speakers, many of whom tried mightily to explain what makes Ballet Theater so American. By Hour 2, it was like being trapped at an increasingly desperate pitch meeting.

title: Steve Jobs: A Cottage Industry of Movies and Books
description: Three weeks after the mercurial Apple co-founder Steve Jobs died, in October 2011, Walter Isaacson published an authorized biography that many then considered to be the definitive account of the billionaires life.

title: Turn Your Fruit Into Ice
description: One of our favorite rites of summer is the opening of our local water ice house. Now Martha Rose Shulman helps cool off with a new way to ice up your favorite fruits. Her mango and lime sorbet is tangy and not very sweet, with just enough sugar and corn syrup to allow the mixture to freeze properly without developing ice crystals.

title: Mattress Protest at Columbia University Continues Into Graduation Event
description: Aided by four friends, and to the cheers of some of her classmates, the student who protested Columbia Universitys handling of her sexual assault complaint by carrying  a mattress around campus all year hoisted it for the last time on Tuesday as she crossed the stage at a graduation ceremony.

title: Debate Over Currency Cheating Intensifies in Trade Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Thirty-six years ago, Japan lowered import tariffs on foreign automobiles to zero, ostensibly opening the worlds fourth-largest auto market to full international competition. Yet United States automakers say 93 percent of the cars on Japans well-tended roads are still made in Japan by Japanese companies.

title: American Innovation Lies on Weak Foundation
description: The iPhone in your pocket has more computing power than the Voyager spacecraft that left the solar system two years ago. High-tech cancer drugs are being approved every month. A few years into the future, Googles Calico project promises to extend our life span.

title: Like It or Not, Isiah Thomas Is the Story
description: The Liberty will kick off a new W.N.B.A. season with their annual media day Thursday. This years event will probably be the best-attended one in franchise history. The reason? Isiah Thomas, the teams new president, will be on hand alongside the players to face reporters.

title: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Burundi, Indonesia, Azerbaijan and Nepal.

title: Whitney Museum Names New Chief Curator: Scott Rothkopf
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, which just moved into a new home, will soon have a new chief curator, the museums director, Adam D. Weinberg, announced Tuesday.

title: May 19, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Burundi, Indonesia, Azerbaijan and Nepal.

title: A Weak Handshake Is Not Necessarily Bad News for Your Heart
description: Last week several headlines wrongly heralded the health effects of a handshake, saying that a firm shake could prevent a heart attack, while a weak one was a harbinger of an early death.

title: New Hampshire Republicans Call on Frank Guinta to Serve His Party by Resigning
description: CONCORD, N.H.  It is hard enough, in the best of times, for either party to hold the congressional seat in New Hampshires First District. In recent years, it has flipped back and forth between Republicans and Democrats like a Ping-Pong ball.

title: A Four-Bedroom Clifftop House Overlooking the Pacific
description: Part of a development called Pacific Marlin outside the town of San Juan del Sur, the house is on the market for $1.25 million.

title: Alessia Cara Speaks Up for the Outsiders on Here
description: Few songs move with the easy saunter of Alessia Caras debut single, Here. Shimmery and springlike, its elegant lounge soul, but its glow masks a tension at the core.

title: Review: New York New Music Ensemble Plays a Tribute Concert for Lee Hyla
description: A 29-year-old stewardess fell 1,500 feet to her death tonight, reported The New York Times on Oct. 20, 1962, when she was swept through an emergency door that suddenly sprang open on an Allegheny Airlines plane. What might Franoise de Moriere, who was found outside the town of Farmington, Conn., have felt on the way down? What might her fall mean? Thats the subject of James Dickeys intense 1967 poem Falling, now the basis of Mathew Rosenblums effective chamber piece, also called Falling (2013).

title: Palestinians Plan New Tack Against Israel: Soccer Sanctions
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian grievances against Israel are familiar ones: hampering travel, blocking import of equipment, rampant racism and the treatment of settlements in the occupied West Bank. The Israeli response is also a repeat: security concerns, mostly.

title: What You Get for  $650,000
description: This weeks properties include a modern house in California, a bungalow in Florida and a contemporary home in Montana.

title: Scott Walker Calls Himself the Most Scrutinized Politician in America
description: Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, is only just beginning to introduce himself to voters nationally. But in a presidential field that includes Hillary Rodham Clinton and, most likely, Jeb Bush, Mr. Walker sees himself as getting the most attention.

title: Potato Salad Done Right
description: A familiar face at a summer meal doesnt have to be prepared the same old way.

title: Takata Doubles Recall of Its Airbags
description: Anthony Foxx, the secretary of transportation, announced that the recall of defective airbags made by Takata now affects nearly 34 million vehicles.

title: A Composed Salad Is a Meal Unto Itself
description: Arranged on a plate rather than tossed in a bowl, this salad shows off vegetables, herbs and fruits  but can also have rich components like cheese, eggs and smoked meat.

title: Summer Dinner Ideas That Work Again and Again
description: Lobster butter, compound butters, dry rub and a marinade are easy, versatile flavor enhancers that can improve most everything they touch.

title: Review: In Sara Fellinis In Vestments, Haunted by More Than Ghosts
description: The teenager crouches on the rectorys kitchen floor, idly inking his forearm with a ballpoint pen. His face is bruised, his complexion pale green, his hair dusted with white. Hes a ghost, and a persistent one, trailing his older brother, Nathan, through life.

title: Brooklyn Museum Picks Anne Pasternak as New Director
description: The Brooklyn Museum announced on Tuesday that its next director would be Anne Pasternak, who has spent the last two decades as president and artistic director of Creative Time, a prominent arts organization that stages free projects, exhibitions and events at public sites throughout New York. Ms. Pasternak will succeed Arnold L. Lehman, who is retiring in June as director after nearly 18 years. He reshaped the museum in significant ways, seeking foremost to reach a larger, more diverse audience.

title: Review: Geros Amid the Mexican Student Protests of 1999
description: Shot in black-and-white, in the boxy, old-fashioned aspect ratio that seems to be the latest thing in art-cinema retro fashion, Alonso Ruizpalacioss Geros manages to feel both sweetly nostalgic and exuberantly now. It takes place in 1999, during a period of student unrest in Mexico, and many of the young people on screen, militants and slackers alike, live consciously in the shadow of 1968, when campus uprisings shook the country and were murderously suppressed by the military.

title: Living in Jackson Heights, Queens
description: Jackson Heights, a historic and heterogeneous neighborhood in north-central Queens, is less than a half-hour from Midtown.

title: Connecticuts Governor, Dannel Malloy, Calls on Congress to Lift Needle-Exchange Ban
description: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut called on Congress Tuesday to lift its ban on funding needle exchange programs, a subject that is getting increased attention because of rising intravenous drug use in several states.

title: A Look at Creative Time's Art Projects
description: Anne Pasternak, the new director of the Brooklyn Museum, led a number of notable public art projects at Creative Time.

title: Review: Netflixs Between Puts a Polite Damper on Growing Old
description: Not all Netflix series are created equal. Between, a Netflix original whose six-episode first season begins appearing weekly on this video-streaming site on Thursday, is a Canadian science-fiction series  Netflix money, north-of-the-border talent and formulas. So were talking about something a lot closer to the Syfy channel  home of Canadian shows like Bitten, Lost Girl and Continuum  than to Daredevil or Orange Is the New Black.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Im a Moderate Biker Gang Member Compelled to Condemn This Violence
description: On Sunday, a biker gang meeting at the Twin Peaks Restaurant in Waco, Tex., erupted in violence that claimed the lives of nine people and injured 18. This tragedy stemmed from the criminal actions of a fringe minority that does not represent the democracy-loving values of the majority of tolerant biker gangs devoted to freedom, denim, mutual understanding and leather accessories.

title: Tanlines Share Their Go-To Clothes, Books and Podcasts
description: I think when we wrote this album, we wanted to incorporate how we play live, says Tanlines Jesse Cohen of the duos sophomore record, Highlights, out today via True Panther. The last album sounds like it was written by two guys sitting in front of a computer. This one feels like it was produced in big rooms and on big stages. Cohen and his bandmate Eric Emm have been making music together since 2008; things really took off after the release of their debut LP, Mixed Emotions, back in 2012. I would say that Mixed Emotions thematically felt like an existential-crisis album, Cohen says. Highlights is about relationships and personal stuff. Its the tone of two people who have answered questions instead of asking questions, though there are some questions still. Nothing is ever figured out if youre as neurotic as the two of us are.

title: Laszlo Krasznahorkai Wins Man Booker International Prize
description: The Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai won the sixth Man Booker International Prize at a ceremony on Tuesday night in London. The prize, which comes with 60,000, about $93,000, is awarded every two years for a body of work published either originally in English or available in English translation.

title: France Answers Hostile Bids With the Two-Vote Share
description: For besieged public corporations in the United States, giving favored shareholders two votes instead of one sounds like an answer. France certainly thinks so.

title: Hillary Clinton Talks to Small-Business Owners in Iowa, Then Gives Reporters a Turn
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa  For close to an hour on Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton talked with owners of small businesses here about the issues on their minds, like whether they would enjoy better access to credit if small local banks were given regulatory relief and whether a major trade deal up for debate in Washington could wind up hurting American workers.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Signs Early Deal With Musicians
description: The Minnesota Orchestra, which just finished a tour of Cuba, announced on Tuesday that it had taken more steps to put its recent labor battles behind it, reaching a new contract agreement with its musicians that will give them raises and adds positions, and also extending the contract of the orchestras music director, Osmo Vanska, through the 2019-20 season.

title: Altice Bids for Cable Operator in St. Louis
description: After building up a French cable empire, Altice appears poised to extend its reach across the Atlantic.

title: Review: In the Music and More Series, Spouses in Harmonious Partnership
description: TriBeCa may have become one of New Yorks most desirable neighborhoods to live and shop in, but one thing thats in short supply there is music. Outside of upscale childrens birthday parties and the annual Tribeca Film Festival carnival, live performances are rare.

title: Happy Rockefeller, 88, Dies; Marriage to Governor Scandalized Voters
description: Happy Rockefeller, the socialite whose 1963 marriage to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, soon after both had been divorced, raised a political storm in a more genteel time and may have cost him the Republican presidential nomination in 1964, died on Tuesday at her home in Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 88.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: U.S. Military Space Plane Begins a Fourth (Mostly) Secret Mission
description: A secretive United States Air Force space plane is on a fourth trip into orbit.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: A Vow to Veto a Schools Bill in Minnesota
description: A visibly frustrated Gov. Mark Dayton of Minnesota pledged on Tuesday to veto an education funding bill that would lift state spending on schools by $400 million over the next two years  an increase that Mr. Dayton said was inadequate to serve the needs of Minnesota schoolchildren.

title: A Conversation With Michael A. Massari
description: Mr. Massari, 45, is the senior vice president for national meetings and events at Caesars Entertainment, the giant hospitality and gambling company based in Las Vegas. Caesars is currently involved in a nearly $126 million conference center project, the Waterfront Conference Center, at Harrahs Resort, one of its three properties in Atlantic City.

title: Computer Sciences to Split Into 2 Publicly Traded Companies
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation is the latest member of corporate America to break up as a way to raise its stock price.

title: Russia and U.S. Find Common Cause in Arctic Pact
description: MOSCOW  The recent diplomatic thaw between Russia and the United States over the crisis in Ukraine has had little impact there, but it is being felt somewhere else  in the Arctic Ocean, near the North Pole.

title: Data Suggests Legs and Toes in Ancestor of Living Snakes
description: From the robust boa constrictor to the venomous rattlesnake, all of the more than 3,400 snake species that slither today may have descended from the same prehistoric forest prowler, whose sinuous body had two small hind legs with toes and ankles, researchers reported on Tuesday.

title: Police Say Man Killed in Manhattan Hotel May Have Been a Pimp
description: Two men and two women checked into a room on Sunday at the Hilton Garden Inn on West 35th Street, one of the many chain hotels that now dot the side streets of Midtown Manhattan. They went upstairs to Room 2203. A few hours later, one of the men was dead.

title: Chinese Plan Investments and Loans for Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Extending a lifeline to the beleaguered Brazilian president, Chinese officials announced a sweeping list of investment plans and loans in Brazil on Tuesday totaling dozens of billions of dollars, including in a contentious project for a railway to the Pacific that would cut through the Amazon rain forest.

title: I.R.S. Look at Spinoffs May Affect Yahoo Plan
description: Marissa Mayers plan to spin off Yahoos $34 billion stake in Alibaba tax-free could run into resistance from federal tax authorities.

title: Rev. John Lo Schiavo Dies at 90; University President Barred Basketball
description: The Rev. John Lo Schiavo, who spent 14 years as president of the University of San Francisco, notably making headlines when he took the rare step of suspending the mens basketball program after repeated violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, died on Friday in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 90.

title: U.S. Details New Efforts to Support Ailing Bees
description: The White House on Tuesday outlined its strategy to restore the nations struggling honeybee and monarch butterfly populations to some semblance of health, mostly by expanding the acreage devoted to the wildflowers and milkweed that are crucial to their survival.

title: Torture Claims in Tunisia Await Truth Commission
description: TUNIS  One of the most notorious forms of torture was the roast chicken, an obscene stress position in which the victim was suspended naked, like a trussed bird on a spit.

title: Japanese Economy Grows at Fastest Pace in a Year
description: TOKYO  Japans climb out of recession accelerated unexpectedly in the first quarter of the year, the government said on Wednesday, as the economy grew at its fastest pace since the beginning of 2014.

title: Studies Confirm Brain Plaque Can Help Predict Alzheimers
description: The largest analysis to date of amyloid plaques in peoples brains confirms that the presence of the substance can help predict who will develop Alzheimers and determine who has the disease.

title: Landmarks Commission Rejects Plan to Change Interior of Four Seasons
description: The interior of the Four Seasons restaurant, a vision of Modernist elegance with its French walnut paneling and white marble pool of bubbling water, should not be changed, New York Citys Landmarks Preservation Commission decided on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Focuses on Top Venezuelan Officials in a Broad Cocaine Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Venezuelan officials are under investigation by the American authorities as part of a wide-ranging inquiry into the distribution of cocaine in the Western Hemisphere, American law enforcement officials said on Tuesday.

title: Boston MarathonBomber to Be Formally Sentenced in June, but Process Is Far From Over
description: BOSTON  Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who last week was condemned to death for his role in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, is to be formally sentenced late next month by Judge George A. OToole Jr., who presided over the four-month trial.

title: Gay Marriage on Ballot Shows Shift in Irish Attitudes
description: DUBLIN  If there was any doubt about the pace at which acceptance of gay rights is taking root in societies around the world, consider Ireland.

title: S.U.V. Drivers Wife on Attack by Bikers: We Needed to Get Out of There
description: A woman who was attacked along with her husband by a gang of bikers on the West Side Highway said on Tuesday that the motorcyclists were using knife handles to hammer on a window of their car just before her husband raced away, running over one of the men and breaking his spine.

title: White House Wont Upend ISIS Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Tuesday defended President Obamas strategy for countering Islamic State militants in Iraq, arguing that while the groups capture of the provincial capital of Ramadi had been a setback, it should not be taken as a broader sign that the American approach is failing.

title: N.B.A. Draft Lottery: Timberwolves Get First Pick, Knicks Fall to Fourth
description: Steve Mills, the general manager of the Knicks, leaned back in his chair and sighed as ESPN went to its final commercial break Tuesday night during the N.B.A.s annual draft lottery. The order of the top three teams had yet to be revealed, but Mills and the rest of civilization already knew that the Knicks would not be among them.

title: Insurgents Continue Advance in Syria, Keeping Pressure on Government Forces
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Insurgents continued to advance in the Syrian province of Idlib on Tuesday, fighters and antigovernment activists said, keeping up pressure on government forces despite President Bashar al-Assads vow to force them out of territory they have seized in recent weeks.

title: Lawmakers Back Broader Access to Contraceptives for Women in the Military
description: WASHINGTON  Both houses of Congress are moving to guarantee greater access to contraceptives for women in the military, actions that lawmakers say are prompted in part by concern about unplanned pregnancies in the armed forces.

title: High Cost of Sovaldi Hepatitis C Drug Prompts a Call to Void Its Patents
description: Activists in several countries are seeking to void patents on the blockbuster hepatitis C drug Sovaldi, saying that the price being sought by the manufacturer, Gilead Sciences, was prohibitive.

title: House Approves Short-Term Financing for Highways
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Tuesday approved a two-month extension of funding for transportation projects, setting up what could be a defining fight over money for highways and other infrastructure this summer after years of stopgap measures.

title: Jim Kenney Wins Philadelphias Democratic Primary for Mayor
description: Jim Kenney, a former Philadelphia city councilman who has cast himself as a progressive in the mold of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, handily defeated five other candidates to win the Democratic nomination for mayor Tuesday, which makes him the overwhelming favorite to be mayor when national Democrats gather in the city in 2016 to pick their nominee for president.

title: David Letterman, Prickly Late-Night Innovator, Counts Down to His Exit
description: In 1988, a rising comic named Jerry Seinfeld went to the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park for a Christmas party for Late Night With David Letterman. Mr. Seinfeld had just made a deal to do a sitcom for NBC, and he buttonholed Mr. Letterman in the corner of the restaurant and asked him for advice.

title: Snowden Sees Some Victories, From a Distance
description: WASHINGTON  For an international fugitive hiding out in Russia from American espionage charges, Edward J. Snowden gets around.

title: Proposed Rule Seeks Details on Antibiotics in Livestock
description: In a step aimed at tackling the growing problem of antibiotic resistance, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed a rule that would require makers of drugs for livestock to detail their antibiotic sales by type of animal. The drug makers already have to report total sales of antibiotics, but under the new rule, they would have to specify how much is meant for use in cows, pigs, chickens, turkeys and other animals  information that would help shape policies to most effectively address problems particular to each species. Consumer health advocates applauded the move, but said sales data was only a rough proxy for data on use. A more important step, they said, would be to require farmers to report how much antibiotics they use.

title: Wind Power Is Poised to Spread to All States
