description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Dance Listings for May 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, May 24 to 30, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 22-28
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jeb Bush Opens His Campaign Playbook by Opening Himself
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  His S.U.V.s motor was running and an open door beckoned. But Jeb Bush, quite possibly the most media-friendly hopeful in the Republican presidential field, was not done answering questions.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 24 to 30, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 22-28
description: Rapunzarella White

title: Movie Review: The Farewell Party
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews The Farewell Party.

title: Spare Times for May 22-28
description: Memorial Day Weekend Events in New York City

title: Review: The Farewell Party Finds Laughs in Euthanasia
description: The Farewell Party, an Israeli comedy about euthanasia, steers a careful course between humor and pathos while playing down overtly political and religious arguments for and against assisted suicide. The first feature of its creative team, Tal Granit and Sharon Maymon, The Farewell Party, which won them an Ophir Award (the Israeli Oscar) for best direction, is set in a Jerusalem retirement home in which one resident, an amateur inventor, devises a mercy-killing machine. News of the device leaks to the homes other residents. That inventor, Yehezkel, a robust bear of a man (Zeev Revah) and his wife, Levana (Levana Finkelshtein), a couple in their 70s, are distressed by the acute suffering of their friend Max (Shmuel Wolf), who is dying of cancer and against his will is kept alive by doctors. Maxs wife, Yana (Aliza Rozen), entreats Yehezkel to assist Max, however he can, in ending his agony.

title: Roves Crossroads PAC Is No Longer G.O.P.s Big Dog
description: WASHINGTON  For three election cycles, American Crossroads, the brainchild of Karl Rove and other leading Republican strategists, has been among the most powerful forces in national politics, a shadow party that has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on advertising, data and opposition research to help elect candidates.

title: Republicans Plan to Replace Health Law Is \_()_/ , Senator Says
description: At precisely 3:56 p.m. on Thursday, Senator Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced a popular Internet symbol for a careless shrug of the shoulders  \_()_/  into the Congressional record, holding it up on a placard and describing it as a pretty good summary of what the Republicans plan is, if the Supreme Court strikes down the Affordable Care Act this summer.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Movie Review: Aloft
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Aloft.

title: Review: Aloft Trains an Eagle Eye on Human Misery
description: Falcons and other large birds of prey are usually harmless to humans, unless recklessly deployed as metaphors. Helen MacDonalds best-selling memoir, H Is for Hawk, bravely and brilliantly flies in the face of this risk, daring to treat the training of a goshawk as a magnet for meaning. Aloft, Claudia Llosas new film, is not so lucky. There are some beautiful half-tamed raptors, and some lovely shots of them soaring and stooping, but their presence, rather than enabling the story to take flight, helps drag it down into a swamp of grim, portentous mumbo-jumbo.

title: Review: Childrens Orchestra Society Discovery Concert Features Two Soloists
description: For 12-year-old Alexandra Wong to play the challenging first movement of Schumanns Piano Concerto as articulately and sensitively as she did on Wednesday evening at Hunter Colleges Kaye Playhouse was most impressive. But what she did after that performance  a highlight of a concert by the Young Symphonic Ensemble of the Childrens Orchestra Society  was even more revealing of her musical depth.

title: Review: 500 Questions (No. 501: Whats a Certified Genius?)
description: I have an idea for a new game show: 500 Things That Are More Interesting Than ABCs 500 Questions.

title: Kayaking, Recreation, Death: Reporters Notebook
description: I have been covering a kayak murder case out of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for a couple of weeks and in the usual manner: I made phone calls, searched the Internet, knocked on doors.

title: Humza Arshad, British Pakistani Comedian, Takes On Jihadists
description: LONDON  HUMZA ARSHAD pokes fun at Pakistani accents and emotional soccer fans. He jokes about his weight, his voice and his own mother. But mostly, he laughs at jihadists.

title: Clip: When Marnie Was There
description: A scene from the film.

title: Review: When Marnie Was There, by Studio Ghibli, Animates a Friendship With Ominous Undertones
description: Beneath its calm, exquisitely detailed surface, When Marnie Was There bubbles with half-formed ideas and undeveloped themes. Suggestion and subtext jostle for attention, and the extent to which they intrude will depend mainly on the age of the viewer. To the tinies, this gorgeously animated adaptation of a 1967 young-adult novel by the British author Joan G. Robinson will seem a simple tale of friendship found and unhappiness banished. Others, however, could experience the storys sweetly supernatural drift as a veil for gnarlier intimations of child abuse, sexual awakening, ethnic confusion and even mental illness.

title: Movie Review: Tomorrowland
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Tomorrowland.

title: Goldman Sachs Meeting in Bay Area Shows Appetite for Tech
description: San Francisco  On the surface, Goldman Sachss annual shareholders meeting on Thursday was a yawn.

title: Calm Down. ISIS Isnt Winning.
description: WASHINGTON  THE fall of the Iraqi city of Ramadi on Sunday, and of the Syrian city of Palmyra on Wednesday, is a big gain for the Islamic State, but not an utter disaster, as many observers fear.

title: Review: Love at First Fight, a Romance in the Wild
description: When it comes to combat readiness, Katniss Everdeen has nothing on Madeleine Beaulieu (Adle Haenel), a feisty, defensive young woman who elbows and kicks her way through the French comedy Love at First Fight. For its first two-thirds, the film, written and directed by Thomas Cailley, seems to be groundbreaking. Then it slides into comforting familiarity.

title: Americans Start to Leave Air Base in Azores, and Locals Fear Economic Impact
description: LAJES, Portugal  Above the mirror in his barbershop, Joo Rocha has an old picture of American airmen filling all the seats and getting, of course, crew cuts.

title: Review: Seeds of Time, a Documentary on a Crusader for Crop Diversity
description: Sometimes the best a documentary can do is put an issue on the publics radar, and, as if to illustrate that idea, Seeds of Time opens with enormous close-ups of asteroidlike seeds floating in a void. But as the director, Sandy McLeod, goes on to track the efforts of a crusader for crop diversity, this often dry film gets stuck on certain points and leaves seed preservation feeling oddly abstract.

title: Review: In Something Better to Come, Growing Up in a Garbage Dump
description: Approach Something Better to Come with the same patience that the filmmaker exhibited in shooting it and youll be rewarded. That is, if your definition of rewarded includes being dismayed by the bleakness that exists on the edges of prosperity.

title: U.S. Offers Florida a Deal That Could Ease Budget Impasse
description: MIAMI  The federal government opened the door on Thursday to a compromise that could ease Floridas budget impasse, rooted in a disagreement over Medicaid expansion and the cost of caring for the uninsured.

title: Review: In Human Centipede 3 Theres No Humanity Left
description: A caldron of unspeakable acts and unpalatable language, The Human Centipede 3 takes the bottom-feeding standards of its previous chapters (released in 2010 and 2011) to new lows of debasement.

title: Justice Dept. Faults Two Mississippi Jails
description: Administrators at two Mississippi jails routinely keep inmates, including juveniles, in custody long after their court-ordered release dates and prisoners are often able to break out of their cells and assault other inmates, the Justice Department said Thursday in a report.

title: Clip: (Dis)Honesty
description: A scene from the film.

title: Exit From Refuge Was on Bin Ladens Mind
description: WASHINGTON  Osama bin Laden was considering leaving his hideaway in Abbottabad, Pakistan, just months before Navy SEALs stormed his compound and killed him, according to a trove of documents seized from his compound during the raid and declassified this week by the Obama administration.

title: Senate Is Sharply Split Over Extension of N.S.A. Phone Data Collection
description: WASHINGTON  With the federal governments bulk collection of phone records set to expire in June, senators remained deeply divided on Thursday over whether to extend the program temporarily or accept significant changes that the House overwhelmingly approved last week.

title: Jacob Jensen, Designer in Danish Modern Style, Dies at 89
description: Jacob Jensen, an industrial designer whose sleek minimalism exemplified the style known as Danish modern, most notably with the stereo systems and other audio products he created for the consumer electronics company Bang & Olufsen, died on May 15 at his home in Virksund, Denmark. He was 89.

title: CNBC Looks at Costs of Liars and Cheats
description: Lying is a crucial element of lots of scripted TV  false-identity dramas like Revenge, for instance. Its pivotal in some game shows, like GSNs Lie Detectors. So why not a documentary? On Thursday at 10 p.m., CNBC obliges with (Dis)Honesty: The Truth About Lies, an illuminating look at the whys, hows and how-oftens of the ancient practice. The program juxtaposes stories of people who have lied  two men from an inside-trader scheme; a woman who used a website that facilitates adulterous hookups; an N.B.A. referee caught in a betting scandal, and more  with studies on the nuts and bolts of lying. That research has produced counterintuitive findings. The high-stakes liars who make headlines, for instance, might draw a disproportionate amount of scorn. Yes, there are some big cheaters out there, says Dan Ariely, a professor at Duke University, but they are very rare, and because of that their overall economic impact is relatively low. On the other hand, we have a ton of little cheaters, and because there are so many of us, the economic impact of small cheating is actually incredibly, incredibly high.

title: Private Equity Executive to Be Released From Uruguay Prison
description: After languishing in prison for more than a year without facing charges, a private equity executive who once controlled Uruguays national airline will be released, the countrys Supreme Court announced on Thursday.

title: Review: (Dis)Honesty  The Truth About Lies Assumes Everyone Tells Them
description: There are little white lies that seemingly hurt no one and whoppers that wreak social and economic havoc. In between are various degrees of dissembling. That is the common-sense perspective of Yael Melamedes documentary, (Dis)Honesty  The Truth About Lies, which starts with the assumption that everyone lies to a greater or lesser extent; its just part of human nature.

title: Ira Harkavy, Common-Sense New York Judge, Dies at 84
description: In the annals of New York jurisprudence, the penalty was considered unprecedented: Judge Ira B. Harkavy of Brooklyn Civil Court sentenced a 77-year-old landlord to 15 days of house arrest in one of his own dilapidated apartment buildings.

title: Baltimore Prosecutor Lists Indictments
description: The states attorney for Baltimore City, Marilyn J. Mosby, read the charges against six Baltimore police officers in the death of Freddie Gray.

title: Review: Sunshine Superman, About the High-Flying Daredevil Carl Boenish
description: Glorious daredevilry is wrapped in a slowly evolving ache in Sunshine Superman, a bittersweet documentary about Carl Boenish, who looked at very tall things and saw an opportunity to leap.

title: Patchwork Oversight Allows Dubious Charities to Operate
description: James T. Reynolds Sr. first ran afoul of state regulators for the way he operated his cancer charity in the 1980s. But he kept going, hopscotching from state to state and helping to create new charities that received federal tax exemptions.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 22, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Tomorrowland, Aloft and The Farewell Party.

title: With Compost Program, Keeping Waste From Going to Waste
description: Dashing out the door on Monday afternoon, Wendy Toribio stopped short when she saw women from the citys Sanitation Department walking up to her home on 58th Avenue in Maspeth, Queens. They came bearing gifts: a brown bin and a smaller bucket, both for organic garbage, like food scraps.

title: 6-Year-Olds Murder Has Mexicans Seeking Answers to Youth Violence
description: MEXICO CITY  The case has caused a wave of anguish: A 6-year-old boy in northern Mexico murdered and a group of five adolescents, who the authorities said were playing a game of kidnap, apprehended for the crime.

title: Guatemalan President Dismisses a Close Aide
description: MEXICO CITY  Facing a political crisis that has led to mass demonstrations and calls for his resignation, President Otto Prez Molina of Guatemala shook up his cabinet on Thursday, dismissing one of his closest ministers.

title: Libertys Isiah Thomas Draws Attention, and Questions
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  About five minutes before Isiah Thomas arrived Thursday for his introductory news conference as the president of the Liberty, the players and coaches began to file in to grab seats along the wall. The room was full of more news media members than many of the players could recall ever having seen at the practice center.

title: California Farmers Offer Concession in Drought
description: LOS ANGELES  Faced with the increasing likelihood that the state will significantly cut their water allotment as a way to deal with the punishing drought, farmers in Californias Sacramento and San Joaquin river delta are offering to give up a quarter of the water they have considered guaranteed for more than a century. In exchange for the voluntary reduction, the farmers are asking the state for a promise of no additional cutbacks beyond the 25 percent.

title: New Communication System, Tested at Newark Airport, Could Ease Takeoff Delays
description: NEWARK  Imagine it is the Friday before a holiday weekend and you are on a plane about to take off from Newark Liberty International Airport, when a thunderstorm rolls right into the flights path.

title: Soul-Searching as Ireland Prepares to Vote on Same-Sex Marriage
description: One person described a vicious fight around the family dining room table. Another said her sister, mother and elderly grandmother were all on the same page. A third said his children couldnt understand why anyone would vote no.

title: Referendum in Ireland Could Complete a Rapid Shift on Same-Sex Marriage
description: DUBLIN  In 1993, Ireland was among the last countries in the Western World to decriminalize homosexuality. Some 22 years later, it could become the first to legalize same-sex marriages by popular vote.

title: Lundqvist Seeks to Put His Porous Performances Behind Him
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Many Rangers who came walking through the bowels of Amalie Arena after their morning skate Wednesday were dressed for the beach  wearing shorts and a T-shirt, sandals, maybe a baseball cap. A few others wore dress pants, some had sharp blazers, but only one player came striding through in a full suit.

title: Chris Christie Teases New Jersey News Media With Profanity, Jokes and Taunts (for Charity)
description: Gov. Chris Christie ridiculed New Jerseys largest newspaper, The Star Ledger of Newark, suggesting it provided a refuge for angry drunks.

title: Memorial Day Holiday Closings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Madame Bovary and Gemma Bovery Revive and Refract a Heroine
description: Flauberts Madame Bovary, the original desperate housewife novel, is one of those 19th-century classics that moviemakers keep going back to despite a mounting body of evidence suggesting it might also be one of those books that arent really filmmable. Among the many who have tried are Jean Renoir, Vincente Minnelli, Claude Chabrol and, for that matter, David Lean, whose Ryans Daughter is a loose knockoff of the Bovary story. And by coincidence there are two new versions coming this spring, both by young French filmmakers: Madame Bovary, directed and co-written by Sophie Barthes, which opens June 12, and Gemma Bovery (May 29), directed and co-written by Anne Fontaine.

title: Mauresmo Tries to Guide Murray to the Prize That Eluded Her
description: PARIS  Amlie Mauresmo made it past the quarterfinals at every Grand Slam tournament except the one that mattered most to her, the French Open.

title: Opposing Voices Inside and Outside McDonalds Meeting
description: As fast-food workers and their supporters rallied for higher pay outside, McDonalds shareholders gathered on Thursday at its headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill. Company officials are fighting to revive sluggish sales and convince people that McDonalds is a modern, progressive burger company. Some shareholders pushed the company to consider diverting money it is spending on stock buybacks to pay higher wages. McDonalds has stood by its position that it doesnt control pay decisions at franchised locations.

title: Bob Belden, Jazz Saxophonist, Composer and Historian, Dies at 58
description: Bob Belden, a jazz saxophonist, composer, arranger, bandleader and record producer who was both a historian of the music and a force in moving it forward, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Clinton Foundation Releases List of Speeches That Filled Its Coffers
description: The Clinton Foundation, facing heavy scrutiny of its fund-raising during Hillary Rodham Clintons 2016 presidential campaign, released on Thursday a list of paid speeches by the Clintons that generated at least $12 million for the organization.

title: Yemen: 5 Migrants Killed by Shells
description: Five Ethiopian migrants were killed Thursday in northern Yemen when the area where they were sleeping, close to the border with Saudi Arabia, was hit by shells, said a diplomat and aid officials. Parts of the border region have become a violent front in the conflict between a Saudi-led coalition and forces allied with Yemens Houthi rebels. The Ethiopians had sought shelter near an aid center in Haradh run by the International Organization for Migration, which has helped evacuate foreigners from Yemen. In a separate attack on Thursday, at least 19 people died when airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition struck a residential neighborhood in Dhamar, south of Sana, the capital, said an official at a nearby hospital.

title: More Money Considered for Health Agencies
description: A bill in the House of Representatives that aims to speed approval of drugs and medical devices would set aside $10 billion over five years for the National Institutes of Health and about half a billion dollars for the Food and Drug Administration, rare funding increases that the bills sponsors say will help carry out the sweeping legislation and spur biomedical innovation. The bill, 21st Century Cures, would pay for the measures in part with money from federally owned oil reserves, an unusual proposal that might meet opposition in the full House. The bill was approved unanimously by the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Thursday and was expected to be taken up for a vote by the full chamber as early as next month.

title: Review: In The Other Thing, a Ghostly Vigil Turns Ominous
description: The Other Thing, a new play by Emily Schwend, spikes a ghost story with a twist of feminism. That unusual recipe gives the play a certain novelty, but Ms. Schwends dark drama, which can be seen at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of the Second Stages uptown summer series, ultimately comes across as preposterous.

title: Review: The Sound and the Fury, Elevator Repair Services Take on Faulkner
description: Time flies and crawls, warps and balances, melts and freezes. It passes by before you know it and it stands still forever. All those contradictory kinetic clichs are pulsing away in Elevator Repair Services mesmerizing The Sound and the Fury, which opened on Thursday night at the Public Theater.

title: Something to Chew
description: Administrivial Sports in Crosswords Alert! Sports editor and crossword aficionado Victor Mather has written a piece on why we tend to see the same sports names pop up regularly in crosswords. You can read it here.

title: Make-Believe Sailors Get a Look at the Real Thing During Fleet Week
description: The actors who play sailors on a one-day shore leave in On the Town, the 1944 musical currently in revival on Broadway, learned long ago that the Bronx is up and the Battery down. But if life in New York had taught them lessons unfamiliar to Chip, Ozzie and Gaby, the shows three dazzled seamen  never, for instance, set foot in tourist-choked Times Square if you can help it  it had left them utterly unprepared for life aboard the very real U.S.S. San Antonio.

title: Sentencing Is Delayed for Ex-Rikers Captain Convicted in Inmates Death
description: In a Manhattan courtroom late Thursday afternoon, Terrence Pendergrass, a former captain at Rikers Island, waited to be sentenced on a charge of violating the civil rights of an inmate. Two tense hours later, the hearing was over and no sentence had been imposed, but the inmates father had confronted Mr. Pendergrass, accusing him of abandoning his son.

title: Staten Islanders Give Mayor de Blasio Cold Shoulder in Rare Visit
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio stood at the precipice of that cherished municipal feat: a friction-free visit to the only borough that never wanted him elected.

title: Tanaka Pitches 3 Innings in Rehab Start
description: Masahiro Tanaka made his first rehabilitation start with Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Thursday night, throwing 41 pitches over three shutout innings against the Durham Bulls.

title: Grueling Pace From Booth to Booth for Indomitable Postseason Voice
description: When Kenny Albert discusses the travel schedule behind his calling 28 N.H.L. playoff games since April 15, he is matter-of-fact, not boastful. His itineraries are as familiar to him as goaltenders saves.

title: Ladylike Loafers for Summer
description: In a slimmer shape and with feminine details, this old-man classic feels like the seasons staple.

title: Word of the Day | conspiracy
description: conspiracy  \kn-spir--se\  noun

title: Ex-Korean Air Executive in Nut Rage Case Freed From Prison After Sentence Is Cut
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A former Korean Air vice president who incited international condemnation by ordering a plane back to its gate in a rage over how she was served macadamia nuts was released from prison on Friday after an appeals court judge reduced her sentence.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 4:15 P.M. (Cinemax) AN OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN (1982) Just in time for Fleet Week, Richard Gere stars as Zack Mayo, a hardened loser who becomes a much better man through basic training in the Navy and the love of a good woman in Taylor Hackfords compelling drama. Louis Gossett Jr. won an Oscar for his performance as the drill instructor determined to beat self-respect into his charge; Debra Winger was nominated for her role as a local girl just waiting for the right guy in uniform to come along. And Up Where We Belong, the No. 1 hit written by Jack Nitzsche, Buffy Sainte-Marie and Will Jennings, and performed by Joe Cocker and Jennifer Warnes, won for best original song. Undeniably, theres an element of corniness to this, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. But that doesnt keep An Officer and a Gentleman from being a first-rate movie  a beautifully acted, thoroughly involving romance. If this summer hasnt previously had a wonderful Hollywood love story to call its own, it has one now.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Sometimes I close my eyes and imagine hes still alive.

title: Corrections: May 22, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Distant Marvels, by Chantel Acevedo
description: We tell ourselves stories in order to die. At least thats the case for Mara Sirena, the senescent narrator of Chantel Acevedos uneven fourth novel, The Distant Marvels, which turns Joan Didions line on its head. Mara Sirena finds relief in narratives, though for her, theyre not so much life-affirming as they are palliative. Nearing the end, she needs to let go of her most closely guarded secrets in order to greet death with equanimity. This is storytelling as hospice.

title: Gutshot, Stories by Amelia Gray
description: When Amelia Gray was asked in an interview if she would always be a writer, she said: If writing makes me feel like this for the rest of my life, Ill do it for the rest of my life, yes, of course. But maybe writing wont always make me feel like this and something else will replace it, and then Ill end up spending the rest of my life making candy or burning down churches. Gray, who is the author of two previous collections, AM/PM and Museum of the Weird, and a novel, Threats, does not need to change careers to achieve either goal  her new story collection, Gutshot, is a bizarre and darkly funny world made of molten sugar and the ashes of everything she has set alight.

title: Start of a Long Trip
description: Mark Z. Danielewskis House of Leaves, published in 2000, announced the start of a visually stunning literary career. In the Book Review, Robert Kelly called that debut wonderful, and described it as a story about a story about a story about a film about a house with a black hole in it.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BILL OF THE CENTURY: The Epic Battle for the Civil Rights Act, by Clay Risen. (Bloomsbury, $18.) The passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is often credited to the political leadership of Lyndon Johnson, or the moral force of Martin Luther King Jr. But in this finely delineated telling, the focus shifts to the unsung heroes and grass-roots activism that ensured the bills survival and triumph. In AN IDEA WHOSE TIME HAS COME: Two Presidents, Two Parties, and the Battle for the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Picador, $18), Todd S. Purdum recreates the legislative maneuvering around the bill, the words and actions of white men, he writes, who possessed the sole official agency to enact  or block  any such law.

title: Editors Choice
description: RISE OF THE ROBOTS: Technology and the Threat of a Jobless Future, by Martin Ford. (Basic Books, $28.99.) Ford shows how the job-eating maw of technology now threatens even the professionally nimble and the most expensively educated.

title: Subversive Pleasure
description: Many of the elements of Angela Carters stories have become commonplace in fiction and popular culture. Sexy vampires? Sure. The exploration of female desire? Yep. Fairy tales reworked in contemporary settings? An embarrassment of riches. What we dont have, of course, is any more Angela Carter stories.

title: The Familiar, by Mark Z. Danielewski
description: Turning thought into writing is an alchemical wonder, says Mark Z. Danielewski, Americas foremost literary Magus. He doesnt just transform leaden narratives like the haunted house tale (House of Leaves) or the teenage romance (Only Revolutions). He transmutes the pages of base books into rare new forms and formats. Alchemists of the past became cult figures by both keeping and revealing secrets. Danielewski actively uses social media to supplement his novels cryptic designs, and his website encourages followers to post recondite explications of his works. But MZD or Z, as he signs his books, is no mere masked Internet phenomenon. After one of his college readings, I witnessed cultists clutching ragged texts form a signing line worthy of the T.S.A.

title: The Millionaire and the Bard, by Andrea E. Mays
description: The Millionaire and the Bard, by Andrea Mays, is an American love story. It is the engaging chronicle of a sober, hard-working, respectably married industrialist of the Gilded Age who became obsessed with the object of his desire. Though generally frugal and self-disciplined, he was willing to pay extraordinary sums in order to put his hands on his mistress, to gaze at her lovingly and longingly, to caress her. To possess her only once was not enough for him; he craved the experience again and again, without limit.

title: The Book of Aron, by Jim Shepard
description: I finished reading The Book of Aron shortly before Yom Hashoah. In observance of the day of Holocaust remembrance, the PBS program Frontline screened the 1945 documentary Memory of the Camps. Partly edited by Alfred Hitchcock, the film is assembled from the scrupulously thorough footage shot by Allied forces as they liberated camps such as Dachau, Buchenwald and Bergen-Belsen. The narration, recorded by the British actor Trevor Howard in 1985 from the original 1945 script, sounds very strange to 21st-century ears. Although ample in its expressions of sympathy and disgust, it also conveys a tone of shocked navet, even a whiff of condescension. The camp survivors are seen but not heard, presented as pitiful, accorded no role in the telling of their own stories.

title: Essays
description: ONGOINGNESS

title: Medicine Walk, by Richard Wagamese
description: Not far into Richard Wagameses Medicine Walk  his ninth novel, and one that, given its earnest embrace of legend and myth, feels less written than painstakingly etched into something more permanent than paper  we learn that its young protagonist, an Indian named Franklin Starlight, is a master outdoorsman. Among other things, Frank knows the value of ammunition. He never wasted a shot. He tracked and waited and bided his time until the animal offered the best possible target. He never rushed.

title: Blogging Begins
description: Brad DeLong has a little note on how and when he began blogging, which comes at a perfect moment for me  Im scheduled to talk with some Oxford undergraduates about changing forms of communication in economics, and Brads note both tells his own story and jogs my memory about how things changed in the late 1990s.

title: Gay Dating Apps New Alert: Hooking Up Is Illegal Here
description: The creators of GPS may not have envisioned that in addition to helping people navigate a cross-country road trip, or just find the nearest Starbucks, the tool would be a key component of gay dating and hookup apps like Grindr and Scruff. Finding the hot guy is only half the battle, after all. The other half is figuring out if hes near you.

title: South Korea: Ex-Executive Is Freed in Ruling on Nut Rage Episode
description: A former Korean Air vice president who had ordered a plane back to its gate in a rage over how she was served macadamia nuts was released from prison on Friday after an appeals-court judge reduced her sentence, striking down one of the charges against her: illegally forcing the plane to change its route. The former executive, Cho Hyun-ah, was sentenced to 10 months in prison on Friday on charges of violating aviation safety laws. But the court suspended the sentence for two years, meaning she will not serve more prison time as long as she does not commit a crime in the next two years. Ms. Cho, whose father is the chairman of Korean Air, was sentenced to a year in prison in a lower-court ruling in February. She forced a Korean Air plane to return to the gate at Kennedy International Airport in New York on Dec. 5 so the chief steward could be removed. She was angry that a flight attendant had served the nuts without first asking her, then in an unopened package rather than on a plate, according to court documents.

title: Tianjin Universitys Response to Professors Indictment in U.S.
description: Two days after the United States Justice Department announced the indictments of six Chinese scientists suspected of stealing technology, including three professors from Tianjin University, the Chinese state news agency Xinhua published a response from the university titled: Tianjin University Expresses Serious and Grave Concern Over Prosecutions of Its Professors.

title: When Every Day Is Memorial Day
description: Over time, so many things lose their meaning. The sting of death, the heartbreak of loss, which loomed so large in the national consciousness after the Civil War, spurred ceremonies that led to Memorial Day. The horrific carnage of World War I  the war to end all wars  led to commemorating military sacrifice from all conflicts. But today, Memorial Day, like other holidays, has been reduced largely to a day for sales, sleeping in or going out.

title: Private School Tax Credits
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortions for Rape Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Conditions That Put Sanitation Workers Lives at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Bias on Social Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Building Spiritual Capital
description: Lisa Miller is a professor of psychology and education at Teachers College, Columbia University. One day she entered a subway car and saw that half of it was crowded but the other half was empty, except for a homeless man who had some fast food on his lap and who was screaming at anybody who came close.

title: In the Heat of the Pacific Trade Battle
Trade and Trust
description: One of the Obama administrations underrated virtues is its intellectual honesty. Yes, Republicans see deception and sinister ulterior motives everywhere, but theyre just projecting. The truth is that, in the policy areas I follow, this White House has been remarkably clear and straightforward about what its doing and why.

title: The Sins of Angelenos
description: LOS ANGELES  ENJOY the end of your spring, America. Here in California, ours was over a long time ago.

title: The Escalation of Unauthorized Wars
description: It seems like ages ago now. But its worth remembering how Americas latest war in the Middle East began.

title: On Trade, Dont Leave Workers Behind
description: International trade typically produces winners and losers. Consumers benefit when they pay less for imported goods than similar domestic products. Some American workers are clearly hurt when foreign competition leads factories to shut down or move overseas. Thats why economists have long argued that government should help those displaced by the dynamics of freer trade.

title: Chinese University Denies Its Professors Stole U.S. Trade Secrets
description: BEIJING  A Chinese university has denied that three of its professors who are among six Chinese scientists charged in the United States with economic espionage and theft of trade secrets stole technology, the Chinese state news media reported this week.

title: Test Yourself | Long-Haired Boys and Their Happy Parents
description: Below are several paragraphs from the May 19 article Some Boys Ask, Whats a Barber, Mom?

title: 6 Qs About the News | Your Tired, Your Poor and Your Xenophobes at a Rebuilt and Re-Envisioned Ellis Island
description: In Your Tired, Your Poor and Your Xenophobes at a Rebuilt and Re-Envisioned Ellis Island, Neil Genzlinger reviews new exhibitions at the Ellis Island National Museum of Immigration.

title: HSBC Considering Strategic Options for Brazil Business
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC confirmed on Friday that it was exploring strategic options for its Brazil business, including selling it.

title: Howard Johnsons, Orange-Roofed Symbol of Bygone Era, Returns to Lake George
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y.  To many children brought up in the 1950s, 60s and 70s, the restaurants with the orange roofs and blue spires were a staple of family road trips from coast to coast  an almost mandatory stop for fried clam strips, an orange freeze and a strawberry sundae.

title: Florence Welch Slows Down the Machine for the Bands Next Album
description: Throughout a surprise club show in Brooklyn this month, Florence Welch of the British rock band Florence and the Machine was stuck on a stool. It was a strange confinement for a performer whose natural state is crisscrossing a festival stage as her red mane and silken gowns float in the breeze. Which is pretty much what she was doing at Coachella last month before she jumped into the crowd and broke her right foot.

title: Mazda, Mitsubishi and Subaru Recall Vehicles Over Takata Airbags
description: TOKYO  Three Japanese carmakers said on Friday that they would recall more than 700,000 vehicles equipped with airbags made by the supplier Takata, citing the companys admission this week that its airbags contained potentially dangerous faults.

title: Diary of a Bookstore and a Wimpy Kid
description: Jeff Kinney, author of the Diary of a Wimpy Kid series, is opening a bookstore. If one kids life is changed because of this bookstore, then the whole thing was worth it, he says.

title: Obama Plans New Rule to Limit Water Pollution
description: The Obama administration is expected in the coming days to announce a major clean water regulation that would restore the federal governments authority to limit pollution in the nations rivers, lakes, streams and wetlands.

title: The Bookstore Built by Jeff Kinney, the Wimpy Kid
description: If anyone knows how to sell books, its Jeff Kinney.

title: New York City Water Views for $500,000 or Less
description: Theres water, water everywhere in New York City, a place mostly made of islands. But sometimes, walking through its dark canyons, you would hardly know it.

title: How Important a Role Has Money, Work or Social Class Played in Your Life?
description: Thats a big question, we know, but its one that inspired the seven winning college essays in a recent contest run by the Business section.

title: Sale of K-Y to Reckitt Benckiser Raises Competition Concerns
description: LONDON  British regulators have raised concerns that the consumer goods maker Reckitt Benckisers planned acquisition of the K-Y brand of personal lubricants from Johnson & Johnson could lead to higher prices.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: May 22
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the World Trade Center observatory, fans waiting for David Letterman and Fleetweek.

title: Learning to Embrace Sexualitys Gray Areas
description: It would be 88 days until I saw her again. Sitting quietly on my bed as I packed my last belongings into two suitcases, she began to cry.

title: Ask Well: Massage and Toxins
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Abby Wambach, Unconcerned With Broken Records or Nose, Craves World Cup Title
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  The Irish goalkeeper reached to punch the ball away and cracked Abby Wambachs nose with her forearm. Wambach began to bleed profusely. Her nose tilted slightly to the left, like a weather vane.

title: Lessons on End-of-Life Care From a Sisters Death
description: The health care professionals entering my sisters hospital room, or answering my questions in the corridor, had perfected a polite method of ascertaining whether I was entitled to information about her condition.

title: New York Today: See Forever, Weather Permitting
description: Good morning on this gusty Friday.

title: Nerves Fray Over New French Open Stadium Plans
description: PARIS  For at least a little while longer, the turtles can live and swim in peace.

title: Hong Kong and Mainland China to Partly Open Markets for Investment Funds
description: HONG KONG  Six months after a groundbreaking link between their stock markets took effect, Hong Kong and mainland China announced on Friday that they would partly open their respective markets for investment funds.

title: Eurozone Economy Is Improving, E.C.B. Chief Says, but Outlook Is Muted
description: SINTRA, Portugal  The eurozone is in better shape than it has been since the beginning of the financial crisis, but political leaders need to overhaul their chronically underachieving economies, the president of the European Central Bank said on Friday.

title: To Feed More, Food Pantries Learn From Supermarkets
description: Nearly a million and a half people rely on food pantries in New York City, and Lugeily Duran is one of them. She was laid off from her job in a medical office and now works as a home health aide at night. She has a husband, who is jobless, and two small boys.

title: Not One of Us
description: I have a name, fingerprints, a fine white scar from the time I put my fist through a window, various pieces of identification and a briefly diverting life story, but to those who see me on the street, especially after dark, I am probably a rando. I may be a rando when I cross your field of vision, but I am definitely a rando when my physical presence intrudes upon yours without introduction, perhaps when I mistake your hotel room for the one where the bash is being held or when I walk into the elevator just as you are venting to your colleague. If I should try to strike up a conversation, I will be consigned to the flames as some rando.

title: His New Old New York Neighborhood
Bill Gross Thinks the End Is Near
description: You had a tough 2014. In September, you left Pimco, the investment firm you founded in 1971, where you became known as the bond king. What was the hardest part about the past year for you? The fact that I was fired. That was hard  very hard  for me, because Im sensitive. Im just sensitive to negative criticism  which I think was unfair and unjust. You havent been divorced yet, have you?

title: Where Ott and Orr Are Most Valuable: 15 Across, or Maybe 7 Down
description: Mel Ott hit 511 home runs in his career and was a worthy entrant to the Hall of Fame. By most measures, he falls just a bit short of greats like Babe Ruth, Walter Johnson and Hank Aaron.

title: To Fly and Die
description: Not long ago, I stood with some friends at Taft Point, a promontory 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley. It was a perfect morning, with nothing but fresh-scrubbed mountain air between us and the wind-polished face of the worlds largest granite monolith, El Capitan, in the distance. We edged close enough to the void to start trembling.

title: Re: The Witnesses
description: After the publication of Jay Caspian Kangs May 10 cover article about Johnetta Elzie and DeRay Mckesson, two of the black activists at the heart of the national protest movement against police brutality, Melissa Harris-Perry devoted segments of her show on MSNBC to the story. She spoke with Mckesson, Kang and other guests about the movement. Harris-Perry asked Wesley Lowery, a reporter from The Washington Post, how journalists view their own role in the protests theyve covered in Ferguson, Mo., and elsewhere.

title: The Lonely Fight Against Belizes Antigay Laws
description: Rozco! Love you, hon! cried a man in baggy jeans. His shout, insincere and taunting, was aimed at the back of Caleb Orozco, a 41-year-old man walking along a row of tarp-covered souvenir stands near one of Belize Citys ferry terminals. Orozcos only acknowledgment was to walk a little faster, car keys clutched in his hand. It was a hot December afternoon, a week before Christmas, high season in the citys tourist zone. Two policemen appraised Orozco but said nothing as more taunts flew. Saw you on TV! a woman dressed in white jeered from her craft stand, where she sold carved wooden boats. Farther down the sidewalk, two men snickered. Caleb! You done rub too hard! leered a man in a blue baseball cap, pointing to Orozcos crotch.

title: How Kentucky Became a Confederate State
description: In the late winter of 1865, Abraham Lincoln was completing a reconciliation-themed second Inaugural Address, pledging the nation to embrace the end of slavery that this mighty scourge of war may speedily pass away.

title: Today in Politics: No Time for a Lazy Summer as Campaigns Ramp Up
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the Senate still has some work to do, even if the House has already left for the holiday. Memorial Day is, after all, a time for beer and Twitter. But, this election season, it is no longer a time of leisure.

title: But What Does the Trade Deal Mean if Youre Not a Cheesemaker?
description: I have spent the past few months trying, and failing, to reach a clear assessment of the upsides and downsides of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the proposed economic agreement among the United States and 11 other countries. This might be because I dont own a dairy farm.

title: American Jailed for Theft Describes Conditions in a Chinese Detention Center
description: In a report it issued last week about the widespread abuse of detainees in Chinas criminal justice system, Human Rights Watch interviewed dozens of people who claimed to have been mistreated and tortured while in police custody. Nearly all of them were given anonymity so they could speak to investigators without fear of retribution from the Chinese authorities.

title: Morning Agenda: Vote Allowed on Export-Import Bank Extension
description: VOTE ALLOWED ON EXPORT-IMPORT BANK EXTENSION  | On Thursday, supporters of the Export-Import Bank won a key concession from the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who agreed to hold a vote to extend the banks life beyond June,  Jonathan Weisman reports in The New York Times. The concession was the result of last-minute negotiations that eventually led to the passage in the Senate of legislation that would empower the president to complete a 12-nation Pacific trade accord, the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

title: Reader Idea | Talking About Home Countries With English Language Learners
description: Here is the third of three Reader Ideas weve posted this week. Were hoping they persuade you to use the long weekend  or the coming summer vacation  to write in and tell us how you have taught with The Times.

She had been discussing the small-business economy at a round-table gathering at a bike shop here on Tuesday when the Fox News correspondent Ed Henry interrupted. When, he shouted, would she take questions from the news media she had ignored for weeks on end?

title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Bombing at Saudi Mosque
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The Islamic State extremist group claimed responsibility Friday for a suicide bombing during midday prayer at a Shiite mosque in eastern Saudi Arabia. The Saudi Health Ministry said at least 21 people had been killed and more than 120 others injured.

title: Texas, Land of Multiple Calamities: Reporters Notebook
description: HOUSTON  The 21st century had barely started when then-Gov. Rick Perry claimed it on behalf of the State of Texas. You might say historians will look back on this as the Texas Century, Mr. Perry said at his last inaugural address in Austin in January 2011. Americans once looked to the East Coast for opportunity and inspiration, then to the West Coast. Today they are looking to the Gulf Coast. They are looking to Texas.

title: Hamburglar and Colonel Sanders Are Back to Sell Fast Food
description: At McDonalds headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., is a room employees call the pulse. It contains a large television monitor and several computer screens. And this month, it was where the fast-food companys marketing team and agency partners waited for the Hamburglar.

description: If this tale were fiction, the contest between the duo renowned as the M&M Boys might seem too contrived. In the summer of 1961, the Yankees Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle competed to break the home run record of a Yankee predecessor, the most famous baseball player of them all, Babe Ruth  60 during the 1927 season.

description: LONDON  The reinsurer PartnerRe said on Friday that it would move forward with its planned merger with its rival Axis Capital Holdings after the Italian investment company Exor effectively rejected an offer to engage in further discussions on a competing bid.

title: Police Shut Down Mosque Installation at Venice Biennale
description: The police in Venice closed an art installation in the form of a functioning mosque on Friday morning, after city officials declared the art project a security hazard and said that the artist who created it, Christoph Bchel, had not obtained proper permits and had violated laws by allowing too many people inside the mosque to worship.

title: How the Pentagon Wasted $36 Million
description: No government department gets what it wants more than the Pentagon. After 9/11, it had a virtual blank check to fight the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Even now, the top civilian and military leaders are lobbying Congress for a bigger budget in 2016 and many lawmakers are all too eager to indulge them.

title: What to Do When Its Time to Pay for All That Knowledge
description: AFTER the mortarboards are thrown into the air comes the reality of student loan payments.

title: The E-Notary Public Is Slow to Catch On
description: When it comes to closing on a mortgage, nothing is final until the notary public says so. Charged with officially affirming the transactions legitimacy, notaries apply their legal stamp of approval after verifying the borrowers identity and willingness to enter into the loan.

title: 1915: Railway Disaster in England
description: LONDON  The worst railway disaster in England in twenty-six years took place this morning [May 22] at Gretna, north of Carlisle. A troop train from Stirling dashed into a local Carlisle train and the London-Glasgow midnight express crashed into the wreckage. The troop train suffered most, bursting into flames. A hundred persons were killed and as many as three hundred injured. The troop train, carrying 500 Highlanders, collided shortly before 7 oclock with the local train from Carlisle as the latter was being sided to allow the London-Glasgow express to pass.

title: Republicans Sharpen Contrasts With One Another
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas have yet to even speak at the Southern Republican Leadership Conference, but the presidential hopefuls who addressed party activists on Thursday indicated the nascent Republican primary is shifting a to a new, harder-edged phase.

title: Ireland Votes in Referendum on Same-Sex Marriage
description: DUBLIN  In the final hours of a political campaign that could make Ireland the first country to adopt same-sex marriage by a popular vote, support for the measure trickled in from overseas and from an even more unexpected place: some of the clergy in this Roman Catholic country.

title: Home Run by Pitcher Madison Bumgarner Evokes a Bygone Era
description: There is once again talk about the National League giving in to the tide of history and adding the designated hitter rule. If it does, it will mean an end to that delightful but rare event, the home run by a pitcher.

title: 1940: More Power for Churchill
description: LONDON  After less than an hours debate, the House of Commons today [May 22] passed the emergency enabling bill proposed by Lord Privy Seal Clement Attlee, which gives to the government sweeping powers to mobilize all Britains human and material resources for prosecution of the war. The bill, which is considered one of the most drastic in Britains long Parliamentary history, makes Prime Minister Winston Churchill a virtual dictator and grants his War cabinet absolute control over private property, industry, labor, the banks, and, more important still, the rights of the individual. The powers are extended for two years and apply equally to North Ireland. In a solemn House, Mr. Attlee gave the bill its second reading and emphasized the gravity of the hour with the declaration that everything for which we stand is in jeopardy.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 23, 1940

title: Cecilia Bartoli to Sing Maria in West Side Story
description: Cecilia, Ive just met a girl named Cecilia? The Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli plans to sing the role of Maria next year in a new production of West Side Story under the baton of Gustavo Dudamel at the 2016 Salzburg Whitsun Festival, the festival announced Friday.

description: There are a lot of ways for a novelist to create suspense, but also really only two: one a trick, one an art.

title: The Three Dramas of Mad Men
description: Ive struggled all week to come up with something fitting to say as a send-off to Mad Men, a show that Ive watched faithfully  if eventually more out of duty than pleasure  for last seven years. In the end, I think the struggle reflects the fact that I experienced the show as three distinct dramas, and I had very different perspectives on each one.

title: I.R.S. Seeks to Define Political Activity for Nonprofits
description: The Internal Revenue Service could issue as early as next month new draft regulations governing political activity by tax-exempt organizations, according to a notice issued on Thursday. But it remains unlikely that the new rules would be in place before the 2016 election.

description: On Super Tuesday of the bitter 2008 Democratic primary campaign, a group of Barack Obama supporters riding the New York City subway noticed Audrey Gelman wearing a Hillary Rodham Clinton campaign button on her jacket.

title: A Hillary Clinton Match-Up With Marco Rubio Is a Scary Thought for Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  They use words like historic and charismatic, phrases like great potential and million-dollar smile. They notice audience members moved to tears by an American-dream-come-true success story. When they look at the cold, hard political math, they get uneasy.

title: The Four Seasons
description: A look at the Four Seasons restaurant in the Seagram Building.

description: There is a slow-motion heartbreak happening on East 52nd Street.

title: Overvalued in Silicon Valley, but Dont Say Tech Bubble
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It is a wild time in Silicon Valley. Two-year-old companies are valued in the billions, ramshackle homes are worth millions and hubris has reached the point where otherwise sane businesspeople muse about seceding from the United States.

title: Michael Sam Signs With Montreal Alouettes of C.F.L.
description: Michael Sam, the first openly gay player to be drafted by the N.F.L., has signed with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, the team announced Friday.

title: Inside the List
description: Mean Girls: A couple of years ago, when the subject of likable characters in fiction resurfaced courtesy of Claire Messuds The Woman Upstairs, the debate touched not only on gender  nobody complains about bad boys, Messud noted  but on genre, with some commentators suggesting unlikable heroines are automatically seen as more literary. But of course pop fiction has long embraced difficult women: Consider Gillian Flynns Gone Girl, which blithely ruled the best-seller list even as the likability argument raged around it. Now theres another mean girl in the clique: Ani FaNelli, the protagonist of Jessica Knolls Luckiest Girl Alive, new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 12. Ani writes a sex column for a womens magazine and schemes to land a trophy husband; some reviewers have called her the mirror image of Amy Dunne in Gone Girl, since Ani seems purely manipulative at the start but becomes more human as the book reveals its secrets. Knoll, a former editor at Cosmopolitan and Self, told me theres a feminist case to be made for unlikable women. Men who are ruthless and aggressive in pursuit of their goals are acting within their culturally sanctioned bounds, she said via email, and we admire them for that. Women who do the same are punished because that hard-nosed behavior is counter to how we believe women should be, which is kind, nurturing and selfless. The knee-jerk reaction is to dismiss Ani as vain and vapid. But when we reward women for showing their full range of humanity, warts and all, when we give their struggles weight, we allow for the possibility that their flaws and stories can endear, inspire and move us, just like those of men. A little spice is O.K., in other words, but please hold the sugar.

title: Dutch Government to Proceed With Sale of ABN Amro Shares
description: LONDON  The Dutch government announced plans on Friday to proceed with a sale of shares of the state-owned lender ABN Amro, possibly via an initial public offering as soon as the fourth quarter of this year.

title: MarquesAlmeida Wins 2015 LVMH Prize
description: MarquesAlmeida, the British label designed by Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, has scooped up the 2015 LVMH Young Designers Prize. With it the designers win not only 300,000 euros (about $333,000), fashions biggest cash windfall for a new brand, but also a years mentorship from executives in the worlds largest luxury group. They also get the LVMH stamp of approval, an invaluable asset when it comes to persuading retailers to invest in a young name.

title: Hypocritical Sloth
description: Yesterday Politico posted a hit piece on Elizabeth Warren, alleging that shes being hypocritical in her opposition to a key aspect of TPP, thats interesting in several ways. First, it was clearly based on information supplied by someone close to or inside the Obama administration  another illustration of the poisonous effect the determination to sell TPP is having on the Obama teams intellectual ethics. Second, the charge of hypocrisy was ludicrous nonsense  You say youre against allowing corporations to sue governments, yet you were a paid witness against a corporations suing the government! Um, what?

title: Piles of Overseas Profits Investors Can See but Not Touch
description: It has become a $2 trillion question. Why dont companies have to make clear exactly how much of their profits are generated offshore each year and not taxed in this country? Why must investors engage in jujitsu to estimate these figures and the risks associated with them?

title: Franklin James Fisher on Protests, the South and an Algiers Album
description: Overeducated and underemployed during the financial crisis in 2009, Franklin James Fisher, the singer of the protest band Algiers, took a job as a bilingual receptionist at a French investment bank. While he formed some lasting friendships at the New York office, it was an old boys club, he said, recalling rampant racism and sexism. A really nasty atmosphere.

title: Chicano Batman Serves Latin Rock With 60s Spice
description: Chicano Batman, from Los Angeles, plays an expanded version of 1960s Latin rock, with wah-wah pedals and organ  the kind of music a lot of non-Latin North Americans seldom heard before the age of scholarly CD reissues uncovering long-ago scenes in Peru, Chile, Brazil and Southern California. What it does is jammy, fuzzed-out and discursive, full of soul vocals and twin-guitar arrangements; it brings together elements of cumbia, bolero, vallenato and the Brazilian pop experimentalists of the late 60s and early 70s. The band members play in ruffled, powder-blue tuxedo shirts and deliver party music from top to bottom, with stylish attention to tube amps and analog warmth. But their sets are serious business: You can climb into one of them and follow it a long way. Theyre rarely in New York but will perform three times this week: Sunday at the Loisaida Festival, in the East Village (loisaidafest.org); that evening at Brooklyn Bowl, in Williamsburg (brooklynbowl.com); and on Wednesday at Subrosa, in the West Village (subrosanyc.com).

title: Manfred Honeck to Conduct New York Philharmonic
description: With his low-key, affable charm, the Austrian conductor Manfred Honeck rarely draws attention to himself. But the stellar work he has done with the Pittsburgh Symphony and a few highly successful guest stints with the New York Philharmonic have made him one of the contenders to succeed Alan Gilbert in New York when he vacates the job of music director. Players and audiences can test the chemistry this week at a series of concerts beginning on Thursday, featuring the magnificent violinist Augustin Hadelich in Mozarts Violin Concerto No. 5 Turkish, Brahmss Fourth Symphony and the overture to Strausss Die Fledermaus. (Avery Fisher Hall Thursday at 7.30 p.m., Friday at 2 p.m. and Saturday at 8 p.m.; nyphil.org)

title: David Duchovny Returns With a New Series, and The X-Files
description: SANTA MONICA, CALIF.  I watch my daughter when she watches TV, and she never turns on a TV, David Duchovny said recently at a seaside lounge here.

title: Places to Grow, and Plenty of Help
description: Most ballerinas would be happy just to dance in new works created for them by four choreographers. But Wendy Whelan is also dancing with her choreographers, making them her partners in Restless Creature, her program of duets. The choreographers and their works are Kyle Abraham, The Serpent and the Smoke; Joshua Beamish, Conditional Sentences; Brian Brooks, First Fall; and Alejandro Cerrudo, Ego et Tu.

title: Summer TV: New Series, Mini-Series and Movies for Those Bored With the Beach
description: From practical magic (Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell) to bare-knuckle politics (David Simons Show Me a Hero), from Cold War spies (Deutschland 83) to kung fu masters (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: The Green Legend)  here are 13 new series, mini-series and movies to watch out for on television this summer. (Dates are subject to change.)

title: Charles Ray: Sculpture 1997-2014 Is at the Art Institute of Chicago
description: Charles Ray, one of todays most critically admired sculptors, has since the 1970s produced an extraordinarily varied oeuvre whose common thread has been a preoccupation with reality and illusion. Since the late 1990s, he has been creating works of terrific technical ambition and sometimes controversial subject matter. For Charles Ray: Sculpture 1997-2014, the Art Institute of Chicago has devoted the 18,000 square feet of its second floor Modern Wing to just 17 pieces, affording lots of breathing room for each. Horse and Rider (2014), a full-scale equestrian self-portrait, will be displayed elsewhere in the museum. Its one of four works in the show that have not been previously exhibited.

title: Kehlani and Nick Catchdubs Release New Albums
description: Juggaknots

title: Sophia Loren in Titanus Film Retrospective at Lincoln Center
description: She had come to Hollywood in the mid-1950s only to be treated as eye candy  Hollywood might be forgiven  and Sophia Loren went home to Italy intent on proving that I am not a sexy pot, but a serious actress. There, she made Two Women for the great Vittorio De Sica, a wrenching story of a mother trying to protect her 12-year-old daughter from the horrors of World War II, and was awarded a best actress Oscar in 1962, the first for a performer in a foreign language film.

title: Handel and Haydn Society Celebrates 200 Years
description: BOSTON  In a classical music world grappling for cultural traction, anniversaries have come to substitute for genuine invention. Sometimes they prove productive, like this seasons festivities for Pierre Boulezs 90th birthday, or New Yorks explorations of Meredith Monks 50 years onstage. But too often, they just provide an excuse for yet another performance of a Sibelius or a Mahler symphony, another heavily marketed Beethoven cycle.

title: Clinton Hill Home Designed for an Artist: $8.5 Million
description: A former union hall at 315 Vanderbilt Avenue in Brookyn that underwent an imaginative 2008 renovation that transformed it and a vacant parking lot next door into a studio/residence/oasis for the artist Jennifer Bartlett is poised to enter the market at $8.5 million.

title: Infidelity Lurks in Your Genes
description: AMERICANS disapprove of marital infidelity. Ninety-one percent of them find it morally wrong, more than the number that reject polygamy, human cloning or suicide, according to a 2013 Gallup poll.

title: Friday Night Music: New From Lucius
description: Again, its late afternoon where I am, and Im going off for drinks. So here we are.

title: Finding a Candidate Youd Like to Have a Beer With
description: It is the time of the year when dreams of running into the likes of Jeb Bush or Hillary Rodham Clinton in a bar just might come true.

title: Bronx Boy, 14, Killed in Point Blank Shooting Caught on Surveillance Video
description: Early on Friday, Christopher Duran, 14, left his home on a Bronx street lined with brick apartment buildings and dotted with trees. He made a stop at a nearby laundromat and then, his family said, he headed off to school, walking with his younger brother and a friend.

title: FGM: A Modern-Day Scourge in the United States
description: When Jaha Dukureh created aChange.orgpetition to tackle female genital mutilation, or female circumcision, in the United States last year, her goal was modest: 1,000 supporters.

title: Young Saudis, Bound by Conservative Strictures, Find Freedom on Their Phones
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Life for many young Saudis is an ecosystem of apps.

title: The Vicious Cycle of High Inequality
description: Conservative political leaders and economists often say that we should not worry about growing inequality because it is not hurting growth or the ability of poor people to become richer by simply working harder. Many liberals have long rejected that argument and a report out Thursday provides fresh evidence that income inequality is indeed bad for the economy and appears to be self-perpetuating.

title: Shamirs Distinctive Voice
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the singers blend of different genres.

Pamela Paul is the host.

title: What to Learn in College to Stay One Step Ahead of Computers
description: Computers and robots are already replacing many workers. What can young people learn now that wont be superseded within their lifetimes by these devices and that will secure them good jobs and solid income over the next 20, 30 or 50 years? In the universities, we are struggling to answer that question.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Shakespeare in Love
description: This week, Alan Riding and Michelle Orange.

title: Feeling Waters Pull
description: Memorial Day  a day of remembrance for the dead  begins the high season for New Yorkers romance with the water. Like clockwork, people move to the often neglected edges of the land, in search of something they cant get online. We shed layers of clothing, and we shed layers of restriction, the photographer Susannah Ray said. We move into these waters that were inaccessible in winter, but arent inaccessible anymore.

title: Myanmars Navy Seizes 2 Boats Carrying Over 200 Migrants

title: De Blasio Is Not Insulting Enough to Be Popular
