description: GILROY, Calif.  About 3,000 miles from New York, members of a camera crew gathered around Anthony Quijada, trying to do for their not-famous, not-rich client what some high-priced lawyers are doing for theirs in New York courts: Make a video that can keep him out of prison.

title: U.S. Defense Secretary Blames Iraqi Forces for ISIS Victory in Ramadi
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Sunday that Iraqi forces had demonstrated no will to fight against the Islamic State, blaming them for a retreat that led to the terrorist groups victory in capturing the Iraqi city of Ramadi.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49); 9:30 P.M. (21) NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT For the 10th year, Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna will host this annual broadcast from the West Lawn of the Capitol; this years event will honor disabled veterans and Gold Star Children, an organization for those who have lost a parent to war, and observe the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II. The American Idol winner Nick Fradiani will sing the national anthem. Gloria Estefan (above), Laura Benanti, Tessanne Chin, Katherine Jenkins, Jason Dolley and Russell Watson will perform with the National Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jack Everly.

title: John Nashs Nobel Prize Ceremony
description: John F. Nash Jr. shared the 1994 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his work on noncooperative games theory.

title: After a Fire, a Pastor Keeps a Harlem School Going From His Brownstone
description: The sounds of children once again fill the ground floor of the Eatmans brownstone on West 119th Street. This was not exactly the plan the Harlem couple had envisioned after raising four of their own children. But as the Rev. Charles Eatman Sr. knows, few things  other than the Ten Commandments  are written in stone.

title: Cleveland Streets Are Calm, but Anger Lingers Day After Officers Acquittal
description: CLEVELAND  The 10 a.m. service at Elizabeth Baptist Church should have been a joyous occasion. It was Pentecost Sunday. The weather was beautiful. Worshipers applauded schoolchildren who received As and Bs on their report cards.

title: Tomorrowland Is a Box-Office Disappointment
description: LOS ANGELES  Disneys big-budget Tomorrowland was a relative bust at the domestic box office over the holiday weekend, a result that will likely make Hollywood even more reluctant to invest in original stories.

title: Nico Rosberg Wins at Monaco After a Crash and Blunder
description: MONACO  A late-race accident by a 17-year-old driver with no drivers license, along with a little too much television watching by the race leader and an over-optimistic calculation by his team caused a sudden reversal of fortune that cost Lewis Hamilton certain victory at the Monaco Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: The Taste That Doesnt Really Satisfy
description: Imagine a meal made of the milk left in the bottom of a bowl of cut-rate cereal, the liquid thickened with sweepings from the floor of a health food store, and you have some sense of what it is like to consume the protein-packed shakes that have replaced Flamin Hot Cheetos and Red Bull in the diets of some tech workers in Silicon Valley.

title: In Busy Silicon Valley, Protein Powder Is in Demand
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Every night, Aaron Melocik, a software developer, follows a precise food routine. He blends together half a gallon of water, three and a half tablespoons of macadamia nut oil and a 16-ounce bag of powder called Schmoylent. Then he pours the beige beverage into jars and chills them before bringing the containers to work the next day at Metrodigi, an education technology start-up.

title: Roger Federer Is Not Amused With Fans Selfie
description: PARIS  A traditionalist, Roger Federer has long struggled to adapt to the new, cheek-to-cheek world of the selfie.

title: Uncertainty and Helplessness Become a Way of Life in Nepal
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  I am not the old me.

title: Afghans Form Militias and Call on Warlords to Battle Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Facing a fierce Taliban offensive across a corridor of northern Afghanistan, the government in Kabul is turning to a strategy fraught with risk: forming local militias and beseeching old warlords for military assistance, according to Afghan and Western officials.

title: Juan Pablo Montoya Wins the Indy 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Sometimes people ask Juan Pablo Montoya, whose intensity can be mistaken for anger, if he still enjoys racing.

title: At Cannes Film Festival, Dheepan Wins Palme dOr
description: CANNES, France  The 68th Cannes Film Festival came to a surprising close on Sunday night when the Palme dOr was awarded to Dheepan, Jacques Audiards tense drama about three Sri Lankan refugees struggling to assimilate in a violent French ghetto only to end up in a pastoral British backyard. The movie was well received by critics if far from a passionate favorite.

title: The New Dictators Rule by Velvet Fist
description: THE standard image of dictatorship is of a government sustained by violence. In 20th-century totalitarian systems, tyrants like Stalin, Hitler and Mao murdered millions in the name of outlandish ideologies. Strongmen like Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire left trails of blood.

title: A Stand for Peace
description: A group of female peace activists calling for a formal end to the Korean War crossed the demilitarized zone from North Korea to South Korea on Sunday.

title: The Rohingya Migrants Plight
description: Migrants at sea find very little welcome in Southeast Asia.

title: Anne Meara, Comedian and Actress, Dies at 85
description: Anne Meara, who was half of one of the most successful male-female comedy teams of all time and who went on to enjoy a long and diverse career as an actress and, late in life, a playwright, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: 911 Call About Motorcyclists
description: Rosalyn Ng describing the scene of motorcyclists surrounding the vehicle that she was riding in on Sept. 29, 2013.

title: Review: American Ballet Theaters Giselle Bounds as Past Giselles Watch
description: Every year, American Ballet Theater announces, more than half a year in advance, not only some eight or nine programs for its eight-week May-July season at the Metropolitan Opera House but, for some of them, as many as eight casts. This establishes a climate of balletomania, where dancers matter as much as repertory; and usually the Met balletomanes reach peak frenzy in late June, with Ballet Theaters productions of Romeo and Juliet (love, death and acting) and Swan Lake (love, death and fouett turns).

title: Review: DanceAfrica Festival Bids a Percussive Farewell to Chuck Davis
description: In 1977, when Chuck Davis planted the first seed for his DanceAfrica festival, he presented his company in the Lepercq Space at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where he built an African village. Now in its 38th year, the event continues at the academys opera house as a beloved tradition that rings in Memorial Day weekend with a cacophonous bang.

title: Fusion Media Aims at Millennials, but Struggles to Find Its Identity
description: In 2011, when Isaac Lee, president of news for Univision, set out to persuade his company and Disney to back Fusion, a digital news service and cable channel he wanted to start, he promised nothing less than the holy grail: young viewers for the older media conglomerates.

title: Review: David Rosenboom: Propositional Music, an Avatar of Experimentalism
description: Whats a major art museum without a performance space for music? The inviting new Whitney Museum downtown in the old meatpacking district has a nice one, the Susan and John Hess Family Theater. It may not be big but its going to be popular.

title: Review: The Last Alaskans, a New Animal Planet Series
description: The word Alaska or a variant of it in a reality-show title sets you up for low expectations. The Last Alaskans, an affecting series that begins Monday on Animal Planet, defies quite a few of them.

title: Todd Hayness Film Carol Draws Attention at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  In 1952, the year the American Psychiatric Association declared homosexuality a sociopathic personality disturbance, readers began discovering Patricia Highsmiths lesbian romance The Price of Salt. Initially published under the name Claire Morgan  the cover promised a modern novel of two women  it involves a nave 19-year-old, Therese Belivet, whose world spins deliriously off its axis when she meets the older Carol Aird, a lovely blonde whose voice, Highsmith wrote, was rich and supple, and somehow full of secrets.

title: Bronislaw Komorowski, Polands President, Concedes Defeat to Right-Wing Challenger Andrzej Duda
description: WARSAW  Andrzej Duda, the photogenic, 43-year-old candidate of Polands leading right-wing party, stunned the nations political establishment on Sunday by wresting the presidency from the incumbent, Bronislaw Komorowski, who is allied with the party that has governed during eight years of stability and prosperity.

title: Review: The Last Two People on Earth Offers Soft-Shoe Aprs Dluge
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The singular talents of Mandy Patinkin and Taylor Mac  yes, you read that correctly  combine to delightful effect in The Last Two People on Earth: An Apocalyptic Vaudeville, the weird and weirdly transfixing entertainment having its premiere here at American Repertory Theater.

title: Review: Grace of Monaco, a Fractured Fairy Tale on Lifetime
description: Grace of Monaco is a Lifetime movie, showing on Monday, that stars Nicole Kidman as Grace Kelly in a not-so-happily-ever-after stage. Its not good, of course, but it is kind of great, almost irresistible. This is a star-studded, lavishly made drama that falls into that special niche: If it were any better, it would be worse.

title: Behind the Downfall at BlackBerry
description: Ever since Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis stepped down as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of BlackBerry, neither has spoken much in public about the once-dominant smartphone makers fall into near market obscurity. The two and many others have opened up, however, to two reporters from The Globe and Mail in Toronto: Jacquie McNish, a senior business writer and author of several books and Sean Silcoff, who reports about the company. The resulting book, Losing the Signal: The Untold Story Behind the Extraordinary Rise and Spectacular Fall of BlackBerry, which will be published in the United States on Tuesday, fills in some details of the early history of BlackBerry. And its later chapters offer gripping details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding its near collapse.

title: Appropriate Exclamation
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  A very happy Memorial Day to you all, and a big thank you to those who have served and who continue to serve our country.

title: Amazon to Stop Funneling European Sales Through Low-Tax Haven
description: In the continuing battle between Europe and American tech companies, score one for Europe.

title: Lincoln Center President Received Increase in Bonus in Final Year
description: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013, his last year with the organization, according to recent tax filings.

title: Olsen Twins Wont Appear in Full House Reboot
description: Youre in big trouble, mister! The coming Netflix reboot of Full House will move forward without Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, the twins who took turns playing the cheeky Michelle Tanner on the 90s sitcom. Although Ashley and Mary-Kate will not be a part of Fuller House, I know how much Full House meant to them and they are still very much considered family, said Robert L. Boyett, the shows executive producer, in a statement given to The Hollywood Reporter. The Olsen twins started filming in the role of Michelle at 9 months old, and remained on the show for its full eight seasons. They now run Dualstar, a lifestyle and fashion company. The new season will center on other members of the original Tanner clan, including D. J. (Candace Cameron Bure) and Stephanie (Jodie Sweetin). The Olsens former co-star John Stamos, who announced the shows return on Jimmy Kimmel Live last month, tweeted that he was heartbroken the twins would not be returning. Still, theres always a chance theyll change their minds: David Lynch recently returned to the revival of Twin Peaks after renouncing his ties to the project.

title: Lincoln Center President Saw Increase in Bonus
description: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013, his last year with the organization, according to recent tax filings. The bonus was on top of his $1.29 million salary and pushed Mr. Levys total compensation package to $2.4 million, including retirement payments and other benefits, up from $2.2 million the previous year. The bonus was based on annual reviews of his performance and his project performance, said Eileen McMahon, a representative for Lincoln Center. She also noted that the bonus, first reported by The New York Post, was based on 18 months of work, not 12. Mr. Levy spent 11 years as president of the performing arts center, where he was renowned for his fund-raising abilities and applauded for completing an ambitious $1.2 billion renovation project. His recently released memoir, They Told Me Not to Take That Job: Tumult, Betrayal, Heroics, and the Transformation of Lincoln Center, depicts the interior struggles over the renovation and included criticism of other New York cultural executives.

title: Review: Afterword, the AACM (as) Opera Lends a Voice to Stories of Black History
description: African-American stories are rarely reflected in opera. But within the span of three weeks, three composers have brought new works to the stage that draw their subject matter from black history.

title: Review: Another Persons Poison, Matthew Smiths Book on Food Allergies
description: If you grew up food-allergic in the late 20th century, you probably grew up haunted by the ghost of Katherine Brodsky, the Brown University student with a peanut allergy who died in 1986 after eating chili at a restaurant in Providence, R.I. The chili had been thickened with peanut butter. It took two spoonfuls to kill Ms. Brodsky.

title: Olsen Twins Wont Appear In Full House Reboot
description: Youre in big trouble, mister! The coming Netflix reboot of Full House will move forward without Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, the twins who took turns playing the cheeky Michelle Tanner on the 90s sitcom.

title: The Heat Is on Greeces Alexis Tsipras, From Inside and Out
description: ATHENS  With Greece in the final stretch of negotiations with its creditors, aimed at unlocking rescue loans the country needs to avert an imminent default, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces growing pressure from the ranks of his own party.

title: Columbia Emerges as a Surprising Force in Baseball
description: On Monday at noon, the Columbia baseball team will gather for what has become a happy, if unlikely, ritual. After practice, team members will go to an athletic complex lounge on 218th Street in Upper Manhattan and watch on television as their program is selected to the 64-team field of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: In Britain, Libor-Rigging Conspiracy Case Is Also a Test for Regulators
description: LONDON  Banks have paid billions. Regulators and prosecutors have extracted guilty pleas from financial institutions. Dozens of employees have been fired, and at least one chief executive has lost his job.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of May 25
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes an auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Catholic Church Ponders Future After Same-Sex Marriage Vote in Ireland
description: DUBLIN  The morning after Ireland learned it had become the first nation to approve same-sex marriage by popular vote, Diarmuid Martin, the archbishop of Dublin, looked out at the future of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Anne Meara Remembered, Through Reviews and Twitter
description: Anne Meara, a comedian, actress and playwright who teamed up with her husband, Jerry Stiller, to form a formidable decades-long comedy duo, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Obama Weighs Strategy as Data Laws Run Out
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is weighing what the looming expiration of three counterterrorism laws  including the provision that has been cited to allow the National Security Agency to vacuum up logs of Americans phone calls  would mean for future operations, even as officials say the wind-down process for the bulk calling data program has already begun.

title: Growing Up in the Gas House District
description: Dear Diary:

title: Police in Florida Grapple With a Cheap and Dangerous New Drug
description: MIAMI  A hazardous new synthetic drug originating in China is being blamed for 18 recent deaths in a single South Florida county, as police grapple with an inexpensive narcotic that causes exaggerated strength and dangerous paranoid hallucinations.

title: El Bronco: Blunt, Frequently Vulgar, and Aiming to Run Nuevo Len
description: MONTERREY, Mexico  He goes by the nickname El Bronco, and he aims to buck the political system in Mexico.

title: The Poetry of Raymond Carver Makes a Leap to E-Books
description: Raymond Carver, the noted author of short stories and poetry, died nearly 27 years ago, long before the digital revolution upended the publishing industry. And until now, his legacy has been confined to print.

title: The Wisdom of a Beautiful Mind
description: While John F. Nash Jr. often said he had regained his mental health by rejecting irrational thought, these remarks show a profound understanding that such thought could not be separated from the mathematical ability for which he was acclaimed.

title: Opposing Views of Menace at Trial in Motorcycle Assault
description: Prosecutors presenting evidence against two motorcyclists accused of taking part in a gang assault on a young family have put a larger phenomenon on trial: wild motorcycle tours, organized on the Internet, that occasionally rip through New York City, with riders snarling traffic, doing stunts, running red lights and generally creating a nuisance.

title: A Comedian Who Stood in a Range of Spotlights
description: Anne Meara was well known for the stand-up act she shared with her husband, Jerry Stiller. But her life in show business had many facets.

title: Law Firm Fraud Trial; Silk Road Sentencing
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: In Some Cases, Pants (Not Shorts) Make the Goaltender
description: PHILADELPHIA  Conditions were relatively cool Saturday in Philadelphia, which wound up be being a good thing for Denver goalkeeper Ryan LaPlante. Besides the bulky gear he wore on his head and torso, LaPlante jogged onto the field with something a little more unusual: a pair of baggy gray sweatpants, cinched at the waist and rolled up at the knees.

title: Ruling Party Loses Hold as Leftists Surge in Spain
description: MADRID  Underlining the rising fragmentation of Spanish politics, two left-wing politicians appeared poised to take charge of the city halls in Madrid and Barcelona, Spains two largest cities, according to the preliminary results of Spanish regional and municipal elections on Sunday.

title: On a Trip Through Time in Montana, a Name Demands Notice
description: FORT BENTON, Mont.  A red bus tottered down a rural road here Sunday, and inside, passengers pressed noses against glass as a guide urged them to envision this place 153 years ago, when the path was a muddy new wagon road cutting through wilderness.

title: European Central Bank Expands Mandate as It Struggles to Keep Zone Intact
description: SINTRA, Portugal  Only a few years ago, the European Central Bank was regarded as relatively powerless when compared with its counterpart in the United States.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: Carly Fiorina Talks, Iowa Swoons, and Polls Shrug
description: DES MOINES  After 11 Republican presidential contenders spoke to a huge gathering of Iowa party activists at the Lincoln Day Dinner this month, they moved to hospitality suites to greet people one on one.

title: Slow Stephen Curry Down? This Division III College Did
description: HOUSTON  Stephen Curry was busy assembling another special performance for the Golden State Warriors on Saturday night when Adam Choice, an admissions official at Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn, started exchanging text messages with Justin Sherman, one of his former college teammates.

title: Sony Terms With Spotify Uncovered in Contract
description: Online streaming may be the music industrys biggest source of growth. But as Sony is learning, when the business arrangements behind it are made public it can expose serious rifts.

title: In Two Losses, Sweden Discerns a Glimmer of Renewed Glory
description: PARIS  In a different era, fans and followers of Swedish tennis would have viewed a day like Sunday at the French Open as a disaster.

title: Fiat Chrysler Raises Hackles by Refusing to Fix Some Recalled Jeeps
description: Fiat Chryslers refusal to repair some of the almost 1.6 million Jeeps recalled for a fire risk has upset some owners and raised questions among current and former regulators.

title: Help Arrives Incognito for Yankees Tired Bullpen
description: The Yankees have been closely following Jacob Lindgrens ascent through the minors, but he still is a bit of an unknown entity around the Bronx.

title: Public-Sector Jobs Vanish, Hitting Blacks Hard
description: MIAMI  For the Ingram clan, working for the Miami-Dade County transit system has led to regular paychecks, a steady advance up the economic ladder and even romance.

title: Hold the Mimosa. Ill Have a Biscuit.
description: Not counting New Yorks several million rats, which it is better not to think about, there is no more ubiquitous mammal in this city of concrete and steel than our pet dogs. They fertilize the sidewalks. They ride the subways in Louis Vuitton totes. They fill the air with their barks.

title: The Synagogue Beyond the Outfield Wall
description: The oldest synagogue in South Bend, Ind., was saved from demolition and then repurposed by the citys minor league baseball team.

title: Popular Demand
description: In San Andreas, Dwayne Johnson has to save his daughter when the Big One hits California. The movie will have to help rescue the summer box office season, too, after a drop of more than 15 percent from 2013 to 2014.

title: Victor Hedman, aLate Bloomer, Gives Tampa Bay a Quiet Spark
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The flashy forwards of the Tampa Bay Lightning are such speedsters and sharpshooters that Rangers defenders often appear to be grasping at ghosts, always a stride or three behind.

title: While at War, Female Soldiers Fight to Belong
description: The days work was in full swing, the men in the platoon needed a break, and one of them began imitating his leaders style of walking. Head down, elbows flapping, legs flying forward, he soon had the other soldiers laughing and calling out modifications:

title: New York Real Estate Executive With Access to Politicians Is at Center of Scandals
description: There are two phrases that Charles C. Doregos friends and colleagues use to describe him: very smart and very charming.

title: Women Describe Their Struggles With Gender Roles in Military
description: In his article, Benedict Carey, a New York Times reporter, writes about the struggles that female soldiers face in the intensely male world of the United States military.

title: John Scalzi, Science Fiction Writer, Signs $3.4 Million Deal for 13 Books
description: John Scalzi, a best-selling author of science fiction, has signed a $3.4 million, 10-year deal with the publisher Tor Books that will cover his next 13 books.

title: Martin Sheets, Who Shone at the Special Olympics, Dies at 62
description: Martin Sheets, who became a face of the Special Olympics, winning more than 250 medals competing for more than 40 years in its events for people with intellectual disabilities, died on Thursday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 62.

title: Bernie Williams, an Improbable Star in Center Field, Is Immortalized Just Beyond It
description: On July 5, 1991, Cal Ripken Jr. drove a pitch from the Yankees Tim Leary to the center-field wall at the old Yankee Stadium. Roberto Kelly chased after it, crashed into the fence and sprained his right wrist. Two days later, Bernie Williams was roaming center field in the Bronx.

title: Explaining a Cornerstone of Game Theory: John Nashs Equilibrium
description: John F. Nash Jr. was best known for advances in game theory, which is essentially the study of how to come up with a winning strategy in the game of life  especially when you do not know what your competitors are doing and the choices do not always look promising.

title: Silicon Valley Recap: Ethics Are for Losers
description: Season 2, Episode 7: Adult ContentBusiness isnt easy, and it doesnt pay to be nice. Youve got to do whatever you can to win, sometimes even play dirty. If that means hacking into a competitors server to undercut his deal with one of the worlds largest online pornography companies, well, then  to quote a memorable line from this weeks Silicon Valley  Welcome to the left-hand path, my friend.

title: Veep Recap: Selina Wants a Girls Night at the White House
description: Season 4, Episode 7, Mommy Meyer

title: A Lightning Blockade Gives the Rangers No Shot
description: Anton Stralman lingered in his zone for a moment as the Rangers retreated and the Lightning turned and headed up ice. Until this point, about halfway through the game, the Rangers had looked like the better team, skating harder and faster, creating the better chances. But all the Lightning needed to score were the puck and an opening.

title: Body Recovered in Hudson Is Identified as Missing Kayakers
description: A body recovered in the Hudson River on Saturday has been identified as that of Vincent Viafore, the man who prosecutors say was killed by his fiance as the couple kayaked last month, members of the fiances defense team said on Sunday.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 25 2015
description: She cant find a full-time job. Shes waiting, waiting, waiting, waiting, waiting for an interview right now.

title: LeBron James Lifts Cleveland to Win With Triple-Double
description: CLEVELAND  The fans in the sellout crowd here gasped for breath and then exploded into a wall of noise on Sunday night as Shelvin Macks potentially game-tying 3-pointer in overtime hung in the air and then clanged off the rim. As the ball bounced away, the final buzzer sounded and the Cleveland Cavaliers secured a 114-111 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Carl Edwards Wins Coca-Cola 600, His First Victory in Nearly a Year
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Carl Edwards left his home at Roush Fenway Racing after 11 years, hoping a switch this season to a more competitive team, Joe Gibbs Racing, would give him a shot at an elusive Sprint Cup championship.

title: On Night to Remember, Game to Forget as Rangers Sweep Yanks
description: Yankees fans finally had something to cheer for Sunday.

title: Game of Thrones Recap: Cerseis Sparrows Come Home to Roost
description: Season 5, Episode 7, The Gift

title: Triplets May Draw Attention, but a Captain Stands Alone
description: The Tampa Bay Lightning have pushed themselves to one game from the Stanley Cup finals thanks in large part to their high-scoring Triplets line, led by the talented Tyler Johnson.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE HURT LOCKER (2009) In this Oscar winner for best picture, the director, Kathryn Bigelow, focuses on the men of an Army unit whose job is to detect and defuse  or if that doesnt work, detonate  improvised explosive devices in Iraq. The units wild card is Staff Sgt. William James (Jeremy Renner, above left, with Anthony Mackie), who looks like a man having the time of his life, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, as he approaches each new bomb or skirmish not with dread but with a kind of inspired, improvisational zeal. He added, Ms. Bigelow, practicing a kind of hyperbolic realism, distills the psychological essence and moral complications of modern warfare into a series of brilliant, agonizing set pieces.

title: Corrections: May 25, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: China Hopes Blacklist Will Curb Its Travelers Misbehavior Abroad
description: Tourists from China intent on celebrating their new wealth  much of it gained since 2008, when the government introduced major stimulus programs amid a sagging global economy  are a fast-growing presence around the world. Their range extends from American cities to European villages, from African safari parks to Southeast Asian beaches. Recently a group of more than 6,000 Chinese tourists attracted attention by taking a company-sponsored vacation in France.

title: Fighting Cyberattacks: A Financial Industry View
Title Insurance Kickbacks
description: To the Editor:

title: How Places Let Us Feel the Past
description: WHAT gives certain places their extraordinary power to move people so deeply?

title: Mitigating Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Meh
description: Remember Douglas Adamss 1979 novel The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy? It began with some technology snark, dismissing Earth as a planet whose life-forms are so amazingly primitive that they still think digital watches are a pretty neat idea. But that was then, in the early stages of the information technology revolution.

title: More Black Doctors
Scientific Collaboration, Then and Now
Stronger Regulation of Toxic Chemicals
description: Both houses of Congress are moving to reform the notoriously weak Toxic Substances Control Act, which is supposed to ensure the safety of chemicals used in a wide range of consumer and industrial products. The measures under consideration have strong bipartisan support and are thus likely to provide the first significant reforms to the law since it was enacted nearly four decades ago.

title: Restoring Memoriam to Memorial Day
description: This Memorial Day, as we head to the lake and the beach, grill and drink, shop and save, lay out in the sun or seek shady places, we must remain cognizant that the holiday didnt begin as a day of celebration or commerce but one of solemnity and, indeed, memoriam.

title: Decision Time on the Hudson
description: This month the dredges and barges went to work again on the upper Hudson River to begin the sixth and last year of one of the largest and most expensive environmental cleanups in American history. The polluter, General Electric, has been digging up toxic PCBs, polychlorinated biphenyls, that it dumped into the river, by the millions of pounds, decades ago. It plans to keep dredging through the fall, then pack up its machinery and walk away from the job.

title: To Baku and Back With Freebies
description: When does a congressional fact-finding trip become an embarrassing junket? Ten House members and 32 of their staff members should be pondering that question now that their all-expenses-paid trip to Baku two years ago has been found by ethics investigators to have been secretly financed by Azerbaijans state-owned oil company. That would be a violation of House ethics rules and federal law against foreign governments intruding into United States policy.

title: Malaysian Police Suspect That Mass Graves Are Those of Migrants
description: HONG KONG  The police in Malaysia said on Monday that they had found mass graves on the countrys border with Thailand that may hold the remains of migrants who died in camps run by smugglers.

title: Still Secret and Secure, Safe Rooms Now Hide in Plain Sight
description: While serving as president of the New School, Bob Kerrey, the former United States senator, needed a residence befitting his station. The university moved him into a red brick Neo-Grec townhouse on West Fourth Street in Manhattan, which was previously owned by the actress Gwyneth Paltrow.

title: Judy Blumes In the Unlikely Event
description: Judy Blume isnt just revered, shes revolutionary. She has dared to write about so-called taboo topics for children and young adults  racism (Iggies House), bullying (Blubber), sex (Forever...)  and has done it so honestly that her work is both beloved and banned. Now, in her first novel for adults in 17 years, she uses her own young life as source material, revisiting a time when three planes crashed over eight weeks in her hometown, during an indelible period of history  the beginning of the 1950s, just as the glossy suburban dream of picket fences and safe conformity jutted up against unrelenting Cold War paranoia.

title: 1871 | To Skewer Boss Tweed, The Times Spoke German
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Malaysia Police Chief Comments on Graves
description: Malaysias police chief says 139 graves believed to contain the remains of migrants have been found near the countrys border with Thailand.

title: Ehud Olmert, Israeli Ex-Premier, Is Sentenced to 8 Months in Jail
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced out of office amid allegations of corruption, was sentenced on Monday to eight months in jail for fraud and breach of trust in a case involving an American businessman.

title: Britain to Curb Who Can Vote in E.U. Membership Referendum
description: LONDON  With the Labour Party accepting that a referendum on British membership in the European Union is inevitable, the Conservative government announced on Monday that the list of eligible voters would be similar to that of the recent general election, meaning that most European Union citizens living in Britain will not be able to cast a ballot.

title: Getting It Right
description: What is it to truly know something? In our daily lives, we might not give this much thought  most of us rely on what we consider to be fair judgment and common sense in establishing knowledge. But the task of clearly defining true knowledge is trickier than it may first seem, and it is a problem philosophers have been wrestling with since Socrates.

title: A Dog of Ones Own
description: Id come to this party to make out with the host, but his attentions were someplace blonder. So when I turned and saw the guy in the old leather jacket  his earnest dance moves, his hopeful smile  I smiled back and danced away. He followed.

title: Obamacares Big Gamble on Hospital Productivity
description: Can hospitals provide better care for less money? The assumption that they can is baked into the Affordable Care Act.

title: How the Civil War Became the Indian Wars
description: On Dec. 21, 1866, a year and a half after Gen. Robert E. Lee and Gen. Ulysses S. Grant ostensibly closed the book on the Civil Wars final chapter at Appomattox Court House, another soldier, Capt. William Fetterman, led cavalrymen from Fort Phil Kearny, a federal outpost in Wyoming, toward the base of the Big Horn range. The men planned to attack Indians who had reportedly been menacing local settlers. Instead, a group of Arapahos, Cheyennes and Lakotas, including a warrior named Crazy Horse, killed Fetterman and 80 of his men. It was the Armys worst defeat on the Plains to date. The Civil War was over, but the Indian wars were just beginning.

title: Soldier in Tunis Fires on Colleagues in Deadly Attack
description: TUNIS  A Tunisian soldier opened fire on fellow troops inside the central army barracks in the capital on Monday morning, killing seven soldiers and wounding 10 others, the Tunisian Defense Ministry said. The soldier was killed in an exchange of fire.

title: More Than 70 Wounded in Bombing of Afghan Government Compound
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A powerful truck bomb rammed into a government compound in southern Afghanistan on Monday morning, wounding more than 70 people, the authorities said.

title: How Theresa Jones, Military Widow and New Real Estate Assistant, Does It
description: Theresa Jones, mother of an 18-month-old and a 7-year-old, knows better than most the grim statistic that more than a quarter of the children left behind when an active-duty service member is killed are under 5. Just over a year ago, she was nursing her youngest child, then 2 months old, when uniformed men arrived at her home to inform her of her husbands death.

title: A Memorial Day Luxury
description: Happy Memorial Day! If you need us, well be at the pool/beach/lake/public water sprinkler for children near the Met in Central Park today. If I had it my way, wed all be together, too  with our toes in the sand, sitting on piles of snuggly soft, body-engulfing velour and terry beach towels like the ones from Ruby Mint. A Laguna Beach native, Erin ONeil launched the line last year primarily so that she could work from home, to spend more time with her daughter, Ryan Ruby. And if the 40-by-72 squares of cotton were just a touch less costly ($78 each), Id stock up on them and do basically the same thing: not go to work (until tomorrow, when its back to business as usual).

title: Uber Closes In on Its Last Frontier: Airports
description: ATLANTA  In a productive week, Ingemar Smith, driver for hire, picks up about 50 passengers from Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. Instead of pulling up to the curb outside the baggage claim area, the typical zone for fetching fliers, Mr. Smith and his silver Toyota Prius often lurk in the short-term parking deck, another minutes walk.

title: The Corporate Archipelago
description: At HowTheLightGetsIn, the other Hay festival, where I just participated in a panel on the future of capitalism. I know, why such a small topic? But what I found myself thinking and talking about is actually the present of capitalism  and in particular about the peculiar delusion that we live in a world of individual competition in freewheeling markets.

title: Your (Long) Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories as the U.S. honors Memorial Day.

title: Grexit and the Morning After
description: We just had another electoral earthquake in the euro area: Podemos-backed candidates have won local elections in Madrid and Barcelona. And I hope that the IFKAT  the institutions formerly known as the troika  are paying attention.

title: In Kansas City, All Things Craft
description: The Westport neighborhood has become a destination for craft beers, local charcuterie and indie-label clothes.

title: 1915: Italian Troops Advance
description: ROME  The Italian Headquarters Staff to- day [May 25] issued the following communiqu describing the operations which took place yesterday in Carniola and in Friuli: On the frontier of Carniola, at seven oclock on the evening of May 23, the Austrian artillery opened fire on our positions without achieving any result. During May 24 our artillery shelled the positions occupied by the enemys artillery. On the frontier of Friuli our troops have everywhere advanced into enemy territory and have encountered only a feeble resistance. We have occupied Caporetto, the heights between the Judrio and Isonzo, Cormons, Cervignano and Terzo.  The New York Herald, European Edition, May 26, 1915

title: Living at High Altitude Is Linked to Higher SIDS Risk
description: Living at high altitude is associated with increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome, a new report has found.

title: Doctoring, Without the Doctor
description: WOOD LAKE, Neb.  There are just a handful of psychiatrists in all of western Nebraska, a vast expanse of farmland and cattle ranches. So when Murlene Osburn, a cattle rancher turned psychiatric nurse, finished her graduate degree, she thought starting a practice in this tiny village of tumbleweeds and farm equipment dealerships would be easy.

title: Ants That Show Some Spring in Their Jaws to Escape
description: Trap-jaw ants are named for their fearsome pair of spring-loaded mandibles that snap shut on prey with speed and finality. The ants also have a stinger they can use for good measure if they feel the need to add venom to injury.

title: ScienceTake | The Great Ant Escape
description: Trap-jaw ants have a startling way to jump out of the slippery-sloped pits of predators.

title: Venerable Korean American Group in New York Descends Into Chaos
description: Should you happen to meet the president of the Korean American Association of Greater New York this spring, you might find yourself speaking with a 60-year-old Korean man named Sung Ki Min. Then again, you might instead find yourself talking with a 54-year-old woman named Minsun Kim.

title: Vacationers Stay Fit (and Out of the Gym)
description: Travel often means a break in fitness routines. After all, not all hotel gyms are inviting (limited equipment can be a problem). But a number of properties around the world are now offering more compelling workout programs.

title: Touring West Greenland, With Camera
description: Photo Tour Summer Highlights of West Greenland is the inaugural tour offered by Big Chill Adventures, established last year by Sarah Aciego, a glaciochemist, and her mother, Mindy Cambiar, a photographer.

title: Jon Stewart, Iraq War Critic, Runs a Program That Helps Veterans Enter TV
description: During the surge in Iraq in 2008, Nathan Witmer led an Army scout platoon in a thicket of villages rife with insurgents and roadside bombs. What he really wants to do is direct.

title: 1965: Plot to Kill De Gaulle Is Foiled
description: PARIS  The arrest of six would-be assassins foiled a plot to kill President Charles de Gaulle during his provincial tour last week, Interior Ministry officials disclosed today. A bomb was to be planted at the foot of a statue of Premier Georges Clemenceau, World War I leader, at Sainte-Hermine, in the Vende region. The plotters would have exploded it by remote control as Gen. de Gaulle laid a wreath. Officials said the plot was directed from abroad by Jean-Jacques Susini, a leader of the terrorist Secret Army Organization.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 26, 1965

title: Migrants Flooding Into Malaysia and Indonesia Trade One Nightmare for Another
description: GELUGOR, Malaysia  The more than 3,000 migrants from Bangladesh and Myanmar who recently landed in Indonesia and Malaysia ended weeks of a nightmare at sea only to fall into an administrative limbo that could last years, even decades.

title: Poles React to Presidential Vote Result
description: Polish voters, clearly eager for a change, elected the conservative Andrzej Duda as president. The morning after the election, Mr. Duda handed coffee out to voters in Warsaw.

title: Two Young Americans Smiling: One Upset Venus Williams. The Other Lost.
description: PARIS  In the fading light of Monday evening, a rare flash of positivity from Sloane Stephens shone across Suzanne Lenglen Court. In their long-awaited first meeting, the 40th-ranked Stephens beat 15th-seeded Venus Williams, 7-6 (5), 6-1, in the first round of the French Open.

title: Naoki Inabas Predator and Prey
Letters to the Editor
description: Animal Behavior

title: Next to Fairyflies, Ants Are Giants
description: Q. Are there microscopic ants or other insects? If not, why not?

title: Making LED Light Bulbs Less Attractive to Insects
description: Making LED light bulbs give off less blue light might help protect people from insect-borne diseases, according to a scientist who specializes in the environmental effects of artificial light.

title: Taliban and Afghan Peace Officials Have Secret Talks in China
description: BEIJING  A peace envoy from Afghanistan met in western China last week with former Taliban officials with close ties to Pakistans intelligence agency, in an attempt to keep open the possibility of formal Afghan peace talks, officials said Monday.

title: Etan Patz Jurors, on Anniversary, Meet at Scene of Boys Disappearance
description: They gathered quietly on the corner in Lower Manhattan just feet from where prosecutors say Etan Patz was strangled in a bodega basement 36 years ago: seven jurors who had voted to convict a former clerk at the store of murder but were unable to convince one holdout among them.

title: One Mans Millions Turn a Community in Florida Around
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Two decades ago, Harris Rosen, who grew up poor on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and became wealthy in the Florida hotel business, decided to shepherd part of his fortune into a troubled community with the melodious sounding name of Tangelo Park.

title: Destroying California On Screen
description: From the 1936 film San Francisco to the soon-to-be-released San Andreas, California has been repeatedly destroyed on the silver screen.

title: Profit Soars at the Vatican Bank After a Governance Overhaul
description: ROME  The Vatican bank said on Monday that its 2014 net profit had soared, recovering from the expense of last years extraordinary overhaul of the organizations governance.

title: California Dream Under Attack in All Manner of Cinematic Imaginings
description: LOS ANGELES  Here it comes again: The California Apocalypse.

title: Wide Use of Antibiotics Allows C. Diff to Flourish
description: You might say Jacob Epstein, a lean, healthy, 88-year-old Floridian, died in early May from a broken arm. Following surgery to reset the bone, he was given an antibiotic to prevent postoperative infection, a common hospital practice.

title: Netanyahu Appoints Hawkish Ally to Run Foreign Ministry
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday named a longtime confidant who is hawkish on Iran and the Palestinian issue to run the Foreign Ministry, the latest in a series of moves that consolidate Mr. Netanyahus conservative grip on his new government.

title: Charter Deal for Time Warner Cable Signals Shift in TV Industry
description: Trying to succeed where Comcast failed, Charter Communications has struck a deal to buy Time Warner Cable, an acquisition that would create a powerhouse in the consolidating American cable and broadband industry.

title: Pensions and Politics Fuel Crisis in Illinois
description: CHICAGO  Illinois is facing one of the worst fiscal crises of any state in recent decades, largely because it has mismanaged its pension system.

title: One-Two Punch of Earthquakes and Landslides Exposes Hydropower Vulnerability in Nepal
description: Heres a Your Dot contribution exploring the vulnerability of Nepals hydrocentric energy system to damage from earthquakes and landslides. Its written by Gagan Thapa, a member of Parliament and chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture, Energy, and Natural Resources, and Kashish Das Shrestha, a photographer and writer who has worked with Thapa for more than 10 years on sustainable development policy. (You can find them on Twitter at @ThapaGK and @KashishDS.)

title: University of TokyoEnds a 94-Game Victory Drought
description: Sooner or later, one way or another, the University of Tokyos baseball team was bound to win a game. Any game. Just one.

title: At Least 5 Are Killed and 12 Are Missing as Storms Ravage Texas and Oklahoma
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Louie Bond called it a tsunami, a surge of water that began late Saturday night with torrential rains in Texas Hill Country and raced down the bluff-lined valley carved out by the Blanco River.

title: Scientists Make Novel Attempt to Save Giant Turtle Species
description: Earlier this month, an international team of scientists, veterinarians and zookeepers gathered at the Suzhou Zoo near Shanghai. Their desperate mission: to attempt the first artificial insemination ever of a softshell turtle, saving the species from oblivion.

title: Decomposed Remains Found in Malaysia
description: Forensic experts collected bags of human remains on Monday that were found at the site of mass graves in northern Malaysia.

title: Facing Elimination, the Rangers Expect to Go Home, for Game 7
description: The Rangers are all too familiar with their predicament against the Tampa Bay Lightning in the Eastern Conference finals. They are facing elimination again, trailing a series by three games to two for the sixth time over the last four postseasons.

title: Cleveland Reaches Settlement With Justice Department Over Police Conduct
description: CLEVELAND  Cleveland has reached a settlement with the Justice Department over what federal authorities said was a pattern of unconstitutional policing and excessive use of force, people briefed on the case said Monday.

title: Shop Owners in a Changing Brooklyn Decide to Call It Quits
description: To hear some mourners of New Yorks late, great nostalgia-filled haunts tell it, the soul of the city is crumbling. With every upward tick in property values, the eternal lament goes, another rapacious landlord muscles out a neighborhood dive bar for a new bank, drugstore or gym.

title: Allegations Against French Peacekeepers Highlight Obstacles in Addressing Abuse
description: UNITED NATIONS  Petit, viens,  little boy, come here  a French soldier called out at a checkpoint in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.

title: Polands Governing Party Reels After Challengers Presidential Victory
description: WARSAW  Polands political establishment was reeling on Monday from the defeat of the incumbent president by a little-known 43-year-old candidate from the right-wing opposition, a result that appeared to be a repudiation of the center-right party that has governed the country during eight years of prosperity and stability.

title: Even Einsteins Research Can Take Time to Matter
description: In science, a sleeping beauty refers to a research paper whose importance is not recognized until many years after it is published. A new analysis of 22 million studies, published over more than a century, finds that sleeping beauties are common.

title: Senator Thad Cochran Marries Longtime Aide
description: Congratulations are in order for Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, who married Kay Webber, a longtime aide, in Gulfport, Miss., on Saturday. The wedding comes about a year after the 77-year-old Republican won his partys nomination in one of the most personal and intense primary battles in the country.

title: Relax, the Terminator Is Far Away
description: In glossy sci-fi movies like Ex Machina and Chappie, robots move with impressive  and frequently malevolent  dexterity. They appear to confirm the worst fears of prominent technologists and scientists like Elon Musk, Stephen Hawking and Bill Gates, who have all recently voiced alarm over the possible emergence of self-aware machines out to do harm to the human race.

title: Oral Steroids May Be Ineffective Against Sciatica Back Pain
description: Prednisone, a drug commonly prescribed to treat acute sciatica  the back and leg pain caused by a herniated disk  is almost completely ineffective against the condition, a randomized trial has found.

title: Review: Joshua Redman Joins the Bad Plus in a Chemistry Experiment
description: THE BAD PLUS JOSHUA REDMAN

title: W.H.O. Plan Aims to Combat Resistance to Antibiotic Drugs
description: GENEVA  United Nations member states agreed Monday to a plan to tackle resistance to antibiotic drugs, spurred by warnings of a catastrophe for public health and heavy economic losses if they did not act.

title: Review: Shana Cleveland & the Sandcastles Demonstrate a Low-Flame Curiosity
description: SHANA CLEVELAND & THE SANDCASTLES

title: Review: Allen Stone Keeps His Distance From Modern Music in Radius
description: ALLEN STONE

title: Review: Guidelines Is Jean-Franois Caissys Look at High School
description: Guidelines was filmed in a high school in rural Quebec, but its insights resonate worldwide. More preoccupied with time than place, this deceptively simple documentary by Jean-Franois Caissy regards the turbulence of adolescence as a negotiation between risk and restraint.

title: Spains Local Election Results Reshape Political Landscape
description: MADRID  Ada Colau, 41, was not even born when Manuela Carmena, 71, joined Spains underground Communist party and started her legal career by attacking labor restrictions imposed by Francisco Franco, the Spanish dictator.

title: Students Measure Space Dust as New Horizons Heads for Pluto
description: In the nine years that NASAs New Horizons spacecraft has spent zooming toward Pluto, most of the seven instruments aboard the piano-size probe have been in hibernation, waiting for their chance to plumb the mysteries of our solar system. One, however, has been collecting and pinging back data all this time, a tireless worker with a taste for dust.

title: Review: The Digital Doctor by Robert Wachter Weighs Medicines Technological Transformation
description: Janus was the Roman god of doorways and beginnings, the one depicted in sculpture with two faces on a single head. An elderly face gazes backward. (Fondly? Bitterly? Regretfully? Who knows.) A youthful face looks forward, presumably with resolution and hope.

title: Review: On II, Metz Plays With Punk Attitude
description: METZ

title: A Coach Reaffirms His Standing as Denver Claims Lacrosse Title
description: PHILADELPHIA  As Denver Coach Bill Tierney slowly made his way toward his jubilant players, somebody handed him a pair of scissors, then a snipped piece of net and then the national championship trophy, which he held in his arms, reluctantly, for about five seconds.

title: Natures Waste Management Crews
description: One of the biggest mistakes my husband made as a new father was to tell me he thought his diaper-changing technique was better than mine. From then on, guess who assumed the lions share of diaper patrol in our household?

title: Review: In Philipp Bloms Fracture, Careening Atoms in the Era Between the Wars
description: In The Vertigo Years: Change and Culture in the West, 1900-1914, the German historian Philipp Blom pulled off a neat trick. He invited readers to indulge in a thought experiment, to imagine the early 20th century without the imminent prospect of a world war; to experience it, in other words, as its contemporaries did.

title: Review: Gwen Welliver Goes Equine at La MaMa Moves!
description: For its 10th edition, La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival is presenting about a dozen choreographers over four weeks. A few of those  Gwen Welliver, Brandon Collwes and Eric Geiger and Anya Cloud  shared a bill over the weekend in the close quarters of La MaMas First Floor Theater.

title: With Money Drying Up, Greece Is All but Bankrupt
description: ATHENS  Bulldozers lie abandoned on city streets. Exhausted surgeons operate through the night. And the wealthy bail out broke police departments.

title: Review: Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg Goes Up and Down
description: Where to begin with Up and Down, the latest production from Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg? Maybe at the end, when the choreographer Boris Eifman takes a bow. On Friday at City Center, where the work had its New York premiere as part of a nine-week North American tour, wild applause greeted Mr. Eifman through multiple curtain calls. Its this loyal following that brings his troupe trundling through City Center every few years.

title: Mets Get a Lift From a Heavy Hitter (and Pitcher) of Their Own
description: Whats not to like about watching hefty Bartolo Colon step into the batters box? Sometimes he even keeps his helmet on his head as he swings away, and on occasion he even makes contact with the ball.

title: Iran Judge Closes Reporters Trial, Ignoring Pleas for Transparency
description: Ignoring foreign requests for court access, the Iranian judge presiding over the espionage case against Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter imprisoned for 10 months, has barred everyone except the defendant and his lawyer, Mr. Rezaians brother said Monday on the eve of the trial.

title: For Kristin Chenoweth and Kelli OHara, a Fearsome Fairy Godmother
description: When it was her turn to sing at Florence Birdwells master class for former students in Midtown Manhattan the other day, Heather Botts, a delicate blonde with a beautiful voice, announced that she would be performing Another Life, from the musical The Bridges of Madison County.

title: One-Time Bonuses and Perks Muscle Out Pay Raises for Workers
description: Yacht-size bonuses for Wall Street big shots and employee-of-the-month plaques for supermarket standouts are nothing new, but companies continued efforts to keep costs down have pushed employers to increasingly turn to one-off bonuses and nonmonetary rewards at the expense of annual pay raises.

title: Review: Welcome to This House, the Private Life of a Poet
description: Welcome to This House, Barbara Hammers impressionistic yet informative portrait of the poet Elizabeth Bishop, certainly pays tribute to the towering literary achievements of Bishop (1911-79). But Ms. Hammer, an experimental filmmaker whose movies have often chronicled lesbian experience, largely examines Bishops private life, an often peripatetic existence strewn with lovers in a deeply closeted era.

title: What Slump? Yankees Hit Five Homers in Rout of Royals
description: Brett Gardner accounted for four of the Yankees eight first-inning runs on Monday, scoring twice and driving in Didi Gregorius and Slade Heathcott with a home run.

title: Review: Junk Ensemble Explores Darkness and Danger in Dusk Ahead
description: Three blindfolded dancers grope in near darkness as two others lead them in different directions to the sound of hand bells. Moments later, four performers execute a squiggly gestural sequence knitted together with shoulder shrugs, flowing arms and slow plis punctuated by quick swipes of the ankle. At the back of the stage, another dancer, wearing a wolfs head, saunters by.

title: City Ballets Spring Season Includes N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz
description: As the current New York City Ballet season advances, every performance brings a sharp change in the company barometer. Not all the news is good news. Some valued dancers have been absent with injuries; some tedious ballets have returned to repertory; some casting has made good choreography look no more substantial than cotton candy; and some debuts of important dancers in important roles havent worked out.

title: Officials Describe the Origins of Four Crucial Words: Established by the State
description: At stake in King v. Burwell is whether the phrase prevents millions of people in federal health care exchanges from receiving tax subsidies through the Affordable Care Act.

title: Bears Release Ex-49er Ray McDonald After Arrest in California
description: The Chicago Bears released defensive lineman Ray McDonald after he was arrested Monday in California on a domestic violence charge, the latest in a string of run-ins that have tested the boundaries of the N.F.L.s tougher personal conduct policy.

title: At Least 3 Die in New York City Crashes on Holiday Weekend
description: A series of fatal car crashes occurred around New York City over the holiday weekend, leaving at least three people dead and a 7-year-old girl with serious injuries. At least one of the accidents involved an intoxicated driver.

title: After a Political Reversal in Alberta, Anything Seems Possible
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  This is the Canadian province known for oil, cowboys and rodeos, and as the adopted home of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, whose Conservative Party has long dominated politics.

title: As Facebook Sweeps Across Europe, Regulators Gird for Battle
description: LONDON  One arm of the European Union is looking into whether Facebook and other tech companies unfairly favor their own services over those of rivals. At least five data protection watchdogs across the region are questioning Facebooks privacy settings.

title: Congress Pursues Deal on Phone Data Collection in Rare Talks During Recess
description: WASHINGTON  Senior lawmakers are scrambling this week in rare recess negotiations to agree on a face-saving change to legislation that would rein in the National Security Agencys dragnet of phone records, with time running out on some of the governments domestic surveillance authority.

title: McNeil Robinson II, 72, Organist and Composer, Is Dead
description: McNeil Robinson II, an acclaimed organist, composer and teacher, died on May 9 in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: The Synagogue Beyond the Outfield Wall
description: The oldest synagogue in South Bend, Ind., was saved from demolition and then repurposed by the citys minor league baseball team.

title: Whos the Watchdog? In Europe, the Answer Is Complicated
description: LONDON  Who has the right to regulate Facebook?

title: Deaths of Math Genius John F. Nash Jr. and Wife Show Need to Use Seatbelts in Back, Experts Say
description: The crash that killed the mathematician John F. Nash Jr. and his wife, Alicia, on Saturday on the New Jersey Turnpike remains under investigation, but preliminary findings by the police seem to make one thing clear: The Nashes, who were thrown from the back seat of their taxi, were not wearing seatbelts.

title: After a Year of Outsize Expectations, Narendra Modi Adjusts His Plan for India
description: NEW DELHI  Standing before India on the first anniversary of his swearing-in, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday gave a speech that was notable for the subjects it avoided: Large-scale job creation. Manufacturing. Urbanization.

title: A Cleaner Fleet Week: What Do You Do With a Cultured Sailor?
description: The High Line.

title: Years Later for Guillermo Vilas, Hes Still Not the One
description: PARIS  It was 1975, and Guillermo Vilas  a charismatic Argentine with long hair, heavy topspin and a poetic streak  reached his first French Open final, losing to Bjorn Borg.

title: Four Words That Imperil Health Care Law Were All a Mistake, Writers Now Say
description: WASHINGTON  They are only four words in a 900-page law: established by the state.

title: In Time Warner Cable Deal, Charter Seeks National Heft
description: It was only 15 months ago that Charter Communications looked like a big loser in the race to add heft in the cable and broadband industry. Comcast, a rival, had swooped in with an audacious $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, appearing to end the prolonged takeover battle that Charter had been waging for the cable operator.

title: How a Fax Helped Rewrite Womens Soccer in the U.S.
description: BRICK, N.J.  To get an idea of how long Christie Rampone has played on the United States womens national team, let her tell you how U.S. Soccer first invited her to try out for the squad.

title: Doubts About Study of Gay Canvassers Rattle the Field
description: He was a graduate student who seemingly had it all: drive, a big idea and the financial backing to pay for a sprawling study to test it.

title: Dellavedova Is a Firebrand and a Spark Plug for the Cavaliers
description: CLEVELAND  Randy Bennett sighed and laughed Monday as he considered the rhetorical storm that had been circling his former player Matthew Dellavedova.

title: Eating Kumquats With Grover
description: Grover visits The New York Times Melissa Clark and some young friends to talk about a new cookbook, Sesame Street Lets Cook! What is Grovers favorite food?

title: Like the Best Bonds
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  This one by Gareth Bain made me smile. Not just because of the sentiment behind the Beatles song that happens to be the revealer, but also because this puzzle was a really smooth solve. Easier, perhaps, than the Monday puzzle, but thats the thing about wheelhouses: We all decorate them differently.

title: Similac Advance Infant Formula to Be Offered G.M.O.-Free
description: The maker of Similac Advance, the top commercial baby formula brand in the United States, says it will begin selling the first mainstream baby formula made without genetically altered ingredients by the end of the month at Target.

title: Jets Are Scrambled Over New York as Airports See a Flurry of Threats
description: Two F-15 jets were sent to escort an Air France flight into New York, the first of at least six intercontinental flights arriving in the region on Monday that were the subject of phone threats about chemical weapons or bombs.

title: Young Treasure Hunters Dig Up History Lessons in a Classrooms Closet
description: Bobby Scotto, a fourth grader at the Childrens Workshop School on 12th Street in the East Village, wants to be an archaeologist when he grows up, and he is already off to a good start. In the past few months he has excavated dozens of old coins, a toy watch and other artifacts, all from an unlikely dig site: his classrooms closet.

title: Fire Kills 38 at Seniors Home in China
description: HONG KONG  A fire possibly caused by an electrical problem killed at least 38 people in a retiree home in central China, according to state news media reports on Tuesday.

title: Hillary and Bill Clinton March In Memorial Day Parade in Chappaqua
description: In their first joint public appearance since she declared her candidacy, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton marched with veterans on Monday in the Memorial Day parade in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Columbia Is the No. 3 Seed in Florida
description: Columbia drew the No. 3 seed in the Coral Gables, Fla., region of the N.C.A.A. Division I baseball tournament. The Lions will play the No. 2 seed, East Carolina, when the 64-team tournament begins on Friday. Miami is the top seed in the region, and Florida International is No. 4.

title: Massimo Botturas Pope Francis-Approved Refectory, and Recipe to Turn Stale Bread Into Gold
description: Italys most progressive exhibition of sustainable cooking commences this Thursday, when the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura throws open the doors of Refettorio Ambrosiano, the once-derelict theater repurposed to educate and feed the refugees and working poor who reside far across town from the multinational pavilions welcoming culinary tourists to this summers Expo Milano 2015. The contemporary refectory in the heart of the citys under-resourced Greco neighborhood will host a coterie of Botturas most charitable colleagues, beginning with Eleven Madison Parks Daniel Humm and former Chez Panise chef Seen Lippert, eager to make a feast of the expositions transported food waste for those most in need by performing culinary alchemy twice daily in a glass-enclosed stage. At lunchtime, there are going to be students there; and the very best chefs in the world, the rock n roll stars, will be cooking scraps for them, says Bottura of the facilitys secondary mission. Its like the Pope washing the feet of the people in the street. While Botturas inspiration for the project draws on local influences including the Italian cinematic fantasia Miracle in Milan and Leonardo da Vincis Last Supper, his greatest motivator has been Pope Francis, whose spontaneous utterance of Buon pranzo! (Good lunch!) five days into his papacy inspired a renewed sense of faith within the chef. Introducing himself with those words reminds everyone to start each day with humility, and humility is the most important thing, Bottura says, because from there others are going to follow you.

title: Word of the Day | inarticulate
description: inarticulate  \i-()nr-ti-ky-lt\  adjective

title: Sesame Street Says Lets Cook
description: Who better to solve the problem of kids and picky eating than Grover, Elmo and Cookie Monster?

title: Man in New Jersey Dies of Rare Viral Disease After Returning From Liberia
description: WASHINGTON  A man died of Lassa fever at a hospital in New Jersey on Monday after returning from Liberia this month, health authorities announced.

title: Houston Remains Alive, and Curry Survives a Scare
description: HOUSTON  Stephen Curry felt as if he was in the air forever. He was simply trying to make a play on the ball when Trevor Ariza pump-faked underneath the Houston Rockets basket. But Curry, the star of the Golden State Warriors, went up and over, sliding off the back of Ariza like an egg on a skillet before tumbling to the court at Toyota Center.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: MIDNIGHT (TCM) PAPILLON (1973) Steve McQueen (left, with Dustin Hoffman) stars as Henri Charrire, a.k.a. Papillon, an honorable safecracker framed for the murder of a pimp and sentenced to life in a penal colony on Devils Island, off the coast of French Guiana. Mr. Hoffman plays his best friend, Louis Dega, a convicted counterfeiter with bad eyesight and enough money to buy Papillon as his bodyguard. After a hairbreadth escape, Papillon is befriended by Indians who inhabit what looks to be the West Indies newest and most chic island resort and cabana colony and, to be hospitable, present him with his very own Dorothy Lamour, a maiden named Zoraima who is played by Ratna Assan, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Though its native girls go topless, and the production budget was huge, Papillon is the escapist movie we used to go see on Saturday night without even bothering to read the marquee.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its half the battle  to visualize they can go to college.

title: Corrections: May 26, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: John Murphy, Congressman Convicted in Abscam Sting, Dies at 88
description: John M. Murphy, a former New York City congressman who served 18 years in the House before being caught taking a $50,000 cash payment in the Abscam sting operation in the late 1970s, died on Monday on Staten Island. He was 88.

title: Blending French and African Identities
description: Nelly Mbonou considers herself French, even if her experiences sometimes strain that bond.
