description: We need a national debate on nicotine, said Mitch Zeller.

title: The University of Minnesotas Medical Research Mess
description: MINNEAPOLIS  IF you want to see just how long an academic institution can tolerate a string of slow, festering research scandals, let me invite you to the University of Minnesota, where I teach medical ethics.

title: Immigrant Families, in a Broken Detention System
description: To the Editor:

title: Talent Loves English
description: Eight hundred years ago next month, English noblemen forced King John to sign the Magna Carta. Its still having amazing effects on the world today. The Magna Carta helped usher in government with a separation of powers. It helped create conditions in which centralized authority could not totally control fiscal, political, religious or intellectual life. It helped usher in the modern Anglo-Saxon state model, with its relative emphasis on the open movement of people, ideas and things.

title: Juvenile Justice Reform in Louisiana
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin America Rethinks Drug Policies
description: During the 1980s and 1990s, as the United States battled the scourge of cocaine throughout the hemisphere, Washington did most of the talking. Latin American governments were forced to listen and fall in line. The American government had the most money to throw at the problem, the toughest justice system and the biggest bully pulpit.

title: The Importance of Play as a Learning Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: A Foolish Attempt to Weaken Truck Safety
description: The trucking industry is again pushing Congress to allow bigger and heavier trucks with overworked drivers behind the wheel onto the countrys roads.

title: Long Odds in the Game of Life
description: LAS VEGAS  THE first essay assignment I give to my freshman composition students is to answer the question, Why are you pursuing a university education?

title: To Save New Yorks Public Housing
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a plan last week to turn the New York City Housing Authority around. It lays out a broad-based assault on a huge problem: the rotten condition of the 328 public-housing developments that more than 400,000 New Yorkers call home.

title: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Goes on Trial in Iran
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent accused by Iran of espionage who has been imprisoned for more than 10 months, went on trial in a Tehran courtroom on Tuesday morning, state news media reported.

title: When Family-Friendly Policies Backfire
description: In Chile, a law requires employers to provide working mothers with child care. One result? Women are paid less.

title: Test Yourself | Minecraft Stars on YouTube
description: Below are several paragraphs from the May 20 article Minecraft Stars on YouTube Share Secrets to Their Celebrity.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Ireland, by Popular Vote, Allows Same-Sex Marriage
description: In Catholic Church Ponders Future After Same-Sex Marriage Vote in Ireland, Danny Hakim writes about the landmark vote and what it could mean for the Roman Catholic Church in that nation.

title: U.S. Caution in Strikes Gives ISIS an Edge, Many Iraqis Say
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence analysts have identified seven buildings in downtown Raqqa in eastern Syria as the main headquarters of the Islamic State. But the buildings have gone untouched during the 10-month allied air campaign.

title: If You Had a Fortune to Donate, What Causes or Organizations Would You Support?
description: Imagine that at some point in the future, you have made a sizable fortune. What would you spend it on? How likely do you think you would be to invest in programs designed to help people? Why?

title: Chinese Distiller Sued in Test of State v. Private Ownership
description: Many of Chinas high-end liquor producers have experienced difficulties since President Xi Jinping assumed power more than two years ago and opened a campaign against official corruption and ostentatious living. But the state-owned Wuliangye, one of the countrys leading manufacturers of alcoholic beverages, now faces a problem with far deeper roots.

title: Palace of Treason, by Jason Matthews
description: Red Sparrow, Jason Matthewss debut thriller, is a challenging act to follow. Lavished with deserved praise, it introduced Dominika Egorova, of the Russian Intelligence Service, one of the most complex and compelling heroines to grace the espionage genre. Brave, beautiful and deadly, Egorova is a synesthete, who sees a halo of color above the heads of those around her, and a graduate of the Sparrow School, where female agents are taught advanced sexual techniques as an aid to seduction and recruitment.

title: Hollywood
description: Who qualifies as an icon? What deserves to be called iconic? In matters of Hollywood, a designation that originally pertained to religious imagery is now regularly applied to subjects as secular as Animal House, Sandra Bullock, Vertigo, W.C. Fields and that scene in the original Friday the 13th where Kevin Bacon is stabbed through the neck with an arrow. One army of admirers may think the title ought to go to This Is Spinal Tap; for a different platoon, Judy Garland deserves the title for life.

title: Humor
description: A complaint: The humor section is a meaningless booksellers term. Think about it for a second. If you go to the bookstore and find yourself browsing the biography section, you know what youre going to get: biographies. Mystery section: mysteries. Sports: books about sports. But humor is something else entirely, conveying an intention rather than a subject. Rare is the humorous book about humor, although Joe Randazzo has just written quite a good one about breaking into the humor industry. Books filed under humor arent about anything specific. Their subjects run the gamut from Calvin and Hobbes anthologies to comedic memoirs to pop culture parodies to the sorts of gift books that are best read from the cozy confines of the commode. Their only commonality is their desire to amuse.

title: A House of Worship, Converted
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Not long ago, the oldest synagogue in this college town underwent a $1 million restoration. The building, to the relief of many, was salvaged from disrepair and possible demolition. But in the process, its character was markedly changed.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Broadband at the Center of Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
description: When Charter Communications announced a pair of deals on Tuesday to acquire Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks for a total of $67.1 billion, it put the focus squarely on the cable industrys future: broadband.

title: Corrupting the Chinese Language
description: HONG KONG  On a recent walk along a street in the southern Chinese city of Sanya, I heard a shop pumping out a rock version of the famous Communist Party anthem Socialism Is Good. Although I loathe this song, as the music became louder, I still found myself singing along under my breath. The reactionaries toppled / Imperialists flee with their tails between their legs. ... The Communist Party is good / The Communist Party is good / The Communist Party is a good leader of the people.

title: New York Today: New Views of the Past
description: Good morning on this tropical Tuesday.

title: Irish Government Votes to Shed Stake in Aer Lingus
description: PARIS  The Irish government agreed late on Tuesday to accept a takeover proposal for its 25 percent stake in the countrys flag carrier, Aer Lingus, from the parent company of British Airways, removing one of the last hurdles to the airlines full privatization after three-quarters of a century of state ownership.

title: Malaysia Denies Entry to Joshua Wong, Hong Kong Democracy Activist
description: HONG KONG  Joshua Wong, a prominent democracy activist from Hong Kong, was denied entry into Malaysia on Tuesday in what critics called an act of political censorship by the Malaysian government.

title: Todays Travel News and Tips
description: In Transit is trying out a new schedule. We will be posting a digest each weekday morning that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know. Wed love your feedback as we refine the format and focus, so please email travmail@nytimes.com or comment below to share your thoughts.

title: Today in Politics: Martin OMalley Readies His Hat Outside the Ring
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where yet more names are set to be added to the list of presidential candidates. While much has been made of the large Republican field, Democrats are ready for their own, if more modest, expansion.

title: Reducing My Dose, Unblocking My Muse
description: Im spending a month at an artist residency in central Mexico, where Ive befriended a local healer named Katuza who believes in the spirit world. He believes in the power of plants, especially peyote. He believes in the temescal (sweat lodge) as a cure for most ailments, including depression, anxiety, and insomnia. He has long gray hair, a long gray beard, the wide eyes of the ecstatic. He says that I need to release the things I hold in my chest. We will teach you how to scream, he says. He often uses the first-person plural  maybe because English is his second language, maybe in homage to interconnectedness.

title: How Should Americans Remember the Post-Civil War Period?
Weekly News Quiz | May 19-25, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: The IMFs New Cloves
description: A brief further note on the European situation: to me, at least, there are some echoes of 1998. Back then the IMF, in its attempt to deal with the Asian financial crisis, focused  as it does now in Europe  on the supposed need to couple financial deals with structural reform. In the case of Asian debtors, this meant taking on crony capitalism  and God knows crony capitalism was very real.

title: Morning Agenda: Charter to Buy Time Warner Cable for $56.7 Billion
description: CHARTER TO BUY TIME WARNER CABLE FOR $56.7 BILLION | Charter Communications said Tuesday that it would buy Time Warner Cable for $56.7 billion in a deal that would reshape the American cable and broadband industry,  Mark Scott writes in DealBook. Under the terms of the proposed deal, Charter offered investors in Time Warner Cable $195.71 for each share in the company  a 14 percent premium over the shares closing price on Friday  in a cash-and-stock deal that values Time Warner Cable at $78.7 billion. Buying Time Warner Cable would transform Charter, a small operator based in St. Louis, into the second-largest cable television operator, behind Comcast.

title: News Clichs From All Over
description: With the help of a reporter across the pond, my colleague Patrick LaForge unearths more examples of journalese:

title: Ex-Trader Is Painted as Ringmaster at Libor-Rigging Trial
description: LONDON  Tom Hayes, a 35-year-old former trader for Citigroup and UBS, was the ringmaster in a concerted effort to manipulate global benchmark interest rates to make as much money as he could, prosecutors said on Tuesday in a London court.

title: Bernie Sanders: A Revolution With an Eye on the Hungry Children
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont wont condemn Hillary Rodham Clinton for raking in millions in speech fees and campaign donations. But he warns it could curb her effectiveness in challenging corporate interests on behalf of working Americans.

title: Four Ways to Earn Airline Miles Quickly With a Hotel Stay
description: Can you parlay a hotel room reservation into thousands of frequent-flier miles?

title: Migrant Crisis in Southeast Asia Shows Signs of Ebbing
description: HONG KONG  No boats of Southeast Asian migrants have landed since the last one washed ashore in Indonesia a week ago. Search and rescue vessels from Malaysia and Indonesia have found no more migrants at sea. Some refugees appear to be returning to Myanmar.

title: Rain Spreads Destruction in Houston, Killing Four
description: HOUSTON  Families in one of the neighborhoods hardest hit by flooding here survived by going onto their roofs, into their attics and on top of dressers. The Toyota Center, the downtown basketball arena where the Houston Rockets played the Golden State Warriors on Monday night, became a kind of emergency shelter, as nearly 1,000 fans were allowed to stay there after the game while the storm passed and some slept in the seats.

description: HONG KONG  It is a stock market mystery.

title: Elastic City Announces Second Annual Festival of Walking and Talking
description: The performance artist Karen Finley, the writer Wayne Koestenbaum and the free-form-radio d.j. Vin Scelsa are among those who will lead participatory walks and other events around various corners of New York as part of the arts group Elastic Citys second annual festival.

title: A Place to Sip Pia Coladas in Your Own Private Pool
description: To escape the tyranny of the all-inclusive big-box resorts that dominate much of the Riviera Maya, the pristine stretch of coastline that stretches from Cancun to Tulum (and beyond), theres Mahekal  a 122-room boutique hotel nestled on the glistening Caribbean Sea and right off bustling Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen. Opened in December, the luxury village is comprised of many thatched-roof, airy casitas that are both plush and vibrant. Splurge for one a stones throw from the beach with your own private plunge pool. When you get tired of sipping banana pia coladas at the infinity pool or in the hammock on your porch, hire a private boat that leaves right from the propertys water edge to take you 30 minutes down the coast to Ihna Bay, where youll find shallow reefs and dazzlingly clear water ideal for snorkeling. Unplugging from the world is practically mandated  there are no televisions, and Wi-Fi, while it is available in the rooms, is spotty. Access to shopping and ruins is easy  but not worth sacrificing a day in paradise.

title: Shopping Online for Hillary Clinton Keepsakes
description: For Hillary Rodham Clinton supporters, the campaign kitsch has arrived.

title: Daily Report: As Facebook Sweeps Across Europe, Regulators Gird for Battle
description: One arm of the European Union is looking into whether Facebook and other tech companies unfairly favor their own services over those of rivals. At least five data protection watchdogs across the region are questioning Facebooks privacy settings, Mark Scott writes.

title: New Jersey Lassa Fever Death Prompts C.D.C. Action
description: WASHINGTON  The story had the grim ring of familiarity. A man who had come from Liberia showed up at a hospital, complaining of fever and tiredness. He was examined and sent home. Several days later he was hospitalized again, in worse condition. In another few days he was dead.

title: The Cannes Catwalk: Brand Ambassadors Run a Little Loose
description: Even beyond the shoes kerfuffle  you know: the one where flats were banned from the red carpet, causing a long, dark night of the soul among those who fear female fashion stereotyping everywhere  the 12 days of celebrity preening and pitching that recently came to an end at the Cannes Film Festival looked pretty noteworthy, at least from a style perspective.

title: Why I Invite Kids to Send Essays About Money
description: For the last several years I have invited readers to submit outstanding college application essays about money, work and social class. Let me start by admitting the selfish motive for this: Reading these essays in their raw and occasionally not-quite-edited glory is an absolute blast.

title: 1915: German Aeroplane Destroyed
description: Describing the failure of a German aerial raid on Paris yesterday [May 26], the French Ministry of War yesterday issued the following communiqu:  A German aeroplane which was heading for Paris this morning encountered the aeroplane squadrons of the entrenched camp and dropped some of his bombs without any results at Villenoy, near Meaux. Warned of the enemys raid, the French aeroplane squadrons at the front awaited his return, and the machine, an Aviatik, which was still carrying four bombs, was brought down by one of our aviators near Braine, in the Soissons region.  The New York Herald, European Edition, May 27, 1915

title: Visa Signature: Experience New York
description: A couples getaway to New York reveals hidden gems, thanks to tips from the Park Hyatt New Yorks concierge service: the citys best pizza, its finest fashions and its most stunning views.

title: Readers Turn: The Dad Bod
description: Each Tuesday, The Upshots newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

title: Jury Is Still Out on European Central Banks Stimulus Program
description: SINTRA, Portugal  By some measures, the European Central Bank is confounding the naysayers.

title: Houston Flooding Is Latest Example of Weathers Sway on Sports
description: After the Rockets beat the Warriors in Game 4 on Monday night in Houston, the team urged fans to stay in their seats to wait out the torrential rainstorms and flooding going on outside. Although many fans left, others played it safe and hung around, as did the Rockets star Dwight Howard.

title: Clintons March in Memorial Day Parade
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton marched with veterans on Monday in the Memorial Day parade in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Bernie Sanders Comes Clean
description: Voters should be grateful for the government transparency laws that required Senator Bernie Sanders, a rival to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination, to reveal how much he made last year in speaking engagement fees. The total is $1,867.42 for three appearances, a grand sum that is chump change in presidential politicking but enough for the senator to respectably donate the money to charity.

title: Two Apple Designers Step Up as Jony Ive Becomes Chief Design Officer
description: Over the last several months, Apple has been cranking up the volume on two lesser-known Apple employees: Richard Howarth and Alan Dye. And its no wonder as the two will soon take over day-to-day design responsibilities from Jony Ive, Apples all-important design guru.

title: Verbatim: Scott Walker Reflects on Israel Trip
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican and likely presidential candidate, on what he learned during his recent trip to Israel.

title: Jeb Bush as John Kerry
description: Almost two months ago, I wrote a column sketching out how Jeb Bush might lose the Republican nomination. Since then, its become more interesting, because its more challenging, to try to figure out exactly how he might win. Yes, he has the money; yes, he has the connections; yes, he still leads, technically, in the current poll of polls. But he isnt going to take the Republican nomination with 15 percent of the primary vote; he needs a whole lot of voters who currently lean toward Marco Rubio or Scott Walker or Paul or Huckabee or Carson or Cruz or PerryFiorinaJindalSantorumKasich to decide, actually, I guess Jeb Bush is the candidate for me. If neither Rubio nor Walker were in the race, it would be relative easy to see how that consolidation would eventually happen (as it did for Mitt Romney in the end). But with them  and their own money, their own respectable center-right supporters, and so on? Lets just say that when youre polling at just 25 percent in a head-to-head against Rubio (and the Rubio-Walker head-to-head is a lot closer), you have a problem that a better answer to questions about the Iraq invasion isnt going to be enough to solve.

title: Does an Award Like the Baileys Womens Prize for Fiction Help or Hurt the Cause of Women Writers?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zo Heller and Dana Stevens debate the merit of literary prizes for which only women compete.

title: Rolling Stones Start Themselves Up in San Diego
description: The Rolling Stones kicked off their 15-city ZIP Code North American tour in San Diego on Sunday night, delivering an energetic 20-song show before a sold-out stadium crowd.

title: A Dutch Festival Returns
description: Le Guess Who?, the nine-yearold free-form Dutch music festival in Utrecht, will take place Nov. 19 to 22, its organizers will announce on Tuesday.

title: Aftermath of Flooding in Texas
description: Aerial views of the Houston area show the aftermath of flooding, after heavy storms and flash floods hit parts of the state.

title: Deutsche Bank to Pay $55 Million to Settle Derivatives Inquiry
description: Deutsche Bank overstated the value of a multibillion-dollar portfolio of sophisticated derivatives during the height of the financial crisis, leading it to file inaccurate financial statements for at least a six-month stretch, securities regulators in the United States said on Tuesday.

title: Things I Wish Id Been Wrong About
description: Brad DeLong remembers a blog post of mine from 2009 about the non-threat of an interest rate spike; I have to say that it looks pretty darn good analytically after all these years. Unfortunately, it was also right about this:

title: Here Comes Hillary: Even Comic Books Arent Immune From Campaign Fever
description: Bluewater Productions, which publishes comic book biographies, has come down with 2016 presidential campaign fever. On Wednesday the company will release Hillary Clinton: The Road to the White House, written by Michael L. Frizell and illustrated by Joe Paradise. It follows the release of a comic devoted to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, and there are plans for comics focusing on Jeb Bush, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

title: French Muslims Say Veil Bans Give Cover to Bias
description: WISSOUS, France  Malek Layouni was not thinking about her Muslim faith, or her head scarf, as she took her excited 9-year-old son to an amusement site near Paris. But, as it turned out, it was all that mattered.

title: Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty, byCharles Leerhsen
description: Only institutions that possess actual powers of war inspire more self-righteous reflection about the uses of their authority than the Baseball Hall of Fame. When more lenient fans discuss what level of villainy should be allowable in members of the hall, a common refrain goes: Well, if they let Ty Cobb in. ...

title: Margaret Atwood Delivers Work to Be Published in 2114
description: LONDON  The author Margaret Atwood  perhaps best known for her dystopian-future-set novel The Handmaids Tale made a further contribution to the fictional future today, handing over a secret manuscript to Oslos public library to be published in 2114.

title: Youth, Pre-Revolt
description: Daniel Kings photographs capture Ukrainian teens months before the recent civil unrest there.

title: Asparagus: Stylish, Slender and Easily Accessorized
description: Hooray and hallelujah. Fat spears of local asparagus have made their triumphant seasonal return to Northeastern farmers markets. Juicier, sweeter and, obviously, far fresher than long-haul asparagus from Peru or Chile, local asparagus is a cheap thrill; get it while you can.

title: SFX Reaches $774 Million Deal for Founder to Take Company Private
description: SFX Entertainment, a company started to capitalize on the popularity of dance music festivals, has reached a $774 million deal for its founder, Robert F.X. Sillerman, to take the company private, less than two years after its initial public offering.

title: Treating Corporations as People
description: As a Republican presidential candidate, Mitt Romney once responded to a heckler by saying, Corporations are people, my friend.

title: Ugly Fruits Get Their Day
description: A European advertising campaign asks why fruit that simply isnt pretty needs to get thrown away.

title: 1965: Voting Rights Bill Adopted
description: WASHINGTON  After five weeks of debate, the Senate today [May 26] approved President Johnsons Negro voting rights bill by a 77-to-19 roll call. Senate passage of the historic measure came after the isolated Southern camp concluded a bitter verbal assault on the bill, which would suspend literacy tests and install federal registrars throughout much of the old Confederacy. The bill now goes to the House. Should the House, however, insist on making some relatively minor changes in the voting bill, a conference could still be avoided by sending the revised draft back to the Senate for approval.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 27, 1965

title: Lassa Fever Carries Little Risk to Public, Experts Say
description: The report that a man who traveled from Liberia to New Jersey had died on Monday from the viral illness Lassa fever is another reminder that infectious diseases can hop continents and elude detection by health care workers who do not know a patients travel history.

title: Iraqi Army and Shiite Militias Begin Push to Take Ramadi From ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi officials said Tuesday that a combined force of Iraqi soldiers and allied Shiite militias had started moving to retake the city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, from Islamic State fighters.

title: Time Warner Cable Finds That Money Covers Charters Flaws
description: Time Warner Cable has concluded that one out of four aint bad.

title: Toogoods Indigo Installation in Amagansett
description: We hereby reject and reprehend the cruel diktats of the discredited fashionista treadmill, reads the brand manifesto for Toogood, the clothing line created by the British designer Faye Toogood and her younger sister, the Savile Row-trained pattern cutter and fashion designer Erica Toogood. Like the elder Toogoods celebrated furniture and interiors, the project  which introduces its second collection this spring, though the sisters disavow the concept of fashion seasons  is a humanistic exploration of the possibilities of handicraft. Each unisex, oversize piece is named for a profession (the plumber jumpsuit, the beekeeper jacket) and finished with droll details (handpainted mask appliqus, Abolish the High Street spelled out in frayed rope) that must be seen in person to be fully appreciated. Now, Statesiders will have the chance to do just that thanks to a new installation created by the sisters at Tiina, the Amagansett boutique owned by the influential Finnish-born stylist Tiina Laakkonen.

title: Kayak Suspect Moved Paddle Away as Fianc Died, Prosecutors Say
description: GOSHEN, N.Y.  Her fianc, separated from his kayak, struggled in the frigid and choppy waters of the Hudson River, reaching for his paddle to save his life. But prosecutors here in Orange County said on Tuesday that Angelika Graswald moved it away, and was slow to call for help.

title: Suspect Killed by Police After Woman Is Fatally Shot Outside Queens Casino
description: Gunshots were fired early on Tuesday in the parking lot of the Resorts World Casino in Queens. The police were called, and officers discovered a 55-year-old woman slumped in her car, fatally wounded.

title: Jeb Bush Signals More Funding and Faster Drug Approval for Alzheimers
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush opened up last week about his mother-in-laws affliction with Alzheimers disease and, on Tuesday, shed some light on what he thinks should be done to fight the illness.

title: More Strikes at National Gallery in London
description: National Gallery employees in London began a new wave of strikeson Tuesdayat one of Londons most-visited museums to protest ongoing measures to privatize some staff positions.

title: Urban Gardening Tips
description: Herbs, tomatoes, blueberries, nasturtiums and many other edibles can flourish in window boxes, pots, hanging baskets and recycled containers.

title: A Garden Suspended From the Top Floor
description: Kerry Trueman and Matt Rosenberg garden from the windowsill of their West Village walk-up.

title: Urban Gardening on the Third Floor
description: Kerry Trueman and Matt Rosenberg began by growing tomatoes on the roof of their third-floor walk-up in the West Village more than 20 years ago.

title: Charters Advisers Stage a Comeback
description: When Comcast swooped in with an offer to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion last year, a small platoon of advisers for Charter Communications found themselves out of a huge payday.

title: Jessica Lange, Gabriel Byrne To Star in Long Days Journey on Broadway
description: Gabriel Byrne and Jessica Lange will play James and Mary Tyrone on Broadway in Eugene ONeills Long Days Journey into Night, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

title: Ann Kirkpatrick to Challenge John McCain for Arizona Senate
description: Representative Ann Kirkpatrick announced on Tuesday that she will run for United States Senate in Arizona, setting up a likely challenge to Senator John McCain.

title: With Short-Term Goals, Go for a Bird in the Hand
description: A friend of mine recently sold his house. It will be a few years before hell buy another one. Because the house was worth a lot more than what he and his wife owed the bank on their mortgage, they are now sitting on a pile of money and wondering what to do with it.

title: Tech Rivalries Impede Digital Medical Record Sharing
description: WASHINGTON  Since President Obama took office, the federal government has poured more than $29 billion into health information technology and told doctors and hospitals to use electronic medical records or face financial penalties.

title: Police in Cleveland Accept Tough Standards on Force
description: CLEVELAND  The Cleveland police department, which has become synonymous with the racially charged debate over police tactics, has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, and it will accept close oversight to make sure those rules are not ignored, city and federal officials said Tuesday.

title: The King of Cable Behind a Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
description: When the billionaire media executive John C. Malone bought a million acres of Maine forestland in 2011, assuming the mantle of Americas top landowner from his friend and fellow mogul Ted Turner, he made no triumphant announcement. Instead, he shielded his identity through a shell company.

title: A Drive for Swing State Votes Has Colorados Latinos Listening
description: AURORA, Colo.  Under the red roof of Lupitas Mexican Restaurant, Elizabeth Oxley and her 23-year-old daughter, Leticia, work seven days a week, from breakfast to last call, to keep pace with the price of their familys American dream. There is a $250,000 renovation on their restaurant to pay off. Mortgage bills. College loans.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Settle Meaning of One Person One Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Tuesday to hear a case that will answer a long-contested question about a bedrock principle of the American political system: the meaning of one person one vote.

title: Reporters Brother on Iran Spying Trial
description: Ali Rezaian  the brother of Jason Rezaian, a reporter for The Washington Post  spoke on Tuesday as his brothers trial on espionage charges began in Iran.

title: Obama Warns Senators on Lapse in Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  With time running out, President Obama on Tuesday urged the Senate to pass legislation to renew surveillance programs that are scheduled to expire next weekend or risk endangering the American people.

title: Aquavit
description: Scandinavian cuisine that stands the test of time in Midtown.

title: Restaurant Review: Aquavit in Midtown
description: Time to cheer for Aquavit and its power to defy the forces of gravity.

title: Key to a Quick Goal? It May Be Resting in the Penalty Box
description: The moment when a hockey penalty is successfully killed has its own rhythm. The goalie whose team no longer has the man advantage pounds his stick against the ice, alerting his teammates the way a guard might signal a prison break. And the punished player bursts from the penalty box, often to join the action, skating harder than ever.

title: Scott Walker May Let Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio Fight Over Florida
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has not formally announced that he is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, but he has clearly given some thought to what his campaign strategy might be if he does run.

title: Will the Charter-Time Warner Deal Benefit Customers?
description: Charters proposed $56.7 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable poses fewer antitrust problems than Comcasts ill-fated plan to buy Time Warner Cable. But the Federal Communications Commission should still study the proposal carefully to make sure it will benefit the companies customers.

title: Portraits of the Youth of a Nation on the Verge of Revolution
description: Everyone knows that adolescence can be a particularly turbulent time. But in the case of the teenagers photographed by Daniel King for Ukraine Youth: Between Days (Damiani, $40), the nations then-impending revolution lends an added dimension of angst to that equation  The Breakfast Club, this is not. Shot in the final months of 2013 leading up to Ukraines descent into civil war, Kings photographs document the innocent revelry and flirtations of kids whose countrys fate is increasingly uncertain. Kings candid work falls somewhere between Larry Clark and Nan Goldin, and his interest in Ukrainian teens is part of a larger project he is working on, photographing youth culture around the world.

title: Federal Panel Lets Injunction Against Obamas Immigration Actions Stand
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday denied the Obama administrations request to lift a hold on the presidents executive actions on immigration, which would have granted protection from deportation as well as work permits to millions of immigrants in the country illegally.

title: Security Researchers Start Effort to Protect Smart Cities
description: Its a brave new world when hackers step in to protect citizens because regulators are not getting the job done.

title: Fledgling Fashion Designers
description: Some of the best looks from the 2015 graduating classes best talent.

title: ASAP Rockys Album Released Early, Thanks to a Leak
description: Album release dates might add an asterisk: *if there is no leak.

title: Supreme Court Rules on Whistle-Blower Case and Bankruptcy Judges
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled in favor of military contractors facing a whistle-blower lawsuit and expanded the power of bankruptcy judges to decide claims ordinarily litigated in other federal courts.

title: Garlic Shrimp Lightened by Its Own Broth
description: Garlic shrimp is a favorite tapa in Spain and a popular seafood dish on both coasts of Mexico. I love everything about it except for the excessive amount of olive oil, so I lightened the traditional dish by swapping out some of the oil for a tasty broth made with shrimp shells.

title: Hand to God Melds Gore and Giggles, Each Often Elicited by a Puppet
description: In Hand to God, a hand puppet named Tyrone violently bites the ear of an unsuspecting young man, and the audience, both times I saw the show, seemed unsure how to react.

title: Jungle Camp in Malaysia Yields Graves and Signs of Migrant Abuse
description: BUKIT WANG BURMA, Malaysia  Among the debris of wood, bamboo and plastic tarpaulin at an abandoned camp in the dense jungle here lies a coffin-size cage made from sticks tied together with rusted barbed wire. Next to it, an enclosure that could have held scores of people also bristles with barbed wire. And over a ridge, the police have started unearthing bodies from shallow graves.

title: Ducks Patrick Maroon, a Fallen Top Prospect, Climbs All the Way Back
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The 2010-11 season was supposed to be a pivotal one for the Philadelphia Flyers prospect Patrick Maroon. A sixth-round draft pick by the Flyers in 2007, he was expected to make the jump to the National Hockey League.

title: Obama Urges Senate to Work During Recess
description: The president urged the Senate on Tuesday to pass legislation that would renew telephone surveillance programs before authorities from the Patriot Act expire on Sunday night.

title: Rucksacks
description: The classic design gets a grown-up feel thanks to dark colors and luxe materials.

title: 2 Rising Players, Bouchard and Dimitrov, Fail to Get Out of First Round
description: PARIS  While most favorites at the French Open advanced past the first round without issue, two of the brightest young lights of last summer could not on Tuesday.

title: Fried Guacamole, an Appetizer Mashup at Abajo
description: To Make: Letting Guacamole Stand on Its Own

title: Review: D Deb Debbie Deborah, a Dizzying Subversion of Identity
description: Have they come up with a name yet for the fear of identity theft? Egokleptophobia, maybe? Whatever you want to call this topical neurosis, it throbs like an insistent bass line in D Deb Debbie Deborah, Jerry Lieblichs dizzyingly clever new play about mutating selfhood.

title: Review: Ibrahim Maalouf Salutes a Great Arabic Performer
description: Ibrahim Maalouf took just one unaccompanied trumpet solo in his early set at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Monday night, but it was a depth charge, a flash immersion in the distinguishing features of his art. A moment earlier his band had been busy with a tumbling vamp in 7/8 meter, and he carried that pulse as he improvised, in dartlike bursts and a shadowy tone. At one point he segued into what sounded like a classical trumpet tude, exuding an impeccable control, before he moved on to a series of quavering embellishments and shivery incantations.

title: Tavern on the Green Adds a Beer Garden
description: Headliner

title: Review: New York Youth Symphony Fearlessly Tackles Beethovens Ninth
description: Bold and fearless. Thats the instruction to the musicians that marks the first page of Molly Joyces Fresh (2014), which had its world premiere as part of the New York Youth Symphonys spring concert at Carnegie Hall. And it could stand as a description of the orchestras playing throughout Sundays program, especially in a properly exciting performance of Beethovens Ninth Symphony.

title: Review: New York Philharmonics Memorial Day Concert
description: British composers should all endeavor to have their works performed in this hall, the waggish English maestro Thomas Beecham is supposed to have said of the vast Royal Albert Hall in London, with its notorious echo. They will thus be assured of at least two performances.

title: Youngstown, Ohio, Reinvents Its Downtown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  This city, long derided for its high crime, is starting to attract something once thought unfathomable downtown: permanent residents. A partnership between Pan Brothers Associates, based in Manhattan, and a local developer, Dominic J. Marchionda, coupled with a few assists from a local architectural firm, is bringing pedestrian traffic into what were once streets of desolation.

title: Mary Ellen Mark Dies at 75
description: Mary Ellen Mark, a trailblazing documentary photographer, could find the essence of a subject by relying on her passion and drive, keeping things simple but deeply honest.

title: FORM Arcosanti
description: Snapshots of the weekends events, captured by the photographer Tonje Thilesen.

title: China, Updating Military Strategy, Puts Focus on Projecting Naval Power
description: BEIJING  China intends to project naval power in the open ocean in coming years, and not just defend the countrys coastal waters, according to a strategy paper released on Tuesday.

title: Hormel Foods to Buy Applegate Farms for $775 Million
description: Hormel Foods, the company behind brands like Spam and Skippy, announced on Tuesday that it was acquiring Applegate Farms, a maker of natural and organic meats, for about $775 million.

title: Sister Megan Rice, Freed From Prison,Looks Ahead to More Anti-Nuclear Activism
description: For more than a year, Sister Megan Rice, 85, a Roman Catholic nun of the Society of the Holy Child Jesus, had caught occasional glimpses of the glittering World Trade Center from her living quarters: the Metropolitan Detention Center, a federal prison on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Review: Mat Johnsons Loving Day Takes a Satirical Slant on Racial Identities
description: Mat Johnsons new novel, Loving Day, takes its title from an unofficial holiday, one his narrator likens to Mulatto Christmas. Its the observance of the Supreme Court ruling in Loving v. Virginia, which in 1967 decriminalized interracial marriage in America.

title: Nebraska Governor Vetoes Bill to Abolish Death Penalty
description: Gov. Pete Ricketts of Nebraska vetoed a bill on Tuesday that would abolish the death penalty in the state, testing the strength of a bipartisan group of lawmakers who said they would try to override his decision.

title: AOL Discloses It Had 3 Suitors Besides Verizon
description: Verizon Communications may have reached a deal with AOL, but others were in the hunt as well.

title: Government R&D, Private Profits and the American Taxpayer
description: The Academy of Radiology Research has resorted to a creative tactic in a bid to halt the decline in public funding for science: It showed Congress a picture of how much the nation earns from the governments research dollar.

title: Irans Secret Trial of a Journalist
description: Ten months after his unjustified detention, Jason Rezaian, The Washington Posts reporter in Iran, had his first day in court on Tuesday. Like every other aspect of his case, the opening hearing of the trial was shrouded in secrecy.

title: 2015 Tony Nominees
description: For the second annual Tony Awards In Performance Live concert, The New York Times invited five Tony nominees to sing in front of a live audience at 54 Below. They got one chance to get it right. Here are their performances.

title: Netanyahu Wants Talks With Palestinians on Settlements, Officials Say
description: JERUSALEM  Hinting at a new strategy as he starts his fourth term with a more conservative coalition, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the European Unions foreign policy chief that he wants to negotiate with the Palestinians over which settlements in the occupied West Bank would be annexed by Israel, officials said Tuesday.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: MaryEllen Elia Named New York State Education Commissioner
description: A former school superintendent in Florida who led efforts to tie teacher evaluations and pay to student achievement and was fired after clashing with her board was appointed New York States education commissioner on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: the Philippines and Elsewhere
description: The Philippines and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Former Strongman, Taking Over Presidency, Raises Hope in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Here in the Nigerian capital, the rows of campaign billboards promoting President Goodluck Jonathan have been ripped down. In some places, images of the soon-to-be ex-president have been defaced. Mr. Jonathan, with his legacy of economic and military disasters, cannot leave soon enough, in the eyes of many Nigerians.

title: May 26, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the Philippines, Greece, Burundi and Indonesia.

title: 25 Looted Artifacts Return to Italy
description: ROME  At first glance the 25 artifacts displayed in the courtyard of a former convent just off the Tiber River here on Tuesday seemed to have little in common: three first-century B.C. fresco fragments from Pompeii were exhibited alongside fifth- and sixth-century B.C. Etruscan and Attic vases, a 17th-century Venetian cannon, a 12th-century mural fragment depicting Christ and three rare 17th-century books.

title: FORM Arcosanti
description: Snapshots of the weekends events, captured by the photographer Tonje Thilesen.

title: A Shareholder Advocate in Word, but Not in Practice
description: Mario J. Gabellis investment firm, Gamco Investors, is another shareholder warrior telling companies to create value through good corporate governance. Yet, what about Gamcos own governance?

title: Mary Ellen Mark, Photographer and Force of Nature
description: Mary Ellen Mark, one of the leading documentary photographers of the last 50 years, died on Monday from myelodysplastic syndrome, a blood disorder, according to her studio librarian, Meredith Lue. She was 75.

title: High Desert Magic (But Dont Call It a Music Festival)
description: It is difficult to imagine improving on the experience of Arcosanti,the architect Paolo Soleris urban laboratory and Arizona desert eco-experiment. That is until the microcity tucked away an hour north of Phoenix among Saguaro cacti and dark, spindly cypress trees  hosts FORM Arcosanti, a three-day gathering curated by the dreamy quartet Hundred Waters. With a lineup of bands like Majical Cloudz, Holly Herndon and How to Dress Well, a standout performance by the folk chanteuse Julie Byrne and a special guest performance by Skrillex, one might be tempted to call the sum of the past weekends events a music festival. But that would be missing the point.

title: Setback for President on Immigration
description: A federal judge had issued an injunction against Obama administration programs for immigrants. Tuesday, an appeals court panel said that public interest favors maintenance of the injunction.

title: Vox Media Adds ReCode to Its Stable of Websites
description: ReCode, the news website led by the veteran journalists Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher, is being acquired by Vox Media, a deal that reflects the turmoil among digital organizations focused on covering the tech industry.

title: A Conversation With Ashwin Y. Verma
description: Mr. Verma, 44, is a founder and the managing partner of Siras Development, which specializes in hospitality and residential developments. The company, which is based in New York, is developing the Hudson Rise Hotel at Hudson Yards and Soori High Line, a condominium with private pools.

title: Motion Picture Academy Contemplates Changes
description: LOS ANGELES  Neighbors are rising against its museum plan. Archivists have been jolted by a sexual harassment suit.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: In Texas, the Race to Build in Harms Way Outpaces Flood-Risk Studies and Warming Impacts
description: The holiday and the type of hazard have changed, but once again fast-growing Texas is seeing outsize (and tragic) impacts from extreme weather events.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Living in North Stamford, Conn.
description: The highest-income section of Connecticuts third-largest city appeals to those who value city conveniences but prefer to live in a more parklike setting.

title: Long Sentence Sought for Silk Road Creator Ross Ulbricht
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are seeking  a lengthy prison sentence for the creator of Silk Road, a once-thriving website that allowed users to anonymously buy and sell heroin, cocaine, LSD and other drugs online until it was shut down by the authorities in 2013.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: A Four-Bedroom Neo-Baroque Mansion in Budapest
description: The 1932 house, which was recently renovated and has an indoor pool, is on the market for $3.58 million.

title: Mary Ellen Mark, Photographer Who Documented Difficult Subjects, Dies at 75
description: Mary Ellen Mark, whose unflinching yet compassionate depictions of prostitutes in Mumbai, homeless teenagers in Seattle and mental patients in a state institution in Oregon made her one of the premier documentary photographers of her generation, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: Justice Dept. on Cleveland Settlement
description: Steven Dettelbach, the United States attorney in Northern Ohio, and Vanita Gupta of the Justice Departments Civil Rights Division announced a settlement with Cleveland over the use of police force.

title: Hamas Is Accused of Using Gaza War as Cover to Torture and Kill Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  The militant group Hamas used last summers war with Israel in the Gaza Strip to carry out extrajudicial killings of at least 23 Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israel and to torture dozens of others, including political rivals, Amnesty International charged in a report issued early Wednesday.

title: Prosecutor Announces Kayak Indictment
description: David M. Hoovler, the Orange County district attorney, announced Tuesday that Angelika Graswald had been indicted on charges of second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.

title: Governor Cuomos Legislative Agenda Faces New and Familiar Obstacles
description: ALBANY  When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unveiled his vision for his second term on New Years Day in an inaugural speech from the heights of 1 World Trade Center, his ambitions were as lofty as the view, an expansive agenda touching on poverty, income inequality, ethics and criminal justice reform.

title: A Female Fantasia in Morocco
description: Zara Samiry rediscovered the North African equestrian tradition of Fantasia when she learned of a troupe of women who pushed traditional boundaries.

title: Danish Radio Station Defends Host Who Clubbed Rabbit to Death During Animal Welfare Debate
description: A radio station in Denmark argued on Tuesday that it was merely fulfilling its public service mandate to provoke debate when the host of a morning show beat a baby rabbit to death with a bicycle pump this week during a live discussion of animal welfare.

title: Mary Ellen Mark Dies at 75
description: Mary Ellen Mark, a trailblazing documentary photographer, could find the essence of a subject by relying on her passion and drive, keeping things simple but deeply honest.

title: Bernie Sanders Challenges Hillary Clinton at His First Rally
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont began drawing implicit contrasts with Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday in the race for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, as he played the liberal purist in throwing down policy gauntlet after gauntlet  a $15 minimum wage, $1 trillion for public works jobs, a Medicare-for-all system of universal health care  in his first campaign rally since declaring his candidacy last month.

title: Sephardic Jews Feel Bigotrys Sting in Turkey and a Pull Back to Spain
description: ISTANBUL  For Rafi, a local newspapers anti-Semitic crossword puzzle was the final affront. He knew he had to leave Turkey.

title: Diarys Pages May Help Jurors Decide if Colorado Gunman Was Methodical or Mad
description: DENVER  The brown spiral notebook that James E. Holmes mailed to his psychiatrist shortly before he opened fire in a sold-out movie theater has been one of the most important, and closely guarded, pieces of evidence in the murder case against him. It has been stored under seal, and the murderous fantasies and rambling writings inside have been shielded from public view.

title: Libyan Prime Minister Survives Assassination Attempt Amid Protests
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The prime minister of Libyas internationally recognized government survived an assassination attempt Tuesday after facing hostile questioning inside Parliament and demands for his resignation from armed protesters outside.

title: Amtrak to Install Cameras to Monitor Locomotive Engineers
description: Amtrak said on Tuesday that it would begin installing cameras intended to monitor the actions of engineers driving locomotives like the one that derailed in Philadelphia two weeks ago, killing eight passengers.

title: Bears Stumble in N.F.L.s Quagmire on Domestic Violence
description: In past years, the Chicago Bears might have been praised for their decision on Monday to cut Ray McDonald, who was arrested on a misdemeanor domestic violence charge. The team might have been lauded for taking a tough stand on players who misbehaved off the field and discredited the N.F.L.

title: Cyberattack Exposes I.R.S. Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON  Criminals used stolen data to gain access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people through an application on the Internal Revenue Services website, the agency said on Tuesday.

title: Afghan Minerals, Another Failure
description: In 2010, the Pentagon and American geologists estimated that Afghanistan has $1 trillion of untapped mineral deposits, including huge veins of iron, copper, cobalt, gold and industrial metals like lithium. Gen. David Petraeus, who was then the chief of the United States Central Command, said there was stunning potential for the war-ravaged country, which by now should have begun to reap much-needed revenue and equally needed jobs.

title: Out of the Loop at the French Open, and Liking It That Way
description: PARIS  The social media age is also the age of the spoiler alert. Surprise movie endings and abrupt plot twists could all be lurking in a timeline.

title: Broadway Sets Sales and Attendance Records With Tourism Boom
description: Buoyed by a rising stream of tourists, the unexpected popularity of an adolescent with Aspergers syndrome, the star power of Larry David and Helen Mirren, and the enduring appeal of a lion named Simba, the Broadway season that just ended was the highest-grossing ever.

title: Charters Guarded Optimism That This Time a Merger Will Clear
description: When Comcast agreed in early 2014 to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion, it looked to a lot of people like a safe bet for regulatory approval. We all know how that turned out.

title: Mexico: Michoacn Killings Prompt Human Rights Inquiry
description: The National Human Rights Commission has opened an investigation into the killing of 42 people last week in a confrontation with the federal police. The authorities have described those killed as members of a powerful gang who fired repeatedly on officers during a three-hour battle in Michoacn State in southwestern Mexico. Security analysts and commentators have raised questions about the lopsided toll; there were only three arrests, no wounded survivors, and only one police officer killed. Last year, the killing of 22 people in a confrontation with the army led to charges against several soldiers when the commission determined that most victims had been summarily executed after an initial gun battle.

title: Transport in an Ellington Tune
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Here is an example of how an everyday experience can spark a creative idea. Jim Quinlan, a middle-school teacher from Westtown, N.Y., came up with todays theme while he was herding middle-schoolers, and the resulting lunchtime conversation has led to his New York Times crossword debut.

title: Al Attles, a Warrior for Life, Is a Bridge to a Lone Bay Area Title
description: Shortly after the Houston Rockets had defeated Golden State in Game 4 of the Western Conference finals on Monday, Al Attles was back in his hotel room, preparing for the trip back to California.

title: Trial Opens in Collapse of Dewey & LeBoeuf Firm
description: Three former executives of the law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf, who are accused of using accounting gimmicks to defraud its lenders, sought to deflect the blame for the once-prominent firms collapse during the start of their trial on Tuesday.

title: Qaeda Member Pleads Guilty in Brooklyn on Terrorism Charges
description: A member of Al Qaeda who led a firefight in Afghanistan in 2008 that killed an Army Ranger pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Brooklyn to four counts related to his terrorism activities.

title: Judge Rules Larry Seabrook, Ex-New York Councilman, Must Forfeit His Pension
description: A former New York City councilman, Larry B. Seabrook, must forfeit his public pension benefits to pay a $418,000 judgment he owes the government as a result of his 2012 conviction on federal corruption charges, a judge ruled on Tuesday.

description: Marcus Belgrave, a trumpet and fluegelhorn player who worked with Ray Charles, Charles Mingus, Max Roach and others before settling in Detroit in the early 1960s and becoming a coach and conscience for that citys jazz scene, died on May 23 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 78.

He stood in his crease, looking stoic, when his counterpart was called off the ice to take a seat on the bench in the third period after having allowed five Rangers goals in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Inside The Timess Apple Watch News App
description: When Apple offered its latest product, the Apple Watch, The Times was ready with a news app designed to catch readers up on the latest news stories with just a glance at their wrists.

title: A Music Video That Takes Cut and Paste to a New Level
description: The musician Paul de Jong could be seen as a spiritual precursor to the Tumblr generation  or, possibly, as its polar opposite. Its not like Im pulling my imagery from the Internet where its already available, says de Jong, referring to the massive collection of music, books and other ephemera that line the walls of his New Lebanon, N.Y. workspace and studio. What appeals to me is that it cant be found anywhere. De Jong is a cellist and songwriter best known for his role as half of the experimental duo the Books, whose cut-and-paste musical collages resulted in some of the 2000s most beguiling records. Now recording solo, de Jongs penchant for found sound and folk-pop has made its way to his new album If (out now via Temporary Residence) and the handmade animated video for Hollywald, which were premiering for the first time here.

title: Sleek Backpacks for Discerning Adults
description: Spare, dark and all in leather, the rucksack sheds its middle-school vibe without losing any of its boyish charm.

title: The Art of Growing (and Eating) Bamboo
description: The chef Hugh Acheson pickles the wild, locally-grown shoots, and shares a recipe for the jarred goods in his new cookbook (and online, here).

title: Londons New Trio of Exceptional Kebabs
description: That bastion of late-night British cuisine, the humble kebab shop, is slowly shedding its boozy reputation thanks to a round of gourmet grill houses opening up in the capital. Foremost is Sesame, a cheerful, no-reservations Mediterranean street-food spot just opened in Londons Covent Garden. Its the first fast-food venture from the upmarket deli group Ottolenghi  conceived by Noam Bar, the longstanding business partner, and former boyfriend, of the influential chef and food writer Yotam Ottolenghi. Its a happy marriage between meat, fresh salad and beautiful condiments, explains the Haifa-raised creator of Sesames spiced lamb kebab, which is served in the traditional Turkish style with mint yogurt, tahini, zhough (a Yemenite chili paste) and a pared-down version of the signature Ottolenghi salad  all neatly encased in the most pillowy pitta youre likely to encounter this side of Istanbul. An awful lot of thought went into the spices, Bar says. Theres even some cinnamon in there. Inspiration for Sesame struck the Ottolenghi co-founder as he raced around central London looking for on-the-run lunch offerings: The possibilities are still pretty limited, he says, adding, I thought, Enough of the sandwiches!

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 3:15 P.M. (TCM) TO SIR, WITH LOVE (1967) Sidney Poitier stars as Thackeray, an idealistic new teacher in London assigned to a school near the citys docks, where his Cockney-accented students are ill-mannered and insolent. Christian Roberts plays Denham, the arrogant teenager who incites Thackerays latest classroom edict: If the students want to be treated as the adults they are about to become, they must act like adults. A nice air of gentility suffuses this pretty color film, and Mr. Poitier gives a quaint example of being proper and turning the other cheek, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times about James Clavells drama. And so To Sir, With Love comes off as a cozy, good-humored and unbelievable little tale of a teacher getting acquainted with his pupils, implying but never stating that it is nice for the races to live congenially together. The singer Lulu performs the title song, which became a No. 1 hit.

title: A Female Fantasia in Morocco
description: The French Romantic painter Eugne Delacroix traveled to North Africa, shortly after his country conquered Algeria in 1830, to experience what he viewed as a more primitive society. He made more than 100 paintings based on an Orientalist view of exotic people wearing colorful costumes, including a series featuring men on horseback firing rifles during what he referred to as military exercises, or Fantasia.

title: Contain and Amplify
description: The Arab world is a pluralistic region that lacks pluralism  the ability to manage and embrace differences peacefully. As such, the Middle Easts pluralistic character  Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds, Christians, Druze, Alawites, Jews, Copts, Yazidis, Turkmen and an array of tribes  has long been managed by iron fists from above. But after we removed the fists in Iraq and Libya, without putting a new bottom-up order in place, and the people themselves tried to remove the fists in Syria and Yemen, without putting a new live-and-let-live order in place, a horrifying war of all against all has exploded.

title: Are Some Extreme Sports Too Extreme?
description: Extreme sports like BASE jumping and unroped climbing have acquired mass audiences and corporate sponsorships. But they are also very risky. Dozens of jumpers have died parachuting off fixed objects, including the celebrated climber Dean Potter just this month. Meanwhile, children are participating in extreme sports at ever-younger ages, looking for more heart-racing thrills and vying to win intense competitions.

title: A Murky Road Ahead for Android, Despite Market Dominance
description: In 2005, Google bought a tiny mobile software company named Android, and almost nobody in the technology industry saw its potential  not even Eric Schmidt, Googles chairman and then chief executive. One day Larry and Sergey bought Android, and I didnt even notice, Mr. Schmidt told reporters in 2009, referring to Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Googles founders.

title: Most Hong Kongers Support Banning Ivory Sales, Poll Finds
description: Animal conservation groups stepped up their campaign to end the ivory trade in Hong Kong this week by releasing the results of a survey that found that most respondents favored a comprehensive ban on the sale of ivory.

title: U.N. Reports About 200 Million Fewer Hungry People Than in 1990
description: The number of hungry people globally has declined from about one billion 25 years ago to about 795 million today, or about one person out of every nine, despite a surge in population growth, the United Nations reported Wednesday.

title: Chinese Tomb Robbers Used Feng Shui to Steal Antiquities
description: Teams of tomb robbers used knowledge of traditional feng shui, high-tech probing devices and the help of archaeologists to steal tens of millions of dollars worth of antiquities, the Chinese authorities said.

title: Horror
description: Thank God for evil. Without it, horror fiction would be a paltry thing, a tattered coat upon a stick or, perhaps, a ragged, bloody, roughly handled zombie action figure for gullible children. That, of course, is what contemporary horror actually is, most of the time. For some writers, though, the damned soul does sometimes clap its hands and sing. Clive Barker knows the tune, and in his new novel, THE SCARLET GOSPELS (St. Martins, $26.99), he belts it out as rapturously as an Irish tenor crooning Danny Boy. Better than half the action of The Scarlet Gospels takes place in hell, where Barker is clearly very much at home. His descriptions of the underworld often recall the grotesque tableaus of Hieronymus Bosch, but are at other times weirdly hushed and lyrical: The sky contained neither sun, nor stars, which was predictable enough, but what it did contain was a stone the size of a small planet. The stone reached high above the immense landscape that spread out below, and it threw off fissures like lightning bolts, through which brightness poured. The effect upon the vast panorama was uncanny. In Barkers work, beauty and evil are an old married couple, living together comfortably, even serenely, with no secrets left from one another.

title: Stephen Kings Finders Keepers
description: Literary celebrity sounds like an oxymoron, but it does happen. Selling millions of books isnt enough; readers have to feel a profound personal connection to the writer. J.K. Rowling is definitely in the club. James Patterson, probably not. Or consider this story, one told to me 20 years ago by a member of the Rock Bottom Remainders, the writer-rock band. (Now that might be an oxymoron.) The band stopped for breakfast at a small-town truck stop before the sun was up. This was pre-smartphone, pre-social media, practically pre-Internet. Yet by the time the band members returned to their tour bus, there were several people lined up, clutching copies of The Stand, eager to meet the bands undisputed rock star, Stephen King.

title: Seveneves, by Neal Stephenson
description: If the moon ever disintegrates, causing Earth to become a fiery hellscape for several thousand years, and we can select only a few hundred humans to entrust with the survival and repropagation of the species, I vote for Neal Stephenson to be one of those humans. Theres just no way he wouldnt do a good job, you know what I mean? Or, at the very least, an astoundingly thorough job.

title: Slushies vs. Frozen Underwear for Hot-Weather Workouts
description: Slushies or frozen underwear  which is better for staying comfortable while exercising in the heat? That pressing question motivated a new study comparing different ways of dealing with workouts in summertime temperatures. It concludes that precooling with ice is helpful, but the benefits depend on where you put the ice.

title: Flying Above Expectations, With Valentinos Name for a Net
description: One sunny afternoon in early May, Maria Grazia Chiuri, a co-designer of Valentino, stood on a platform 23 feet above the roof of a former warehouse sandwiched between the Hudson River and the West Side Highway.

description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: U.S. and Allies to Tie North Koreas Rights Record to Nuclear Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The top nuclear envoys of the United States, South Korea and Japan agreed on Wednesday to ratchet up pressure on North Korea, including a more effective and creative enforcement of sanctions on the impoverished country.

title: How Do You Define a Gang Member?
description: On a rainy day last December, in a courtroom in downtown Modesto, Calif., a 24-year-old white man named Jesse Sebourn, along with five co-defendants, sat accused of second-degree murder. The victim, Erick Gomez, was only 20 when he was shot to death. He was a reputed Norteo gang member who had lived just a few minutes drive from the working-class Modesto neighborhood where Sebourn was raised. The police estimate that there are as many as 10,000 gang members in Stanislaus County, where Modesto is, most either Norteos and Sureos, two of Californias most notorious Latino street gangs. The feud between them often turns deadly, and according to Thomas Brennan, the district attorney, this was one such instance: Sebourn and his co-defendants were Sureo gang members hunting for rivals on Valentines Day in 2013, when they found Gomez, out on a walk with his girlfriend.

title: Another Body Blow for FIFA, and for Sepp Blatter
description: As Sepp Blatter sought election to his first term as president of FIFA, ahead of the 1998 World Cup in France, word spread at the Mridien hotel in Paris of cash-stuffed envelopes meant for something other than Christmas bonuses.

title: New York Today: Drying Up
description: Good morning on this very warm Wednesday.

title: New Online, Interactive View of Ligetis Works
description: BERLIN  The composer Gyorgy Ligetis Piano tudes are considered by some scholars to be the most important contribution to the genre since the works of Chopin. But with influences as varied as sub-Saharan African music and fractal geometry, they place demands on the performer that a printed score cannot fully render.

title: Twitter Reaction to the FIFA Indictments
description: Soon after Swiss authorities  arrested several top soccer officials early Wednesday, journalists and soccer figures took to Twitter to share their reactions and opinions.

title: European Union Asks Member Countries to Accept Quotas of Migrants
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union authorities formally appealed to the blocs member states on Wednesday to accept quotas of migrants to relieve the burden on southern states like Italy and Greece that are the main landing points for them.

title: Wall Street Is Using the Power of Dodd-Frank Against Itself
description: Regulating Wall Street is an Old Testament sort of affair: Like Leviticus, it is all about the persnickety details. But politicians try to talk about it in New Testament terms, with sinners and saints, salvation and damnation. Only they cant agree on who the sinners are  the bankers or the bureaucrats  and wherein lies salvation. Such moralizing, however, does very little to shine light on the benefits and drawbacks of the byzantine 2010 banking regulations known as Dodd-Frank.

title: Can We Finally Treat Food Workers Fairly?
description: Two pieces of seemingly unrelated news last week show just how deficient our values are when it comes to the treatment of the lowest paid workers in our economy, the largest portion of whom are employed in the food chain.

title: Questions for Chef Enrique Olvera
description: Having conquered New York, the Mexican chef Enrique Olvera is returning to his native country to extend his empire. Mr. Olvera, who runs the acclaimed Mexico City restaurant Pujol, opened Cosme in the Flatiron neighborhood of New York last year. Its now one of the hottest restaurants in the city. His next project, to open on June 26, is Manta, the restaurant at the Cape, a Thompson Hotel in Los Cabos on the Baja Peninsula. Mr. Olvera, 39, is also an ambitious, food-centric traveler. During a conversation at Cosme he spoke fondly of the trip he had just taken, which included the Rhine region of Germany, Tokyo and San Sebastin in Spain. And then back to New York, he said. It was two and a half weeks of a lot of eating. Following are edited excerpts from that conversation.

Wed love your feedback as we refine the format and focus, so please email travmail@nytimes.com or comment below to share your thoughts.

title: Matthew Aucoin, Operas Great 25-Year-Old Hope
description: We want to feel like this shape is coming out of the mist, growing legs or something, Matthew Aucoin said to the woodwinds. They were in a rehearsal hall in Boston, workshopping Crossing, Aucoins new opera based on Walt Whitmans Civil War diaries. To the cellos and basses, Aucoin said, I want this to feel psychotic, like the kick drum in a techno song. To the whole orchestra, on the subject of the works constant shifts in meter and cross-grained tempos  designed to counteract what he regards as the innate Italianness of opera and give Crossing the distinctive rhythms of American English  he said: We want it to splinter. Ninety percent of the time Im going to be like, Its not supposed to be together, and 10 percent of the time Ill be like, I messed up.

title: Shermans March on Washington
description: Early on the morning of May 24, 1865, a bright, pleasantly warm day in Washington, D.C., Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman calmly guided his horse to the head of his army. He was about to lead his veteran troops on their last march, this time down Pennsylvania Avenue, before tens of thousands of thronging, wildly cheering citizens and the nations leaders, as part of the two-day Grand Review that celebrated the Union victory.

title: Morning Agenda: Return of the King of Cable
description: RETURN OF THE KING OF CABLE | John C. Malones name was not mentioned in Charter Communications announcement of the acquisitions of Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, nor did the Charter stakeholder participate in the investor call that followed. Yet there is little doubt that Mr. Malone is behind the scenes, orchestrating an upheaval of the industry he helped create two decades ago,  David Gelles writes in DealBook. The way Charter eventually acquired Time Cable Warner  patiently looking for the right time to come in with a winning bid even after a series of setbacks  reflected Mr. Malones style of deal-making. Malone is like an alligator, said Mark Robichaux, author of Cable Cowboy: John Malone and the Rise of the Modern Cable Business. He is perfectly content to wait for the right opportunity for a long time, then will pounce with a ferocity that knows no bounds.

title: Brazilian Soul Food
description: I thought I knew feijoada, that terrific black hole of meats that is the national dish of Brazil: Sausages and ribs and bellies and other cuts sweating fat into inky beans. A party in a pot. When I was a teenager, I read a recipe for it, my eyes growing wider with each meaty entry in the ingredient list, and I vowed one day to make it. Years later, in culinary school, I did, charging the sweet, musky taste of black beans with the muskier taste of muscle and bone. So I know this dish. But it turns out that its even more familiar to me as an American than I thought.

title: Do I Have to Tell About a Co-Workers Rape?
description: My first job out of college was at a major political campaign. Late in the year, an intern told me she had been raped by one of my colleagues and that campaign higher-ups made the problem go away. Im not sure what that means, but the police werent involved, nothing made the news, all the people involved kept their jobs. To my knowledge, this young woman told me and one other colleague. I kept the secret to myself for the last seven years until the other night. I let slip to a journalist friend the very basics of what happened, and now I'm being asked for contacts who can confirm that it happened. The candidate I worked for is running again. I still support the candidate, and I do not want the opponent in office. On the other hand, I am aghast that the organization would cover up such a heinous crime. Im ashamed of myself for not saying anything at the time. Thinking about it makes me feel physically ill. Do I have any obligation to disclose information to this journalist friend? Would I be doing right for the country? For the victim? I signed a nondisclosure agreement when I went to work for the campaign  would leaking information about this to the press put me in any potential legal trouble? NAME WITHHELD

description: As Rick Santorum prepares to officially enter the 2016 race on Wednesday night, a favorite parlor game of Republican insiders is explaining his plummet from the heights of 2012, when he won 11 state caucuses and primaries, to the indifference of voters today, as reflected in polls.

title: Shadowing Jason Matthews, an Ex-Spy Whose Cover Identity Is Author
description: Jason Matthews is a retired spy but doesnt look like one. He more nearly resembles a high school principal: calm, patient, a little bland. The only clues to his former occupation  33 years with the C.I.A.  are his uncanny peripheral vision and his occasional use of terms like ops and intel.

title: Queen Elizabeth on E.U. Referendum Plan
description: Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday announced the British governments plan to seek an in-out European Union referendum.

title: Trans-Pacific Trade Pact Highlights the Political Power of the Affluent
description: The Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal making its way through Congress is the latest step in a decades-long trend toward liberalizing trade  a somewhat mysterious development given that many Americans are skeptical of freer trade.

title: Jeb Bush Adviser at Odds With Him on Immigration Action
description: Jeb Bushs team, which has looked for many of its advisers to pledge fidelity to his all-but-declared campaign, has at least one who is still involved in multiple projects.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 518 & 519
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 518 & 519

title: Some California Farmers Share the Drought Burden
description: A group of California water rights-holders have volunteered to cut their water use significantly to avoid steeper cuts later on. Their plan, approved by the state water board on Friday, is a positive step in a state thats still struggling to rein in agricultural water use.

title: Migrants Rescued From the Sea Face Uncertainty in Indonesian Camps
description: BAYEUN, Indonesia  Mohammed Salim sat on a straw mat in an open-air tent, trying to avoid the stifling midday heat.

title: Entrepreneurs Raising the Next Generation of Chief Executives
description: Perhaps the most compelling family business narrative has long been about passing on an enterprise to the next generation. But with small business start-ups proliferating, and frequently growing in step with the children of company founders, it is not just the enterprise but the spirit of enterprise  the desire to create a new one  that is being passed on to the next generation.

title: Rand Paul Holds Republican Hawks Responsible for ISIS
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been doing his best to differentiate himself from fellow Republicans who are running for president and, on Wednesday, he ratcheted up his talking points by holding foreign policy hawks in his own party responsible for the growing strength of Islamic State militants.

title: With New Resorts, Macau Places Its Bets on the Chinese Middle Class
description: Macau, already the worlds most prosperous gambling destination, opened a new casino on Wednesday: the Galaxy Macau Phase II.

title: What You Get for  $775,000
description: This weeks homes include a cabin in California, a stone and stucco house in Texas and an old church in Massachusetts.

title: Fresh-Out-of-Fashion-School Designers to Watch
description: Graduates from around the world presented voluminous and otherworldly silhouettes, skillfully designed around bold textiles, in their final runway shows. Here, some of the best looks from the talented young designers to watch.

title: 1940: Roosevelt Ends Isolationism
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt, in a nation-wide broadcast that wrote finis to the chapter of United States isolationism, outlined a program last night [May 26] through which, he declared, the United States can match the strength of the aggressors while retaining its social gains and its American way of living. The President attributed the attitude of the isolationists to good faith but lack of interest or knowledge. There are some among us, he said, who were persuaded by minority groups that we could maintain our physical safety by retiring within our continental boundaries.
