title: James Bond to Find an Old Acquaintance in New Novel: Pussy Galore
description: LONDON  Will you visit me in Sing Sing? the violet-eyed Pussy Galore asked James Bond at the end of Ian Flemings Goldfinger. Did he? Perhaps well find out soon: Pussy Galore is set to return in Anthony Horowitzs new James Bond novel, the author announced Thursday. Mr. Horowitz also divulged the title of the novel, which will be published in September. Those averse to puns, look away: its Trigger Mortis.

title: 1965: Hussein: Jordan Will Retaliate
description: AMMAN  King Hussein of Jordan declared today [May 28] that Israeli border attacks endanger regional security and world peace. He warned that Jordan will retaliate the next time Israel violates truce provision. The king summoned the ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States and cited the provocative attacks by Israeli forces on three border villages last night. A government spokesman charged that Israel prepared for the action by distributing a memorandum at the UN Security Council accusing Jordan of blowing up two houses at Affula in Israel.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 29, 1965

title: Bulls Dismiss Coach Tom Thibodeau and End a Rocky Tenure
description: In five seasons as coach of the Chicago Bulls, Tom Thibodeau compiled a 255-139 record and guided the team to five straight playoff appearances while dealing with serious injuries to stars like Derrick Rose.

title: Latvia: The Thrill Is Gone
description: Back in 2013, when Olivier Blanchard presented a paper on Latvia at the Brookings Panel, many of the participants were bemused: why was the august panel devoting so much time to a country with the population of Brooklyn? But Latvia was, for a time, the great poster child for austerity.

title: U.S. to Limit Petroleum Drilling on Habitat of Greater Sage Grouse
description: The Obama administration, aiming to keep a finicky, chickenlike bird called the greater sage grouse off the endangered species list, moved on Thursday to limit petroleum drilling and other activities on some of its wide-ranging habitat in the American West.

title: Art and Hypocrisy in the Gulf
description: LONDON  On May 11, the Lebanese artist Walid Raad was turned away at the airport when he tried to enter the United Arab Emirates, where the government is making a big investment in art with the Saadiyat Island project. The project, in the capital, Abu Dhabi, will include branches of the Louvre and the Guggenheim as well as a campus of New York University.

title: An Artist Recreates Her Mothers All-White-Everything Closet
description: Sara was beautiful inside and out; her hair was white, and she wore only white clothes, explains the artist Maira Kalman in the audio guide to her new exhibition, Sara Bermans Closet, a painstaking recreation of her mothers closet. Mostly, she was adored. Berman, who was born in Belarus in 1920, lived in Palestine and the Bronx before relocating in 1982 to Greenwich Village, where she maintained an impeccably organized closet filled with all-white clothing and accessories. The closet was both ordinary and extraordinary, and Kalman wanted to share with others its clarity of vision. I thought it would be amazing to have people come see the closet and pay 50 cents to a dollar, Kalman says with a laugh. It was a crazy idea that made a lot of sense to me.

title: Dalai Lama Urges Aung San Suu Kyi to Help Myanmars Rohingya
description: BANGKOK  When they embraced democracy and vowed to leave behind their repressive and dictatorial past, the leaders of Myanmar enjoyed a honeymoon of praise and admiration from luminaries across the globe.

title: Texas Storm Victims Start Cleaning Up, Even as Rain Still Falls
description: WIMBERLEY, Tex.  The Blanco River runs past the house Sue Sweat has rented for 13 years, and its usually ankle deep, she said, low enough to walk across.

title: Kennedy Center Sets Lineup for New American Orchestras Festival
description: When the Kennedy Center in Washington announced this year that it would start a new festival of American orchestras to fill the void that was left after the adventurous Spring for Music Festival at Carnegie Hall folded after four years, the orchestral world took notice.

title: Rhubarb, From Plant to Salad
description: Chef Michael Reardon prepares a salad with the pie plant and other springtime ingredients.

title: What Is Your Experience With the Legal System?
description: Describe your interaction with a city or county court, probation system or jail using this form.

title: European Soccer Leaders Discuss Blatter
description: The English Football Association chairman, the president of the German Football Federation, the Russian sports minister and the UEFA president weighed in on Sepp Blatter and FIFAs coming election.

title: How to Get the Most Out of the National Parks This Summer
description: Last year saw a record number of visitors to the National Park Services more than 400 parks, monuments, battlefields, seashores and other sites. Those numbers are expected to increase as the agency approaches its centennial on Aug. 25, 2016.

title: Spotted Pig Team Plans a High-Rise Project Downtown
description: Heres fresh evidence that downtown, far downtown, has become a major dining draw: The chef April Bloomfield and the restaurateur Ken Friedman of the Spotted Pig are planning a high-altitude project spanning four of the top floors of 70 Pine Street, a 1931 Art Deco building that was the New York headquarters of the insurance giant AIG.

title: Celebrating The Goonies in Oregon
description: Goonies never say die. But they do enter their 30s.

title: S.E.C.s Kara Stein Takes Aim at Deutsche Bank
description: The recent spate of settlements by big Wall Street banks has underscored their astonishing ability to persuade powerful government officials to let them escape without any real penalty for wrongdoing.

title: Ever Elusive Sonoma Chardonnay
description: Good wine has a seemingly endless capacity to surprise. It scorns expectations, dismissing them almost at first sniff and swallow, and turning them inside out by the time the bottle is done. This is one of the most beautiful things about wine, yet one of the most difficult obstacles to overcome.

title: Jewelry
description: A bouquet of colorful floral jewels.

title: Review: In Inequality, a Respected Scholar Wades Into a Contentious Political Issue
description: The crisis of income inequality has become a cause clbre. Until recently, the gap between the rich and poor was a topic rarely championed aggressively even by the more liberal wing of the Democratic Party out of fear of being branded a tax-and-spender or class warmonger.

title: Charlie Parkers Yardbird Ties Jazz and Opera Together in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  On a recent morning in a rehearsal room behind the Academy of Music here, the tenor Lawrence Brownlee practiced a tricky passage at the piano. The melodic profile of his vocal line zigzagged and spiked like an erratic electrocardiogram, but what gave Mr. Brownlee the most trouble was the text.

title: Your Next Lesson: Cava
description: Cava, like California chardonnay, has suffered from a bad reputation. Not without reason. Millions of bottles of cava, the Catalonian sparkling wine, are sold every year, and much of it is inexpensive and not particularly good. Yet a handful of cava producers, working conscientiously in the vineyards and diligently in the cellar, have demonstrated that it can be among the most distinctive of all sparkling wines.

title: Google Intensifies Focus on Its Cardboard Virtual Reality Device
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has seen the future, and it is littered with cardboard boxes.

title: A Jewelry Designer Who Sculpts First
description: The French jewelry designer Charlotte Chesnais delineates her preliminary ideas in clay, rather than in the form of flat sketches. I like volumes, Chesnais says. The infinity of possibilities, the technical constraints One need only look at the lean sculptural wristlets and entwined rings in Chesnaiss first collection for corroboration. Shes quick to cite sculptors as a main source of inspiration  particularly Constantin Brancusi, Anthony Caro, Franois-Xavier and Claude Lalanne and Lygia Clark. Moreover, she never tires of her home base, Paris, as a storehouse of creativity. My answer will seem pretty clichd, she says, but a simple ride on my bike fills me with images and interesting silhouettes.

title: George Pataki Takes Aim at Hillary Clinton
description: EXETER, N.H.  George E. Pataki may be the most centrist candidate running for the Republican presidential nomination, but there was nothing moderate about his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton during his announcement speech Thursday.

title: When an Off-the-Rack Rolls-Royce Just Wont Do
description: IN the rarefied world of ultraluxury cars, buyers can already own some of the most lavish vehicles on the planet.

title: Finance Officials Focus on Economic Growth at Group of 7 Meeting
description: DRESDEN, Germany  Central bankers and chief finance officials of the worlds wealthiest democracies received a master class in economics Thursday, as they struggled to find ways to make their torpid economies grow faster.

title: Robert S. Wistrich, Scholar of Anti-Semitism, Dies at 70
description: Robert S. Wistrich, who devoted his four-decade scholarly career to dissecting anti-Semitism, from the biblical Haman, who warned King Ahasuerus of Persia against strangers whose laws are diverse from all people, to modern Islamist extremists who deny Israels right to exist, died on May 19 in Rome. He was 70.

title: George Pataki Flubs New Hampshire Locale in Kickoff Speech
description: Presidential campaigns have become long, gaffe-filled affairs and former Gov. George Pataki found out on Thursday that the flubs can start as early as day one.

title: Viewfinder: Alison Rossiter
description: The artist dips found, vintage photographic papers into developing solution to coax out their history.

title: 10 Public Figures Who Arent Running for President
description: With the entrance of Rick Santorum on Wednesday and George Pataki on Thursday morning, the Republican field has grown to eight candidates  and thats not including those, like Jeb Bush, who are all but sure to enter the race but just havent formally announced yet. As the field grows, it is perhaps easier to keep track of those who arent running than those who are. To that end, the following is a partial list of prominent public figures who have not yet declared their candidacy:

title: Year-End Roundup, 2014-15 | Language Arts, Journalism and the Arts
description: As we do after Memorial Day each year, this week we are looking back and collecting the years teaching materials for each subject area, so teachers can find them all in one place.

title: Study on Attitudes Toward Same-Sex Marriage Is Retracted by a Scientific Journal
description: A leading scientific journal on Thursday retracted a highly publicized study reporting that attitudes toward same-sex marriage could be altered by brief face-to-face conversations with people who have a stake in the issue.

title: Putin Declares Soldiers Deaths and Wounds Secret, in War and Peace
description: MOSCOW  The deaths or wounds of Russian soldiers in special operations can be classified as military secrets, even in peacetime, President Vladimir V. Putin decreed Thursday. The decree comes as Russia faces accusations that it is sending its soldiers clandestinely to fight in Ukraine, an allegation the Kremlin denies.

title: Modern Love | Losing My Religion
description: Once a devout Christian, Arla Knudsen wore a silver purity ring symbolizing no sex before marriage until, at 16, she stopped believing and it became her mission to lose her virginity.

title: Studio Museum in Harlem Plans a Stanley Whitney Solo Show
description: The Studio Museum in Harlem announced that it would open the first solo New York museum exhibition devoted to the work of Stanley Whitney, whose heavily brushed, brightly colored canvases have made him a kind of painters painter over the last few decades.

title: After a First Time, Many Second Thoughts
description: I was 13 years old, standing on stage with a group of fellow teenagers, when our pastor announced in front of the entire congregation, These young people have all made the righteous decision to save themselves for marriage.

title: Race and Gender Biases Can be Reduced With Sleep Therapy, Study Finds
description: It may be possible to reduce biases regarding race and gender while a person sleeps, according to a new study published in the journal Science.

title: Readers Around the World Shed New Light on the News
description: In the past couple of weeks, the International desk had a number of stories that we knew would be told even better if we invited our readers and others on social platforms to share with us their experiences.

title: Pictures of the Day: Niger, India and Elsewhere
description: Niger, Greece and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: A. R. Gurneys Sylvia Coming to Broadway With Annaleigh Ashford
description: The original production featured Sarah Jessica Parker as a dog. The show has been repeatedly performed around the country. And now, for the first time, Sylvia is coming to Broadway.

title: Cameron Presses E.U. for Better Deal for Britain
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron, with a majority mandate from the British people, is off on a whirlwind tour of European Union capitals to seek a better deal for Britain, warning that otherwise, Britain will leave the bloc. Not so very long ago, Alexis Tsipras, with a fresh mandate from the Greek people, tried the same with the threat of an exit.

title: May 28, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Niger, Burundi, Greece and India.

title: Chris Ofilis The Holy Virgin Mary to Be Sold
description: The Australian collector David Walsh is selling Chris Ofilis 1996 painting The Holy Virgin Mary, which caused a furor when it was shown at the Brooklyn Museum in October 1999 as part of Charles Saatchis touring Sensation exhibition of works by Young British Artists (YBAs).

title: Signs of Slower Growth in Top-End Art Sales
description: The huge numbers generated by Christies, Sothebys and Phillips at auction binges in New York from May 11 to 15 created a sense that prices for the most desirable Modern and contemporary artworks are rising unstoppably. But new research by the London art market analysts ArtTactic suggests the pace of growth for high-value contemporary works is slowing.

title: National Gallery Buys George Caleb Binghams The Jolly Flatboatmen
description: In its pre-Instagram, pretelevision, all-but-pre-photography day, George Caleb Binghams The Jolly Flatboatmen (1846) was a viral image, a joyous genre painting of Americas westward expansion that became wildly popular through mezzotints and lithographs. The work itself, considered one of the most important American paintings of its kind, has hung in the National Gallery of Art in Washington for so many decades  regularly since 1956  that it long ago came to seem like a part of the museums fabric. But the painting was privately owned, for many years by the Pell family and then by the Detroit collector Richard Manoogian, who bought it in 1986 for $6 million, at the time the most ever paid privately or at auction for an American painting. Now, the National Gallery has brought the boatmen fully into the fold, acquiring the painting from the Richard and Jane Manoogian Foundation for an undisclosed price.

title: Avago Deal Offers Blueprint for Chip Maker Consolidation
description: Avago Technologies is offering what might become a textbook merger case. In its $37 billion acquisition of rival chip maker Broadcom, Avagos record, industry logic, cash-and-stock mix, premium of just less than 30 percent and synergies all add up. Only an interloper could spoil the party.

title: A Primer on Android Pay and Google Wallet
description: Google on Thursday confirmed the arrival of Android Pay and a revamped Google Wallet, an overhaul of the companys mobile payments products, which was previously reported by The New York Times.

title: Ask Grover: Whats Your Favorite Breakfast Fruit?
description: Question:

title: Grand Jury Indicts Dean Skelos, Ex-New York Senate Leader, and Son in Corruption Case
description: Roughly three weeks after their arrest in a federal corruption case, Dean G. Skelos, the former majority leader of the New York Senate, and his son were indicted by a grand jury on Thursday on charges of extortion, wire fraud, conspiracy and bribe solicitation.

title: A Chat on the Clash of Meteorology and Politics Behind Texass Flood Dangers
description: The Austin Disaster Relief Network has established a Memorial Day Weekend Flood Fund.

title: Profile in Style
description: The Nigerian-born, British-educated lawyer-turned-fashion-designer merges riotous prints with daring shapes for collections that transcend trends  and global boundaries.

title: Review: International Contemporary Ensemble Weaves Among Tonalities
description: Pianists are usually the only musicians who require a helper onstage  the page turner. But during Wednesdays concert by the International Contemporary Ensemble at the Abrons Arts Center, the guitarist Dan Lippel was aided by an assistant of a different kind: a peg turner. At certain moments during the performance of Larry Polanskys Preamble for two harps and guitar, the multitasking percussionist Nathan Davis reached over to adjust the tuning of Mr. Lippels instrument in midplay.

title: Inside 1045 Fifth Avenue
description: A 10-room penthouse was bought by Paul McCartney and his wife, Nancy Shevell.

title: Appeal of Savings Bonds Wanes in Ultralow Interest Environment
description: Government savings bonds arent meant to be blockbuster investments; they are intended to be safe havens for your cash. But lately, rates on savings bonds are downright anemic.

title: Exploring Hawaiis Different Landscapes
description: Donning a parka atop a mountain, relaxing at the pool or watching lava flow, visitors to this part of Hawaii encounter vastly different landscapes.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 31 to June 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Council Members Complain, and Summer School Money Is Restored
description: While Mayor Bill de Blasio fights in Albany to maintain his control over New Yorks school system, his schools chancellor on Thursday got a cool reception from an audience that is usually much friendlier to the administration: the City Council.

title: Jeb Bushs Book List: Not Light Summer Reading
description: LANSING, Mich.  As summer draws closer, book recommendations are in high demand. So at a question-and-answer session here, Jeb Bush was asked for his, which werent quite the beach-read variety.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, May 31 to June 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Lpreuve Villageoise, a Rare Gem, at Gould Hall
description: Believe it or not, we have Parisian music critics from the mid-1780s to thank for the existence of Lpreuve Villageoise (The Village Trial), an utterly charming French comic opera by Andr Grtry. And a delighted audience at Gould Hall on Wednesday night had Opera Lafayette to thank for presenting a rarity in such a beguilingly simple production, directed by Nick Olcott, with a winning cast.

title: Review: Russian Modernism at Neue Galerie, Figurative Focus With Amorphous Results
description: Russian Modernism: Cross-Currents of German and Russian Art, 1907-1917 at the Neue Galerie is a lively, scattershot exhibition, with numerous paintings of great interest, others of not so much and many by Russian artists most of us have barely heard of.

title: Review: Simon Denny Sees the Dark Side of Technology at MoMA PS1
description: In a recent column for The New York Times, the economist Paul Krugman argued that the benefits of the digital technology revolution of the past four decades have been greatly overestimated. The new technologies, he suggested, might be more fun than fundamental. Worse, euphoric media chatter about how theyre changing the world for the better acts as a distraction from more mundane issues, like putting people to work in usefully productive jobs.

title: Arrests Overshadow Palestinians Bid to Oust Israel From FIFA
description: ZURICH  The protesters outside the arena where FIFA staged the opening ceremony for its annual congress Thursday held Palestinian flags and blunt banners.

title: Review: Lilja Birgisdottir, If Your Colors Were Like My Dream
description: When artists refer to color theory, they usually mention thinkers like Isaac Newton, Goethe and Josef Albers. The Icelandic artist Lilja Birgisdottir takes a different approach, employing New Age aura reading and wardrobe color analysis. The results in this small, minimal show  her first solo exhibition in New York  are poetic and provocative.

title: An Unsettling Report on Iran and North Korea
description: As the clock ticks down to a June 30 deadline for a nuclear deal with Iran, the news has emerged that North Korean nuclear and missile experts may (I emphasize may because I have seen no confirmation) have visited a military site near Tehran last month.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, May 31 to June 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Tabor Robak, Fake Shrimp
description: If memory serves, the artist John Baldessari once argued in effect that a new medium loses it newness when artists start using it as naturally as they would a pencil. The brilliant digital artist Tabor Robak is way past that point, as demonstrated by his second solo show in New York, and at this gallery.

title: On Twitter, Obama Talks Climate, Trade, Bulls and LeBron
description: President Obama got some use out of his new Twitter account on Thursday, logging on for a live chat about climate change.

title: John Wesley: Important Works From 1961 to 1966
description: The cartoon-based paintings and sculptures that John Wesley produced at the start of his career in the 1960s were widely seen as examples of Pop Art. But the works had a poetic psychology unlike those of most other Pop stylists. An apposite piece in this wonderful show is a table from 1965 with the profiles of Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant painted on its round top and pictures of a standing, sexy woman on each side of its square base. The two parts appear unrelated, but considering that Mr. Wesley was then in the middle years of a marriage to the painter Jo Baer that he once called a disaster, a play between civil war and union of the sexes comes to mind.

title: How Netflix Keeps Finding Itself on the Same Side as Regulators
description: Whatever the outcome of the latest proposed mergers and acquisitions in the media industry, a clear winner has already emerged, and its not even a party to any of the deals: Netflix, the streaming television pioneer.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, May 31 to June 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Madoff Accountant Avoids Prison Term
description: By his own admission, David G. Friehling was not much of an auditor for Bernard L. Madoff  pretty much rubber-stamping financial statements for the man who masterminded an enormous Ponzi scheme.

title: Review: Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh and Hesam Rahmanian
description: Satire, gender-bending and exuberantly mixed mediums are among the feats of this art extravaganza, an exhibition that never stops giving. It features the collective and individual efforts of two Iranian brothers  Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh  and their Iranian-American friendHesam Rahmanian. To unite the array, the artists have painted the gallerys floor and walls to suggest a Middle Eastern courtyard; they have also festooned white plastic lawn chairs with blue tape and collaborated on videos, assemblages, bulky but often arresting paintings and a functioning fountain that once graced the foyer of their home in Dubai. Adding to the shows expansive embrace are impressive works from their art collection by six women: Martha Wilson, Etel Adnan, Rose Wylie, Angela Dufresne, A. K. Burns and Hannah Barrett.

title: Anxiety on Campus: Reporters Notebook
description: Ive been working for more than a month on the  article about increased anxiety among college students. But Ive been reporting stories about teenagers and young adults since long before my girls were born  and now theyre teenagers.

title: Risks to Hands-Free Driving
description: A growing number of new cars have sophisticated technologies designed to prevent accidents and make driving less stressful and monotonous. Some of these advances also pose a potential problem: they could increase distracted driving.

title: Colorado Killer James Holmess Notes: Detailed Plans vs. a Whole Lot of Crazy
description: DENVER  The spiral notebook is a road map to murder, filled with plans, diagrams and to-do lists that James E. Holmes laid out in scrupulous detail before carrying out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater. In his own handwriting, he plans a mass murder spree and considers theaters and times to attack for maximum casualties. He also plots his own psyche with pages of self-diagnosis of what he calls his broken mind.

title: A Proposal to Modify Plants Gives G.M.O. Debate New Life
description: Whats in a name?

title: Another Huge Statue in Russia? Not Rare, but Hugely Divisive
description: MOSCOW  Moscow does not exactly want for colossal statues.

title: As Royals Fever Lifts Ratings, Announcers Enjoy the Buzz
description: For most of the 17 years that Ryan Lefebvre has called Kansas City Royals games, the team was predictably lousy. But their unexpectedly fast ascent to play in last years World Series and their 28-18 start this season have added a missing dimension.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: An 1800s Painter Steps Out of the Shadows
Review: David Oyelowo, Going Mad in Nightingale
description: Titanic may be one of the most technically ambitious and expensive movies ever made, but Nightingale, a film that will be shown Friday on HBO, seems even harder to pull off because it is so astoundingly simple.

title: Jazz Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Highway Restaurant & Bar in East Hampton
description: When it comes to restaurants, is there such a thing as a doomed location? An address where nothing can survive, no matter the quality of the venture? If so, then 290 Montauk Highway in East Hampton might be such a spot. Its the restaurant version of a black hole, swallowing no fewer than five establishments in a little over 10 years. Many of these lasted but a single season; others just a few months.

title: Review: Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes Give Farewell Performances of Giselle
description: The affection in which the ballerinas Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes have been held was matched on Wednesday by the warmth with which they greeted their colleagues and audiences at their farewell performances. Ms. Herrera danced the matinee of Giselle at the Metropolitan Opera House, Ms. Reyes the evening.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Locali Pizza Bar & Kitchen in New Canaan
description: In recent years, the former Ford showroom on the corner of Forest Street and Locust Avenue in downtown New Canaan has been a revolving door for restaurants. The latest, which opened in November 2013, is Locali Pizza Bar & Kitchen, whose name is Italian slang for the spot, and whose food and fair prices suggest it may have found a permanent home.

title: Spare Times for May 29-June 4
description: Museums and Sites

title: Review: George Cables Trio at the Village Vanguard
description: The patience and optimism in the pianist George Cabless music, from his improvisation down to the spirit of his songwriting, looks like it has prevailed. At 70, hes led a band at the Village Vanguard only once before, and only last August. This week hes there for the second time, and played to a full and engaged room on a Wednesday night.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Comedy Listings for May 29-June 4
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: River Crossings, a Contemporary Art Exhibition at 2 Historic Sites of the Hudson River School
description: WHEN warm weather arrives, artists by the hundreds, including me, venture outside with paint boxes and portable easels. This passion for plein air painting is a phenomenon of recent years that has come to include competitions, workshops and shows in towns, villages and scenic spots like the Eastern Shore of Maryland, which hosts more than 200 artists each July at Plein Air Easton.

title: A New Jersey Sausage-Eaters Tour of Europe
description: When Herminio Lopes, the owner of Lopes Sausage Company in Newark, got a call from the White House in 1996 with a request for 100 pounds of linguia and chorizo to be packed for President Bill Clinton, he didnt believe it  until Secret Service agents showed up two hours later to check the shipment.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 29-June 4
description: kidsfilmfest

title: Undefeated Boxer Keeps Up the Fight for His Mothers Oxtail Stew
description: Doris Jeffreys one-bedroom apartment in Staten Island contains, among other things, a Bible in the kitchen and an unusually extensive collection of mens designer sneakers, size 10, in the corner. It also contains her 24-year-old son, Marcus Browne, a professional boxer.

title: U.S. AccusesEx-House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Paying to Hide Misconduct
description: CHICAGO  J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, has been charged with lying to the F.B.I. and making cash withdrawals from banks in a way that was designed to hide that he was paying $3.5 million to someone for his misconduct from years ago, a federal indictment released on Thursday said.

title: Review: From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola, a Bicontinental Couple
description: Divided into alternating his-and-hers rooms and zigzagging across the Western Hemisphere, its hard to tell at first if From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola at the Museum of Modern Art is about an artistic couple, 20th-century migration or European modernism and its diaspora. In many ways, its about all of these. But despite more than 300 somber, high-contrast vintage black-and-white photographs, films and display cases of ephemera organized in neat rows, the exhibition is a bit of a hot mess.

title: U.S. Soccer Will Support Blatter Rival in FIFA Election
description: ZURICH  At dawn on Wednesday, Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, woke with a start, his phone buzzing on the desk of his room at a luxury hotel here. A police raid was quietly going on in the halls around him, and some of Mr. Gulatis closest professional colleagues  a few of them his friends  were being arrested on various charges related to corruption. The calls and texts did not stop for hours.

title: Mmuseumm 2 to Open in TriBeCa, All 20 Square Feet of It
description: LOTS of New Yorkers faced with space-starved apartments and carefully assembled obsessions have joked about opening a museum of their stuff. Not many would actually go through with it. Not many are the Kalman family.

title: Review: Aloha, a Hangout Movie With Bradley Cooper and Emma Stone in Hawaii
description: Let me say right up front that I will always root for Cameron Crowe. Thats the kind of blunt, sincere, slightly inappropriate statement one of his characters might blurt out at an odd moment, and so much the better. He had me at the Fast Times at Ridgemont High script, and Im probably not the only self-conscious, music-crazed guy of my generation who found possible alternate selves in Mr. Crowes alter egos: Lloyd Dobler in Say Anything, William Miller in Almost Famous and even Jerry Maguire himself.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Results
description: Andrew Bujalski narrates a sequence from his film featuring Cobie Smulders.

title: Be Here Now
description: With the rise of texting and mobile communication, I have noticed that people are generally less punctual. I often make plans with friends and receive a text five minutes before the appointed time saying: Running late. Be there in 15. When the offending parties finally arrive, they say, Sorry, Im late. I reply, Thats O.K. And we move on. But it isnt O.K. Its annoying and disrespectful of my time. What can I say without seeming like a jerk?

title: Breaking Silence, Richard Fuld Speaks on Love, Putin and Rocky
description: After nearly seven years of public silence, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, had a lot to say.

title: Andrew Bujalski Narrates a Scene From Results
description: A comedy about personal trainers and the clients who fall for them, the latest film from the Austin independent filmmaker Andrew Bujalski has something his work has previously lacked: well-known actors. This one stars Guy Pearce, Cobie Smulders and Kevin Corrigan. In a recent interview, Mr. Bujalski, whose last film was the more experimental Computer Chess, talked about working with his cast and in this video, discussed this early scene, introducing the intense Kat (Ms. Smulders) as she spots one of her clients eating a cupcake and decides to chase her down.

title: A Havana Home
description: Pamela Ruiz and Damian Aquiless house is finally as they imagined it  a place for Americans to experience the countrys newly opened cultural scene.

title: Movie Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Review: Results Tracks Exertions in Matters of the Cardio
description: Results is something of a paradox: a straightforward movie that reveals itself by stealth and indirection. Tracing the awkward interactions of three Austin, Tex., residents  a personal trainer, her boss and an out-of-shape client  the film seems to wander amiably, almost aimlessly through daily routines and low-key surprises. Only toward the end do you realize that the characters have been arranged into a pleasing and familiar romantic-comedy triangle and that youve been watching a beautifully played game of underhand slow-pitch screwball.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 29-June 4
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hillary Clinton Plans Livelier Campaign Schedule for June
description: The opening phase of Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign, with its sporadic and somewhat sheltered schedule of small round-table discussions, is coming to a close, her aides said Thursday.

title: Bicyclist Is Killed by Car Fleeing Court Police
description: The pursuit began around 11:30 p.m. Wednesday, with an attempted traffic stop in the Bronx, executed by an unlikely set of enforcers: New York State Court officers, who are more practiced in shepherding defendants to their hearings than in patrolling the nighttime streets.

title: A New York Dive Bars Last Call
description: When Timothy Fadek learned that the Subway Inn, a New York dive bar that was one of his haunts as a student, was about to close, he set out to document its end (and relocation).

title: Chris Christie Ready to Desert Common Core Standards
description: Gov. Chris Christie said on Thursday that New Jersey could abandon Common Core education standards, changing his position as he tries to reconcile policies that he embraced as the moderate governor of a blue state with his bid to win over conservative voters in the presidential contests.

title: Theater Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for May 29-June 4
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Indictment of John Dennis Hastert
description: Federal authorities accused the former House speaker of structuring withdrawals from various accounts in order to avoid bank reporting requirements.

title: Review: Gemma Bovery, a Modern Sex Comedy With a Nod to Flaubert
description: Dont expect Gemma Bovery, Anne Fontaines contemporary riff on Flaubert, to shed any new light on that authors most famous character. This version of the 19th-century masterwork Madame Bovary, adapted from a graphic novel by Posy Simmonds, is only a platform for a frothy modern sex comedy, much of which takes place in the prurient imagination of its narrator and central character, Martin Joubert (Fabrice Luchini).

title: Rare Early Proof of The Bell Jar to Be Auctioned
description: LONDON  In 1985, a college student bought a second-hand copy of a novel by Victoria Lucas in a Winchester bookshop. It was called The Bell Jar, and for 30 years, it has sat on a shelf. Recently its owner, known only by her blogging name, Lucy WithaY, searched online for the name and the title. The book turned out to be a rare 1962 proof of Sylvia Plaths famous  and only  novel, published under a pseudonym in 1963, shortly before the writer committed suicide at the age of 30.

title: Movie Review: San Andreas
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews San Andreas.

title: Movie Review: Aloha
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Aloha.

title: Movie Review: Results
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Results.

title: Masthead Executives in Name, but No Longer in Place
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Massachusetts: Sentencing Date Is Set for Boston Bomber
description: The judge in the Boston Marathon bombing case on Thursday set June 24 as the date he will formally sentence Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber, to death. A jury on May 15 recommended he be put to death; the official sentencing next month, by Judge George A. OToole Jr. of Federal District Court, will complete that phase of the process. But defense appeals are likely to extend the case for years, and there is no telling when or even whether an execution might take place. Twenty survivors and relatives of victims of the bombing are expected to speak at the sentencing hearing. Mr. Tsarnaev, 21, may also speak if he wishes; he did not testify during his trial.

title: Kentucky: Outcome Unchanged in Governor Race
description: A statewide recanvass on Thursday did not change the outcome of the closely fought election for the Republican nomination for governor, regulators said. The state agriculture commissioner, James R. Comer, requested the recanvass after preliminary results from the May 19 primary election showed him trailing Matt Bevin, a businessman from Louisville, by 83 votes. But after the procedure, which differs from a recount, Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes announced that the margin between the two men had not changed. Mr. Comer must decide by Friday whether to seek a recount through the courts. His campaign said he would announce on Friday afternoon the next steps he will take in this race.

title: Nebraska: Challenge to Repeal of the Death Penalty
description: Doug Peterson, the attorney general of Nebraska, said he would challenge the constitutionality of the states new law repealing the death penalty. The bill, which was passed on Wednesday after lawmakers overrode a veto from Gov. Pete Ricketts, replaces the death penalty with life imprisonment in Nebraska. But Mr. Peterson, who has been a vocal opponent of the bill, said on Thursday that he believed the law was unconstitutional because it effectively changed the sentences of the 10 inmates on death row. One senator who opposed repeal of the death penalty has begun another effort to fight the new law and is trying to collect at least 115,000 signatures from registered voters, which would force a voter referendum in 2016.

title: Anthony C. Yu, Translator of the Saga of a Chinese Pilgrimage, Dies at 76
description: The epic saga of a heroic Chinese monks pilgrimage to India with a Monkey King, a pig spirit and other disciples in a search for sacred Buddhist scriptures was first published in 1592. The novelistic quest lasted 16 years.

title: Sepp Blatters Embattled FIFA Presidency
description: As Mr. Blatter emerges from a week of scandal with a fifth term as the head of soccers world governing body, a look back at his troubled tenure.

title: James Patterson Is Starting Imprint for Childrens Books
description: The novelist James Patterson is so prolific that his annual output rivals that of many small publishing houses. Last year, with help from his stable of co-authors, he published 16 new novels, and sold around 20 million copies of his books.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 29, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review San Andreas, Aloha and Results.

title: Greenleaf Music Label Turns 10 With a Show at SubCulture
description: Just after he was introduced on Wednesday night as the C.E.O. of Greenleaf Music, Dave Douglas hopped onstage at SubCulture in Manhattan and, with a chuckle, tried to dial back any hint of grandiosity. But Mr. Douglas  the irrepressible trumpeter-composer-bandleader, and an organizer of people and ideas  wasnt undercutting the point of the evening, a 10th-anniversary celebration for his record label. If anything, he seemed proud, and a bit protective, of the labels tenacious modesty of scale.

title: Retracted Scientific Studies: A Growing List
description: The retraction by Science of a study of changing attitudes on gay marriage is the latest in a growing number of prominent withdrawals of the results of studies from scientific literature.

title: Many Companies Cut Ads From TLCs 19 Kids and Counting
description: At least 20 companies have distanced themselves from TLCs popular reality show 19 Kids and Counting since the cable network announced last week that it was withdrawing the program from its lineup. The networks decision  and the subsequent move by brands to remove ads  came after a report that one of the shows stars, Josh Duggar, had been investigated on suspicion of molesting several underage girls.

title: World Cup Sponsors Situation Is Complex
description: World Cup sponsors demonstrated various levels of caution in their responses this week to the United States Justice Departments indictment of nine FIFA officials on corruption charges.

title: Review: Heaven Knows What Dramatizes a Young Junkies Life
description: The characters of the junkie chronicle Heaven Knows What lead their lives in the open, which is to say on the streets of New York. Whenever a couple of them are arguing  which is frequently  you glimpse passers-by steering their way around the commotion with the practiced resolve of New Yorkers trying to mind their own business. At the very least, the directors, Josh and Benny Safdie, have created a small, beautiful classic of street theater by rendering these public disputes within a vibrant Manhattan setting through ingenious photography.

title: Reality Checks in Debate Over Surveillance Laws
description: WASHINGTON  As the Senate moves closer to a Sunday night showdown over whether it will let Patriot Act surveillance powers expire on Monday, supporters and critics of how the government has used those authorities have been using increasingly alarming language.

title: Gigi Jordan Receives 18-Year Sentence for Killing Her Son
description: A wealthy businesswoman who poisoned her son in a Manhattan hotel room was sentenced to 18 years in state prison for manslaughter on Thursday, ending a bizarre case that turned on her claim that she murdered her child to prevent him from being sexually tortured.

title: Morris Wilkins, Who Lured Honeymooners to Poconos, Dies at 90
description: During the post-World War II marriage boom, when gas shortages persuaded honeymooners from New York and Philadelphia to stay closer to home, hoteliers began luring newlyweds to the Poconos instead of to Niagara Falls.

title: Michael King, Builder of a TV Empire, Dies at 67
description: Michael King, who with his brother transformed King World Productions, a modest company they inherited from their father, into a syndicator of television megahits like The Oprah Winfrey Show, Jeopardy! and Wheel of Fortune, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 67.

title: Review: In I Believe in Unicorns, a Princess Meets Her Punk Prince Charming
description: Like its heroine, I Believe in Unicorns is faltering and undeveloped, but with a wiry core that belies its apparent uncertainty. Stretched to 80 minutes, the story (by the director Leah Meyerhoff) almost breaks; that it holds together without compromising its simplicity or emotional authenticity only proves that, contrary to the  maxim, you dont need a gun if youve got the right girl.

title: Obama, in Miami, Comments on Extreme Weather, Terrorism, Cuban-Americans and Basketball
description: MIAMI  The visit lasted less than 24 hours, but President Obama managed to use a stop in South Florida to maximum advantage as he touched on some of the highest priorities of an administration heading into its final stages.

title: Review: In Tu Dors Nicole, the Daughter Loafs While the Parents Are Away
description: Tu Dors Nicole, the third feature by the Qubcois director Stphane Lafleur, is a movie about wasting time. Is there really such a thing? Or is all of life what might be called a learning experience with interludes in which nothing seems to be happening, while a storm brews.

title: Chimpanzees in Liberia, Used in New York Blood Center Research, Face Uncertain Future
description: After about 30 years of using a colony of chimpanzees in Liberia for biomedical research, which ended 10 years ago, the New York Blood Center has now withdrawn all funding for them, prompting animal welfare groups to urge the center to reconsider its decision.

title: ISIS Alternates Stick and Carrot to Control Palmyra
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hours after they swept into the Syrian city of Palmyra last week, Islamic State militants carried out scores of summary executions, leaving the bodies of victims  including dozens of government soldiers  in the streets.

title: U.N. Resolves to Combat Plundering of Antiquities by ISIS
description: Increasingly frustrated by the Islamic States brazen pillaging and trafficking of artifacts in the Middle East, all members of the United Nations agreed on Thursday to take new steps intended to thwart and prosecute antiquities smugglers, ensure the return of plundered ancient treasures and counter what diplomats described as cultural cleansing, a new tactic of war to spread hatred and erase the heritage of civilizations.

title: Review: The True Cost Investigates High Price of Fashion Bargains
description: A distressing overview of the consequences of our addiction to fast fashion, The True Cost might suggest another expos of corporate greed versus environmental well-being. That is certainly in evidence, but under the gentle, humane investigations of its director, Andrew Morgan, what emerges most strongly is a portrait of exploitation that ought to make us more nauseated than elated over those $20 jeans.

title: Pataki Kept His Own Counsel on Matters of Family and Citizenship
description: I dont want to get into that, George E. Pataki said one evening in 1996, when asked why he was hanging around in the audience at the San Diego Convention Center instead of backstage with the other speakers.

title: Forget the Calls. Players Challenge the People Who Make Them.
description: PARIS  The cooling-off period continuedThursdayat the French Open.

title: Chinas Publishers Court America as Its Authors Scorn Censorship
description: A few years ago, the Chinese writer Murong Xuecun had the kind of career most novelists dream about. His eight books had sold two million copies in China, and he had amassed more than eight million social media followers.

title: Complaints Rise Against Nations Railroad Police
description: WASHINGTON  Since the days when Jesse James robbed trains in the Old West, obscure police forces run by the nations railroads have operated with the power to make arrests, issue warrants and perform undercover work.

title: Let Patriot Act Provisions Expire
description: Barring a last-minute compromise, congressional authorization for the program the government uses to sweep up Americans phone records in bulk will lapse on Sunday. That would be perfectly fine.

title: Political Fights Throw Sand in Gears of S.E.C.
description: More than once this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission was close to securing a landmark accounting fraud case. Then it came undone, the result of divisions within the S.E.C. And now the case might be back on track  that is, unless its not.

title: 15 Chinese Accused of Using Test-Taking Impostors for College Entrance Exams
description: BOSTON  Fifteen Chinese nationals have been accused of cheating the college entrance examination system with a scheme that involved fake passports and test-taking impostors, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Thursday.

title: Yemen: Amnesty Says Antiaircraft Fire by Houthis Has Killed Many Civilians
description: Antiaircraft munitions fired by Yemens Houthi rebels have killed or maimed scores of civilians in Sana, the capital, Amnesty International said in a report issued on Thursday. Doctors and residents told the group that the munitions were the leading cause of casualties in the city, adding to the many dangers that have confronted civilians during the conflict between the Houthis and their allies and a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Airstrikes by the Saudi coalition that struck weapons depots in residential areas in the capital have also killed and wounded residents, the group found. In two recent airstrikes, residents told Amnesty that the coalition had provided no warning beforehand.

title: Rangers Rule New York, a City of Shrinking Success
description: New York City has never been a good try kind of town. That applies, quite naturally, to its sporting interests.

title: Syria: Insurgent Coalition Pushes Assads Forces From a Stronghold
description: Insurgents seized one of the last Syrian government positions in the northern province of Idlib on Thursday night, in the latest in a series of recent gains by a newly effective opposition coalition that includes the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda as well as other Islamist factions and a few nationalist groups backed by the United States. The government forces quick retreat from the small city of Ariha left insurgents celebrating in the streets and made it appear increasingly unlikely that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad would retake the provincial capital, also called Idlib, as officials vowed to do when it fell to insurgents two months ago. The government is also facing advances by the Islamic State, which seized the central desert city of Palmyra last week. Taking Ariha puts the insurgents a step closer to the governments coastal strongholds and the plains around the city of Hama.

title: North Carolina Governor Vows to Veto a Bill Seen as Targeting Gay Marriage
description: ATLANTA  In a sharp rebuff to lawmakers in his party, North Carolinas Republican governor said on Thursday that he would veto a measure to allow certain public officials to refuse to perform marriage ceremonies on the basis of their religious beliefs.

title: New Round in a Rivalry for de Blasio and Cuomo
description: ALBANY  Mayor Bill de Blasio, his political agenda imperiled in the final days of the state legislative session, let off some steam this week when he urged Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to show leadership with lawmakers.

title: Review: Cagney, a Tribute to the Tough Guy Who Tapped
description: Normally, if youre doing a musical about James Cagney, casting is a challenge. Not so for the York Theater Companys Cagney. Robert Creighton, who wrote the music and lyrics (with Christopher McGovern), just cast himself.

title: Review: An Act of God, With Jim Parsons as an Almighty Comedian
description: If God were really as adorable and funny as Jim Parsons in the new Broadway show An Act of God, perhaps many more of us would be minding our morals, rapaciously atoning for our sins and generally doing unto others as we would like to be done unto, all in the hopes of a breezy welcome at the pearly gates.

title: Mandela Documentary Wins Top Prize for Audio Books
description: The Audiobook of the Year is not a book.

title: Doing Particularly Well
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Now, this is an excellent Friday puzzle. Really crunchy entries, ramped-up cluing that keeps those entries just out of mental reach and a few lessons (for me) to learn. This was a fun 68-worder by Patrick Berry.

title: Puerto Rican Mayor Faces Taxi Troubles on a Trip to Bronx
description: It was a trip that drivers balked at not once, but twice.

title: Port Authority Picks Group to Remake La Guardia Airport
description: The first step toward turning La Guardia Airport into a travel hub fit for the 21st century was belatedly set in motion on Thursday afternoon. But the entire makeover probably will not be completed until the century enters its third decade.

title: Taxi Commission Reassures Uber That Proposed Rules Are Not a Threat to Innovation
description: Opponents have attacked proposed rules aimed at strengthening New York Citys regulation of car-hailing apps, like Uber, calling the measures a threat to innovation.

title: The 24/7 Work Cultures Toll on Families and Gender Equality
description: The biggest obstacle to women in joining the highest ranks of the business world is a lack of family-friendly policies. That, at least, has been the conventional wisdom in recent years, and it has been embraced by progressive companies that offer flexible schedules or allow people to work from home.

title: Masahiro Tanaka May Soon Return to Majors
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  If Masahiro Tanaka, with his fragile right elbow ligament, seems to be a pitch-by-pitch proposition for the Yankees, then it is not surprising that his return is a halting, step-by-step process as well.

title: Coachs Process Fuels Rangers Procession
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The day before another defining Game 7, Coach Alain Vigneault stood near center ice at the Rangers practice complex, leaning on his stick, hand on hip, as practice whirled around him. Assistants ran drills and issued instructions, players raced about, and Vigneault watched quietly.

title: Review: Unfreedom, a Raj Amit Kumar Tale of Sex, Religion and Tradition
description: Balanced precariously on the twin pillars of female sexuality and male sadism, Raj Amit Kumars Unfreedom conjures a pandemonium of religious violence and rampant homophobia.

description: Milla Jovovich spends most of Survivor, a thriller about a terrorist plot, running from various people. She runs from London to New York and, ultimately, into the land of the preposterous.

title: S. Parker Gilbert, 81, Dies; Led and Later Shook Up Morgan Stanley
description: S. Parker Gilbert, a former chairman of Morgan Stanley who led its public stock offering in 1986 and organized a management revolt at that storied investment house 20 years later, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA: ANDRIS NELSONS INAUGURAL CONCERT Mr. Nelsons (above), the Latvian conductor, makes his debut as the ensembles music director in this program of Wagnerian and Italian verismo repertory, featuring his wife, the soprano Kristine Opolais, and the German tenor Jonas Kaufmann. Among the works in this Great Performances presentation, taped in September, are Wagners Tannhuser overture, which Mr. Nelsons has credited with inspiring him at the age of 5 to pursue a life in music. As he walked to the podium on Saturday he was greeted with a long, rousing ovation; many people were on their feet, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times in his review of that concert. But the best indication that Mr. Nelsons was a strong choice for the job was the superb playing of the musicians of this great orchestra, especially in, of all things, Respighis familiar 1924 symphonic poem, Pines of Rome. If you are going to conclude an important inaugural concert with a shameless showpiece, well, picking this skillfully written, dazzlingly orchestrated and colorful score was the way to go. Mr. Nelsons drew a glittering, textured and cinematic account of that 20-minute work from his players.

title: Quotation of the Day

title: A New York Dive Bars Last Call
description: There is nothing artisanal, twee or ironic about real-deal New York City dive bars like the Subway Inn. Its walls and tables absorbed decades of smoke, beer and heaven knows what else as it offered an after-work haven to construction workers, sales clerks and executives. And like all things that gave this city character, it fell victim to a hot real estate market.

But many Americans are economically insecure, with little protection from lifes risks. They frequently experience financial hardship; many dont expect to be able to retire, and if they do retire have little to live on besides Social Security.

title: Horrors of Human Trafficking in South Asia
description: Thousands of migrants fleeing ethnic persecution in Myanmar and poverty in Bangladesh have taken to the Andaman Sea, west of Thailand and Malaysia, in a desperate search for someone to take them in. Some 8,000 have been abandoned in the last month alone by smugglers who offered passage and a better future. Their plight, coupled with grim tales of abuse emerging from makeshift camps in the jungles of Thailand and Malaysia, paint a horrific picture of a regionwide network of human trafficking.

He was, according to several officials who met with him, strangely quiet and introspective. He even talked about the possibility of losing the presidential election.

title: On the Way Back Home
description: I first encountered Christopher Gilberts poems in his debut volume, published more than 30 years ago. Ive been waiting for another installment of his particular vision ever since. This poem reads like a love letter to the world  always new to the keen observer. The pacing of the lines enacts the experience of witnessing what seems an ordinary event made extraordinary by the speakers attention.

title: Brushed Off
description: When I was young, my mother and father would say, He will become a doctor, hell be something. But my passion was art. In school, in my village near the Afghan border, I studied through matric, finishing 10th grade, and I made quite a name for myself in class with my drawing skills. But I would often skip school, and when I left school for good, this passion for painting grew. I worked as an apprentice to a painter in Quetta for almost three years. I used to do just calligraphy, but then I developed an interest in painting trucks.

title: Bomani Jones Takes the Dismal Science to ESPN
description: You have three degrees in economics, which I assume is not common among your colleagues at ESPN. Do you still consider yourself an economist? Yes. Being an economist is much more about a thought process than it is anything specific about your job. Its thinking about how to maximize utility and the allocation of scarce resources  thats what Im doing every day now.

title: How to Ride a Bull
description: Superstition is not going to help you, Adriano Moraes says. When he started riding bulls professionally in the United States in 1993, he found American cowboys to be oddly obsessed with bad luck  they didnt put their hats on beds, accept $50 bills or eat chicken before getting on a bull. Instead, Moraes says, develop your core strength. He did 2,000 crunches a day during the 15 years he competed with the Professional Bull Riders, the international organization known as the P.B.R., eventually becoming its first three-time world champion. Bulls can weigh up to 2,200 pounds and are bred for their explosive leaps and midair spins. Dance with the bull, advises Moraes, 45, who retired in 2008 and now scouts talent (bovine and human) and runs events for the P.B.R. in his native Brazil. Never try to fight; if you fight, you always lose. Stay up near the animals shoulders, away from its high-kicking hindquarters.

title: The Arrogance of Jeb Bush
description: You thought he was the smart Bush. You thought he was the reasonable one. You thought he was the Republican with one foot in the 21st century, the man who wasnt going to say crazy things to win the primary voter who believes in crazy things. But you havent been paying attention to Jeb Bush.

title: In Varazdin, a Thriving Arts Scene Emerges

Situated on the top floor of a two-story 18th-century building thats surrounded by cobblestone streets, the flat overlooks a small garden where more than 50 open umbrellas in bright shades rest on thin metal crisscrossing wires, forming a canopy, and the mishmash of seating includes a white bathtub that the owner, Martin Kaminic, cut in half and fashioned into a bench.

title: Morning Agenda: Fuld Breaks His Silence
description: FULD BREAKS HIS SILENCE | In his first public appearance since the financial crisis, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, used his speech at the Marcum MicroCap Conference in New York to touch on a wide range of topics like the Islamic State and the American economy, quoted from the movie Rocky and ruminated on the meaning of life. But while Mr. Fuld, known as the Gorilla of Wall Street for his brusque style, was eager to share his views about the world, he assiduously avoided talking about his role in the largest bankruptcy in United States history,  David Gelles writes in DealBook. Instead, Mr. Fuld offered his views on personal topics and made frequent references to his resilience. One example: What did Rocky say? Its not how hard you hit but whether you get up after youve been knocked down. I love Rocky.

title: 1940: Female Spy Is Given Death

The death penalty was the second to be meted out to women spies in France since the war began. Carmen Mory, a Swiss woman, three days ago exhausted her last appeal in an effort to escape a death sentence passed on her April 28 in Paris.

For the next two years, he spent most of his days in bed, occasionally showing up in public without changing out of his bathrobe.

title: 42nd Street and Looney Tunes Classics: Showstoppers Live and Animated

Imagine roots growing from the soles of your feet, she said. Now, a branch shoots from your head.

title: Jamie xx Looks Inward and Back on In Colour
description: Though hes best known for playing guitar and percussion with the minimalist rock trio the xx, Jamie xx  born Jamie Smith in London  grew up steeped in dance music and was a D.J. in bars and clubs at the same time the band was taking off. Now, with In Colour, his first solo album, Mr. Smith, 26, is tapping a broader tonal range than the xxs severe palette allows. On my own, I become very self-indulgent and go off on tangents, he said.

title: Dany Laferrire, a Guardian of French, Joins the Acadmie Franaise

description: Novelists do all kinds of things as they wait for their books to be published, from imagining unforeseen commercial success to imagining unforeseen commercial success. Just kidding  we also update our websites. But eventually we have to face the fact that we are finished with that book  finished, and its not even in bookstores yet  and it is time to start something new.

title: Matt Bevin Prevails as James Comer Concedes Kentucky Governor Primary
description: After a recanvass of vote totals left him still narrowly trailing, James R. Comer, the Kentucky agriculture commissioner, on Friday conceded the Republican primary race for governor to Matt Bevin, a wealthy Louisville businessman and Tea Party favorite.

title: Jacob Lew Warns Time Is Running Out to Reach Greek Debt Deal
description: DRESDEN, Germany  The United States Treasury secretary on Friday once again warned eurozone countries that they should not delay reaching a deal on further aid for Greece, highlighting a growing sense that negotiations are moving too slowly to avoid the countrys disorderly exit from the eurozone, with repercussions for the global economy.

title: U.S. Soccers Next Generation Set to Kick Off in Under-20 World Cup
description: Even as FIFA reels from the indictments of some of its top officials, its tournaments continue around the world. Next up in New Zealand is the under-20 World Cup, a proving ground for future stars. And the United States could be a contender.

title: Aided by the Sea, Israel Overcomes an Old Foe: Drought
description: JERUSALEM  At the peak of the drought, Shabi Zvieli, an Israeli gardener, feared for his livelihood.

title: Request for Delay of Mortgage-Disclosure Rule
description: New rules intended to make mortgage terms more transparent and easier for consumers to understand are scheduled to take effect on Aug. 1. But although the changes have been in the works for almost two years, the lending industry says it is not prepared for the shift.

title: Shrinking Economy? No, but Its Not Surging Either
description: The government reckons that the American economy shrank over the winter, but no one really believes it.

title: Nigerian Leader on Fighting Boko Haram
description: During his inaugural speech on Friday, President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria said the countrys military would intensify its offensive against Boko Haram.

title: What I Love | Judy Kuhn
description: The actress Judy Kuhn lives with her husband, David Schwab, and their daughter in a TriBeCa loft.

title: Palestinian Soccer Association Drops Effort to Suspend Israel From FIFA
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinians dropped their bid to suspend Israel from international soccer competition at the last minute Friday, and agreed to instead form a committee of the sports governing body, FIFA, to handle their complaints of racism and discrimination.

title: They Told Me Not to Take That Job, by Reynold Levy
description: When Reynold Levy was approached in the early 2000s about becoming the president of Lincoln Center, friends and colleagues gave him the advice embodied in the blunt title of this chatty memoir. The performing arts center on the Upper West Side, one of the largest in the world, had become a rats nest of competing fiefs and bureaucratic infighting. Who would want to lead it?

title: My Paris Dream, by Kate Betts
description: Well always have Paris. And as long as there are Americans who long to reinvent themselves, well always have books about Paris  books that still mention Hemingway and pigeon-gray rooftops, lovers in cafes and swirling Gauloise smoke. If theres anything new to be said about the city, or a surprising new way in which to describe it, its as rare as a helpful French bureaucrat  at least in the latest batch of books in which Paris is a main character. Kate Betts, at least, got what she went there for. And now, almost 30 years later, she shares her coming-of-age in a self-assured book that should be given to every college senior with a Doisneau poster (or Chanel ad) on her wall.

title: Buzzing in Midtown
description: This weekend, publishing-industry insiders and readers of all stripes will be in New York for BookExpo America, the annual trade convention. Jonathan Franzen was scheduled to kick off this years event, discussing his forthcoming novel, Purity, with the literary critic Laura Miller. Franzen represents an old-fashioned bookish draw, but much of the conference could be mistaken for a TV upfront, with new books peddled by big names like Mindy Kaling, B.J. Novak, Aziz Ansari, Nick Offerman and David Duchovny.

title: Letters: One Nation Under God
description: One Nation Under God

title: Gardening
description: Gardeners have active fantasy lives to keep us going despite constant setbacks. Fifty shades of green dont begin to capture whats looping through our brains. Lucky is the gardener who can bring those fantasies to life  to the delight or comfort of family and strangers alike. In Charleston, S.C., David Rawle has created a beautifully tranquil public garden dedicated to the memory of his mother, Theodora, an avid gardener. Theodora Park features palmetto trees and camellias; a ceramic artist has created colorful tiles for a fountain. On the other coast, Apples chief executive, Tim Cook, is sinking five billion shades of green into an Eden for his companys new California campus. Perhaps no one will ever be tempted to leave.

title: U.S. Removes Cuba From State-Sponsored Terrorism List
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday removed Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism, a crucial step in President Obamas push to normalize ties between Washington and Havana.

title: Emma: A Modern Retelling, by Alexander McCall Smith
description: As bicentenaries come and go, so do adaptations of Jane Austen. Pride and Prejudice (1813) begat Pride and Prejudice and Kitties (2013), not to be confused with Pride and Prejudice and Zombies (2009). In 2011, two centuries after Austen broke into print, the Austen Project commissioned modern retellings of her six novels.

title: Re Jane, by Patricia Park
description: You act like an orphan! The Korean-American writer Patricia Park was always struck by the strange rebuke her mother hurled at her in limited English whenever she was bad. In an interview with her publisher, Park said that when she read Charlotte Bronts classic 19th-century orphan tale, Jane Eyre, it came together: Whether 170 years ago in England or 60 years ago during the Korean War when her mother was growing up, parentless children who hadnt gotten a good family education, as her own family put it, were scorned, the lowest kind of misfit.

title: American Epics: Thomas Hart Benton and Hollywood
description: Thomas Hart Benton was already 14 in 1903, when The Great Train Robbery flickered onto screens, but he was still impressionable enough to become part of the first generation of American artists to let the influence of movies run through their work. In Bentons case, run is almost literal; everything in the fluid, vivid murals that made him famous seems to be pulsing or coursing. His pictures were, in a sense, motion pictures, which may be why, in 1937, Life magazine commissioned him to go to Hollywood to create a movie mural that would bring its readers closer to the heart of the still-newish mystery of how films were created.

title: Burning Down George Orwells House, by Andrew Ervin
description: In this debut novel, Andrew Ervin works familiar ground: the burnt-out protagonist who gives up a comfortable but spiritually toxic life in order to refresh his soul and seek redemption in a far-off  or, in current parlance, off the grid  place, which according to the formula will inevitably be populated by locals for whom the appropriate collective noun is menagerie. One approaches the scenario braced for clich. But Ervin pulls it off, and then some. Burning Down George Orwells House is a sweet book full of delights. Since many of its best passages are rhapsodies on single malt whiskies, one is tempted to call it a wee bonny dram of a tale.

title: Californias Hellhole for Traffic Violators
description: The harsh lessons of the confrontation between the citizens and police of Ferguson, Missouri, last year are registering nationwide  notably in California where Gov. Jerry Brown is proposing amnesty for poor people buried under the escalating costs of unpaid traffic fines. Its a hellhole of desperation, Mr. Brown said, underlining charges that the state has been exploiting low-income and minority residents caught in a spiraling accumulation of court costs that they cant pay.

title: The Brethren, by Robert Merle
description: Historical fiction plays a delicate trick, honoring the factual record even as it embroiders it. Where to adjust the register without straying beyond the fixed range? One of the many delights vouchsafed by Robert Merles The Brethren is the sense that the author is astonished that what hes writing about actually happened  that 450 years ago France consisted of a batch of tenuously allied provinces, with Catholics and Protestants locked in holy and civil war; that 14-year-old nobles were joined in marriage; that kings died in jousting matches; that Gypsies haunted untamed forests; that castles were defended with blunderbusses and cutlasses. Where Merle teases this history is through his invented Huguenot family, headed by two Jeans, the exemplary Baron Jean de Siorac and his austere best friend, Jean de Sauveterre  the brethren of the novels title, united by war and joint masters of Mespech, a castle in southern Prigord.

title: Mutual Fund Giants Vote to Keep the Insiders In
description: Are Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, two of the nations largest mutual fund companies, the skunks at the proxy access party?

title: Y.A. Crossover
description: KISSING IN AMERICA

title: Daughters of the Samurai, by Janice P. Nimura
description: For college students today, junior year is considered the optimal occasion for study abroad, a time when they have transitioned from the comforts of home, declared a major and acquired a smattering of a foreign language. For three Japanese girls in 1871  Sutematsu Yamakawa, age 11; Shige Nagai, 10; and Ume Tsuda, 6  study abroad began much earlier and lasted for 10 long years. They were transformed in the process, as was the country they left behind. Though they were, each of them, purebred daughters of the samurai, Janice P. Nimura remarks in this beautifully written book, they became hybrid by nurture, at home neither in their adopted country nor in their homeland.

title: Oh! You Pretty Things, by Shanna Mahin
description: Recent transplants to Los Angeles are often mocked for their jejune view of the city. Why, nobody walks here ... or eats bread ... and yikes, Harry, theres another set of breast implants!

title: Beale Street Dynasty and Dreams to Remember
description: In 1917, the composer W.C. Handy titillated the nation with Beale Street Blues, his song about a true-life Sodom and Gomorrah in downtown Memphis. If Beale Street could talk, if Beale Street could talk, he wrote, married men would have to take their beds and walk. Fats Waller, Lena Horne and the former Beale resident Alberta Hunter all went on to sing it, but probably few people today know about that post-Civil War nirvana for liberated slaves. On Beale Street, freedom ran raucously, dangerously amok. Races cohabited and brothels thrived; heated games of dice-rolling often ended with the flash of switchblades. Cocaine was sold over the counter. The anarchy was set to a soundtrack of early jazz, much of it provided by Handy, the bandleader and composer of St. Louis Blues.

title: Gironimo! and Lanterne Rouge
description: There are many sensible reasons the British travel writer and humorist Tim Moore cycled the 1914 route of the Giro dItalia (the Tour of Italy) wearing antique woolen biking shorts held up by a safety pin, on a bike with wine corks for brakes, wooden rims, no gears and 100-year-old parts.

title: The Sculptor, by Scott McCloud
description: If you want to read ambitious comics and graphic novels, you have many choices, but if you want to learn how to read them, you probably have to start with Scott McCloud. The writer and artist first got noticed for a teenage superhero series, Zot! (1984-91), then broke through with Understanding Comics (1993), an exegesis, in comics form, of comics form. McCloud drew himself as a friendly, bespectacled guide, demonstrating why cartoony, stylized faces (as in Peanuts) help us identify with characters; and how comics can tell many sorts of stories, whether or not there are superpowers or family traumas involved. Reinventing Comics (2000) predicted broad uses for digital platforms; Making Comics (2006) showed potential creators how to use the pen-and-ink and electronic tools we have.

title: Physical Evidence Scant, Focus Is on Statements in Kayak Case
description: Until last weekend, the biggest challenge facing prosecutors in the murder case involving two kayakers was the missing body. That was resolved Saturday, however, when the police found the body of Vincent Viafore, 46, in the middle of the Hudson River, just north of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blumes In the Unlikely Event
description: This week, Judy Blume talks about her new novel; Liesl Schillinger rounds up new travel books; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vanessa Grigoriadis discusses Wednesday Martins memoir, Primates of Park Avenue; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blumes In the Unlikely Event
description: This week, Judy Blume, Liesl Schillinger and Vanessa Grigoriadis.

title: Church of Marvels, by Leslie Parry
description: Leslie Parrys debut novel opens with a strange discovery: Sylvan, an isolated young man living on the Lower East Side of 1890s Manhattan, finds an infant abandoned in a privy. Sylvan is a night-soiler  if youre unfamiliar with the profession, imagine the worst possible sanitation job that a person could hold before the age of indoor plumbing  and until he finds the baby, hes had very little in the way of direction or hope. The family who raised him have all died of TB.

title: Bitter Bronx and Just Kids From the Bronx
description: Brooklyn, Brooklyn, Brooklyn. Its all anyone talks about. From a punch line to a symbol of cool urban affluence with a literary bent, its had a niche in the national psyche for decades. The other boroughs look on, some more annoyed than others.

title: The Last Bookaneer, by Matthew Pearl
