description: You will not find bookaneer in any dictionary, says the narrator of Matthew Pearls fifth novel, The Last Bookaneer, and hes right. In his afterword, Pearl does claim to have encountered this unfortunate pun in an 1837 text by the poet Thomas Hood, but if so it never managed to appear in the Oxford English Dictionary. Either the editors of the O.E.D. are slipping or Matthew Pearl is having us on.

title: Gary Clements Swimming, Swimming, and More
description: Swimming pools loom giant in the imaginations of children. Theyre symbols of summer, and of vacations. The big ones can be vast and terrifying. The kiddie ones can be conquered. If we learn to swim, most of us in America first learn how in pools.

title: Inside the List
description: Feeling Lucky: To anybody whos known a toddler, it might seem counterintuitive that the childrens picture book list at the moment is so stable and calm  seven of this weeks 10 entries have been on the list for six months or longer. (In some cases much longer: Herv Tullets Press Here is coming up on four years.) That means that Dan Santats sweet story The Adventures of Beekle, about an imaginary friend in search of his human, is a relative newcomer: Its No.7 after 13 weeks. Santats book got a bump when it won the Caldecott Medal in February, setting it apart as last years most distinguished American picture book. The award caught Santat off guard, he told Publishers Weekly at the time. I never really thought that I had a chance, he said. When I got the call, I hate to admit it, but I started crying. I crumpled to the floor and started crying. Santat has illustrated other peoples books for a long time (he previously hit the list as the illustrator for Ahmet Zappas Because Im Your Dad, in 2013), but The Adventures of Beekle is just the second story hes written on his own. He almost chose not to, he told Publishers Weekly: Five years ago he had a chance to join Google, drawing doodles for the home page. Should I take this job and make money to support my family, he asked himself, or should I chase my dream? Turning Google down, he continued, motivated me to use the other side of my creative brain, to write more. It paid off. Among the highlights of Santats February, according to his Tumblr account, was outselling 50 Shades of Grey (for a brief moment) and receiving the following Valentines newsletter from his 9-year-old son, Alek: Dan Santat has just won his amazing Caldecott award. Many people think that Dan is known around the world.

title: For Cruise Visitors, an On-Shore Taste of Alaskas Bounty
description: Nearly one million cruise passengers annually visit Juneau, Alaskas rugged state capital, from May through September, often swarming the town of nearly 33,000 residents on day trips and shore excursions. Its main attractions include the nearby Mendenhall Glacier, where the visitors center offers boardwalk trails that overlook bear-viewing areas, and small boat trips to watch orca and humpback whales.

title: Blatter Speaks Before FIFA Election
description: Sepp Blatter addressed the FIFA congress in Zurich on Friday, speaking through a translator before the presidential election. Mr. Blatter is running for a fifth term as president of FIFA.

title: Drink and Draw
description: An all-female art show in East Williamsburg, cleverly named Girls of Summer.

title: Meet Harry, a Detective Wrestling With Grief and Drug Trafficking
description: Someone once said the darkness that surrounds us cannot hurt us, Harry Anglesea, a police detective in New Zealand, says a month after the unexpected death of his wife. It is the darkness in our hearts that we should fear. Unable to cope with his searing grief in solitude, he returns early from bereavement leave to solve a vicious murder involving a young Samoan high on the drug P. But when the trail leads to a major meth shipment headed to Auckland from offshore, the world of the psychologically scarred Harry, which includes a daughter, starts to disintegrate.

title: Classical Music Ensembles Offer Free Concerts
description: The barriers to entry are nil in three free concerts by leading new-music groups. On Sunday, in honor of Henry Street Settlements 100th anniversary, the International Contemporary Ensemble and the guest conductor Steven Schick perform George Lewiss raucous, sly The Will to Adorn, Varses Intgrales and the original 1944 ballet-score version of Coplands Appalachian Spring. (7 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, iceorg.org.) In the first of two back-to-back Pop-Up Concerts at the Miller Theater, the American Contemporary Music Ensemble plays works on Tuesday by the composer and pianist Timo Andres, including his 2012 Piano Quintet and the New York premiere of Clear and Cold for solo piano. The event on Wednesday features an enviable ensemble  the pianist Vicky Chow, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the cellist Michael Nicolas  in three trios by John Zorn. (6 p.m., Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, 212-854-7799, millertheatre.com.)

title: Maria Schneider, With New Album, to Perform at Birdland
description: The composer-arranger Maria Schneider has been the farthest thing from idle in recent seasons: Last year, her music turned up on a film-noirish new song by David Bowie, months after her ambitious album Winter Morning Walks won three Grammys in the classical field. But it has been eight years since Ms. Schneider released an album with the Maria Schneider Orchestra, her flagship band.

title: David Gulpilil Stars in Charlies Country
description: When moviegoers first met David Gulpilil in the 1971 film Walkabout, he was an unknown teenager. Now hes one of Australias best-known Aboriginal actors. And hes still playing characters who are exploring the intersection of traditional and modern cultures in that country  most recently in Charlies Country, a film by Rolf de Heer that opens on Friday at Lincoln Plaza Cinema.

title: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Will Take Final Bow at BAM
description: Richard Branson has his Virgin Galactic, Elon Musk has his SpaceX, and Nancy Laurie, a Walmart heiress, had her Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet: all visionary pet projects shooting for the stars. For 12 highly visible years, Cedar Lake traced a burning arc through the dance world and, like a meteor, is about to expire. The company abruptly announced its closure in March to the surprise of many and takes a final bow this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Robert Irwin Instillation of Color and Light Returns
description: Robert Irwin  an artist whose work migrated from galleries out into the world, as he put it, in the form of architectural interventions, gardens and barely there tweaks to the perception of the everyday  has had a rich history with the Dia Art Foundation. He collaborated with the foundation on the master plan for its sprawling outpost in Beacon, N.Y., shaping even the parking lot. Now Mr. Irwin, 86, is returning to Beacon with an installation that brings him back into the galleries as a sculptor of space and light. Excursus: Homage to the Square (1998-99), which goes on view Monday and remains through May 2017, is a maze of translucent chambers, formed with scrim and fluorescent lights, that Mr. Irwin describes as being mostly about color, with very little matter involved, and a nod to the color theories of the painter Josef Albers. The installation represents the return of Excursus to public view almost 17 years after its premiere at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, where it became a kind of touchstone of Mr. Irwins working methods. (3 Beekman Street, Beacon, N.Y.; 845-440-0100, diaart.org.)

title: Paperback Row
description: IN THE KINGDOM OF ICE: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette, by Hampton Sides. (Anchor, $16.95.) In June 1881, two years into its Arctic expedition, the U.S.S. Jeannettes hull was crushed by ice, forcing the commander, George Washington De Long (1844-81), and his 32-man crew to abandon ship 1,000 miles north of Siberia. Sidess first-rate narrative recounts the horrors (crude amputations, madness, starvation) in the crews desperate struggle to survive.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in the West Village, on the Upper West Side and in Manhattan Beach.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE DAEMON KNOWS: Literary Greatness and the American Sublime, by Harold Bloom. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) Inspirations origin, sought through close readings of daemon-possessed writers interrogated in pairs (e.g., Twain with Frost).

title: Cooking
description: Ask anyone what makes a cookbook a success and youre bound to get a range of answers. Some of us require the full escapist experience wed expect of a novel, a cover-to-cover immersion in another food lovers world. Some call it a win if the book offers a single recipe to add to the Forever Repertoire. Others ask: Will it offer techniques and inspiration to apply elsewhere? Will it romanticize the food we grew up with? Or have us sprinting to the nearest farmers market to exorcise the food demons of our past? By any of these measures, this springs new cookbooks deliver.

title: Primates of Park Avenue: A Memoir, by Wednesday Martin
description: A few pages into Primates of Park Avenue, I raised an eyebrow as high as a McDonalds arch. Was Wednesday Martin, a Midwestern-born Ph.D., trying to explain the rites of the Upper East Side to me, an autochthonous Manhattanite schooled at one of the neighborhoods top learning huts? She was a late transfer to the New York troop  a particularly vicious troop, at that  and its a weak position to be in throughout the primate kingdom, whether human or monkey.

title: Debate Over the Rabbi and the Sauna
description: For years, Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt, the leader of an affluent Modern Orthodox synagogue in the Bronx, did something unusual with the boys in his congregation.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a farmhouse in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Glen Cove, Long Island.

title: 1915: Mental Strain on German Sailors
description: LONDON  Twelve sailors employed aboard interned German liners in New York have lately gone mad. Three became so violent, says the Daily Telegraphs correspondent, that they have been placed in a padded room in the county jail. Dr. King, the official medical officer, describes their malady as acute melancholia, produced largely by homesickness and absence from their native land in a time of stress.

title: A Hobby Anthropologist Dissects the Tribes of the Upper East Side
description: A few weeks ago, a woman named Wednesday Martin, a hobby anthropologist whose graduate degree is in comparative literature, published an op-ed article in The New York Times outlining some of the observations she makes in her forthcoming book, Primates of Park Avenue. News of the book, a memoir that presents itself as a pop ethnography of Upper East Side motherhood, immediately prompted intense reaction in part because of some of the claims made in it  that wealthy nonworking mothers receive a wife bonus for outstanding domestic performance, to cite an example  and in part because Ms. Martin, observed last week table-hopping at Michaels in jeans and heels, had seemed to so thoroughly embrace the manners of the women she had written about with such an imperious strain of sympathy.

title: At the Races With a Top Horse Trainer and an Owner
description: When Sheila Rosenblum, a New York socialite, met Linda Rice, a trainer and owner, three years ago, Ms. Rosenblum owned a small number of horses that had never won a race. The pair joined with another woman, Iris Smith, to create Triumphant Trio, a rare all-female partnership, which has been attracting attention.

title: Cher for Marc Jacobs, Hillary Clinton Merch and Cannes Flatgate
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: The Women Who Bought American Pharoahs Half Brother
description: For an industry in which the ultimate compliment is being a real horseman, Linda Rice is an anomaly. Barely topping 5 feet, Ms. Rice has shoulder-length blond hair and sharp features that could make her a Ralph Lauren model. The first female horse trainer to top the standings at a major racetrack, shes tough and she speaks at a no-nonsense clip.

title: One-Tap Giving? Extra Steps Mire Mobile Donations
description: On Monday, perhaps it was a Memorial Day parade that moved you. The sight of veterans marching might have touched off a desire to make a donation right then and there to the American Legion.

title: Soft-Shell Crab Arrives With the Heat
description: An Alaskan King crab is enormous, with incredibly long legs. By comparison, the hefty, meaty West Coast Dungeness crab seems small.

title: Australian Start-Ups Lure Silicon Valley Money
description: SYDNEY, Australia  In November 2013, John Locke and Nate Niparko, two members of the investment team at the American venture capital firm Accel Partners, got off a plane here and jumped in a taxi.

title: Candida Hfers Wide Open Spaces
description: The German photographer Candida Hfer is often described as a photographer of empty space. Since 1980, she has focused her lens almost exclusively on the uninhabited interiors of public buildings around Europe and the United States: libraries, universities, museums, palaces, theaters, opera houses.

title: 20 More Cookbooks
description: BENU. By Corey Lee. (Phaidon, $59.95.) A lavishly illustrated celebration of the three-Michelin-starred San Francisco restaurant and its Korean-American chef.

title: Green Garlic Toast
description: Melissa Clark makes compound butter with green garlic to spread on toast, among things.

title: Green Garlic Toast Offers a Hint of Springtime
description: Green garlic season is fleeting.

title: A Guiding Hand for Those in the Backstretch
description: ELMONT, N.Y.  In his years as a chaplain to grooms and hot walkers and exercise riders and the rest of the workers at three racetracks in New York State, the Rev. Humberto Chavez had made countless hospital visits and seen more than enough fractured skulls and shattered legs. Nothing, however, prepared him for the sight of a jockey named Andrew Lakeman in a Long Island medical center one night in May 2007.

title: Talking Baseball With Bill de Blasio
description: The mayor was trying not to crack up.

title: Judy Kuhn, Fun Home Star, on Her TriBeCa Loft
description: In 1989, when Judy Kuhn moved from Chelsea to TriBeCa with David Schwab, prospective visitors seemed to think a Sherpa would be required for the journey.

title: Vacant Majesty
description: Candida Hfers photographs of empty theaters and opera houses.

title: E.P.A. Proposes Changes to Fuel Standards
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday released a much-delayed proposal for the amount of biofuel that must be blended into conventional vehicle fuel, seeking to reduce the levels now specified but still require modest increases over the next few years.

title: ASAP Rocky Returns to a Haze
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss ASAP Rockys new album.

title: New York Nail Salons Now Required to Post Workers Bill of Rights
description: Effective immediately, every nail salon in New York will be required to post a manicurists bill of rights in clear sight of customers and employees, the latest effort by city and state leaders to curb the widespread exploitation of workers in the sprawling nail salon industry.

title: Northern Discomfort
description: The FT has an interesting although garbled story about Finlands economic woes. Ignore the numbers, which as best I can tell are all wrong (is this becoming an FT trademark?); more crucially, someone seems confused about the difference between wages and unit labor costs. If you go to the Conference Board numbers, you find that Finland has indeed seen a rapid rise in ULC, but not because of a wage explosion; its all about collapsing manufacturing productivity.

title: After Divorce, Losing Veterans Support Along With a Spouse
description: My wedding day was the first best day of my life. I could not have ordered a more perfect day if I had had a menu of choices in front of me. The marriage to my best friend was what I was really looking forward to. I wanted to settle down and start a family and thats what we did. Our ideal world was lost on Sept. 6th, 2003. My husband, a member of the National Guard, was activated two days before our second son was born. Two weeks later he went to Iraq on what ended up being almost a year-and-a-half journey where he fought for his country and I fought to maintain our home.

title: Popcast: ASAP Rocky Returns to a Haze
description: ASAP Rockys music has been blurry before, but on his new album, At.Long.Last.ASAP, its blurry in a new way. On his first mixtape, in 2011, he was adapting Houston slowness as one of many ways to expand the possibilities of New York hip-hop. Now hes gone farther and made something closer to an hour-plus of psychedelia, a major hip-hop record with many different producers and guest rappers from many different precincts  Kanye West, Lil Wayne, Future, M.I.A., Rod Stewart  that doesnt act on the listener the way such records normally do. It remains coherent and unified no matter how much it drifts and disorients. Jon Caramanica, whowrote about the album this week, explains how the album represents the aesthetics of Rocky and his associate ASAP Yams, who died in January.

title: Friday Night Music: The Most Ugly Child
description: I had a really good time over the weekend at How The Light Gets In; to be honest, more the music than the deep thought, but maybe thats me. Heres one example, your basic terrific country/Americana band from Nottingham (hey, they have sheriffs too, right)?

title: Study Using Gay Canvassers Erred in Methods, Not Results, Author Says
description: The graduate student at the center of a scandal over a newly retracted study that has shaken trust in the conduct of social science apologized for lying about aspects of the study, including who paid for it and its methodology, but he said Friday in his first interview since the scandal broke that he stands by its finding that gay canvassers can influence voters attitudes on same-sex marriage.

title: Devious Defecator Case Tests Genetics Law
description: Seven years ago, Congress prohibited employers and insurers from discriminating against people with genes that increase their risks for costly diseases, but the case that experts believe is the first to go to trial under the law involves something completely different: an effort by an employer to detect employee wrongdoing with genetic sleuthing.

title: The Unreleased Nikes President Obama Got First
description: What do you give to the man who has everything  no, really, everything, including a bowling alley in his house? Nike has an answer thats hard to top: When President Obama visited the companys world headquarters in Beaverton, Ore., earlier this month, he was the first person on Earth to receive the soon-to-be-released MTM, a new two-pair pack Nike is releasing in June in celebration of 30 years of Air Jordan. MTM is named for the three men who designed the two pairs in collaboration: Nike C.E.O. Mark Parker and designer Tinker Hatfield and, of course, Michael Jordan himself. The MTM is a great way to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Air Jordan franchise, Jordan says of the collaboration. It was a lot of fun to work with Tinker Hatfield and Mark Parker on reimagining two of the best shoes we have ever created.

title: Why Homeowner Insurance Deductibles Vary by State
description: AS with most types of insurance, you can lower the monthly premium on your homeowners policy by raising your deductible. But whether it makes sense to do so can vary by state, a new report finds.

title: The Girls of Summer, Anatomically Speaking
description: On Thursday evening, bare breasts abounded in Vandervoort Studio in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Not in the flesh. But rather, on paper (and on a few pots) along the studios white walls and on a table beneath the windows. The art showcased the Girls of Summer  a clever anatomic euphemism that lent the pop-up show its name. I originally wanted to call it free the nipple,' says Nikki Cohen, the curator of the one-night-only exhibition and founder of the conceptual art project This Place. The concept originated at a Drink and Draw  a gathering that This Place regularly hosts around New York City, at which guests sip boozy drinks and sketch a nude female model.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: New Class of Drugs Shows More Promise in Treating Cancer
description: A new drug that unleashes the bodys immune system to attack tumors can prolong the lives of people with the most common form of lung cancer, doctors reported on Friday, the latest example of the significant results being achieved by this new class of medicines.

title: Readers Respond: On Lets Do Some Railing
description: Many readers brought an international perspective to conversation about a fatal train derailment in Philadelphia earlier this month, saying the crash and a national reluctance to invest in passenger rail were signs of U.S. decline.

title: Review: Betty Buckleys Dark Blue-Eyed Blues Has Hardly Any Blues at All
description: Forget that Betty Buckleys brilliant new show at Joes Pub, Dark Blue-Eyed Blues, has only a distant resemblance to a blues concert. Yes, Thursdays opening night included the Harold Arlen-Johnny Mercer standard Blues in the Night, but thats just one of many elements.

title: Blatter Expresses Thanks to FIFA
description: FIFAs president, Sepp Blatter, spoke after being elected to a fifth term on Friday. His only rival, Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan, withdrew his candidacy after the first round of voting.

title: Book Review Podcast: Judy Blumes In the Unlikely Event
description: In the annual Summer Reading issue of The New York Times Book Review, Caroline Leavitt reviews In the Unlikely Event, Judy Blumes first novel for adults in 17 years. The novel was inspired by a historical incident, when three planes crashed over eight weeks in Ms. Blumes hometown, Elizabeth, N.J., in the 1950s. Ms. Leavitt writes:

title: Russian Military Insignia Are Reported in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  International monitors tracking cease-fire violations in eastern Ukraine reported Friday that they had encountered four people wearing military uniforms with Russian insignia in a town about 25 miles southeast of the regional capital of Donetsk, which is controlled by pro-Russian separatists.

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Hastert Case Is Said to Be Linked to Decades-Old Sexual Abuse
description: WASHINGTON  J. Dennis Hastert, who served for eight years as speaker of the House of Representatives, was paying a former student hundreds of thousands of dollars to not say publicly that Mr. Hastert had sexually abused him decades ago, according to two people briefed on the evidence uncovered in an F.B.I. investigation.

title: In Israel, Desalination at the Heart of a Water Revolution
description: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.

title: Jeb Bush Assails  Obama on Removing Cuba From Terror List
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush continued to take a hard line against normalizing relations with Cuba on Friday, accusing the Obama administration of capitulating to an oppressive regime by removing it from a state-sponsored terrorism list.

title: ISIS Claims Deadly Car Bombings at Baghdad Hotels
description: BAGHDAD  The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people and wounded 25.

title: Chirlane McCray, in Italy, Speaks at a Conference on Black Images in Art
description: FLORENCE, Italy  The travel logs of New York Citys first family this week appear to be a bit lopsided.

title: Palestinians End FIFA Bid Against Israel
description: Jibril Rajoub, president of the Palestine Football Association, told delegates at FIFAs annual congress on Friday that the group was ending its efforts to have Israel excluded from FIFA.

title: Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island to Announce Presidential Bid
description: Democrats are finally starting to line up to take on Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: The Lower East Side Goes From Gritty to Glossy
description: There was a time when immigrants fought to get out of the gritty Lower East Side, but some of their descendants are fighting to get back in as the area has been revitalized. That battle is becoming a bit harder as condominium prices start hitting highs comparable to those in pricier Lower Manhattan neighborhoods like SoHo, NoLIta and NoHo.

title: Home Is Where the Boards Are
description: Eugene Kangs shop in Upper Manhattan grew from a sometime venture in the corner of his living room into a store for those in the know.

title: Ring 5A for the Secret Skateshop of Washington Heights
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Eugene Kang sat in the middle of Terminal Skateshop, telling a story about a problem customer, a neighborhood barber who came in looking to buy a board. Mr. Kang helped him pick one out, along with trucks, wheels, bearings  the works  and, making small talk, asked him where he normally skates. The barber explained that he didnt; he just wanted to hang the board up at work, for show.

title: Edward P. Gilligan, American Express Executive, Dies at 55
description: Edward Gilligan, the president of American Express and heir apparent to the companys chief executive, Kenneth Chenault, died on Friday after falling ill during a flight to New York. He was 55.

title: Practicing the Dying Art of TV Repair
description: Marty Jennings, Tough Guy, reads the plaque on the counter at Jennings TV, a tiny repair shop on First Avenue near 55th Street.

title: Humana Is Said to Consider Sale of Company
description: The wave of deal-making that has swept across the health care industry now appears poised to pull in health insurers, a development driven by the Obama administrations insurance overhaul.

title: Irish Media, Fearing Lawsuits, Steers Clear of a Billionaire
description: LONDON  When the financial crash hit in 2008, it plunged Ireland into a crippling recession from which it has only recently stirred. But the toxic legacy of those years has not gone away, and now it has provoked another crisis, this time over media freedom.

title: Review: Treetop Cat Rescue on Animal Planet
description: Whether youll enjoy Animal Planets latest show comes down to how much you trust cats. If you think theyre merely adorable, innocent balls of fur, sure, help yourself to a mindless half-hour. If, on the other hand, you view them as manipulative little buggers intent on world domination, then prepare to be alarmed.

title: Ross Ulbricht, Creator of Silk Road Website, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: Ross W. Ulbricht, the founder of Silk Road, a notorious online marketplace for the sale of heroin, cocaine, LSD and other illegal drugs, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Great Barrier Reef Is Not in Danger but Needs Care, U.N. Experts Say
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Despite threats to the Great Barrier Reef from climate change and human activity, United Nations conservation experts stopped short of recommending on Friday that the reef, a World Heritage site, be classified as in danger.

title: Warriors Klay Thompson Has a Concussion and Is Indefinitely Sidelined
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Klay Thompson of the Golden State Warriors sustained a concussion, the team said Friday, casting doubt on his availability for the start of the N.B.A. finals next Thursday.

title: No, You Cant Blame Your Belly on Traffic
description: Honking horns and screaming sirens could give a city dweller a migraine. But can an urban areas unruly rhythm also give a person love handles? Thats the claim that some recent headlines made based on a study that looked at traffic noise and obesity.

title: Elizabeth Wurtzel Finds Someone to Love Her
description: The author Elizabeth Wurtzel was never on the short list for bride. She has stated as much in her inflammatory writings for decades, and has even written that single people are more interesting by necessity.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Photographs of the presidential hopefuls Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders, Gov. Chris Christie and Rick Santorum, and more.

title: HowTanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett, Founders of Makers Row, Spend Their Sundays
description: Tanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett are the founders of Makers Row, a Brooklyn start-up that connects entrepreneurs with American manufacturers. Forbes magazine recently included Ms. Menendez, 27, in its 30 under 30 issue. Mr. Burnett, 30, is a former watch designer who worked for Marc Jacobs and DKNY. Makers Row is their second company: In 2011, Ms. Menendez left a job at Goldman Sachs to join Mr. Burnett at a leather goods line he had started called the Brooklyn Bakery. A year before that, she joined him romantically. The two met through friends at a Roots concert in Prospect Park. They live in a one-bedroom apartment near Borough Hall in Downtown Brooklyn with their dog, Mr. Pickles.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Review: Young Dancers of Graham 2 Show Palpable Passion for the Legend
description: It takes more than just good dancers or a committed artistic director, or even a stellar board of directors, to preserve a choreographers legacy. Good teachers are also essential, to train all those future heirs.

title: A Fresh Lens on the Notorious Episode of Ota Benga
description: Last week, a New York State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan heard arguments on an engaging issue: whether two caged chimpanzees at Stony Brook University can be defined as legal persons, and are therefore being unlawfully held against their will.

title: Review: Manfred Honeck Coaxes a Burnished Sound From the New York Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic played Mozart, Brahms and Johann Strauss on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. A program so crustily traditional almost feels like news, given the orchestras innovative track of the last few months, with intriguingly balanced programs and new(ish) works by Thomas Ads and John Adams, Thierry Escaich and Peter Eotvos. Under Alan Gilbert, evenings of Old World heft are no longer the norm.

title: Why the S.E.C. Could Use Commissioners With Wall Street Experience
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will soon have two top vacancies, and a Wall Street pedigree would be a plus for new watchdogs. Nominees with financial industry ties might prompt gripes about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the market works.

title: Have We Learned Anything From the Columbia Rape Case?
description: Last week, one of the messiest campus sexual-assault cases in recent memory came to an equally messy conclusion when Emma Sulkowicz, aided by four friends, carried a 50-pound mattress onto the stage at a Columbia University graduation ceremony. In a much-publicized art-performance-slash-protest, Sulkowicz had carried the mattress everywhere she went on campus since the beginning of her senior year last fall, vowing to continue to do so until she graduated  or until Columbia expelled a classmate she accused of rape in April 2013. More than seven months earlier, she says, Paul Nungesser, a friend at the time, raped her during what had until that point been a consensual encounter at the start of their sophomore year.

title: Previous Mass Die-Offs of the Endangered Saiga Antelope Hint at a Warm, Wet, Weedy Culprit in Kazakhstan
description: Update, Nov. 4 | Carl Zimmer has filed a fresh update from the scientists investigating the mass die-off of saiga populations. They see signs of weather conditions triggering a toxic change in normally harmless bacteria.

title: Suge Knight Gets New Lawyer, and Murder Trial Is Delayed
description: LOS ANGELES  In an unusual set of hearings on Friday, Marion Knight, the former chief executive of Death Row Records, who is known as Suge among associates in the music world, was granted a delay in his scheduled murder trial as he enlisted a new lawyer, Thomas A. Mesereau Jr., in both that case and a separate robbery case.

title: Living Large
description: A photographers work tries to show the daily lives of people whose dreams and accomplishments exceed their stature.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, Indonesia, Germany and Switzerland.

title: Inside the Mind of a Criminal
description: FOR decades, researchers have interviewed criminals to find out how and why they break the law. But the accounts are not always accurate: Narrators manipulate, suffer from faulty memory or justify actions rather than recount facts.

title: Finding a Toad With a New York Accent
description: Walking along a little-used trail in Bergen Beach three or four years ago, I came across a pudgy toad scampering across the sandy path. Unlike frogs, which leap gracefully, toads scramble through the underbrush on shorter legs. This one, traveling at top toad speed, may have been motivated by a garter snake following closely, probably with dinner in mind. I sensed a photo opportunity, but the snake preferred to dine alone, and veered off quickly. Undeterred, I photographed the toad and filed the photos. This was fortunate  though I have heard the bleats of a few Fowlers toads since, this was the last one I have seen in the five boroughs.

title: For Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, a Partnership That Stays in Step
description: Ah, the first year of married life, when yesterdays wanderlust ends and a couple settles into snug domestic routines without tomorrows distractions of children and accumulating responsibilities.

title: May 29, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, the West Bank, Indonesia and Germany.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Share Your Manhattanhenge Instagram Photos
description: The New York Times invites readers to share their photos of Manhattanhenge, when the sun aligns with Manhattans cross streets.

title: Activist Hedge Fund Elliott Hires Chief Operating Officer
description: Elliott Management, the activist hedge fund run by Paul E.. Singer, has poached a top Citigroup executive to serve as its new chief operating officer, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

title: Death on the Steppes: Mystery Disease Kills Saigas
description: Before the end of the last Ice Age, saigas roamed by the millions in a range stretching from England to Siberia, even into Alaska. Eventually they moved to the steppes of Central Asia, where they continued to thrive  until the 20th century, when these strange-looking antelopes began flirting with extinction.

title: Brooklyn Hamlet of Free African-Americans Was Ahead of Its Time
description: The houses on Hunterfly Road, an abandoned Colonial trail, are the last vestiges of a lost settlement in Brooklyn. Clustered behind a dense meadow rippling with bluestem grass and dandelions, the three wooden houses were once part of Weeksville, a hamlet where more than 500 free African-Americans lived the white-picket-fence dream years before President Lincolns Emancipation Proclamation in 1863.

title: Washington Bans Political Ads From Public Transit
description: WASHINGTON  Officials in Washington said on Friday that they had suspended all issue-oriented advertising in the public transit system because of fears that granting a request to display a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad would make the regions buses and trains a target.

title: Worlds 50 Best Restaurants Defends Its List
description: A slow-burning squabble in the culinary world heated up on Friday, when the website for Occupy 50 Best, a movement started this month to protest favoritism, opacity and sexism in an influential annual list of the Worlds 50 Best Restaurants, was briefly shut down at the request of the 50 Best organization.

title: FIFA Charges Instantly Earn Loretta Lynch Global Recognition
description: WASHINGTON  Thabiso Sithole, a sports reporter with the South African Broadcasting Corporation, had just finished his Wednesday evening segment on the American indictments that had rocked international soccer when his cousin called.

title: Bill Cunningham | Man Code
description: Established dress codes are under assault, but arent they always?

title: Bill Cunningham | Man Code
description: Established dress codes are under assault, but arent they always? Younger men want to express themselves at work. They attempted to eliminate the necktie decades ago. It never happened. Today, for serious young men, its all about the disappearance of socks. City men have new transportation options: bicycles, scooters and skateboards for young creatives working where dress codes dont exist.

title: The Economy Will Rebound, but Prosperity Wont
description: Rearview mirrors exist for a reason: to help us see whats sneaking up on us from behind. The quarterly economic report is a rearview mirror. The latest one, released on Friday, shows that the economy contracted at an annual pace of 0.7 percent in the first quarter of 2015. Activity has picked up since then, so the tendency is strong to dismiss what is in the mirror, along these lines:

title: Flowers, Gardens and Picasso
description: With the warmer weather, parties spread outdoors.

title: Bank of America Fined for Violations of Military Relief Law
description: Bank of America must pay a $30 million fine after a financial regulator found numerous violations related to the accounts of 73,000 military service members.

title: Inside the 2015 Havana Biennial
description: The 12th edition of this exhibition runs through June 22.

title: Surfing Headlong Into a New Life
Moone Boy: The Blunder Years and The Imaginary
description: Imaginary friendhood is suitable only for children. Unlike riding scooters and having tantrums  done by the fully grown as often as the young  chatting with invisible pals beyond a certain age can result in hospital stays for exhaustion. But do todays overscheduled kids even have time for an imagined companions limitless adventure and unconditional love? Two new novels made me hope they do.

title: Google Wants to Turn Your Clothes Into a Computer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If you thought it was only a matter of time before Google tried to turn your pants into a computer, well, guess what, you were right.

title: Painting Parties Mix Creativity and Cocktails
description: Lets start by taking two scoops of yellow paint and one-half scoop of red, then mixing them together with your Bart Simpson brush, said an affable illustrator from the Bronx named Tony Tan. Mr. Tan, donning a wireless headset mike, was in the dimly lit lower level of Sofrito in White Plains calling out instructions to 40 students on how to paint a tropical landscape called Lazy Sunset in several simple steps.

title: The Havana Biennial Is Running at Full Throttle
description: HAVANA  With the recent political thaw between Cuba and the United States, changes are already lapping the shores of this island nation and may soon be pounding the great sea wall, the Malecn, that stands between Havana, the open water, and a big-spending, big-building, culturally big-footing neighbor to the north.

title: In Sequins or Mufti, Chita Rivera Makes a Big Entrance
description: When the speakers on the rooftop of the Strand Hotel in Midtown began to blare a disco version of America from West Side Story, Chita Rivera, the original Anita in the 1957 Broadway production, cut loose, splaying her crimson-tipped fingers and breaking into a giddy trot.

title: Standoff Over Rescued Dogs in Northeast China
description: Dog traders, animal rights activists and the authorities have been negotiating for more than a week over control of nearly 500 dogs rescued from a truck stopped on a highway in northeast China.

title: Lets Celebrate the Art of Clutter
description: We are in a collective, and most unfortunate, paroxysm of guilt and anxiety about stuff.

title: At Donohues, a Nightly Steak, a Life Gone By
description: His was the corner table to the left of the bar. Four days a week, twice daily, at seven meals out of eight for decades, Robert Hatfield Ellsworth could be found seated in a booth of channel-quilted vinyl at Donohues Steak House.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: As Insults Fly in the Greek and German Media, Some Wish for Less News
description: ATHENS  As a nightly news anchor for Skai TV in Greece, Sia Kossioni closely monitors Germany, checking the latest remarks from German politicians, studying public opinion polls and reading the German news media to learn what they are saying about the Greek bailout negotiations. She even speaks German.

title: How to Find Your Place in the World After Graduation
description: PARIS

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Details Uncovered in Bostons 2024 Olympic Bid May Put It in Jeopardy
description: BOSTON  The so-called bid book that Boston business leaders presented last year to the United States Olympic Committee helped the city win the competition over Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington as Americas candidate to host the 2024 Summer Games.

title: Old School
description: Out of Line: The Art of Jules Feiffer, 100 Great Childrens Picturebooks and more.

title: Indian University Suspends Student Group Accused of Spreading Hatred Toward Modi
description: NEW DELHI  A branch of Indias most prestigious engineering university in the southern city of Chennai has suspended a left-wing student group that was accused of spreading hatred toward Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a university official said on Friday.

title: After a Protest, a Toronto Festival Removes Action Bronson From Main Stage
description: A Toronto music festival is trying a compromise with Action Bronson, the colorfully foul-mouthed New York rapper, after an online petition that accused him of violent misogyny in his lyrics led to a decision ask him to perform at a different venue at the festival rather than as a headliner in a public square on June 21.

title: Hundreds of Watches Are Stolen but a Victim Remains Undaunted
description: Thirty-five years ago, a Mexican sculptor named Elias Lifshitz, who had recently moved to New York City to accept the challenge he more or less knew from a song  If you can make it here, he said this week, you can make it anyplace  opened a little shop on East 77th Street. He called it Lifshitz Gallery, and there he learned an early, hard lesson: Not as many people were interested in buying art  his or anyone elses  as he had hoped.

title: Comics
description: Nick Sousaniss Unflattening, Drawn and Quarterlys celebration of 25 years and more.

title: Intel Takeover of Altera Is Expected
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel is close to clinching a takeover of fellow chip maker Altera for more than $15 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday, the latest sign of consolidation in the semiconductor industry.

title: Review: An Abundance of Giselles, With Debuts and Farewells
description: Its not unusual for American Ballet Theater to present eight performances of Giselle in eight days at the Metropolitan Opera House; this occurs most years. This years casting, however, prompted many in the audience to undertake unusually large Giselleathons, thanks to important debuts, farewells and returns.

title: What the U.S. Can and Cant Do in a Violent Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Democrats More Liberal Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventing Sexual Abuse by U.N. Peacekeepers
description: To the Editor:

title: Initially Delayed, Iggy Azaleas Tour Is Now Canceled
description: Iggy Azaleas Great Escape tour, which had already been pushed back from spring to the fall due to tour production delays, according to a statement in March, has now been canceled.

title: A U.S. Tax Investigation Snowballed to Stun the Soccer World
description: WASHINGTON  Chuck Blazer was a powerful figure in international soccer, and he enjoyed the trappings that came with the role: two apartments at Trump Tower in Manhattan, expensive cars, luxury properties in Miami and the Bahamas.

title: Firing of Seton Hall Priest Highlights a Catholic Debateon Gay Believers
description: When the Rev. Warren Hall called a reporter for the gay sports website Outsports.com last week to discuss his firing as director of Seton Hall Universitys campus ministry, there was a certain logic to his move.

title: Review: Deep Web on Epix Explores Dark Corners of the Internet
description: The Silk Road case, about the online drug-selling enterprise broken up by law-enforcement officials in 2013, has already received some television attention and understandably so. Its a real-life version of the kinds of tech-heavy crime dramas that TV has been serving up for several years now.

title: Review: For the Last Time Sets a Hawthorne Novel in New Orleans, in 1950
description: There must be less likely sources for a jazz musical, but Nathaniel Hawthornes novel The Marble Faun, from 1860, seems pretty improbable. Steeped in Puritan piety, its a misty melodrama set in Rome among four artist friends, one of whom is hiding a sinister secret.

title: Bernie Sanders Recants 1972 Article on Womens Fantasies of Rape
description: MUSCATINE, Iowa  Senator Bernie Sanders said a 1972 article he wrote describing womens fantasies of rape had been misinterpreted, and its resurfacing showed how campaigns had become soap operas.

title: Review: A. R. Rahman, Full of Bollywood Hits at the Beacon
description: Idealism and omnivorousness converge in the music of A. R. Rahman, the hugely prolific Oscar-winning Indian film composer whose Intimate Concert Tour sold out the Beacon Theater on Thursday night.

title: Reynaldo Rey, 75, Actor and Comedian, Is Dead
description: Reynaldo Rey, an actor and comedian known for his work in the 1995 Ice Cube hit film Friday and some 50 other movies, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: B.B. King Returns to a Mississippi Home, and Its Warm Embrace
description: INDIANOLA, Miss.  B.B. King, the man some called the ambassador of the blues, came home this week for the last time.

title: Review: In The Upper Room, Homesteaders Living an Eco-Nightmare
description: Doom is more than lapping at the shores of their wooded sanctuary off the coast of Maine. The rising surf is claiming the island, and not so slowly either.

title: Review: Jane Comfort Signals a Departure With a Moody New Work
description: Jane Comfort is a choreographer with a penchant for fusing text and movement  until now. Altiplano, which received its premiere on Thursday as part of the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, signals a departure for this longtime modern choreographer, who in past dance-theater works has explored the myth of Persephone and notions of beauty with Barbie.

title: Paying Tribute to a Blues Giant
description: People lined up in Mississippi to view the body of B.B. King, whose bronze coffin was flanked by Gibson guitars.

title: Nikki Finke, Feared Hollywood Reporter, Turns to Fiction
description: LOS ANGELES  If Nikki Finke had not been a journalist, she says she could have been a detective. The police in New York, where she reported decades ago, used to show her these gruesome homicide photos, she said, to try to freak her out. Instead she found them fascinating.

title: Jerry Dior, Designer of Major League Baseballs Logo, Dies at 82
description: Jerry Dior, a graphic designer who created one of the most instantly recognizable logos in the history of American marketing  the silhouetted batter that has long symbolized Major League Baseball  but who received official credit for it only 40 years after the fact, died on May 10 at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 82.

title: Once-Calming Leader and a Stunning Turn
description: WASHINGTON  J. Dennis Hastert was propelled to power in Congress by one sex scandal only to see his House majority dragged down by another. Now the former speaker is himself caught in a murky criminal episode with dark overtones and sexual allegations.

title: Iraq: 14 Are Killed in Hotel Bombings
description: The Islamic State took responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people and wounded 25. The bombings took place in the parking lots of the hotels around midnight Thursday, highlighting the ability of militants to maneuver around strict security measures. Foreigners frequently stay at the hotels. In one attack, a bomb in a parked car hit the Cristal, which used to be called the Sheraton, in the city center, starting a fire in the middle of one of the citys busiest areas. The hotel is a frequent spot for weddings and is next to an upscale private club. The other attack, a suicide car bombing, hit the Babylon, a recently renovated hotel that sits on the banks of the Tigris opposite the American Embassy.

title: Iran: Prisoners Relatives to Testify
description: Relatives of three Americans imprisoned in Iran and of a fourth who has been missing there for eight years will be the featured witnesses on Tuesday at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, its chairman, Representative Ed Royce, Republican of California, announced Friday. Mr. Royce said in a statement that their testimony would provide an opportunity to hear from the families of these four Americans and explore ways to secure their release. The four are Nagameh Abedini, wife of Saeed Abedini, an Idaho pastor sentenced to eight years; Sarah Hekmati, a sister of Amir Hekmati, a Marine veteran from Michigan sentenced to 10 years; Ali Rezaian, brother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Posts Tehran correspondent, who has been held since July and could face up to 20 years on charges including espionage; and Daniel Levinson, son of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in 2007. The hearing is taking place a week after the start of Mr. Rezaians trial in Tehran, which has been described as a sham by the United States government, outside rights groups and his family.

title: Los Angeles Labor Group Backs Minimum Wage Increase, Then Seeks Exemption
description: LOS ANGELES  Labor unions across the country have been among the most vocal and important backers of the nationwide fight to increase the minimum wage to $15. At the same time, some labor leaders  including one here who helped lead the successful effort to raise the minimum wage in Los Angeles  have encouraged cities to adopt provisions that would allow employers with unions to pay below that level.

title: One World Observatory Opens Atop Trade Center
description: Visitors on Friday took in the view from the One World Observatory, on floors 100, 101 and 102 of One World Trade Center.

title: Chinese Security Laws Elevate the Party and Stifle Dissent. Mao Would Approve.
description: BEIJING  Chinas new national security law, released in draft form this month, has little to say about such traditional security matters as military power, counterespionage or defending the nations borders.

title: Wheres Edward Snowden Now?
description: Edward Snowden went from unknown intelligence contractor to international celebrity-in-exile in June 2013. Today he is on a worldwide speaking tour, making his virtual rounds from Texas to Stockholm.

title: Obama Warns the Senate to Pass Surveillance Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama suggested ominously on Friday that allowing domestic surveillance programs to expire at a Sunday deadline could lead to a terrorist attack on the United States.

title: Jack Sock Carries a Torch and a Fiery Forehand
description: PARIS  The young American Jack Sock has played well  even brilliantly at times  to get himself back into the third round of the French Open. And guess who is waiting for him? The even younger Borna Coric, a Croatian and a Roland Garros rookie with a buzz cut, a deep tan and star mentors galore who is just 18 and already resolute beyond his years.

title: U.N. Role Is Questioned in Sexual Abuse Inquiry
description: GENEVA  Questions over the handling of a confidential United Nations inquiry into allegations of sexual abuse by French soldiers in the Central African Republic deepened on Friday when an advocacy group published leaked documents that it said detailed the reactions of senior human rights officials.

title: Vladimir Katriuk, Beekeeper Accused of Nazi War Crimes, Is Dead at 93
description: Vladimir Katriuk, a Ukrainian-born beekeeper and former butcher who was No. 2 on the Simon Wiesenthal Centers list of most wanted Nazi war criminals, died this month in a hospital in Salaberry-de-Valleyfield, Quebec, near where he lived. He was 93.

title: Governor Cuomo, City Boy
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo recently mocked Mayor Bill de Blasios latest frustrations with Albany, suggesting that such complaints from City Hall were part of a long New York tradition of squabbling between governors and New York City mayors. While true, that history does not mean the governor can play the political bully with the mayor and shortchange more than eight million city residents. The mayor is pushing for real solutions  for schools, housing and mass transit. These issues deserve Mr. Cuomos leadership, not political one-upmanship.

title: Federal Judge to Quit Post; He Faced Abuse Charge
description: A federal judge who was arrested last summer in Atlanta on accusations of domestic abuse resigned on Friday.

title: Saving Canadas Boreal Forest
description: STRETCHING from interior Alaska across Canada to Newfoundland, and sandwiched between the prairies and the Arctic, North Americas boreal forest is a mind-boggling 1.5 billion acres in size  bigger even than the vast rain forests of the Brazilian Amazon or the Congo. And despite the relentless pace of development and industrialization worldwide, 80 percent of it remains wild and intact.

title: Duncan Keith Remains Cornerstone of Blackhawks Dynasty and Defense
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Chicago Blackhawks have endured the rigors of five trips to the Western Conference finals in the past seven seasons thanks, in no small part, to their longest-tenured and most heavily used player, defenseman Duncan Keith.

title: Police Unions Must Not Block Reform
description: WASHINGTON  THE decline of public trust in the police weve seen after a string of incidents in Ferguson, Mo., Cleveland, New York and Baltimore has many causes. Policies like hot-spot policing and stop-and-frisk searches  outgrowths of the broken windows law enforcement strategy  have put enormous pressures on minority and low-income communities. But the role played by police unions in shielding their members from accountability for excessive force has also contributed to the erosion of trust.

title: Pushback in the South China Sea
description: The United States has good reason to push back more forcefully against Chinas grab for power in the South China Sea, as Defense Secretary Ashton Carter did on a trip to Asia this week. Beijing has repeatedly ignored earlier warnings to moderate the aggressive behavior that is unsettling its regional neighbors and further undermining its relations with the United States.

title: To Fill Budget Hole, Kansas G.O.P. Considers the Unthinkable: Raising Taxes
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  With the state facing a $400 million budget hole for the coming fiscal year, the conservatives who dominate the Legislature here say they are agonizing over the likelihood of doing something that did not seem to be in their DNA: raising taxes.

title: Jury in the Bronx Awards $45 Million for a Death After Surgery
description: A Bronx jury has awarded $45.6 million to the parents of a man who was paralyzed at 14 and later died as a result of a spinal operation at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center, according to court papers released Friday.

title: Families Press for Changes in Policy on Hostages
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama met recently with the mother of James Foley, the American hostage beheaded last August by the Islamic State, she said, he told her that freeing her son and the other American hostages held with him had been his top priority.

title: The Man Who Built the N.C.A.A.
description: In the course of working on a book about the N.C.A.A. these past few years, Ive found myself grappling with the legacy of Walter Byers.

title: Noted Employee of Slate
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Sometimes you get the puzzle, and sometimes the puzzle gets you. This was a tough one for me, and its all because 1) I got excited that I finally recognized a rebus in a puzzle that didnt actually contain one and 2) I momentarily conflated two characters in a famous television series that was nearly before my time.

title: Whats Obamas Plan C for Immigration?
description: What a bad week it was for President Obamas immigration policies, and for millions living in limbo in the United States.

title: Paying Tribute to a Blues Giant
description: People lined up in Mississippi to view the body of B.B. King, whose bronze coffin was flanked by Gibson guitars.

title: Gov. Walker and the Cool Thing
description: Weve been wondering when a presidential candidate would say something incredibly insensitive about women and reproduction.

title: Some Things Change and Others Dont, Says 41 Police Recruit
description: In 1941, a police recruit named John T. Downer began walking a beat in Brooklyns 84th Precinct, and was taken out to lunch by a patrolman.

title: City Panel Moves to Designate Stonewall Inn as a Landmark
description: With its burned-out neon sign and darkened windows, there was little to distinguish the Stonewall Inn from any other West Village bar when it was raided the night of June 28, 1969.

title: Rangers Are Shut Out in Game 7 as Lightning Reach Finals
description: When Alex Killorn spun away from the boards and darted toward the slot, Henrik Lundqvist looked ready, crouching in the net, his glove up, his stick out.

title: Harveys Strong Start Slips Away in Mets Loss
description: In 10 pitches, Matt Harvey electrified the Friday night crowd at Citi Field as if it were 2013, zipping 98-mile-an-hour fastballs past overmatched hitters and reloading as quickly as the catcher could toss the ball back his way. He pitched the first inning like he had a late-night movie to catch. He pitched like he was laughing at those who feared he might have a so-called dead arm.

title: C.C. Sabathia Has a Big Heart for Home
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Margie Sabathia-Lanier, asleep in bed after working the graveyard shift as a phone operator at Travis Air Force Base, was awakened by a knock on the bedroom door.

title: Magic Slips Away From Henrik Lundqvist at the Place It Had Helped Him Most
description: At least on paper, the Rangers were the favorites heading into the finale of the Eastern Conference finals against the Tampa Bay Lightning. They were playing on home ice, they had demolished the Lightning on the road in Game 6 and they had their ultimate trump card, Henrik Lundqvist, in goal.

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) 2015 ROCK AND ROLL HALL OF FAME INDUCTION CEREMONY Joan Jett & the Blackhearts, the Paul Butterfield Blues Band, Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble, Green Day, the 5 Royales, Lou Reed, Bill Withers and Ringo Starr were honored at this 30th annual induction ceremony, taped on April 18 at the Public Auditorium in Cleveland. Revelers including Patti Smith, Paul McCartney, Stevie Wonder, Miley Cyrus (above left with Ms. Jett), Beck, Jimmie Vaughan, Dave Grohl, John Mayer, Karen O and Joe Walsh help serve up hits like Crimson and Clover, Aint No Sunshine, American Idiot, Pride and Joy, Satellite of Love and With a Little Help From My Friends.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: All Ross Ulbricht cared about was his growing pile of bitcoins.

title: Corrections: May 30, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Real America
description: Younger and/or foreign readers may not recall how big a role the alleged moral superiority of small-town America used to play in conservative politics (and still does, to some extent). Republicans portrayed themselves as the party of the real America, of family values, as opposed to the decadent left in its enclaves on the coasts. Defense of traditional values played a big role in the 2004 campaign.

title: Last Exit Before Chaos
description: Theres an odd summer-of-1914 feel to the current state of the Greek crisis. While some of the main players are, rightly, desperate to find a way to head off Grexit and all it entails, others  on the creditor as well as the debtor side  seem not just resigned to collapse but almost as if theyre welcoming the prospect, the way, a century ago, far too many Europeans actually seemed to welcome the end of messy, frustrating diplomacy and the coming of open war.

title: World Science Festival Finds Success in Physics, and More, as Spectacle
description: Brian Greene grasps a beam of light. He freezes in an electrified rock-star pose, and as a live orchestra begins to hum, the beam of light slips through his fingertips and flashes across the stage.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to new exhibits at the Bronx Zoo.

title: In Travel Accessories, Style Meets Convenience
description: There is no shortage of tech gadgets designed to make travel easier, but equally innovative accessories have been few and far between. That is finally changing with an array of stylish options.

title: In Morocco, Exploring Remnants of Jewish History
description: Boy 1: What are those two guys doing walking around here?

title: Profiting From the Desperate
description: Daniel Puff, a recovering drug addict, is caught in an unregulated housing system, known as three-quarter housing, that preys on the vulnerable homeless.

title: Response From Yury Baumblits Lawyer
description: A lawyer for Mr. Baumblit responded to questions from The Timess Kim Barker about his client and Back on Track, a company that runs three-quarter homes. The transitional homes provide housing for the mentally ill, homeless and addicts.

title: A Choice for Recovering Addicts: Relapse or Homelessness
description: After a lifetime of abusing drugs, Horace Bush decided at age 62 that getting clean had become a matter of life or death. So Mr. Bush, a homeless man who still tucked in his T-shirts and ironed his jeans, moved to a flophouse in Brooklyn that was supposed to help people like him, cramming into a bedroom the size of a parking space with three other men.

title: Easy Peasy
description: An abundance of fresh English peas can turn any dish into a bright springtime meal, writes Martha Rose Shulman, who offers a light summer shrimp and pea dish made with green garlic. Weve added some of our favorite recipes from Martha that include peas.

title: Mohamed Soltan, U.S. Citizen Imprisoned in Egypt, Is Released
description: CAIRO  Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen who spent nearly two years in an Egyptian prison on charges that he supported an Islamist protest, has been released by the Egyptian authorities and flew back to the United States on Saturday, his family said in a statement.

title: Martin OMalley Announces Presidential Campaign, Pushing Image of Vitality
description: BALTIMORE  In another campaign year, Martin OMalleys rsum and good looks might be irresistible to Democratic primary voters. He is a former big-city mayor whose story of renewal in Baltimore seemed well tailored to an increasingly urban and minority party. He is a former two-term governor of Maryland  and the lead singer and guitarist in a rock n roll band.

title: What Martin O'Malley Would Need to Do to Win
description: Mr. OMalley, a former governor of Maryland, is running for the Democratic presidential nomination. Here is a look at his prospects.

title: Martin OMalley on the Issues
description: Martin OMalley, a former governor of Maryland, announced his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination on Saturday. Positioning himself to the left of Hillary Rodham Clinton, he says he has a more consistent record than she does on matters like supporting same-sex-marriage, opposing the Iraq war and advocating on behalf of immigrants. Here are his stands on key issues.

title: White-Glove Co-op Rules That Rankle
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Reply From Yury Baumblits Lawyer
description: A lawyer for Mr. Baumblit responded to questions from The Timess Kim Barker about his client and Back on Track, a company that runs three-quarter homes. The transitional homes provide housing for the mentally ill, homeless and addicts.

title: Battle Lines in G.O.P. Set Stage for Surveillance Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Since 2011, when Republicans took control of the House, Congress has lurched from one deadline to the next, as Republicans and Democrats have sparred bitterly over funding for the government, the ability to lift the debt ceiling and other policy matters.

title: Martin OMalley Reached Out to Hillary Clinton Ahead of Campaign Announcement
description: When Martin OMalley began actively exploring a presidential run in 2013, he reached out to Hillary Rodham Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, to let her know. She told him he should dowhat he needed to do.

title: For the Golden StateWarriors, Practice Makes Perfect Silliness
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Golden State Warriors are a joy to watch. Their offense is based on movement and spacing, all five players working together to create open shots. If Coach Steve Kerr is the conductor, Stephen Curry is his soloist, a 6-foot-3, 190-pound virtuoso in high-tops.

title: Tokyo Police Respond to the Call of Football
description: KAWASAKI, Japan  The members of the Tokyo Police Departments Ninth Riot Squad are professionals at containing demonstrations, foiling terrorists and preventing mayhem. On any given Sunday, they also make mayhem on the football field as the Keishicho Eagles.

title: A Little Praise for Sepp Blatter. Very Little.
description: Now that Sepp Blatter has won his fifth term as president of FIFA, defying all common sense that the leader of a corrupt sport should be ousted instead of rewarded, he can move on to the next big event on his calendar: the Womens World Cup.

title: Marlins Gordon Tries to Match Notable Names: Cobb. Sisler. Snuffy Stirnweiss.
description: Howie Kendrick has delivered the type of production the Los Angeles Dodgers were hoping for when they traded for him in December. After going 1 for 4 on Friday night, Kendrick had a .291 batting average, which was in line with his .292 career average entering the season.

title: The Vision of Walter Byers, a Flawed Leader, Still Shapes the N.C.A.A.
description: Walter Byers died last week at the age of 93, but his legacy as the first executive director of the N.C.A.A. resonates in virtually every aspect of the multibillion-dollar enterprise of intercollegiate athletics.

title: Variety: A Trained Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Unlike the New York City subway system, this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon showed up on time, was incredibly clean and did not emit a strange odor, and was easy to solve. [You dont solve the New York City subway system.  Ed.] [You do if you miss your connection on the 1, 2 or 3 Line.  D.A.]

title: For Horse Trainer Dallas Stewart, Diamonds in the Rough Are a Specialty
description: The trainer Dallas Stewart admits that his willingness to enter horses who seemingly lack the background to be competitive in major races comes off as a little bit sketchy. His wife, Yvette, is more blunt in discussing her husbands makeup.

title: Nick Imison Is Tenniss Workaholic Diplomat
description: PARIS  The yellow brick road of interviews leads to Nick Imison.

title: At the French Open, Nick Kyrgios and Other Young Standouts Hit a Wall
description: PARIS  The three youngest men remaining in the French Open took the court for their third-round matches Saturday, and all three lost without taking a set.

title: New Jersey State Trooper Killed After Patrol Car Hits Deer
description: A New Jersey State Police trooper was killed early Saturday after his patrol car struck a deer and veered off a highway in Monmouth County, the authorities said.

title: Keeping Shoppers Happy
description: Juan Carlos Linares, 34, is general manager of Tanger Outlets in National Harbor, Md.

title: How the Cayman Islands Became a FIFA Power
description: GEORGE TOWN, Cayman Islands  Chickens scurried about on Friday morning as a bulldozer spread crushed rock for a new soccer field with artificial turf at the Cayman Islands Football Association.

title: Talks Begin to Conclude Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: GENEVA  With only a month to go before a deadline for a nuclear accord with Iran, Secretary of State John Kerry began a major push Saturday to conclude the agreement.

title: A Beehive That Takes the Sting Out of the Harvest
description: Cedar Anderson sometimes drizzles an entire jars worth of honey on his food. Some people call me Pooh Bear, he says.

title: Hundreds Protest After Gunmen Target Ethnic Pashtuns in Southern Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Tensions were running high on Saturday in southwestern Pakistan after dozens of heavily armed gunmen, wearing the uniforms of security forces, stopped two buses, singled out ethnic Pashtuns and fatally shot at least 22 of them on Friday night.

title: Martin OMalley Running for President
description: Former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland announced his campaign on Saturday.

title: Obama Seeks Support on Surveillance
description: President Obama addresses gridlock in the Senate over the renewal of a federal surveillance program.

title: At Odds Over a Sloppy Rsum
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Manhattanhenge: Scenes From the Streets
description: A collection of Instagram photographs taken by readers of the sun setting on Friday in alignment with Manhattans east-west street grid.

title: Creative Spending Benefits the Astros
description: Lance McCullers Jr. was new to the Fresno Grizzlies in mid-May, promoted to the Houston Astros highest minor league affiliate after 29 overpowering innings in Class AA. His plan all along was to pitch for Houston this season, but he figured he would have to prove himself at a new level before getting there.

title: For Mets, David Wrights Injury Could Bring Back Revolving Door at Third
description: For most of the last half-century, at least until David Wright arrived, one of the least exclusive clubs in baseball was third baseman for the Mets. The position seemed available to one and all  from Don Zimmer on Day 1 of the franchise, to Manny Alexander and almost every alphabetical permutation in between.

title: Sepp Blatter Blames U.S. and England for FIFA Arrests
description: The embattled Sepp Blatter struck a familiarly defiant tone as he began his fifth term as president of FIFA, blaming others for the widespread corruption scandal that has engulfed international soccer.

title: Wanted: A Theology of Atheism
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  ONE Sunday last month, I walked into an auditorium past greeters and a table loaded with coffee, fruit and cookies. Onstage two young men tuned their guitars. A blank screen hung down, a silent signal that not knowing the words would be no excuse for not singing along. But this was no typical church service.

title: Who Will Watch the Charities?
description: LAST week federal authorities disclosed that four cancer charities had bilked tens of millions of dollars from donors. Questions continue to surface about the lack of transparency at the Clinton Foundation. Philanthropy, were learning, is a world with too much secrecy and too little oversight. Despite its increasing role in American society, from education to the arts to the media, perhaps no sector is less accountable to outsiders.

title: What YouTube Taught Me
description: IVE been watching a lot of how-to videos on YouTube about baseball gloves, and heres what Ive learned. The will to teach  a close cousin of the desire to perform  far exceeds the educational value of most online tutorials. Of course, if youve ever sought advice about how to break in a new glove, you already know that.

title: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: My Fathers Kidnapping
description: MY father was kidnapped in Nigeria on a Saturday morning in early May. My brother called to tell me, and suddenly there was not enough breathable air in the world. My father is 83 years old. A small, calm, contented man, with a quietly mischievous humor and a luminous faith in God, his beautiful dark skin unlined, his hair in sparse silvery tufts, his life shaped by that stoic, dignified responsibility of being an Igbo first son.

title: Guess Who Doesnt Fit In at Work
description: ACROSS cultures and industries, managers strongly prize cultural fit  the idea that the best employees are like-minded. One recent survey found that more than 80 percent of employers worldwide named cultural fit as a top hiring priority.

title: The Education Assassins
description: A CONTEST for the least popular arm of the federal government would have many strong contenders.

title: Hooray for Hillarywood?
description: IS Hollywood really ready to give a 67-year-old woman a leading role in a big-budget production?

title: Overcoming a Lifetime of Stage Fright
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  IT had been 40 years since my last recital, but the first time I played the piano at Mineta San Jose International Airport, my body responded right on cue. My hands turned wet with sweat, my heart pounded, my feet gave a soft little drum roll on the floor.

title: The Pressure to Look Good
description: I LOVED that letter you wrote! the woman in the elevator of the Medical Arts Building on Walnut Street in Philadelphia said.

title: Cynthia Moss
description: Cynthia Moss is a wildlife researcher and conservationist who has spent more than 40 years living with and observing elephants in Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Tanzania and Botswana.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Dave Sweet, a Quiet Pioneer of Surfboarding, Dies at 86
description: Dave Sweet, whose obsessive tinkering 60 years ago in search of a better way to ride a wave resulted in a surfboard revolution  the first board with a core of polyurethane foam, still the leading choice of surfers from Oahu to the Maldives  died on May 18 in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: How a School Network Helps Immigrant Kids Learn
description: IN 1982, the Supreme Court ruled that the children of illegal immigrants cannot be denied a free public education. Its not their fault, after all, that their parents brought them into this country.

title: Directing the Final Scene
description: When they pulled out the pump that was keeping my fathers heart going, his hands shot up in the air, and he shouted Wonderful! My brother, Jeff, and I knew why. He had been waiting to die for a year, having tried to take his life with far too few pills to do the job. It left him, at 81, doomed to a life sentence with a failing heart that wouldnt let him be the fun-loving, bridge-playing, romantic crooner we had known. He was happy to be leaving us and we, in turn, were happy to see him go. Wed been mourning him for a year as he faltered and despaired.

title: Afghan Police Chief, Long a Taliban Target, Faces a New Emotion: Fear
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  He says he has lost count of the number of times the Taliban have tried to kill him.

title: Cashing In on a Charter-Time Warner Cable Merger
description: Whatever cable customers and regulators may think of Charter Communications plans to acquire Time Warner Cable for $56 billion, one small group of men has reason to celebrate.

title: Treating H.I.V. Patients Before They Get Sick
description: A major international clinical trial has provided the strongest evidence yet that people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, should get treated as soon as possible, even if they are feeling well, to ward off serious illness and fatal complications in future years. The finding raises the powerful moral question of whether global and national organizations can find the will  and the resources  to protect millions of people from deaths and diseases that could be prevented.

title: Racial Penalties in Baltimore Mortgages
description: The mortgage crisis that brought the economy to its knees seven years ago was especially devastating for black communities, where homeowners who qualified for safe, traditional mortgages were often steered into ruinously priced loans that paid off handsomely for brokers and lenders while leaving borrowers vulnerable to foreclosure. The crisis left many middle-class minority communities strewn with abandoned houses, further widening the already huge wealth gap between African-Americans and whites.

title: The Non-Candidate Money Spigot
description: Campaign watchdog groups are wisely urging the Department of Justice to investigate the ever cozier relationships between candidates and their supposedly independent super PACs, which are reducing the presidential campaign to a free-for-all shopping mart for megadonors seeking influence.

title: Presidential Races Under Microscope, and The Times, Too
description: SEVENTEEN months before the presidential election, The Times is already in a full-court press on campaign coverage: eleven reporters, hundreds of stories, one major scoop, and an intensive focus on presenting the news attractively for mobile devices.

title: 2015 Fantasy Football Preseason Player Rankings
description: These player rankings are for standard and PPR scoring formats and will be updated throughout the preseason.

title: In France, a Partys Name Change Tracks a Drift to the Right in Europe
description: PARIS  In one sense, it was just an effort at rebranding a party that has suffered electoral defeat, scandal and internal divisions in the past few years.
